# Chapter 1: Arrival

The plane touched down at KLIA2 with the kind of graceless thud that only budget airlines could deliver, a gut-punch of rubber on tarmac that rattled the overhead bins and jolted awake every backpacker who'd passed out during the three-hour haul from Denpasar. Connor Briggs didn't flinch. He'd flown AirAsia enough times to know that the landing was less an arrival and more a controlled argument with the ground. Besides, he was busy. His phone was angled at the window, filming the blur of tropical green and grey runway sliding past, the afternoon light thick and golden, the kind of light that Instagram was built for.

"KL, baby," he murmured, already composing the caption. *New country, new chapter. No plans. No limits. Just vibes.* He'd workshop the hashtags later. He had a system: location tag first, then the aspirational ones -- #digitalnomad, #livingmybestlife, #noplannoworries -- and finally the bait for the algorithm, #malaysia #kualalumpur #backpackerlife. He knew what he was doing. Four years on the road, twelve countries, forty-two hundred followers. Well, forty-one-eighty-something, but you round up. Everyone rounds up.

The seatbelt sign dinged off and the cabin erupted into the usual Pavlovian scramble of people reaching for bags they'd spent three hours pressed against. Connor stayed seated. He'd learned this move in Bangkok, years ago: let the amateurs clog the aisle while you sit back, relaxed, visibly unbothered. It was a small performance, but performance was the point. He stretched his arms above his head, letting the hem of his singlet ride up over the flat, sun-browned plane of his stomach, and yawned like a man who had nowhere to be. Because he didn't. That was the whole thing. That was the life.

The woman in the middle seat -- Chinese, maybe, or Malaysian, Connor wasn't great with distinctions -- squeezed past him with an apologetic nod. He flashed her his best grin, the one that crinkled the corners of his eyes and made him look like a guy in a toothpaste ad, if the toothpaste ad took place in a Bali surf shack.

"No worries," he said, even though she hadn't said anything.

He waited until the aisle was nearly clear, then stood, pulled his battered Osprey pack from the overhead bin with practiced ease, and joined the slow shuffle toward the exit. The air shifted as he neared the door -- the seal of the cabin breaking, the first breath of outside pushing in. It was warm. Not Bali-warm, which was a dry, volcanic warmth that sat on your skin like powder. This was different. This was *wet*. The humidity hit him in the jetway like walking into someone's open mouth, a living heat that was part water, part engine exhaust, part something botanical and unnameable. His skin went slick in the time it took to walk thirty meters.

*Welcome to Malaysia*, he thought. *This'll do.*

Connor had no plan for Kuala Lumpur. This was by design. Plans were for amateurs -- for the gap-year kids with their colour-coded itineraries and their Lonely Planet guides bristling with Post-it flags, for the couples who booked everything three months in advance and then spent the whole trip anxious that reality wouldn't match the TripAdvisor photos. Connor didn't do that. Connor *flowed*. He arrived somewhere, found the cheapest hostel with decent reviews, and let the city tell him what to do. This approach had served him well across twelve countries and four years of what he called, with no irony whatsoever, *living deliberately*. It had also, on three separate occasions, left him sleeping in a bus station, but those were stories now. Content. The bus station in Vientiane was one of his most-liked posts.

The terminal at KLIA2 was a cathedral of budget travel -- high ceilings, wide corridors, the antiseptic gleam of a building designed to move millions of people who'd each paid forty dollars for the privilege. Connor moved through it with the loose-hipped confidence of a man who'd done this many times, which he had. He knew airports the way some people knew their local supermarket: the rhythms, the shortcuts, the unspoken rules. Find the signs for immigration. Join the shortest queue. Passport out, landing card ready, pen behind the ear. Smile at the officer. Don't joke. They never think you're funny.

He was filling out his landing card when the pen ran out, the cheap blue ink fading to nothing halfway through *Purpose of Visit*. He'd written *TOUR* in careful block capitals. He looked around for another pen, patting his shorts pockets with one hand. A Malay family in the queue behind him -- mother, father, two kids in school uniforms -- noticed his predicament. The father offered his pen without a word. Connor took it with a grin.

"Legend. Cheers, mate."

The father smiled politely. The mother pulled her children slightly closer. Connor didn't notice.

He breezed through immigration. The officer, a woman in a hijab with an expression of practised neutrality, stamped his passport without looking up. Ninety-day visa on arrival. The stamp was a little crooked. Connor photographed it for his stories, the navy blue of the Australian passport played artfully against his tanned hand and the faded compass tattoo on his inner forearm. He'd gotten the tattoo in Ubud -- a compass with no cardinal points, because, as he'd explained to approximately two hundred people, "I don't need directions, I just need momentum." It had cost him the equivalent of twelve dollars and three Bintang beers, and it was, he believed, the single most authentic thing about him.

He was still looking at his phone when he walked through the arrivals hall.

The sign was impossible to miss, which is why it was remarkable that Connor missed it. It hung above the corridor at eye level, backlit, in English and Bahasa Melayu, in letters the size of a man's hand. White text on red. The universal colour of warning, of stop, of *pay attention*:

**WARNING**
**DEATH FOR DRUG TRAFFICKERS UNDER MALAYSIAN LAW**

Beneath it, in smaller text: *The Dangerous Drugs Act 1952 prescribes the MANDATORY DEATH PENALTY for trafficking in dangerous drugs. This includes possession above threshold amounts of heroin (15g), methamphetamine (50g), cannabis (200g), and other controlled substances.*

There was a graphic, too -- a stylised noose, rendered in the kind of stark, government-issue design that left nothing to interpretation. The sign was in four languages. It was flanked by Malaysian flags. It was, by any reasonable measure, the least subtle thing in an airport full of duty-free perfume advertisements and currency exchange signs.

Connor walked past it. His eyes were on his phone, his thumb scrolling through the notifications that had loaded now that he was connected to the terminal Wi-Fi. Seven Instagram likes. A comment from his mother: *Beautiful sunset! Stay safe darling xx*. A DM from a girl he'd met in Canggu asking if he was still in Bali. A WhatsApp message from Jake -- some American he'd been chatting with on a hostel forum -- saying *bro im at a sick hostel in KL petaling street area come thru*.

He thumbed a reply to Jake: *just landed bruh. On my way. Where u at?*

He did not look up. The sign hung above him for three full seconds, close enough that he could have reached up and touched the perspex casing, close enough that the red glow of the backlight fell briefly across the screen of his phone, colouring his mother's message the shade of arterial blood.

Then he was past it, and the sign was behind him, and it did not follow.

---

The KLIA Ekspres was the best thirty-five ringgit Connor didn't want to spend. He knew there were cheaper options -- a bus, probably, or one of those shared vans he'd seen in other Asian airports -- but his phone was at twelve percent and he needed to get to the city while he still had GPS. He didn't carry a power bank. He'd owned one, briefly, in Vietnam, but it had been heavy and he'd left it at a guesthouse in Hoi An and never replaced it. His position on power banks, which he'd articulated to several people who hadn't asked, was that they were a crutch. "If your phone dies, you just talk to people. That's how you *actually* travel."

This philosophy had a few cracks in practice, such as the time his phone died in rural Cambodia and he'd walked for two hours in the wrong direction on a road with no signage, but that was also a story now. Content.

The train was fast, clean, and air-conditioned to the point of violence. After the swamp-heat of the terminal, the carriage hit Connor like a refrigerator. He dropped into a window seat, pressed his forehead against the glass, and watched Malaysia unscroll.

The view from the Ekspres was a time-lapse of a country assembling itself. First: palm oil plantations, the trees in military rows, their fronds like green explosions frozen in mid-detonation. Then: industrial sprawl, warehouses with corrugated roofs, the skeletons of construction projects rising from red earth. Then, gradually, then all at once: the city. Kuala Lumpur emerged from the haze like a hallucination -- towers of glass and steel erupting from a canopy of tropical green, the skyline a jagged fever chart of ambition. And there, dead centre, unmistakable, ridiculous, magnificent: the Petronas Twin Towers, their tapered silver forms catching the late afternoon light and throwing it back in sheets of white fire.

Connor pressed record. His phone was at nine percent.

"Fully sick," he said to no one, panning across the skyline. The Petronas Towers filled the frame, then a golden mosque dome slid into view, then a cluster of palm trees, then a highway overpass, then a billboard for Milo in Bahasa Melayu. He held the shot until the towers disappeared behind a wall of apartment blocks, and then he stopped recording and checked the battery. Seven percent.

*She'll be right*, he thought. *Just need to get to the hostel and plug in.*

KL Sentral was a hive. Connor emerged from the Ekspres platform into a multi-level transit hub that thrummed -- escalators flowing in both directions, digital boards flickering with Malay text, the hum of a million commuters compressed into architecture, the smell of fried chicken from a KFC that seemed to exist in a pocket dimension between the LRT platforms. People moved with purpose. Connor moved with the carefully calibrated purposelessness of a man who wanted you to know he was in no rush.

He found the LRT almost by instinct. Years of navigating foreign transit systems had given him a sixth sense for the architecture of trains -- follow the signs, follow the flow of people with bags, and if all else fails, look lost near a security guard until they point you in the right direction. The LRT to Pasar Seni was two stops. He stood in the carriage, one hand on the overhead rail, his Osprey between his feet, and watched the city slide past the windows at a different speed now, closer, the buildings no longer a skyline but a street-level blur of signage and movement and life.

Pasar Seni station spat him out onto a covered walkway that led, in short order, to the edge of Petaling Street. And there, the city stopped being a postcard and became a body.

The heat was the first thing. Not the gentle warmth of the air-conditioned train or the filtered chill of the airport, but the full, unmediated assault of equatorial afternoon -- thirty-two degrees and eighty-something percent humidity, the air so thick with moisture that breathing felt like drinking. Connor's singlet adhered to his chest in the time it took to walk twenty steps. Sweat tracked down the channel of his spine. His flip-flops -- Havaianas, the only footwear he'd owned for two years -- slapped against wet pavement.

The second thing was the noise. Not noise, exactly -- noise suggested chaos. This was more like an orchestra tuning up, every instrument playing a different song. Cantonese shouted from a market stall to his left, a vendor holding up a fake Louis Vuitton bag and quoting a price in three currencies. Mandarin from somewhere behind him, rapid-fire, the tonal shifts like music. The sizzle and clatter of a wok from a hawker cart to his right, where a man in a stained apron was tossing flat noodles in a blackened pan, flames licking up around the edges. The roar of a motorbike splitting the pedestrian traffic. The tinny echo of Cantopop from a speaker balanced on a stack of shoeboxes. The distant, almost subliminal rumble of thunder, somewhere over the hills to the east, promising the afternoon storm that came every day like clockwork.

And the smell. Connor had been to markets in Bali and Bangkok and Ho Chi Minh City, and he'd thought he understood what a Southeast Asian street market smelled like. He was wrong, or at least incomplete. Petaling Street had its own olfactory signature, layered and complex: the char-sweet smoke of char kway teow frying, the waxy tang of incense drifting from a temple doorway, the diesel bite of a passing lorry, the vegetal funk of morning glory piled on a cart, and beneath it all, rising from the storm drains in the heat, a sulfurous note that wasn't exactly unpleasant but wasn't exactly pleasant either, the smell of a tropical city sweating through its infrastructure.

Connor raised his phone. Four percent. He filmed anyway. A slow pan across the market -- the canopy of blue and red tarpaulins stretched over the stalls, the riotous colour of fake designer goods hanging from every surface, the signs in Chinese and Malay and English all shouting at once, the faces of the crowd -- local and tourist, young and old, all moving through the narrow corridor of the market with the particular shuffle of people who are simultaneously going somewhere and going nowhere.

He narrated as he walked, his voice low and conspiratorial, the voice he used for his stories: "Day one in KL. No plan. No agenda. Just dropped into Chinatown and, like -- look at this. Look at this place. You can't plan this. You just have to let it happen." He turned the camera on himself, grinning, the market a kaleidoscopic blur behind him. "This is what travel is, guys. This right here. Hashtag no filter, hashtag no plan."

His phone died mid-selfie, the screen going black with the abruptness of a power cut. Connor stared at it for a moment, then laughed.

"Classic."

He needed directions. He had the hostel name -- The Lantern -- and a vague sense that it was somewhere on or near Petaling Street, which was where he was, which meant it couldn't be far. The backpacker logic was sound: hostels in Chinatown clustered together like barnacles on a hull. He just needed a vector.

He approached the nearest vendor, a middle-aged Chinese man surrounded by a fortress of phone cases and charger cables. The man was reading a newspaper folded into quarters, his reading glasses perched on the end of his nose.

"Hey, mate," Connor said. He did the thing he always did in countries where English wasn't the first language: he spoke louder and slower, as if volume and tempo were the same as translation. "Do. You. Know. The Lantern. Hostel? The. Lantern?"

The man looked up from his paper. He regarded Connor with an expression that contained, in its various layers, patience, amusement, and something that might have been pity.

"The Lantern?" the man said, in English that was not only perfect but faintly accented with the clipped precision of someone who'd studied in an English-medium school. "Yes. Go to the end of this row, turn left at the temple, walk fifty meters. It's between the phone repair shop and the Chinese medicine store. You'll see the red lanterns."

Connor blinked. "Oh. Cheers. Legend."

"You're welcome," the man said, and returned to his newspaper.

Connor walked. The vendor's directions were exact. At the end of the market row, a Chinese temple appeared on the corner -- red and gold, dragons on the roof, the sweet fog of joss sticks rolling from the open door. Connor turned left. The street narrowed. The market stalls thinned and gave way to shophouses -- old, beautiful, slightly decrepit, their facades decorated with plaster mouldings that might have been ornate once but were now softened by decades of humidity and neglect. The colours were pastels gone dark: mint green, faded coral, a yellow that had surrendered to ochre.

Fifty meters. And there it was.

---

The Lantern Hostel announced itself in the way that the best hostels always did -- not with a sign (though there was a sign, small and hand-painted, hanging from a bracket above the door) but with a feeling. A narrow entrance, squeezed between a phone repair shop on the left and a traditional Chinese medicine store on the right. The phone repair shop had a cluttered window display of cracked screens and coiled cables and a fluorescent light that buzzed with the resigned hum of a machine that had been on too long. The medicine store's window was darker, lined with jars of dried things -- roots, bark, something that might have been seahorses -- and a faded poster of an anatomical diagram with meridian lines drawn in red. Between these two businesses, a door. Not even a wide door -- Connor had to turn slightly sideways with his pack on. But above the door, and in the narrow hallway beyond it, and strung along the ceiling like a procession of small, soft fires: red paper lanterns.

They were beautiful. Connor would grant the place that before he'd even seen the reception desk. The lanterns hung at irregular intervals, their glow warm and amber, turning the narrow corridor into something that felt less like a hallway and more like a throat, leading down into the belly of an old building that had been breathing for nearly a century. The floor was tile -- patterned, cracked, original -- and the walls were close enough to touch on both sides. The air was different in here: cooler, tinged with the smell of damp wood and something herbal and sharp that Connor couldn't identify but which was, in fact, Tiger Balm.

He emerged from the corridor into a small reception area. A wooden counter, scarred and ancient, with a brass bell on it and a rack of pamphlets behind it -- tour operators, restaurant recommendations, a laminated sheet of LRT maps. A bookshelf against one wall, stuffed with the paperback detritus of a thousand travelers: dog-eared thrillers, Lonely Planet guides three editions out of date, a German-English dictionary, a copy of *Shantaram* so swollen with humidity it looked like it was trying to become a different book. A ceiling fan turned overhead with the languid dedication of something that had been turning for decades and would continue turning long after everyone in the room was dead.

Behind the counter, a young woman was looking at him with an expression that suggested she'd seen his exact type walk through this door approximately once a week for two years and had long since stopped being charmed.

"Hi," Connor said, deploying the grin. "I'm after a bed? Dorm, cheapest you've got."

Mei Ling Chen was twenty-four, Malaysian-Chinese, and constructed almost entirely of sharp angles -- cheekbones, elbows, the precise line of her ponytail, the geometric efficiency of her movements behind the counter. She wore a polo shirt with a small red lantern embroidered on the breast pocket, and she moved with the practiced economy of someone who had checked in enough backpackers to have reduced the entire process to its essential elements: look, assess, process, assign, forget.

"Passport," she said.

Connor handed it over. She opened it, glanced at the photo -- younger, cleaner, the ghost of a haircut -- and then at him, and then back at the photo, performing the comparison with the clinical detachment of a customs officer.

"Australian," she said. It wasn't a question.

"Melbourne." Connor leaned on the counter. "You been?"

"No." She placed the passport face-down on a small photocopier behind the counter, pressed a button, and returned it to him in a single fluid motion. "How many nights?"

"Two, to start. Maybe more. See how the vibes are."

"RM seventy for two nights. Cash preferred."

Connor peeled three fifty-ringgit notes from the thin fold of Malaysian currency he'd exchanged at the airport, and Mei Ling made change with the same economical precision. She placed a key on the counter -- not a key card, an actual key, brass, attached to a wooden fob with the number 3 burned into it.

"Dorm 3, second floor. Bed 7." She slid a laminated sheet across the counter. "House rules."

Connor glanced at the sheet the way he glanced at safety cards on airplanes: with the performative attention of someone who had already decided not to read it.

The rules were printed in four languages -- English, Malay, Mandarin, Japanese -- in a font size that suggested someone had tried to fit a lot of information into a small space. He caught fragments: *Quiet after 11 PM... No drugs on premises... Check-out by 11 AM...* Standard hostel fare. His eyes skated over the text with practised speed, catching nothing, retaining less.

At the bottom of the sheet, in a different colour -- red, the colour of the lanterns, the colour of the sign at the airport, the colour of all the things Connor did not read -- a final line:

*Guests are responsible for knowing and obeying Malaysian law. The hostel is not liable for the consequences of guests' actions.*

Connor picked up the pen on the counter and signed the guest book -- an actual ledger, paper, the pages thick with the accumulated signatures of hundreds of travelers. He signed with the loose, confident scrawl of someone who had signed many guest books in many countries and had never once read what he was signing. His name joined the column of others: a Japanese name, an unreadable European signature, the careful block letters of someone named PRIYA S.

"WiFi password?" he asked.

"On the whiteboard behind you. Changes every Monday."

"Legend."

Mei Ling watched him turn to look at the whiteboard, and in the brief moment when his back was turned, something crossed her face -- not quite concern, not quite recognition. More like the expression of a person who has watched the same movie enough times to know exactly when the jump scare is coming and has stopped flinching but hasn't stopped noticing.

"Enjoy your stay," she said, when he turned back. Her voice was neutral. Her eyes were not.

---

The staircase to the second floor was a relic. Narrow enough that Connor's shoulders nearly brushed both walls, the steps worn into shallow bowls by decades of feet, the wooden bannisters dark with the oil of a thousand hands. Travel stickers from hostels around the world covered the walls -- peeling, overlapping, a geological record of backpacker culture going back years. *Viraporn's Place, Chiang Mai. The Mad Monkey, Phnom Penh. Loki Hostel, La Paz.* Connor recognized some of them. He'd stayed at the Mad Monkey. That was the place with the pool and the happy hour that started at noon. He'd been twenty-three then. A lifetime ago. Three lifetimes.

Dorm 3 was at the end of a corridor lit by two more red lanterns and a single bare bulb. Connor pushed open the door -- no lock, just a handle -- and stepped inside.

Eight beds, arranged in four bunks of two, the frames made of dark wood that might have been beautiful once and was now merely solid. The room was deep and narrow, the architecture of the original shophouse asserting itself -- the building had been designed to be long rather than wide, and the dorm followed suit, stretching back into shadow. There were no windows on the side walls. The only natural light came from the far end, where an opening in the wall looked out onto the air well -- the central shaft of the building, open to the sky, a rectangle of grey afternoon light and the sound of rain beginning to fall somewhere above. The air well carried the smell of wet concrete and the faint, drifting sound of someone playing music on a phone two floors up.

Bed 7 was a bottom bunk, second from the back, against the right wall. Connor tossed his Osprey onto the thin mattress -- the universal hostel mattress, a slab of foam sheathed in vinyl that squeaked when you moved and smelled of disinfectant and the accumulated dreams of strangers. He sat on the edge and bounced, once.

"Not bad," he said, to the empty room.

He unpacked. This was a ritual, and like all of Connor's rituals, it was quick and devoid of ceremony. Four years of backpacking had reduced his possessions to the essentials, or what he considered essentials: three pairs of board shorts (two identical, one with a bleach stain that he'd decided was "character"), four singlets of varying degrees of fading, underwear that he would not submit to close inspection, his Havaianas and a single pair of running shoes he hadn't run in for seven months, a phone charger with a fraying cable, a half-empty bottle of sunscreen, and his toiletries bag -- a Ziploc that contained a toothbrush, toothpaste, a razor he hadn't used in a week, and a stick of deodorant that was optimistic at best.

And the towel.

He pulled it from the bottom of his pack with something approaching reverence. His blue Sea to Summit microfiber travel towel. It was, and Connor would tell you this without prompting, the single best purchase he had ever made. Four years old. Been to every country he'd been to. Dried him on beaches in Bali, in rivers in Laos, in showers in thirty different hostels across Southeast Asia. It was compact -- rolled down to the size of a beer can -- and it was absurdly absorbent, and it dried in an hour, and it was the exact shade of blue as the ocean at Nusa Penida on a clear day. He'd photographed it in twelve countries. It had its own hashtag: #towelofadventure. Eleven posts. Forty-seven total likes.

He draped the towel over the end of the bunk frame, where it hung like a small blue flag.

The last item from his pack was a book: a battered, water-damaged copy of *The Beach* by Alex Garland. He'd bought it at a secondhand bookshop in Bangkok three years ago because it seemed like the kind of book a traveler should have, and he'd been carrying it ever since, reading it in sporadic bursts that never lasted more than ten pages before his phone offered something more immediately stimulating. He was on page eighty-six. He'd been on page eighty-six for four months. He set it on the narrow shelf above his pillow, next to a pair of earplugs left by a previous guest.

Connor lay back on the bunk and stared at the slats above him. The wood was old, scarred, and covered in the graffiti of travelers past -- initials, dates, tiny drawings, the usual declarations of love and obscenity that people leave in places they'll never return to. Someone had drawn a surprisingly detailed penis. Someone else had written *BERLIN FOREVER* in Sharpie. Another hand had carved, with a key or a knife, the words *IF YOU'RE READING THIS, GO HOME*.

Connor smiled. He wouldn't be reading any of it. He was already reaching for his phone before he remembered it was dead. He plugged it in -- the socket was behind the bed frame, requiring a contortion that pressed his face against the mattress of the bunk above -- and lay back.

His right hand rested on the bed frame. His fingers, idly tracing the wood grain, passed over something that wasn't grain. Letters, carved shallow into the dark wood, small and careful, as if the person carving them had been trying to be quiet:

**LENA**

Connor's fingers moved across the name without recognition, without pause, the way a hand moves across a surface in the dark -- registering texture but not meaning. He was already thinking about the WiFi password, about the Instagram post he'd make when his phone came back to life, about whether the hostel had a rooftop. His fingers left Lena's name and found his own knee, which he scratched absently.

If he had looked, he would have seen the name. If he had asked, someone might have told him about the Swedish girl who'd slept in this bed a year ago, who'd been friendly and blonde and trusting, who'd also met a charming European man in the common room, who was now in Kajang Prison, four hundred and seven days into an indefinite wait for a trial that would almost certainly end with a judge pronouncing the words *gantung sampai mati* -- hanged until dead.

But Connor did not look, and did not ask, and instead lay in the dark of Dorm 3 and listened to the rain falling into the air well and thought about absolutely nothing, which was his preferred state and his greatest vulnerability.

---

The common room at dusk was a living thing.

Connor came downstairs at half six, his phone resurrected to nineteen percent, his hair freshly wet from a shower that had oscillated between lukewarm and ambitious-but-cold, wearing clean board shorts and a singlet that read *BINTANG BEER* across the chest in the font of the famous Bali brewery. He'd considered the singlet that said *I SURVIVED THE FULL MOON PARTY* but decided it was trying too hard. The Bintang shirt struck the right balance: casual, travelled, alcoholic without being aggressive about it.

The common room occupied the ground floor's front section, between the reception desk and the kitchen. It was a space that had been furnished, over the years, through what appeared to be a combination of donations, salvage operations, and the gradual accumulation of things that nobody had thrown away. A sofa in brown corduroy, sagging in the middle like a horse that had given up. Two armchairs of different eras and upholstery. A low table covered in ring stains and a half-completed jigsaw puzzle that depicted the Petronas Towers and was missing, Connor would later count, at least thirty pieces. A bookshelf. A wall-mounted TV playing CNN with the volume low, a correspondent standing in front of something on fire somewhere. The ceiling fan. Always the ceiling fan, turning with its slow, eternal patience.

A few travelers were scattered through the room in the poses of early evening -- that liminal hour between the day's exertions and the night's decisions, when backpackers are at their most contemplative, their most sociable, their most vulnerable to suggestion.

A couple on the sofa, European, speaking French, sharing a bag of crisps. A guy with a guitar -- the three-stringed one that lived on the bookshelf -- plucking something that was either very avant-garde or very bad. A woman at the communal computer, an ancient Dell that hummed like a beehive, scrolling with the frustrated intensity of someone trying to load a webpage on a connection that had given up trying.

Through the air well, visible through the arched opening at the back of the room, the last of the daylight was draining from the sky. The rain had stopped, but the air well was still dripping, the sound of water on tile a slow, irregular percussion. Beyond the hostel's walls, the city was performing its evening transformation: the call to prayer from Masjid Jamek, distant but clear, a human voice rising above the traffic noise with the practiced beauty of a ritual performed five times a day; the growl of motorbikes; the first stirrings of the night market; a vendor somewhere calling out prices in a singsong Cantonese that carried over the rooftops and through the air well and into the common room like a voice from another world.

Connor breathed it in. The familiar alchemy was working. The chemical hit of a new place -- novelty cut with comfort, the hostel trick, the sense that you were somewhere foreign but also somewhere safe, that the world was enormous and strange and you had found a small pocket of it that was, for tonight at least, yours. His shoulders dropped. His jaw unclenched. The low-grade anxiety that he carried always -- about money, about the future, about the creeping suspicion that his life was a performance for an audience that didn't exist -- softened to a background hum.

*This is the life*, he thought. Not ironically. Not for content. Just the genuine, uncomplicated thought of a young man in a foreign city at the beginning of something, who did not know yet that the something had a shape, and the shape was a trap, and the trap had been baited long before he landed.

He walked to the small cooler behind the reception desk -- Mei Ling was gone, replaced by a laminated sign that read *BEER RM8, PAY TOMORROW, WE KNOW WHERE YOU SLEEP* -- and pulled out a can of Tiger. The beer was cold and good. He popped it and took a long pull and stood there for a moment, surveying the common room with the proprietary satisfaction of a man who has just claimed his territory.

That was when someone said his name.

Not his name, exactly. His nationality, which for a certain type of Australian male abroad amounts to the same thing.

"Hey, Australia."

Connor turned. The voice had come from the far corner of the common room, past the jigsaw table and the guitar player, near the arched doorway that led to the air well. A man was sitting there in one of the mismatched armchairs, one leg crossed over the other, a posture of studied ease. He was tall -- Connor could tell even though the man was seated -- and lean, with close-cropped dark hair and an angular face that looked like it had been designed to sell something expensive. He wore a linen shirt, white, improbably clean for a backpacker hostel, the sleeves rolled to the elbows with a precision that suggested the roll itself had been considered. Leather sandals. No visible tattoos. A thin scar through his left eyebrow, a small imperfection that somehow made the rest of his face more symmetrical.

He was holding two beers. He was smiling. The smile was the kind that created an immediate, instinctive binary in the people who received it: either you trusted this man completely, or you didn't trust him at all. There was no middle register.

Connor, who had never met a stranger he didn't provisionally adore, felt the warmth of the smile before he'd consciously registered the face.

"You look like you could use one of these," the man said, lifting one of the beers. His English was accented -- German, maybe, or Dutch -- and precise, each word placed like a tile in a mosaic.

Connor grinned. The grin was automatic, the same grin he'd flashed at the woman on the plane, at the immigration officer, at the pen-lending father, at Mei Ling. The grin of a man who believed, in his bones, that the world was a friendly place full of friendly people who existed, on some level, to make his journey more interesting.

"Legend," Connor said.

He walked over.

The man extended the beer and, when Connor took it, offered his other hand. The handshake was firm, dry, and lasted exactly the right amount of time.

"Felix," the man said. "Felix Decker. Welcome to The Lantern."

"Connor. Just got in from Bali."

"I know," Felix said, and his smile widened by a fraction. "I can always tell. The tan, the boardshorts, the flip-flops. Bali is a uniform."

Connor laughed. It was a good line. He dropped into the empty chair opposite Felix and cracked the beer. Tiger again. He'd drink anything, but Tiger felt right. Tiger felt like Malaysia.

"How long you been here?" Connor asked.

"At The Lantern? A few weeks. In KL? On and off for a year." Felix sipped his beer. "I travel for work. Photography. KL is a good base."

"Photographer. Sick. I'm sort of in the same space -- social media, content creation, digital nomad stuff." Connor heard himself say these words and felt the usual small thrill of presenting the fiction as fact. It wasn't exactly a lie. He did post things on social media. He had, once, been paid forty dollars to write an Instagram caption for a surf school in Canggu. These facts, arranged correctly, constituted a career.

Felix nodded, and in his nod was something that Connor didn't detect -- a flicker of assessment, the brief, clinical appraisal of a professional evaluating raw material. It was there and gone in less than a second.

"A content creator," Felix said. "I like that. So what's your plan for KL?"

"No plan," Connor said, and he said it the way he always said it -- as a declaration of philosophy, as a badge of identity, as the thing that separated him from the ordinary people back home who planned their lives into submission. "Plans are for amateurs. I just go where the city takes me."

"I like that even more," Felix said. He leaned back in his chair, crossed his ankles, and looked at Connor with an expression of what appeared to be genuine interest. "A man with no plan. KL is a good city for men with no plans. There's always something happening here. You just have to know where to look."

The ceiling fan turned above them. CNN murmured about a crisis in a country Connor couldn't locate on a map. The guitar player had given up and was now examining the instrument with the confused respect of someone who had just been defeated by an inanimate object. Through the air well, the night sounds of Petaling Street were building -- the clink of dishes, the hiss of rain on hot metal, the laughter of people who knew this city and lived in it and belonged to it.

Felix raised his beer. "To no plans," he said.

Connor raised his. "To no plans."

They drank. The beer was cold. The night was warm. The lanterns glowed red above them, and somewhere on the second floor, in an empty dorm, a blue towel hung from a bed frame like a flag of surrender, and a dead girl's name waited in the wood for someone who would never read it.

Connor Briggs was twenty-seven years old, and he had just arrived in the city where he would die, and the city didn't care, and neither did he, and the beers were eight ringgit each, and the night was young, and everything, everything, was going to be fine.
# Chapter 2: The German

The beer was cold and it was free and that was enough for Connor Briggs.

He took the bottle without hesitation -- a Tiger, sweating in the heat, its label already peeling -- and dropped himself into the nearest chair in the common room of The Lantern Hostel like a man arriving at a party that had been waiting for him. The European who'd handed it to him was still standing, one arm resting on the back of an adjacent chair, watching Connor with an expression of mild, unreadable amusement.

"Cheers, mate," Connor said, and took a long pull. The beer was crisp and bitter and exactly what he needed after a day of cheap flights and cheaper trains and hauling his pack through the wet furnace of Kuala Lumpur's streets. He let the cold settle in his chest and looked around the common room.

It was a good room. The red paper lanterns -- dozens of them, strung across the ceiling on wires that sagged in the humidity -- threw a warm amber light over everything, softening the mismatched furniture, the battered bookshelf stuffed with abandoned novels in six languages, the TV mounted on the wall playing CNN with the sound off. Two ceiling fans rotated overhead in that slow, thoughtful way that ceiling fans have in the tropics, as if they'd long ago accepted that the heat would win and were just going through the motions. The tile floor was cool underfoot, the old encaustic pattern cracked and uneven, and the air smelled of cooking oil and Tiger Balm and the faintly sweet rot of old wood in a wet climate. Through the central air well -- that strange open shaft in the building's core -- Connor could hear motorbikes on Petaling Street, the thump of bass from the clubs on Changkat, a cat screaming at something in the alley. The sounds came down the air well amplified and distorted, as if the building were cupping its hand around its ear.

*This is the vibe,* Connor thought. *This is what travel looks like.*

"You just arrived today?" the European said.

Connor looked at him properly for the first time. The man was tall and lean, maybe early thirties, with the kind of angular face that belonged on the cover of a men's travel magazine -- sharp jaw, close-cropped dark hair, cheekbones you could slice cheese on. He was dressed in a clean linen shirt, untucked, with well-fitted shorts and leather sandals that looked like they cost more than Connor's entire backpack. There was a thin scar through his left eyebrow, a pale line that caught the lantern light when he tilted his head. He didn't look like a backpacker. He looked like someone who'd been cast to play a backpacker in a European art film.

"Yeah, flew in from Bali this arvo," Connor said. "AirAsia. Absolute cattle class, but you can't beat fifty bucks."

"From Bali," the man repeated, and smiled. It was a good smile -- warm, unhurried, like he had nowhere to be and nothing to do except hear about Connor's day. "How was it?"

"Bali? Yeah, it was sick. Did Seminyak for a bit, then Canggu. Got the tattoo topped up." Connor pulled up his left sleeve to show the compass on his inner forearm, the lines faded to blue-grey from sun and salt water. "The surf was going off. You been?"

"Twice," the man said. He sat down across from Connor, crossing one leg over the other with the ease of someone who was always comfortable. "But I preferred Siargao. In the Philippines. The surf is better and the tourists haven't found it yet." He paused. "Well. They're finding it now."

"Siargao," Connor said, filing it away. He didn't know where it was, exactly, but he'd look it up later. Or not. The name was enough -- he could drop it in conversation, on Instagram, the way you collected stamps. *Been meaning to hit Siargao. Mate of mine says the surf is unreal.* "Mate, I haven't even asked -- what's your name?"

"Felix," the man said. "Felix Decker."

He extended his hand and Connor shook it. The grip was firm, dry, precise -- the handshake of a man who'd practiced it.

"Connor. Connor Briggs. From Melbourne."

"Melbourne," Felix said, as if this was interesting. "A great city. I spent a month there in 2019. Fitzroy. The coffee is exceptional."

"Fitzroy! Legend. That's basically my neighbourhood. Well, Hawthorn, but close enough." It wasn't close enough, geographically or culturally, but Connor had learned to blur the distinction. "Where are you from?"

"Hamburg. Germany."

"No way. I love Germans. Every hostel I've been in, you guys are there. Efficient, you know? Always got the best gear." Connor grinned and gestured at Felix's outfit. "Case in point."

Felix laughed -- a short, clean sound, like the closing of a well-made door. "We do take our packing seriously." He tilted his Tiger towards Connor. "Welcome to The Lantern. It's a good place."

"Yeah? How long have you been here?"

"Two months."

Connor's bottle paused halfway to his mouth. "Two months? In a hostel? In KL?"

"KL has layers," Felix said. He held Connor's gaze for a beat longer than was strictly normal. "Most travelers pass through in three days. See the Towers, eat at Jalan Alor, take a selfie at Batu Caves, move on. They never get past the surface."

"And you're past the surface?"

"I'm a photographer," Felix said. "I need time. I need to understand a place before I can photograph it properly." He shrugged one shoulder, an elegant continental gesture. "So I stay. I watch. I learn."

*A photographer,* Connor thought. That explained the polish, the confidence, the sense that Felix was always composing a frame. Connor understood people in creative fields. He was, after all, basically in a creative field himself. Social media consulting was a creative pursuit. It was. He'd told people that enough times that it was true.

"That's sick," Connor said. "What kind of photography?"

"Documentary, mostly. Remote villages. Markets. The human infrastructure of places tourists don't see." Felix took a measured sip of his beer. "I spent three months in Myanmar last year, in the hills north of Mandalay. Villages that don't appear on any map. The people there have never seen a smartphone." He smiled at a private memory. "It was extraordinary."

"Mate. That sounds unreal."

"It was. I have a photo of a Shan woman, ninety years old, her face tattooed in the traditional way, and she's laughing at something her granddaughter said. It's the best photo I've ever taken." Felix shook his head. "Probably the best photo I'll ever take."

Connor believed every word of it. The story had texture, specifics, the Shan woman's tattooed face and the granddaughter's joke and the hills north of Mandalay. It sounded true because it sounded lived. What Connor couldn't hear -- what he had no ear for -- was the polish. The way the story's beats landed with the precision of a comedian's set, each detail chosen for maximum effect, the pause before the final line calibrated to make it feel spontaneous. Felix told stories the way a watchmaker assembled movements: every gear in place, every spring under tension, and the whole mechanism invisible behind the face.

"So what do you do, Connor?" Felix asked. He leaned forward slightly, elbows on knees. The posture said: *I'm genuinely interested.*

This was the part Connor liked. He had the spiel down cold.

"I'm a digital nomad," he said. "Location independent. Social media consulting, mostly -- I help brands with their online presence, content strategy, that kind of thing. The beauty of it is I can work from anywhere, right? All I need is a laptop and wifi." He took a swig of Tiger. "I've been doing it for four years now. Since I dropped out of uni. Best decision I ever made."

"Impressive," Felix said. "And your clients are--?"

"Global," Connor said, which was technically true if you counted a yoga studio in Northcote, Melbourne, that paid him one hundred and fifty dollars a month to run their Instagram. "I've got a few regulars and then I pick up freelance stuff as I go. It's not about the money, though, you know? It's about the freedom. The experiences."

Felix nodded slowly, as if he were absorbing something profound. "I understand that. The freedom. It's why I do what I do, too." He held up his bottle. "To freedom, then."

They clinked bottles. The sound was small and bright in the warm room.

"Speaking of," Felix said, "are you hungry? The cook here -- Mama Siti -- she makes the best nasi lemak in Chinatown. Five ringgit. An absolute steal."

"I could eat."

"I'll get us two plates." Felix stood, and Connor watched him walk to the kitchen counter with the loose, unhurried stride of a man who owned the space he moved through. He spoke to the ancient woman behind the counter in what sounded like Malay -- fluid, easy, nothing like a tourist reading from a phrasebook. The old woman, small and hunched and wrapped in a headscarf that made her look like a cloth doll, peered up at Felix with dark eyes that seemed to be measuring something behind his face. She ladled rice and sambal and anchovies onto two plates without smiling.

*He speaks Malay,* Connor thought. *Two months here and he speaks the language. That's commitment.* It didn't occur to Connor to wonder why a German travel photographer would invest that heavily in a place he was only passing through. It didn't occur to him to wonder about any of it. Felix was interesting, generous, and cool, and Connor liked interesting, generous, cool people. That was the beginning and end of his assessment.

Felix returned with two plates of nasi lemak, the coconut rice fragrant and steaming, flanked by crispy anchovies, roasted peanuts, half a boiled egg, a cucumber slice, and a devastating red sambal that smelled of chillies and dried shrimp and something darker beneath. He set one plate in front of Connor and sat back down.

"Enjoy."

Connor ate. It was incredible -- the coconut rice rich and nutty, the sambal nuclear, the anchovies shattering between his teeth. The flavours were layered and complex in a way that made him want to photograph the plate and immediately felt inadequate to describe it.

"This is unreal," he said, mouth full.

"Mama Siti has been cooking since before this building was a hostel," Felix said. "Since before it was a brothel, if you believe Uncle Razak."

"A brothel?"

"The building has had many lives. Warehouse, brothel, gambling den. Japanese headquarters during the war." Felix ate neatly, precisely, his fork and spoon working in the Malaysian style. "The walls remember everything."

Connor looked at the walls. Peeling paint, faded plaster, the ghosts of old signage in Chinese characters. The red lanterns hung from wires like paper organs, pulsing gently in the current from the ceiling fans. He could almost believe it -- that the building was alive, that it remembered. Almost. Then he took another bite of nasi lemak and the thought dissolved in sambal.

---

The American arrived like a weather event.

"Dude. DUDE. Is this the common room? This is sick. This is, like, the sickest common room I've ever been in. Are those real lanterns? Are they, like, actual paper? Can I touch one?"

He was stocky, sunburned to a shade of aggressive pink, wearing a backwards cap over sandy hair, a surf brand t-shirt two sizes too small, and the permanent grin of a golden retriever who'd just discovered a tennis ball factory. He stood in the doorway of the common room with a beer in one hand and the other extended towards the nearest lantern, fingers reaching.

"I wouldn't," Felix said mildly. "They're old. And flammable."

"Right. Right, right, right. Smart." The American retracted his hand and turned his grin on Connor and Felix. "Hey, I'm Jake. Jake Porter. San Diego."

"Connor. Melbourne."

"No way! Australia? Dude, I love Australians. You guys are, like, the Americans of the Southern Hemisphere."

Connor wasn't sure this was a compliment, but he liked Jake immediately. There was something disarmingly guileless about him -- his enthusiasm was too large and too unqualified to be anything but real. He was the human equivalent of a labrador: loyal, eager, absolutely no idea what was going on.

"Pull up a chair, mate," Connor said. "The German here is buying."

Felix smiled. "I'm Felix. And apparently I'm buying."

"Dude, a German! No way. My roommate at SDSU was German. Klaus. Crazy dude. Used to drink beer for breakfast." Jake dropped into a chair, which protested audibly. "Not, like, in a bad way. In a German way."

"We do have a reputation," Felix said, and the warmth in his voice was exactly right -- amused but not condescending, welcoming the new addition without seeming to try. He reached behind his chair and produced another Tiger from a plastic bag Connor hadn't noticed. The bag had at least six more in it. "Beer?"

"Dude. Yes. Thank you." Jake cracked it open with practiced ease. "So what's the deal with this place? How long have you guys been here?"

"I arrived today," Connor said.

"Two months," Felix said.

Jake's eyes went wide. "Two months? In a hostel? Dude, that's, like--"

"Commitment," Connor offered.

"I was going to say nuts, but sure. Commitment." Jake drank. "I've been in KL for, like, four days? Five? I don't know. What day is it?"

"Wednesday," Felix said.

"Cool. Cool cool cool. Is it, though? I feel like it's Thursday. Whatever. Days are just, like, labels, right? Social constructs."

"Profound," Felix said, and Connor caught the faintest flicker of something in his eyes -- not contempt, exactly, but assessment. A quick, surgical look, the kind a mechanic gives an engine before deciding if it's worth fixing. Then it was gone, replaced by the warm smile, and Felix was pouring Jake another beer from a fresh bottle before Jake's first was half empty.

They talked. The conversation followed the predictable hostel trajectory -- where are you from, where have you been, where are you going -- the same catechism repeated in common rooms across Southeast Asia, a liturgy of itineraries and recommendations and "oh you HAVE to go to" that served less as information exchange and more as mutual verification of tribal membership. *We are travelers. We are the same. We belong here.*

Jake was twenty-four, from San Diego, "taking a year off" after college. When Connor asked what he'd studied, Jake said "business" with the cheerful indifference of a man who'd already forgotten. The year off had been two years now, a fact Jake volunteered without embarrassment. He'd been to Thailand ("insane"), Vietnam ("also insane"), Indonesia ("bro, INSANE"), and was now "just vibing" his way through Malaysia before heading to -- he paused to think -- "wherever, dude. I don't plan."

"A man after my own heart," Connor said.

"Yeah, dude! Plans are, like -- plans are for people who are afraid of life, you know?"

Connor knew. He'd said the same thing a hundred times, in a hundred common rooms, and every time he said it he believed it slightly more and the truth receded slightly further. The truth being: he didn't plan because planning required admitting he didn't know what he was doing. But here, in the red lantern glow of a hostel common room, surrounded by people who'd made the same choice, the absence of a plan felt like liberation rather than deficit.

Other travelers drifted through the common room as the night deepened. A French couple arguing softly about Penang. A solo Korean woman reading *Sapiens* on a beanbag. Two British lads comparing Tinder matches. The hostel at night was a living thing -- bodies flowing in and out, conversations starting and ending and merging, the communal kitchen clanging as someone boiled ramen, a phone playing lo-fi beats from a shelf. The red lanterns swayed in the draft from the air well, and the ceiling fans rotated, and the tile floor was cool, and it was, Connor thought, exactly the kind of place he'd been looking for without knowing he was looking.

Felix moved through it all like a host. He seemed to know everyone -- greeting the French couple by name, asking the Korean woman about her book, trading a joke in halting French with one of the British lads. He was generous with the beers, pulling them from his seemingly bottomless plastic bag, always cold, always offered before you realized you wanted one. His stories were perfect: a street food crawl in Penang that nearly ended in a fistfight over the best char kway teow, a sunrise hike in the Cameron Highlands with a group of monks, a near-miss with a monitor lizard while kayaking in Langkawi. Each story was specific and vivid and landed with a punchline, and each one ended with Felix turning the conversation back to someone else. "But tell me about your trip. Where have you been?"

He was, Connor decided, the best kind of traveler. The kind who'd seen everything and wasn't a wanker about it.

"This bloke's been everywhere," Connor told Jake, thumbing towards Felix. "Myanmar, Philippines, the lot."

"Dude. That's sick. I want to do Myanmar but like, isn't it, like -- heavy there right now?"

"It's complicated," Felix said. "But the people are extraordinary. The most generous people I've ever met." He smiled. "And the beer is cheap."

"That's all I need to know, dude."

Connor laughed. Jake was an idiot, but he was the right kind of idiot -- uncomplicated, enthusiastic, safe. He was the kind of mate you wanted at a party: would never steal your drink, would always laugh at your jokes, and would never, under any circumstances, ask you a hard question. Connor collected people like Jake the way some people collected stamps -- quickly, casually, and without bothering to learn their real value.

---

Sometime after eleven, when the French couple had gone to bed and the British lads had headed to Changkat and the common room had thinned to its late-night residents, Felix looked at Connor and Jake and said, "Rooftop?"

They climbed the narrow staircase single-file, the old wooden steps groaning under their weight. The staircase was barely wide enough for one person -- Connor's shoulders nearly touched both walls -- and the air grew warmer as they ascended, the building holding its heat like a clay oven. On the second-floor landing, Connor caught a glimpse of Japanese characters showing through the peeling paint, faded military signage from the occupation era, and felt a small chill that he immediately dismissed as a draft from the air well.

The third floor was quieter, darker. Two doors on the right -- dorms -- and two on the left. One of the left-hand doors was open a crack, revealing a room barely larger than a closet, but with a real bed, a nightstand, a reading lamp. A private room. Felix's door, Connor assumed, because Felix paused there for a moment and reached inside to grab something -- another bag of beers -- before closing the door and locking it with a key.

*A private room,* Connor noted. *In a hostel. For two months.*

The thought surfaced and sank without consequence, like a fish breaking the surface of a pond. It was odd, sure. Private rooms in hostels weren't cheap -- maybe RM85 a night, which over two months was... Connor didn't do the math because Connor didn't do math, but it was a lot. More than a travel photographer working on speculative documentary projects should be spending. But then Felix always seemed to have money, and some people just did, and Connor wasn't the kind of person who questioned other people's finances because that would invite questions about his own.

The rooftop was a revelation.

They emerged through a fire door propped open with a brick and stepped out onto a flat concrete terrace ringed by a low wall that was probably not up to code. Plastic chairs were scattered about in no discernible pattern, a clothesline stretched between two poles with someone's underwear and sarongs flapping in the night breeze, and there -- there, above the corrugated zinc rooftops of Chinatown, above the tangle of electrical wires that cross-hatched the sky like a mad architect's blueprints, above the dark mass of the Guan Di temple and the glowing neon of Petaling Street's shuttered market stalls -- there were the Petronas Towers.

They rose from the city like two silver syringes, lit from within, their faceted surfaces catching and refracting the light so that they seemed to pulse against the dark sky. The skybridge connecting them at the forty-first floor hung like a filament of light suspended between two columns of glass. Everything around them -- the office blocks, the construction cranes, the distant ridge of jungle-covered hills -- fell away into darkness, and the Towers stood alone, ridiculous and beautiful and utterly dominant, saying what they'd been built to say: *We are here. We are the future. Look at us.*

"Jesus," Connor breathed.

"That never gets old," Felix said. He'd already settled into a plastic chair and was opening beers with a Swiss Army knife he'd produced from his pocket. Always prepared, always equipped, always one step ahead of the moment. "Here."

Connor took the beer and sat down. Jake sat beside him, his mouth still open at the skyline.

"Dude. Those are the Petronas Towers."

"They are," Felix confirmed.

"I've seen pictures. But, like -- dude. They're RIGHT THERE."

"That's what I love about this rooftop," Felix said. "You're in Chinatown, which is ancient. Half these buildings are a hundred years old. And then you look up and there's the twenty-first century, right there." He took a sip. "Layers."

Connor drank and watched the Towers and felt something open in his chest -- not an emotion, exactly, but a kind of vindication. This was the moment. This was the shot. The rooftop terrace, the beers, the new mates, the Petronas Towers glittering against the Malaysian sky. This was the life that people back in Hawthorn, back in their cubicles and their mortgages and their Monday meetings, would never understand. He was living. Actually living.

He took out his phone and photographed the skyline. Then he photographed his beer with the Towers behind it. Then he adjusted the angle and took a selfie -- the three of them, Connor in the front, Felix behind his left shoulder, Jake behind his right, the Towers between them. He didn't post it yet. He'd find the right filter in the morning.

They talked. Jake dominated the first twenty minutes with a story about getting lost in Ho Chi Minh City that was approximately sixty percent digressions and forty percent "and then, dude, get this." Felix listened with what appeared to be genuine engagement, asking follow-up questions that made Jake feel like his story was interesting, which it was not. Connor marvelled at it -- at the patience, the generosity of attention. Most people would have glazed over three minutes into Jake's labyrinthine narration. Felix leaned in.

The night expanded around them. The heat softened to something bearable -- not cool, never cool, but the edge taken off by the breeze that moved across the rooftops, carrying the smell of char kway teow and diesel and jasmine from the temple below. The city sounds rose and fell -- a motorcycle accelerating on Jalan Sultan, the distant thrum of a club's bass line, a woman laughing in the apartment block across the street, the endless, irreducible hum of a city of eight million people settling into its evening.

Around midnight, Jake yawned. It was a yawn of magnificent proportions -- a full-body, eye-watering, jaw-cracking performance that seemed to temporarily dislocate his face.

"Dudes. I'm done. I'm, like, dead." He stood and nearly knocked over his chair. "What time is it? Midnight? Bro. That's, like, my bed time in San Diego. I mean, no it isn't. But tonight it is." He pointed at Connor. "You. Tomorrow. We're exploring. I saw a sign for like a bird park or something."

"The KL Bird Park," Felix said. "It's good."

"See? The German knows. Felix knows." Jake clasped Felix's hand in a complicated handshake that Felix navigated flawlessly. "Thanks for the beers, dude. You're a legend."

"Goodnight, Jake."

"Night, dudes. Night, Petronas." Jake waved at the Towers, then stumbled through the fire door and was gone, his footsteps descending the staircase in a series of creaks and thuds.

And then it was two.

---

The silence that followed Jake's departure was different. It had texture. Felix let it breathe for a while, sipping his beer, his eyes on the skyline, his face half-lit by the city's ambient glow. Without Jake's cheerful noise filling the space, Connor became aware of smaller sounds: the click of insects, the hum of an air conditioning unit somewhere below, the distant call to prayer from a mosque he couldn't see -- late, mournful, beautiful.

"He's a good guy," Felix said eventually.

"Jake? Yeah, he's a crack-up."

"Very American." Felix smiled. "Not much going on behind the eyes, but a good heart."

"That's harsh, mate."

"It's observation, not criticism. I like Jake. People like Jake are important. They keep things light." Felix turned the beer bottle slowly in his fingers. "But I don't think Jake is someone who wants more from travel than the surface. The photos, the parties, the 'I was there.' You know?"

Connor said nothing. He was aware that Felix was drawing a distinction -- between Jake and Connor, between surface travelers and something else -- and that the distinction was flattering to him.

"You're different," Felix said, as if reading the thought. "I could tell when we started talking. You're not just passing through. You're trying to understand something."

"Mate, I'm just winging it, to be honest."

"No. You're not." Felix looked at him. The scar on his eyebrow caught the light. "You dropped out of university to travel. You built a career around freedom. That takes courage. Most people talk about breaking free, but they never actually do it."

Connor felt something warm and unfamiliar move through him. It was the feeling of being seen -- not the Instagram version, not the curated feed, but the actual person underneath. Or at least, the person he wanted to believe was underneath.

"I just couldn't do the nine-to-five thing," Connor said. "I watched my dad go to work every day, come home tired, do it again. And for what? A house in the suburbs? A car? I wanted more than that."

"And you got more."

"I think so. Yeah."

Felix nodded slowly. "I understand that. When I left Hamburg, my family thought I was insane. A good German boy doesn't become a photographer. A good German boy studies engineering, gets a job at Siemens, marries a girl named Katrin, and buys a Volkswagen." He laughed softly. "My mother still asks when I'm coming home."

"Mine too," Connor said, and for a moment they were just two men on a rooftop in a city that wasn't home, bonding over the particular guilt of the runaway. It felt real. It probably was real, on some level -- the story about Felix's mother might even have been true. The best lies are built on foundations of truth, and Felix was a master architect.

"How do you afford it?" Connor asked. The beer had loosened his tongue. "Two months in a private room. All the beers. The travel. Photography doesn't pay that well, does it?"

Felix's expression didn't change, but something behind it shifted -- a door closing and another opening, so smoothly that you'd only notice if you were watching for it. Connor was not watching for it.

"It doesn't," Felix admitted. "Not the documentary work. That's for love, not money." He paused, seemed to consider something, then continued in a lower, more confidential tone. "But I've been in Southeast Asia for a long time. You learn how things work. How the economies really function. There are... opportunities that don't appear in any guidebook."

"What kind of opportunities?"

"Logistics, mostly. Helping people move things from one place to another. Connecting buyers with sellers. Import-export on a small scale." Felix waved a hand, as if these were trivial details. "Nothing glamorous. But it supplements the photography. And it means I can stay as long as I want, wherever I want."

Connor nodded. It made sense. Southeast Asia was full of hustles -- everyone he'd met was running some angle, from the tuk-tuk drivers in Bangkok to the surf instructors in Bali who sold weed on the side. Felix's version sounded cleaner, more professional, but the principle was the same: find the gap, fill it, get paid.

"Smart," Connor said.

"Practical," Felix corrected. "I prefer to think of it as practical." He drained his beer and set it down with a precise click on the concrete beside his chair. "And what about you, Connor? How's the social media consulting business?"

The question was asked without malice, but Connor heard the gears turning inside it. Felix already knew. He'd seen the way Connor had flinched, microscopic but visible, when the conversation turned to money. He'd noticed the old phone, the fraying board shorts, the way Connor had accepted the free beer with a gratitude that was just a shade too eager.

"Yeah, it's good," Connor said. "Ticking along."

"Good."

A silence. Connor drank. The Petronas Towers pulsed against the sky.

"Look," Felix said, "I'm going to say something, and you can absolutely say no. No pressure, no offence taken."

"Go for it."

"I could use someone reliable around here." Felix said it casually, almost as an afterthought, the way you'd mention that you'd seen a good restaurant down the street. "Just small stuff. Logistics. I've got the photography business -- the legitimate side -- and it needs occasional help. Runners. Someone to deliver prints, pick up equipment, that kind of thing. It's not full-time. A few hours a week. But it pays."

The offer hung in the warm night air between them. Below, a motorcycle growled through the alley. The clothesline flapped. The Petronas Towers watched from across the city, twin sentinels, indifferent and magnificent.

"How much?" Connor asked, and hated himself slightly for asking so quickly.

"Depends on the job. Two, three hundred ringgit per delivery. Sometimes more." Felix shrugged. "It adds up."

Two hundred ringgit was about sixty Australian dollars. For a delivery. Connor's freelance rate for a full month of Instagram management was a hundred and fifty dollars. The maths -- for once, the maths -- were clear.

"No offence," Connor said, "but I literally just met you."

"Of course." Felix held up his hands. "I'd be suspicious if you said yes immediately. Think about it. There's no deadline." He stood, smoothly, and collected both their empty bottles, his and Connor's, holding them loosely by the necks. Always cleaning up, Connor noticed. The common room earlier, the beer bottles, the nasi lemak plates -- Felix left no mess behind him. It was the tidiness of a man who was either deeply considerate or deeply careful, and Connor chose to read it as the former.

"I'm heading down," Felix said. "Long day tomorrow -- I've got a shoot in Brickfields." He tucked the bottles under one arm. "Think about what I said, Connor. No pressure."

"Yeah. Yeah, I will."

Felix smiled. "Goodnight, Connor."

"Night, mate."

He watched Felix cross the rooftop and disappear through the fire door, moving with that unhurried, confident stride. A moment later, Connor heard footsteps descending, then a door opening and closing on the third floor. The private room. Felix's private room, where he'd lived for two months, paying rates that would have drained Connor's bank account in a fortnight.

*How does he afford that?* Connor thought.

And then: *Maybe that's exactly what he's offering to show me.*

He sat alone on the rooftop for a while longer, finishing a beer that Felix had left open for him on the armrest of the adjacent chair. The man had known Connor would stay. He'd prepared for it. Connor didn't find this unsettling. He found it thoughtful.

The city murmured below. A siren in the middle distance, rising and falling. The bass from the clubs on Changkat had faded to a faint pulse, like a heartbeat. The Petronas Towers' lights shifted through some programmed cycle, blue to white to silver, and the skybridge between them glowed. The sky above KL was too polluted for stars, but the city made its own constellation -- a sprawl of light that went to every horizon, pulsing, alive.

*This could be something,* Connor thought. Not the delivery thing specifically, but the whole picture -- KL, the hostel, Felix's connections, a way to stay that didn't involve crawling home to Hawthorn with his tail between his legs. A life. The kind of life he posted about but hadn't quite achieved. The kind where the money flowed and the doors opened and every sunset was earned rather than stolen.

He stood, stretched, and headed for the fire door. The staircase groaned under him as he descended, third step from the top squeaking like it always did, like it had for a hundred years. Second floor. Dorm 3. He pushed the door open quietly.

The room was dark except for the blue glow of phone screens and a faint red light that filtered through the gap above the door -- the lanterns in the hallway, never extinguished, casting their warm arterial glow across the threshold. Eight bunks, most occupied. The breathing of strangers in the dark, the private sounds of sleep -- a murmur, a shift, the scratch of a hand against a sheet. The room smelled of insect repellent and sweat and the slightly sour scent of clothes that had been hand-washed in a sink and hung to dry in humidity that never let anything fully dry.

Connor climbed into Bed 7 -- lower bunk, against the wall, the one with the mattress that was thin enough to feel the wooden slats through the foam. He plugged in his phone and lay on his back, staring at the ceiling. The fan above him rotated in slow circles, click-click-clicking where one blade was slightly off balance, a metronome measuring out the night in irregular intervals.

His phone buzzed. He picked it up, squinting at the brightness.

A notification from his banking app. He tapped it, already knowing and dreading.

**Available Balance: $847.32 AUD**

He stared at the number. Eight hundred and forty-seven dollars. His flights from Bali had cost four hundred. Hostel was thirty-five ringgit a night -- about twelve dollars -- but over a week that was eighty-four. Food. Transport. Beers. The number had been bigger when he'd last checked in Bali, but he hadn't checked carefully, because careful checking was a form of planning, and planning was for people who were afraid of life.

Eight forty-seven. His parents' next deposit wasn't for ten days. If he was careful -- genuinely careful, rice and instant noodles careful -- he could stretch it to three weeks. After that: the credit card, which was already carrying two thousand dollars he tried not to think about. After the credit card: phone calls. The kind of phone calls where you hear your father sigh before he speaks, and the sigh says more than the words that follow.

Or.

Two hundred ringgit per delivery. Sixty bucks. A few hours a week. Felix's offer, sitting there like a door left open.

Connor closed the banking app and opened Instagram instead. His latest post -- a photo of the Petaling Street night market stalls from that afternoon, captioned "KL, you absolute legend" -- had thirty-one likes. He scrolled through the comments. Three fire emojis, a "Living the dream bro" from a mate in Sydney, and a "Miss you xx" from a girl he'd met in Chiang Mai whose name he'd already forgotten.

Thirty-one likes. He told people he had about five thousand followers. He had 4,217. Close enough. The number hadn't moved in months.

He put his phone down and rolled onto his side. Through the thin wall, he could hear the air well amplifying the sounds of the city settling -- a last motorcycle, a dog barking, the rattle of a shutter being pulled down over a shop front. The ceiling fan clicked. Someone in a lower bunk muttered in their sleep, something in a language Connor didn't recognize.

He thought about Felix's smile on the rooftop. The easy confidence of it. The way he'd said "someone reliable" -- not "someone available" or "someone who needs cash," but "reliable." It was a word that meant something. It was a word that suggested Felix saw in Connor a quality that Connor wanted to believe he possessed. Reliable. Trustworthy. The kind of person you brought into your inner circle.

*She'll be right,* Connor thought. *It's just deliveries. Photography equipment. Prints. Felix is a photographer, it makes sense. And even if it's something else, so what? Everyone's got a hustle out here. That's how it works. That's how Asia works.*

He closed his eyes. The red glow of the hallway lantern filtered through the gap above the door, painting the inside of his eyelids a warm, shifting red. It pulsed there, rhythmic, alive, like the building itself was breathing, like the old shophouse was drawing air in through its central well and exhaling it out through its cracks and gaps and half-closed doors.

The last thought before sleep was not a thought but an image: Felix collecting the empty bottles on the rooftop, holding them loosely by the necks, carrying them away. A man who leaves no trace. A man who cleans up after himself.

Connor slept. The fan clicked. The lantern pulsed.

Outside, Kuala Lumpur hummed on, vast and hot and indifferent to the small dramas unfolding in its oldest buildings. The Petronas Towers stood watch over the city like chrome headstones, beautiful and meaningless, catching the light of a moon that nobody on the rooftop had thought to look up and see.

In his private room on the third floor, Felix Decker set down two empty beer bottles on his nightstand, aligned perfectly parallel. He opened his phone and typed a message in German to a number with a Hong Kong area code. The message was short.

*Neuer Junge. Australier. Leichtglaubig. Er wird ja sagen.*

New boy. Australian. Gullible. He will say yes.

He locked his phone, placed it face-down beside the bottles, and turned off his reading lamp. The room went dark except for the red glow bleeding under the door from the hallway lanterns.

Felix closed his eyes and slept the easy, dreamless sleep of a man who had done this many times before.
# Chapter 3: Petaling Street

The call to prayer woke him at 5:30 in the morning.

Connor didn't know what it was at first. The sound bled through the dorm's thin walls like something from a dream he was already forgetting -- a long, wavering note that seemed to hang in the humid air, rising and falling, reaching for something beyond the cracked plaster ceiling. He lay in Bed 7, blinking at the underside of the bunk above him, trying to slot the sound into a category his brain could file and dismiss. Not a siren. Not music, exactly. Something older than either.

He pulled his pillow over his head and went back to sleep.

When he woke again, it was ten past nine, and the dorm was empty. Every other bunk was made or unmade but abandoned -- the German guy from Dorm 2 who wore hiking boots to breakfast, the Korean couple who always left before dawn, the silent Scandinavian woman who Connor had never actually heard speak. All gone. Out in the city being productive travelers while Connor lay in his own sweat on a foam mattress that smelled faintly of Tiger Balm and the bodies of everyone who'd slept on it before him.

He checked his phone. Three percent battery. He'd forgotten to charge it again. The Instagram notification count sat at seven -- he tapped it before anything else, the way other people checked for earthquakes or air-raid warnings. Three new followers (all bots), two likes on yesterday's sunset shot from the rooftop, and a comment from his mother: *Please call when you can sweetheart Dad and I worry xx.* He swiped it away. There was also a text from Jake: *dude where are you breakfast is INSANE come to kitchen.* The timestamp said 8:14 AM. An hour ago. Connor groaned, swung his legs off the bunk, and stepped barefoot onto the tile floor.

The tiles were cool and uneven beneath his feet, cracked in geometric patterns that might have been decorative a century ago but now just caught his toes at odd angles. He shuffled out of the dorm and onto the second-floor landing, and the hostel opened up around him in the morning light.

He hadn't really seen it yesterday. He'd arrived in the late afternoon, when the building was all shadows and red lantern glow and the smell of other people's cooking. But now, with the tropical sun pouring through the central air well, The Lantern Hostel revealed itself.

The air well was the building's heart -- a rectangular shaft cut through the center of all three stories, open to the sky. Light fell through it in a solid column, so thick and golden it looked like something you could climb. It illuminated the interior courtyard below: potted ferns with leaves the size of dinner plates, a clothesline heavy with travelers' laundry -- underwear and sarongs and a pair of board shorts that might have been his -- and a mosaic tile bench, chipped and sun-bleached, where someone had left a paperback face-down and open. The walls around the air well were painted white, or had been once, but the tropics had softened them to a mottled cream, blooming with patches of green-grey mould that crept up from the ground floor like the building was slowly returning to jungle.

It was, Connor thought, reaching for the word -- *aesthetic*. His fingers twitched toward his phone before he remembered: three percent. He'd have to charge it before he could capture any of this. The thought caused a small, genuine pang, as though something didn't fully exist until he'd photographed it.

On the second-floor landing, between the bathroom and the stairwell, a section of the wall was different. The paint had peeled away in a rough rectangle, revealing something underneath: characters, painted directly onto the plaster in a faded red-brown. Japanese. Connor didn't read Japanese -- he didn't read anything that wasn't an Instagram caption -- but there was something about the precision of the brushstrokes that made him pause. They looked official.
