Military, maybe. A sign from the occupation era, from when this building had been something other than a hostel. Something with locked doors and sounds that didn't carry to the street.

He looked at the characters for three seconds, felt nothing he could identify, and went downstairs.

---

The kitchen was on the ground floor, tucked behind the common room, and Mama Siti was in it.

She was there the way a stove is there. Not waiting, not arriving, just *present* -- as though the kitchen had been built around her rather than the other way around. She stood at the counter in a floral housedress that looked older than Connor's parents, her grey hair tucked under a loose headscarf, stirring something in a blackened wok with the practiced economy of someone who had been making the same motion for longer than anyone still alive could confirm. The kitchen smelled extraordinary. Coconut and chili and something frying in hot oil, layered over the deeper base notes of rice steaming and pandan leaves and a sweetness he couldn't place.

Connor stood in the doorway. "Morning," he said, with what he considered charm.

Mama Siti didn't look up. She reached to her left, picked up a banana leaf that had already been arranged into a plate, and loaded it: a mound of rice so white it was almost blue, a splash of red sambal that glistened like lacquer, a scattering of tiny anchovies fried to bronze, a handful of peanuts, a wedge of hard-boiled egg, and a single slice of cucumber. She set it on the counter in front of Connor the way you'd set a bowl of water in front of a dog -- not with unkindness, but with the calm certainty that the creature would do exactly what you expected.

"Erm," Connor said. "How much is--"

"Lima ringgit." Five ringgit. She held up five fingers, then turned back to the wok. Her fingers were knotted and dark, the knuckles swollen in the way that hands get when they've been working for decades without rest.

Connor dug a crumpled blue note from his pocket and placed it on the counter. Mama Siti made it vanish without looking. He picked up the banana leaf plate -- it was warm, the rice still steaming -- and carried it to the communal table, a scarred wooden surface that looked like it had been repurposed from something larger. A dining table, maybe, or a door.

He sat down. He reached for his phone, remembered the battery, and swore under his breath. Three percent was enough for one photo if he was quick. He angled the banana leaf, tried to find the light from the air well, framed the shot --

"Makan dulu."

He looked up. Mama Siti was watching him from the kitchen doorway, arms folded. Her face was a landscape of lines, each one earned, and the expression on it was not quite disapproval and not quite pity. Somewhere between the two. A look that said she had seen this exact scene play out a hundred times, in this exact kitchen, and she already knew how it ended.

"Eat first," she said. "Phone later."

"Yeah, no, I was just going to--"

"*Makan.*"

Connor put the phone down.

He ate.

The nasi lemak was, without exaggeration, the best thing he had eaten in six countries of backpacking. The rice was impossibly fragrant, cooked in coconut milk until each grain was separate and slick and faintly sweet. The sambal hit him three seconds after the first bite -- a slow-building heat that started at the back of his tongue and crawled forward until his eyes watered. The anchovies were salty and crunchy, the peanuts grounding the whole thing with an earthy depth, and the egg was just an egg but somehow better than any egg he'd eaten before, as though Mama Siti had a personal arrangement with the chickens.

"This is incredible," he said, mouth full. "This is actually -- this is amazing."

Mama Siti said nothing. She stood in the kitchen doorway, watching him eat with an expression he couldn't read and wouldn't have tried to read even if he could. Something old and settled and final. The look of someone watching the tide come in, knowing what it would take when it went back out.

Connor didn't notice. He was thinking about how he'd describe the nasi lemak in an Instagram caption. *When the hostel auntie is a better chef than your whole country* with a fire emoji and a Malaysian flag. Something like that. Casual. Relatable. The kind of thing that got engagement.

He finished the plate, wiped the sambal from his lips with the back of his hand, and grinned at her. "Cheers, legend."

Mama Siti turned back to the kitchen. As she went, she said something in Malay, so quietly it might have been to herself, or to the building, or to no one at all.

Connor didn't ask for a translation.

---

Jake was waiting for him in the common room, sprawled across a wicker chair that creaked under his sunburned weight, scrolling his phone with the vacant attention of someone who had no destination and no urgency. He was wearing a backwards San Diego State cap and a shirt that said *I SURVIVED FULL MOON PARTY KOH PHANGAN* in neon lettering. His face lit up when he saw Connor.

"Dude! Finally. I've been waiting like an hour. Did you try the rice thing? The coconut rice?"

"Nasi lemak. And yeah, mate, it was unreal."

"Nah-see lem-ack," Jake repeated, getting it approximately right. "Dude, we should go explore. I heard Petaling Street is like, right outside. It's supposed to be this crazy market."

Connor looked at the common room. Mismatched furniture -- the wicker chair, a vinyl couch with a split down the middle leaking yellow foam, two plastic stools, a beanbag that had seen better decades. A bookshelf of abandoned novels, mostly thrillers and romance, their spines cracked and wavy from humidity. A wall-mounted TV showing CNN with the sound off, the ticker scrolling news that belonged to a world Connor had excused himself from. Above it all, ceiling fans rotated with the hypnotic slowness of things that have given up on urgency.

"Yeah," Connor said. "Let me charge my phone first. I need to film this."

He plugged in at the sole available outlet, the one near the reception desk that every guest in the hostel competed for like animals at a watering hole, and waited for the phone to climb to eleven percent. It would have to do. He had content to create.

---

Petaling Street hit them the way KL hit everyone who wasn't prepared for it: all at once, from every direction, with no mercy and no volume control.

They stepped out of the hostel's narrow doorway -- squeezed between the phone repair shop and the traditional Chinese medicine store, whose window displayed jars of dried things Connor didn't want to identify -- and into the street, and the street swallowed them whole.

The market ran the length of Petaling Street under a permanent canopy of green tarpaulins and corrugated metal that blocked the worst of the sun but trapped the heat like a greenhouse. Stalls lined both sides, stacked with goods that cascaded from tables onto the ground and up the walls: fake Louis Vuitton bags, fake Gucci wallets, fake Ray-Ban sunglasses, fake Beats headphones, fake everything, piled in bright cheap abundance. Between the stalls, in gaps that shouldn't have been wide enough for commerce, vendors had set up food carts -- woks hissing with oil, steamers billowing, grills smoking with satay sticks that sent plumes of charcoal-scented fog into the canopy. The smell was a wall: frying noodles, roasting peanuts, the sulfurous funk of open drains, incense from a temple somewhere nearby, diesel exhaust, and beneath it all, the sweet rot of overripe tropical fruit.

And the noise. Vendors calling out in Cantonese, Mandarin, Malay, English -- "Hey, you want watch? Good price!" "Best bag, real leather!" "Makan, makan, come eat!" -- layered over the rumble of traffic from the streets beyond, motorbike engines revving, a radio playing Cantopop from a hardware stall, the clatter of metal bowls and plastic chairs, the indecipherable hum of a thousand overlapping conversations. Bodies pressed in from all sides -- tourists with cameras, locals with shopping bags, children darting between legs, a man pushing a cart loaded with durian fruit that people stepped away from as if it were radioactive.

Connor raised his phone and pressed record.

"What's up, legends," he said to the camera, adopting the slightly louder, slightly more performative voice he used for content. "Day two in KL, and we're hitting up Petaling Street. This is the famous Chinatown market, and as you can see, it is absolutely *pumping*. Let's go find some bargains."

No one had asked for this. His 4,200 followers -- about five K, he'd tell you -- mostly scrolled past his stories without watching. But Connor filmed with the conviction of someone addressing a vast and hungry audience, panning the phone slowly across the market, zooming in on things that caught his eye, providing commentary that no one would hear.

"Look at this -- fake Rolexes, fake Nikes, fake everything. This is what I love about Asia, man. You can get anything for nothing."

Jake trailed behind him, equally awed but less inclined to narrate. He pointed at things and said "dude" and "no way" at intervals, which was his contribution to most conversations.

They stopped at a stall selling watches. The display was a glass case of imitation luxury, Rolexes and Omegas and Breitlings laid out on velvet in a way that was almost touching in its aspirational sincerity. The vendor, a Chinese Malaysian man in his fifties with reading glasses pushed up on his forehead and an expression of infinite patience, watched Connor approach.

"How much for this one?" Connor picked up a fake Submariner. It was surprisingly heavy.

"Eighty ringgit."

"Eighty? Mate, come on. I'll give you twenty."

The vendor's expression didn't change. "Sixty."

"Twenty-five."

"Fifty. Good price. Best quality."

Connor grinned the grin of someone who had watched three YouTube videos about haggling in Asian markets and now considered himself a master negotiator. "Thirty. Final offer. I'm doing you a favour, there's heaps of these stalls."

The vendor looked at Connor for a long moment. The glasses on his forehead caught the light. He said, in English so precise and clipped it could have cut glass: "Thirty ringgit. For a watch you'll lose in a swimming pool next week. Take it and please stop performing for your telephone."

Jake burst out laughing. Connor's grin faltered for exactly one second before reassembling itself. "Legend," he said, laying the thirty ringgit on the glass case. He strapped the watch to his wrist, held it up to the phone camera. "Just got a Rolex in KL for like seven bucks. This place is unreal."

They moved deeper into the market. Connor filmed everything. He filmed a woman making fresh popiah at her stall, her hands moving with mesmerizing speed, rolling the thin crepe around shredded jicama and peanuts. He didn't ask permission. The woman looked up, saw the phone, and turned her back. He filmed a display of traditional Chinese calligraphy brushes and asked the vendor, "Do you speak English?" The vendor, a woman in her thirties with a university lanyard still hanging from her bag, replied in English with a received pronunciation that made Connor's Australian drawl sound like he was speaking through a mouthful of gravel: "I have a degree in English literature from the University of Malaya. Would you like a recommendation? You seem like you'd enjoy Hemingway. He also mistook brevity for profundity."

Jake laughed so hard he choked on his own spit. Connor said "Sick burn, actually" and moved on, because nothing penetrated, nothing stuck, nothing altered the fundamental architecture of his certainty that the world was a playground built for his amusement.

They passed the Guan Di Temple. It rose from the street like something from a different century, which it was -- red pillars, gold trim, the deep green of glazed roof tiles, and above the entrance, a carved dragon that looked down at the market with an expression of magnificent indifference. Incense smoke drifted from the doorway, sweet and thick, and inside, Connor could see the dim glow of candles and the burnished gold of altar pieces.

"Sick," he said. "Let's check it out."

He walked straight for the entrance in his flip-flops. One foot was on the threshold when a hand caught his arm -- firm, not aggressive, but unmistakably a stop. An elderly Chinese man in a white undershirt, sitting on a plastic stool beside the entrance, shook his head and pointed at Connor's feet. Then at a rack of plastic sandal bags. Then at a sign, written in four languages, that said *PLEASE REMOVE SHOES BEFORE ENTERING*.

"Oh," Connor said. "Right. Yeah. Sorry, mate."

He kicked off his flip-flops, dropped them in a bag, and entered the temple barefoot. The stone floor was cool and smooth, worn by decades of feet that had entered with more reverence than his. The interior was dark after the market's glare, and the smoke from a forest of joss sticks turned the air into something you could almost chew. A massive statue of Guan Di -- the red-faced god of war and righteousness, though Connor didn't know that and wouldn't have been interested -- loomed at the far end, flanked by smaller figures and offerings of oranges and flowers.

Connor raised his phone and took a selfie. Flash on. In a temple.

Jake, to his credit, looked uncomfortable. "Dude, should you be doing that in here?"

"Relax, it's Asia. Everyone takes photos everywhere."

A woman praying at a side altar turned and looked at him. Her look was not the vendor's cutting wit or the calligraphy seller's dry dismissal. It was something quieter and harder to shrug off. Sadness, maybe. The sadness of watching someone walk through a sacred space without seeing it.

Connor didn't see it. He was checking the selfie. The lighting was good.

---

They emerged from the temple and followed their noses to a row of fruit stalls at the edge of the market, where the permanent canopy gave way to a strip of open sky and the sun fell on piles of rambutan, mangosteen, jackfruit, and -- unmistakable, even to someone who'd never encountered it before -- durian.

The smell arrived before the visual. It was a smell that seemed to have ambitions beyond the olfactory, reaching for something truly transcendent in its awfulness -- a concentrated essence of rotting onion, turpentine, old gym sock, and an indefinable sweetness that somehow made the whole thing worse. The durians sat in their spiky green husks, looking like medieval weapons designed by someone with a cruel sense of humour, and the vendor -- a wiry man in a singlet who clearly had no functioning sense of smell -- was hacking one open with a machete.

"Oh my god," Jake said, pulling his shirt over his nose. "What IS that?"

"Durian, bro," Connor said, already filming. "King of fruits. You've got to try it when you're in Southeast Asia. It's like a rite of passage."

He had never tried it. He had seen Instagram posts about trying it. This was functionally the same thing in Connor's epistemology.

"How much?" he asked the vendor, pointing at the open durian.

"Ten ringgit."

Connor paid without bargaining -- the smell had disabled his negotiation instincts -- and the vendor scooped out a segment of the custard-yellow flesh and placed it on a plastic plate. It sat there, glistening, looking like something that had already been eaten once. The smell, freed from the husk, intensified to the point where nearby shoppers visibly adjusted their trajectories.

"This is going to be content gold," Connor told Jake. "Film me."

He handed Jake his phone. Jake held it up with one hand, the other pinching his nose shut. Connor picked up the durian segment, mugged for the camera, and bit into it.

The first thing was the texture -- soft, almost gelatinous, with the consistency of a custard that had lost the will to live. It coated the inside of his mouth immediately, clinging to his teeth, his tongue, the roof of his mouth, as though it were trying to colonize him. Then the flavour arrived. It was not one flavour but several, in rapid and contradictory succession: sweet, then savory, then something that tasted like caramelized onion mixed with vanilla ice cream, then a garlicky aftertaste that had no business being in a fruit, and through all of it, the *smell*, which was now coming from inside him, rising through his sinuses and establishing a permanent camp behind his eyes.

Connor's face went through a full cycle of human emotion in about four seconds. Surprise. Confusion. Dawning horror. A brief, wild-eyed moment of wondering if this was poisonous. And then, inevitably, the gag.

He lurched forward, one hand on his knee, the other still holding the half-eaten durian segment, and produced a sound that was somewhere between a cough, a retch, and a prayer. He didn't actually vomit -- he would later insist on this, on his Instagram story, with the passion of someone defending a war record -- but it was a near thing. His body convulsed. His eyes streamed. A small, involuntary whimper escaped his lips.

Jake, filming, was laughing so hard that the footage would be unusable -- just shaking and wheezing and Jake's voice saying "dude -- dude -- DUDE --" between gasps.

The durian vendor watched with the detached amusement of a man who had seen this performance approximately eight thousand times. He leaned against his stall, arms crossed, and when Connor finally straightened up, red-faced and watery-eyed, the vendor offered him a single piece of practical advice.

"Next time, don't breathe through nose."

"Cheers," Connor croaked. He looked at the durian segment in his hand, looked at the camera, and -- because content was content -- took another bite. This time he chewed with his mouth open, breathing through his mouth like a drowning man, and managed to swallow. He gave the camera a thumbs-up with the expression of someone who has just been informed of a family death.

"That," he said, "is an acquired taste."

The vendor said nothing. He was already serving the next customer, a local woman who ate her durian with the relaxed pleasure of someone enjoying ice cream on a park bench.

---

The hawker center was two streets behind Petaling Street, down a narrow lane that smelled of drains and jasmine, in a covered open-air space filled with plastic tables and metal stools that had been welded together in configurations that discouraged comfort. The lunch rush was on. Every table was occupied by people eating with the focused intensity that Malaysians brought to food -- heads down, elbows out, the conversation secondary to the meal.

Connor and Jake found a table with two empty spots at the end, across from someone who was already sitting there. They sat down without asking, because that was how hawker centers worked -- Connor knew this from a YouTube travel channel, one of the few pieces of cultural research he'd ever conducted.

The person across from them was a woman. She was young -- mid-twenties, Connor estimated -- with dark skin and long black hair pulled into a practical braid that hung over one shoulder. She wore round glasses, the kind that looked like they'd been chosen for function rather than fashion, and a plain grey T-shirt and jeans. No jewelry. No visible brand logos. No effort, Connor thought, to project a curated identity -- which was, in his worldview, almost as baffling as the durian.

She was reading a book. Not a phone, not a Kindle -- an actual physical book, a Lonely Planet guide so battered it was held together with rubber bands. She was eating roti canai with one hand and turning pages with the other, her eyes tracking lines of text with the focused attention of someone used to processing large volumes of information. A cup of teh tarik sat at her elbow, milky and sweet-smelling, half-finished.

Connor noticed her immediately, because Connor always noticed women, the way a satellite dish always points at the sky. But there was something else -- something about the self-sufficiency of the scene, the completeness of a person who needed nothing beyond a book and a meal and a table. She looked like she belonged here, even though she clearly wasn't local. She looked like she'd done her homework.

"That any good?" Connor asked, nodding at the roti canai.

She looked up. Brown eyes behind the round glasses, sharp and assessing. She took him in -- the man-bun, the singlet, the fake Rolex, the flip-flops, the phone lying on the table like an extra organ -- and something moved behind her expression. Not interest. Not disinterest. Categorization.

"It's excellent," she said. London accent, precise, the vowels clipped in a way that made Connor's Australian sound like it was melting. "The dhal is particularly good here. They use fresh curry leaves."

"Sick. I'll get some. I'm Connor, by the way. This is Jake."

"Priya," she said, and went back to her book.

Connor was not deterred by disinterest. Connor was never deterred by disinterest. Disinterest was, in his experience, just interest that hadn't been properly introduced to his personality.

"What are you reading? Like, I know it's a Lonely Planet, but what section?"

Priya pushed her glasses up her nose. "The legal section. Malaysian civil and criminal law."

Connor stared at her. Then he laughed -- a genuine, full-bodied laugh that turned heads at the next table. "You're actually reading the *rules section*? That's like reading the terms and conditions. Nobody does that."

"Everybody should do that," Priya said, without smiling. "Especially in a country where the legal system is significantly different from whatever you're used to."

"What are they going to do, arrest me for being too good-looking?"

She did smile then, despite herself. Just a flicker at the corner of her mouth, barely enough to register, but Connor saw it and felt the small, warm hit of dopamine that came from making a pretty girl crack. He leaned back in his chair, arms behind his head, the fake Rolex catching the light.

"Where are you from?" he asked.

"London."

"Travelling long?"

"Six weeks. I'm a medical student. This is my break before final year."

"A doctor! Legend. So you're on holiday and you're doing *homework*." He gestured at the guidebook. "That's dedication."

"It's common sense," Priya said. She turned the guidebook toward him, tapping a section of text. "Did you know that Malaysia has a mandatory death penalty for drug trafficking? Not just dealing -- even carrying above certain amounts. Fifty grams of methamphetamine, for instance. That's less than the weight of a candy bar."

Connor's expression didn't change. He heard the words -- *mandatory death penalty* -- the way he heard all words that didn't directly relate to his immediate comfort: they entered his ears, grazed the surface of his brain, and slid off without leaving a mark.

"Heavy," he said. "You might want to tell that to the actual drug dealers though, not the tourists."

"Tourists get caught too. That's rather the point."

"Yeah, but--" He waved a hand, the universal gesture of someone dismissing information they haven't processed. "That's like, big-time dealer stuff. Cartels and all that. They're not going to hang some backpacker for having a good time."

Priya looked at him for a long moment. "You might want to read this section," she said, pushing the book slightly closer.

"Why? Are they going to arrest me for being too good-looking?" He said it again, grinning, because in Connor's world, a line that worked once would work forever.

"You already used that one," Priya said, but she was smiling now, properly, the kind of smile that acknowledged the joke was terrible while conceding that the delivery had a certain brainless charm. She closed the guidebook and took a sip of her teh tarik. "Where are you staying?"

"The Lantern. In Chinatown. It's this old shophouse place, really cool."

"I know it. I'm staying there too. Dorm four."

"No way. I'm in three. We're practically neighbours."

"Practically."

Connor ordered roti canai from a passing hawker -- pointing at Priya's plate and holding up two fingers, because ordering by imitation was easier than learning words -- and when the food arrived, he ate it with the messy enthusiasm he brought to everything. Priya ate neatly, methodically, and asked him questions with the diagnostic precision of someone trained to take patient histories. Where was he from? (Melbourne.) How long had he been travelling? (Four years, on and off.) What did he do for work? (Digital consulting, very flexible, location-independent.) Had he been to KL before? (Nah, first time, just vibing.)

She didn't challenge his answers directly. She just listened with an attentiveness that Connor found flattering and slightly unnerving, as though she were running his responses through some internal diagnostic algorithm and noting the results without sharing them.

Jake, meanwhile, had ordered a plate of char kway teow and was eating it with the focused joy of a golden retriever encountering a steak. He contributed to the conversation at intervals -- "Dude, this is so good" and "Wait, you're going to be a doctor? That's sick" -- before returning to his noodles with the contentment of someone for whom the present moment was the only moment that existed.

"Your friend is having a good time," Priya observed.

"Jake's having the time of his life. Jake's always having the time of his life. It's his superpower."

"And yours?"

Connor thought about this for less than a second. "Being in the right place at the right time."

Priya said nothing to this, but she pushed her glasses up her nose -- the gesture Connor would come to learn meant she was filing something away for later examination -- and something in her expression shifted. Not suspicion. Not attraction. Something in between, something careful and curious and, beneath it all, concerned. As though she'd just heard a cough in a patient's chest and was deciding whether to order an X-ray.

---

They walked back toward the hostel in the early afternoon, the three of them, through the thinning market crowds and down the side streets where the tourist chaos of Petaling Street softened into something older and quieter. Here the shophouses leaned together over narrow lanes like old men sharing secrets, their facades layered with decades of paint and wire and air-conditioning units bolted to walls at precarious angles. Laundry hung from upper windows. A cat slept on a parked motorbike. The heat sat on everything like a physical weight.

It was in one of these side lanes, between a shuttered hardware store and a wall of peeling movie posters in Chinese, that Connor saw the graffiti.

It was written in black marker on a stretch of grey concrete wall, at about head height, in a hand that was neat and deliberate -- not a rushed tag, but something placed there with intention. Two words and a symbol:

**@HostelReaper**

Below the words, drawn with the same black marker, a small icon: a robed figure holding a scythe, rendered in a few simple lines but unmistakable. And beneath that, in smaller lettering:

*Check-in is optional. Check-out is not.*

Connor stopped. He raised his phone and photographed it. The composition was good -- the dark marker against the grey wall, the peeling posters in the background, the heat-shimmer in the air giving the whole thing a faintly hallucinatory quality.

"Sick street art," he said.

Jake leaned in. "What's a Hostel Reaper?"

Connor shrugged. "Probably some band or something. Or like, a travel account. There's heaps of these edgy backpacker brands."

Priya had stopped a few steps ahead and was looking back at them. She looked at the graffiti. She didn't take a photo. She adjusted her glasses and said nothing, but her eyes stayed on the words a beat longer than Connor's had.

They walked on. The graffiti stayed. The afternoon heat pressed down on the lane, and the small reaper figure stared out from the wall with the patient attention of something that had all the time in the world, because it did.

---

The common room of The Lantern Hostel was cooler than the street but not by much. The ceiling fans turned with their eternal reluctance, pushing the humid air around in slow circles that accomplished nothing but the illusion of effort. CNN murmured from the wall-mounted TV. The bookshelf of abandoned novels -- their spines warped, their pages thick with absorbed moisture -- stood against the far wall like a monument to every traveler who had ever left something behind.

Priya settled into the vinyl couch with her guidebook, folding her legs beneath her and propping the battered Lonely Planet against her knee. She was already lost in it before Connor and Jake had finished kicking off their flip-flops. She read the way some people meditate: fully, completely, as though the rest of the room had been dimmed to nothing.

Connor sat in the wicker chair, his phone charging at the outlet by reception, and scrolled through the photos from the day. The market stalls. The fake Rolex on his wrist. The durian selfie -- his face red, eyes streaming, a comedy of suffering that would get more engagement than anything genuine ever could. The calligraphy brushes. The temple. The roti canai. The graffiti.

He was curating the day into a story that bore an approximate relationship to the day he'd actually had. The vendors' cutting English became "hilarious locals." The temple became "incredible vibes." The durian became "I nearly died lol." The girl with the guidebook became -- he wasn't sure yet. He didn't post about girls he'd just met. That was a later move, a week-two move, when the story had developed enough to be captioned.

His phone buzzed. A text message, not a notification. From Felix.

*Free tonight? Got something fun planned.*

Connor looked at the message. He looked at Priya, who was curled on the couch with her guidebook, the afternoon light from the air well falling across her in a warm stripe, turning the pages gold. She was reading with her lips slightly parted, the way people do when they're genuinely absorbed, and her braid had come partially undone, dark hair falling across her face. She pushed it back absently. She didn't look up.

Connor looked at his phone.

He typed a thumbs-up emoji and hit send.

He put the phone down and leaned back in the wicker chair, which creaked under him like the building sighing. On the TV, CNN was showing something about trade agreements. The ceiling fans turned. From the kitchen, the distant sound of Mama Siti washing pans, a rhythmic clang that sounded almost like a bell, or a warning.

Priya looked up from her guidebook. She'd caught something -- not the text, she was too far away for that, but something in his posture, the small shift in his body language when the message arrived. The way he'd leaned forward, then leaned back. The way his thumb had moved with a decisiveness the rest of him rarely showed.

"Who's that?" she asked.

"Just a mate," Connor said. "The German."

Something crossed Priya's face. Not suspicion -- the architecture of suspicion hadn't been built yet, there were no foundations, no framework, just an empty lot where something would eventually be constructed. What crossed her face was something earlier and smaller: attention. The slight narrowing of the eyes, the fractional tilt of the head, the medical student's instinct for symptoms that didn't quite add up. She looked at Connor, and Connor looked back at her, and for a moment the common room was very quiet except for the fans and the TV and Mama Siti's pans.

Then Priya smiled. "Have fun," she said, and went back to her book.

Connor smiled too. He stretched, laced his fingers behind his head, and watched the ceiling fans turn. Through the air well above, the sky was clouding over -- the afternoon thunderstorm building, the light shifting from gold to grey, the humidity thickening toward the downpour that came every day at this hour in this city, as regular and as indifferent as the law.

His phone sat on the arm of the chair, screen dark, the thumbs-up emoji already delivered, already read, already part of a sequence that would not stop until it reached its conclusion.

Outside, thunder rolled across the Kuala Lumpur skyline like a door closing.
# Chapter 4: The Crew

The rooftop of The Lantern Hostel had no business being anyone's idea of a good time. Five plastic chairs arrayed around a plywood table held steady by a folded beer coaster. A clothesline sagged between two poles, heavy with the damp ghosts of traveler laundry: elephant-print harem pants, a sports bra faded to the color of dishwater, someone's cargo shorts pinned by a single clip and rotating slowly like a weathervane nobody needed. The railing was a waist-high strip of corrugated zinc that inspired confidence in absolutely no one.

But the view.

The Petronas Towers framed between shophouse roofs and a chaos of electrical wire so dense it looked like the city's nervous system turned inside out. The towers stood silver and alien against the dark, twin needles of money and ambition punching through the orange murk of light pollution. Below, Petaling Street hummed -- motorbike engines, hawker vendors, the bass-note vibrations from Changkat three blocks east. The air was warm and thick and smelled of exhaust and incense and, beneath that, the sulfurous breath of the open drains.

Connor leaned against the zinc railing with a Tiger beer sweating in his hand and thought: *This is going on the grid.*

He held up his phone and framed the shot -- the towers between the wires, the red glow of the hostel's lanterns bleeding up from below. He took four photos, selected the best, applied a filter that deepened the reds and cooled the sky to a moody indigo, and saved it to drafts. Caption later. Something about perspective. His 4,200 followers -- about five K, if anyone asked -- would eat it up.

"Connor! My man!"

Jake Porter emerged through the rooftop access door like a golden retriever who'd heard a treat bag rustle. Backwards cap, surf brand singlet stretched across his stocky sunburned frame, a grin so wide it was almost a medical condition. He was carrying two cans of Tiger in each hand, pressed against his chest like he was rescuing them from a building fire.

"Dude, Felix said drinks are on the roof. I brought supplies."

"Legend," Connor said. Jake was exactly the kind of person Connor understood on a cellular level: easygoing, up for anything, never asking difficult questions. They'd bonded in under twenty minutes on Connor's first night, and in the hostel economy of instant friendship, that was practically a blood oath.

Jake dropped into a plastic chair that screamed under his weight and cracked a Tiger with practiced ceremony. "So Felix organized this whole thing? Like, he just decided we're all going out?"

"That's Felix, mate. Man's a social architect."

"A what?"

"He just -- he makes things happen. You know? Some people talk about doing stuff, Felix just does it."

Jake nodded with the gravity of someone receiving wisdom. "Totally. He's like, the guy, you know? Every hostel has one."

They clinked cans. The beer was lukewarm but Connor didn't care. The night was happening. He could feel it the way you feel weather coming in -- a charge in the air, a loosening of constraints, the city below rearranging itself into possibility.

Priya arrived next, and Connor could tell from the way she climbed through the access door that she'd already had the argument with herself and lost.

She was dressed practically, as always -- jeans rolled at the ankle, a plain navy top, trainers that had actually been laced properly. Her battered Lonely Planet guide was not in evidence, which for Priya constituted going wild. She pushed her round glasses up her nose and surveyed the rooftop with the expression of someone inspecting a crime scene.

"I can only stay for one drink," she announced to no one in particular. "I have an early start tomorrow. I'm doing the Batu Caves at seven."

"Priya!" Connor stood, spread his arms. "You came! See, I told Jake you'd come."

"You said she wouldn't," Jake said.

"I said she *might* not, which is basically the same as saying she would. Sit down. Drink. The Batu Caves aren't going anywhere -- they've been there for, what, four hundred million years?"

"The limestone, yes. The temples are about a hundred and forty years old." She sat in the plastic chair Connor pulled out for her, accepted the beer he pressed into her hand with minimal resistance. "One drink."

"One drink," Connor agreed, already knowing it would be more.

A Swedish couple appeared -- Astrid and Erik, tall and blonde and so symmetrically attractive they looked like they'd been cast by a Scandinavian tourism board. Then Min-ho, a Korean guy from Dorm 1 who spoke minimal English but communicated entirely through enthusiastic thumbs-ups and an encyclopedic knowledge of drinking games. The rooftop filled with voices and the percussion of cracking cans and the warm, electric hum of people who'd known each other for less than forty-eight hours but were, by the transient mathematics of hostel life, already a family.

Connor noticed the woman sitting apart.

She was on the far side of the rooftop, perched on a plastic crate near the clothesline. Short. Athletic. Hair cropped close to her skull, the tips dyed a dark red that caught the lantern light like embers. Multiple piercings climbed the cartilage of her left ear -- silver studs and tiny hoops, precise as Morse code. In her hands was a camera that was not a tourist's camera. Heavy, black, professional-grade -- the kind of equipment that cost more than Connor's entire travel fund.

"Who's that?" he asked Jake.

"Oh, her? That's Tomoko. Japanese. She's in the premium dorm, I think. Keeps to herself."

Connor watched her for a moment. She moved the camera with an economy of motion that suggested thousands of hours of practice -- no wasted gestures, no fumbling with settings, just the smooth pivot of someone who saw the world through a viewfinder as naturally as breathing.

He walked over, beer in hand, smile deployed.

"Hey! I'm Connor. You're Tomoko, yeah?"

She lowered the camera. Her eyes were dark, steady, weighted -- the eyes of someone who had learned to see things other people chose not to see.

"Yes."

"Sick camera. You a photographer?"

"Photojournalist."

"Oh, rad. Like, for a magazine?"

"Sometimes."

Connor waited for her to elaborate. She didn't.

"Cool, well -- we're all heading out to Changkat tonight. You should come. Felix is organizing it. He knows all the spots."

At the name Felix, something shifted in her expression. Not quite a flinch. More like a door closing behind a window -- the light changed but you couldn't say exactly how.

"The German," she said.

"Yeah. You've met him?"

"Briefly."

"He's a legend. The guy knows everyone in KL."

Tomoko looked at him with an expression he couldn't read. "Have a good night, Connor."

She raised the camera back to her eye and turned toward the skyline. Connor stood there for a moment, dismissed, then walked back to the group with a shrug.

"She's a bit intense," he told Jake.

"Right? I tried to talk to her about surfing and she just, like, looked at me."

*Unfriendly,* Connor decided, and the word slotted neatly into his mental filing system. Friendly. Unfriendly. Useful. Not useful. Fun. Not fun. Tomoko: not fun. He put her away and opened another beer.

Felix arrived at nine o'clock, and it was like the volume on the rooftop went up.

He came through the access door with a bottle of duty-free Hendrick's gin in one hand and a bag of limes in the other, and the rooftop rearranged itself around him like metal filings around a magnet. White linen shirt that should have been wrinkled but wasn't. Dark linen shorts. Leather sandals. When the red lantern light hit the thin scar on his left eyebrow it gave him the faintest suggestion of danger, which is to say, exactly the right amount.

"Good evening, everyone," Felix said, and he said it the way he said everything -- calmly, warmly, with the soft German accent rounding the consonants into something musical. "Gin and tonics on me. Who has ice?"

Nobody had ice. This didn't matter. Felix produced a plastic bag of ice cubes from behind his back like a stage magician and the rooftop erupted -- the full-throated cheer of people who are already two beers in and have just been promised free spirits.

He made the drinks himself, slicing limes with a Swiss Army knife, remembering everyone's name as he handed them their glasses. "Priya, a little less tonic? Jake, extra lime for you. Astrid, Erik -- skol. Min-ho, I added some cucumber."

*He remembers everything,* Connor thought. *Everyone's name, everyone's preference. That's a superpower.*

When Felix reached Connor, he poured a generous gin with the ease of a man who had never checked a price tag. "Connor. Ready for tonight?"

"Born ready, mate."

"I know a place on Changkat. Rooftop bar, fourth floor, best view of the city. The owner owes me a favor." He said this casually, like it was nothing, like everyone had bar owners in Kuala Lumpur who owed them favors. "We start there. Then we see where the night takes us."

"That's the attitude."

Felix's smile widened fractionally. He leaned in, lowered his voice, though not low enough that it felt secretive -- just intimate. "I want you to have a good night, Connor. You deserve it. You've been working hard."

Connor had not been working hard at anything, unless drinking Tiger beers and filming Instagram stories qualified. But the flattery landed like a warm hand on his shoulder, and he felt -- genuinely felt -- that Felix saw something in him that other people missed. Something worth investing in.

From the far side of the rooftop, Tomoko watched over the top of her camera. The shutter clicked once, twice, and then she lowered the lens and watched with her own eyes. Her expression was unreadable.

Priya, near the clothesline, watched Felix too. She watched the way he distributed drinks and attention with the precision of someone dealing cards, the way each person leaned toward him, postures opening like flowers. She felt something she couldn't quite name: not jealousy, not suspicion exactly, but a dissonance, like a note played slightly flat in an otherwise perfect chord. Real generosity has friction -- awkwardness, miscalculation. Felix never miscalculated. Felix was frictionless.

She pushed her glasses up and took a sip of her drink, which was, in fact, exactly how she liked it.

---

Changkat Bukit Bintang hit Connor's senses like a slap.

The nightlife strip ran uphill through a corridor of converted shophouses, each one bleeding light and noise into the tropical night. Neon signs -- blue, pink, green, electric orange -- competed along facades draped with string lights. Bass lines from competing sound systems collided in the air, a dissonant heartbeat you felt in your sternum before you heard it. The smell was cocktail garnish and charcoal satay smoke and perfume and sweat. Bodies everywhere -- tourists, locals, expats -- all flowing in the same direction: further in, deeper, louder.

"This," Connor said, walking backward so he could film the street on his phone, "is absolutely mental."

He was already recording. The Instagram story would be iconic: neon-soaked street, bass thumping, Connor's face appearing in frame with a grin that said *are you seeing this?* He added a location tag and a caption: "Tuesday night in KL hits different." He didn't mention it was Wednesday.

Felix led them up the street like a man who owned it, past the first three bars without a glance, past the touts offering two-for-one cocktails, past a bouncer at a reggae bar who called out "Welcome, welcome!" to anyone with a pulse. At a narrow doorway between a Thai restaurant and a cocktail bar, he spoke to a man in a black polo shirt. The man looked at Felix, nodded, and unclipped the velvet rope.

"VIP entrance," Felix said. "Elevator to the roof."

They arrived at a rooftop bar that was everything The Lantern's rooftop was not. Real furniture. Actual cocktails. A DJ playing deep house. The Petronas Towers close enough that their spire-points seemed to scratch the low clouds, lit from within like the bones of something luminous.

"Oh my God," Priya said, and she said it without irony.

Felix guided them to the best table and ordered a round. The cocktails arrived with elaborate garnishes: kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass stalks, thin slices of torch ginger flower. This was RM45 a drink. Connor did the math and then immediately stopped doing the math.

"To the crew," Felix said, raising his glass. The group repeated it: the crew. Connor clinked his glass against Priya's and caught her eye and felt the night rearrange itself around them.

They moved through Changkat the way Felix moved through everything: smoothly, inevitably. A cocktail bar in a converted colonial house. A live music venue where a Filipino cover band played "Hotel California" with more conviction than the Eagles ever had. A hole-in-the-wall club where the DJ played Afrobeats and the dance floor was so packed you moved by consensus rather than choice.

At each stop, Felix knew someone. The bartender at the cocktail bar -- "Felix! Long time, brother!" -- poured extra-strong drinks and waved away his money (Felix left a crisp RM50 note under his glass anyway, precise and uncreased). The doorman at the club put them at the front of the line with a handshake that lingered. A waitress at the live music venue brought complimentary satay and whispered something in Felix's ear that made him smile.

Connor noticed. He noticed Felix paid for everything in cash -- crisp ringgit notes in denominations that suggested either a very good ATM or a very different source. Never a card. Never a bill. Never a hesitation. The man moved through the financial world the way water moves through rock: around every obstacle, leaving no trace.

*Where does his money come from?*

The thought surfaced and submerged, drowned by the next drink, the bass drop, Jake attempting to moonwalk and wiping out into a group of German tourists who turned out to be from Felix's hometown and suddenly there were shots being ordered and Connor was filming it all, phone held high, capturing chaos for the grid.

His Instagram story by midnight was nine slides long. A neon sign. A cocktail close-up. Connor and Jake with their arms around each other, mouths open in a synchronised shout. The Petronas Towers from the rooftop bar. A blurred dance floor. Each one captioned with performative casualness: "KL nightlife is no joke," "This crew tho," "If you know, you know."

Nobody back home knew. That was the point. The stories existed to create envy in people who would never be here, doing this, living like this. Connor was curating a life, frame by frame, and the fact that he was three months behind on his credit card and his "digital nomad" income last month totaled $47 AUD was a detail that existed in a different file, one he kept closed.

Priya loosened up around the third bar. The gin had softened the edges of her caution and the music had found its way past her resistance. She danced -- self-conscious at first, then less so, then not at all. On the packed floor of the Afrobeats club she moved with a natural rhythm that surprised Connor, and when he danced toward her she didn't move away. They danced together in the crush of bodies, laughing at nothing, at the absurdity of being here, at the heat that prickled their skin, at the sheer volume of being alive in a city that didn't know their names.

There was a moment -- brief, genuine -- where their faces were close and the laughter stopped and something else was there. Not lust, not yet, but recognition. Priya's eyes behind her glasses, dark and clear and seeing him.

Then Jake crashed between them with a bucket of beer from a street vendor and the moment dissolved, and Connor thought: *This is the content. This is the story I came here to live.*

At the bar, Felix watched them. His gin and tonic was barely touched. His face, when the strobe lights caught it, was difficult to categorize. Not happiness, though it neighbored happiness. Not predatory, though it bordered on assessment. The expression of a chess player watching pieces move to positions he'd anticipated three moves ago.

He caught the bartender's eye. Another round. The crisp RM50 notes appeared and disappeared.

---

By one-thirty, Connor had spent RM250.

He knew this because he'd checked his banking app in the bathroom of the third or fourth bar, forehead against cool tile while the room performed a slow rotation around him. The number was smaller than it should have been, and for a moment the pleasant fog of alcohol thinned and he saw the mathematics of his life with horrible clarity.

Current balance: RM1,847. Roughly $580 AUD. His parents' next deposit was ten days away. At this rate he'd be broke in less than two weeks.

He closed the app. Opened Instagram. Forty-three likes on his stories. Three new followers, two of them bots.

*She'll be right. Something will come up.*

The night fractured after two AM. The Swedes peeled away with polite European goodbyes, their arms around each other's waists. Min-ho had vanished into a group of Korean travelers. Jake was at the end of the bar, deep in conversation with a British girl named Gemma or Jemma who was traveling alone and had the bright, open face of someone who hadn't yet learned that Jake's stories about surfing Pipeline were exaggerated by a factor of roughly ten.

Priya had found Connor in the crowd, put her hand on his arm, leaned close to his ear: "I'm going. Early start. Don't do anything stupid." She'd lingered long enough for him to feel the warmth of her breath, the faint trace of her perfume cutting through the smoke and sweat, and then she was gone, and the space she'd occupied felt briefly colder.

Which left Connor and Felix.

They ended up at a rooftop bar four stories above Changkat, a place you had to know existed. Unmarked door, staircase that smelled of concrete dust. But the bar was open-air, low couches and candles in glass jars, the Petronas Towers close enough to see the skybridge connecting them, lit from within, a bridge between two pillars of money.

Felix ordered two whiskeys. They arrived in heavy tumblers with a single ice sphere.

"You had a good night, Connor," Felix said. It wasn't a question.

"Mate, that was one of the best nights of my life. And I've had some big ones. There was this one time in Koh Phangan--"

"But you're not really here for parties, are you?"

Connor paused, his drink halfway to his mouth. "What do you mean?"

Felix gazed out at the towers. "Most backpackers come to Asia to escape," he said. "But they bring their whole world with them. Their rules. Their fears. Their need to turn everything into a photograph." He glanced at Connor's phone. "They never actually leave home."

"I mean, yeah. I've seen that. Definitely."

"The ones who sit in Western cafes, eating Western food, talking to other Western people. They fly ten thousand kilometers to re-create the life they had. They change the backdrop but they keep the frame."

Connor nodded, though he wasn't entirely sure which side of that equation he was on. "Totally. That's what I always say."

Felix turned to look at him. The scar on his eyebrow caught the light. "You're different, Connor. You're adaptable. Most people say they want freedom but what they really want is permission. You don't need that. I noticed it the first night we talked."

The whiskey was warm in Connor's chest and the compliment was warmer. Felix had a way of articulating things Connor felt about himself but couldn't quite express. It was like having a mirror that showed not your reflection but your best self.

"I've been on the road for four years," Connor said. "Not a gap year. Four actual years. The only way to do it is to let go. Stop planning. Just let the next thing happen."

"Exactly." Felix's voice was soft. "And the next thing always happens, doesn't it?"

"Always."

They drank. The city below was a river of light and exhaust and the distant sound of a hundred different musics playing simultaneously. Somewhere a motorcycle engine whined. A siren rose and fell. The humidity sat on Connor's skin like a second shirt.

"I should head back," Connor said, and reached for his phone. He opened the banking app out of the automatic masochism of someone who already knew what the number would say. The screen glowed in the dark. The number stared at him.

RM1,847. And he'd been drinking since eight.

No. He refreshed. RM1,597. The pending transactions had posted. RM250 gone in a single night. A night that had felt like freedom and looked, on his banking app, like a countdown.

He must have made a face, because Felix said: "Money problems?"

Connor locked his phone. "Nah. All good, mate. Just -- doing the maths."

"The maths are never kind at this hour."

"She'll be right. I've got some freelance stuff coming in."

He didn't have any freelance stuff coming in. His one client -- a surf shop in Torquay that paid him $150 a month to manage their Instagram -- had emailed last week asking if he could "do more for the same rate." He hadn't replied. He wasn't going to reply.

Felix sipped his whiskey. He let the silence do its work -- and Felix was good at silence, Connor noticed, the way some people are good at music. He wielded it. The candle between them flickered in a breeze that carried the smell of charcoal and jasmine from the street below.

"I meant what I said about the logistics work," Felix said, his tone conversational, the same tone he'd use to recommend a restaurant. "RM200 for twenty minutes. That was a real offer, Connor."

"Yeah, no, I remember. What exactly--"

"Simple courier work. Import consulting. Documents, electronics samples. I have a driver but some contacts prefer a friendly face." He smiled. "You have a very friendly face."

"RM200 for twenty minutes."

"Sometimes less. You could do it every day. That's twelve hundred a week, more than your hostel costs."

The numbers arranged themselves with the seductive clarity of alcohol and desperation. RM1,200 a week. More than his parents sent him monthly. Staying in KL for months. Never checking his banking app at two AM and feeling the floor tilt.

"I mean," Connor said, "that sounds..."

"Think about it." Felix stood, left two RM50 notes on the table -- more than the bill required -- and buttoned his linen shirt at the cuff with the precision of a man who attended to details the way other people attended to breathing. "No pressure. But you know where to find me."

He offered his hand. Connor shook it. Felix's grip was dry and firm and lasted exactly the right amount of time.

"Good night, Connor."

"Night, mate."

Felix left. Connor finished his whiskey and watched the Petronas Towers standing in the dark like a challenge, or a promise, or a headstone for something that hadn't died yet.

---

The common room of The Lantern Hostel at three AM was a place of residual warmth and abandoned intention. Mismatched furniture casting crooked shadows under the single fluorescent tube Razak kept on all night. The bookshelf of abandoned novels -- dog-eared Lonely Planets, water-damaged thrillers, a copy of *Shantaram* so swollen with humidity it looked pregnant. The ancient Dell humming in the corner like something dreaming.

Tomoko Sato sat cross-legged on the couch with her laptop, uploading photographs. The Nikon D850's SD card held 847 images, already culled to sixty-three in her head. Tomoko did not take photographs indiscriminately. Every frame was a decision.

The images scrolled: the rooftop, the lantern glow, Changkat in neon excess. Good images. Professional. The kind that would make her editor at The Guardian nod.

But she wasn't looking for those.

She scrolled past landscapes and street scenes until she found the sequence from the first bar. She'd been at the edge of the group, camera on the table, shooting through the gap between a candle and a drink menu.

She found the frame.

Felix and Connor. Felix's hand on Connor's shoulder -- a casual gesture, the kind that said *I'm your friend.* But to Tomoko's eye, not casual at all. Guiding. Directing. The way a handler touches an asset.

In the foreground, Connor leaned in, mouth open, his expression the open enthusiasm of a man who has found his favourite person in the room. Over Connor's shoulder, Felix was looking at him. And the expression on Felix's face was not friendship.

It was assessment.

The clinical attention of someone evaluating a tool. What is this person worth? What can this person carry? How far can this person be pushed before they break?

Tomoko zoomed in. Felix's eyes, caught by strobe light, were perfectly steady. No alcohol blur. Stone sober in a bar full of drunk people, watching Connor the way a spider watches a fly that has just touched the web.

She saved the photo to a separate folder on her desktop. The folder was labeled, in Japanese, with two characters that translated roughly to "watch closely." She opened a text file inside the folder. Three entries already -- notes from previous nights, logged with the precision of field reportage.

She typed:

*Night 4. The German. Changkat. Cash only, high denominations. Knows staff at multiple venues. Avoids cameras. Hand-on-shoulder with the Australian -- guided conversation, controlled body language. Expression when unobserved: evaluative, not social.*

She paused. Added:

*The Australian trusts him completely.*

She closed the laptop. Through the air well, the hostel breathed -- creaking wood, a cough from an upper-floor dorm.

She thought about saying something to Connor. She could show him the photograph. She could say: look at the way this man looks at you. Look at his eyes. But she had tried, on the rooftop, in the way she tried things -- economically, without force. She'd offered a door. He'd walked away and called her unfriendly, or something equivalent. She'd heard the dismissal in his tone the way she heard most things people tried to hide: clearly.

Tomoko had been a journalist long enough to know that people who don't want to see will not be shown. They will look at evidence and see coincidence. They will look at a man measuring them for a coffin and see a friend buying drinks.

She saved the file. Created a backup on her phone.

Then she went to bed.

---

Dorm 3 was dark and close and smelled of Tiger Balm and damp and the particular musk of six strangers sleeping in a room designed for two. The ceiling fan turned with its metronomic click -- *tick, tick, tick* -- stirring the air without cooling it. Through the narrow opening to the air well, the sounds of KL filtered in as a distant murmur: the city's breathing, its three AM pulse.

Connor climbed into Bed 7 with the careful deliberation of a man drunker than he wants to admit. Flip-flops and singlet removed; the board shorts stayed because the coordination required exceeded his operational capacity. The thin mattress -- vinyl-covered foam, body-temperature, sticky against his bare back -- received him with indifferent resignation.

The room spun. Not violently, not the full carousel of real drunkenness, but the slow tilt of a ship in a mild swell. He closed his eyes and opened them again. The underside of the bunk above him was covered in stickers -- surf brands, band logos, a peeling Che Guevara, a scratched-off Hostelworld badge. In the dark they were just shapes, hieroglyphics left by previous occupants in a language of allegiance and memory.

*Tick, tick, tick.* The ceiling fan.

He picked up his phone. The screen brightness hit his eyes like a flash and he fumbled to dim it. Three seventeen AM. A WhatsApp from Jake: "dude gemma is so cool we're at some after party where are you." A missed call from his sister Megan. He would not return it.

He opened his banking app.

RM1,597.

The number sat on the screen with the blunt authority of a verdict. He stared at it. Eleven days until his parents' deposit. Eleven days of hostel fees (RM495), food (RM300 minimum, more if he kept eating out), transport, water, the occasional beer. He was RM200 short at a minimum, and that was if he ate instant noodles and drank nothing and went nowhere and became, effectively, the kind of traveler he despised: the one counting coins and choosing between lunch and a museum ticket.

He thought about Felix's offer.

RM200. Twenty minutes. The framing made sense in the way things make sense at three AM when you're drunk and broke and the alternative is admitting that the entire architecture of your life is built on parental subsidy and willful ignorance.

He could do that every day and never worry about money again. He could stay in KL for months. Self-funded, self-sufficient, free in the way that mattered. Free in the way that his parents' monthly deposit, with its invisible string of guilt, could never make him.

He opened WhatsApp. Found Felix's name. Typed:

*That logistics thing.*

Three dots blinked. The cursor waited.

He looked at the words. They sat in the text field like a dare.

It was an opening, not a commitment. He could send it and see what Felix said and then decide. No pressure. Just information gathering. The kind of thing a smart person would do.

He put his phone down.

He picked it up again.

*That logistics thing.*

His thumb hovered over the send arrow. The blue triangle pointed right, pointing forward, pointing toward something that had no name yet but already had momentum.

He didn't send it.

But he didn't delete it either.

He put the phone face-down on the mattress. His hand found the edge of his travel towel, bunched at the foot of the bed -- the bright blue Sea to Summit microfiber he'd bought four years ago on Elizabeth Street, Melbourne, two days before his first flight to Bali. Twelve countries. It smelled of sunscreen and the South China Sea. He pulled it over his chest like a thin, inadequate blanket.

The ceiling fan clicked. *Tick, tick, tick.*

Through the air well, Kuala Lumpur hummed: distant, patient, indifferent. A city that would not notice if Connor James Briggs stayed or left or lived or died.

He closed his eyes. The room swayed. The unsent message waited.

The decision was already made. He just hadn't admitted it yet.
# Chapter 5: Content Creator

---

The laptop screen had gone to sleep again. Connor tapped the trackpad, watched the login prompt bloom to life, and typed his password -- *balivibes69* -- with the grim efficiency of a man performing surgery on his own ambitions. The screen unlocked to reveal exactly what he'd left twenty minutes ago: an open Google Doc with three lines of text, an Instagram scheduling dashboard, and seventeen browser tabs he would never revisit.

The cafe was called Grind Culture. Of course it was. It occupied the ground floor of a pre-war shophouse on Jalan Sultan, two streets over from The Lantern, and it had been gutted and rebuilt in the image of every third-wave coffee temple from Brooklyn to Byron Bay. Exposed brick. Edison bulbs. A chalkboard menu in deliberately imperfect handwriting. Pour-over stations gleaming like laboratory equipment. The whole place smelled of single-origin Sumatran and the unspoken agreement that everyone here was doing something important on their MacBooks.

He adjusted his man-bun, sipped his flat white -- RM14, which his brain helpfully converted to about five Australian dollars, which his bank balance helpfully pointed out he didn't have -- and surveyed the room.

Six other laptops open. Three looked like genuine developers, deep in code, headphones on, the thousand-yard stare of people wrestling with something that would actually compile. One was a girl with a ring light clipped to her screen, recording a whispered podcast into her AirPods. One was typing what appeared to be an actual manuscript. And one -- the only one who met Connor's gaze -- was watching a cooking video with the sound off.

*Probably actually working*, Connor thought, casting his eyes over the developers. *Mugs.*

He returned to the Google Doc. The three lines read:

> Hey legends!! Your weekend vibes are about to get INSANE. New boards dropping next week from our mates at Pacific Soul -- crafted by shapers who live and breathe the Byron break. Link in bio for 10% off. Catch the wave or watch it from shore. Your call.

That was Caption One. For Pacific Soul Surf Co. of Byron Bay, New South Wales, Australia. His one client. His single, solitary source of earned income. One hundred and fifty American dollars a month for three Instagram posts a week, scheduled in advance, each one requiring approximately four minutes of effort and a stock photo Connor pulled from Unsplash with "surf lifestyle" in the search bar.

He'd told Pacific Soul he was a "content strategist" with "a network of over five thousand engaged followers." Three lies wrapped in marketing jargon, offered with a confidence that functioned exactly like competence until someone checked. No one ever checked. The whole infrastructure ran on trust and vibes.

Connor copied Caption One into the scheduling dashboard, assigned it a stock photo of a blonde woman holding a surfboard at sunset, and set the publish time for 7 AM AEST.

Caption Two came faster:

> Monday doesn't have to be a wipeout. Grab your board, grab your crew, and ride into the new week like you mean it. Pacific Soul -- where every day is a swell day. #surflife #byronbay #pacificsoul #mondaymotivation

*Where every day is a swell day.* Christ. He was writing puns for a surf shop while the humidity of equatorial Southeast Asia liquefied his will to live. But it was technically work, in a technical sense, if you squinted.

Caption Three: something about life being too short, riding bad boards, chasing dreams. He didn't think about it. He published all three, closed the tab, and felt the warm glow of accomplishment that a man feels when he has performed the absolute minimum required to justify his existence. Three captions. Fifteen minutes. That was his work for the day.

Now came the real work. The Work of Connor.

He turned the laptop sideways, pulled his phone from his pocket, and photographed his flat white from above. Not right. The foam pattern -- some vaguely leaf-shaped thing the barista had scratched out -- was off-centre in the frame. He adjusted the cup a quarter turn. Shot again. Better. But the light was wrong. He shifted the laptop to create a negative space in the background, a clean wooden surface with the cafe's logo just visible on a napkin. Third shot.

That was the one.

He opened VSCO, applied a preset -- *C1, always C1, the thinking man's filter* -- and pulled the exposure up a touch. Warmed the tones. The flat white now looked like an artifact from a better life than the one he was actually living. He switched to Instagram, typed a caption:

> Office for the day. No walls, no ceiling, no limits. Just me, my laptop, and the best flat white in KL. This is what they don't tell you about the digital nomad life -- every day is different, every cafe is a new perspective.
>
> #digitalnomad #remotework #laptoplifestyle #kualalumpur #KL #coffeeshop #livingmybestlife #nooffice #workfromanywhere #flatwhite #cafecrawl #contentcreator

Twelve hashtags. Connor considered this restrained. He'd read somewhere that the algorithm preferred under fifteen. He posted.

Then he sat back and watched the likes trickle in. One. Two. A pause. Three. The dopamine was barely perceptible, the serotonin equivalent of licking the foil lid of a yoghurt container. But it was something. A pulse. A proof of life.

He checked his follower count: 4,207. Down three from yesterday. That was about five K, give or take. If anyone asked. Some of them were bots, and some of them were his mum's friends, and some of them were other digital nomads following him purely so he'd follow back, a daisy chain of mutual delusion stretching around the globe. But five K sounded like a man with a brand.

He opened LinkedIn on a whim. Scrolled past posts from people his age in Melbourne -- someone promoted to Associate Director, someone launching a startup, a girl from school celebrating her third anniversary at Google. Connor's own profile listed him as "Digital Nomad | Content Strategist | Global Citizen" and hadn't been updated in eleven months. He began drafting a thought-leadership post:

> The future of remote work isn't an office without walls. It's a mindset without borders. For the last four years, I've been living proof that you don't need a corner office or a zip code to build something meaningful. You just need wifi, a willingness to embrace uncertainty, and the

He stopped. The sentence had nowhere to go. He didn't know what you needed. He didn't know if he'd built anything meaningful. He didn't even know what the wifi password was this week. He closed LinkedIn and reopened Instagram and scrolled through other people's curated lives until the flat white went cold and the guilt became load-bearing.

---

The walk back to The Lantern took four minutes down Jalan Sultan to Petaling Street, past the textile shops and the traditional medicine stores. The heat had settled into its midday configuration -- not the morning heat, which was merely uncomfortable, but the lunchtime heat, which was a statement of intent. His singlet was soaked through before he'd gone half a block.

He passed Wei's shop. Phone repairs. A narrow glass frontage crammed with charging cables and screen protectors and handwritten signs in Mandarin and English: REPAIR 30 MIN, UNLOCK ANY PHONE, WE FIX WATER DAMAGE. A man sat behind the counter, head down, soldering something under a magnifying lamp. Connor walked past it the way he walked past everything in KL that didn't photograph well: without seeing it.

Back at the hostel, Connor climbed the narrow staircase to Dorm 3, the third step squeaking under his flip-flop, and dropped onto Bed 7. The ceiling fan rotated above him with the weary commitment of something that had given up on making a difference but hadn't technically stopped trying.

He opened his banking app.

The number sat there on the screen, small and plain and devastating. RM 847.23. He stared at it the way a man stares at a medical result that confirms his suspicions. Then he closed the app. Then he opened it again, as if the number might have changed in the interim -- a digital miracle, a banking glitch in his favour, a misplaced decimal that would reveal he actually had RM 8,472.30 and everything was fine.

RM 847.23.

His parents' next deposit was ten days away. Two thousand Australian dollars, which converted to roughly RM 5,800 at current rates. That money would land in his account on the twenty-first and he would feel the hot relief of reprieve, the way a drowning man feels when the wave recedes and leaves him gasping on the sand. But the twenty-first was ten days away. And RM 847 divided by ten days was RM 84.70 per day.

Connor did the maths, which was not a thing Connor typically did, which was itself a measure of how serious this had become. RM 84.70 a day. His hostel bed was RM 35. That left RM 49.70 for food, transport, and everything else.

RM 49.70 per day was survivable if he ate exclusively at hawker stalls. Nasi lemak from the aunty on Jalan Tun H.S. Lee, RM 5. Roti canai from the mamak stall on the corner, RM 2.50. Rice and a curry from any of the twenty places within stumbling distance of The Lantern, RM 8. He could eat three meals a day for under RM 20 if he abandoned every pretence of the lifestyle he photographed for Instagram.

No more RM 14 flat whites at Grind Culture. No more RM 18 avocado toast. No more RM 30 cocktails at the rooftop bar on Changkat where Felix had taken them two nights ago. No going out. The thought arrived with the weight of a prison sentence -- sitting in the hostel every evening while everyone else disappeared into the neon maze of the city and came back at 2 AM with stories and hangovers and the flushed contentment of people who could afford to be young.

Connor rolled over on the thin mattress and considered his options. There were four. There were always four.

Option A: Ask his parents for more money. His thumb hovered over his mother's contact. He could hear the conversation already. "Of course, darling, I'll talk to your father." And she would. And David Briggs would transfer the money, because David Briggs loved his son in the helpless, exasperated way of a man who understood that cutting the cord would require a conversation neither of them was ready for. But Megan would find out. Megan always found out. His sister had a forensic accountant's attention to the family finances and a prosecutor's enthusiasm for cross-examination. "He's twenty-seven, Mum. I was supporting myself at twenty-three. He's taking the piss." Connor could hear Megan's voice as clearly as if she were in the dorm. He put his phone down.

Option B: Get a real remote job. He'd considered this before, usually at 3 AM after three beers. He would learn web development. Or graphic design. Or real copywriting. He'd sign up for a course, build a portfolio, join the ranks of the genuinely location-independent.

The problem was sequential. To get a remote job, he needed a portfolio. To build a portfolio, he needed skills. To acquire skills, he needed discipline. And discipline was the one resource Connor had never possessed, not in twenty-seven years of life.

Option C: Go home.

The thought entered his mind the way a kidney stone enters the urinary tract -- unwelcome, excruciating, and impossible to ignore once it had arrived. Go home. Back to Melbourne. Back to Hawthorn. Back to his old bedroom with the posters of bands he didn't listen to anymore, back to his father's careful questions about "next steps," back to the brunch circuit with his parents' friends asking "So what are you up to now, Connor?" with the gentle concern of people addressing a terminal patient. Back to watching Megan and his mates continue their march through the milestones of adult life -- promotions, mortgages, engagements, babies -- while he stood on the platform wondering which train he was supposed to catch.

Going home meant admitting that the last four years had been an extended holiday funded by his parents. Going home meant admitting that "digital nomad" was a costume, not an identity.

The thought was physically revolting, like swallowing broken glass. He felt his chest tighten and his jaw clench, and he knew, with the certainty of a man who has confused cowardice for freedom, that he would rather starve in Southeast Asia than prosper in Melbourne.

Which left Option D.

Felix's offer. RM 200 for twenty minutes. Logistics. He'd done it twice already -- the envelope, the package to Brickfields -- and both times had been smooth, easy, weightless. If he did it once a day, that was RM 6,000 a month. More than his parents gave him. Enough to stay. Enough to live, properly, the way he pretended to on Instagram. Enough to buy Priya dinner at that Japanese place she'd mentioned.

He caught himself calculating. The numbers tumbled through his mind with the frictionless ease of a slot machine. RM 200 a day, seven days a week, RM 1,400 a week, enough for a private room, enough for flights to the next country, enough for --

He put his phone face-down on the mattress. The fan turned above him. Someone in the next dorm was playing lo-fi beats from a tinny speaker, the universal soundtrack of people pretending to be relaxed.

*She'll be right*, Connor thought. Then, less certainly: *She'll be right.*

He ordered another coffee at Grind Culture. RM 14. Because the cafe had aircon and the alternative was the hostel's common room, where the ceiling fan stirred the humidity into a warm soup. The barista made a better leaf pattern this time. Connor didn't photograph it. Progress, or exhaustion. Hard to tell.

---

Priya was already at the Pasar Seni LRT station when Connor arrived, forty minutes late, wearing the same board shorts from yesterday and a singlet that said GOOD VIBES ONLY in a font that suggested the vibes were, in fact, compulsory.

"You're late," she said, pushing her round glasses up her nose in the way that Connor found annoyingly endearing.

"I'm on island time."

"We're not on an island."

"It's a state of mind, Priya."

She looked at him with the expression she reserved for his more philosophical contributions -- part amusement, part despair, the face of a woman who was attracted to a man she couldn't fully respect and was negotiating the distance between the two.

"Come on," she said. "It's this way."

The train to Batu Caves took thirty minutes. Connor had never heard of the place until Priya mentioned it that morning in the hostel kitchen, while he was failing to operate the rice cooker and she was reading her battered Lonely Planet.

"Hindu temple complex in a limestone cave. Two hundred and seventy-two steps. Monkeys. A massive golden statue."

"Is there wifi?"

"Connor."

"Joking. Mostly. Yeah, sounds sick. Let's do it."

He'd agreed partly because she'd asked, and partly because he had nothing else to do that didn't cost money, and partly because there was a quality to Priya's enthusiasm that made resistance feel churlish.

The train deposited them at a station that opened directly onto the base of the caves, and Connor's first thought was that his phone camera was not going to be enough for this.

The limestone cliff rose up from the earth like the jawbone of something impossibly ancient, grey-white and sheer, jungle-draped at its crown. At its base, a golden statue stood guard -- Lord Murugan, Priya told him, the Hindu god of war, forty-two metres tall, its surface blazing in the afternoon sun so intensely that Connor had to squint.

"Forty-two metres," Priya said, tilting her head back. "Tallest Murugan statue in the world. Three hundred litres of gold paint."

"Where do you even buy three hundred litres of gold paint?"

She laughed. She had a good laugh -- unstudied, a little too loud, the laugh of someone who hadn't yet learned to perform her own amusement. He found himself smiling back in a way that felt genuine and slightly dangerous.

The 272 steps were painted in the colours of a rainbow -- red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet, repeating in bands up the face of the cliff, as though someone had dropped a paintbox from the top and let gravity do the work. Tourists and pilgrims streamed up and down in a mixed current of devotion and breathlessness, pausing to photograph each other, to pray, to gasp, to buy water from the vendors stationed at strategic intervals like aid stations on a marathon course.

The monkeys were everywhere. Long-tailed macaques with the confidence of old-money aristocrats and the morals of pickpockets, perched on railings and tourists' shoulders, watching the procession with amber eyes that missed nothing. Connor saw one steal a water bottle from an elderly woman's bag with surgical precision. Another sat on the rainbow steps eating a mango, regarding the humans below with the tolerant contempt of a creature that had never needed to invent the concept of a job.

"Don't show them your phone," Priya warned, grabbing his wrist as he raised it for a photo. "They'll take it."

"What, the monkeys?"

"They grab shiny things. There are signs everywhere, Connor."

There were signs everywhere. Connor hadn't read them.

They climbed. The heat was a living thing on the exposed staircase -- direct equatorial sun on painted concrete, no shade until the cave mouth above. Connor's flip-flops slapped on the steps.
