Priya, in sensible trainers, kept a steady pace, her braid swinging against her back like a metronome. He watched her climb and thought about things he hadn't thought about in a while -- not sex, which he thought about constantly, but something quieter. Something that didn't have a hashtag.

The cave mouth swallowed them like a throat.

Inside, the temperature dropped -- the limestone breathing its stored chill into the trapped air. The cavern opened up and Connor stopped walking because his brain needed a moment to accommodate the scale. The cave chamber was the size of a cathedral, the ceiling a hundred feet overhead, stalactites hanging like the pipes of an organ, light pouring in through gaps in the rock in dusty golden shafts that illuminated a Hindu shrine -- draped in garlands of marigolds and jasmine, attended by priests in white, surrounded by incense smoke and the quiet murmur of prayer.

"Bloody hell," Connor said.

Priya didn't correct his language. She was looking up, her glasses reflecting the shafts of light, and her face had the openness of someone standing in the presence of something they took seriously.

They sat on a low wall at the edge of the chamber. Below them, the stairs cascaded down to the green suburban sprawl of Selangor. Above them, the cave ceiling dripped with mineral deposits that had taken a hundred million years to form. The air smelled of wet stone and incense and the faint green rot of jungle. A priest chanted somewhere nearby, the words rising and falling in a cadence that felt older than the rock itself.

Connor's phone was in his pocket. He didn't take it out. He wasn't sure why. The light was good. The content was exceptional. But something about the cave -- the scale, the silence, the weight of all that time frozen in limestone -- made performing his own experience feel small.

"It's nice here," he said, and then winced at the inadequacy of the word.

"It's been a sacred site for thousands of years," Priya said. "People have been climbing those steps to pray for longer than most countries have existed."

"And now there's a bloke in board shorts sitting in the middle of it wondering if his flat white was tax-deductible."

She looked at him. "Is that what you're wondering?"

"No." He picked at the leather bracelet on his wrist. The full moon party bracelet. He'd had it so long it was part of his body now, a second skin he'd grown in Thailand and never shed. "I don't know what I'm wondering. That's sort of the problem."

Priya waited. She was good at waiting. It was a quality that Connor found unnerving -- the patience of someone who listened not to respond but to understand. Most people Connor talked to were just waiting for their turn to speak. Priya waited like a doctor waits for a patient to describe the pain.

"Everyone back home has a job," he said. "A mortgage. A plan. Megan -- my sister -- she's an accountant. My mates are buying houses. Dave got engaged last month. Simmo's having a kid. And I'm..." He gestured vaguely at the cave, at the stairs, at the general concept of Southeast Asia. "I'm here. I'm twenty-seven and I'm here."

"What's wrong with here?"

"Nothing. Everything. I don't know." He laughed, but there was nothing behind it. A laugh without fuel. "Here is amazing. Here is a cave with a temple in it and monkeys that steal your phone. Here is incredible. But here isn't a plan, is it? Here isn't something you put on a CV. Here isn't..." He trailed off. The incense drifted past them. A child ran by, chasing a macaque, both of them shrieking. "Here isn't real life. That's what my dad says, anyway. 'When are you going to start your real life, Con?' Like this is the rehearsal."

"Maybe it is," Priya said. Not unkindly.

"Yeah. Maybe." He stared at his hands. The compass tattoo on his inner forearm -- the one he'd got in Bali, the one that was supposed to mean *I go where the wind takes me* but actually meant *I was drunk in Kuta and the tattoo parlor was open* -- stared back at him, permanently pointing nowhere in particular. "The thing is, right, I left uni after a year. Business degree at Monash. Hated it. Not because it was hard -- I don't know if it was hard, I never actually tried. I just hated what it represented. The conveyor belt. Go to school, go to uni, get a graduate job, buy a house, retire, die. I thought, sod this, I'm going to live. And I did. For four years I've lived more than anyone I know."

"Have you, though?"

The question landed softly but precisely, like a surgeon's scalpel touching the nerve. Connor looked at her.

"What do you mean?"

"I mean, living more -- what does that look like? Not the Instagram version. The actual version. Are you learning things? Growing? Or are you just... in a different place, doing the same nothing?"

He should have been offended. A week ago he would have been. He would have hit her with the standard defence -- *at least I'm not a slave to the system, at least I'm experiencing the world, at least I'm not going to look back at forty and wish I'd taken the risk.* But something about the cave, or the incense, or the fact that he'd spent the morning photographing coffee he couldn't afford while calculating how many days he had until he was broke, had worn a hole in his armour, and Priya's question went right through it.

"I don't know," he said. And for once, he meant it.

They sat in the cave for a long time after that. The light shifted as the sun moved, the shafts turning from gold to amber to a deep honeyed orange that made the chamber look like the inside of a lantern. Priya told him about her degree -- the impossibility of fourth-year medicine, the patients she'd already lost on placement. She told him about her parents in Ealing -- her father the cardiologist at St Thomas' who was never home before nine, her mother who ran a GP practice in Wembley and had channelled her own medical ambition into Priya with a ferocity that was sometimes love and sometimes something harder.

"So you're running from something too," Connor said.

"I suppose. But I'm running toward something as well. The two aren't mutually exclusive."

He wanted to kiss her. The desire arrived fully formed, not as lust but as something closer to gratitude -- the need to close the gap between his loneliness and her attention. He leaned slightly. She was close enough that he could see the tiny scar on her upper lip. Her eyes, behind the round glasses, were dark and serious and very still.

He didn't kiss her. The moment held, balanced on its point like a coin on edge, and then a macaque screamed somewhere above them and a child laughed and the moment fell on its side and was just a moment, one of many, unremarkable except for the fact that Connor would remember it for the rest of his life, which would not be as long as either of them expected.

"We should head back," Priya said. "There's a thunderstorm coming."

She was right. By the time they descended the 272 rainbow steps, the sky had darkened to that particular equatorial purple that meant the clouds had been holding their breath all day and were about to exhale. The first drops fell as they reached the station, fat and warm. Then the sky opened and the world became water.

They stood under the station awning and watched the rain -- a wall of water descending vertically, turning the road into a river, the noise a sustained roar like standing inside a drum. The temperature dropped ten degrees in as many seconds, and the relief was physical, the city exhaling after a day of holding itself in.

"I like KL," Connor said, watching the rain.

"I know," Priya said. "That's what makes it dangerous for you."

He looked at her. She was looking at the rain.

---

Felix was on the rooftop when Connor got back to The Lantern that evening, sitting in one of the plastic chairs with a Tiger beer sweating in his hand, looking at the Petronas Towers as they did their nightly transformation from architectural achievement to jewellery. He looked, as always, like a man who never sweated, even in a city that was basically a sauna with traffic lights.

"Connor." He raised his beer. "Sit down."

Connor sat. Felix produced a second Tiger from somewhere -- he always had beer, the way other people always had anxiety -- and handed it over. Connor drank and felt the first sip spread through his chest like an argument he was losing.

"Good day?" Felix asked.

"Yeah. Went to Batu Caves with Priya."

"Ah, the caves. Beautiful place. I went when I first arrived in KL. Three years ago now." He sipped his beer. "You and Priya, you're spending a lot of time together."

"She's cool."

"She is cool. Smart, too. That's rare in hostels." Felix looked at him sideways, the scar on his eyebrow catching the last of the light. "She'll leave though. They always do, the smart ones. They have somewhere to go back to."

The sentence landed in the silence between them like a stone in still water. Connor felt the ripples but didn't acknowledge them. He drank his beer instead.

"How's the work going?" Felix asked. The question was casual. Everything Felix did was casual. It was his native register, the key in which he played every note.

"Yeah, good. Smashing it."

"The social media thing."

"Content strategy. Yeah."

"Pays well?"

Connor hesitated. The hesitation was microscopic -- a quarter-second pause before the breezy facade reassembled itself -- but Felix caught it. He'd been watching Connor for days, watching the way his eyes flickered to his phone screen and away, watching the quiet arithmetic of a man dividing dwindling resources against remaining time. Felix had seen this before. This was the shape of the trap -- not a trap he set, exactly, but a trap that already existed, a trap made of currency exchange rates and the cost of staying abroad. All Felix had to do was wait.

"It pays," Connor said. "Enough to keep me going."

"Going where?"

Connor laughed. "Here. There. Wherever." He drank. The beer was almost gone. The city spread out below them, a carpet of light, and above them the stars were appearing one by one through the gaps in the clouds, and the air smelled of rain and exhaust and the jasmine plant that someone had left in a pot by the rooftop railing.

"Can I be honest with you?" Felix said.

"Always, mate."

"The system is designed to make you go home." The speech was polished, rehearsed -- a script he'd delivered in hostels across Asia to broke, proud, afraid young travellers who looked exactly like Connor. "Rent. Bills. Visa restrictions. It's all engineered to force you back into the machine. But there are ways around it. If you know the right people."

He let the silence sit. A gecko chirped somewhere on the wall behind them, its small voice absurdly loud in the quiet.

"That offer's still open, mate," Felix said. "Nothing illegal. Just... logistics. Delivering documents, picking up packages. Import-export business. RM 200 per run, sometimes more."

The way he said it. That was the thing. The way he said *nothing illegal* with the relaxed authority of a man stating a fact. The way he said *RM 200* like it was a casual figure, not the difference between staying and going home, between freedom and defeat.

Connor thought about the maths. RM 200 a day. No more counting. No more photographing coffee he couldn't afford. RM 200 a day was staying. RM 200 a day was not going home.

"I'll think about it," Connor said.

"Of course." Felix leaned back. "No pressure. Ever. I just hate seeing good people go home because the system's rigged against them."

He finished his beer, stood, clapped Connor on the shoulder with the easy affection of a man who had just placed a bet and knew, with quiet certainty, that the house always wins.

"Goodnight, Connor. Think about it."

He disappeared down the staircase. Connor sat alone on the rooftop. The Petronas Towers watched him back.

---

The common room was nearly empty when Connor came downstairs. The red lanterns cast their permanent warm glow across the mismatched furniture and the bookshelf of abandoned novels.

Priya was in the corner, curled into an armchair, reading her Lonely Planet by the amber light of the nearest lantern. A pen in her hand, marking the margins. Planning. Always planning. She looked up when Connor entered and smiled, and he thought about the cave, the light through the gap in the rock, the conversation he couldn't quite believe had come out of his mouth.

He sat on the sofa across from her. Checked his phone. His Instagram post from that morning -- the flat white, the twelve hashtags, the lie about the digital nomad life -- had accumulated forty-one likes and two comments. One was from his mum: "Looks lovely darling! Stay safe xx." The other was from Pacific Soul's official account: a surfboard emoji, algorithmically deployed.

His phone buzzed.

A text from Felix: *No pressure. But if you're interested, I have something tomorrow. Easy. Quick. Think about it.*

Connor looked at the message. He looked at Priya, absorbed in her guidebook, lips moving slightly as she formed Malay words she was teaching herself. Because Priya learned the languages and read the signs and researched the laws. Because Priya did not assume that the world would rearrange itself around her convenience.

He thought about the afternoon. The vulnerability that had leaked out of him in the cave like blood from a wound he hadn't known he had. The way she'd looked at him when he said *I don't know* -- not with pity, not with judgment, but with something that felt like being seen for the first time in four years.

He thought about his bank balance. RM 847.23. Minus the two coffees today. Minus the train fare. Minus whatever tomorrow would cost. The number dropping like a countdown.

He texted Felix back: *Tell me more.*

He put his phone face-down on the armrest.

Priya looked up from her guidebook. "Everything okay?"

"Yeah," Connor said. He smiled -- the Instagram smile, confident, easy, bulletproof. The one he'd perfected over four years of pretending everything was fine.

"Everything's sweet."

Priya looked at him a moment longer. Then she nodded and returned to her book, and the pen resumed its quiet marking, and the red lanterns glowed, and somewhere outside a motorbike engine coughed to life and faded into the distance, and Connor sat in the warm amber light of The Lantern Hostel with his phone face-down and his future face-up and the word *logistics* turning over and over in his mind like a coin he couldn't stop flipping.

The smile didn't reach his eyes. But nobody was looking at his eyes. Nobody ever was.
# Chapter 6: The Envelope

Felix found him in the common room at half nine in the morning, which was early for Felix and obscene for Connor. The German was showered, shaved, and wearing a fresh linen shirt the colour of cream, looking less like a man who lived in a backpacker hostel and more like a man who had stepped out of a cologne advertisement to temporarily grace one with his presence. He was carrying two coffees from somewhere outside -- not the instant Nescafe that the hostel kitchen offered in a jar with a rusted lid, but real coffee, in paper cups with sleeves and lids and a logo that looked expensive. Felix always had good coffee. Felix always had good everything.

Connor was on the corduroy sofa, horizontal, one arm draped over his eyes. He was wearing the board shorts he'd slept in and a singlet with a faded Corona logo that had been through enough wash cycles to achieve a transparency that bordered on the conceptual. His phone was on his chest, playing a podcast about cryptocurrency investing he wasn't listening to.

"Morning," Felix said, and placed one of the coffees on the jigsaw table. The jigsaw had not progressed since Connor's arrival. The Petronas Towers remained headless.

Connor peeled his arm from his face and squinted up. "What time is it?"

"Nine-thirty."

"Jesus." He sat up, rubbed his face, and reached for the coffee. Flat white. Perfect. The caffeine began its repair work on the damage done by last night's beers -- four Tigers on the rooftop with Jake, followed by two rum-and-Cokes at a karaoke bar on Changkat where a group of Korean tourists had performed a genuinely moving rendition of "Bohemian Rhapsody."

"You're a legend," Connor said, meaning the coffee, meaning Felix, meaning the simple fact that someone in this city knew what he wanted before he did.

Felix sat in the armchair opposite, arranging himself with his usual studied ease. "How's the bank account?"

Connor's jaw worked. Seven hundred and twelve ringgit. Roughly two hundred and thirty Australian dollars. His parents' monthly deposit wasn't due for another eight days. He could survive on hostel noodles and free toast, but surviving wasn't the point. You couldn't curate the digital nomad life on seven hundred ringgit.

"It's fine," Connor said, because he said this about everything.

"I have something for you."

Felix reached into his canvas messenger bag and produced a Manila envelope. Standard size. Sealed. The kind of envelope you'd see in any office -- the universal container of boring adult things. He placed it on the jigsaw table.

"What's that?"

"A favour. A small one. Twenty minutes, maybe."

Connor picked it up. Light -- the weight of a few sheets of paper. He turned it over. No markings. The seal was firm, gummed flap and brass clasp.

"I do some work for an import-export company," Felix said. "Photography, mostly -- product shots for their catalogue. Boring stuff, but it pays. They need these documents delivered to one of their associates. Physical copies. Their courier service in KL is --" he grinned -- "*scheisse*. Unreliable. These are contracts, invoices, sensitive business documents. They need a human being to walk them from A to B."

"Why can't you do it?" Connor asked, and later -- much later -- he would recognise this as the only sensible question he'd asked in the entire conversation, and how easily Felix had navigated around it.

"I have a meeting. A gallery in Bangsar wants to exhibit some of my Malaysia series. The meeting is at eleven and I can't be in Bukit Bintang and Bangsar at the same time."

It made sense. That was the thing about Felix's explanations -- they always made sense. Not the aggressive sense of a lie trying too hard, but the easy sense of a truth that had nothing to prove.

"Two hundred ringgit," Felix said. "For twenty minutes of walking."

Connor did the math. Not the real math -- not *why would anyone pay two hundred ringgit for a twenty-minute walk*, or *what kind of business documents can't be emailed*. He did the other math. Two hundred ringgit was almost a third of his remaining funds, materialised from thin air. Four nights at the hostel. Ten plates of Mama Siti's nasi lemak. The difference between anxiety and comfort.

"Where am I going?"

"A cafe in Bukit Bintang. Brickhouse -- exposed brick, minimalist, charges fifteen ringgit for a flat white." He smiled. "You'll meet a man sitting alone. Blue polo shirt, reading a newspaper. Hand him the envelope. He won't say much. I'll send the money via GrabPay as soon as you confirm."

"That's it?"

"That's it."

Connor turned the envelope over. His thumb found the seal. He could open it. The thought arrived and departed in the same instant, the way a fish surfaces and vanishes -- visible for a fraction of a second, gone before the brain can form the word *fish*. He could open the envelope and make an informed decision about carrying it across the city for a man he'd known for six days, in a country where the drug laws were printed in red on signs the size of doors.

Connor did not open the envelope.

"One thing," Felix said, his voice shifting by a degree -- not colder, just more precise. "Don't open it. Sensitive business documents -- invoices, client details. Confidentiality is a big deal. If the seal is broken, they won't accept delivery and neither of us gets paid."

"Easy as," Connor said.

He put the envelope in the back pocket of his board shorts. Felix finished his coffee, stood, and adjusted his messenger bag.

"Text me when it's done." At the archway, he paused. "And Connor? Thanks, mate."

He said *mate* with the German accent, the *a* wider and flatter than an Australian would make it, and this small linguistic mimicry made the whole thing feel like a favour between friends.

Felix's footsteps climbed the narrow staircase -- the third step from the top squeaked -- and his door opened and closed with a soft click.

Connor sat in the common room with the envelope in his pocket and the morning light falling through the air well onto the mosaic tiles. From the kitchen, the clatter of Mama Siti's pans. The smell of coconut rice and sambal. He finished his coffee, checked his phone -- 10:07 -- and walked out into the heat.

---

The walk from Chinatown to Bukit Bintang was a transit through layers of Kuala Lumpur, each one thinner and more polished than the last, as if the city were shedding its history block by block and emerging into something chrome and air-conditioned and new.

Connor stepped out of the hostel's narrow door -- the phone repair shop on his left humming its fluorescent hum, the Chinese medicine store on his right dark and aromatic -- and into the late-morning chaos of Petaling Street. The market was in full throat: vendors unfolding trestle tables, hanging counterfeit handbags from wire frames, stacking bootleg sneakers in their boxes. A man was grilling satay over a portable charcoal grill, the smoke rising in a column that caught the light and turned it amber. Cantonese clattered above the traffic noise. A motorbike threaded through the pedestrian flow with the casual disregard for physics that Malaysian motorbikes treated as a religious principle.

He filmed, of course. Phone up, one-handed grip, low confessional voice.

"Morning walk through KL. Chinatown first thing -- the energy here is unreal. No itinerary, just stepping out the door and letting the city happen to you."

He turned the camera on himself. Grin. The market a blur behind him.

"Day six in Malaysia. Six days of no plan and everything's working out."

Past the Guan Di Temple, its red facade glowing like an ember, joss stick smoke curling from the open door. Past the dried goods shops and the old men playing Chinese chess on an upturned crate. Jalan Sultan widened. Shophouses gave way to commercial buildings. A 7-Eleven. A bank. Traffic thickened in a three-way negotiation that Connor couldn't parse but which never resulted in collision.

The humidity was building toward its daily crescendo. Connor's singlet darkened between his shoulder blades. His Havaianas slapped against the pavement. The envelope sat in his back pocket. He didn't think about it. He thought about the money, about extending his stay, about buying Priya dinner at that place Jake had mentioned on Jalan Alor.

He passed a police officer.

The officer was standing on the corner of Jalan Sultan and Jalan Tun Tan Cheng Lock, a young Malay man in the light blue uniform of the Polis Diraja Malaysia, his cap pulled low against the sun, a walkie-talkie crackling on his hip. He was watching the traffic with the practised boredom of a man on a routine post. Connor walked past him -- two meters from a uniformed officer, a sealed envelope of unverified contents in his back pocket, given to him by a man he'd known for six days, to be delivered to a stranger across the city. He felt nothing. No spike of adrenaline, no flutter of conscience, no whisper of *maybe you should think about what you're doing*. He was carrying business documents. Boring stuff. A mate's favour.

He was invisible in the way that privilege makes you invisible -- not hidden, but beneath notice, unworthy of suspicion, because people who looked like Connor didn't do things that warranted suspicion. That was for other people. Connor knew this without knowing it, the way a fish knows water -- it was the medium he moved through, and he had never once been asked to name it.

Jalan Sultan became Jalan Bukit Bintang by degrees. Shophouses vanished. Glass-fronted malls appeared -- Zara, H&M, Uniqlo, the same brands in every city. The sidewalks widened. He stopped filming. Modernity didn't play well on Instagram. Nobody double-tapped a Zara storefront.

He followed Felix's directions: past the intersection, left at the Starbucks, down a side street of gentrified shophouses -- a barber shop with exposed bulbs, a boutique selling "curated" handicrafts, a yoga studio. And there: Brickhouse Cafe.

It was exactly the kind of place Felix had described. Exposed brick walls -- the original shophouse brickwork, cleaned and sealed and turned from functional material into aesthetic statement. Blonde wood tables, black metal chairs, the kind of Scandinavian-Japanese hybrid aesthetic Connor had seen in a hundred cafes across Southeast Asia. An enormous Italian coffee machine gleamed like a surgical instrument behind the counter. The menu was written in chalk: *Flat White RM15. Pour Over RM18. Matcha Latte RM16.* A single monstera plant in a ceramic pot guarded the entrance.

Air conditioning hit him like a wall of cold, the sudden shift from tropical humidity to controlled coolness that was, in its way, as much a feature of KL as the heat itself.

The cafe was half-full. A young woman with a laptop and the focused expression of someone meeting a deadline. Two men in business shirts having a meeting over espressos. A mother with a toddler in a highchair, the toddler systematically disassembling a croissant. And at the back, alone, reading a newspaper, wearing a blue polo shirt: the man.

Malaysian, maybe Chinese-Malaysian. Middle-aged. Nondescript. The kind of face you'd forget before you'd finished looking at it. His newspaper was the *New Straits Times*, folded to the business section. He read with the absorption of a man who had been told to look like he was reading.

Connor approached. "Hey, mate. I've got something from Felix."

The man looked up. His eyes met Connor's for a fraction of a second, then swept the cafe -- door, windows, other customers. Then his eyes dropped to Connor's chest -- specifically the area where a wire might be taped -- then to the envelope Connor was pulling from his pocket.

He did not speak. He did not smile. He reached out and took the envelope with a motion closer to extraction than acceptance, his fingers closing around it in a single fluid movement.

The envelope disappeared below the table. The soft tear of the clasp opening. Rustle of paper. Silence. The man's eyes were lowered, his face a mask of professional blankness, his hands invisible beneath the tabletop.

"So... we're good?" Connor said.

The man nodded once. A single, minimal dip of the chin. There was nothing in his eyes. Not hostility, not warmth. The eyes of a man who had trained himself to be a surface with nothing behind it.

Connor got the social cue -- the conversation was over -- without getting the actual hint: normal business associates make eye contact. They say hello. They do not scan rooms for surveillance before accepting envelopes, and they do not open them under tables. These were not the behaviours of a man receiving invoices.

Connor noticed none of this. He noticed that the man was rude, and that the cafe had good natural light.

"Right. Cool."

He walked out. Three steps along the pavement. His phone buzzed. GrabPay: *You have received RM200.00 from F. Decker.*

The hit was immediate and chemical, a flush of warmth that started in his chest and radiated outward to his extremities. It was not unlike the feeling of the first beer of the day, or the feeling of a post getting more likes than expected, or the feeling of a pretty girl laughing at something he'd said. It was the feeling of the world confirming that you were doing it right, that your instincts were correct, that the approach of just going with it and saying yes and not overthinking things was, in fact, the superior way to live. Two hundred ringgit for twenty minutes of walking. The hourly rate was -- Connor calculated with the only mathematics he respected -- approximately six hundred ringgit per hour, which was more than most people in this city earned in a day, and he'd earned it by putting one foot in front of the other.

He grinned. He grinned at the street, at the shopping malls, at the taxis lined up outside Lot 10, at a pair of girls in hijabs who walked past and did not grin back.

He texted Felix: *Done. Smooth as. Cheers legend.*

Felix's reply came within thirty seconds: *Perfect. Told you - easy money. Enjoy your day.*

---

He stopped at a street stall two blocks from the hostel and ordered a teh tarik. The stall was one of his discoveries -- a narrow counter under a zinc awning, run by an Indian-Malaysian man in his sixties who made pulled tea with the theatrical flair of a bartender and the precision of a chemist. The man held two metal cups at arm's length -- one high, one low -- and poured the milky tea between them in a long, frothy arc, the liquid streaming down in a golden rope that never broke, never splashed. It was a performance. It was a skill refined over decades. It was exactly the kind of thing Connor would have filmed if he hadn't already filmed it twice.

The teh tarik was sweet and milky and perfect. Connor drank it standing at the counter, two hundred ringgit richer, savouring not just the money but the sense of capability -- that he, Connor Briggs, had a skill the world would pay for. Granted, the skill was walking, but still. Felix had needed someone reliable. Felix had chosen him. There was something flattering in that, something that confirmed what Connor had always believed about himself: that he was a person who attracted opportunity because he was open to it in a way that planners and worriers simply weren't.

He left a five-ringgit note on the counter -- a generous tip, the generosity of the newly flush -- and walked back to the hostel.

The common room was occupied. Jake was sprawled on the corduroy sofa like a golden retriever that had been asked to sit and had interpreted the instruction liberally. He was wearing a backwards cap, a Quiksilver T-shirt, eating a banana, and watching surfing wipeouts on his phone without headphones.

"Dude! Where you been?"

Connor dropped into the armchair. "Side hustle," he said, and grinned. He was already constructing the narrative -- converting the morning into anecdote, shaping experience into content, which was what he did with everything. "You know that import-export company Felix does photography for? They needed someone to run some documents across town. Business papers, contracts, that kind of thing. Twenty minutes of walking. Two hundred ringgit."

Jake's eyebrows rose above the frame of his sunglasses, which were perched on his forehead despite being indoors. "Dude. Two hundred ringgit for *walking*? That's sick."

"For walking."

"That's like fifty bucks for doing nothing."

"Right?" Connor leaned back. The armchair smelled of dust and Tiger Balm and the collective exhaustion of a thousand backpackers. "Felix reckons there might be more. Regular thing."

"You're, like, living the dream, man. Side hustle in KL. That's content right there. You should post about it."

Connor considered this. An Instagram story: *Making money while making memories. The digital nomad life isn't just laptops and lattes. #sidehustle #KLlife #makingitwork.* He could see the likes accumulating, the comments from people back home who worked nine-to-five and scrolled through his feed thinking *how does he afford this?* Now he'd have an answer.

Neither of them heard the footsteps. Neither noticed Priya until she was already there, standing in the archway, her battered Lonely Planet under one arm, her round glasses pushed up her nose, her hair in its single long braid. She had heard the last two minutes.

"What kind of company?" she asked.

Connor straightened. He liked Priya. More than liked. She was smart and sharp and looked at him like she could see something in him that he couldn't see himself.

"Import-export. Photography equipment, I think. Felix's thing."

Her expression changed in a way Connor didn't have the resolution to detect -- a tightening at the corners of her mouth, the face of a fourth-year medical student registering a symptom. She held it for half a second.

"Hm. Right." She pushed her glasses up. "What were you delivering?"

"An envelope. Business documents. Invoices, contracts, boring stuff."

"Did you look at them?"

"Nah, they're sealed. Confidential."

Priya looked at Connor for a long moment. Then at Jake, who wasn't looking at either of them. Then at the floor.

"Be careful," she said.

"Of what?" Connor laughed -- his reflex against seriousness. "It's an envelope, Priya. Business papers. Felix is a mate."

"You've known him for six days."

"And they've been a great six days." The grin was a wall, and behind it, nothing. "Relax. It's all good."

Priya said "Okay" in a voice that communicated the opposite, and walked out the front door into Petaling Street.

Connor watched her go. He felt something -- not guilt, not concern, but a vague irritation, the itchy displeasure that arrived whenever someone introduced friction into the smooth narrative of his life. Priya was doing the thing that careful people did: worrying about things that didn't need worrying about. She was a planner. A Googler. A reader of guidebooks and fine print. He liked her, genuinely, but sometimes being around her was like wearing a seatbelt in a parked car. Necessary, she'd argue. Unnecessary, he'd counter. And he was right. He was always right about these things.

"She's cool," Jake said, not looking up. "Kind of intense though."

"She's great," Connor said, and went upstairs.

---

Dorm 3 was empty except for the ceiling fan, which turned with patient indifference, and the smell of old wood and damp cotton. The afternoon light came through the air well in a shaft of grey-white -- clouds gathering for the daily storm.

Connor climbed into Bed 7. The mattress squeaked. He lay on his back, scrolled Instagram, liked photos, the mechanical rhythm soothing in its mindlessness. He was buzzing with the teh tarik and the two hundred ringgit and the residual irritation from Priya's concern.

A noise in the doorway.

Aziz was standing at the entrance to Dorm 3, filling the frame the way a boulder fills a streambed -- wide shoulders touching both sides of the doorway, the air rerouting around him. He was holding a toolbox and a replacement motor for the ceiling fan, and he was looking at Connor.

In six days, Connor had heard Aziz say exactly four words: "Fan. Tomorrow. Morning." and, on a separate occasion, "No." He was in his fifties, broad-shouldered, with the kind of forearms that suggested a lifetime of physical work and the kind of eyes that suggested a lifetime of things he'd rather not have seen. He chain-smoked Gudang Garam kretek cigarettes in the alley. He fixed things. He checked IDs. He was, in Connor's taxonomy, a background character.

But Aziz was looking at him now with an expression that was something closer to grief -- the look of a person watching a thing happen that they have seen happen before and will see happen again and cannot stop.

Aziz set down his toolbox. He set down the motor. He stood in the doorway and opened his mouth.

The silence that followed was not empty. It was full of the words Aziz was not saying, words he had said once before in a different life and the saying of which had cost him his badge, his pension, his marriage, and very nearly his life. *I know what the envelope was. I know who Felix is. I have seen this play out before, with someone who slept in that exact bed, and she is in prison now.* The words were behind his teeth. He could feel them the way you feel a sneeze building.

Aziz's jaw worked. The muscles in his face shifted, rearranged, settled.

He had been a police officer once. Twenty-two years with the Polis Diraja Malaysia, twelve as a narcotics detective. He had been good at it. He had, on one occasion in 2014, followed the evidence to a place his superiors didn't want him to go and filed a report about connections between a trafficking ring and certain officers. The report had ended his career. Not violently -- just a transfer, then a redundancy, then a pension that evaporated in an administrative error never corrected. His wife left six months later. Aziz had taken the handyman job because Razak was his cousin and because the building needed things fixed and because speaking up was a luxury for people with nothing to lose, and he had discovered, too late, that he had everything to lose.

He had watched Lena. The Swedish girl. Bed 7. He had watched her carry envelopes, then packages, then a backpack. He had watched Felix build around her the same architecture closing now around Connor. He had said nothing, and Lena was in Kajang Prison, and Aziz fixed ceiling fans and smoked kretek cigarettes in the alley and said nothing.

He closed his mouth.

He picked up his toolbox. Picked up the motor. Stood in the doorway one more second, his eyes meeting Connor's -- a transmission of something not quite information, a frequency of human distress that required, on the receiver's part, a sensitivity Connor did not possess.

"You right, mate?" Connor said.

Aziz turned and walked down the corridor. His footsteps receded -- the third step from the top squeaked -- and then he was gone.

Connor shrugged. The physical gesture, shoulders up and down, a one-second dismissal. A weird bloke having a weird moment. Hostel people. You got all types.

He opened Instagram.

---

The storm came at 2:14 PM, as it always did, with a rumble of thunder that vibrated through the old building's bones and then the sudden, percussive fury of tropical rain on zinc roofs and tile courtyards and the open throat of the air well. The dorm darkened. The air cooled. Connor spent the afternoon in the common room -- the storm had driven the hostel's population inside, filling the space with the restless, stir-crazy energy of travellers trapped by weather. The French couple were there, and the guitar player who had located a fourth string. Jake was teaching a Japanese girl a card game he was inventing as he went. Mama Siti shuffled through the kitchen and produced a pot of curry that filled the ground floor with the smell of turmeric and coconut milk and lemongrass.

Connor ate the curry. He ate seconds. He told Mama Siti it was "insane, restaurant-quality," and she looked at him with the expression of a woman who had been cooking since before he was born and did not require his assessment. He posted a photo to his stories: *When the hostel cook is better than any restaurant in the city. #KLfood #hostellife.*

When Priya came back from the Islamic Arts Museum, she showed him photos on her phone -- geometric patterns, illuminated manuscripts, ceramic tiles in shades of blue. He listened. He asked questions. She was surprised. He was surprised by himself. For twenty minutes on the bench by the air well they talked about art and the weight of time, and Connor was, for those twenty minutes, a better version of himself -- curious, attentive, almost wise. It didn't last. It couldn't. But Priya saw it, and filed it in the part of her mind where she kept the evidence that Connor might be worth saving.

Night. The hostel quieted. The rooftop drinkers drank. The snorers snored. The ceiling fan turned.

He was in his bunk, Bed 7, Dorm 3. The room was dark except for the blue-white glow of phone screens -- the universal nightlight of the modern hostel, the scattered constellations of people lying in the dark, connected to everywhere except where they were. Someone above him watching a video, the volume barely audible -- a woman's voice, Korean, rhythmic and soothing. A gentle snore across the room. The air well letting in the city's deep-night sounds -- a motorbike, a cat, the long low moan of a cargo truck on Jalan Sultan.

Connor was scrolling. He'd posted the photo from his walk -- the KL skyline, slightly blurred in a way he'd decided was "intentional." Filter to deepen the shadows, add grain. The caption had taken twelve minutes:

*The city reveals itself to those who walk it. No map. No destination. Just motion and the faith that the next corner holds something worth seeing. #KL #kualalumpur #digitalnomad #streetphotography #noplan #livingmybestlife #malaysia*

Forty-seven likes. His mother: *Love this! Dad says hi xx.* A girl from Chiang Mai: *Omg KL is on my list!* A bot offering collab opportunities.

He rolled onto his side. The bunk creaked. His hand slid off the mattress and brushed the wooden frame -- dark, old wood, warm from the room's trapped heat. His fingers trailed along the surface, idle, sensing without seeking.

His fingertips found the grooves.

Letters. Carved small and shallow, someone pressing a point into the grain, letter by letter. The grooves were smooth with age. His fingers passed over them, reading the name in Braille, in the dark, without his eyes.

L. E. N. A.

If he turned on his phone flashlight and looked, he would see it. If he asked, someone might tell him about the Swedish girl who'd slept in this bed, who'd met a charming European man in the common room, who was now in Kajang Prison, four hundred and seven days into a wait for a trial that would almost certainly end with a judge pronouncing the words *gantung sampai mati* -- hanged until dead.

But Connor did not look. His hand was already back under his pillow, his eyes already closing, and the name was already forgotten -- not forgotten, because it had never been known. It was a texture. A roughness in wood. An imperfection he slept against every night and had never examined, because examining things was not what Connor did.

---

His phone screen lit up.

White light cutting through the dark. Connor's eyes opened. His thumb unlocked the screen before his brain had surfaced from sleep.

A text from Felix. 12:47 AM.

*See? Easy. Got another one tomorrow if you're keen. Same deal.*

Connor read the message. *See? Easy.* Yes. *Got another one tomorrow.* Another envelope. Another walk. Another two hundred ringgit. *If you're keen.* If. As if there were a version of Connor who would think *I'd like to know what I'm carrying and who I'm carrying it to and why a man I've known for six days is paying me to do something he could do himself*. As if there were a version of Connor who would lie in the dark and think, really think, about what it means when someone pays you not to ask questions.

His thumb hovered over the keyboard. The cursor blinked. The dorm was silent except for the breathing of seven people and the fan and the rain on the air well -- the particular, charged quiet of a moment that is, though the person living it does not know, a hinge.

Connor typed four letters.

*Keen.*

He sent it without thinking. Because why wouldn't he? It was just envelopes. It was just paper. Easy money in a city where money was the difference between the life he was living and the life he was afraid of. She'll be right. She'll always be right. Tomorrow another envelope, another walk, another two hundred ringgit, each one just as easy and just as harmless and just as light in his back pocket.

He put the phone face-down on the mattress. The screen went dark.

Connor closed his eyes. In two minutes he was asleep.

In the wooden frame of Bed 7, four letters held their shape in the dark, and the name they spelled belonged to a woman who had typed the same word -- *keen* -- on the same bed, to the same man, thirteen months ago, and who was now in a cell three hours south of this city, counting the days until a judge decided whether she would live or die.

The ceiling fan turned.

The rain fell.

The city did not care.
# Chapter 7: The Law You Don't Know

The toaster was trying to kill him.

Not in the Malaysian way -- not with the slow, systemic patience of a country whose legal code contained provisions that Connor Briggs had never read and would never read until the provisions were being read to him in a courtroom. No, this was more immediate. The toaster in the communal kitchen of The Lantern Hostel was a chrome relic of indeterminate origin, its brand name worn to a smear by years of backpacker abuse, and it had two settings: nothing, and inferno. Connor had inserted two slices of the hostel's complimentary white bread -- the kind of bread that existed in a quantum state between food and packing material -- and pressed the lever. The lever had refused to stay down. He'd pressed it again, harder. It had sprung back with a metallic complaint. He'd pressed it a third time, holding it with his thumb, and the element had glowed orange with a suddenness that suggested it had been waiting to do this, that the toaster had opinions about the people who used it and had chosen violence.

"Come on, you piece of--"

"Tekan sini."

The voice came from behind him, low and unhurried, and accompanied by a hand that reached past his elbow and pressed a small button on the side of the toaster he hadn't noticed. The lever clicked and held. The element settled into a steady glow. Toast commenced.

Connor turned. Mama Siti stood at the counter behind him, already back to her own station, already in motion, as if helping him with the toaster had been a thing that happened between moments rather than within one. She was small -- not just short but condensed, as if time had been slowly pressing her down toward the earth and she had responded by becoming denser rather than smaller. Her headscarf was white, clean, wrapped in a style that Connor couldn't have described but that looked deliberate and ancient, like a piece of origami that had been folded the same way for centuries. Her face was a landscape of lines -- deep grooves around her mouth, crow's feet that radiated from her eyes like the spokes of a wheel, the particular weathering of skin that has been exposed to tropical humidity and cooking steam for longer than most of the hostel's guests had been alive. She claimed to be sixty-eight. The building's foundations believed otherwise.

She was making nasi lemak, and the kitchen was her temple.

The hostel kitchen was a galley-sized strip of countertop, tile, and compromise, wedged between the common room and the air well courtyard. It contained one stove (gas, temperamental), one rice cooker (industrial, the only appliance that functioned without argument), a microwave that smelled permanently of someone's leftover curry, and a refrigerator whose interior represented a kind of archaeological dig through the dietary habits of a dozen nations -- jars of kimchi next to tubes of Vegemite next to plastic containers of something that might have been hummus or might have been a biohazard, all of it sweating in the tropical air whenever the fridge door opened, which was constantly. The kitchen was cramped, warm, perpetually crowded with backpackers trying to boil water for instant noodles or assemble sandwiches from ingredients they'd optimistically purchased at the 7-Eleven on the corner. It smelled of cooking oil and chilli and the ghost of a thousand meals.

But at 6 AM, before the backpackers stirred, the kitchen belonged to Mama Siti.

She had been there when Connor came downstairs, bleary-eyed, his hair a disaster, wearing the board shorts he'd slept in and a singlet that read CANGGU SURF CO. She was always there. She arrived at five, or she never left, or she materialised from the building's fabric like a spirit of the hearth -- the specifics were unclear and no one asked. What was clear was the food. The coconut rice was already steaming in the rice cooker, the sambal was bubbling in a small pot that seemed to be as old as she was, and the ikan bilis -- the tiny dried anchovies -- were frying in a shallow pan of oil, their bodies curling in the heat, filling the ground floor with a smell that was simultaneously fishy, nutty, and addictive. Roasted peanuts sat in a bowl. Hard-boiled eggs, halved, waited on a plate. Cucumber slices, cool and green, were arranged in a neat row on a cutting board.

She assembled a plate without being asked. She always knew who needed feeding. It was, Connor had decided during his seven days at The Lantern, one of the small miracles of hostel life -- that this ancient woman appeared every morning and produced food that was, objectively and without exaggeration, the best thing he'd eaten in any country, and that this food cost five ringgit, which was about a dollar fifty Australian, which was less than he'd pay for a bad coffee in Hawthorn.

She placed the plate in front of him. The nasi lemak was perfect: the coconut rice in a tight mound, glossy and fragrant, flanked by the sambal -- deep red, volcanic, flecked with dried shrimp and chilli seeds -- the anchovies crisp and golden, the peanuts scattered like small brown stones, the egg halved to show its pale yellow heart, the cucumber as an afterthought of freshness. It was beautiful in the way that food prepared by someone who has made the same dish ten thousand times is beautiful -- not arranged but inevitable, each element finding its correct position through the muscle memory of decades.

Connor ate. He made the sounds that the nasi lemak demanded -- small involuntary noises of gratitude that bypassed his brain entirely and came from somewhere deeper, somewhere that understood food in a way his conscious mind, with its Instagram filters and its #foodie hashtags, never would.

"Mama Siti," he said, mouth full, fork raised in a gesture of reverence, "this is unreal. Seriously. You could open a restaurant. You'd make a killing."

She didn't turn from the stove. She made a sound -- a soft exhalation through the nose -- that could have been acknowledgment or dismissal or both.

"I'm serious," Connor pressed. "Back in Melbourne, people pay thirty bucks for brunch that's half as good as this. You could charge whatever you wanted."

Now she turned. She looked at him with those dark eyes -- eyes that were not unkind but were very, very old, the kind of old that comes not from years alone but from having watched years pass over and over and over again, each one carrying away someone who sat where Connor sat now, eating what Connor ate now, saying what Connor said now.

"Ini bukan tentang wang," she said quietly. This is not about money.

"Yeah, nah, I know, but--"

"Orang yang tak tahu undang-undang," she said, and her voice changed. Not louder -- softer, actually, as if the words were being spoken from a distance, from a place behind her eyes where the kitchen and the hostel and the present moment were thin layers over something deeper. "Undang-undang tak tahu dia."

Connor paused, a forkful of sambal-drenched rice halfway to his mouth. "What's that mean?"

Mama Siti turned the stove down. The sambal stopped bubbling. In the sudden quiet, Connor could hear the morning call to prayer from Masjid Jamek, faint but clear through the air well, a human voice rising over the city in a melody that was simultaneously alien and familiar, like a memory from a life he hadn't lived.

She considered the question. Not the way people consider questions when they're translating -- she spoke English perfectly well, everyone knew that. She considered it the way a doctor considers how much to tell a patient.

"The man who does not know the law," she said, "the law does not know him."

Connor chewed. Swallowed. "Is that a good thing or a bad thing?"

She wiped her hands on the cloth that hung from her waistband, a slow and deliberate motion. "When the law comes," she said, "it does not ask if you know its name."

The words settled between them like something dropped into water, sending out ripples that Connor couldn't see and wouldn't feel until they reached the shore of a moment he hadn't arrived at yet. He blinked. The nasi lemak was getting cold. The call to prayer was fading. Mama Siti was looking at him -- really looking, the way you look at someone standing at the edge of a cliff who thinks they're standing on flat ground. Her eyes held something that wasn't warning, exactly, and wasn't pity, exactly, but sat in the unnamed space between the two where the old women of the world keep their most terrible knowledge.

"Hey," Connor said, "do you have any hot sauce?"

The look lingered. It lingered for one full second longer than was comfortable, long enough that a more attentive person might have felt the hairs rise on the back of their neck, might have put down the fork and said *What do you mean? What law? Why are you looking at me like that?* A second that contained, compressed within it, the full weight of everything Mama Siti knew and could not say directly, because prophecy, like cooking, had rules -- you could not force someone to taste what they refused to put in their mouth.

Then she reached behind her and produced a bottle of sambal from the shelf. She set it in front of him.

"You already have all the fire you need," she said.

She turned back to the stove. The sambal began to bubble again. The moment closed over itself like water, leaving no visible trace.

Connor upended the bottle over his nasi lemak, dousing it in additional chilli, and ate with the uncomplicated pleasure of a man who had been handed a prophecy and mistaken it for condiment advice. He finished the plate, left five ringgit on the counter, and headed upstairs to shower.

Mama Siti stood at the stove and watched the sambal turn in the pot, the same slow red circles it had been making since before this building was a hostel, since before the boy upstairs was born, since before the law he did not know was written on the paper he would never read.

She picked up his plate and washed it. She washed all the plates eventually.

---

Priya was waiting for him in the common room at nine, her battered Lonely Planet held against her chest like a shield, her round glasses pushed up on her forehead, her long braid swinging as she turned to face him. She was wearing jeans and a loose cotton shirt and trainers -- practical, appropriate, researched. She looked like she was going somewhere specific, which she was.

"I want to visit Masjid Jamek," she said.

"The what?"

"Masjid Jamek. One of the oldest mosques in KL. It's at the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers." She said this the way she said most things -- with the quiet authority of someone who had read the relevant chapter. "It's beautiful. Mughal-style architecture. I've been wanting to see it all week."

Connor rubbed his wet hair with the sleeve of his singlet. "A mosque?"

"A mosque."

"Like a... praying mosque?"

Priya's expression performed a complex operation -- the smile that wanted to happen was intercepted by the eye-roll that deserved to happen, and the result was something in between: an expression of fond exasperation that Connor had become increasingly familiar with over the past seven days. It was the look she gave him when he said things that were not quite stupid enough to be offensive but not quite smart enough to let pass.

"Yes, Connor. A praying mosque. As opposed to the other kind."

"I just meant -- I'm not really a mosque guy. I'm more of a... beach guy."

"We're in Kuala Lumpur. There are no beaches."

"There might be."

"There are not." She tucked the guidebook under her arm. "Come with me. You'll like it. And you need to see something in this city that isn't a bar or a night market."

He should have said no. He had no interest in mosques, in architecture, in the history of a city he'd been in for a week and still thought of primarily as a backdrop for content. But Priya was standing there in the warm light of the common room, her dark skin luminous against the white of her shirt, her eyes bright behind the glasses that had slipped back down to the bridge of her nose, and she was asking him to spend the morning with her, and Connor Briggs was many things -- ignorant, reckless, dangerously incurious about the world he moved through -- but he was not immune to Priya Sharma.

"Yeah, go on then," he said.

They walked.

KL in the morning was a different beast from KL at night -- shopkeepers hosing down pavements, roti canai frying at corner stalls, the particular golden quality of equatorial morning light hitting old plaster. They followed the river past colonial-era buildings and through the edges of the financial district.

"KL means 'muddy confluence,'" Priya said, gesturing at the brown river below the bridge they were crossing. "It was literally named for the mud where these two rivers meet."

"That's sick," Connor said. "Like, literally muddy? Gross."

She rolled her eyes but smiled, and the smile was the thing he was after -- the crack in her composure, the moment where her curated intelligence gave way to something warmer. He collected those smiles the way he collected everything: casually, greedily, without understanding their value.

They approached Masjid Jamek from the south. The mosque sat at the actual confluence, the two rivers meeting at its feet -- white stone and onion domes and arched colonnades, salmon pink stripes catching the morning light.

"Wow," Connor said, and meant it.

"Built in 1909," Priya said. "Mughal and Moorish style."

"You memorised that?"

"I read a book, Connor. You should try it sometime."

They crossed to the entrance, where signs in Malay and English explained the rules for visitors. Priya had already read them. Connor had not.

He was two steps from the entrance when she caught his arm.

"Connor."

"What?"

She looked at him. Then she looked at his outfit. He followed her gaze. Board shorts. The Bintang Beer singlet. Flip-flops. The compass tattoo visible on his forearm. He looked like what he was: an Australian backpacker who had rolled out of a hostel and into a sacred space with all the preparation of a man stumbling into the wrong room at a party.

"You can't go in like that," Priya said. Her voice was patient but firm -- the voice of a medical student explaining to a patient why, no, they couldn't just take the bandage off because it itched.

"What's wrong with what I'm wearing?"

"Everything. Shoulders need to be covered. Legs need to be covered. No shoes inside. This is a mosque, not a beach bar."

"Seriously?"

"Seriously."

He looked at the entrance. A rack stood to one side, hung with folded garments -- robes for men, longer coverings for women -- provided by the mosque for visitors who hadn't come prepared. A sign above the rack, in English: PLEASE DRESS RESPECTFULLY. COVERINGS PROVIDED. Connor looked at the sign. For once, he actually read it.

"So I wear one of those?"

"They're sarongs and robes. Yes."

"Like a skirt?"

"Like a sarong. And you're a guest in their sacred space, Connor."

The words landed with a weight that Connor didn't expect. *A guest in their sacred space.* He thought about that for a moment. He was always a guest, everywhere -- that was the point of travel, wasn't it, being a guest in places that weren't yours? But he'd never thought about what that word actually meant. A guest had obligations. A guest behaved. A guest didn't walk into someone's house in flip-flops and a beer singlet and expect the house to accommodate them.

He was not, by nature, a man who was chastened. But Priya had a way of framing things that got through -- not by lecturing, not by shaming, but by presenting the reality so simply that even Connor's defenses couldn't find a way to deflect it.

"Right," he said. "Yeah. Fair enough."

He selected a robe from the rack -- pale green, long, lightweight cotton -- and pulled it on over his singlet and shorts. He removed his flip-flops and placed them on the shoe rack, where they sat among dozens of other pairs: leather sandals, trainers, delicate women's shoes, and his battered Havaianas, the most disreputable items in the collection by a considerable margin. Priya had already wrapped a scarf around her hair, borrowed from the women's section, and was adjusting it in the reflection of the glass door.

"How do I look?" Connor asked, holding out his arms. The robe hung to his shins, and with his sun-bleached hair and stubbled jaw and the green fabric draping loosely over his board shorts, he looked like a surfer who'd been press-ganged into a nativity play.

"You look appropriate," Priya said. "For once."

"Harsh."

"Accurate."

They stepped inside.

---

The interior of Masjid Jamek was cool -- not air-conditioned but the coolness of marble and shade and water, a building designed to shelter people from equatorial heat. After the furnace of the street, it was a physical relief.

Connor stood in the main prayer hall and felt something shift.

White marble columns rose to pointed arches, the geometry repeating in a rhythm that drew the eye upward toward the dome, where light entered through small windows and fell in soft shafts to the floor. Against one wall, the mihrab -- Priya murmured the word, indicating the direction of Mecca -- was decorated with geometric patterns in gold and blue, the kind of design that rewarded attention in a way that Connor's attention was almost never rewarded.

But the sound. From somewhere outside, ablution fountains were running -- a gentle splash of water on stone that entered the prayer hall as a presence rather than a noise. And woven through it: silence. Not the absence of sound, but the particular hush of a space consecrated for listening to something beyond human speech.

Connor stood still. This was rare. Stillness was not his natural state. But here, in the cool marble silence, something in him stopped. The constant, exhausting performance of being Connor Briggs fell away, and what was left was just a person in a beautiful building, breathing cool air, not filming anything.

Priya was watching him. Her borrowed scarf framed her face, and her expression was softer than the fond exasperation he was used to. She was seeing something in him that he rarely showed -- a capacity for genuine experience, for being present without trying to extract content from it.

The moment lasted perhaps thirty seconds.

Then Connor took out his phone, turned the camera on himself, and took a selfie with the dome behind him, angling his jaw to catch the light, deploying the travel-selfie face he'd perfected over four years and twelve countries: slightly squinted eyes, half-smile, chin tilted up. The prayer hall became a backdrop. The awe became content.

"Delete that," Priya said.

"What? Why?"

"Because this is a mosque, not a photo studio. And because the moment you had just then -- that real one, before the phone came out -- was worth more than anything you'll ever post."

Connor looked at her. She was serious. Not angry, not lecturing -- serious in the way that people are serious when they've seen something valuable being discarded.

He looked at the selfie on his screen. He looked good. The light was incredible. The dome behind him was perfectly framed. It would do well on the grid, definitely break a hundred likes, maybe more with the right hashtags -- #malaysia #mosque #travel #culture --

He deleted it.

He didn't know why. Something about Priya's face, something about the quality of the silence. He put his phone in his pocket and stood there, empty-handed, in a sacred space, genuinely present.

"Good," Priya said softly.

They stayed for another twenty minutes. Connor listened while Priya read the plaques and explained the architecture. He didn't retain much, but he listened, and listening was enough.

When they left, stepping back into the assault of heat and noise, he put his flip-flops on and hung the robe back on the rack and became, once again, a backpacker in board shorts squinting in the sun.

"Thanks," he said.

"For what?"

"I dunno. That was... yeah. That was something."

She took his hand briefly and squeezed it, and they walked back toward Petaling Street, and Connor did not film any of it, which was, by his standards, an act of extraordinary restraint.

He would not visit another mosque. The moment in the prayer hall would sink below the surface of his days, joining the other moments of genuine experience that accumulated beneath the performance of his life like coins at the bottom of a pool -- visible if you looked, unreachable if you didn't dive. But it had happened. And Priya had seen it.

---

The common room was full by eight o'clock, and someone had turned on the TV.

The screen -- perpetually smeared with fingerprints, its remote held together with tape -- was showing a documentary. Someone had been flipping channels and landed here by accident or inertia.

The documentary was about drug trafficking in Southeast Asia.

Connor was on the sofa, a Tiger in his hand, Priya beside him reading her guidebook, Jake on the floor scrolling his phone. Two Swedish girls occupied the armchairs. A solo Korean traveler sat cross-legged on the beanbag.

The documentary was well-made. The camera work was careful, the narration measured, the kind of production that had been funded by a European public broadcaster and took its subject seriously. It opened with aerial footage of the Golden Triangle -- where Thailand, Laos, and Myanmar meet -- the green hills and brown rivers filmed from above with a drone, beautiful and ominous. Then it moved south. Malaysia. Indonesia. The Philippines. The supply chains. The couriers. The arrests.

A map appeared on screen, red lines tracing drug routes through Southeast Asia. The narrator's voice -- British, female, steady -- explained: "Malaysia remains one of the world's strictest jurisdictions for drug offenses. Under the Dangerous Drugs Act of 1952, trafficking in certain quantities of controlled substances carries a mandatory sentence."

Cut to a courtroom. Malaysian. High-ceilinged, wood-panelled, a judge in robes, the formality of the setting absolute. A defendant in a dock. The camera didn't show his face yet -- just his hands, cuffed, resting on the wood in front of him. The narrator continued:

"The mandatory sentence for drug trafficking above threshold amounts -- as little as fifteen grams of heroin, or fifty grams of methamphetamine -- is death."

The common room was quiet. Not the comfortable quiet of before, but the tight, attentive quiet of people receiving information they didn't want. The Swedish girls had stopped talking. Jake's thumb had paused on his phone screen. The Korean traveler looked up from his beanbag.

The camera moved to the defendant's face.

He was young. Western. Maybe twenty-five, maybe younger -- hard to tell because his face had the collapsed quality of a person who has not slept in a very long time and has been crying and has stopped. His hair was light brown, overgrown. His eyes were fixed on something beyond the courtroom walls, something internal and unimaginable.

He looked like someone Connor might meet in a hostel.

The judge spoke. The subtitles translated: "This court finds the accused guilty under Section 39B of the Dangerous Drugs Act 1952. The sentence of this court is that you shall be hanged by the neck until you are dead."

The screen cut to exterior footage of a prison -- high walls, barbed wire, the Malaysian flag hanging limp.

Something cold moved through Connor's gut. Pre-thought. The body's own intelligence recognising threat before the conscious mind had finished constructing its denial. The young man on screen had blue eyes. Not quite the same blue as Connor's, but close enough.

For a synapse-thin fraction of a second, Connor saw himself in the dock.

The fraction passed.

Connor reached for the remote. It was on the sofa cushion beside him, half-buried under Priya's guidebook. He picked it up and changed the channel.

A football match appeared. Manchester City versus somebody. Green grass, running figures, the roar of a crowd. The screen flooded with colour and motion and the comfortable, comprehensible drama of sport.

"That's heavy, man," Connor said. His voice was light. His voice was always light. "Can we not?"

Jake, from the floor: "Yeah. Yeah, put the game on. Who's playing?"

"City, looks like."

"Sick."

The common room exhaled. Shoulders dropped. Someone reached for their beer. The two Swedish girls resumed their conversation. The Korean traveler returned to his book. The French couple drifted away. The documentary was gone, replaced by football, and the cold thing in Connor's gut receded, pushed down by the beer and the noise and the comfortable fiction that the screen now provided -- a world where the stakes were points and trophies and where nothing permanent ever happened.

Priya did not resume reading her guidebook.

She sat very still, looking at the side of Connor's face. Her expression was complicated -- layers of emotion stacked like geological strata, each one partially visible through the one above. Concern. Frustration. Something deeper and sadder that she couldn't quite name, the feeling you get when you watch someone walk toward an edge they can't see and you know that shouting will only make them walk faster.

She didn't say anything. Not yet. She turned back to the screen, where Manchester City was pushing forward on the counterattack, and she held her guidebook in her lap -- open, still, to the page about Malaysian law, the section about the Dangerous Drugs Act, the paragraph about the mandatory death penalty that Connor had never read and would never read and that was, at this moment, four inches from his right thigh.

He didn't look down. He watched the football. He drank his beer.

The documentary was gone. The young man in the courtroom was gone. The cold feeling was gone. Connor Briggs, twenty-seven, Australian, had been shown the truth -- clearly, directly, on a screen three meters from his face, in a language he understood, with subtitles -- and he had picked up the remote and changed the channel.

The thing about changing the channel is that it only changes what you see. It doesn't change what's there.

---

Connor and Priya sat on the mosaic bench in the air well courtyard at half past eleven, the red lantern casting its warm glow above them. The hostel was quiet -- that particular deep quiet of midnight, the layered breathing of dozens of sleeping strangers. Through the open rectangle of sky above, the faint suggestion of stars through KL's orange haze.

Priya was close beside him. Not touching, but close -- the careful proximity of two people who have been circling each other for a week. Her glasses were off, folded in her lap, and without them her face looked softer, younger. She was looking up at the sky.

"Connor," she said. "Have you looked into Malaysian laws? At all?"

"What, like jaywalking?"

Her eyes, without the glasses, were large and serious. "Like drug laws."

"Oh, come on--"

"They have the death penalty here, Connor. For trafficking. Mandatory. As little as fifty grams."

He sighed -- the defence mechanism, the sound that said *we're not doing this.* "Yeah, but that's for actual drug dealers. Kingpins. Not backpackers."

"That's not how the law works. It doesn't matter who you are."

"I'm not carrying any drugs," he said.

"I know. I'm just saying. Be careful. This isn't Australia."

"You worry too much."

She looked at him -- a long, searching look, the medical student's diagnostic eye at work. She wanted to ask about Felix. About the envelopes, the "side hustle," the RM200 deposits. But the evidence was circumstantial, and she didn't want to accuse, and she didn't want to ruin the moment.

Connor kissed her.

Partly because he'd wanted to for days. And partly to stop the conversation -- the questions getting closer to something he didn't want to examine, something that lived in the same territory as the cold feeling from the documentary, as Mama Siti's eyes across the kitchen counter. A kiss was a channel change.

She tasted of teh tarik and spearmint gum and herself, warm and alive in the red lantern light. She kissed him back with a tenderness that was also, underneath, a kind of grief, though he couldn't have known that and she might not have known it either.

They pulled apart.

Priya smiled. The smile was small and genuine and more complicated than any selfie could capture.

Connor smiled. His smile was larger, more confident, the smile of a man who had gotten what he wanted, which was both the kiss and the end of the conversation.

His phone buzzed in his pocket.

The vibration was a single pulse against his thigh -- short, insistent, unmistakably a text. He pulled the phone out, angled the screen away from Priya -- a reflex, automatic, the muscle memory of a man who'd been reading his phone privately for long enough that the gesture was invisible to him even when it shouldn't have been.

The screen lit up. A message from Felix:

*Morning job tomorrow. RM300 this time. Package, not envelope. Same deal. You in?*

Connor read the message twice. RM300. Nearly a hundred Australian dollars for a single delivery. That was more than his monthly social media client paid. That was breathing room.

The other thing -- *package, not envelope* -- sat in the message like a step on a staircase that was noticeably higher than the one before it. He did not examine the progression. He did not think about the young man in the courtroom documentary.

He looked at Priya, her face soft in the lantern light. She was trying to save him, and he didn't know it.

He texted back, holding the phone under the bench where she couldn't see:

*In.*

"Who was that?" Priya asked.

"Just Mum," Connor said. "Checking in."

The lie came easy. They always did. But this one was slightly larger, because it was told to someone looking at him with trust, in the warm dark, after a kiss that had meant something.

"That's sweet," Priya said. "Tell her you're being safe."

"I will."

He put his arm around her. She leaned into him. And somewhere on the third floor, Felix Decker watched the *In* message arrive on his screen and smiled the smile of a man whose machinery was working exactly as designed.
# Chapter 8: The Package

The box was on the table between the toast and the Vegemite.

Connor almost didn't see it. Felix had arranged the scene with the casual precision that characterized everything he did -- a plate of white bread toast, a knife, an open jar of Vegemite that he must have bought from an import store somewhere in the city because it damn well didn't come from the hostel kitchen, and there, slightly to the left, in a plastic bag from a 7-Eleven, a brown paper package about the size of a shoebox. Wrapped neatly. Taped shut. Unremarkable. The kind of thing you'd walk past in a post office without a second thought.

"Morning," Felix said.

He was sitting in the wicker chair by the common room window, where the morning light fell in a flat white sheet through the glass and made everything look like a photograph of itself. He was eating toast with the methodical, unhurried attention he brought to everything -- small bites, clean fingers, the knife wiped on a napkin between spreads. His linen shirt was fresh, his leather sandals clean. He looked like someone in an advertisement for a lifestyle that didn't exist.

It was just past nine. The common room of The Lantern Hostel had the drowsy, half-assembled feeling of a Tuesday morning in a backpacker hostel -- a French girl on the vinyl couch scrolling her phone, the ceiling fans turning with their eternal, futile patience, CNN murmuring from the wall-mounted TV about something happening in a country that was not this one. Through the arched doorway to the air well, the sound of Mama Siti's pans. The smell of coconut rice and sambal, threading through the humid air like a summons.

Connor had come downstairs in his board shorts and a singlet that said *GOOD VIBES ONLY* in faded block letters. His hair was still damp from the shower -- the one that ran lukewarm if you caught it before eight-thirty and cold after. His phone was at forty-seven percent. He'd checked Instagram before his eyes were fully open: eleven likes on last night's sunset photo from the pedestrian bridge, a comment from Jake that said "DUDE sick shot" with three fire emojis, and a DM request from a bot pretending to be a swimwear model. Standard morning.

"Is that Vegemite?" Connor said.

"I remembered you mentioned it. Found some at a specialty store in Bangsar." Felix pushed the jar toward him. "Consider it a professional courtesy."

"Mate. Legend. You absolute legend."

Connor sat down, reached for the bread, and began assembling toast with the focused pleasure of a man reunited with his national condiment. He spread the Vegemite thin -- he wasn't an animal -- and took a bite, and the salty, yeasty, deeply specific taste of home hit him with a force that was briefly, unexpectedly emotional. He thought of his mum's kitchen in Hawthorn, the white Formica bench, the jar of Vegemite that was always there, that was as fixed a part of the house as the walls. He swallowed.

Felix watched him eat. He had the patience for it. He had the patience for everything.

"So," Felix said, after Connor's third bite. "I've got a job for you."

Connor's eyes went to the plastic bag on the table. The brown paper package inside it.

"Same deal as before," Felix continued, as if he were describing the weather. "Delivery. Brickfields this time. Near KL Sentral." He nodded at the package. "Phone accessories. Chargers, cables, screen protectors. There's a distributor in Little India who sells them -- small electronics shop, wholesale operation. He orders in bulk from a supplier here in Chinatown, but the shipping takes forever and the couriers are unreliable. I've been helping him cut out the middleman."

The explanation arrived fully formed, pre-assembled, with the seamless logic of a story that had been told many times. Felix delivered it while buttering another piece of toast, his voice level, his eyes on the bread, the whole performance communicating one thing: *this is boring. This is mundane. This is beneath our attention.*

"Three hundred ringgit," Felix added. "Shouldn't take more than an hour."

Connor swallowed his toast. Three hundred ringgit. Ninety-something Australian dollars. For walking a box from Chinatown to Brickfields -- a distance he could have covered in twenty minutes on the LRT. He'd done two envelope deliveries for Felix already over the past few days, both smooth, both quick, both followed by the little buzz of a GrabPay notification that felt like the world tipping in his favor. RM200 each time. This was more. This was a raise.

"Three hundred?" he said. "For phone chargers?"

"Portable chargers. Power banks. Screen protectors in bulk. The box is heavier than you'd think." Felix smiled. The scar through his eyebrow caught the light. "The markup on accessories is insane. The distributor makes good money, so he pays good money to keep his supply chain moving. Simple economics."

"Yeah," Connor said. "No, yeah, that makes sense."

He reached across the table and pulled the plastic bag toward him. The package inside was wrapped in brown paper, the kind you'd find at any stationery store, sealed with clear packing tape in neat horizontal strips. No labels, no address, no return sender. Just a box, wrapped, anonymous. He picked it up.

The weight was wrong.

He knew it immediately, in the way the body knows things before the mind catches up -- the same way your hand pulls back from a hot surface before the pain signal arrives. The package was heavy. Not impossibly heavy, not suspicious-on-its-own heavy, but heavier than a shoebox of phone chargers and cables should be. He was holding maybe a kilo and a half, possibly more.
