The weight sat in his hands with a density that spoke of something packed tight, something compressed, something that occupied less space than its mass suggested.

"This is heavier than I expected," he said.

He said it casually. He heard it casually. But somewhere deep in the machinery of his nervous system, in the reptile brain where survival instincts lived, a wire tripped. A small electrical pulse, smaller than a thought, more like the shadow of one: *wrong*.

Felix didn't miss a beat. He never missed beats. Missing beats was for amateurs and the guilty.

"Power banks," he said. "Those things are basically bricks. Lithium batteries, yeah? Dense as anything." He took a sip of his instant coffee, holding the cup with both hands, unhurried. "I had to carry a box of twenty from Sim Lim Square in Singapore once. Nearly threw my back out."

Connor nodded. Of course. Power banks. Lithium batteries. Dense. He knew this -- he'd owned a power bank once, briefly, before leaving it at a guesthouse in Hoi An. Those things were heavy. Everyone knew that.

The wire in his reptile brain went slack. The shadow of the thought dissolved. The package was just a package, heavy because power banks were heavy, sealed because that's how you shipped things, anonymous because Felix's supplier was a wholesale operation and wholesale operations didn't bother with fancy labeling. The logic was clean, airtight, self-reinforcing. It was also a construction, built piece by piece over nine days of carefully dispensed trust, free beers, and Vegemite.

Connor put the package in his daypack. It sat at the bottom like ballast, adding weight, pulling the straps taut against his shoulders. He zipped the bag shut.

"Address?" he said.

Felix produced his phone, typed something, and sent it. Connor's phone buzzed in his pocket. He pulled it out and read the message: a street name in Brickfields, a building number, and a single instruction.

*Back entrance. Metal door. Knock twice.*

"His name's Mr. Tan," Felix said. "He doesn't talk much. Don't take it personally -- he's just busy. Hand over the package, he'll check it, and you're done. I'll send the payment as soon as he confirms."

"Easy."

"Easy," Felix agreed. He raised his coffee cup in a small salute. "You're good at this, Connor. Some people overthink it. You just do it."

Connor grinned. The compliment landed where Felix intended it -- in the part of Connor that was hungry for validation, for the sense that he was good at something, that his casual, untethered approach to life was not a deficit but a talent. *You just do it.* Felix made it sound like a philosophy. Like something you'd put on a motivational poster, or a singlet.

"Back in an hour," Connor said, and headed for the door.

He passed through the narrow entrance corridor with the daypack riding heavy on his shoulders, the red paper lanterns glowing overhead in their perpetual amber procession. The phone repair shop on his left was already open -- the fluorescent light buzzing, the window display of cracked screens and coiled cables, and behind the counter, a man Connor had never properly looked at, sorting through components with quick, precise fingers. Wei. Not that Connor knew his name.

He stepped onto Petaling Street, and the city took him.

---

The walk from Chinatown to Brickfields was a lesson in KL's layers, though Connor wasn't the type to learn lessons that didn't come with likes and engagement.

He headed south along Jalan Sultan, past morning market stragglers packing up stalls -- vendors folding tarpaulins, hosing down pavement with water that ran brown into the storm drains. The air was already thick with heat, the humidity doing that thing it did in KL where you stepped outside and your body immediately began losing a fight it hadn't agreed to participate in. The daypack straps bit into his shoulders. The package sat at the bottom of the bag, a dense weight against his lower spine.

He passed the Guan Di Temple on the corner, incense drifting from its open doors. He passed a man drinking kopi-o at a marble-topped table outside a kopitiam, and for a moment Connor saw Felix in the posture -- the same unhurried confidence, the same sense of a man who knew exactly where he was.

He was filming. Phone in his right hand, narrating in the low, conspiratorial voice of his content persona: "Morning walk through Chinatown, KL. Day nine. This is what travel's about, guys. The real streets."

He was carrying a package of unknown contents toward a delivery address specified by a man he'd met nine days ago, and he was filming it for content. Connor's mind was a room with all the lights on and all the doors locked.

He turned onto Jalan Tun Sambanthan and the world changed. Chinatown fell away in the space of a single block.

Brickfields. Little India.

The transition was total. Chinatown's red-and-gold palette gave way to saffron and magenta and the electric blue of Hindu temple gopurams rising above rooftops like frozen fireworks. Sari shops lined both sides of the street, their storefronts hung with silk in every colour the eye could register -- emerald, vermillion, violet, a gold so bright it looked like it should be warm to the touch. Between them, garland sellers sat behind cascading displays of jasmine and marigold, the flowers strung on thread in thick ropes, the scent so sweet and dense it was almost narcotic. Tamil replaced Cantonese -- rapid, musical, a whole new frequency. A Hindi film song blared from a speaker above a sari shop with a volume that suggested the owner had confused music with a military offensive. Two women in salwar kameez walked past, their conversation a bright, overlapping duet that Connor couldn't parse but instinctively understood was gossip of the highest order.

And the food -- curry leaves frying in oil, the deep warmth of a biryani pot simmering since dawn, cardamom-laced chai steam rising from a streetside stall. Banana leaf rice restaurants were opening, long tables covered in fresh green leaves like place settings.

Connor filmed it all, turning in a slow circle on the pavement.

"Okay, this is insane," he said to his phone. "We've basically left one country and entered another. This is what I mean about KL, guys. Layers."

He walked deeper into the neighborhood, following Felix's GPS pin. Past a roti canai stall where dough stretched and spun in the air like a thin, wheaten planet.

He stopped at the garland sellers -- three stalls in a row, three women on low stools, their hands working with a speed that made the process invisible. Flowers in, garland out. Connor took a photo: brown hands against white jasmine, marigold garlands hanging in thick orange ropes behind. He'd caption it something about "the art of everyday life" or some other borrowed profundity.

"For the temple," one seller said, holding up a finished garland. "For prayer. You want?"

"Oh, nah, I'm not really--"

"Five ringgit."

Connor bought one. He had no temple to bring it to, no prayer to offer. But the garland was beautiful, and the jasmine smelled like something he couldn't name but wanted to be near. He draped it over his daypack strap, where it hung against the bag's grey fabric like a bright and fragrant rebuke.

Inside the bag, beneath the garland, the package sat dense and anonymous, waiting.

---

The address was on a side street off the main Brickfields drag, where the sari shops and restaurants thinned out and the buildings became more industrial -- low concrete structures with roller shutters, wholesale operations dealing in textiles, electronics, cleaning supplies. The street was quieter here. The Hindi music from the speakers didn't reach this far. A lorry was unloading boxes at a warehouse entrance, two men in work clothes passing cardboard cartons hand-to-hand with the rhythm of an assembly line.

Connor found the building. It was a narrow, two-story concrete structure with a roller shutter at the front -- currently down -- and a sign above it in English and Chinese: **GLOBAL TECH WHOLESALE SDN BHD**. An electronics wholesaler. Just as Felix had described. The sign was faded and the building was unremarkable, the kind of place you'd walk past without seeing, which was, of course, part of the arrangement.

He walked around to the back, as instructed.

The alley behind the building was narrow and shaded, the kind of space that existed between buildings in KL by accident rather than design -- a gap where rubbish bins sat and air-conditioning units dripped condensation and cats investigated things in the shadows. The ground was uneven concrete, cracked and stained. A steel door was set into the back wall of the building, painted grey, no handle on the outside. No window. No signage. Just a door, in a wall, in an alley.

Connor knocked twice.

He waited. The alley was quiet. He could hear the lorry at the warehouse a few doors down, the distant hum of traffic on the main road, a bird somewhere above him producing a sound like a squeaky hinge. The jasmine garland on his daypack strap was wilting already in the heat, the petals browning at the edges.

The door opened.

A man stood in the doorway. Middle-aged, Chinese-Malaysian, with close-cropped grey hair and a face that gave nothing away. He wore a white polo shirt and dark trousers and he looked at Connor the way you'd look at a package on your doorstep -- noting its presence without welcoming it.

"Hi," Connor said. "I'm here from Felix? I've got a delivery."

The man said nothing. His eyes dropped to Connor's daypack.

Connor swung the bag off his shoulder, unzipped it, and pulled out the brown paper package. He held it out. The man took it with both hands -- quickly, smoothly, the way you'd receive something you'd been expecting. He didn't thank Connor. He didn't make eye contact. He didn't step aside to reveal the interior of the building, which remained a dark rectangle behind him, lit by the blue-white glow of fluorescent tubes. Connor caught a glimpse of shelves, of cardboard boxes stacked to the ceiling, of something that might have been a counter or a desk, and then the man stepped back and the door began to close.

The whole exchange took fifteen seconds.

The door shut with a click that was softer than Connor expected -- not a slam, not a statement, just a quiet, mechanical sealing of one space from another. Like an airlock. Like a mouth closing around something it didn't want to show you.

Connor stood in the alley for a moment.

Something bothered him.

He couldn't identify it. It wasn't the man's silence -- some people were quiet. It wasn't the back door -- wholesale operations often used rear entrances for deliveries. It wasn't the steel door itself, or the lack of signage, or the fluorescent light. It was something about the totality. The silence, the speed, the avoidance of eye contact, the door closing before he could see inside. It was the feeling you get when you're watching a movie and the music changes key and you know something is about to happen even though nothing on screen has changed. A tonal shift. An atmospheric pressure drop.

*That was weird,* Connor thought.

And then his phone buzzed.

He pulled it from his pocket. A GrabPay notification.

**RM300 received from F. DECKER**

Three hundred ringgit. The number sat on his screen in the clean sans-serif font of financial apps, simple and undeniable. Ninety-something dollars. For walking a box through a colorful neighborhood and handing it to a man through a steel door. The discomfort in his chest -- the tonal shift, the atmospheric pressure drop -- receded like a tide going out. Not disappeared. Receded. The difference was important, because disappeared would have meant it was resolved, and receded meant it was still there, under the surface, waiting for the next thing to bring it back.

But Connor didn't do subtext. Connor didn't do undercurrents. Connor lived on the surface of his life the way a water strider lives on the surface of a pond -- entirely, confidently, and with no understanding whatsoever of the depth beneath him.

He pocketed his phone, walked out of the alley, and stopped for a teh tarik at a streetside cart, drinking it in three long gulps. He paid with a five and told the vendor to keep the change, feeling generous and expansive -- an identity he could afford now.

The garland on his daypack had given up entirely, jasmine petals browning and dropping from the string. He plucked it off and draped it over a bollard. A small offering, left by a man who didn't know he was praying.

---

He walked back through Brickfields toward Chinatown, passing KL Sentral where commuters streamed in and out in office clothes and reusable coffee cups. Connor moved through them like a different species -- board shorts, flip-flops, daypack, man-bun. Two worlds, occupying the same pavement, going in opposite directions.

He was feeling good. Better than good. Seven hundred ringgit total now, from three deliveries over four days. That was more than his parents sent him in a week. That was financial independence, or something close to it.

He crossed a main road and on the far side, a police officer was standing on the corner.

He was standing the way Malaysian police officers stand -- feet apart, hands behind his back, the posture of a man who has been given a post and intends to occupy it with maximum visibility. He wore the dark blue uniform of the Royal Malaysia Police, peaked cap pulled low, and he was speaking on his phone, his free hand resting on his belt near the holstered baton. He was not looking at Connor. He was looking at nothing in particular. He was just *present* -- a uniform, an authority, a representative of a system that Connor did not understand and had never tried to.

The officer glanced up as Connor passed.

Connor's stomach dropped.

It was instant, involuntary, and total -- a flash of fear so pure and primal it bypassed every cognitive filter he'd built and hit him in the gut like a physical blow. His hand tightened on his daypack strap. His pace quickened by a half-step. His vision narrowed for a fraction of a second, tunneling, the officer's blue uniform becoming the only thing in his visual field, everything else -- the traffic, the pedestrians, the bus, the orange-sticky kid -- falling away into peripheral noise.

His body knew. Without language, without logic -- adrenal glands firing, heart rate spiking, muscles tensing along the flight pathway. The ancient mammalian hardware preparing to run from a predator it had identified before the thinking brain registered the threat.

Then the thinking brain caught up: *I'm not carrying anything.* The package was delivered. The bag was empty. He was clean.

Connor's hand loosened on the strap. He smiled at the officer. The officer didn't smile back -- his eyes lingered a moment and moved on. A non-event.

Connor walked on. He didn't explore the connection between the flash of fear and the package he'd just delivered, between the adrenal spike and the brown paper and packing tape and the weight that was wrong. He didn't ask himself the question his nervous system had just asked and answered in the space of a heartbeat: *Why would an innocent man be afraid of a police officer?*

He walked on, because Connor Briggs walked on from everything -- from warning signs and proverbs and guidebook sections and women who tried to tell him things -- and the walking on was not a conscious strategy but a reflex, as automatic and as doomed as the rabbit that freezes in headlights and then bolts too late.

Two blocks later, the fear was gone. Not resolved -- gone. Overwritten by the smell of satay, the brightness of the sky, the pleasant weight of RM300 in his digital wallet.

He stopped on a pedestrian bridge and leaned against the railing. The Towers caught the late morning light to the east. Below him, traffic poured through an intersection in streams of color and noise. He was absolutely certain he was winning at life -- the certainty of a man who had never once stopped moving long enough to check whether the ground beneath his feet was solid.

---

That evening, Connor was on the vinyl couch, phone in hand, scrolling Instagram.

He'd showered, eaten Mama Siti's nasi lemak (she'd looked at him again with that expression he couldn't read, the one that seemed to come from a long way away), and settled in with the comfortable heaviness of a man who'd earned his evening. Priya was in the kitchen making tea. They hadn't talked about last night's kiss yet. Everything was later with Connor.

His thumb moved through the feed on autopilot -- swipe, pause, double-tap. Sunsets, flat-lays, hostel memes. He drifted into the Explore page, Instagram's algorithmic underworld, where the app served you content based on your pauses and taps and the things you looked at two seconds longer than other things.

A post caught his eye.

The account was @HostelReaper.

Connor's thumb stopped. He recognized the name -- the graffiti on the wall in Chinatown, the day he'd arrived with Jake and Priya. The black marker, the small reaper icon, the words *Check-in is optional. Check-out is not.* He'd photographed it. Called it "sick street art." Hadn't thought about it since.

The profile picture was a black square. No bio, no highlights. Just a grid of posts -- backpacker gear in empty spaces.

The post in his Explore feed was a photo of a backpack sitting on an empty bus seat. Blue and grey, medium-sized, centered in the frame as if someone had placed it there and then ceased to exist. Flat fluorescent light. No people. No reflections. Just the bag, alone.

The caption: *Another one packed for the journey. #NoReturn #101Ways*

The discomfort from the delivery -- the steel door, the weight, the police officer -- flickered in Connor's chest. A pilot light of anxiety.

He looked at the photo for three more seconds. Then he scrolled.

The next post was a girl in a bikini on a beach in Bali. Connor double-tapped. A red heart bloomed.

The @HostelReaper post was already gone -- scrolled past, pushed down by algorithms and the devastating efficiency of a thumb on glass. Gone, like a proverb spoken in a kitchen. Like a name carved in wood.

---

The dorm was dark.

Connor lay in Bed 7, bottom bunk, the mattress foam thin enough to feel the wooden slats beneath. The ceiling fan clicked overhead -- the off-balance blade, the irregular metronome, counting out the night in its broken rhythm. The room smelled of insect repellent and damp wood and the faintly sweet rot of an old building in a wet climate. Through the air well opening at the far end of the room, the sounds of the city settling: a motorcycle, distant, fading. A television in another dorm, volume low. The breathing of other sleepers in other bunks, the private sounds of unconscious bodies, undisturbed. The tick of the building cooling, contracting, doing whatever old buildings do when the humans inside them sleep.

His phone buzzed.

The screen lit up in the darkness, painting his face blue-white, illuminating the wooden bed frame above him, the slats, the underside of the mattress, the graffiti carved and written by travelers past. He held the phone close to his face, squinting.

Felix.

*Good work today. You're a natural, Connor. I've got something bigger coming up -- more money. Let me know when you're ready.*

Connor read the message twice. *Good work. Natural. More money. Ready.* Each word a compliment, a validation, a small brick in the edifice of a version of himself that he wanted to believe in. Felix saw potential in him that his parents didn't, that his sister didn't, that the yoga studio in Northcote that paid him $150 a month to run their Instagram certainly didn't.

The screen's glow caught the wooden bed frame inches from his pillow. There, in the grain of the dark wood, five letters had been carved with something sharp -- a key, a knife, a fingernail pressed hard enough to leave a mark in the soft timber. The letters were small and careful, the work of someone who had been trying to be quiet, who had carved in the dark, in this bed, in this room, while the ceiling fan clicked above them the way it clicked above Connor now.

**LENA**

The light from his phone fell across the name for two full seconds. The L and the E and the N and the A were illuminated in blue-white, each letter distinct, each groove visible. The name of a twenty-two-year-old Swedish girl who had slept in this bed, who had met a charming European man in this common room, who had carried packages for that man through these streets, who was now in Kajang Prison waiting for a trial that would not go well. The name was right there. It was inches from Connor's face. All he had to do was turn his head slightly to the left. All he had to do was look.

Connor did not look. He was looking at his phone. He was composing a reply.

He typed a thumbs-up emoji and hit send.

The screen went dark. The room went dark. The name went dark, sinking back into the wood grain, invisible, patient, carved into the architecture of the bed frame like a footnote in a book no one was reading.

Somewhere on the third floor, in the private room he paid triple for, Felix Decker noted the thumbs-up emoji and updated a spreadsheet on his laptop. The spreadsheet had columns for names, dates, amounts, and reliability ratings. Connor's reliability rating had just been upgraded from 3 to 4. The scale went to 5. No one had ever reached 5. Lena had been a 4 when they arrested her.

Connor put his phone on the mattress beside his pillow, rolled onto his right side, and closed his eyes.

Sleep came quickly, as it always did for Connor. He had the gift of the unburdened mind -- the ability to pass from wakefulness to sleep without the intermediate purgatory of reflection that kept so many people staring at ceilings in the dark. No review of the day, no accounting of choices, no inventory of things that might have been done differently. Consciousness to unconsciousness in sixty seconds, like a light switch being flipped. Like a door closing.

In his sleep, Connor dreamed. A grey room, windowless, fluorescent. His blue travel towel in his hands, wrapped tight around something dense. He couldn't see what. Someone behind him he couldn't turn to see -- not wouldn't, couldn't, the dream's logic walling off the action like a locked door. The towel constricting, the microfiber pulling taut. The light buzzing louder. The presence closer. His fingers white-knuckled and unable to let go.

He woke gasping, heart hammering, sheets damp. The ceiling fan clicked its broken rhythm. The dream was already dissolving -- grey walls, a buzzing light, something in his hands, someone behind him -- falling apart even as he tried to hold the images. Within thirty seconds the dream was just a feeling. Within a minute the feeling was just a heartbeat. Within two minutes, nothing.

He reached for his phone by reflex, then stopped. The screen would light up and the blue-white glow would find Lena's name in the wood grain, though Connor didn't know this and would never know it, because he had never looked at the bed frame closely enough to see.

He closed his eyes. The fan clicked.

By morning, the dream would be gone. Only his body would carry it -- a bruise below thought, pulsing once before it too faded.

The law doesn't require your belief. That's what makes it the law.

Connor slept. The name waited in the wood.
# Chapter 9: The Map of the Dead

The door was behind reception, and Connor had walked past it every day for eleven days without seeing it.

This was not difficult. The door was the same colour as the wall -- a mottled cream that had once been white, softened by decades of tropical damp into something organic, something that looked less like paint and more like skin. There was no sign on it, no handle visible from the common room side, just a thin vertical line where the door met the frame, hairline-thin, barely distinguishable from the cracks that ran through the plaster like the building's own nervous system. If you didn't know it was there, it was a wall. If you did know, it was a door. This was the kind of detail that said something about Uncle Razak, though Connor would never work out exactly what.

It was mid-morning on Day 11, and Connor was in the common room eating Mama Siti's nasi lemak with the reverent focus of a man who had discovered religion through coconut rice. His phone was propped against a water bottle, filming the plate at an angle that made the banana leaf look like an artifact from an undiscovered civilisation. He was composing the caption in his head -- *When the hostel aunty's cooking is so good you consider permanent residency* -- when Uncle Razak appeared.

"Appeared" was the right word. Razak had a way of being in a room that bypassed the conventional mechanics of arrival. One moment the common room contained Connor, his nasi lemak, and the background furniture of hostel life -- the bookshelf, the jigsaw puzzle, the TV showing a cooking competition in Mandarin. The next moment there was also a man of approximately sixty-three years standing beside the reception desk, as though the building had generated him from its own substance.

Uncle Razak bin Omar was a large man made small by posture -- broad-shouldered, barrel-chested, his thick scarred hands hanging at his sides like tools he no longer quite needed. His face was round and deeply creased, the skin darkened to mahogany by six decades of equatorial sun, and when he smiled the creases deepened into something that looked genuinely warm. He wore a batik shirt in blues and browns, loose cotton trousers, and plastic sandals. Reading glasses hung from a cord around his neck.

"Connor!" He said everyone's name like that -- with the exclamation mark audible. "Come, come. You have finished eating? I want to show you something interesting."

He reached behind the reception counter, found a point on the wall that looked like wall, and pushed. The door opened inward on silent hinges, revealing a narrow corridor lit by a single bulb, and beyond it, a room. "My office."

Connor followed. The corridor was barely two metres long, the air different here -- cooler, drier, carrying the particular smell of newsprint ageing in a humid climate. Not quite mould, not quite dust. The olfactory equivalent of sepia.

Razak's office was small. A wooden desk scarred by decades of use, piled with papers and ledgers and a laptop so old it might have been the communal Dell's grandfather. A leather chair, cracked, the stuffing leaking from one arm. A reading lamp with a green glass shade casting amber across the desk. A shelf of books lined up with a collector's neatness: *The Backpacker Murders*, *Death Abroad*, *Hostel: The True Stories*, *Missing Persons of Southeast Asia*. All true crime.

But it was the walls that stopped him.

Every surface that wasn't shelf or door was covered. Newspaper clippings, dozens of them, pinned directly to the plaster in overlapping layers -- some yellowed to the colour of old teeth, some recent enough that the ink was still sharp. Different languages: English, Malay, Thai, German, French, Indonesian. Headlines visible even in the low light:

*FIRE IN BUDAPEST HOSTEL KILLS 4 -- FAULTY WIRING BLAMED*

*BACKPACKER DIES IN BARCELONA BALCONY FALL -- RAILING FOUND DEFECTIVE*

*METHANOL POISONING IN VANG VIENG: 5 TOURISTS HOSPITALISED, 3 DEAD*

*CAPE TOWN BACKPACKERS' MURDER: SUSPECT ARRESTED*

Some clippings had handwritten notes in the margins -- dates, names, annotations in Razak's cramped script. Some were circled in red pen. Some had single words: *avoidable*, *covered up*, *no investigation*.

And on the wall behind the desk, dominating the room the way the Petronas Towers dominated the skyline: a map.

Large -- at least a metre wide -- a standard Mercator projection stuck with red pins, small and round-headed. Connor's eyes moved across the continents: three pins in Western Europe, two in Eastern, five across South America, one in Australia, two in Africa. And Southeast Asia -- Southeast Asia was a constellation. The pins there were so dense they overlapped, a cluster of red dots marking Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Malaysia. Thirty pins in that region alone. Maybe forty. Each pin had a small paper tag dangling from it by thread: a name, a year, a cause.

*Bangkok 2014 -- CO. Quito 2017 -- Fall. Phnom Penh 2019 -- Methanol. Siem Reap 2016 -- Drowning. Pai 2012 -- Motorbike.*

Connor stood in the doorway and stared. The map covered the entire wall. The red pins were like a disease, spreading outward from a central mass in Southeast Asia, thinning at the edges of the world but never disappearing entirely. There were pins in Alaska. There were pins in New Zealand. Wherever people slept in shared rooms in foreign countries, the red pins followed.

"Sit, sit," Razak said, squeezing past to his desk. He lowered himself into the leather chair with the deliberate care of a man whose knees had opinions. "I'll make tea."

From a shelf hidden behind papers, he produced two metal cups and a warm kettle and performed a trick Connor had seen in hawker stalls but never in an office. He raised one cup above his head and poured the tea in a long, arcing stream into the cup held at waist height -- the liquid falling in a smooth amber rope, foaming as it hit the surface. He switched hands, pouring back, the stream longer this time, a full arm's length of liquid suspended in air, catching the desk lamp's light like a thread of gold. Back and forth, three times, four, the foam building on the surface.

"Teh tarik," Razak said, setting a cup in front of Connor. "Pulled tea. The secret is the height. The higher you pour, the better the foam." He smiled. "In the old days, the tea stall operators on Petaling Street would compete to see who could pull the highest. Two metres, three metres. The champion was a man named Ah Beng who could pour from a stepladder and not spill a drop. He's dead now. Heart attack. But the tea lives on."

The teh tarik was sweet, milky, rich -- condensed milk and strong black tea, the foam on top thick enough to leave a moustache.

"This," Razak said, nodding at the walls, "is my collection."

He sipped. He let the word settle.

"Fifteen years ago, a boy died in a hostel in Chiang Mai. Carbon monoxide from a faulty water heater. He went to sleep in the shower and never woke up." Razak pointed to a pin in northern Thailand. "The hostel covered it up. Filed it as a heart attack. The family never knew the truth. Nobody else records them, Connor. The hostels cover them up. The police file them away. But I remember."

His finger moved across the map. "Bangkok, 2014. Three dead -- carbon monoxide, faulty heater. A whole dorm. An American, a Briton, a Canadian. The hostel changed its name and reopened three months later." Another pin. "Quito, 2017 -- a girl, Swedish, twenty-two. Fell from a fourth-floor balcony. The railing had been loose for months. Guests had complained." Another. "Phnom Penh, 2019 -- methanol in the rice wine. Five backpackers poisoned, two survived. The bar closed. Another opened in the same location six weeks later, different name."

Connor leaned forward, both hands around the teh tarik, eyes moving between Razak's face and the map. He was fascinated. Not with the weight of it, not with the accumulation of preventable death. Connor was fascinated the way he was fascinated by anything with narrative potential. He was seeing content. He was seeing posts. He was seeing a thread, a series, a story that his 4,200 followers would find darkly compelling.

"Uncle," he said, "this is sick."

Razak looked at him.

"Like, in a good way. How many pins are on there?"

"Sixty-seven. That I know of. The real number is higher. Hotels keep records. Hostels keep secrets."

"Can I photograph the map?"

He was already reaching for his phone, already framing the shot -- the red pins catching the desk lamp's light, the handwritten tags like tiny epitaphs. He'd caption it: *The death map. Uncle Razak at The Lantern Hostel has been tracking backpacker deaths for 15 years. Every red pin is someone who didn't come home.* The hashtags wrote themselves.

Razak hesitated. Then he waved his hand. "Sure, sure."

Connor took six photos from different angles. Close-ups of the Southeast Asian pins. A wide shot of the whole map. Detail shots of the tags.

"You should start a podcast, Uncle. Seriously. 'Deaths in Hostels.' True crime is massive right now. You'd get a huge following."

Razak sat behind his desk, watching Connor photograph the dead the way you'd photograph street art. "These are real people, Connor."

"No, yeah, totally. That's what makes it so powerful. Every pin is a story. You could do an episode per death. That's a Netflix series right there."

Razak looked at him for a long time. The expression on his face was difficult to categorise -- something between pity and disgust, with recognition underneath. He'd seen this type before. The bright, confident young traveler who walks through the world seeing everything as raw material, every human experience as something to be captured and captioned and posted for strangers who will scroll past it in three seconds.

He offered more tea. He changed the subject.

---

"The building has been many things," Razak said, refilling Connor's cup with the theatrical pour.

"Built in 1928. A Hokkien textile warehouse. Then the Japanese came." The word settled in the room the way a heavy stone settles in water. "1942 to 1945. This building was used as an administrative office. That's the official record." He paused. "Unofficially, people went in and did not come out. The old neighbours call it *rumah tangisan*. The house of crying. You've seen the Japanese characters on the second-floor landing? Under the paint?"

Connor had. He'd walked past them every day without thinking about what they said.

"After the war, the Lim family reclaimed the building, but they didn't live here. Nobody wanted to live here. They rented the ground floor to a businessman who ran a gambling den through the fifties and sixties. Mahjong, mostly. Illegal, of course, but this was Chinatown in the old days -- the police came for tea and left with their pockets full." He chuckled, but the chuckle was thin. "Then a brothel in the seventies. Women from Indonesia, the Philippines, some local." He touched the desk. "This was the madam's room. The blue tiles in the hallway -- she chose those. After the brothel closed, the building sat empty for twenty years. When I renovated, we found things in the walls. Japanese military buttons. Old mahjong tiles. A woman's shoe." He tapped the desk. "Every use leaves something behind. The building doesn't forget."

Connor's phone was in his hand, filming. "That's content gold, Uncle. Seriously. You could do ghost tours. 'The Haunted Hostel of Petaling Street.' Charge fifty ringgit a head."

Something moved in Razak's expression -- something tired and faintly nauseated. The expression of a man watching someone use a gravestone as a selfie stick.

"The building has seen enough commerce. It doesn't need to sell its dead."

He poured more tea. Changed the subject with the practised redirection of a man who had been a host for seventeen years. Then he set down his cup and said, very quietly:

"Be careful who you trust in this city, Connor. Not everyone who smiles at you is your friend."

The words sat between them. The desk lamp flickered -- a momentary brownout in the old wiring -- and the newspaper clippings on the walls seemed to shift.

Connor smiled. "You're alright, Uncle. Everyone here is awesome."

Razak watched him go. He didn't finish his tea. He didn't stand. He sat behind his desk in the amber light, in his small room papered with the dead, and looked at the map. His eyes found a pin in Kuala Lumpur -- one among many, unremarkable, positioned right where they were sitting. The tag read: *KL 2025 -- Custody.* A girl. Swedish. Twenty-two. The name he never said aloud. Lena. The name that was also scratched into the wooden frame of Bed 7, where Connor slept every night without seeing it.

Razak had known about the trafficking network for years. He had known about Felix -- not this Felix specifically, but the Felixes, the succession of charming Europeans who passed through Chinatown with too much cash and too little luggage, who befriended the lonely and the broke. He had made his arrangement: they don't recruit from his hostel, he doesn't call the police. The arrangement had protected him. It had protected his guests. It had worked, in the way that all bargains with the dark work -- as long as nobody looked at it too closely.

Felix had broken the arrangement. Felix had recruited Connor from inside the hostel, from the common room, from under the red lanterns that Razak had hung with his own hands. And Razak had told Connor to be careful, and Connor had smiled, and the arrangement was broken and there was nothing left to do but sit in the amber light and know what was coming and not stop it.

He reached for his tea. It was cold.

---

The Petaling Street night market was a different creature after dark.

The harsh daytime fluorescents were supplemented by strings of LED lights -- white, blue, orange -- that turned the canopy into a low-slung galaxy. Food stalls dominated: charcoal smoke rose through the lights like fog, carrying the smell of satay and char kway teow and the caramelised edges of frying popiah. Chinese opera music drifted from a tinny speaker, the falsetto wail rising and falling over the crowd noise like a bird circling above a forest.

Connor walked through it with Priya on his left and Jake on his right, and for a suspended half-hour, nothing else existed. The press of the crowd was warm and chaotic -- tourists with cameras, locals with shopping bags, children darting between legs. The calls of vendors layered over each other in Cantonese and Mandarin and English: "Hey, you want bag? Good price!" "Best watch, real leather!" "Makan, makan, come eat!" The air was thick with charcoal smoke and frying oil and the sugary tang of shaved ice being drizzled with syrup at a dessert stall.

He was generous with his money -- Felix's money. The RM700 from three deliveries sat in his account like a small promotion, lifting him from anxiety to ease. Two envelopes and a package, delivered without incident, without a single question about what he was carrying or for whom. The money changed who he was. It made him the person he wanted to be: the one with his hand in his pocket, the one who said "I've got this."

At the clothing stalls, he pulled a fake Supreme t-shirt from a rack -- white, with the familiar red box logo across the chest. The lettering was slightly too thick and the tag said SUPPREME if you looked closely, which no one would.

"How much?"

"Thirty."

"Twenty-five."

The vendor, a young woman scrolling her phone, didn't look up. "Fine."

Connor dropped the money on the counter. "There you go, mate. Early Christmas present."

Jake held the shirt up against his sunburned chest. "Dude. You didn't have to do that."

"I know. I'm a legend. Put it on."

Jake pulled his old shirt off right there in the market and pulled on the fake Supreme, and several vendors watched this display with the practised indifference of people who had seen far stranger things on Petaling Street.

At a jade stall near the temple end, Connor stopped. Small table, green velvet, trays of jade jewelry in shades from nearly black to the pale translucent colour of new leaves. He pointed at a bracelet -- thin, delicate, deep forest green.

"How much?"

The vendor held up three fingers.

"Try it on," he told Priya.

"Connor, no--"

"Just try it."

She picked it up. The jade was cool against her dark skin, vivid green against brown. She turned her hand, watching the light move across the stone's surface. The bracelet was slightly too large, sliding toward her knuckles, and she pushed it back -- a small, unconscious gesture, the gesture of a woman who has already imagined owning this thing.

"Done." Connor handed the vendor fifty ringgit. "Keep the change."

"You don't need to buy me things," Priya said, in the tone of someone simultaneously touched and annoyed.

"I know. I want to."

She looked at the bracelet on her wrist. She pushed her glasses up -- the diagnostic gesture. Then: "Thank you." Her voice was different. Simpler. The irony stripped away.

The bracelet cost thirty ringgit -- about ten Australian dollars. A sum that had come from an envelope delivered to a man in Bukit Bintang whose name Connor didn't know, on behalf of a German whose business Connor didn't question. The jade sat on Priya's wrist like a small, green promise, and it was beautiful, and it was paid for with money that was not clean, and neither of them knew this.

They ate satay. A vendor at the market's edge was working a charcoal grill, the coals glowing orange-red, plumes of smoke spiralling into the LED lights above. Thirty sticks of marinated chicken, peanut sauce thick enough to stand a skewer in, compressed rice cake, cucumber wedges. They stood at the counter and ate with their hands and didn't speak because speaking would have been an interruption. They drank fresh coconut water from green coconuts hacked open with machetes -- the juice cool and faintly sweet, cutting through the richness of the satay.

Then Jake announced he needed a watch.

At the stall, he pointed at a gold Rolex Submariner.

"Eighty ringgit," the vendor said.

Jake straightened up, his face set in borrowed seriousness. "I watched a TED Talk about negotiation. You say eighty, I say twenty, we meet in the middle." He paused. "So. I'll give you a hundred."

The vendor blinked. Looked at Connor. Connor shook his head. The vendor looked back at Jake.

"One hundred ringgit," he said. "For a watch I was selling for eighty. Deal."

He took the note with the delicate speed of a man pocketing a miracle.

Priya laughed. Not the measured, ironic half-laugh she deployed for Connor's jokes, but a real laugh -- full and sudden and surprised out of her, her head tipping back, her hand going to her mouth, her glasses sliding down her nose. Jake started laughing because Priya was laughing, and Connor started laughing because the night was warm and the market was beautiful and Priya's laugh was the best sound he'd heard in twelve countries.

For a moment -- brief, specific, unrepeatable -- everything was perfect. The three of them stood under a canopy of LED lights and charcoal smoke, laughing about a fake watch, and the Guan Di Temple glowed red and gold at the end of the market with incense smoke rising from its open doors, and somewhere a speaker played Chinese opera in a high, wavering voice that sounded like it was singing about something that had happened a long time ago and would happen again.

Connor reached for Priya's hand. She let him take it. Her fingers were cool from the coconut water, and the jade bracelet slid against his wrist as their hands interlocked. She was watching Jake try to take a selfie with his new watch -- an operation requiring both hands, which Jake was solving by holding the phone in his teeth. She was smiling. Not the diagnostic smile. Just smiling.

Connor held her hand and felt, with a clarity that surprised him, happy. Not content. Not performing happiness for an audience. Just happy, the way a glass is full, the way a room is warm.

He would think about this moment later. In a room without windows, under a light that never turned off, he would close his eyes and try to find his way back to this market, this smoke, this hand in his hand. He would try, and he would almost succeed, and then the door would open and the trying would stop.

But that was later. Now the night was young, and Priya's hand was in his, and the red and gold glow of the temple lit the smoke above the market like something sacred.

---

They walked home through the darkening streets after eleven.

The night market was contracting -- a galaxy collapsing back into ordinary matter. Metal shutters rolled down with bangs and clatters that echoed off the shophouse facades. Vendors packed fake designer goods into cardboard boxes with the practised speed of people who did this every night. The food stalls were the last to close, their grills still smoking, their fluorescent tubes still buzzing, a few last customers eating standing up with the hurried focus of people aware that the night was ending. The LED light strings went dark section by section, and the market's galaxy collapsed back into a corridor of shuttered stalls and swept pavement and the lingering smell of charcoal and peanut oil.

Jake walked ahead, filming a TikTok of himself in slow motion with his fake Rolex extended toward the camera, his narration audible from ten metres away: "When you're balling on a budget in KL. Link in bio for discount designer watches. Not sponsored but should be."

Connor and Priya walked behind, still holding hands. The street was quieter now, reduced to its nighttime essentials: a motorcycle parked at an angle, its engine ticking as it cooled; a cat picking through a rubbish bag; the distant bass of a club on Changkat, felt more than heard.

They turned the corner onto the hostel's street. The Guan Di Temple was closed, its red doors shut, but incense still leaked from the gaps, sweet and lingering. The traditional Chinese medicine store was dark, its jars of dried things invisible behind the glass. And next to it, Wei's phone repair shop.

The light was on.

The fluorescent tube cast a flat, blue-white light onto the pavement -- the kind of light that made everything it touched look slightly ill. Through the cluttered window display -- cracked screens, coiled USB cables, a handwritten sign reading REPAIR CHEAP FAST -- two figures were standing at the counter inside. One was Wei, the quiet Chinese-Malaysian man in his forties Connor had seen every day, always bent over a phone with a magnifying glass. The other was Felix.

Connor stopped walking. Felix was leaning forward, hands flat on the counter. Wei was opposite, also leaning forward. Between them, on the surface, something Connor couldn't quite make out through the glass -- a shape. It could have been a phone. It could have been a box. Their body language was not customer and shopkeeper. It was the tense, focused intensity of a negotiation, or a briefing -- two men discussing something that mattered.

Connor raised his hand and waved.

Felix looked up.

For one second -- too brief for analysis, too long for comfort -- Felix's face was not the face Connor knew. The warm smile was absent. The easy charm was absent. What remained was something Connor had never seen on Felix's features: flat, still, and cold. Not angry. Not surprised. Just empty. The way a shop window is empty after closing, the displays removed, the lights still on but illuminating nothing.

Then the second passed. Felix raised a hand -- not a wave, a half-gesture, an acknowledgement -- and his mouth moved in something that stopped short of a smile. He turned back to Wei. He did not come to the door. He did not call out. He did not do any of the things Felix always did when he saw Connor.

Connor's hand was still raised. He lowered it.

"What's Felix doing in there?" Jake asked, appearing beside them.

"Probably getting his phone fixed. His screen's been cracked for weeks."

Felix's phone screen was not cracked. Connor had seen him using it that morning, the screen perfectly intact. He knew this, and he said the other thing, and the lie came out smooth and easy, because lying about something you don't want to think about isn't lying -- it's management. The management of a reality you haven't decided to examine yet.

Priya said nothing. She'd looked at the phone shop when Connor stopped. She'd looked at Felix through the glass, at the counter between them, at the posture of two men who were not discussing phone repairs. She'd looked at Connor's face when Felix didn't wave back -- the brief confusion, the quick smoothing-over, the lie that came too easily. She saw something, or the beginning of something, or the shadow of something that hadn't fully formed. But she didn't say it. She held Connor's hand, and she walked, and the jade bracelet was cool on her wrist.

---

Bed 7 in Dorm 3 at midnight was a coffin of foam and vinyl and the breathing of strangers.

Connor lay on his back, staring at the underside of the bunk above him -- the stickers, the carved graffiti, the ghost of a Che Guevara someone had tried to scrape off. The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.* Through the air well, a motorcycle in the distance. Then silence. Then a cat. Then silence again.

He thought about the night market. Priya's hand in his, warm and then cool. Her laugh -- real, unguarded, the kind of laugh that breaks out of a person rather than being performed by one. The jade bracelet, green against brown, sliding on her wrist. Jake's face, guileless and happy, strapping on his overpaid watch with the satisfaction of a man who believed he'd won.

He thought about Uncle Razak's map. Sixty-seven red pins. He could still see the Southeast Asian constellation, thick as a rash. He thought about the pin in Kuala Lumpur -- Razak tapping it with his thick finger, saying quietly: "This one is nearby. A girl. Swedish. Last year." He hadn't elaborated. Connor hadn't asked. The Swedish girl. The pin. The cause of death -- *Custody* -- a word he hadn't thought about, hadn't connected to anything, hadn't allowed to mean what it meant.

He thought about Felix.

The thought arrived clearly, like a bubble rising from deep water. It broke the surface of his mind and sat there, perfectly formed: *What if Felix isn't what he says he is?*

He examined it. He turned it over. He held it up to the light.

Then he popped it.

*Felix is a legend. Felix is my mate. Felix gave me RM700 for basically nothing. That's not sketchy, that's generous.* Felix paying cash for everything? He's European; Europeans use cash. Felix's private room for two months? He values his space. Felix's too-good stories? He's been travelling for years. Felix's cold expression through the phone shop glass? Connor caught him off-guard. Everyone looks weird when they're caught off-guard.

*It means nothing. It all means nothing.*

The rationalisation was smooth and fast and complete, a machine of self-deception so well-oiled it ran without friction. Each doubt was met by a counter-doubt. Each shadow was chased by a spotlight. The machine hummed, and the doubt dissolved, and Connor was left with the warm residue of certainty.

He turned over. The mattress squeaked under him. He thought about Priya's hand because that was warm and good, and the other thing -- the thought about Felix, the cold expression, the phone shop at eleven PM -- was cold and uncertain and would, if he let it grow, threaten everything warm and good.

So he didn't let it grow. He did what he always did with uncomfortable information. He changed the channel. He swiped left on the truth and right on the story he preferred, and the algorithm of his own mind delivered exactly what he wanted: reassurance, comfort, the conviction that everything was fine.

Everything was fine. Everything was absolutely fine.

He closed his eyes. Sleep came slowly, then all at once. He didn't dream. The building dreamed for him -- its old wood creaking, its pipes humming, its ghosts walking corridors that had been corridors for a century, past the Japanese characters on the second-floor landing, past the blue tiles the brothel madam had chosen, past the hidden door to Razak's office where sixty-seven red pins marked sixty-seven stories that had ended badly.

At seven-fifteen the next morning, his phone buzzed on the mattress beside his head. He reached for it with his eyes still closed.

A text from Felix.

*Big day tomorrow. Come find me.*

Connor read it. He smiled. He put the phone down. He rolled over.

Outside, the call to prayer rose from Masjid Jamek, long and wavering, reaching for something above the rooftops and the wires and the heat. It washed over the building and asked the same question it asked every morning, five times a day, a question that had been asked in this city for centuries:

*Are you awake? Are you listening? Do you know where you are?*

Connor was not listening. He was already asleep again, dreaming of night markets and jade bracelets and the faces of people who smiled at him, and not one of those faces, not one, belonged to the man who was going to get him killed.
# Chapter 10: Comfortable

---

The call to prayer came at 5:32 AM, as it always did, rising from the minarets of Masjid Jamek in a long, wavering note that threaded through the pre-dawn dark and found its way up the air well and through the walls of Dorm 3 and into the shallows of Connor's sleep. He heard it the way you hear rain on a window when you're warm in bed -- not as information, not as meaning, but as texture. Background. Part of the room. Part of the city. Part of what KL sounded like when you'd been there long enough that the unfamiliar had become furniture.

He rolled over, pulled the pillow across his ear, and sank back down.

When he woke again it was ten fifteen, and the heat had already settled into the dorm like something that paid rent. The ceiling fan turned overhead -- *tick, tick, tick* -- stirring the air without conviction. Through the air well, the sounds of the city rose in the familiar sequence: motorbike engines, the rattle of metal shutters going up on Petaling Street, Mama Siti's wok hitting flame in the kitchen below, and somewhere, a mynah bird making its single-note declaration into the wet morning air.

Connor lay in Bed 7 and let the sounds wash over him. He didn't reach for his phone. Not immediately. Not the way he had in the first week, when the notifications were the first pulse of the day, the proof that the outside world still knew his name. Now his phone was just there, face-down on the thin mattress beside him, and the notifications could wait because the morning could wait because everything, for the first time in four years of movement, could wait.

He was comfortable. That was the word. Not happy, exactly -- happiness was too active, too demanding. This was something more dangerous: the feeling of a man who has stopped running and found that nothing was chasing him. The panic of the first week -- the money panic, the 3 AM arithmetic on the ceiling -- had receded like a tide pulling back from shore. He was settled. He had a routine. The routine had its own gravity, and gravity doesn't feel like a trap. Gravity feels like the ground.

He swung his legs off the bunk. Dressed in the order he always dressed: board shorts, singlet -- today's read SUNSET CHASER in a font manufactured in Guangzhou -- flip-flops, leather bracelet, phone in left pocket. He splashed water on his face in the second-floor bathroom where the shower head dripped its permanent percussion onto tiles the colour of old teeth.

By the time he reached the kitchen, Mama Siti had his nasi lemak waiting.

She didn't greet him. She hadn't greeted him since day three. The banana leaf was already plated -- rice, sambal, anchovies, peanuts -- assembled with the offhand precision of someone who had made this particular constellation ten thousand times. Connor placed a five-ringgit note on the counter. It vanished. He ate with his fingers the way she'd silently taught him by the fourth morning, and thought about nothing at all.

Out the front door. Past the phone repair shop -- Wei's shop -- where the fluorescent light was on and a figure hunched over the soldering bench inside. Connor walked past without looking. He'd stopped looking weeks ago. Whatever he'd seen that night -- Felix in the shop, the way Felix hadn't waved back -- had been absorbed into the sediment of things-that-didn't-matter, compacted beneath the days that followed.

He bought a roti canai from the mamak stall on the corner. Ate it standing up, watching the market unfold: stall holders shouting in Cantonese, tourist couples consulting phones, the old man with the bird cages who sat in the same spot every morning outside the temple. Connor knew this man now. Not his name, just his presence. KL was becoming legible in a way no city had before -- not in words, but in the way your body learns a room in the dark.

At eleven, his phone buzzed.

Felix: *Got one for today. Package to Jalan Ipoh. RM300. Grab at the usual.*

Connor typed back without breaking stride: *On it.*

He collected the package from Felix's room on the third floor. Brown paper, taped shut, roughly the size of a hardcover book. Felix handed it over the way you hand someone a book you've already read: casually, without ceremony. "Jalan Ipoh. Number 47. Ask for Mr. Tan." Connor slid it into his daypack without weighing it in his hand, without asking what was inside, without thinking about it at all.

The delivery took forty minutes. Grab to Jalan Ipoh. A shophouse with a metal roller door half-raised. A man took the package, examined the tape seals, nodded once. No handshake. No small talk. The brisk efficiency of a machine completing a cycle.

Connor's phone buzzed: RM300 transferred.

Banking app in the back of the Grab: RM4,280. He was earning faster than he was spending. Connor Briggs, who had never saved a ringgit in his life, was saving money. He closed the app and posted a photo of his morning roti canai -- "#streetfood #kualalumpur #digitalnomadlife" -- without a trace of irony.

This was his fourth delivery. Two envelopes, two packages. RM700 total. He barely thought about it anymore. The deliveries had migrated from the category of *unusual things I do* to the category of *things I do*, which was a shorter journey than it sounded. First you do something strange. Then you do it again. Then it's not strange. Then it's not even something you do -- it's just something that happens, automatic as breathing. The normalization was total. The normalization was the point.

He went to Grind Culture. RM14 flat white, but now the RM14 didn't sting. Scheduled three posts for Pacific Soul. Scrolled job boards he had no intention of applying to. At two, he met Priya at the Central Market. They ate ice kacang from a stall outside, the shaved ice melting in the heat, and she told him about a patient she'd seen on placement -- a man with motor neurone disease, completely lucid, completely trapped -- and Connor listened in the way he'd learned to listen to Priya, which was not the way he listened to anyone else.

That evening he emailed his parents.

He sat on Bed 7 with his laptop balanced on his knees, the ceiling fan ticking overhead, and composed the kind of email he sent once a fortnight -- breezy, reassuring, carefully emptied of any information that might cause concern.

> Hey Mum & Dad,
>
> KL is amazing!! Seriously loving it here. The food is incredible, the people are so friendly, the city has this energy that's hard to describe. I've been doing some freelance work (social media stuff) and picking up a few local gigs so the finances are actually pretty solid for once. Been exploring the whole city -- temples, markets, even went to a mosque (don't worry, I was respectful!). Made some great friends at the hostel including this really cool girl from London who's doing medicine.
>
> Thinking I might actually stay here for a few months. It's that good. Don't worry about me -- I'm eating well, sleeping well, and being smart. Promise.
>
> Love you both. Tell Megan I said hi (she won't care but tell her anyway).
>
> Connor x

He read it back. It contained three lies, four omissions, and one truth. The truth was that he was thinking about staying for months. The omissions were Felix, the deliveries, the packages, and the RM4,280 in his account that came from carrying things for a man whose income source he had never asked about.

He hit send. Connor was thinking about extending his Malaysian visa.

---

The common room was nearly empty at three in the afternoon -- the dead hours, when the morning travelers had left for their activities and the night travelers hadn't yet stirred. The ceiling fans turned. The TV was off. The red lanterns cast their permanent warm glow across the battered furniture and the bookshelf where *The Beach* had been replaced by *The God of Small Things*, as though the bookshelf had a curriculum.

Connor was on the sofa, scrolling his phone, doing the kind of nothing that takes complete attention. Priya was in the armchair across from him, her Lonely Planet on her lap, not reading it. She was watching him. He could feel it -- the pressure of being watched by someone who sees you clearly -- but he hadn't looked up yet because looking up meant acknowledging the thing that had been sitting between them for two days, the thing that had no name but had a shape, the shape of a question that Priya had been carrying and Connor had been avoiding.

"Connor."

He looked up. She was pushing her glasses up her nose -- the gesture she made when she was about to say something careful.

"Yeah?"

"Can I ask you something?"

"Always." He smiled. The Instagram smile. Confident, easy, bulletproof.

"Those deliveries you do for Felix."

The smile held. The thing behind the smile -- the thing that was not a smile at all but a wall built from charm and eye contact -- went up another six inches.

"Yeah? What about them?"

"What exactly is in the packages you carry?"

He'd been ready for this. Not consciously, but some deeper mechanism -- the survival engine that ran beneath his awareness -- had been assembling the answer for weeks. It came out smooth and warm and so reasonable it almost convinced him.

"Phone accessories. Chargers, cables, that sort of thing. Felix does consulting for import businesses. I'm basically a courier."

"Have you ever opened one?"

"No. Why would I? They're sealed for the client."

"Don't you think that's odd?"

"What's odd about it?"

Priya set the Lonely Planet down on the armrest. The rubber bands that held it together shifted, a small sound in the quiet room. She leaned forward, elbows on her knees, and looked at him with an expression he recognised from the cave at Batu -- the doctor's patience, the willingness to wait for the truth to surface on its own.

"Connor, don't you think it's odd that he won't let you see what you're carrying? That the packages are always sealed, always taped shut? That you never meet these clients in a normal place -- it's always the back of a shop, or a loading dock, or a man at a door who takes the package and closes the door?"

"It's business, babe. Confidentiality. This is how import-export works."

"It's not how import-export works." Her voice was level, controlled -- the voice of someone who had spent three years of medical school learning how to deliver information that patients didn't want to hear. "Normal businesses use courier services. DHL. FedEx. Pos Laju. They don't use backpackers carrying brown paper packages across the city by Grab."

The word *backpackers* landed wrong. He felt it in his chest -- not as logic, not as argument, but as insult. He wasn't a backpacker being used. He was an entrepreneur seizing an opportunity. There was a difference. He was certain there was a difference.

"You don't know Felix," he said.

"I know what this looks like."

"And what does it look like, Priya? What does it look like to you?"

He hadn't meant his voice to harden. It hardened anyway. The warmth between them -- the warmth that had been building for two weeks, through Batu Caves and night markets and afternoon walks and the particular intimacy of two people learning each other's rhythms -- cooled by several degrees in the time it took to finish the sentence.

Priya held his gaze. Behind the round glasses, her eyes were steady and dark and holding something that was not quite fear and not quite anger but was close enough to both that the distinction didn't matter.

"It looks like something I've read about," she said. "In the guidebook. In the news. It looks like something that happens in this part of the world to people who don't ask questions."

"Right. Because you read it in a guidebook, that makes it real. Meanwhile, I've actually been doing this. I've met Felix. I've done the deliveries. Nothing has happened. Nothing dodgy, nothing weird. Just a bloke paying me to carry phone accessories because his regular driver isn't always available."

"Connor--"

"You don't know Felix. Not the way I do. He's a photographer. He does import-export on the side. He's been nothing but good to me. And frankly--" He caught himself. The sentence had been heading toward *it's none of your business*, which was the one thing he knew, even in this moment, would break something that couldn't be fixed. He diverted. "Look, I appreciate you caring. I do. But I've been doing this for four years. Traveling, living on my own, dealing with people. I know how to read people. Felix is good people."

Priya was quiet for a long time. The ceiling fan turned. Somewhere on the second floor, a door closed. Through the air well, the sound of the afternoon call to prayer began, distant and beautiful and completely meaningless to the man on the sofa who was too busy defending his own blindness to hear anything at all.

"Okay," she said. Not agreement. Surrender of a different kind -- the surrender of someone who has extended a hand and had it pushed away and knows that extending it again will only make the refusal permanent.

She picked up her Lonely Planet. Opened it to a page she wasn't going to read. The rubber bands snapped softly against the cover.

Connor picked up his phone. Opened Instagram. Scrolled through a feed of sunsets and flat whites and people pretending their lives were curated.

Between them, in the warm amber light of the common room, a crack had appeared. It wasn't visible. It didn't make a sound. But both of them felt it -- the particular silence that descends when two people have stopped talking about the thing that matters and started performing the pretence that everything is fine.

They sat like that for twenty minutes. Then Priya closed the guidebook, said "I'm going to shower," and left the room without looking at him.

Connor watched her go. He felt a flash of guilt -- or the shadow of guilt, the pressure drop before a storm. He pushed it down. He was good at pushing things down.

*She's overthinking it. She's a med student. They're trained to see pathology everywhere.*

The rationalisation machine ran. It had been running since he was eighteen and dropped out of university and told his parents it was a *conscious choice*. It had been running every time someone told him something he didn't want to hear and he converted their concern into their problem. The crack between him and Priya didn't close. But he stopped looking at it, which amounted to the same thing.

---

Tomoko Sato did not sit down.

She appeared in the common room forty minutes after Priya left, while Connor was still on the sofa, still scrolling. She came from the staircase -- the third step squeaked -- and walked to where he was sitting and stood over him with her arms crossed.

No camera today. Plain black T-shirt, cargo pants, the red-tipped hair dark and damp. Her expression was the one she always wore -- neutral, watchful, the face of someone who had decided long ago that charm was a weapon.

"Connor. I need to say something."

He looked up from his phone. "Sure. What's up?"

"Your friend Felix."

The words landed like coins on a counter. Connor's jaw tightened. Two conversations about Felix in one afternoon. The universe apparently had opinions.

"I've seen men like him before," Tomoko said. "In Myanmar. In Laos. In the Philippines. They're always charming. They always have money. They always have a private room. They always need 'someone reliable.'"

She said *someone reliable* with quotation marks made of voice, the inflection precise and deliberate, like a scalpel unwrapping suture silk.

Connor sat up straighter. "And what exactly are you saying?"

"I'm saying be careful. The people Felix knows are not who he says they are. The money he has is not from photography."

"You don't know Felix."

"I know his type."

"His type? What, German?"

The joke -- if it was a joke -- fell into the silence and died there. Tomoko's expression didn't change. She had the particular stillness of someone who had stood in front of warlords and corrupt officials and was not going to be deflected by an Australian in a singlet attempting sarcasm.

"Dangerous," she said. "I'm saying his type is dangerous. I've watched him since the first week. The cash. The packages. The people who come to the hostel at night and go to the third floor and leave before morning. The way he looks at you when you're not looking at him."

Connor felt something cold move through his chest -- a quick, involuntary contraction, the body's honest response to a truth the mind had not yet processed. The way he looks at you when you're not looking at him. For a half-second, the image surfaced: Felix in Wei's shop, bent over the table, not waving back. The camera-flash memory of something seen and immediately unseen.

He pushed it down. The machine ran.

"Look, I don't know what your problem is with Felix. He's my mate. He's been nothing but good to me. He's helped me out when I was broke, he's introduced me to people, he's--" Connor heard himself building the case and felt the familiar heat of defensive certainty, the kind that burns hottest when you're defending something you haven't examined. "And frankly, it's none of your business."

Tomoko looked at him for a long moment. The ceiling fan turned overhead. Through the air well, the mynah bird sang its one note.

"I've said what I came to say," she said.

She walked away. Her footsteps were quiet on the cracked tiles. The third step didn't squeak on the way up -- she knew where to place her feet, the way someone who watches everything learns the geography of a building's betrayals.

Connor watched her go and felt the guilt arrive faster this time -- a hot bloom in his stomach. *She's just uptight. She's probably jealous she didn't think of the side hustle herself.*

The rationalisations came, each one thinner than the last, like cards from a deck running out.

*Felix is a photographer. It's import-export. The packages are phone accessories. I've done four deliveries and nothing has happened. Nothing has happened. Nothing has happened.*

He said it three times because repetition is how spells work, and what Connor was doing -- what he had been doing since the first envelope -- was casting a spell on himself. An incantation of normalcy. A prayer to the god of she'll-be-right. And the god answered, as that god always does, by making the thing you're afraid of invisible for a little while longer.

He went upstairs to shower. Stood under the cold spray and felt the two warnings -- Priya's face, Tomoko's voice -- circle each other in his mind like fish in a bowl, going around and around, never arriving anywhere. The water ran. The warnings dissolved. He towelled off with the blue Sea to Summit and went to meet Priya for dinner as though nothing had happened, because the definition of *something happening* was one he controlled, and he had decided that this wasn't it.

---

The rooftop at night was the place where Connor went to feel like the person he performed on Instagram.

The plastic chairs. The clothesline swaying empty. The Petronas Towers between the shophouse roofs and the snarl of electrical wire, silver and luminous against the dark. It was after eleven. Priya had gone to bed early. They'd had dinner at the Indian place on Jalan Tun Sambanthan -- the conversation warm but careful, two people navigating around the thing they'd argued about.

She'd kissed him goodnight at the door to Dorm 4. A brief kiss, her hand on his arm. Then the door closed and he'd stood in the hallway trying to name the feeling in his chest, which was something between gratitude and loss, like holding a cup you know you're going to drop.

Now he was alone. He had a Tiger, bought from the cooler behind reception, RM8, paid for with Felix's money -- though Connor didn't think of it as Felix's money anymore. It was his money. He'd earned it. It was all just logistics. Just moving things from one place to another.

He called his mother.

She picked up on the second ring. She always picked up on the second ring -- never the first, never the third. By the third ring the anxiety would have already started, the quick inventory of worst-case scenarios that mothers run in the time between the second ring and the voicemail.

"Connor! Are you alright?"

She always started with this. Not *hello*, not *how are you*, but *are you alright*, as though every phone call from her son was potentially the one where everything had gone wrong.

"I'm fine, Mum. I'm great, actually. Just sitting on the hostel roof looking at the Petronas Towers."

"Oh, lovely. I've seen photos. They look enormous."

"They are. Like, properly massive. You can see them from everywhere in the city. It's like they're watching you."

"That's a bit creepy, darling."

He laughed. "Nah, it's beautiful. KL's beautiful. I wish you could see it."

"Well, your father and I were saying just the other day that we should do a trip. Maybe next year. When you're -- well, wherever you are next year."

The sentence snagged on the word *wherever*. Connor heard the weight of it -- the gentle, careful weight of a mother who had learned not to ask *when are you coming home* because the answer had stopped changing and had started hurting.

"How's Dad?"

"Oh, he's fine. Playing golf on Saturdays, which you'd think would be enough, but now he's joined a Tuesday group as well. I think he's avoiding the garden."

"Tell him I said g'day."

"I will. Oh -- Megan got a promotion. She's some sort of senior analyst now. At that firm in the city. She's very pleased."

"Good for Megs." He said it and meant approximately forty percent of it. The other sixty percent was the complicated alloy of jealousy and guilt and defensive dismissal that Megan's achievements always produced in him -- the reminder that the Briggs family conveyor belt was still running and he was the only one who'd stepped off.

"And how are you, really?" Karen said. "Are you eating properly? Sleeping?"

"Mum, I'm eating the best food of my life. There's this woman at the hostel -- Mama Siti -- she makes this coconut rice thing every morning. It's unbelievable."

"That's nice, love. And you're being careful? Your father saw something on the news -- one of those current affairs programs -- about drug crime in Malaysia. Something about trafficking. It sounded quite frightening."

The word *trafficking* arrived on the rooftop like a cold draught through an open window. Connor felt it move across his skin and then felt himself close the window.

"Always careful, Mum. You know me."

"I know you *think* you're invincible," she said, with the particular tone of a mother who has been watching her child walk toward edges since before he could walk, who has spent twenty-seven years calculating the distance between his confidence and the ground. "I just want you to be safe, Connor. That's all I ever want."

"I'm always safe, Mum. Promise."

He meant it. He genuinely, completely, profoundly meant it. He was sitting on a rooftop in a city he'd come to love, drinking a beer, talking to his mother, and the sincerity of his promise was total and unperformed and that was what made it devastating -- not that he was lying, but that he believed absolutely in the truth of a statement that could not have been more wrong.

"I love you, darling."

"Love you too, Mum."

"Call me next week? On Sunday, if you can. Your father will be home."

"Will do."

"Goodnight. Or -- good morning? I always get confused with the time difference."

"It's night here, Mum. Late."

"Well, get some sleep. And eat your vegetables."

He laughed. "There aren't a lot of vegetables in Malaysian food."

"Then find some. Goodnight, Connor."

"Night, Mum."

The call ended. The screen went dark. Connor sat with the phone in one hand and the beer in the other and felt something expand in his chest -- a warmth different from the humid air, different from the beer. It was the warmth of being loved without conditions, without performance -- uncomplicated, unearned, the kind that came from Melbourne and arrived intact despite twelve time zones. His mother loved the real him -- the boy who'd skinned his knees in Hawthorn, the teenager who'd failed chemistry. She loved the man on the rooftop, though she had no idea that the man she loved was carrying packages for a trafficker and calling it logistics.

He thought about Priya, asleep two floors below. Jake, at a bar on Changkat. The hostel -- the red lanterns, the squeaking third step, Mama Siti's kitchen. The building that had absorbed him the way it absorbed everyone, offering warmth and the gentle narcotic of belonging.

He thought about none of the things he should have been thinking about.

*This is the life,* Connor thought. *This is what people back home will never understand. This right here. The rooftop and the skyline and the warm night and the beer and the money and the girl and the friends and the hostel that feels like home. Everything is exactly right. Everything is exactly where it should be.*

He finished his beer. He sat for a while longer -- not thinking, not performing, not curating. Just being. A man on a rooftop in a country whose laws he'd never read, in a building that had been a warehouse and a military office and a gambling den and a brothel and was now the place where Connor Briggs had found the thing he'd been looking for without knowing he was looking for it.

Comfort. The most dangerous thing in the world.

He went downstairs at midnight. Climbed into Bed 7 and pulled the blue towel over his chest and lay there in the dark, listening to the ceiling fan tick and the air well breathe and the city hum its endless, indifferent hum.

He was happy. Not the performed happiness of Instagram, but the quiet, real, dangerous happiness of a man who has mistaken the floor of a trap for solid ground.

It was the last time he would feel this way.

---

Morning. Day 15.

The knock came at six AM, while the call to prayer was still echoing across the rooftops. Connor was deep in sleep. The knock pulled him up through layers of unconsciousness and deposited him in the real world with a jolt. The dorm was grey with early light. The ceiling fan turned. The French guy above was a motionless lump.

Three raps. Precise. Patient.

Connor swung his legs off the bunk, rubbed his eyes with the heels of his palms, and shuffled to the door. He was in his board shorts, shirtless, his hair a construction of sleep and humidity. He opened the door and squinted into the hallway.

Felix was there.

Clean shirt, linen shorts, leather sandals, the scar on his eyebrow catching the grey light. But something was different. The usual Felix -- the smiling Felix, the one who made you feel chosen and warm -- was not entirely present. In his place was something leaner, as though the charming surface had been peeled back to reveal the mechanism beneath. His eyes were steady and held none of the social warmth Connor had come to expect. They were the eyes of a man at work.
