"Morning, Connor." His voice was calm, measured, the German accent a little more pronounced than usual, the way it got when Felix was being precise rather than performing. "Got something different for today. Can we talk on the roof?"

Connor blinked. "What time is it?"

"Just after six. Sorry for the early start."

"Yeah, mate. No worries." He yawned, scratched his jaw, tried to assemble his face into something that looked awake. "Give me five."

"Of course." Felix inclined his head -- a small, European gesture that managed to convey both patience and expectation. "I'll be up there."

He turned and walked down the hallway. His footsteps were quiet. The third step didn't squeak.

Connor closed the door. The call to prayer was fading through the air well, the muezzin's voice thinning to silence.

He pulled on a singlet -- GOOD VIBES ONLY, soft and thin from washing in hostel sinks across three countries. Flip-flops. Phone from the mattress.

On the way out, he steadied himself against the bunk frame with one hand, his fingers wrapping around the wooden edge as he ducked under the upper bunk. His palm pressed flat against the wood. His fingers curled over the rail. Beneath them, carved into the grain by a fingernail or a key or the desperate edge of a coin, were five letters: L-E-N-A.

He didn't look down. He didn't feel the grooves. His hand was there for a second, maybe two, and then it was gone and he was in the hallway and the door was closing behind him and the name was behind him, unseen, unread, unfelt.

The way it had been since the first night. The way it would stay.

He climbed the staircase -- the third step squeaked -- and pushed through the rooftop access door. The Petronas Towers caught the early light, silver against the brightening sky.

Felix was standing at the zinc railing. He didn't turn. His posture was relaxed but not casual -- the posture of a man who has arranged things and is waiting for the next arrangement to begin.

"So," Connor said, dropping into a plastic chair, "what's up?"

Felix turned. He looked at Connor for a long moment -- the kind of look you give something you've been building when you've finished the foundation and are ready to start on the walls. Then he smiled. The smile was thinner than usual, more efficient -- a smile that existed to facilitate a transaction rather than create warmth. The mask was thinner today. Connor didn't notice, because Connor had never noticed the mask.

"I've got something a bit different," Felix said. "Something bigger. Better money. But I want to explain it properly."

He pulled up a chair and sat across from Connor. Behind them, the Petronas Towers watched. Below, the city moved.

Part 1 ended here, on a rooftop in Kuala Lumpur, with the call to prayer fading and the morning light growing and a twenty-seven-year-old Australian in a GOOD VIBES ONLY singlet sitting across from the man who was going to get him killed, waiting to hear what came next.

He waited the way he did everything: confidently, carelessly, with the serene certainty of a person who had never once in his life imagined that the ground beneath him might not hold.
# Chapter 11: The Upgrade

The rooftop at six in the morning was a different country.

The plastic chairs were beaded with dew -- the overnight condensation that settled on every surface in KL like a tax levied by the climate. The clothesline hung empty, its nylon cord sagging between two poles in a curve that caught the first grey light. The Petronas Towers were silhouettes against a sky the colour of dishwater, their silver cladding not yet lit, their twin forms rising into the low cloud like something waiting to be revealed. Below, the city was stirring but not yet awake -- the distant diesel cough of a bus on Jalan Sultan, the metallic clatter of a shophouse shutter going up too early, and from somewhere close, the last trailing note of the Fajr call to prayer from Masjid Jamek, thin and wavering and ancient, fading into the hum of air-conditioning units on a hundred rooftops.

Connor sat in the plastic chair, shirtless, in board shorts and flip-flops, his hair a monument to the night's humidity. His singlet -- GOOD VIBES ONLY -- was balled in his fist because putting it on had seemed like too much commitment at six AM. The air was warm but not yet aggressive, the brief window between the cool of pre-dawn and the furnace-blast of a KL morning. In two hours the sun would turn the zinc roof into a griddle. Now it was almost pleasant.

Felix stood at the railing. He'd pulled two Tiger beers from somewhere -- cold, sweating, the kind of gesture that was so perfectly timed it felt rehearsed. He set one on the arm of Connor's chair without asking.

"Beer at six AM?" Connor said.

"It's a special occasion."

"What occasion?"

Felix turned from the railing. The scar on his eyebrow caught the early light. He was wearing a clean white linen shirt, untucked, sleeves rolled to the elbow. His leather sandals looked new. Everything about Felix looked deliberate in a way that Connor admired without examining -- the way you admire a building's architecture without wondering about the foundation.

"I've been thinking," Felix said. "About you."

"Flattering."

Felix didn't smile. This was notable. Felix's smile was his primary tool, deployed with the precision of a surgeon's scalpel -- to disarm, to include, to create the warm illusion that you were the most important person in the room. The absence of the smile meant something, though Connor was not equipped to read what.

"You've been reliable, Connor. Four jobs, no problems. No questions." He paused on the word *questions* the way you'd pause on a speed bump -- acknowledging it existed without slowing down. "I appreciate that. Most people I work with ask too many questions, or they get nervous, or they talk. You don't talk."

"I'm an easy-going bloke."

"You are. And that's valuable." Felix pulled a chair around to face Connor and sat in it the way Europeans sat -- upright, knees apart, elbows on thighs, the posture of a man conducting an interview he'd already decided the outcome of. "The deliveries you've been doing -- the envelopes, the packages -- those are small. Entry-level. Think of them as... the probation period."

"Probation." Connor repeated the word and felt something move in his stomach -- not alarm, exactly, but the distant cousin of alarm, the first faint signal from a warning system he'd spent twenty-seven years learning to ignore. The word *probation* implied a structure, and structures implied organisations, and organisations implied something larger than two mates helping each other out.

"Let me explain," Felix said. "I work with an import-export company. Based in Hong Kong. We handle logistics for various products moving through Southeast Asia. Electronics, phone components, specialty goods. The company has partners in KL, Penang, Singapore, Bangkok. The envelopes and packages you've been carrying -- those are samples, invoices, small shipments. Routine stuff."

He spoke with the calm, measured cadence of a man reading from a script he'd polished through repetition, each word tested for weight and placed with care. The German accent softened the edges. The early-morning light softened everything else.

"But the business is growing. More product, more routes, more volume. I need someone here -- in KL, at this hostel, who can handle regular pickups and drop-offs. Not one-offs. A schedule. Three, maybe four times a week. Bigger items sometimes -- not envelopes. Backpacks. Suitcases. You'd be the KL leg of a chain that runs from here to Penang, sometimes to Singapore."

Connor drank his beer. The Tiger was cold and thin and tasted like every other Tiger he'd drunk in Southeast Asia, which was to say it tasted like being somewhere that wasn't home. He was aware of a sensation he did not immediately recognise, because it was not a sensation he often experienced. The sensation was hesitation.

"Backpacks?" he said.

"Backpacks. Sometimes boxes. Nothing that would look unusual -- you're a backpacker carrying a backpack, or a tourist with luggage. The items go from a pickup point to a drop-off point. Same as before, just more frequent and higher volume."

"And the money?"

Felix reached into the pocket of his linen shorts and produced his phone. He opened a banking app -- European, the interface in German -- and turned the screen toward Connor. The balance was visible for approximately two seconds, long enough for Connor to register the number and feel his pupils dilate.

"That's what three months of this work looks like," Felix said. "For me, at my level. You'd start lower, obviously. But RM2,000 a week is realistic. More, once you're established."

RM2,000 a week. Connor's parents sent him $2,000 Australian per month -- roughly RM6,000. Felix was offering him the same amount in three weeks, for work that took a few hours a day. The arithmetic was immediate and intoxicating, the way all arithmetic is when it tells you what you want to hear.

His phone buzzed in his pocket. Instagram notification. He ignored it.

"That's..." Connor started, and the word he wanted was *insane* but the word that came out was "serious money."

"It is serious money. Because it's serious work. Not dangerous," Felix added, reading the thought before it formed, "but serious. Regular. Professional. You'd need to be punctual, discreet, and reliable. No telling people what you're doing -- not Jake, not Priya, not the hostel staff. This stays between us."

The hesitation was still there, a small stone in the mechanism of Connor's confidence. He could feel it catching on something, producing a sound he'd never heard before: doubt. Not the intellectual doubt of someone weighing evidence -- Connor didn't weigh evidence, he surfed over it -- but the bodily doubt of an animal that senses a change in the air before the storm arrives. His stomach was doing something it didn't usually do. His palms were damp, which he attributed to the humidity.

"Felix," he said. "Mate. Level with me."

Felix waited. His eyes were steady, the colour of creek water, and they held Connor's gaze with the patience of someone who had played this scene before and knew every possible line the other actor might deliver.

"This is all legit, yeah? Import-export. Phone stuff. Because I'm not--" He laughed, the defensive laugh, the laugh that precedes a sentence the speaker doesn't want to finish. "I mean, I'm not carrying drugs or anything. That's not--"

"Connor." Felix's voice was gentle, almost parental -- the tone of a father explaining to a child that the noise in the night is just the wind. "I'm a photographer. I do logistics work to fund my travels, the same way you do social media consulting. If I were involved in anything illegal, do you think I'd be living in a hostel in Chinatown? I'd be in a penthouse in KLCC."

The logic was so clean it gleamed. Connor picked it up and turned it over and found no scratches.

"Besides," Felix said, leaning back, letting the tension drain from his posture with the deliberate ease of a man releasing a hooked fish back into the water, "this is Malaysia. You've seen the signs at the airport. You know what happens to people who deal drugs here. You think I'd risk that? You think I'd put *you* at risk?"

The sign at the airport. Connor had walked past it on Day 1 -- red text, white background, the Malay crest. DADAH MEMBAWA MAUT. He hadn't read it. He hadn't read it but he'd seen it, and the seeing was enough for Felix to reference, enough to create the impression that Connor was informed, that Connor had considered the risks and judged them acceptable, that Connor was making an educated decision.

He wasn't. He was making the decision the way he'd made every decision since leaving Monash University: by following the path that felt good and assuming the universe would handle the rest.

"Yeah, no, of course," Connor said. "Sorry, mate. Didn't mean to--"

"No need to apologise." Felix smiled. The smile was back, warm and generous, and its return was like sunlight breaking through clouds -- a relief so palpable that Connor felt grateful, actually grateful, that Felix wasn't offended by the question. This was the mechanism at work: the brief withdrawal of warmth created a vacuum, and the vacuum created need, and the need made the return of warmth feel like a gift rather than a manipulation. It was textbook. Felix had learned it from a man in Bangkok who'd learned it from a woman in Guangzhou who'd learned it from whoever first discovered that love, strategically withheld, becomes a tool.

"Take today to think about it," Felix said. "No pressure. If you want to keep doing the small stuff, that's fine. But this is a proper opportunity, Connor. The kind of money that means you don't have to go home. The kind of money that means you stay."

He stood. Collected both beer bottles -- his half-finished, Connor's nearly empty. Walked to the rooftop door. At the threshold, he turned.

"RM2,000 a week, Connor. How long would that keep you here?"

The door closed. Felix's footsteps descended the staircase -- quiet, measured, the third step not squeaking because Felix had learned, as all predators learn, the exact geography of the terrain they hunted.

---

Connor sat on the rooftop for an hour.

The sun climbed. The dishwater sky brightened to white, then to the flat, merciless blue that KL produced on clear mornings, the blue that promised heat and delivered on the promise by nine. The Petronas Towers caught the light and became mirrors, throwing silver across the skyline. Below, the city was fully awake now: the motorcycle chorus, the vendor calls, the steady percussion of construction somewhere behind the hostel where a new condo was going up, crane visible above the shophouse rooftops like a mechanical bird feeding on concrete.

He thought about money.

This was what Connor did when the world presented him with a decision that had moral dimensions: he converted it into a financial problem, because financial problems had clean solutions and moral problems did not. The question was not *should I do this* but *can I afford not to*.

The arithmetic: RM2,000 a week was RM8,000 a month. His current expenses -- hostel (RM70/night, negotiated to RM50 for long-stay), food (RM40/day average), beer (RM30/day average), Grab rides (RM20/day), miscellaneous (RM200/week) -- totalled roughly RM5,500 a month. That left RM2,500 surplus. Per month. For the first time in his adult life, Connor would be saving money. Not the theoretical saving of someone who says "I should save" while spending -- the actual, mathematical saving of income exceeding expenditure.

He could stay in KL for six months. A year. He could get a proper apartment, leave the hostel, live like a local. He could stop asking his parents for money. He could stop the monthly deposit that came with the invisible weight of his mother's worry and his father's disappointment and his sister's silent judgement. He could be, for the first time, genuinely self-sufficient.

He could be what his Instagram said he was.

The thought was narcotic. It entered his bloodstream through the eyes -- the vision of himself as the man he performed -- and it moved through him with the warm, spreading ease of something designed to feel good and engineered to destroy.

He pulled out his phone. Opened Instagram. His last post -- the rooftop selfie from three days ago, Petronas Towers behind him, caption: *Office for the day. Your 9-5 could never.* -- had 52 likes. He scrolled through his feed: other nomads in Bali, Lisbon, Chiang Mai, Medelln. They all looked the same. They all claimed the same freedom. But Connor knew -- he knew with the certainty of a man who checks his bank balance at 2 AM -- that most of them were funded by parents, or credit cards, or the slow erosion of savings that would eventually pull them home.

He could be different. He could be the one who actually made it work.

The hesitation was still there, somewhere, a pebble in his shoe. He shifted his weight and it moved, and then it was in a different place, still there but differently uncomfortable, and he decided it was the chair and not the pebble and stood up and went downstairs.

---

The communal kitchen at half past seven was Mama Siti's kingdom.

She stood at the stove -- an ancient two-burner that should have been condemned during the Mahathir administration -- stirring a pot of curry with a wooden spoon the length of her forearm. The spoon was dark with decades of turmeric staining, smooth with use, and Mama Siti wielded it with an authority that suggested the spoon had opinions and she was the only person who could translate them.

She wore her uniform: a cotton baju kurung in faded blue, a white headscarf pinned with pragmatic indifference, and the expression she always wore, which was the expression of a woman who had been watching people eat her food for longer than most of them had been alive and had formed conclusions about the human race that she kept to herself.

Connor entered. Sat at the counter. The nasi lemak appeared.

"Selamat pagi, Mama."

She didn't respond. She'd stopped responding to Connor's attempts at Malay on day four, when he'd asked for "nasi goreng pedas" and pronounced it in a way that somehow sounded like a request for her grandmother's undergarments. She simply placed the banana leaf in front of him -- rice, sambal, egg, anchovies, peanuts, a slice of cucumber -- and returned to her pot.

Connor ate with his fingers. He'd become good at this -- the technique of compacting the rice with the fingertips, adding sambal, scooping to the mouth. The first time he'd tried, he'd gotten rice on his chin, his shirt, the counter, and an adjacent backpacker. Now he ate with something approaching grace, and the eating was a small ritual that connected him to the building, to the kitchen, to the morning, in a way that his Instagram posts about "authentic cultural immersion" never quite captured because the posts were about the image and the eating was about the thing itself.

"Mama," he said, between bites. "You ever think about money?"

She looked at him. The wooden spoon paused mid-stir.

"Money?" she said, as though the word was a variety of insect that had landed on her counter.

"Like, what would you do if someone offered you really good money for easy work? Would you take it?"

Mama Siti stirred. The curry bubbled. From the pot rose the smell of coconut milk and lemongrass and galangal, and beneath it, the deeper, darker smell of spice paste that had been ground by hand on a batu lesung that Mama Siti kept under the counter like a weapon.

"*Siapa makan cabai, dialah rasa pedas,*" she said.

Connor waited. Mama Siti did not translate. She never translated. The proverbs arrived in Malay and stayed in Malay, and if you wanted to understand them you could learn the language, and if you didn't want to learn the language, the proverbs would wait. They'd been waiting for centuries.

"Right," Connor said. "Cheers, Mama."

He finished his nasi lemak. Left a ten-ringgit note on the counter -- double the usual, because the extra money from Felix's deliveries had already changed the way he spent. The ten vanished. Mama Siti did not acknowledge the tip. She stirred her pot and spoke to it quietly in Malay, and the pot listened, which was more than the boy had done.

The proverb she'd spoken -- *Siapa makan cabai, dialah rasa pedas* -- meant: *He who eats the chilli is the one who feels the heat.*

Connor would never look it up.

---

He found Priya in the common room at nine, cross-legged in the armchair, her Lonely Planet open on her lap. She was wearing a white cotton T-shirt and denim shorts and her round glasses, and her hair was braided over one shoulder, and she was reading with the focused absorption of someone who believed that understanding the place you were in was not optional.

"Morning, babe."

She looked up. Smiled. Not the full smile -- the careful one, the one that had been recalibrated since their argument about the packages two days ago. The crack between them had been painted over but not repaired, and both of them could feel the paint.

"You were up early," she said. "I heard the door."

"Felix wanted to chat. Business stuff."

The word *business* crossed the space between them and landed at Priya's feet like something she hadn't ordered. She looked at it. She looked at Connor. She adjusted her glasses.

"What kind of business stuff?"

"Just the import-export thing. He wants me to do more regular work. Better pay."

"More deliveries."

"Regular deliveries. A proper schedule. Like a job."

Priya closed the Lonely Planet. The rubber bands snapped softly against the cover. She placed both hands flat on the book and looked at Connor with the expression he'd learned to recognise as her diagnostic face -- the face she wore when a patient presented symptoms they were trying to hide.

"Connor, can I tell you something without you getting defensive?"

"I'm never defensive."

"You're always defensive."

"That's a bit defensive of you to say."

She didn't laugh. This was bad. Priya's failure to laugh at his deflections was the barometric pressure drop before a storm.

"The more you work for Felix, the more you depend on Felix. The more you depend on Felix, the harder it is to stop. Do you see that? It's a pattern. It's -- in medicine, we'd call it a dependency loop. The treatment creates the condition that requires more treatment."

"Right, so Felix is a disease. Great. That's a really supportive thing to say about my mate."

"He's not your mate, Connor. He's your employer. And you don't know what he's employing you to do."

The sentence was precise and cold and it hit the wall of Connor's defences and left a small crack -- smaller than the one between them, but there. He felt it. For one suspended moment, the arithmetic dissolved and the question beneath it surfaced: *What am I carrying?*

He met her eyes. She was looking at him the way she looked at everything -- carefully, completely, with the full weight of her attention -- and he understood that she was not arguing with him. She was trying to save him. The realisation was uncomfortable because it implied he needed saving, and Connor Briggs did not need saving. Connor Briggs was fine. Connor Briggs had been travelling for four years and had never once needed saving.

"I know what I'm doing," he said.

She held his gaze for three full seconds -- counting, he could almost see her counting, the way doctors count before delivering results -- and then she looked down at the Lonely Planet and opened it and said, "Okay."

Not agreement. Not acceptance. Just the sound of a hand withdrawing.

Connor stood. "I'm going to Grind Culture. Coming?"

"No. I want to visit the Islamic Arts Museum. I've been meaning to go all week."

"Cool. Have fun."

He walked to the door. At the threshold, he stopped. Turned. She was reading -- or performing reading, her eyes moving across the page at a speed that suggested comprehension but her posture rigid, angled toward the door, listening to his footsteps fade.

"Priya."

She looked up.

"It's just logistics. Moving things from A to B. That's all it is."

She pushed her glasses up. "Okay, Connor."

He left. The word *okay* followed him down the staircase and out the front door and into the morning heat of Petaling Street, where the sun hit the pavement like a physical force and the air smelled of fried dough and diesel and the beginning of something that could not be undone.

---

Grind Culture was the caf where Connor went to be a digital nomad.

It was on a side street off Jalan Sultan, a narrow shophouse that had been converted with the usual formula: exposed brick, Edison bulbs, a chalkboard menu with pour-over options no one ordered, a barista with a man-bun and an expression of cultivated boredom. The Wi-Fi was fast. The coffee was expensive. The clientele was a mixture of actual remote workers and people like Connor, who sat with laptops open and the appearance of productivity while doing exactly nothing.

He ordered his flat white -- RM14, which he no longer winced at -- and sat at his usual table by the window, the one that got good light for laptop selfies. He opened his MacBook. He opened a browser. He opened the Pacific Soul Retreats Instagram account, which he nominally managed, and spent seven minutes choosing between two nearly identical sunset photos for the Thursday post.

Then he opened a new tab and typed: *import export jobs kuala lumpur salary*

Google delivered. He scrolled through results: logistics coordinator, RM3,000-5,000/month. Supply chain analyst, RM4,000-7,000. Import clerk, RM2,500. The numbers confirmed what Felix had told him -- RM8,000 a month for courier work was high but not impossible, not insane, not the kind of figure that should trigger alarm bells. It was the upper end of logistics work. That was all.

He did not Google *drug trafficking penalties malaysia*.

He did not Google *backpacker drug mule southeast asia*.

He did not Google *signs you are being recruited as a drug courier*.

These searches would have taken seconds. They would have returned thousands of results -- news articles, embassy warnings, survivor testimonials, legal explainers, the Dangerous Drugs Act itself in full searchable text, with Section 39B highlighted in the red of a stop sign. The information was there, abundant, free, a wall of evidence standing between Connor and the decision he was about to make.

He did not look. He never looked. Looking was what careful people did, and careful people were the people who went home and got jobs and stopped travelling and became the people Connor pitied from the window of a caf in a city they'd never visit.

He closed the tab. Opened Instagram. Posted the sunset photo for Pacific Soul. Caption: *Find your light.* Scheduled for 6 PM EST.

Then he texted Felix.

*I'm in. When do I start?*

The reply came in eleven seconds.

*Tomorrow. I'll set up the schedule tonight. Welcome aboard, Connor.*

A second message, two seconds later:

*This is going to change everything.*

Connor read it and smiled and felt the smile all the way down, through his chest and into his stomach where the hesitation had been sitting, and the smile was so wide and so warm that it buried the hesitation entirely, the way sunlight buries a shadow, the way noise buries a warning, the way the person you want to be buries the person you are.

He ordered a second flat white. He sat in the window of Grind Culture and watched Petaling Street move in its daily rhythm -- the tourists, the vendors, the old man with the bird cages, the motorcycle couriers threading between cars -- and he thought about RM2,000 a week and what it would feel like to not need his parents' money and what it would feel like to be free.

He did not think about what he would carry or where it came from or where it went or why it needed to move by hand through the streets of a city that killed people for moving certain things.

The flat white was good. The Wi-Fi was strong. The sun came through the window and made his laptop screen glow and he felt, with a certainty that had no evidence beneath it, that he had made the right decision.

---

Felix's schedule arrived at eleven PM, delivered in person.

Connor was in Bed 7, scrolling his phone, the blue light of the screen the only illumination in the dorm besides the ambient glow from the air well. The French backpacker above him was asleep, breathing with the congested regularity of a man whose sinuses had not adjusted to the tropics. Two beds down, a Korean girl was listening to something through earbuds, her face green-lit by her phone. The ceiling fan turned. The hostel breathed.

Three raps on the dorm door. Soft. The particular softness of a knock designed to wake one person without disturbing others.

Connor padded to the door in his board shorts. Felix was in the hallway, leaning against the wall with the easy posture of someone who had been waiting and didn't mind waiting, the way cats don't mind waiting because the waiting is part of the hunt.

"Walk with me," Felix said.

They went to the air well. The internal courtyard was small -- four metres square, open to the sky, the walls rising around it like a well shaft. During the day, light fell straight down and lit the mosaic tile bench and the potted plants and the small patch of ground where nothing grew because nothing had grown there since the building was built. At night, the air well was a column of dark air connecting the hostel's floors, and if you stood at the bottom and looked up, you could see a rectangle of sky framed by the building's walls, and sometimes stars, and sometimes the running lights of a plane descending toward KLIA.

No stars tonight. Just the orange ambient light of the city reflected off low cloud, and the hum, and the smell -- the hostel's nighttime smell of damp wood and mosquito coil and the ghost of Mama Siti's evening curry.

Felix produced a folded piece of paper from his shirt pocket. White, A4, creased into thirds. He unfolded it and held it so the glow from the second-floor hallway light fell across the surface. Connor leaned in.

It was a table. Handwritten, in Felix's precise European script. Days of the week across the top. Rows beneath: times, addresses, contact names.

Monday -- 10:00 -- Jalan Ipoh 47, Mr. Tan
Tuesday -- 14:00 -- Brickfields, Lorong 3, "Blue Door"
Wednesday -- REST
Thursday -- 11:00 -- Chow Kit, Jalan Raja Bot 12, Auntie Lim
Friday -- 10:00 -- Jalan Ipoh 47, Mr. Tan (return)
Saturday -- 16:00 -- Bukit Bintang, Lot 22B, ground floor, ask for Danny
Sunday -- REST

"Six drops a week, two rest days," Felix said. "You pick up from me or from Wei's shop, depending on the day. I'll text you each morning with the specifics. The items vary -- sometimes a package, sometimes an envelope, sometimes a backpack. You don't open them. You don't discuss them. You deliver, you collect confirmation -- usually a handshake or a nod -- and you leave."

Connor studied the schedule. The locations were spread across KL -- Jalan Ipoh to the north, Brickfields to the south, Chow Kit to the northeast, Bukit Bintang central. A geography of drops that covered the city like a net. Each location was a place he'd been to or passed through, ordinary streets in ordinary neighborhoods, the kind of places where a backpacker with a daypack would be invisible.

"Pay is weekly," Felix continued. "RM2,000, transferred to your account every Sunday night. If a job gets cancelled -- rain, schedule change, whatever -- you still get the base rate. Think of it as a salary."

A salary. The word landed like a key in a lock, the tumbler turning, the door opening onto a room Connor had wanted to enter since the day he dropped out of university. A salary meant legitimacy. A salary meant he was working, earning, contributing. A salary meant the next time his mother asked "What are you doing over there, Connor?" he would have an answer that didn't require creative editing.

"What about the items?" Connor asked. The question surprised him -- it emerged from the space where the hesitation had been, a small survivor clinging to a piece of wreckage. "Like, if someone asks me what I'm carrying--"

"Nobody asks. You're a tourist with a bag. But if someone asks, you're carrying gifts for a friend. Or supplies for a business. Or your own things. Nobody looks twice at a backpacker."

"Right."

"One more thing." Felix's voice changed register -- not louder, not harder, but more focused, the way a spotlight narrows. "This stays between us. Completely. Not Priya, not Jake, not the hostel staff. Nobody. The people I work with value discretion above everything else. If word gets out that I'm running a logistics operation from this hostel, the landlord shuts it down. Razak shuts it down. Immigration gets involved. It's bad for everyone."

"Yeah, no. Of course. I'm not going to--"

"I know you won't." Felix folded the paper and handed it to Connor. "Keep this somewhere safe. Don't photograph it. Don't put it in your phone."

Connor took the paper. It was warm from Felix's pocket, the folds sharp and deliberate. He held it the way you hold a ticket -- a ticket to somewhere better, somewhere the bank balance didn't fall and the parents' deposit wasn't needed and the Instagram posts weren't lies.

"Starting tomorrow," Felix said. "Monday. Jalan Ipoh. I'll have the package ready by nine. Meet me in my room."

"Done."

They stood in the air well. Above them, the rectangle of sky was orange and starless and alive with the reflected glow of eight million people going about the business of a city that did not know or care that a twenty-seven-year-old Australian had just agreed to carry things he'd never opened for people he'd never met to places he'd never questioned, on a schedule written by a man whose real name might not be Felix Decker.

"One more thing," Felix said.

He reached into his pocket and produced a phone. Not his phone -- a different one. Small, cheap, a Samsung with a cracked case and a prepaid SIM. He handed it to Connor.

"Work phone. I'll text you on this. Keep it charged, keep it on you. Don't use it for anything personal. No Instagram, no calls to Mum. This is for business only."

Connor held the phone. It was light in his hand, anonymous, the kind of phone that was sold in plastic blister packs at 7-Eleven for RM80. A burner. The word appeared in his mind, surfacing from the reservoir of crime dramas and true-crime podcasts he'd consumed over the years. A burner phone.

The hesitation made one last attempt. It rose from wherever it had been pressed, broke through the surface of his thoughts, and formed a sentence: *Legitimate businesses don't give you burner phones.*

He looked at the phone. He looked at Felix. Felix was watching him with the same expression he always wore when Connor was on the edge of a question -- patient, calm, faintly amused, as if watching a child puzzle over something simple.

"Standard practice," Felix said. "The company uses prepaid phones for all field staff. It's a liability thing. Corporate policy."

The sentence was absurd. The sentence was so transparently, obviously absurd that any person paying the slightest attention would have laughed. Corporate policy. For a logistics company that operated out of a Chinatown hostel and a phone repair shop and paid cash. Corporate policy.

Connor put the phone in his pocket.

"Cool," he said. "Makes sense."

And that was the moment. Not the moment when he'd agreed, not the moment when he'd texted *I'm in*, not the moment when he'd looked at the schedule and felt the key turn in the lock. This was the moment. The pocket. The phone. The weight of it against his thigh, small and warm and cheap, the weight of a second life he was choosing to carry without examining, the way he'd carried every package without examining, the way he'd carried Felix's friendship without examining, the way he'd carried himself through the world for twenty-seven years without examining any of it.

The phone was in his pocket and the paper was in his hand and Felix was smiling and the air well was dark and somewhere above them, in the rectangle of sky, a plane was descending toward KLIA, its lights blinking, carrying someone new to the city -- a new arrival, a new guest, a new body to fill a bed in a hostel that had been filling beds and emptying them for nearly a century.

"Get some sleep," Felix said. "Big day tomorrow."

He turned and climbed the staircase. Second floor, third floor, the third step not squeaking. His door closed. The corridor was silent.

Connor stood in the air well alone. The mosaic tiles were cold under his bare feet. The sulfurous breath of the building's drains rose from somewhere below, mixing with the faint smell of Mama Siti's curry from the kitchen, left to cool in a pot on the stove, spiced and ancient and indifferent. He looked up. The orange sky looked back. From somewhere on the second floor, the Korean girl's music -- a high, sweet voice singing in a language he didn't understand about something he would never know.

He went back to Bed 7. He folded the schedule and tucked it into the inner pocket of his daypack, the zippered compartment where he kept his passport and emergency cash and the blue Sea to Summit towel that had been with him through twelve countries and would be with him at the end.

He placed the burner phone on the mattress beside his regular phone. Two screens. Two lives. The old phone -- cracked, sticker-covered, 4,200 followers, his mother's contact, his sister's silence, the Pacific Soul Retreats account, the Instagram grid of a life performed. The new phone -- clean, anonymous, no contacts except one, no history, no followers, no identity. A blank screen waiting to be filled with work he would not question, for money he would not trace, from a man he would not doubt.

He lay in the dark and listened to the building settle -- the wood expanding and contracting with the temperature, the pipes groaning, the ceiling fan's metronomic *tick, tick, tick*. Somewhere below, a door opened and closed. Somewhere above, Felix's floorboards creaked as he paced his private room, doing whatever Felix did at midnight, which Connor had never wondered about and wasn't going to start wondering about now.

*RM2,000 a week,* he thought. *She'll be right.*

He fell asleep with both phones on the mattress beside him, one in each hand, the digital nomad and the courier, the person he showed the world and the person he was becoming, both warm, both humming faintly with the electromagnetic life of their circuits, both connected to networks that stretched across the city and beyond, one visible and one invisible, one counting likes and one counting something else entirely.

In the morning, the call to prayer would come at 5:32, and Connor would not hear it, and the city would ask its question -- *are you awake, are you listening, do you know where you are* -- and Connor would not answer, because Connor was not listening, and he did not know where he was, and the knowing, by now, was already too late to help.

But morning was hours away. Now there was only the dark, and the fan, and the two phones, and the building breathing around him like something patient and very old, and the name on the bed frame -- L-E-N-A -- five letters carved into wood by a girl who had slept in this exact spot and carried packages for this exact man and was now in a place where the fluorescent lights never turned off and the doors did not open from the inside.

Connor slept. The building didn't.
# Chapter 12: Don't Ask

Monday morning arrived with the smell of rain on hot concrete and the sound of Mei Ling arguing with a Grab driver on the street below.

Connor heard it through the air well -- the rapid-fire Cantonese that Mei Ling deployed in situations that required a precision weapon rather than the polite English she used at reception. The driver was arguing back. Their voices rose and fell in a rhythm that sounded like a negotiation conducted at swordpoint, each syllable a thrust, each pause a recalibration. It ended the way Mei Ling's arguments always ended: with the sound of a car door closing, an engine starting, and silence. The silence of victory.

Connor reached for the phone on his mattress. Not the old phone. The new one -- the Samsung, the burner, the work phone, which he was already thinking of with the casual familiarity of a tool you've owned for years rather than hours. The screen showed one message, received at 7:14 AM:

*Package ready. Room 301. Come when you're dressed.*

He swung his legs off Bed 7. The morning routine -- board shorts, singlet (today: LIFE'S A BEACH in fading letters), flip-flops, leather bracelet. He splashed water on his face in the second-floor bathroom. The mirror above the sink was spotted with age and humidity, the silvering gone dark at the edges, and the face that looked back at him was the face he always saw: tanned, stubbled, squinting. The face of a man who had figured things out.

He climbed to the third floor. Felix's door was closed. Connor knocked twice -- a pattern that was already becoming habit, the specific two-knock rhythm that meant *it's me*, that meant *I'm ready*, that meant *I'm the one who doesn't ask questions*.

The door opened. Felix was dressed, groomed, the private room behind him neat and intentional in the way Felix's world was always neat and intentional. The bed made with hospital corners. A laptop open on the desk, displaying something Felix minimised before Connor could see it. The window overlooking Petaling Street, shuttered against the morning light, the wooden slats throwing striped shadows across the floor.

On the desk, beside the closed laptop, a package.

This one was different.

The previous packages had been small -- shoebox-sized, wrapped in brown paper, light enough to carry in one hand. This was larger. A sports bag -- black nylon, generic, the kind sold at every market stall in Southeast Asia for thirty ringgit. Zippered shut. Not sealed with tape the way the brown paper packages had been, just zipped, the two halves of the zipper meeting in the middle with a casualness that was either confident or careless.

Connor looked at the bag. The bag looked like a bag.

"Jalan Ipoh," Felix said. "Mr. Tan. Same as the schedule. The address is in your work phone -- I texted it last night."

"Got it."

Connor reached for the bag. Lifted it. And paused.

It was heavier than the packages. Not dramatically heavier -- not the weight of bricks or metal -- but heavier than phone chargers. Heavier than cables. He felt the weight settle into his arm, into his shoulder, and the weight had a texture to it, a density that suggested whatever was inside was packed tightly, compressed, occupying less space than its mass suggested it should.

"What's in this one?" The words came out before the machine could stop them, emerging from the same place the hesitation had lived -- the shrinking territory of Connor's self-preservation, the last patch of ground where doubt still grew.

Felix looked at him. The look lasted one second. In that second, something moved behind Felix's eyes -- a calculation, a recalibration, the quick assessment of a man who manages risk for a living and has just detected a variable. Then the look was gone and Felix was Felix again, warm and easy and unconcerned.

"Phone components. The same as always. Just a bigger order." He gestured at the bag. "Mr. Tan's shop is expanding. He needs more stock."

"Right. Yeah. Course." Connor hoisted the bag onto his shoulder. The weight distributed. It became ordinary. He was a backpacker with a bag, and in this city, in this neighbourhood, that was the most invisible thing you could be.

"Connor."

He turned at the door. Felix was standing by the desk, one hand on the closed laptop, and his expression was the one he wore when he was about to say something he wanted Connor to remember.

"Don't open the bag."

"I wasn't going to--"

"The clients are particular about packaging. If the seal is broken -- even if you rezip it -- they'll know, and they won't accept the delivery. It's a quality control thing. The components are packed in a specific configuration. If you disturb it, the whole shipment has to be redone."

"Mate, I wasn't going to open it."

"I know you weren't. I'm just telling you."

The words were reasonable. The tone was reasonable. Everything about the exchange was so perfectly reasonable that it should have been unremarkable, a boss telling an employee to follow procedure, nothing more. But there was something in the instruction -- the specificity of it, the pre-emptive quality, the way Felix had answered a question Connor hadn't asked -- that lingered. Like a taste you can't identify. Like a sound in an empty room.

"Have a good run," Felix said, and smiled, and the smile closed the conversation the way a lid closes a box.

---

The Grab from Petaling Street to Jalan Ipoh took twenty-two minutes.

Connor sat in the back seat with the black sports bag on his lap. The driver -- a young Malay man with a skull-cap and a dashboard Quran -- drove in silence, the radio tuned to a station playing dangdut, the Indonesian pop genre that sounded like someone had put a love song and a drum machine in a blender and poured the result directly into Connor's neural pathways. The music was hypnotic, repetitive, the kind of sound that fills a car the way water fills a glass -- completely, leaving no room for thought.

Which was useful, because thought was the enemy this morning.

The bag sat on his lap. His hands rested on the nylon. Through the fabric, he could feel the shape of the contents -- not individual items but a mass, a single compressed form, wrapped in something, packed tight. The shape was rectangular, approximately the size of a laptop, but heavier. Denser. His fingers found the edge of the zipper -- the small metal tab, warm from the car's interior, resting against the nylon like a door handle.

He could open it. Right now, in the back of this Grab, with the driver absorbed in dangdut and the traffic crawling past the Chow Kit market. He could unzip the bag six inches, look inside, see the phone components or the chargers or whatever was in there, confirm the story, and zip it back up. Felix would never know. Mr. Tan would never know. The zip would realign. The "quality control configuration" would be undisturbed.

His thumb found the zipper tab. Pressed against the metal. Felt the tiny ridge of teeth beneath.

The car stopped at a traffic light. Outside the window, a billboard rose above the shophouses: POLIS DIRAJA MALAYSIA -- the Royal Malaysia Police crest, blue and gold, above a public safety message in Malay and English. The English text read: KEEPING OUR COMMUNITIES SAFE. Below the crest, in smaller text: REPORT DRUG ACTIVITY -- 999.

Connor looked at the billboard. The billboard looked back. The light changed. The car moved. The billboard slid away.

His thumb was still on the zipper. He could feel his own pulse through the pad of his thumb, the blood fast and hard, the body already deciding what the mind refused to. Open the bag. See what's inside. Know the truth.

*And then what?*

The question arrived with the force of practical reality. If he opened the bag and found phone components, he'd feel stupid for doubting Felix. If he opened the bag and found something else -- something that was not phone components, something that the billboards warned about, something that the airport signs promised death for carrying -- then he would know. And knowing would require action. Knowing would require a decision: continue, or stop. And stopping meant losing the RM2,000 a week. Stopping meant losing Felix. Stopping meant going back to RM14 flat whites and his parents' deposit and the slow, grinding arithmetic of a life that didn't add up.

Not knowing was easier. Not knowing was free.

His thumb moved away from the zipper. The bag sat on his lap, unopened, and the not-knowing settled over him like a blanket -- warm, comforting, the comfort of a man who preferred the dark room he was sitting in to the light that would show him what was in it.

The Grab pulled up outside a shophouse on Jalan Ipoh. Connor got out. The heat hit him like a wall of wet wool. He slung the bag over his shoulder, walked to the metal roller door that was half-raised, ducked under, and found Mr. Tan.

Mr. Tan was approximately fifty, thin, with the compressed energy of a man who had been doing this for decades and had reduced the process to its most efficient form. He took the bag. Unzipped it -- Connor watched, trying to see inside, but Mr. Tan's body blocked the view -- inspected the contents for approximately three seconds, rezipped, nodded once.

No handshake. No conversation. The roller door descended.

Connor's work phone buzzed: RM350 transferred.

He walked back to the main road in the sun. The delivery had taken four minutes. Three hundred and fifty ringgit for four minutes of walking. The mathematics of it was so absurd that it functioned as its own anaesthetic: anything that paid this well had to be legitimate, because the alternative -- that it paid this well because it was dangerous, because the risk premium was built into the rate, because the money was compensation for the probability of catastrophic consequences -- was a thought Connor did not have the architecture to construct.

He flagged a Grab. Went home.

---

The Lantern Hostel at midday was in its somnolent phase -- the quiet hours between check-out and the afternoon rush, when the building drifted in a warm stupor of ceiling fans and empty corridors. The common room TV was playing a Malay cooking show to nobody. The bookshelf had acquired a new addition: *Shantaram*, dog-eared, its spine cracked at page 200, the exact point where every backpacker in Southeast Asia stopped reading *Shantaram*.

Connor came through the front door and turned right toward the staircase, his daypack over one shoulder, the black sports bag no longer with him, the RM350 warming his account, the morning's delivery already migrating from *thing I did* to *thing that happened*, the active voice becoming passive, the agency dissolving.

"Connor."

He stopped. Mei Ling was behind the reception counter.

She was always behind the reception counter. The counter was her territory, the wooden surface scarred with seventeen years of key-drops and ledger-signings and the casual violence of backpackers leaning too hard on cheap wood. Mei Ling presided over it with the calm authority of someone who had seen every kind of guest pass through and had catalogued them all.

Today she was not doing what she usually did -- the quiet busywork of reception, the shuffling of papers, the checking of the ledger. She was standing. Arms at her sides. Looking at Connor with an expression he had never seen on her face before.

The expression was difficult. It contained several things at once, layered like the sediment in old rock: concern at the base, irritation above that, and at the surface, the particular exhaustion of someone who has watched a preventable disaster approach and has been unable to stop it.

"Can I speak with you?"

"Yeah, sure. What's up?"

She didn't answer immediately. She looked past him, at the front door, at the street beyond where the phone repair shop's fluorescent light was visible. Then she looked back.

"Come here. To the counter."

Connor approached. The reception counter was chest-high, the wood dark with age, a bell and a hand-sanitiser bottle and a laminated card of house rules the only objects on its surface. Behind Mei Ling, the wall of guest keys -- metal hooks, most empty at this hour. The hostel's guest ledger, thick and cloth-bound, sitting on a shelf beside a box of passports being held for current guests.

Mei Ling placed both hands flat on the counter. Her nails were short, unpainted, practical. Her polo shirt -- white, red lantern logo on the breast pocket -- was pressed. Everything about Mei Ling was pressed: her clothes, her expression, her patience, which she was pressing to its limit.

"I see you," she said. "Every morning. Going out with a bag that isn't yours. Coming back without it. Sometimes twice a day."

Connor's stomach performed a small, cold contraction. He smiled. The Instagram smile -- wide, warm, weaponised.

"That's my freelance gear, Mei. Laptop, chargers, camera stuff. I work from cafs."

"Your laptop is in your dorm. I saw it on your bunk this morning when Aisha was cleaning."

The smile held. Behind it, the machine was running -- the rationalisation engine, the defence system, the twenty-seven years of practised evasion that Connor deployed with the fluency of a native speaker. "Sometimes I don't bring the laptop. Sometimes it's just camera gear. I'm doing some photography work for a client--"

"Connor." Her voice cut through his sentence with the precision of someone who had spent two years learning when guests were lying, which was most of the time, and had decided that today she was not going to let the lie land. "Please be careful what you carry for other people."

The sentence arrived in the space between them and stayed there. It did not move. It did not qualify itself. It sat on the reception counter like a stone, and Mei Ling looked at Connor with the expression of a woman who had just placed her last card on the table and was waiting to see if the man across from her was capable of reading it.

Connor heard the words. The words were clear. The words were, in fact, so clear that they required no interpretation, no context, no additional information. *Be careful what you carry for other people.* It was not a riddle. It was not a proverb. It was not Mama Siti's Malay wisdom, opaque and beautiful and ignorable. It was a direct, English-language warning from a young woman who was looking at him with something very close to fear.

He heard it. He processed it. And then the machine ran.

*She's just doing her job. It's a liability thing. The hostel has a policy about guests' belongings. She's covering herself. She doesn't know anything -- she's making assumptions because she's seen me carrying bags. Everyone carries bags. I'm a backpacker. Bags are what we do.*

"Mei, I appreciate the concern. But I'm a big boy. I know what I'm doing."

She held his gaze for a long moment. Behind her round face and her practical ponytail and her pressed polo shirt, behind the reception counter and the guest ledger and the laminated house rules, something was happening -- a decision being made, a line being drawn, the quiet recalibration of a person who has extended a hand and felt it pushed away.

"The rules are posted," she said, her voice flat now, the concern drained away, replaced by the professional neutrality of an employee returning to protocol. She pointed at the laminated card on the counter. Connor's eyes followed her finger to the bottom of the list, where rule number 6 was printed in red:

**Guests are responsible for knowing and obeying Malaysian law. The hostel is not liable.**

"I've read them," Connor said. He hadn't.

"Good."

She sat down behind the counter. Opened the ledger. Began writing. The conversation was over. The warning had been issued, received, and dismissed, and Mei Ling had added Connor to the mental ledger she kept -- the one that wasn't cloth-bound, the one that tracked not room assignments and payment dates but the guests she expected never to see again.

Connor climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked. On the second-floor landing, the Japanese characters were visible under the peeling paint -- brush strokes from 1943, administrative notations from an occupation that had used this building for purposes the building still remembered. Connor walked past them the way he walked past everything: without looking, without reading, without knowing that the characters he passed every day said *processing room*, which in 1943 meant something no one in the building wanted to remember.

---

The afternoon unfolded in the way KL afternoons unfolded: slowly, hotly, with the gathering promise of rain.

Connor was in the common room, on the sofa, doing his impression of a man at work. His laptop was open. The Pacific Soul Retreats account was loaded. He was choosing between three stock photos of a yoga retreat in Ubud -- all identical, all featuring a woman in white doing a pose that looked like she was trying to reach something on a high shelf -- when the rain began.

It didn't start gradually. KL rain arrived like a decision -- one moment the sky was grey and swollen, the next the air was water, the zinc roofs of Petaling Street hammered with a sound like ten thousand drummers playing the same beat. Rain cascaded down the air well in sheets, turning the courtyard into a small waterfall. The gutters overflowed. The smell changed -- the hot concrete and diesel of a tropical afternoon replaced instantly by the green, electric smell of ozone and wet earth.

Connor closed his laptop and watched. The rain was extraordinary in the way KL rain was always extraordinary -- not the grey drizzle of Melbourne but a vertical ocean, a biblical demonstration of water's capacity for volume. It hit the pavement so hard it bounced, creating a secondary mist that rose from the ground and merged with the falling rain, so that for a few minutes the street was barely visible, a grey-white haze punctuated by the red taillights of stalled traffic.

The hostel filled. Travelers who had been out on afternoon excursions came streaming through the front door, laughing, drenched, wringing out hats and squeezing water from hair. The common room's population tripled in ten minutes. Conversations started the way conversations always started in hostels during rain: Where are you from? How long are you here? Have you been to...?

Connor was drawn into a group. Three Scandinavians -- two Swedish women and a Danish man -- who were sharing a bottle of duty-free vodka mixed with canned passion fruit juice, a combination that tasted like a tropical sunset designed by someone who had never seen one. The Swedish women were medical students on placement in Penang, down to KL for the weekend. The Danish man, Lars, was a software developer "on sabbatical," which appeared to mean "drinking in hostels until the money ran out."

They were loud. They were fun. They were the specific kind of fun that hostels manufactured -- the effortless, temporary, chemistry-of-strangers fun that happened when you put young people from different countries in a room with alcohol and rain.

Connor drank. He told his stories -- the Bali stories, the Cambodia stories, the time he'd ridden a motorcycle across Vietnam without a licence ("Mate, the cops just waved me through, it's different in Asia"). He was good at this. This was his skill, his actual skill: the transformation of unremarkable experiences into compelling narratives, the alchemy of turning a cheap holiday into an epic. He held the group. He made them laugh. He made the Swedish women lean in. He made Lars nod with the earnest agreement of a man three vodkas deep.

For an hour, he was the person he believed himself to be. The traveler. The storyteller. The one who had figured it out.

Then one of the Swedish women -- Astrid, blonde, tall, with the angular features of a Bergman film -- said something that detonated quietly in the middle of the conversation.

"We had a lecture before we came," she said. "At the university. On practicing medicine abroad. Part of the briefing was about local laws."

She was two vodkas in, her English precise and musical in the way Swedish-accented English was, every vowel clear. She was talking to the group generally but looking at Connor specifically, the way people looked at the person who talked the most.

"Did you know that Malaysia has the death penalty for drugs?" she said. "Like, actual death penalty. Not life in prison -- death. If you're caught with more than fifty grams of methamphetamine, you're automatically charged with trafficking. Mandatory death sentence."

The common room was warm. The rain hammered outside.

"Yeah, they've got signs at the airport," Connor said. "Mental, isn't it?"

"We had to sign a declaration before we came. That we understood the drug laws and wouldn't carry anything for anyone. Even prescriptions -- our professor said you can get into trouble for carrying painkillers without documentation."

Lars, the Danish man, nodded. "Same in Singapore. My friend's cousin -- this was ten years ago -- got caught at the Causeway with hash. He was in prison for two years. And that's light. In Malaysia, with the quantity they're talking about..."

He drew a finger across his throat. The gesture was theatrical, clumsy, the kind of thing a drunk man does when he thinks he's being dramatic. But the meaning was unambiguous.

"That's for dealers though, isn't it?" Connor said. "Like, actual drug dealers. Big fish. They're not going to execute some backpacker who's got a joint in his pocket."

"The law doesn't distinguish," Astrid said. She said it the way medical students said things -- with the flat certainty of someone quoting a textbook. "Over fifty grams, you're presumed to be trafficking. The burden of proof reverses. You have to prove you *weren't* trafficking. And the mandatory sentence is death."

"Mandatory meaning--"

"The judge has no choice. It's automatic. You're convicted, you're sentenced. There's an appeal process but the success rate is..." She shrugged. The shrug contained the entire weight of a legal system designed to be merciless.

"That's insane," Jake said. Jake had appeared from somewhere, beer in hand, attracted by the gravity of a group. "They can't just kill you for carrying drugs. Like, there have to be exceptions. For foreigners."

"There are no exceptions for foreigners," Astrid said. "They've executed Australians. Nigerians. Iranians. A British woman in the eighties, though I think that was in a different country. The point is, the law applies to everyone."

"They've executed Australians?" Connor's voice did something he didn't intend -- it rose half an octave, the register of surprise rather than the register of casual dismissal. He corrected immediately. "I mean, that's -- when was this? Ages ago, right?"

"I don't know the details. Our professor mentioned it. The point was clear: know the law before you go."

"Right. Well, I'm not carrying any drugs, so." He laughed. The laugh was supposed to close the topic the way a door closes a room -- firmly, completely, with the clear message that whatever was on the other side was not relevant to whoever was on this side. But the door didn't close all the way. A draught came through.

He drank his vodka-passion-fruit. It was warm now, the ice melted, the taste cloying. The rain was beginning to ease, the percussion on the zinc roof fading from fury to murmur. The common room was steamy, the air thick with the humidity of twenty wet bodies and the smell of cheap vodka and rainwater.

Connor's mind was doing something it rarely did: operating on two levels simultaneously. The surface level -- the talking, the laughing, the performing -- continued without interruption. Beneath it, a second process was running, involuntary and unwelcome, playing back Astrid's words in a loop.

*Mandatory death sentence. Over fifty grams. The law doesn't distinguish. No exceptions for foreigners.*

The sports bag he'd carried that morning. The weight of it. The density. The rectangular shape, compressed, heavier than phone chargers. How heavy was fifty grams? He didn't know. He'd never thought in grams. Fifty grams was... the weight of a few coins? The weight of a small chocolate bar? The weight of something that could fit in the palm of your hand?

*What was in the bag?*

The question surfaced, bright and sharp, like a fish breaking water. He looked at it. The machine started running.

*Phone components. Felix said phone components. Felix has never lied to me. The bag was full of phone components for Mr. Tan's shop, which is expanding. It was heavier because it was a bigger order. Simple. Logical. Done.*

The fish sank. The water closed. The surface was smooth again.

"Anyway," Connor said, refilling his cup from the vodka bottle, "who wants to hear about the time I accidentally crashed a wedding in Bali?"

The group laughed. The conversation moved on. The rain stopped. KL's sky cracked open and revealed the late-afternoon sun, which hit the wet streets and turned them to mirrors and made everything -- the shophouses, the temples, the market stalls, the Petronas Towers in the distance -- glow with the specific, temporary beauty that follows a tropical downpour, the beauty that makes you forget what came before and not think about what comes next.

---

That night, Connor lay in Bed 7 and could not sleep.

This was unusual. Connor's relationship with sleep was the same as his relationship with most things: uncomplicated, requiring no effort, arriving when expected. He typically fell asleep within minutes of closing his eyes, his consciousness dimming like a phone screen timing out, the day's inputs dissolving into the static of dreams that he never remembered.

Tonight the static wouldn't come.

The dorm was dark. The ceiling fan turned. The French backpacker above was asleep. Two beds over, the Korean girl's earbuds emitted a faint tinny pulse. Through the air well, the residual sounds of the city's midnight -- a motorcycle, a distant stereo, a cat in the alley -- filtered up through the building's open core and settled into the room like sediment.

Connor's mind was replaying the afternoon's conversation. Not all of it -- not the Bali wedding story or Lars's software sabbatical or the Swedish women's medical placements. Just one part. Just Astrid's voice, precise and Swedish-accented, saying: *The law doesn't distinguish.*

He turned over. The mattress squeaked. The thin foam compressed under his shoulder with the familiar inadequacy of hostel bedding. He stared at the wooden slats of the bunk above him, at the stickers -- BINTANG BEER, FULL MOON PARTY KOH PHANGAN, a Thai flag, a peace sign -- and tried to think about something else.

*RM2,000 a week. That's what matters. That's the reality. Not some hypothetical, paranoid, what-if scenario about drug laws that don't apply to me because I'm not carrying drugs.*

*Am I carrying drugs?*

The question came. It was not the first time it had come. But it was the first time it stayed.

He lay in the dark and held the question and looked at it the way you look at something you've found in a drawer that you don't recognise -- turning it over, trying to determine if it's valuable or dangerous or both. The question had weight. It had the same weight as the sports bag -- the weight of something compressed, dense, occupying less space than its mass should allow.

He thought about the bag. The black nylon. The zipper. The rectangular shape inside. The way Mr. Tan had unzipped it with his body blocking the view. The way Felix had said *don't open it* with the specific emphasis of a man who was not talking about quality control.

He thought about Mei Ling. *Be careful what you carry for other people.* The stone she'd placed on the counter between them, the stone he'd stepped over.

He thought about the burner phone on the mattress beside him. The work phone. The corporate-policy phone. The phone that legitimate import-export businesses definitely gave their field staff, because that was how the corporate world worked, obviously, everyone knew that.

He thought about Priya's face in the common room two days ago. *It looks like something I've read about.*

He thought about Tomoko's voice. *The people Felix knows are not who he says they are.*

He thought about Mama Siti's proverb. *He who eats the chilli feels the heat.*

He thought about Astrid's words. *Mandatory death sentence. No exceptions for foreigners.*

The thoughts circled. They moved through his mind the way the ceiling fan moved through the humid air -- around and around, never arriving anywhere, never resolving, just circulating. Each thought produced a counter-thought. Each doubt produced a defence. The machine ran. But tonight the machine was not running smoothly. Tonight there was grit in the gears, sand in the engine, the accumulated friction of too many warnings dismissed and too many questions unasked.

Connor lay in the dark and felt something he had not felt since the night before his Monash University exam results came back, the exam he knew he'd failed, the exam that would confirm what he'd been running from for the rest of his life: that he was not the person he'd told everyone he was.

The feeling was fear.

Not the clean, sharp fear of immediate danger -- not the fear of a snake or a cliff or a car coming too fast. This was the other fear, the slow one, the one that lives in the back of the skull and wakes you at three AM and asks questions you can't answer. The fear of having done something that cannot be undone. The fear of a mistake so large it doesn't have edges, so you can't see where it ends and where you begin.

He thought: *I should open the next bag.*

The thought was clear. It was responsible. It was the thought of a man engaging with reality for the first time in weeks, reaching out to touch the surface of the water he'd been floating on and checking whether it was water or something else.

He thought: *If it's phone components, then I'm right and everyone else is wrong and I'll keep going and the money will come and everything will be fine.*

He thought: *If it's not phone components--*

He stopped. The sentence had a second half but the second half contained a world he could not enter from the warm safety of Bed 7 in Dorm 3 in the Lantern Hostel on Petaling Street in Kuala Lumpur. The second half contained police and lawyers and embassies and phone calls to his mother at three AM Melbourne time and the sound of her voice breaking and the word *mandatory* and the word *death* and the word *sentence*, and these words were too large for this small dark room with the ceiling fan and the French snorer and the stickers of places where people had been happy.

He didn't finish the sentence. He turned over. He pulled the blue Sea to Summit towel from beneath his pillow -- he slept with it there, always, a habit from years of hostels where things went missing -- and draped it across his chest. The microfiber was cool and smooth and smelled faintly of sunscreen and the Andaman Sea and all the places the towel had been with him, all the countries and the showers and the beaches and the laundry sinks where he'd washed it by hand and wrung it out and hung it to dry and known, in the simple, animal certainty of possession, that this was his.

The fear was still there. But the towel was on his chest and the fan was turning and the building was breathing and somewhere in the machinery of his mind, the operator was reaching for the off switch.

*She'll be right,* Connor thought. *She's always been right. I'll open the next one. Just to check. Just to be sure. And it'll be phone components, because it's always been phone components, and then I'll know, and I'll stop worrying, and everything will be fine.*

He wouldn't open the next one. He knew this already, the way you know you won't go to the gym tomorrow even as you set the alarm. The promise to check was a sedative, not a plan. It existed to get him through the night, to bridge the gap between the fear and the morning, to give the machine time to reassemble itself and smooth the grit from its gears and resume the production of certainty that was Connor Briggs's primary manufacture.

Sleep came. It took longer than usual -- forty minutes, maybe fifty, the longest he'd been awake in a hostel bed since the cockroach incident in Phnom Penh -- but it came, descending through the layers of his consciousness and carrying him down to a place where the questions didn't follow.

He slept. The phones lay beside him -- one cracked and sticker-covered and full of the life he showed the world, one clean and anonymous and full of a life he carried in the dark. The blue towel rose and fell on his chest with his breathing.

Beneath his hand, unlit, unfelt, the name in the bed frame waited.

L-E-N-A.

She had laid in this exact position. She had held this exact fear. She had told herself the same lies, in the same dark, in the same bed, with the same fan turning overhead. And she had not opened the bag, and she had not asked the question, and the machine had run, and the morning had come, and she had carried the next one and the next one and the next one until the morning came when the bag didn't matter anymore because the police were at the bus station and the handcuffs were cold and the word *mandatory* was no longer theoretical.

Lena was in Kajang Prison, forty kilometres south of this bed. She had a number now instead of a name. She had a cell instead of a dorm. She had a sentence instead of a future. And the bed frame still carried her name, five letters carved with a fingernail or a coin, a message to whoever came next, a message that said *I was here, I was real, I carried the bags and I didn't ask and this is where it ends*, and the message went unread every night by the boy who slept above it, the boy who was following the same path, step by step, bag by bag, into the same dark.

The building creaked. The rain had passed. The city hummed. And in the morning, the work phone would buzz with a new address, and Connor would dress and descend and collect a new bag and carry it without opening it to a new man in a new doorway, and the money would arrive in his account, and the machine would run, and the fear would dissolve in the daylight the way it always dissolved, the way it was designed to dissolve, the way it would keep dissolving right up until the moment when the fear was the only thing left and even the machine couldn't make it go away.

But that was later. Now there was sleep, and the towel, and the dark, and the building holding him the way buildings hold everyone who sleeps inside them -- gently, temporarily, without promise.
# Chapter 13: The Other Traveler

The man's name was David, and he had a story Connor didn't want to hear.

It was a Thursday night, Day 19, and the bar on Changkat Bukit Bintang was called The Whiskey Kitchen, which was a lie twice over because it served mainly beer and contained no kitchen. What it did contain was a long zinc bar, twenty barstools, a sound system playing nineties hip-hop at a volume that made conversation a competitive sport, and the particular strain of artificial energy that bars in tourist districts generate after ten PM -- the sense that something was happening, or about to happen, or had already happened and you'd missed it.

Connor was three beers in and feeling that internal warmth, different from the air's warmth -- more generous, the kind that made the world's edges soften and your own significance expand. He was perched on a barstool between Jake and a German couple he'd been talking to for twenty minutes without remembering either of their names.

Felix was not here. Felix was rarely at the bars anymore. Since the schedule had started, Felix had become more present and less visible -- texting daily, providing packages, transferring money, but spending his evenings in his private room or out of the hostel entirely, returning late, his movements untracked and unremarked upon. Connor had noticed this without noticing it, the way you notice a change in weather without looking at the sky.

Jake was telling the German couple about the fake Rolex. This was the third time Connor had heard the story, and it had evolved: the price had increased from eighty to a hundred and fifty ringgit, the vendor had become increasingly aggressive, and Jake's negotiation failure had been reframed as a deliberate act of magnanimity. "I let the guy have it," Jake was saying, his backward cap tilted at the angle of maximum sincerity. "It's, like, their economy, dude. Trickle-down tourism."

Connor laughed. The laugh was genuine. Jake's gift was the opposite of Connor's: where Connor curated stories for maximum impression, Jake told them with zero awareness of how they landed, which gave them an accidental honesty that was funnier than any calculated joke.

It was at the tail end of the Rolex story that David arrived.

He appeared on the barstool beside Connor the way people appeared on barstools in places like this -- without preamble, without introduction, materialising from the crowd like a chemical precipitate. He ordered a Tiger, drank a third of it in one motion, and set the bottle down with the deliberate care of a man who was pacing himself for a long night.

David was approximately forty. Australian -- Connor could tell before he spoke, by the tan, the deep crow's feet, the particular brand of stubble that Australians cultivated the way the French cultivated scarves. He wore a faded grey T-shirt, cargo shorts, and the expression of someone who had been somewhere recently that he hadn't come back from entirely.

"G'day," Connor said, because one Australian greeting another in a foreign bar was a gravitational inevitability. "Where you from?"

"Perth. You?"

"Melbourne."

"Right. Hawthorn?"

Connor blinked. "How'd you know?"

"Wild guess. You look like Hawthorn." He said *Hawthorn* the way Perth people said anything about Melbourne's eastern suburbs -- with a precision that managed to be simultaneously accurate and insulting.

"I'll take that as a compliment."

"You probably would."

David drank. Connor drank. The nineties hip-hop transitioned to nineties R&B, and two British girls at the end of the bar began singing along to TLC's "No Scrubs" with the passionate inaccuracy of people who'd learned the words phonetically.

"How long you been in KL?" David asked.

"Three weeks, give or take. Loving it. Best city in Southeast Asia, reckon."

"It's a good city." David's voice was level, careful, the voice of a man calibrating how much to say. "I've been here before. Few times. Back when I was younger. Traveling."

"Yeah? Backpacking?"

"Something like that." He drank. "I'm here for something different this time. Visiting someone."

"Oh yeah? Mate of yours?"

David looked at Connor. The look lasted two seconds. In those two seconds, Connor saw something in David's eyes that he would later describe to himself as tiredness but which was actually something deeper -- a bone-deep weariness, the kind that comes from carrying a story too long and telling it too many times.

"My brother," David said. "He's in Kajang Prison."

The words arrived at the bar and sat between them. Connor's hand paused, the beer bottle halfway to his mouth. Kajang Prison. He didn't know what Kajang Prison was, but the word *prison* was clear enough to change the temperature.

"Shit," Connor said. "What happened?"

David turned his bottle on the bar, rotating it slowly between his palms. The label -- Tiger Beer, orange and gold -- moved in a circle, the tiger's face appearing and disappearing.

"My brother Steve. Thirty-two when it happened. He was backpacking. Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia. You know the route."

Connor knew the route. He'd done the route. He was doing the route.

"He was in KL. Staying in a hostel in Chinatown. Not yours -- a different one, closer to the river. He'd been here about a month. Made friends. Met some people."

David paused. The "No Scrubs" performance had reached its crescendo. Jake was clapping.

"He met a guy. An older guy, European. Charming. Had money, had connections, knew everyone. My brother liked him. Trusted him. Started doing favors for him -- carrying things around the city. Packages, envelopes. My brother thought it was legit. Import-export, the guy told him. Electronics."

Connor's beer was still halfway to his mouth. He lowered it. The warmth of three beers was receding, replaced by something cooler, something that moved through his chest like a cold draught through an open door.

"He carried packages for this guy for about six weeks," David said. "The money was good. Really good. Better than anything my brother had earned in his life. He stopped questioning it. Stopped thinking about it. Just carried the bags, collected the money, lived the life."
