The bar noise was there -- the music, the voices, the clinking -- but Connor heard it from a distance now, as though someone had turned the volume down on everything except David's voice, which was close and clear and moving through the space between them with the weight of something that had been said many times and never got lighter.

"Then he got arrested. Highway checkpoint. North-South Expressway, heading to Penang." David pronounced *Penang* the Australian way, flat and final. "Police pulled the bus over. Drug dog went straight to his bag. Suitcase, actually -- the guy had asked him to take a suitcase this time, said it was a bigger order. My brother didn't check what was inside. He'd never checked."

Connor set his beer on the bar. The condensation ran down the bottle and pooled on the zinc, a small circle of water that he watched as though it contained something worth seeing.

"Methamphetamine. In the lining of the suitcase. Three hundred grams." David said the number the way you'd say a temperature reading at a hospital -- factual, clinical, already knowing what it meant. "Fifty grams triggers the mandatory death penalty in Malaysia. He had six times that."

The bar pulsed. The R&B played. The British girls had moved on to Destiny's Child. Jake was trying to teach the German couple how to do a keg stand with a barstool, which was physically impossible but entertainingly attempted.

"That was five years ago," David said. "He's been in Kajang since. The death sentence was handed down in 2022. It's been through three appeals. All failed. He's on death row."

The words *death row* landed on the bar like stones dropped from a height. Connor heard them hit. He felt the impact in his stomach, in his hands, in the suddenly cold surface of the beer bottle he was holding.

"The guy who recruited him -- the European, the charmer -- was gone before the police even opened the suitcase. Just vanished. Nobody at the hostel knew his real name. He'd paid cash, given a fake passport at check-in. The CCTV at the hostel had been 'malfunctioning' for the whole period. My brother was the only person arrested. The only name on the evidence. The only face on the camera at the bus station."

David finished his beer. Set the empty bottle on the bar with a care that was almost reverent, the way you set down something fragile.

"He was the mule," David said. "That's what they call it. The person who carries the drugs doesn't know what they're carrying, or doesn't want to know. They're expendable. If they get caught, the network cuts them loose. No connection. No evidence. Just some backpacker with a suitcase full of meth and a story about import-export that no court in the world would believe."

Connor was aware that he should speak. The social mechanics of the situation demanded a response -- sympathy, outrage, something. But the machine in his head was running at full speed, processing David's story not as a story but as a pattern, a template, a description of events that bore a resemblance to other events that Connor did not want to compare them to.

*It's different,* the machine said. *David's brother's situation is completely different. Felix is a photographer. The packages are phone components. I've done the deliveries and nothing has happened. Nothing has happened.*

"That's..." Connor started. The sentence wanted to be *that's exactly what's happening to me* but the machine intercepted it and rerouted and what came out was: "That's awful, mate. I'm really sorry."

"Thanks." David nodded. The nod was small, practiced, the nod of a man who had received condolences so many times they'd become a ritual rather than a comfort. "I visit him every year. Four times now. The prison is... it's not what you'd imagine. It's worse. The heat, the overcrowding. Steve's in a cell with eight other men. He gets one hour of exercise a day. He's lost twenty kilograms."

"Is there anything -- can he get out? Can the government do something?"

"The Australian government has made representations. Diplomatic channels. Legal aid. But the Malaysian courts are independent, and the law is the law. Mandatory sentencing means mandatory. The judge couldn't have given him less even if he'd wanted to."

David ordered another beer. The barman -- a young Malay guy with a nose ring and a Metallica T-shirt -- popped the cap and set it down without making eye contact. The economy of bar service in places where stories like this were not uncommon.

"The hardest part," David said, "isn't the sentence. I mean, it is -- it's a death sentence, it's the hardest thing there is. But the hardest part is knowing he didn't have to be there. He could have said no. He could have opened one of the packages. He could have Googled 'Malaysian drug laws' and found out in thirty seconds what the penalties were. The information was there. It was everywhere. Signs at the airport. Travel advisories. Guidebook warnings. He just... didn't look."

The word *didn't look* moved through Connor's mind like something alive.

"He trusted the wrong person," David said. "That's it. That's the whole story. He trusted a man who was designed to be trusted, who made trusting him feel natural, who made not trusting him feel like paranoia. And the man was designed that way because design is what predators do. They design the approach, and they design the friendship, and they design the dependency, and by the time you realise you're in a trap, the trap is the only structure you have."

Connor drank. The beer was warm. The bar was loud. Somewhere behind them, Jake had successfully performed a modified keg stand that involved balancing on one hand while a German woman poured beer into his mouth, and the resulting applause was genuine and surprised.

"Can I ask you something?" Connor said.

"Sure."

"Did your brother ever... I mean, did he suspect? Before he got caught. Did he ever think something was off?"

David looked at him. The look was longer this time -- three seconds, four -- and in it, Connor saw something that might have been recognition. The recognition of one Australian looking at another and seeing the same species of confidence, the same architecture of denial, the same belief that the rules of the universe contained a clause excusing people who looked like them from consequences that applied to everyone else.

"He says he didn't," David said. "He says he never suspected. But I know my brother. He's not stupid. He's... trusting. Optimistic. The kind of bloke who assumes people are good because he's good. And he was broke and the money was easy and the alternative was going home and getting a job and admitting the whole travel thing was just running away."

The sentence hit Connor in the chest. It didn't hit the wall. It went through the wall and into the space behind, the space where the things he didn't examine lived.

"I think he knew," David said. "Not consciously. Not in a way he could articulate. But somewhere in there, he knew. He just chose not to look. Because looking would have meant stopping, and stopping would have meant facing everything the travel and the money and the friendship were helping him avoid."

The music changed. Someone had commandeered the bar's Bluetooth and "Bohemian Rhapsody" erupted at maximum volume, the opening piano notes cutting through the conversation like something from a different world. The bar surged with the energy of collective recognition -- drunk tourists singing along, hands in the air, the song functioning as it always did in bars: as a temporary religion.

Connor stood up. Not because the conversation was over but because his body was making a decision his mind hadn't caught up with. The barstool scraped on the floor. He reached for his wallet, pulled out a fifty-ringgit note, and placed it on the bar.

"This one's on me," he said.

"You don't have to--"

"I know. I want to." He paused. The sentence wanted more. It wanted *because your brother is in prison for doing what I'm doing and the least I can do is buy you a beer.* But the machine ran, and the sentence that came out was: "Take care of yourself, mate. And your brother. I hope it works out."

David nodded. "Thanks." He paused, then: "How long are you staying in KL?"

"Haven't decided."

"Can I give you some advice? Unsolicited?"

"Sure."

"Be careful who you trust. That's all. In this city, in this part of the world. Be careful who you call a friend, and be careful what you carry, and if someone offers you easy money, ask yourself why the money is easy. Because the money is never easy. The ease is the product. The ease is what they're selling you."

Connor heard the words. Every one of them. They entered his ears and moved through the auditory cortex and arrived in the part of his brain where meaning was assembled, and the meaning was clear. It was the clearest warning he had received -- clearer than Priya's concern, clearer than Tomoko's suspicion, clearer than Mei Ling's instruction, clearer than Mama Siti's proverb. It was the testimony of a man whose brother was on death row for doing the exact thing Connor was doing, delivered without ambiguity, without metaphor, without the comfortable distance of hypothetical.

Connor heard it. He understood it. And then he did what he always did with information that threatened the structure of his self-deception.

He changed the channel.

"Will do, mate. Cheers."

He clapped David on the shoulder -- the Australian gesture of solidarity, which functions simultaneously as a greeting, a farewell, and a way to end a conversation you can no longer sustain. David's shoulder was thin under the faded T-shirt. The man felt smaller than he looked, as though the story had been holding him up and now that he'd told it, the support had gone.

Connor walked back to Jake and the Germans. He ordered a shot of something amber. He drank it. He ordered another. The bar noise reassembled around him -- the music, the laughter, Jake's voice rising above it all with the indestructible buoyancy of a man who had never been troubled by a thought he couldn't resolve with another beer.

"Dude, who was that?" Jake asked.

"Just some bloke. His brother's in prison here."

"No way. What for?"

"Drugs."

"Shit. That's heavy."

"Yeah."

Jake processed this for approximately four seconds -- the amount of time Jake allocated to heavy topics before returning to baseline. "Want to do shots? The German girl's buying."

"Yeah. Shots."

They did shots. They did more shots. The bar swelled and contracted with the rhythm of the night, the crowd thickening past midnight and thinning after one. Connor drank with the specific, deliberate purpose of a man trying to flood an engine -- pouring alcohol into the machine until the rationalizations blurred and the fear numbed and the only thing left was the warm, idiot comfort of being too drunk to think.

It worked. Alcohol was reliable that way.

---

---

The hours between midnight and two AM blurred the way they always blurred on Changkat -- alcohol and bass and the friction of bodies in a space too small to hold them.

Connor moved from the bar to the dance floor to the smoking area, cycling through the stations of a night out with the practiced efficiency of a man who had done this in thirty cities. At every station, David's story followed him. It didn't sit on the surface of his thoughts -- he'd pushed it below, buried it under shots and music and the deliberate energy of a man trying to outrun something that wasn't chasing him. But it was there, the way a stone is there at the bottom of a river: invisible, immovable, changing the current.

In the smoking area -- a concrete courtyard strung with fairy lights and populated by the international fellowship of people who had quit smoking in their home countries but not abroad -- he stood next to a group of Malaysians. Young, well-dressed, speaking a rapid mix of English and Malay that Connor had learned to identify as "Manglish" -- the colloquial hybrid that sounded like two languages having an argument they were both enjoying.

One of them, a woman in her twenties with dyed blue hair and a T-shirt that said NASI LEMAK IS MY LOVE LANGUAGE, noticed Connor listening and switched to English.

"You're Australian, right? I can tell from the tan lines."

"Is it that obvious?"

"Very." She grinned. "First time in KL?"

"Been here three weeks."

"Three weeks! You like it?"

"Love it. Best food in the world."

This was the correct answer. The woman's grin widened and she launched into a five-minute lecture on where to find the best nasi kandar (a stall in Bangsar that had no name, you just had to know), the best cendol (a cart near Masjid India that only appeared on Tuesdays), and the best char kway teow (her grandmother's kitchen, but second-best was a hawker in Kepong who used so much lard his cholesterol was a medical concern).

Connor listened. He laughed. He took notes in his phone -- the real phone, the Instagram phone, the phone that existed in the world of food recommendations and normal conversations and people who didn't have brothers on death row.

"Be careful though," the woman said, as the conversation wound down and her friends beckoned from inside. "KL is safe, but it's not -- how do you say -- it's not without teeth. Don't walk alone in Chow Kit after midnight. Don't flash your phone on the LRT. And for the love of God, don't get involved with anything illegal. This country does not play."

She said it lightly, the way locals said it -- a casual caveat, a speed bump in an otherwise smooth conversation. But the word *illegal* caught on something in Connor's chest and held there, a fishhook in soft tissue.

"Wouldn't dream of it," he said.

"Good boy." She patted his arm with the maternal authority of a woman eight years his junior. "Enjoy your stay. Eat the cendol on Tuesday."

She disappeared inside. The fairy lights swayed. Connor stood in the smoking area and didn't smoke and felt the fishhook pull.

---

They walked home at two AM, Connor and Jake, weaving through the Changkat aftermath -- the street littered with cigarette butts and promotional flyers and the occasional shoe, the bars disgorging their final patrons into the humid dark, taxis lined up at the intersection like yellow insects drawn to the remaining light.

Jake was monologuing about a girl he'd talked to at the bar -- Swedish, or Finnish, or possibly Estonian, he wasn't sure, but she had great hair and had given him her Instagram and this was basically a proposal. Connor listened with the fractional attention of a man whose mind was elsewhere, in a prison forty kilometres south, in a holding cell, in the back of a bus on the North-South Expressway where a drug dog was moving down the aisle and the suitcase in the overhead compartment was humming with the energy of three hundred grams of compressed catastrophe.

*It's not the same,* the machine said. The machine was drunk but still operational, still producing its product, still smoothing the rough edges of reality into shapes Connor could hold without cutting himself. *David's brother was unlucky. David's brother trusted the wrong person. I trust Felix, and Felix is different, because Felix is my mate, and David's brother's recruiter was a stranger, and the situations are completely different.*

They were not completely different. They were, in fact, identical -- the same mechanism, the same design, the same trap baited with the same friendship and the same money and the same carefully engineered ignorance. The only difference was time. David's brother was five years ahead of Connor on the same road, and the road's destination was the same, and the road did not fork or bend or offer exits. It went in one direction, and the direction was Kajang Prison, and beyond Kajang, a room with a rope, and beyond the room, nothing.

But Connor could not see the road because Connor was on the road, and when you are on a road, the road looks like the ground, and the ground looks like the only option, and the only option looks like a choice.

They reached Petaling Street. The market was collapsed for the night -- stalls shuttered, tarps tied, the corridor empty except for a few last food vendors sweating over cooling grills. The Guan Di Temple was dark, its red doors shut, incense still leaking from the gaps. The Chinese medicine store was a wall of shadows behind glass.

Wei's phone repair shop was dark too. For once, the fluorescent light was off. The cluttered window display -- cracked phones, coiled cables, the handwritten sign -- was barely visible in the street's ambient light. Connor glanced at it as he passed. A reflex. The glance lasted less than a second and contained no conscious thought, but his eyes registered something his mind would not process until much later: on the counter inside the shop, barely visible through the glass, a digital scale. The kind with a flat metal platform and an LCD readout. The kind used to weigh things in grams.

He walked past.

The hostel's red lanterns were off -- they were on a timer, midnight shutdown, though their glow lingered in the retina the way afterimages did. Connor pushed through the front door. The reception counter was unattended, Mei Ling long gone, replaced by the honesty system of an unlocked door and the assumption that backpackers who came home at two AM were not a security risk.

Jake headed for Dorm 1. "Night, dude. Epic night."

"Night, mate."

Connor climbed the staircase. On the second-floor landing, the Japanese characters waited under their layer of paint, patient and illegible. He pushed open the door to Dorm 3. The dorm was dark. Bodies in bunks, the anonymous shapes of sleeping travelers, the collective breathing of strangers sharing air.

He sat on the edge of Bed 7 and pulled off his flip-flops. His head was thick with beer and shots and the residue of David's story, which had settled into his consciousness the way silt settles after a flood -- covering everything, changing the colour of the water, making it impossible to see the bottom.

The burner phone was on the mattress where he'd left it. He picked it up. No messages. The screen glowed briefly, a flat blue rectangle in the dark, then dimmed. He set it down.

He lay back. The blue towel was under his pillow. He pulled it out and draped it across his chest, the ritual gesture, the comfort object, the microfiber membrane between him and the world.

*Mandatory death sentence.*

He closed his eyes.

*No exceptions for foreigners.*

He turned over.

*Be careful who you trust.*

He pulled the towel tighter.

*The ease is what they're selling you.*

The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.* The building creaked. The city hummed. And in the dark, in the quiet, in the space between waking and sleep, the machine faltered.

It didn't stop. The machine never stopped. But it faltered -- a skip, a stutter, a momentary gap in the continuous production of reassurance. And in that gap, in the half-second of silence between one lie and the next, Connor Briggs felt the full weight of what he was doing land on his chest like a stone, and the weight was real and the stone was real and for one fractured, terrifying moment he saw himself as he was: a man carrying packages for a stranger, in a country that killed people for carrying packages, and the packages were not phone components, and he knew they were not phone components, and he had always known, and the knowing was the thing the machine existed to bury.

The moment lasted. It lasted the way a match lasts -- bright, brief, illuminating the dark with a clarity that was almost cruel. He saw the room. He saw the bed. He saw the towel on his chest. He saw the two phones on the mattress. He saw the schedule in his daypack. He saw the name on the bed frame.

Then the moment passed.

The machine recovered. The gears caught. The production resumed. The rationalizations arrived in their familiar order -- *it's different, I'm different, Felix is different, the packages are different, the money is different, I'm Australian, she'll be right, nothing's happened, nothing will happen* -- and the stone on his chest dissolved into the general numbness of four AM and six beers and the body's desperate need for sleep.

Connor slept. The building held him. And in Kajang Prison, forty kilometres south, a man named Steve who had once been a backpacker in a Chinatown hostel stared at a concrete ceiling and counted the days, which was what you did when the days were all you had, when the days were numbered, when the number had been set by a judge in a courtroom and the number meant the days would end and after the days ended there was nothing, just the ceiling and the concrete and the memory of a bar in KL where someone had offered him easy money and he had said yes without asking why the money was easy.

Two men in two rooms in the same city. One with a sentence. One carrying the evidence for his.

Dawn was coming.

---

Morning came the way KL mornings came: with heat and noise and the call to prayer and the smell of Mama Siti's kitchen.

Connor woke at ten. Headache. Dry mouth. The specific hangover that was equal parts alcohol and sleep deprivation, the body's invoice for the previous night's expenditure. He lay in Bed 7 and waited for the room to stabilise -- the ceiling fan spinning, the light from the air well making the dorm's contents visible in soft grey: the bunks, the lockers, the backpacks, the accumulated personal effects of eight transient lives.

The burner phone buzzed.

He reached for it with the practised reflex that two weeks of the schedule had already built into his nervous system. The message was from Felix:

*Friday delivery. Package at Wei's shop. Pick up by 11. Drop at Bukit Bintang, Lot 22B. Danny. RM400.*

Connor read the message. He read it again. The words were the same words they always were -- a pickup, a destination, a name, a number. The machinery of the schedule, ticking over, indifferent to what he'd heard the night before, indifferent to David's story, indifferent to the stone on his chest that had not fully dissolved.

He lay there. Through the air well, the sounds and smells of the hostel's morning: water running, a door closing, the sulfurous whiff from the drains that the heat always stirred, the clang of something in the kitchen, Mama Siti's voice saying something in Malay that contained the word *bodoh*, which Connor had learned meant *stupid* and which Mama Siti applied to a generous range of subjects including the stove, the plumbing, the government, and most of her guests.

He could stop. The thought was there, clear and available, sitting at the front of his mind like an exit sign above a door. He could text Felix and say *I'm done*. He could delete the schedule, throw away the burner phone, and go back to being a broke backpacker with a cracked phone and 4,200 followers and a parents' deposit that kept him alive. He could go home. He could walk out of this building and take a Grab to KLIA2 and board a flight to Melbourne and be in his mother's kitchen by tomorrow morning, eating Vegemite toast and being asked about his plans and knowing that the question had no answer but that the asking was not dangerous.

He could stop.

The thought sat there. The exit sign glowed.

He picked up the burner phone and typed: *On it.*

The exit sign went dark.

Connor Briggs swung his legs off Bed 7, pulled on a singlet -- GOOD VIBES ONLY, the same one from yesterday, slightly beer-scented -- and went downstairs to collect a package from a phone repair shop that repaired no phones, to carry it across a city that would kill him for carrying it, for money that was not money but the price of his own ignorance, which he had placed on the counter and accepted in exchange for the life that was already ending, one delivery at a time.

Mama Siti watched him pass through the kitchen. She did not offer nasi lemak. She did not speak. She stirred her pot and looked at the boy and her lips moved once, forming a word that might have been a prayer or might have been a proverb or might have been the Malay word for *gone*, which was *pergi*, which was what you said when someone left a room and also what you said when someone left the world.

The front door opened. The heat rushed in. Connor stepped through.

The door closed behind him.

Mama Siti stirred.
# Chapter 14: The Law

The morning started with a delivery that almost didn't happen.

It was Day 21, a Tuesday, and the schedule said Brickfields -- Lorong 3, the "Blue Door," RM350. Connor collected the package from Felix's room at nine. Sports bag again, black nylon, zipped shut. The weight was the same as last time -- that particular density, that specific heft that he'd stopped thinking about and started accepting, the way you accept the weight of your own body.

The Grab took him south through the morning traffic, past the gleaming cylinder of KL Tower and the construction cranes that lined the sky like skeletal birds. The driver played Tamil radio, the music rich and complex, tablas and strings and a voice that climbed and descended in patterns Connor couldn't follow but found hypnotic.

The Blue Door was exactly that -- a metal door painted a blue that had faded to the colour of old jeans, set into the wall of a narrow lorong behind a row of shophouses in Brickfields. The lorong smelled of curry leaf and diesel and the warm, composting sweetness of overripe jackfruit from a tree that hung over someone's back wall. Connor knocked twice. The door opened. A woman this time -- middle-aged, Indian-Malaysian, wearing a salwar kameez in forest green, her expression carrying the professional neutrality of someone conducting a transaction. She took the bag. The door closed.

RM350.

He walked back through Brickfields. Little India -- the neighbourhood's unofficial name -- was in its midmorning rhythm. Garland shops were stringing jasmine and marigold into thick ropes for the temples. A banana leaf restaurant was opening its shutters, the staff laying down fresh leaves on metal trays with the reverent precision of altar preparation. Bollywood music leaked from a textile shop where mannequins wore saris in colours that existed nowhere in nature and everywhere in dreams.

Connor stopped at a tea stall. Teh tarik -- the pulled tea, milky and sweet, poured in a long golden arc from glass to glass. He drank it standing up at the counter, watching the garland maker across the street thread flowers with hands that moved like water, and he felt the warmth of the tea and the warmth of the money and the warmth of a Tuesday morning in a city he had come to know, and the warmth was good, and the warmth was the problem.

Because warmth was what made the carrying possible. Not the money -- the money was incentive, but incentive alone doesn't overcome the instinct for self-preservation. It was the warmth. The warmth of routine. The warmth of a city that had become home. The warmth of belonging to something -- a schedule, a network, a structure that gave his days shape and his wallet weight. The warmth made the packages invisible, made the drops ordinary, made the whole arrangement feel like life rather than the specific, engineered mechanism that would end it.

He finished his tea. He went home. He spent the afternoon at Grind Culture, posting for Pacific Soul, and in the evening he met Priya.

---

Priya had printed the law.

Not summarised it, not paraphrased it, not read about it in a guidebook and referenced it in conversation. She had found an internet caf on Jalan Tun H.S. Lee -- one of the last surviving specimens, a narrow room of ancient Dells and rattling keyboards that charged RM3 per hour and smelled of instant coffee and the stale urgency of travelers who needed to print boarding passes -- and she had sat at terminal number four and searched the Malaysian legal database and found the Dangerous Drugs Act 1952, Section 39B, and printed it.

Five pages. Single-spaced. The paper was cheap, the ink slightly smudged, the margins too narrow because the internet caf's printer was calibrated for A4 and these were A4 pages but the margins had been set by someone who didn't understand margins. The header read: LAWS OF MALAYSIA -- ACT 234 -- DANGEROUS DRUGS ACT 1952. The text beneath was small and dense and written in the particular English of Commonwealth legislation -- formal, archaic, devastating in its precision.

She had highlighted the relevant sections in yellow. The yellow marker -- borrowed from the hostel's communal stationery drawer, which contained three pens (one working), a roll of tape, and a selection of markers abandoned by travelers who had used them to write their names on food in the communal fridge -- bled slightly into the cheap paper, creating halos around the words it was meant to emphasise.

The highlighted passages said this:

*Section 39B(1): Any person who, on his own behalf or on behalf of any other person, whether or not such other person is in Malaysia --*

*(a) traffics in a dangerous drug;*

*(b) offers to traffic in a dangerous drug; or*

*(c) does or offers to do an act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a dangerous drug,*

*shall be guilty of an offence against this Act and shall be punished on conviction with death.*

And this:

*Section 37(da): Any person who is found to have in his custody or under his control --*

*(i) anything which contains more than 5 grammes of heroin or morphine;*

*(ii) anything which contains more than 15 grammes of cannabis;*

*(iii) anything which contains more than 50 grammes of methamphetamine...*

*shall be presumed, until the contrary is proved, to be trafficking in the said dangerous drug.*

Priya had read these passages six times. She had sat at terminal four in the internet caf with the screen casting blue light on her glasses and the ceiling fan overhead turning with the same lazy inevitability as the one in the hostel, and she had read the law six times because the first five times she kept hoping the words would rearrange themselves into something less absolute.

They didn't. The law was the law. The law said *death*. The law said *presumed*. The law said fifty grams of methamphetamine and you were presumed to be trafficking and the sentence was mandatory and the sentence was death and the judge had no discretion and the defendant had no exemption and nationality was irrelevant and ignorance was irrelevant and the gap between carrying a package and dying for carrying a package was measured in grams.

She had paid RM6 for the printing and walked back to the hostel through the afternoon heat with the five pages folded in her Lonely Planet, between the chapter on Kuala Lumpur and the chapter on Penang, and she had waited.

She waited through the afternoon. She waited through dinner -- she and Connor eating roti canai at the mamak stall on the corner, the conversation careful and warm, two people navigating around the topic they both knew was coming. She waited through the evening, through the common room hours when the hostel's social life assembled and dispersed, through Jake's announcement that he was going to Changkat ("Again? You were just there." "Dude, it's Changkat. It's always just there."), through Tomoko's silent transit from the staircase to the rooftop with her camera.

She waited until the common room was nearly empty -- just her and Connor and the TV playing a nature documentary in which a komodo dragon was pursuing something that didn't want to be caught. Then she set her Lonely Planet on the coffee table, opened it to the marked page, and removed the five printed sheets.

"I need to show you something."

Connor was on the sofa, phone in hand, scrolling with the absent focus of a man using his thumb to avoid his thoughts. He looked up.

"What's that?"

"The law." She placed the pages on the coffee table, the yellow highlights facing up, the words DANGEROUS DRUGS ACT visible even from his angle. "Malaysian drug law. I printed it."

The reaction was immediate and involuntary. Connor's body shifted -- a small, physical withdrawal, the torso leaning back an inch, the shoulders pulling together, the instinctive recoil of an animal presented with something it recognised as dangerous before the brain had time to intervene.

"Priya--"

"Just read it. Please. Just read this one section."

She pointed to the highlighted passage: Section 39B(1). The word *death* in yellow.

Connor didn't look at the page. He looked at Priya. She was sitting on the edge of the armchair, her back straight, her hands flat on her thighs. She was wearing her glasses and a white T-shirt and her hair was in its usual braid and she looked, in the amber light of the common room, like a doctor about to deliver a diagnosis that the patient had not asked for and would not accept.

"We've been over this--"

"No, we haven't. We've talked around it. You've told me it's phone accessories. I've told you I'm worried. We've had the same non-conversation three times and nothing changes. This is different. This is the actual law. Read it."

Her voice was steady but there was a pressure behind it -- the pressure of a woman who had been holding something back for two weeks and had decided, tonight, in this room, that holding it back was no longer a kindness. The pressure was love. Connor would not recognise this until much later, in a room where recognising it could no longer help him.

He looked at the page.

The words were small and dense and they sat on the cheap paper with the calm, immovable weight of something that had been true for seventy years. *Shall be guilty of an offence against this Act and shall be punished on conviction with death.* The yellow highlighting made the word *death* brighter, louder, more present. It was not a metaphorical death, not a figurative death, not the death that people meant when they said "I'd die for a coffee." It was the death of the body, permanent, administered by the state, in a building forty kilometres south of where Connor was sitting.

He read the sentence. His eyes moved across the words. The words entered his brain. Then the machine started running.

"Okay," he said. "So Malaysia has harsh drug laws. I know that. Everyone knows that. What's your point?"

"My point is--" Priya leaned forward. Her glasses caught the lamp's light and for a moment her eyes were invisible behind twin circles of reflection. "Connor, do you know what fifty grams looks like? It's this much." She held up her hand, cupped, the fingers forming a hollow the size of a tennis ball. "That's it. That's the threshold. If you're caught carrying that much methamphetamine, you're automatically presumed to be a trafficker. The prosecution doesn't have to prove intent. The burden shifts to you. You have to prove you *weren't* trafficking."

"I'm not carrying methamphetamine."

"How do you know?"

The question was a scalpel. It cut through the layers -- through the confidence, through the certainty, through the phone-accessories story and the logistics explanation and the Felix-is-a-photographer narrative -- and it touched something underneath. Something that flinched.

"Because Felix told me--"

"Felix told you it was phone components. Felix told you it was import-export. Felix told you it was logistics. Felix told you a lot of things. Has Felix ever *shown* you what's in the packages?"

"He can't. The clients--"

"Have you ever opened one?"

"No--"

"Have you ever weighed one?"

"What? No--"

"Have you ever noticed that the packages are heavier than phone accessories should be? That the drop-offs are always in back rooms, through side entrances, with people who don't make eye contact? That Felix gave you a burner phone -- a prepaid, anonymous phone that can't be traced? That the money he pays you is always cash transfer, never documented, never receipted?"

Each question landed like a step on a staircase, each one lower than the last, each one taking them further from the surface and closer to something dark and solid. Priya's voice did not rise. It remained clinical, measured, the voice of a woman who had been trained to deliver terrible news in controlled doses. But her hands were shaking. Not visibly -- the tremor was small, internal, the kind you felt rather than saw. Connor didn't see it.

"You sound like a conspiracy theory," he said. The words came out sharp, defensive, the verbal equivalent of the physical recoil from earlier -- the body protecting itself from information that threatened the architecture of the self. "Felix is a photographer. He does consulting work. The packages are phone components. I've done fifteen deliveries and nothing has happened."

"Nothing has happened *yet*."

"Right. And nothing's going to happen. Because it's legit. Because I know what I'm doing."

Priya reached across the coffee table and picked up the printed pages. She held them in front of Connor -- not aggressively, not theatrically, but with the quiet insistence of someone holding up an X-ray of a fracture the patient insists doesn't exist.

"Section 39B. Trafficking in dangerous drugs. Punished on conviction with death. Mandatory. The judge has no choice. There is no plea bargain. There is no first-offender exception. There is no exemption for foreigners." She paused. "Connor, if what Felix is giving you contains methamphetamine -- even if you didn't know -- the law doesn't care. The law says you're a trafficker. The law says you die."

The common room was quiet. The TV documentary had moved on -- the komodo dragon had caught its prey and was consuming it with the patient efficiency of a predator that had all the time in the world. The ceiling fan turned. The red lanterns cast their warm, permanent glow, and in that glow, in the amber light that made everything soft and safe and hostel-warm, the word *die* sat between two people who looked at each other across a coffee table and saw different things.

Priya saw a man she cared about walking into traffic.

Connor saw a woman who didn't understand.

"Priya." His voice softened. The sharpness dropped away, replaced by something warmer but no less defensive -- the gentle condescension of a man explaining to a woman that her fears are unfounded. "I appreciate this. I really do. I know you care about me and I know you're worried. But you're making assumptions based on -- what? A guidebook? A law you printed from the internet? You don't know Felix. You don't know the business. You're extrapolating from fear."

"I'm extrapolating from evidence."

"What evidence? That the packages are heavy? That Felix has money? That's not evidence. That's suspicion."

"I met a photojournalist who's been covering drug trafficking in Southeast Asia for three years. A woman from Japan who photographs things for a living. She says--"

"Tomoko." Connor's voice hardened again. "You've been talking to Tomoko about me?"

"She came to me. She's concerned--"

"She's paranoid. She's a stranger who decided she doesn't like Felix and now she's spreading--"

"She's not a stranger. She's a journalist. She recognises patterns."

"Patterns." Connor laughed. The laugh was thin, humourless, the acoustic signature of a man who is running out of defences and has resorted to the one that requires no argument: ridicule. "Patterns. So now Tomoko's a pattern expert and Felix is a drug dealer and I'm a -- what? A drug mule? Is that what you think?"

The word *mule* entered the room and the room changed. Not physically -- the fans still turned, the lanterns still glowed -- but the word carried a charge that altered the air, the way static electricity alters the feeling of a room before a storm. Connor had said it. He'd said it sarcastically, dismissively, weaponising the word to make it ridiculous. But the word was not ridiculous. The word was the exact, precise, correct term for what he was. A drug mule. A person who carries drugs for someone else, unknowingly or unwillingly. The word was the truth, and he'd spoken it himself, and now it was in the room, and it could not be un-spoken.

Priya didn't flinch. "I think," she said, with the careful precision of a surgeon making an incision, "that you are carrying things you have not looked at, for a man you do not know, in a country that will kill you for it. And I think you know this. And I think the reason you won't open one of those packages is because you're afraid of what you'll find."

The sentence was the most dangerous thing anyone had said to Connor since he'd arrived in KL. Not because it was unkind -- it was the kindest thing anyone had said to him in months, possibly years -- but because it was true. And the truth, in Connor's architecture of self-deception, was the one structural element that could bring the whole building down.

He stood up. The movement was sudden, physical, the body's response to a fight-or-flight signal that the brain had been too slow to intercept. He was standing before he knew he was standing, and the standing was a decision, the decision to be above this conversation, to be on his feet while Priya was seated, to occupy more space, to assert the physical dominance that men resort to when intellectual dominance has failed.

"You know what your problem is?" he said. "You plan everything. You research everything. You print out laws and highlight them in yellow and you think that preparation is the same as understanding. But you've been here three weeks, the same as me, and you haven't lived. You've studied. You've read guidebooks and printed laws and talked to journalists and worried about things that aren't happening. And meanwhile, I've been out there. Living. Experiencing. Actually doing the thing you're too afraid to do."

He heard himself speaking and felt the familiar momentum of a rant that has escaped the control of its speaker -- the sentences building on each other, each one louder and more wrong than the last, the rhetorical engine running on anger and fear and the desperate fuel of a man who knows, somewhere beneath the noise, that the person he's yelling at is right.

Priya sat in the armchair and watched him. She did not speak. She did not flinch. She did not cry. She held the printed pages on her lap and she looked at Connor with the expression of a woman who had just watched a patient refuse treatment, and the expression was not anger and it was not contempt. It was something worse. It was the particular sorrow of someone who understands that love, by itself, cannot save a person from themselves.

"Are you finished?" she said.

He was. The rant had spent itself. The room was quiet. The komodo dragon documentary had ended, replaced by a cooking show in Mandarin.

"I'm going to bed," Connor said.

"Connor."

He stopped at the foot of the staircase. She was standing now, the printed pages in one hand, her Lonely Planet in the other, her posture straight, her face illuminated by the red lanterns in a way that made her look both ancient and young, a woman from a painting, a woman who had seen something the painter couldn't capture.

"I'm leaving this on the coffee table," she said. She placed the five pages on the table, fanning them slightly so the highlighted sections were visible. "In case you want to read them. In case you decide that knowing the truth is worth more than not knowing it."

She walked past him. Her shoulder brushed his arm. The jade bracelet -- the one he'd bought her at the night market with money from the first envelope delivery -- slid on her wrist and caught the lantern light, green and vivid and paid for with something that was not clean.

She climbed the staircase. She was gone.

Connor stood alone in the common room. The cooking show played. On the coffee table, the five printed pages sat in the amber light, the yellow highlights glowing like small fires, the word *death* visible from where he stood, the word *mandatory* visible, the word *trafficking* visible, the whole ugly architecture of the law laid out in black ink on cheap paper, waiting to be read.

He could read them. Right now. He could sit on the sofa and read five pages and know, with legal precision, exactly what would happen to him if the packages contained what Priya believed they contained. Five pages. Ten minutes. The difference between ignorance and knowledge, between the comfort of not-knowing and the terror of knowing, between the man he was and the man he'd have to become.

He looked at the pages.

He looked at the staircase.

He went upstairs.

---

On the second-floor landing, the Japanese characters under the paint said nothing to him. They'd been saying nothing to him for three weeks, and they would continue to say nothing until the building was demolished or the paint was stripped or someone who could read wartime Japanese happened to pause on the landing and translate: *Processing Room 3 -- Detainees Report Here.* The building had always been a place where people were processed. The system had changed. The processing hadn't.

He passed the door to Dorm 4 -- Priya's dorm. A line of light showed under the door. She was awake. She was in there, awake, with her Lonely Planet and her knowledge and her fear for him, and the light under the door was like a hand extended, and he walked past it.

At the top of the staircase to the third floor, he almost collided with Tomoko.

She was coming down. Camera in hand -- the professional Nikon she carried everywhere, the lens cap off, as though she'd been shooting something on the third floor. In the dim hallway light, her face was unreadable, the dyed red tips of her hair dark as wine.

They looked at each other. The hallway was narrow. Neither moved.

"She told you," Connor said. Not a question.

Tomoko tilted her head. The gesture was economical, precise. "She told me she was going to talk to you. I told her what I've seen."

"And what have you seen, Tomoko? What exactly have you seen that makes you such an expert on my life?"

"I've seen Felix," she said. "I've been watching him since my first week. I've seen the packages arrive at the hostel at night. I've seen the people who bring them -- different people, always at night, always through the back entrance from the alley. I've seen Wei's shop and what happens there after midnight. And I've seen you, Connor. Every morning, going out with a bag. Coming back without one."

She spoke without emotion, without judgment, reciting observations the way a journalist recites facts -- assembled, verified, presented for the record. She was not trying to convince him. She was not trying to save him. She was documenting.

"I've taken photographs," she said. "Of the people who come at night. Of the packages. Of Felix and Wei together in the shop. I have a record."

"Great. You have a record. What are you going to do with it, Tomoko? Send it to the papers? Call the police?"

"I haven't decided."

The sentence was flat. It contained no threat and no promise. It was the sentence of a woman who had seen enough of the world to know that decisions made in hallways at midnight were rarely the right ones.

"But I want you to know," she said, "that the record exists. And that if something happens -- to you, to anyone at this hostel -- I will use it."

Connor stared at her. In the dim light, with the camera in her hand and the quiet certainty in her voice, she looked like something from a different genre -- not the dark comedy of backpacker culture but something more serious, more consequential, a woman standing at the intersection of witness and intervention and choosing, for now, to remain on the side of the former.

"Nothing is going to happen," Connor said.

Tomoko stepped past him on the narrow staircase. Her shoulder didn't touch his. The space between them was precisely maintained.

"*Ki wo tsukete*," she said. The Japanese was soft, almost inaudible. She didn't translate. She descended the staircase -- the third step didn't squeak for her -- and was gone.

Connor stood on the landing. He didn't know the phrase. He wouldn't look it up. It meant *be careful*, which was the same thing everyone had been telling him, in English and Malay and now Japanese, the same message in every language, the same warning he had been receiving and refusing since the day he arrived, the same two words that bridged every culture and every tongue and every human who had ever watched another human walk toward a cliff and tried, with nothing but words, to make them stop.

---

In Bed 7, in the dark, with the blue towel on his chest and the two phones beside him and the ceiling fan turning its endless, indifferent rotation, Connor did not sleep.

He lay on his back and stared at the underside of the bunk and thought about nothing, which was harder than thinking about something because nothing was not empty -- nothing was full of the things he was not thinking about, the pages on the coffee table and Priya's voice and the word *mule* and the word *death* and the weight of a sports bag and the face of a man named David at a bar on Changkat who had a brother in Kajang Prison.

At three AM, he got up. He crept out of the dorm, down the staircase -- the third step squeaked, louder in the empty building -- and into the common room.

The pages were still on the coffee table.

He stood over them. The common room was dark now, the lanterns off, the only light from the street lamps filtering through the front window. The pages were grey rectangles on the dark wood. He could see the yellow highlights, dimly, like reflections of something from a distance.

He reached out. His hand hovered above the pages. His fingers were close enough to feel the paper's texture -- cheap, slightly warm from the room, the surface rough.

He picked them up.

He held them in the dark. The weight was nothing -- five sheets of paper, an insignificant mass, the lightest thing he'd carried in weeks. But the weight was also everything, because the weight was knowledge, and knowledge was the thing he'd been running from since the first envelope, since the first RM200, since the first time Felix said *don't open it* and Connor obeyed.

He stood in the dark common room, in the hostel that had been a warehouse and an interrogation centre and a gambling den and a brothel, in the building that remembered every use and every user, and he held the law in his hands.

He put the pages back on the table.

He went upstairs.

In the morning, the pages would be gone. Aisha, the part-time cleaner, would collect them during her six AM sweep of the common room, mistaking them for rubbish, which in a certain sense they were -- rubbish to a man who would not read them, wasted paper, wasted ink, wasted yellow highlighter, wasted love. She would crumple them into the bin bag and they would join the compressed mass of hostel detritus -- empty bottles, food wrappers, boarding passes, the discarded evidence of lives in transit -- and the bin bag would be collected by the municipal truck at seven and carried to the Taman Beringin landfill, where the Dangerous Drugs Act 1952, Section 39B, would decompose in the tropical heat alongside everything else the city no longer needed.

And Connor would go downstairs, and the table would be empty, and he would feel a brief, complex relief -- the relief of a man who has been offered salvation and declined it, and now the offer has expired, and the declining is permanent, and the permanence is a kind of freedom, the terrible freedom of a man who has chosen not to know.

He would eat Mama Siti's nasi lemak. He would check the burner phone. He would collect a package from Felix's room and carry it to Chow Kit, to Jalan Raja Bot 12, to a woman called Auntie Lim who would take the package through a beaded curtain and return with a nod, and the nod would be worth RM350, and the RM350 would join the growing balance in his account, the balance that now exceeded what his parents deposited monthly, the balance that was the proof of a life working, a life that worked, a life that was working right up until it didn't.

He would not speak to Priya. She would be at the Islamic Arts Museum, alone, sitting in the gallery of Quran manuscripts where the calligraphy was so beautiful it made her eyes water, not because of the art but because the precision of it -- the care, the intention, the refusal to be careless with something that mattered -- was the exact opposite of everything she'd witnessed in the common room the night before. She would sit with the manuscripts and think about Connor and think about the law and think about the word *death* in yellow highlight on cheap paper, and she would not cry because Priya Sharma did not cry about things she could still fight, and she had not stopped fighting, not yet, though the man she was fighting for had done everything possible to make her.

And Connor would make his delivery and collect his money and come home to the hostel and the warmth would close around him like water around a stone, and the stone would sink, and the water would smooth, and by evening the argument would be something that had happened, past tense, archived, filed in the cabinet of things-that-didn't-matter alongside every other warning he'd received and refused.

The machine would run. The machine would always run. The machine was Connor's greatest invention and his most reliable companion, more faithful than any friend, more constant than any love, working every moment of every day to produce the one product Connor could not live without: the absolute, unshakeable conviction that everything was fine.

Everything was fine.

The building breathed.

Somewhere, forty kilometres south, in Kajang Prison, a man named Steve stared at his ceiling and counted the days left on a mandatory sentence, and the number was a number that got smaller every morning, and the morning was coming, and the morning always came.
# Chapter 15: The Checkpoint

Connor had been at this for ten days, and the deliveries had begun to feel like weather.

Not in the sense that they were natural -- nothing about carrying sealed sports bags across a tropical city for a German operative was natural -- but in the sense that they had become atmospheric, part of the climate of his days, present but unremarked upon, the way humidity was present but unremarked upon after you'd been in KL long enough to stop noticing the sweat.

His schedule had settled into a rhythm. Monday: Jalan Ipoh, Mr. Tan. Tuesday: Brickfields, the Blue Door. Thursday: Chow Kit, Auntie Lim. Friday: Jalan Ipoh again, return leg. Saturday: Bukit Bintang, Lot 22B, Danny. Wednesday and Sunday: rest. The rhythm had its own music -- pickup, carry, deliver, transfer -- and the music was so regular, so unvarying, that it had migrated from the foreground of his consciousness to the background, from the category of *things I think about* to the category of *things I do without thinking*.

The money was accumulating. RM2,800 in ten days, plus the RM700 from before the schedule. His bank balance had crossed RM5,000. Five thousand ringgit. He'd never had five thousand of anything except followers, and the followers were aspirational whereas the ringgit were real, countable, spendable. He'd upgraded his toiletries from hostel-grade to the good stuff from Watsons. He'd bought three new singlets at the Petaling Street market. He'd been tipping Mama Siti double. He'd even opened a separate savings account on his banking app, though the phrase "savings account" was doing more work than the account, which contained RM1,200 that he'd already mentally allocated to a PADI diving course in Sipadan once he left KL.

If he left KL. The leaving was becoming theoretical. The staying was becoming concrete.

This was the Wednesday when the police appeared, and the concrete cracked.

---

The police appeared on a Wednesday.

It was a rest day -- no deliveries, no schedule, no burner phone buzzing with addresses and contact names. Connor was walking through Bukit Bintang at midday, alone, wearing his SUNSET CHASER singlet and the board shorts he'd been wearing since Bali, his daypack over one shoulder containing nothing more incriminating than a water bottle, a cracked phone, a portable charger, and a copy of *The Beach* he'd taken from the hostel bookshelf and had no intention of reading.

He was clean. This was the word he used in his head -- *clean* -- and the word itself was a confession, because you only describe yourself as clean when the alternative is dirty, and the fact that Connor had begun categorising his days into *carrying* and *not carrying* was a development he hadn't noticed, or had noticed and filed under the increasingly crowded heading of things-that-didn't-matter.

Bukit Bintang at midday was a sensory assault disguised as a shopping district. The monorail glided overhead on its elevated track, silent and silver against the white sky. Below, the pavement seethed: tourists photographing the Pavilion mall's glass facade, locals navigating with the purposeful weave of people who knew the shortcuts, touts for massage parlours and tailors and watch shops creating a gauntlet of cheerful persistence. The smell was durian -- always durian in this part of KL, the spiky fruit's custard-and-gasoline aroma radiating from a stall on the corner with the insistence of something that refused to be ignored.

Connor was walking toward Lot 10 for lunch -- there was a hawker food court in the basement that served the best Hokkien mee in the city, according to Felix, which was an endorsement Connor trusted with the same uncritical faith he extended to everything Felix said. He was crossing Jalan Sultan Ismail at the pedestrian signal, phone in hand, thumbing through Instagram, when the checkpoint materialised.

It hadn't been there five minutes ago. Or it had been there and he hadn't seen it, which amounted to the same thing. A police barricade -- orange and white traffic cones, a portable barrier, two police vehicles parked at angles on the pavement -- had appeared on the corner of Jalan Sultan Ismail and Jalan Bukit Bintang, at the precise intersection where foot traffic was densest and avoidance was impossible.

Six officers. Four in the standard PDRM uniform -- dark blue, peaked caps, the Royal Malaysia Police insignia on the shoulder. Two in plainclothes, distinguishable only by the badges clipped to their belts and the particular way they stood -- weight distributed, hands free, the posture of people whose job it was to watch.

Connor saw the barricade from twenty metres away. His body responded before his mind did.

The response was immediate, physiological, and completely disproportionate to the circumstances. His heart rate spiked -- he felt it in his chest, a sudden, galloping acceleration from seventy to a hundred and twenty in the time it took to take three steps. His palms went wet. Not damp from the humidity -- wet, the sudden, cold sweat of adrenaline hitting the bloodstream. His stomach dropped, the way it dropped on a turbulent flight, the body's centre of gravity shifting as though the ground had moved. His vision narrowed -- the peripheral world dimmed, the central focus sharpened, and everything in his field of view except the six police officers became less real.

This was fear. Not the ambient fear he'd been carrying since David's story, the low-grade hum that lived beneath his confidence like a bass note beneath a melody. This was acute fear, the animal kind, the fear of the rabbit that has seen the fox and cannot yet determine whether the fox has seen the rabbit.

*I'm clean,* he thought. The word again. *I'm not carrying anything. My daypack has a water bottle and a book. There's nothing illegal on me or in me or near me. I'm clean.*

The logic was sound. The fear persisted. The logic and the fear operated on different systems -- the logic on the cortex, where reasoning happened, and the fear on the amygdala, where survival happened, and the amygdala didn't care about logic because the amygdala had been calibrated by three weeks of carrying packages through this city, and the amygdala had recorded every delivery, every drop, every sports bag and its weight, and the amygdala was now doing what it was designed to do: alerting the organism that the predator was near.

Connor's feet kept walking. This was the critical thing -- his feet kept walking toward the checkpoint, because stopping would be conspicuous, and turning around would be more conspicuous, and conspicuousness was the thing he could not afford, even though he was clean, even though his daypack contained nothing, even though the worst that could happen was a passport check and a smile.

He walked toward the barricade. The pavement was crowded. Other people were passing through the checkpoint without incident -- a Malay couple with shopping bags, a group of Japanese tourists with cameras, a European man in a business suit. The officers were checking bags, asking questions, waving people through. Routine. Standard. The ordinary machinery of a police state that was not a police state but was a country with laws that carried consequences Connor had never learned.

An officer stepped into his path. Young -- mid-twenties, clean-shaven, the peaked cap casting a shadow over his eyes. His English was accented but clear.

"Good afternoon, sir. Routine check. May I see your identification?"

"Yeah, no worries." Connor's voice came out at the wrong pitch -- slightly too high, slightly too fast. He adjusted. "My passport's at the hostel. I've got a photo on my phone."

He pulled out his phone -- the real phone, the Instagram phone -- and scrolled to the passport photo he kept in his camera roll. The officer looked at it. Australian. Connor James Briggs. The photo was three years old and showed a slightly younger, slightly less tanned version of the man in front of him.

"Australian," the officer said. Not a question. An inventory item.

"Yeah, mate. Melbourne."

"How long have you been in Malaysia?"

"About three weeks."

"Purpose of visit?"

"Tourism. Backpacking."

The officer nodded. He looked at Connor's daypack. "May I check your bag, sir?"

"Sure. Go for it."

Connor slipped the daypack off his shoulder and held it open. The officer looked inside. Water bottle. *The Beach*. Portable charger. A crumpled receipt from Grind Culture. The officer's gloved hand moved the items, checking beneath, checking the pockets. Finding nothing. Because there was nothing to find.

The officer handed the bag back. "Thank you, sir. Enjoy your stay."

It was over. Thirty seconds. A passport photo, a bag check, a polite exchange. The checkpoint had examined Connor and found him unremarkable, which he was -- today, on this corner, in this moment. Tomorrow, on a different corner, carrying a different bag, he would not be unremarkable. He would be carrying enough methamphetamine to trigger a mandatory death sentence. But today was today, and the officer was already looking at the next pedestrian, and Connor was already walking away with the particular lightness that follows a spike of fear -- the giddy, post-adrenaline relief that feels like joy but is actually the body's reward system congratulating itself for surviving something that wasn't dangerous.

He was ten steps past the barrier when a voice behind him said:

"Sir."

Connor stopped. Turned. A different officer was approaching -- older, mid-forties, in plainclothes. He was compact, muscular, his dark face carrying the particular weathering of a man who had spent decades outdoors in equatorial sun. His badge said SERGEANT and his name tag said AHMAD BIN ISMAIL. He walked toward Connor with the measured pace of a man who had been watching him since before the checkpoint and had decided, in the way that experienced officers decide things, that this conversation was worth having.

"Sir, a moment." Sergeant Ahmad's English was better than the younger officer's -- the accent lighter, the vocabulary more precise, the product of years of dealing with foreign nationals. He stood in front of Connor with his hands loosely clasped behind his back and his weight centered and his eyes reading Connor the way a radiologist reads a scan -- not the surface but the structures beneath it, the hidden architecture of a person under stress.

"Is there a problem?" Connor said.

"No problem, sir. Just a conversation." Ahmad smiled. The smile was professional, warm, and entirely unrelated to warmth. "You said you're backpacking. Three weeks in KL. That's a long time for a backpacker. Most tourists pass through in three or four days."

"I like it here."

"KL is a wonderful city. What do you like about it?"

"The food. The people. The energy."

Ahmad nodded as though these were the correct answers on a form he was filling out. "And where are you staying?"

"A hostel. In Chinatown. Petaling Street."

"The Lantern Hostel?"

The name landed like a coin on glass -- small, clear, impossible to ignore. Connor felt something tighten in his chest. Ahmad knew the hostel. Ahmad knew the hostel by name. This was not random. This was not routine.

"Yeah," Connor said. "That's the one."

"I know it. Old building. Uncle Razak's place." Ahmad's smile remained, but behind it, a different expression was forming -- the expression of a man assembling information in real time, connecting dots that the person in front of him didn't know were dots. "Good hostel. Interesting history."

"Yeah, Uncle Razak told me about it. The Japanese occupation, the--"

"Razak likes to talk." Ahmad's voice dropped a register -- not louder, not aggressive, but more focused, the conversational equivalent of a camera lens narrowing. "Do you know why I'm talking to you, Connor?"

He'd used his name. Connor's name, which he'd given to the younger officer on his phone screen, was now in Ahmad's mouth, and the use of it was deliberate, a signal that this conversation had moved from the territory of routine check into the territory of something else.

"No."

"I'm talking to you because you're an Australian backpacker who has been in Kuala Lumpur for three weeks, which is unusual. You're staying at a hostel in Chinatown that I know well. And when you approached this checkpoint, your body language changed."

Connor said nothing. Ahmad watched him saying nothing.

"You were walking normally. Relaxed. Phone in hand, like everyone else. Then you saw us, and your shoulders came up, and your pace changed, and your hand went to your bag. These are things I'm trained to notice. They don't mean anything by themselves. But they're things I notice."

The afternoon sun was directly overhead. Connor could feel it on the back of his neck, on his bare arms, on the top of his head. The heat was there but he was cold, the cold of adrenaline's second wave, the cold that comes when the body realises the danger has not passed but has merely changed form.

"I was just surprised," Connor said. "I wasn't expecting a checkpoint."

"Nobody expects checkpoints. That's the point." Ahmad's smile softened into something that was almost genuine. "Sir, I'm going to tell you something. It's not an accusation. It's a piece of information."

He paused. A motorcycle passed on Jalan Sultan Ismail, its engine cutting through the air like a tear in fabric. A woman at the durian stall laughed. The monorail hummed overhead.

"Malaysia is not a game, sir." Ahmad spoke the words with the calm, unembellished directness of a man who had said them before and would say them again and had long ago stopped hoping they would make a difference. "This country has laws. Some of those laws carry penalties that are -- severe. More severe than what you may be used to in Australia. The Dangerous Drugs Act, for example. Section 39B. I assume you've heard of it."

"Yeah. They had signs at the airport."

"They did. Signs. Warnings. The information is available. My concern--" He paused again, and in the pause, Connor saw something shift in Ahmad's expression: the professionalism thinned, and beneath it, briefly, was the face of a man who was tired. Tired of saying the same thing to the same kind of person and watching them nod and walk away and come back in handcuffs. "My concern is that the signs are seen and not read. The warnings are heard and not understood. Young travelers come to this city and they assume that the laws apply to other people. They assume that their passport is a shield. It is not."

The words settled on Connor like rain -- each one landing, each one cold, each one absorbed into the fabric of his shirt and his skin and his consciousness, leaving marks he'd feel later.

"I'm not doing anything illegal," Connor said.

"I hope not." Ahmad reached into his pocket and produced a business card. White, simple, the PDRM crest in blue and gold. SERGEANT AHMAD BIN ISMAIL. NARCOTICS DIVISION -- DANG WANGI. A phone number. An email.

Narcotics Division. The card said Narcotics Division. Ahmad was not a random officer at a random checkpoint. Ahmad was narcotics. Ahmad was the man who arrested people for carrying the thing that Connor might be carrying.

"If you ever need help," Ahmad said, placing the card in Connor's hand, "or if you become aware of something that concerns you, this number is direct. Day or night."

Connor took the card. The cardstock was thick, crisp, the ink sharp. It sat in his palm like a small, white brick.

"Thank you," Connor said. "But I'm fine. Really."

Ahmad looked at him for a long moment. The look was the longest anyone had given Connor since he'd arrived in KL -- longer than Priya's diagnostic stare, longer than Tomoko's watchful assessment, longer than Felix's calculating gaze. It was the look of a man who had been doing this job for twenty years and had developed, over those years, the ability to see through the surface of a person and into the architecture beneath. What Ahmad saw, Connor would never know. But the look ended with a nod -- not the brisk nod of a concluded transaction but the slow, heavy nod of a man who has recognised something and accepted that recognition is not enough.

"Enjoy your stay, sir. Be safe."

He turned and walked back to the checkpoint. His posture was straight. His steps were measured. He did not look back.

Connor stood on the corner of Jalan Sultan Ismail and Jalan Bukit Bintang with the business card in one hand and his daypack over his shoulder and the city pressing around him -- the monorail, the traffic, the durian stall, the Pavilion's glass facade reflecting the sky, the hundred thousand lives moving through the intersection without pause, without looking, without knowing that a man was standing in the middle of them holding a narcotics officer's card and trying to decide what to feel.

---

He went to the Pavilion. He went to the hawker food court in the basement and ordered the Hokkien mee and sat at a plastic table under fluorescent lights and ate.

The Hokkien mee was good. Dark soy sauce, fat yellow noodles, prawns, pork belly, the wok hei -- the breath of the wok, the charred, smoky flavour that came from cooking over maximum heat with maximum skill. He ate it with a fork and spoon and looked at the business card propped against his water glass and thought about the word *narcotics*.

Sergeant Ahmad. Narcotics Division. Dang Wangi. He didn't know where Dang Wangi was. He didn't know what the Narcotics Division did beyond the obvious. He didn't know why Ahmad had singled him out at the checkpoint, though some part of him -- the shrinking, gasping part that still had access to reason -- suspected it was because Ahmad was good at his job and Connor was bad at hiding.

He thought about the body language Ahmad had described. *Your shoulders came up, and your pace changed, and your hand went to your bag.* The officer had read him like text. The officer had seen, in the two seconds between Connor noticing the checkpoint and Connor reaching the barrier, the physical signature of guilt. Not the guilt of a man carrying drugs today -- he wasn't carrying drugs today -- but the guilt of a man who carried them other days, the residual guilt that lived in the muscles and the posture and the involuntary responses of a body that had been trained by repetition to associate police with danger.

His body knew. That was the thing. His mind could produce any narrative it wanted -- phone components, import-export, logistics -- but his body had been keeping its own records, honest records, recording every delivery and every sports bag and every back-door drop-off, and when the police appeared, the body's records were the ones that played.

The Hokkien mee sat in his stomach. He pushed the plate away.

He looked at the business card again. SERGEANT AHMAD BIN ISMAIL. NARCOTICS DIVISION. The phone number. The email. The card was a lifeline, thrown across the water to a man who was drowning and didn't yet know he was drowning. All Connor had to do was call. He could call right now, from this plastic table, and say: *I've been carrying packages for a German man in a hostel in Chinatown and I don't know what's in them and I'm scared.* He could say that. He could say it and the phone call would change everything -- the packages would stop, the schedule would end, Felix would be investigated, and Connor would be a witness rather than a defendant, and the difference between witness and defendant was the difference between living and dying.

He picked up the card. Turned it over. The back was blank -- white cardstock, no text, no logo. He ran his thumb across the surface. The card was real. The offer was real. The lifeline was real.

He put the card in his wallet, behind a crumpled Malaysian banknote and a loyalty card for a Bali smoothie bar he'd never revisit. He put the wallet in his pocket. He finished his water. He left the food court and walked through the Pavilion's air-conditioned corridors and out into the heat and back toward Petaling Street and the hostel, and the card rode in his pocket like a small, white fact that he was not yet ready to use.

---

That night, on the rooftop, he told Felix about the checkpoint.

Not everything. Not Ahmad's card, not the Narcotics Division, not the body-language assessment. Just the checkpoint itself -- the cones, the barrier, the bag check.

"They're doing random checks in Bukit Bintang," he said, keeping his voice casual, the voice of a man reporting a traffic delay rather than a surveillance state. "Just thought you should know."

Felix was in his usual chair, beer in hand, the Petronas Towers behind him. He listened. His expression didn't change. When Connor finished, Felix nodded once.

"Good to know. Thanks." He drank. "Was it standard? Passport check, bag check?"

"Yeah. Routine."

"And you weren't carrying anything."

"No. Rest day."

"Good." Felix's voice was even, balanced, the voice of a man adjusting a variable in a spreadsheet. "These checkpoints rotate. They're usually in tourist areas -- Bukit Bintang, KLCC, sometimes Petaling Street. They're looking for pickpockets, illegal hawkers, overstayed visas. It's public relations as much as policing."

"Right. That's what I figured."

"The important thing," Felix said, "is that you weren't carrying anything. And on days when you are carrying something, we'll adjust the routes. Away from tourist areas, away from the obvious spots. I'll update the schedule."

He said it the way a project manager discusses logistical adjustments -- calmly, competently, without any acknowledgement that the "something" being discussed was the thing that could not be named, the thing in the packages, the thing that turned routes into risks and tourist areas into minefields. The normality of his tone was its own anaesthetic. Felix discussed the movement of illicit cargo through a Southeast Asian capital with the same vocal register he used to discuss restaurant recommendations, and the register said: *This is normal. This is business. This is fine.*

Connor drank his beer. The Petronas Towers watched. The city hummed. In his pocket, behind the crumpled banknote and the smoothie-bar loyalty card, Sergeant Ahmad's business card sat in the dark and waited to be relevant.

It would not be used. Connor would carry it for the rest of his time in KL -- through every delivery, every drop, every escalation. The card would ride in his wallet like a talisman, a physical manifestation of the help he could summon but never would, the exit he could take but never did. When his belongings were eventually catalogued at Dang Wangi police station, on the night he was arrested, an officer would find the card in his wallet and show it to Sergeant Ahmad, who would look at it and recognise it and say nothing, because there was nothing to say about a man who had been given a lifeline and had chosen to drown.

The rooftop was quiet. The beer was cold. Felix was talking about a restaurant in Bangsar that served the best rendang in the city, and Connor was listening, and the listening was easy, and the ease was the product.

---

Later -- past midnight, after Felix had gone to his room and the rooftop had emptied and the city's noise had settled into its nighttime register -- Connor sat on the zinc railing and did something he rarely did.

He thought about his father.

David Briggs, property developer, Hawthorn, Melbourne. A man of routines and certainties, of golf on Saturdays and now Tuesdays, of the morning Herald Sun and the evening news and the quiet, dependable architecture of a life built on work and family and the assumption that these things were enough. Connor had spent four years defining himself in opposition to his father -- the nomad against the suburbanite, the free spirit against the nine-to-five, the explorer against the man who hadn't left Australia since a honeymoon in Fiji in 1994.

But sitting on the railing with the Petronas Towers before him and Ahmad's card in his pocket, Connor thought about something his father had said to him at the airport when he'd left for Asia the first time. He'd been twenty-three. His father had driven him to Tullamarine, parked in the short-term lot, and walked him to the international departures gate with the particular gait of a man carrying something heavier than luggage.

At the gate, David had put his hand on Connor's shoulder. The hand was large, square, calloused from decades of site visits and handshakes. "Mate," he'd said, and the word *mate* from his father's mouth was different from the *mate* Connor used -- his father's *mate* was serious, connective, the word of a man who had limited vocabulary for love and used the words he had. "Mate, I need you to understand something. In other countries, the rules are different. Not worse, not better. Different. And the rules don't bend for you because you're Australian. The rules don't care who you are."

Connor had nodded. He'd been in a hurry -- the gate was closing, his backpack was heavy, his phone was dying. He'd said "Yeah, Dad, I know" with the breezy dismissiveness of a twenty-three-year-old who had never been in trouble and therefore assumed trouble was something that happened to other people.

His father's hand had stayed on his shoulder. "Connor. I'm serious. The rules don't care who you are."

He'd said it twice. Connor had heard it once. The second time had gone where all his father's repeated warnings went -- into the category of parental excess, of middle-aged caution, of the specific kind of fear that Connor believed was the defining limitation of people who stayed home.

Now, on a rooftop in Kuala Lumpur, three and a half years later, the second saying of the sentence arrived. It had been traveling a long time.
