It had crossed the distance from Tullamarine to Petaling Street at the speed of a lesson unlearned, and it arrived at the exact moment when it could do the most good and the least damage, which was also the moment when Connor was least likely to act on it.

*The rules don't care who you are.*

He finished his beer. He went downstairs. He climbed into Bed 7 and pulled the blue towel over his chest and lay in the dark with his father's voice in his head and Ahmad's card in his wallet and the city outside the air well breathing its hot, wet, indifferent breath.

He thought about calling his dad. Not to tell him about the packages -- he would never tell his father about the packages -- but just to hear the voice. The square, certain, Australian voice that said *mate* like it meant something and repeated warnings because repetition was the only tool a father had when his son was too far away to reach.

He didn't call. The time difference -- KL was two hours ahead of Melbourne -- made it ten PM in Hawthorn. His father would be watching the news, his mother reading in bed. A phone call at ten PM from KL would trigger the worry, the questions, the careful voice his mother used when she was trying not to sound scared. He couldn't do that to them. He couldn't call without reason, and the reason -- *Dad, I think I might be carrying drugs for a trafficker, there's a narcotics officer who gave me his card, a journalist has photos, a medical student printed the law, and a man at a bar told me his brother is on death row for the same thing I'm doing* -- was not a reason he could speak aloud, because speaking it would make it true, and truth was the one thing Connor Briggs could not afford.

So he lay in the dark. The ceiling fan turned. The phones sat on the mattress. The name waited on the bed frame. And somewhere in the building, in his private room on the third floor, Felix was updating a schedule, adjusting routes around a checkpoint that an Australian backpacker had helpfully reported, the way a well-trained courier reports obstacles to his handler, the way a tool reports its own wear to the mechanic who will continue using it until it breaks.

The city hummed. The building held. The night was warm and long and full of the kind of silence that wasn't silence at all but the sound of a machine running so smoothly you forgot it was there, producing its product hour after hour, the product being certainty, the certainty being false, the falseness being the only thing keeping the man in Bed 7 from the truth that was already forming in the dark like a storm, far away but approaching, inevitable, its thunder not yet audible but its pressure already changing the air.
# Chapter 16: Tomoko's Camera

Day 24 began with a delivery to Chow Kit that left a taste in Connor's mouth like copper.

Not literally -- the taste was metaphorical, the taste of something wrong, the lingering aftertaste of a morning that had been subtly different from every other morning. The difference was in the pickup. Felix had not been in his room when Connor knocked at nine. Instead, the door was ajar, a package on the desk -- sports bag, black nylon, zipped shut -- with a Post-it note in Felix's handwriting: *Chow Kit. Auntie Lim. Usual spot.*

Felix had never left a package unattended before. Felix had always been there for the handoff -- the eye contact, the brief instruction, the warmth that made the transaction feel like friendship rather than commerce. The empty room, the package on the desk, the Post-it note -- these were the mechanics of a different arrangement, an arrangement that no longer required the human element because the human element was already trained and the training was complete.

Connor took the package. Rode a Grab to Chow Kit. Walked through the morning market -- Chow Kit Market, the sprawling wet market where the smell of fresh fish and raw meat and the metallic tang of blood on butcher's blocks combined into something that was simultaneously repulsive and vital, the smell of a city feeding itself. Women in headscarves moved between stalls of vegetables and spices, their shopping bags swelling. Men carried crates of live chickens past bins of dried shrimp and towers of durian. The market was loud and close and alive in the way that only markets in this part of the world were alive -- every sense saturated, every surface wet, every voice raised.

He found Jalan Raja Bot 12. Knocked. Auntie Lim -- small, sixties, silver hair in a tight bun, her face a map of wrinkles that suggested she had been frowning professionally for decades -- took the bag through a door that opened onto a corridor that smelled of incense and chemical solvent. She closed the door without nodding. This was new. The nod had been part of the protocol -- the acknowledgement, the confirmation, the small human signal that the transaction was complete. Its absence left a gap, a silence where a signal should have been, and the gap was the thing that tasted like copper.

RM350. The money arrived. The money always arrived.

He went home. He showered. And at four in the afternoon, the photographs were on the common room table, arranged in a grid, and they were the most dangerous things in the building.

Tomoko had printed them at the same internet caf Priya had used -- terminal four, the one by the window where the afternoon light hit the screen and made the images glow. She had uploaded sixteen photographs from the SD card of her Nikon D850, selected the eight most relevant, and printed them on the caf's colour printer, which rendered them in the slightly oversaturated tones of cheap ink on cheap paper, the colours too vivid, the shadows too dark, the overall effect somewhere between documentary evidence and art.

She laid them on the coffee table in two rows of four. Each photograph was labelled on the back in her precise, small handwriting: date, time, location. She had been watching for weeks. The photographs were the harvest.

Connor came downstairs at four fifteen, freshly showered, his hair still wet, wearing a singlet that said WANDERLUST in a font designed in a factory in Shenzhen. He was heading for the door -- Grind Culture, the afternoon flat white, the performance of productivity that had become as much a part of his routine as the deliveries. He saw Tomoko sitting in the armchair. He saw the photographs on the table. He kept walking.

"Connor." Her voice was calm, level, carrying the weight of something rehearsed. "Sit down. Please."

"I'm heading out--"

"This will take five minutes."

He looked at her. She was wearing her usual uniform -- black T-shirt, cargo pants, the red-tipped hair pulled back. No camera today. The camera was in her room, its memory card backed up to a cloud server in Tokyo that Tomoko had configured with the paranoia of a journalist who had worked in Myanmar and learned that hardware was confiscatable but data was not.

Connor sat. Not because he wanted to but because the alternative -- walking past her, ignoring the photographs, performing the kind of aggressive avoidance that would confirm everything she suspected -- was worse than sitting.

"What are these?"

"Look at them."

He looked.

The first row:

**Photo 1.** Felix and Wei in Wei's phone repair shop. Night. The fluorescent light casting its blue-white pall through the glass. Felix's hands flat on the counter, leaning forward. Wei opposite. Between them, on the counter, a package -- brown paper, rectangular, taped shut. The same brown paper. The same tape. The same packages Connor had been carrying. Date: eleven days ago. Time: 11:47 PM.

**Photo 2.** A man Connor didn't recognise entering the hostel's alley entrance -- the back door, the one that led from the narrow lorong behind the building through a gate and into the ground floor's utility corridor. The man was carrying a large holdall. He was not a guest. The date was nine days ago. Time: 1:12 AM.

**Photo 3.** The same man leaving the hostel's alley entrance forty minutes later. No holdall. Time: 1:54 AM.

**Photo 4.** Felix on the rooftop, talking on his phone. His expression was the one Connor had seen through Wei's shop window that night -- flat, focused, emptied of charm. The Felix behind the mask. Date: six days ago. Time: 2:23 AM. Tomoko had been on the rooftop in the dark, camera in hand, her presence undetected because Tomoko moved through the world the way experienced journalists moved through the world -- silently, watchfully, with the patience of someone who understood that the truth was usually found in the spaces between noise.

The second row:

**Photo 5.** Wei's shop, daytime. Shot through the window at an angle. On the workbench behind the counter, visible among the phone screens and soldering equipment: a digital scale. The kind with a flat metal platform and an LCD readout. The kind used to weigh things in grams.

**Photo 6.** Felix entering a black sedan on Jalan Sultan. Night. The driver was visible through the windshield -- a man in his fifties, Chinese-Malaysian, wearing a dark polo shirt. The sedan's plates were partially visible. Felix was carrying a large backpack -- not his own, not the daypack he used daily, but a larger bag, full, the straps tight.

**Photo 7.** Connor. Walking down Petaling Street. Morning. Daypack on his shoulder, the bulge of a package visible through the nylon. His face in profile, caught mid-stride, his expression blank, emptied, the face of a man performing a task he has stopped thinking about. He looked, in the photograph, like a delivery driver. He looked like exactly what he was.

**Photo 8.** The hostel's entrance at night. The red lanterns glowing. And on the wall beside the door, barely visible in the low light, fresh graffiti that hadn't been there the week before. Two words, in black marker, in a hand that was neither artistic nor careless: @HOSTELREAPER. Beneath it, a small symbol -- a scythe, or an hourglass, or something in between.

Connor looked at the photographs. The photographs looked back.

They were clear. They were dated. They were the kind of evidence that a journalist assembled not for publication but for proof -- proof that a pattern existed, proof that the pattern was consistent, proof that the person denying the pattern was the person most deeply embedded in it.

"These don't prove anything," Connor said.

He said it automatically, the way the machine produced its output -- without deliberation, without pause, the defence emerging fully formed from the assembly line of denial. The sentence was in the air before he'd finished looking at the photographs, which meant the sentence was not a response to the photographs but a pre-loaded response to any evidence, any challenge, any information that threatened the structure.

Tomoko didn't argue. She picked up photograph number one -- Felix and Wei -- and held it up. "This is your friend Felix, at one in the morning, in a phone repair shop, with a package identical to the ones you carry. The shop is closed. The owner is not repairing phones. They are looking at a package on the counter. What do you think they're doing?"

"I don't know. Business meeting. Felix does import--"

"Import-export." Tomoko said the words the way you'd say the name of a disease you'd identified too many times. "Import-export is the cover story. It's the same cover story in every country I've worked in. In Myanmar, they said import-export. In Laos, they said import-export. In the Philippines, they said logistics consulting. The words change. The mechanism doesn't."

She picked up photograph seven. Connor. Walking. Carrying.

"This is you, Connor. This is what you look like from outside. You look like a courier. You look like a man carrying something he hasn't checked, to somewhere he doesn't question, for someone he doesn't know."

"I know Felix."

"You know what Felix shows you. I've been a journalist for seven years. I've covered drug networks in three countries. The person who recruits the mule is never the person the mule thinks they know. They're a performance. A mask. A character designed to produce trust."

Connor's jaw tightened. He could feel the anger building -- not the clean anger of being falsely accused but the hot, defensive anger of being accurately described. The anger that comes when someone points at the thing you've been hiding from yourself and gives it a name.

"You've been stalking me," he said. "You've been following me around the city taking photos of me without my permission."

"I've been documenting a trafficking operation that runs out of the building I sleep in. You happen to be part of it."

"I'm not part of anything--"

"You are. You just don't want to know what." She set the photograph down. "I'm not showing you these to accuse you. I'm showing you because I want you to see what I see. And what I see is a young man being used by a professional criminal, in a country where being used by a professional criminal gets you killed."

The common room was empty except for the two of them. The TV was off. The ceiling fans turned. Through the air well, the afternoon call to prayer began, the muezzin's voice rising from Masjid Jamek with the particular beauty that Islamic prayer possessed -- a beauty that existed regardless of whether the listener understood the words, a beauty that asked for nothing and offered everything.

Connor looked at the photographs. Photograph seven -- himself, walking, carrying -- was the one his eyes kept returning to. He looked at his own face in the image. The expression was blank. Not happy, not afraid, not aware. Blank. The face of a man on autopilot, executing a programme he hadn't written, moving through a city he didn't understand toward a destination he hadn't chosen.

He looked like a mule.

The word arrived and he couldn't deflect it this time. The photograph was too clear, the image too precise, the evidence too visual. In words, the accusation could be argued with. In photographs, the truth was flattened into two dimensions and made inescapable, the way a mirror is inescapable, the way your own face is inescapable when you're forced to look at it without the filter of your own narrative.

The moment lasted three seconds. In those three seconds, the machine stuttered. The gears slipped. The production line halted, and in the silence, the truth was briefly, painfully visible -- not as a thought but as a sensation, a full-body recognition that he was in danger, that the danger was real, that the photographs on the table were a map of his own destruction and the map was accurate and the destination was fixed.

Then the machine caught. The gears engaged. The production resumed.

"You don't know what you're talking about," Connor said. His voice was quiet now -- the anger had burned through its fuel and what remained was something harder, colder, the voice of a man building a wall brick by brick. "Felix is my friend. The packages are phone components. Your photos prove nothing except that you've been creeping around the hostel at night with a camera, which frankly is more suspicious than anything I've done."

Tomoko watched him. Her expression did not change. She had the stillness of a woman who had sat across from people in denial before -- in Yangon, in Vientiane, in Manila -- and had learned that the denial was not the obstacle. The denial was the symptom. The obstacle was the fear that the denial was protecting, and the fear could not be reached by argument because fear was not an argument. Fear was a wall. And walls could only be broken by what was on the other side, pressing outward, demanding space.

"I'm going to keep watching," she said. "I'm going to keep photographing. And when the time comes -- when the evidence is complete -- I'm going to take it to someone who can use it."

"Who? The police? Go ahead. Call the police. Tell them you've been stalking guests at a hostel with your camera. See how that goes."

"I wasn't thinking of the police." She gathered the photographs from the table, stacking them with the careful alignment of a person handling evidence. "I was thinking of someone at The Star. Or The Guardian. Or the Australian embassy."

She stood. The photographs disappeared into a manila envelope she'd been holding behind the armchair. The envelope went under her arm with the quiet efficiency of someone who knew the value of what she was carrying.

"Connor," she said. She stood over him, and for a moment, the journalist dropped away and what remained was a person -- a twenty-nine-year-old woman from Osaka who had seen too much of the world's cruelty and could not stop trying to prevent it, even when the people she was trying to save were the ones fighting hardest to stay in danger.

"I like you," she said. "You're funny and you're kind, when you're not being a fool. But you are being a fool. And if you don't stop, what happens next will not be funny and it will not be kind, and there will be no photograph that can help you."

She left. Her door on the third floor opened and closed.

---

Connor sat in the common room alone. The coffee table was empty. The photographs were gone. But their afterimages remained -- burned into his retinas, the way bright lights left shadows when you closed your eyes. Felix and Wei. The midnight visitor. The digital scale. Himself, carrying, blank-faced, a courier in profile.

He sat for fifteen minutes without moving. Through the air well, the afternoon call to prayer ended, the muezzin's voice descending to silence, and in the silence the hostel breathed and the hostel remembered and the hostel waited with the patience of something that had been waiting for a very long time.

Then he stood. He went to the staircase. He climbed to the third floor, past the Japanese characters, past the blue tiles, to Felix's door.

He knocked.

Felix opened. The smile appeared -- warm, generous, the Felix that Connor knew and needed.

"Hey, mate. What's up?"

"Tomoko," Connor said. "She's been taking photos. Of you, of me, of the deliveries. She has pictures of us at Wei's shop, pictures of the packages, pictures of me carrying. She says she's going to take them to someone."

He said it the way a soldier reports enemy positions -- factual, urgent, loyal. He was reporting the threat to his commander. He was protecting the operation. He was choosing, in this moment, the side he had chosen since the first envelope, the side of easy money and warm friendship and the comfortable lie, and the choosing was so natural that it didn't feel like choosing at all. It felt like reflex. It felt like gravity. It felt like the ground.

Felix's expression changed. The smile didn't vanish -- it altered, reconfiguring into something thinner, more focused, the smile of a man who has received tactical intelligence and is already processing countermeasures. His eyes moved to a place Connor couldn't see -- the space behind the eyes where calculations happened, where variables were adjusted and risks were assessed and expendable elements were identified.

"How many photos?" Felix's voice was calm. The German accent was slightly more pronounced, the precision of the consonants sharpening, the way they did when Felix was working.

"Eight. Printed. She said she has more on her camera."

"Where does she keep the camera?"

"Her room, I think. Dorm 5."

Felix nodded. The nod was slow, deliberate, the nod of a man adding an item to a list. "Don't worry about Tomoko," he said. "I'll handle it."

"What does that mean?"

"It means I'll talk to her. Journalist to photographer. Professional courtesy." The smile returned, fuller now, warmer, the mask repaired, the surface restored. "She's just being thorough. It's what journalists do. I respect it. But she doesn't have the full picture, and once I explain the business properly, she'll understand."

Connor nodded. The nodding was easy. Nodding was what he did when Felix spoke, the physical affirmation that the words were landing, that the explanation was sufficient, that the world Felix described was the world they lived in.

"Thanks, mate," Connor said. "Sorry for the--"

"No need to apologise. You did the right thing, telling me."

"Of course. We're a team."

The word *team* sat between them -- a word that Connor believed and Felix used, the way a carpenter uses a hammer: to drive things into place. Felix clapped Connor on the shoulder. The hand was warm. The gesture was intimate. The intimacy was engineered.

"Go have your coffee," Felix said. "I'll sort this out."

Connor left. He went to Grind Culture. He ordered his flat white. He sat at his window table and posted a sunset photo for Pacific Soul and felt the relief of a man who has passed a problem to someone competent, the way you feel when the mechanic says "I'll fix it" and you believe him because believing him is easier than understanding the engine.

He did not think about what "I'll handle it" meant. He did not think about why Felix had asked where Tomoko kept her camera. He did not think about the word *handle* and its implications, or the look in Felix's eyes when Connor had said *Dorm 5*, or the slow nod that had added something to a list Connor could not see.

The flat white was good. The Wi-Fi was strong. The afternoon passed.

---

Three days later, Tomoko's camera was gone.

She reported it to Mei Ling at reception. Her room had been entered while she was out -- no sign of forced entry, but the Nikon D850 was missing from its case. The SD cards, two of them, were also gone. Her laptop was untouched. Her money was untouched. Only the camera and the cards.

Mei Ling documented the theft in the guest complaint ledger. She offered to call the police. Tomoko declined. She knew who had taken the camera. She knew why. And she knew that calling the police would alert the people she was trying to document, which would make the documentation impossible, which was the entire point of the theft.

Tomoko stood at the reception counter, her expression flat, her fists clenched at her sides. She looked at the common room where Connor was sitting on the sofa, scrolling his phone, performing ignorance with the fluency of a native speaker.

"You told him," she said, across the room, her voice carrying the cold, precise weight of someone stating a fact.

Connor looked up. "What?"

"You told Felix about the photographs. And now my camera is gone."

"I didn't--"

"Don't." The word was a door slamming. "Don't lie to me. You told him, and he sent someone to take my camera, and now the evidence is gone, and you did this. You did this because you chose him over the truth."

The common room was not empty. Two Dutch backpackers were playing cards at the far table. They looked up, looked at Tomoko, looked at Connor, and performed the universal backpacker response to interpersonal conflict: they put their heads down and pretended the room contained only them and the cards.

Connor opened his mouth. The machine tried to produce a defence but the machine had been running hard for weeks and the gears were grinding and what came out was not a defence but a silence, and the silence was the most honest thing he'd said in a month.

Tomoko looked at him. The look lasted five seconds. In those five seconds, something ended -- the last residual goodwill, the last trace of the concern that had motivated her to show him the photographs, the last molecular bond of human care that had connected a Japanese journalist to an Australian courier across a coffee table in a hostel in Chinatown.

"I backed up the photos," she said. "Cloud storage. You can steal a camera but you can't steal a cloud." She paused. "When this ends -- and it will end, Connor, the same way it always ends -- remember that I tried. Remember that we all tried."

She climbed the staircase. Her footsteps continued to the third floor. Her door opened and closed with a sound that was final in a way that transcended the mechanics of hinges and frames. It was the sound of a witness deciding that the witness phase was over, and the next phase was coming, and the next phase would involve not a camera but a keyboard, and not photographs but words, and the words would be published, and the published words would outlast the camera and the photographs and the evidence and the man who had caused them to be stolen.

Connor sat on the sofa. The Dutch backpackers played cards.

---

That evening, Priya found him on the rooftop.

He was sitting in the dark, no beer this time, just the plastic chair and the humid air and the Petronas Towers doing their permanent silver performance against the night sky. He wasn't looking at his phone. He wasn't doing anything. He was sitting absolutely still, hands on his knees, staring at nothing, waiting for the numbness to wear off and the feeling to arrive.

Priya sat in the chair beside him. She didn't speak immediately. She let the silence hold, the way she did when she was being a doctor rather than a girlfriend, giving the patient space to arrive at the conversation in their own time.

"Tomoko told me about the camera," she said, eventually.

"Yeah."

"You told Felix about her photographs."

"I told him because she was going to make trouble. She was going to go to the papers, the embassy, the -- I was protecting--"

"You were protecting Felix."

The sentence was accurate and it cut. Connor felt it land below the numbness, in the place where the things he didn't want to know lived.

"I was protecting myself," he said. "If those photos went public -- if she went to the Australian embassy and said I was doing deliveries for someone -- that's my reputation. That's my travel life. That's everything."

"That's your concern? Your *reputation*?"

"Don't do that. Don't make it sound stupid."

"It is stupid, Connor. Your reputation is not the thing at risk here. Your *life* is the thing at risk. Tomoko wasn't going to the embassy to embarrass you. She was going because she thought it might save you. And instead of letting her try, you went to Felix and handed him the information he needed to shut her down."

Connor opened his mouth. The machine tried to engage. But the machine was exhausted -- weeks of continuous operation, the gears worn, the belts stretched, the motor overheating. What came out was not a defence but a sound, a small exhalation, the sound of something deflating.

"I know," he said.

The words surprised him. They surprised Priya too -- he could feel her posture shift, the slight forward lean of someone who has been pushing against a door and felt it give.

"You know what?"

"I know I shouldn't have told him. I know the camera -- I know that was because of me." He rubbed his face with both hands. The stubble scraped his palms. "I just -- Priya, I don't know how to stop. I'm in it now. The schedule, the money, the people who take the packages. They know my face. They know where I live. If I stop, Felix will -- I don't know what Felix will do."

It was the most honest thing he had said since arriving in KL. The words came from beneath the machine, from the dark space where the truth lived, the space that the rationalisations were designed to keep sealed. The truth was simple and enormous: he was afraid. Not of the law, not of the police, not even of the death penalty. He was afraid of Felix. He was afraid of what Felix represented -- the infrastructure, the network, the system that had absorbed him so completely that extraction felt impossible.

Priya reached for his hand. He let her take it. Her fingers were cool, the jade bracelet sliding against his wrist.

"You can stop," she said. "Right now. Tonight. You can go to Sergeant Ahmad -- you told me about the card, Connor, I know you have it -- and you can tell him everything. What you've carried, where you've taken it, who gave it to you. They'll protect you. You'll be a witness, not a defendant."

"And Felix?"

"Felix will be arrested. Or he'll run. Either way, he won't be your problem anymore."

"He'll know it was me. The network -- they'll know I talked."

"The network is already watching you. Tomoko's photos prove that. The man who comes at one AM with a holdall? He's not delivering phone accessories, Connor. He's a supplier. And suppliers know their couriers. If you don't stop, the only question is whether you get caught by the police first or used up by the network first, and I don't know which outcome is worse."

The Petronas Towers glowed. The city hummed. A plane descended toward KLIA, its lights blinking, carrying someone new toward a city that was simultaneously beautiful and lethal, the way all beautiful things were lethal when you mistook the surface for the substance.

"I'll think about it," Connor said.

"Don't think about it. Do it."

"I'll think about it."

Priya held his hand. She held it the way you hold something you know you're about to lose -- tightly, completely, with every finger and every gram of pressure, as though the holding itself could prevent the letting go.

"I love you," she said. She hadn't said it before. The words arrived in the space between them with the weight of something that had been carried a long time and was being set down, carefully, in the dark. "I love you and I'm terrified. And if you don't stop, I'm going to have to watch something happen to you that I can't prevent, and that will break me, Connor. Not in the way heartbreak usually works -- in the way that bone breaks. The way that things break when they can't bend anymore."

He turned to her. In the dark, her face was visible only by the city's ambient light -- the round glasses reflecting orange, her eyes dark and steady, her expression carrying the weight of everything she'd tried to tell him and everything he'd refused to hear.

"I love you too," he said, and he meant it, and the meaning was the truest thing in his life, and the truest thing in his life was not enough to save him.

They sat on the rooftop. They held hands. The night passed. Neither of them mentioned the photographs, or the camera, or the printed law, or the business card in Connor's wallet. They sat in the dark and held onto each other and the holding was the only thing either of them had, the only thing that didn't require a decision or an action or a confrontation with the truth, the only thing that was simply human and simply real in a situation that had become neither.

The building breathed. The fans turned. And in her room on the third floor, Tomoko Sato sat at a desk with her laptop open, composing an email to a contact at The Star newspaper, attaching files from a cloud server in Tokyo, writing in English that was precise and economical and contained no adjectives that weren't necessary, the way she wrote everything, the way a scalpel contains no metal that isn't necessary.

The subject line read: *Drug trafficking operation -- Petaling Street hostel -- evidence attached.*

She read it once. She read it twice.

She did not press send. Not yet. The evidence wasn't complete. The camera was gone but the cloud wasn't, and the cloud contained sixteen photographs, and the photographs contained a story, and the story was still being written by a twenty-seven-year-old Australian in a WANDERLUST singlet who was sitting on a rooftop holding hands with a woman who had tried to save him and failing, night by night, delivery by delivery, to save himself.
# Chapter 17: Easy Money

Days 25 through 30 passed the way water passes over a stone -- continuously, invisibly, wearing everything smooth.

---

**Day 25. Monday. Jalan Ipoh.**

Package: sports bag, black nylon, 3.2 kilograms. Pickup from Felix's room, 9:00 AM. Delivery to Mr. Tan, 9:47 AM. Mr. Tan took the bag, inspected the contents behind a partially closed roller door, nodded. RM350. Grab home. Total time: one hour twelve minutes.

Connor spent the afternoon at Grind Culture. Flat white, RM14. Scheduled three posts for Pacific Soul Retreats. Received a DM from a boutique resort in Lombok asking about social media management: 500K IDR per month, which was approximately RM150, which was less than one delivery. He replied with his rate card -- the one he'd made in Canva six months ago that listed his services at prices no one had ever paid -- and never heard back.

Bank balance: RM11,830.

He bought Priya dinner at a Korean restaurant in Bukit Bintang. Spicy tofu stew, fried chicken, three side dishes. She ate quietly. The conversation was careful -- they talked about her medical studies, about the neurology rotation she was dreading, about the difference between the NHS and the Malaysian health system. They did not talk about packages or photographs or the law. The not-talking was a new feature of their relationship, a room they'd built together and agreed not to enter, and the room grew larger every day.

---

**Day 26. Tuesday. Brickfields.**

Package: brown paper, taped shut, 1.8 kilograms. Lighter than usual. The lightness produced a brief, irrational relief -- as though the weight of the package correlated with the weight of the crime, as though carrying something light was less illegal than carrying something heavy. This was not how the law worked. The law did not care about kilograms. The law cared about grams -- fifty of them -- and the law did not weigh the package. The law weighed the contents.

Connor delivered to the Blue Door. The woman in the green salwar kameez took the package, closed the door, and the door's colour -- that faded, institutional blue -- stayed in his mind for the rest of the day, the way certain colours stay after you close your eyes, an afterimage that was not visual but emotional.

Afternoon: he walked through Brickfields back to the hostel instead of taking a Grab. Little India unfolded around him -- the garland shops and textile stores and the banana leaf restaurants where lunch was served on actual banana leaves, the rice and curries arranged in a pattern that was both aesthetic and practical, the leaf's natural coating preventing the food from sticking, the eating done with the right hand, the leaf folded toward you when you were done to signal satisfaction.

He stopped at a temple. Sri Mahamariamman, the oldest Hindu temple in KL, its tower rising from the street in a riot of painted gods and goddesses, each figure expressing an emotion Connor couldn't name, each colour -- red, green, gold, blue, purple -- saturated beyond reality into the territory of the divine. He stood at the entrance and looked up and felt, for a moment, the specific smallness that comes from standing before something that was ancient when your country was not yet a country. The temple had been here since 1873. It would be here long after Connor was gone.

He photographed it. He captioned it: *When the universe is bigger than your plans.* Twelve hashtags. Thirty-one likes.

Bank balance: RM12,180.

---

**Day 27. Wednesday. Rest day.**

He slept until eleven. Ate Mama Siti's nasi lemak. Sat on the rooftop in the morning heat and did nothing.

The doing-nothing was different now. Previously, Connor's rest days had been genuinely restful -- the absence of deliveries creating a lightness, a freedom, the day stretching open like a hand unclenching. Now the rest days were the days when the machine ran hardest, because the machine had nothing to process except itself, and the self it was processing was increasingly difficult to maintain.

He thought about Priya. She was leaving in twelve days. Her six-week break was half over, and the return flight to London was booked and paid for, and the final-year placements were waiting, and the life she'd built -- the real life, the life with structure and purpose and a future -- was pulling her back with a gravity that Connor's world could not match.

He thought about Jake. Jake was still in KL -- Langkawi had been postponed because Jake had met an Italian girl named Chiara who worked at a bar on Changkat and Jake had decided, with the confident romanticism of a man whose decisions were made entirely by his limbic system, that Chiara was "the one." The one lasted approximately five days before Chiara left for Penang, but the postponement meant Jake was still here, still a presence, still the golden retriever in board shorts whose function in Connor's life was to be the friend who didn't question, didn't push, didn't see beneath the surface.

He thought about the money. RM12,180. *She'll be right.* The phrase arrived the way it always did -- automatic, reflexive, the Australian mantra that had carried him through twelve countries. But the phrase was beginning to sound, even to him, like something a man said when he was falling and couldn't reach the railing. He'd never had this much money in his life. The number sat in his banking app like a small monument, a stack of ringgit that represented four weeks of packages and sports bags and brown paper and blue doors and men who didn't make eye contact. The money was clean in his account and dirty in its origin and the difference between clean and dirty was a question Connor had stopped asking because asking was the first step on a road he couldn't afford to walk.

He went to the cinema. Pavilion KL, the mall in Bukit Bintang, where the multiplex had leather seats and air conditioning cold enough to make him shiver. He watched a Marvel film -- he couldn't remember which one by the end, they were all the same film now, the same indestructible heroes fighting the same impossible odds with the same outcome, the good guys winning, the bad guys losing, the universe restored. He ate popcorn and drank a Coke and sat in the dark and felt the comfort of clean rules and just consequences and nobody dying who didn't deserve to.

Bank balance: unchanged. RM12,180. The money sat there. The money waited.

---

**Day 28. Thursday. Chow Kit.**

The delivery to Auntie Lim was routine. Sports bag, 2.6 kilograms, taxi, drop, transfer. RM350. The wet market was in full morning cry -- fish sellers hawking in Malay and Cantonese, the ice on the tables melting in the heat, the smell of the sea competing with the smell of raw poultry and the sulfurous funk of the storm drains, the same rotten-egg stench that had hit Connor on his first night in Chinatown and that he'd stopped noticing weeks ago.

But something happened on the way back that Connor would not think about until much later.

He was walking through the market, past the stalls, past the vendors, past the displays of tropical fruit stacked in pyramids -- rambutans red and hairy, mangosteens purple and smooth, dragonfruit pink and alien. A woman bumped his shoulder. She was Malay, middle-aged, carrying a shopping bag in each hand, and the bump was accidental -- the crowded market, the narrow aisles, the inevitable physics of too many people in too small a space.

"Sorry, sorry," she said, in English, and then looked at his face and stopped.

She looked at him the way Mama Siti looked at him. The way Razak had looked at him in the office with the map. The way Mei Ling had looked at him at the reception counter. The way people looked at a person when they knew something about that person that the person didn't know about themselves.

"You're from the hostel," she said. "Petaling Street."

"Yeah, I--"

"I see you. Every Thursday. Walking through here with the bag." She shifted her shopping bags from one hand to the other, the gesture of a woman redistributing weight. "My stall is there." She pointed to a vegetable stall three metres away. "I sell kangkung and okra and I see everything from my stall."

Connor said nothing.

"Be careful, boy." She said *boy* the way Malaysian aunties said *boy* -- not as a diminutive but as a term of address that simultaneously acknowledged your existence and implied your stupidity. "The police come through here too. They see the same things I see."

She walked away. Her shopping bags swung at her sides. She didn't look back.

Connor stood in the market. The fruit pyramids rose around him. The vendors called. The ice melted. And the woman's words settled into him like rain into soil, reaching a depth that the surface warnings -- Priya's arguments, Tomoko's photos, Mei Ling's instruction -- had not reached, because this was not a warning from a friend or a journalist or a receptionist. This was a warning from a stranger. A vegetable seller. A woman who had no investment in Connor's survival except the basic, unremarkable human impulse to tell a person they are walking into traffic.

He went home. He didn't tell Felix about the woman. He wasn't sure why. Maybe it was because telling Felix about the checkpoint had led to the checkpoint being avoided, and telling Felix about Tomoko had led to the camera being stolen, and telling Felix about this woman would lead to -- what? What could Felix do about a vegetable seller in Chow Kit who had eyes?

He ate lunch. He met Jake for beers. He went to bed.

Bank balance: RM12,530.

---

**Day 29. Friday. Jalan Ipoh.**

Return leg. Mr. Tan. RM350. The delivery was unremarkable. The delivery was always unremarkable. That was the point.

Connor spent the afternoon with Jake at the Petronas Towers -- the skybridge tour, which Connor had been meaning to do since he arrived and hadn't because doing tourist things felt like regression, like admitting he was a tourist rather than a resident, a visitor rather than a local. But Jake wanted to go and Connor wanted to not think, and the Petronas Towers delivered on both counts: the skybridge was forty-one floors up, the city spread below like a circuitboard, the buildings and roads and parks and mosques miniaturised by distance into something comprehensible, something you could hold in your eye and know.

From the skybridge, you could see everything. Petaling Street, a sliver of red and gold in the urban grid. Bukit Bintang, its malls glinting. Chow Kit, a dense cluster of low-rise rooftops. Brickfields, identifiable by the temple towers. The North-South Expressway, a grey ribbon heading north toward Penang. The LRT lines, silver threads connecting the city's parts. And in the distance, green hills, and beyond the hills, more hills, and beyond those, the edge of the Malaysian peninsula, where the land ended and the sea began and the rest of the world waited.

"Dude," Jake said, pressing his forehead against the glass. "This is insane."

"Yeah."

"Like, we're literally standing between the tallest twin towers in the world. How is this our life?"

"It's pretty sick."

Jake took seventeen selfies. Connor took three. In one of them, looking at it later, he noticed his own reflection in the glass -- a figure standing against the city's grid, transparent, ghostlike, as though the city was already showing through him, as though he was already becoming less solid, less present, less there.

He posted the photo. Caption: *Standing on top of the world. KL, you absolute legend.* Forty-three likes.

Bank balance: RM12,880.

---

**Day 30. Saturday. Bukit Bintang.**

The drop to Danny at Lot 22B was the last of the week. Sports bag, heavier than usual, 4.1 kilograms. Danny was young -- mid-twenties, Chinese-Malaysian, thin, with the nervous energy of a person who was not at the top of any chain but was somewhere in the middle, the disposable middle, the part that could be replaced without the machine noticing.

Danny took the bag through a door in the back of a building that, from the front, looked like a defunct karaoke bar -- the sign still up, the neon tubes dark, the windows papered over. The interior, glimpsed briefly as Danny pulled the door open, was not a karaoke bar. It was a room with a table and scales and bags and the smell of something chemical that Connor's nose registered and his brain rejected.

The door closed. RM400. Higher than the others. Saturday deliveries paid more. Connor did not ask why.

He walked through Bukit Bintang in the late afternoon sun, the pavement crowded with Saturday shoppers, the monorail humming overhead, the durian stall pumping its signature aroma into the air. He felt the RM400 arrive in his account with the small, warm pulse of validation that each transfer produced, the Pavlovian response that the schedule had built into his nervous system -- delivery, transfer, dopamine. The cycle was complete. The cycle was repeating. The cycle was all there was.

Bank balance: RM13,280.

---

On Sunday, rest day, Connor sat on his bunk and opened the banking app and looked at the number and felt something he had never felt before.

The feeling was not happiness. Happiness was what he told himself it was -- the satisfaction of accumulation, the security of surplus, the quiet triumph of a man who was making it work. But beneath the happiness, beneath the number, beneath the green bar graph that showed his balance climbing week over week in a line that looked like success, there was something else.

The something else was this: the number was not a number. The number was a weight. Each ringgit was a gram. Each transfer was a delivery. Each delivery was a package he'd never opened, a bag he'd never checked, a sports-bag-sized piece of the unknown carried across a city that would kill him for carrying it. The balance in his account was an inventory of risk, denominated in currency, and the inventory was growing, and the risk was growing with it, and the growth was silent and smooth and invisible the way all growth was when you weren't looking.

RM13,280. In thirty days. For carrying things.

---

**Day 31. Monday.**

Jalan Ipoh. Mr. Tan. RM350. The routine.

Something happened on the way home that was not part of the routine.

The Grab dropped Connor on Jalan Sultan, two blocks from the hostel, because a food delivery truck was blocking the lane and the driver refused to navigate around it with the particular stubbornness of a KL Grab driver encountering a situation that required effort. Connor walked. The midday sun was a white disc in a white sky, the heat landing on exposed skin like a physical weight, the humidity turning every breath into something that had to be earned.

He passed the Guan Di Temple. The red doors were open, the interior visible -- the altar, the smoke, the golden statue of the Chinese god of war sitting in his niche with the calm authority of someone who had been settling disputes for two thousand years. An old man knelt at the altar, burning joss paper, the flames leaping and dying in the still air. The smoke rose straight up, undisturbed.

Connor paused. He'd passed the temple every day for a month and had never gone inside. Today, he stepped through the door.

The interior was cool -- not air-conditioned cool but the stone-and-shade cool of a building designed for a tropical climate, the thick walls absorbing the heat and releasing it slowly, the open doorway creating a draft that moved the incense smoke in lazy spirals. The smell was intense: sandalwood incense, burning paper, the waxy fragrance of red candles, and beneath it all, the dusty sweetness of old wood and old gold.

He stood in the middle of the temple and felt something shift. Not a thought -- a sensation. The sensation of being very small in a very old place, the same feeling he'd had at the Hindu temple in Brickfields, the same feeling that religious architecture was designed to produce: the dissolution of the ego, the reminder that the self was temporary and the building was not.

He looked at the altar. Guan Di sat in gold, his beard flowing, his halberd beside him, his expression carrying the particular serenity of a deity who had seen everything human beings could do to each other and had decided to help anyway.

Connor didn't pray. He didn't know how to pray, and if he had known, he wouldn't have known what to pray for, because the thing he needed was not divine intervention but the human courage to stop doing what he was doing, and courage was not something you could request from a statue, however gold, however serene.

But he stood there. For three minutes, in the cool and the smoke, he stood and felt the smallness and let it hold him. Then he left. The heat hit him at the door. The city resumed. He walked home with the feeling fading and by the time he reached the hostel it was gone, replaced by the afternoon routine, the scrolling, the performing, the slow, warm erosion of everything that was not the machine.

---

**Day 32. Tuesday.**

Brickfields. Blue Door. RM350. Routine.

In the evening, he received an email from his sister.

Megan Briggs, senior analyst, accounting firm, Sydney. The email was brief, as Megan's communications always were -- she wrote the way she lived, efficiently, without excess, each sentence carrying exactly the information it needed and not a syllable more.

> Connor,
>
> Mum told me you're staying in Malaysia for a while. She's worried. She's always worried about you but she's more worried than usual, which means something is different, even if she can't say what.
>
> I'm not going to lecture you. You're 27 and you've been doing this for four years and nothing I say will change your mind. But I want you to know that Dad is not well. He hasn't told you because he doesn't want you to come home out of guilt. He has high blood pressure and his doctor has put him on medication and reduced his golf to once a week, which is making him miserable.
>
> I'm telling you this not to make you feel bad but because I think you should know. And because I think, at some point, you might want to consider that the people who love you are getting older, and the time you have with them is not unlimited, and spending it on the other side of the world carrying a phone you never answer is a choice that has consequences for more people than just you.
>
> That's all. Take care of yourself.
>
> Megan

Connor read the email three times. The words were sharp -- Megan's words were always sharp, honed by years of numbers and reports and a lifetime of saying difficult things concisely so the numbers did the feeling for her. But the sharpness was a surface; beneath it, in the spaces between the sentences, was something softer. Something that sounded like: *I'm your sister and I love you and I'm scared and I don't know how to say it because we've never been good at saying it.*

His father. High blood pressure. Medication. Golf reduced. The images arrived: David Briggs, sixty-one, square-shouldered, the property developer who'd built half of Hawthorn's new townhouses, reduced to a pill organiser and a doctor's caution. His father, who never complained, who never showed weakness, who'd driven Connor to the airport and said *the rules don't care who you are* and meant it and been right.

Connor typed a reply:

> Thanks for telling me, Megs. Tell Dad I'll call him this week. And tell Mum not to worry.

He sent it. He put down the phone. He stared at the wall of the common room -- the bookshelf, the TV, the red lanterns -- and thought about consequences, and time, and the brutal arithmetic: earning RM13,000 in a country that would kill him while his father was taking medication in a country where he could have been safe.

The image came without permission: David Briggs at the kitchen table in Hawthorn, the pill organiser open in front of him -- one of those plastic trays with the days of the week printed on each compartment, the kind of object that belonged in the homes of the very old, not in the hands of a sixty-one-year-old property developer who had built half a suburb with those hands. His father's hands. The hands that had poured foundations and signed contracts and gripped Connor's shoulder at the airport and held on for a beat longer than the protocol allowed. Those hands, now sorting pills. Monday through Sunday. The small, coloured capsules that were keeping his blood from doing what blood, left to its own devices, apparently wanted to do -- which was to press against the walls of the vessels that carried it with a force that could kill the man who carried them.

Connor did the arithmetic. He couldn't help it. The arithmetic was reflexive, the way flinching was reflexive, a thing the body did before the mind could intervene. His father was sixty-one. The life expectancy for an Australian male was eighty-two. That was twenty-one years. Twenty-one years of pills and reduced golf and his mother watching his father's face for the signs of something worse. Twenty-one years was seven thousand, six hundred and sixty-five days. Connor had been in KL for thirty-two of them. Thirty-two days of packages and sports bags and blue doors, during which his father's blood pressure had been doing its quiet, domestic violence, and Connor had not called, had not come home, had not been there for any of it, because being there would have required being someone who did not carry things through Chow Kit for money.

He could call now. He could pick up the phone and dial the Melbourne number and say the words: *I'm coming home, Dad. I'll be on the next flight.* He could feel the words forming -- the shape of them in his mouth, the weight of them in his chest, the specific, physical relief they would produce, the way setting down a heavy bag produces relief, the sudden lightness of a body freed from cargo. He reached for the phone. His hand moved. And the machine intercepted it -- not with logic, not with argument, but with the blank, smooth refusal of a system that had learned to redirect impulse before it became action. The phone stayed on the table. The call was not made. The words dissolved back into the silence they had come from, and in their place the machine substituted the familiar calculation: the RM13,280 in the account, the schedule that continued, the packages that needed carrying, the steady accumulation that felt, from inside the machine, like purpose.

He picked up the phone. He opened the banking app instead. The green bar graph climbed. The number sat. And the email from Megan -- the email with its sharp sentences and its soft centre, the email that weighed nothing in megabytes and everything in grams -- joined the list of things Connor had received and registered and filed in the part of his mind where warnings went to be acknowledged and then, systematically, ignored.

---

---

**Day 33. Wednesday. Rest day.**

He called his father.

David Briggs picked up on the fourth ring, which was unusual -- David Briggs picked up on the first ring, always had, the reflexive grab of a man who'd spent thirty years taking calls from site managers and councils and lawyers. The fourth ring meant he'd been looking for the phone, or hesitating, or both.

"Connor." The voice was the same -- square, solid, Australian in the way that eucalyptus trees were Australian, deeply rooted and slightly weathered. "How are you, mate?"

"I'm good, Dad. How are you?"

"Can't complain. Well, I can, but your mother tells me nobody wants to hear it." A chuckle. The chuckle was the same too -- dry, brief, the humour of a man who rationed his laughter the way he rationed his affection, not because he lacked it but because he believed economy was a virtue.

They talked for twelve minutes. Connor learned that his father's blood pressure was "under control" (David's term), that the medication was "a nuisance" (David's term for anything that reminded him of mortality), and that golf once a week was "criminal" (David's term for anything that prevented him from playing golf). They talked about the Melbourne property market, which David tracked the way astronomers tracked the stars -- with precision, with passion, with the conviction that the patterns meant something. They talked about Megan's promotion. They talked about the dog, a labrador named Bruce, who had developed a limp.

They did not talk about Connor's life. This was the protocol: David asked "How are you?", Connor said "Good," and the subject was closed. David did not ask what Connor did for money, where he slept, who his friends were, or when he was coming home. These questions lived in the space between father and son like furniture in a dark room -- present, immovable, navigated by memory.

At the eleven-minute mark, David said: "Your mother tells me you've been in KL a while now. She says you might stay longer."

"Yeah. Thinking about it."

"Right." A pause. The pause was David's version of a paragraph break, a space in which unspoken things accumulated. "Just -- look after yourself, Connor. That's all."

"I will, Dad."

"I know you will. You're a sensible bloke." He said it without irony, which was worse than irony, because irony would have acknowledged the gap between the statement and the reality, and the absence of irony meant David believed it, the way parents believe things about their children that the children have long since disproven.

"Love you, Dad."

"Love you too, mate. Call your mother. She misses you."

The call ended. Connor sat on the rooftop with the phone in his hand and the Petronas Towers in his eyes and the word *sensible* in his ears and the word was wrong, the word was the wrongest word in the English language applied to the most wrong person in the most wrong situation, and the wrongness hurt in a way that the warnings hadn't, because the warnings came from people who saw the truth and the word *sensible* came from a man who loved the lie, and the lie was the only thing Connor had given his father in four years.

---

**Day 34. Thursday.**

Chow Kit. Auntie Lim. RM350.

The vegetable seller was at her stall. She saw him. She didn't speak. She didn't need to. Her eyes tracked him as he walked through the market with the sports bag, and her expression -- the same expression from last week, the expression of a woman who sees a boy walking toward something that will hurt him -- was the speech. The silence was louder than the words.

Connor walked faster. He delivered the package. He went home.

That evening, Tomoko was at the reception counter when he came down for dinner. She had a new camera -- smaller, cheaper, a Fujifilm compact that looked like a downgrade from the Nikon the way a car looked like a downgrade from an airplane. But it was a camera, and it had a lens, and the lens was pointed at nothing in particular, but its presence was a statement.

*I'm still watching. The camera was stolen but the watcher was not. You can take the tool but you can't take the eye.*

She didn't look at Connor. She didn't need to. The camera was the communication. The camera said: *I have a cloud. I have contacts. I have patience. And I am not done.*

Connor went to dinner. He ate roti canai at the mamak stall and watched the evening traffic on Jalan Sultan and thought about cameras and clouds and women from Osaka who didn't give up and wondered, briefly, whether not giving up was a form of kindness or a form of cruelty, and decided it was both, the way most true things were both.

---

He closed the app. He opened Instagram. He posted a photo of the Petronas Towers at sunset -- the one Jake had taken, the one where the light turned the silver cladding to gold. Caption: *Living the dream. No alarm clock. No boss. Just sunsets and good vibes.* Twenty-two hashtags.

Sixty-one likes.

The likes were the smallest number he cared about and the largest number anyone would see. The bank balance was the largest number he cared about and the number no one would see. Between the two numbers -- between the public metric of a curated life and the private metric of an illegal one -- Connor Briggs existed, a man with two phones and two identities and two accounts, one that counted followers and one that counted ringgit, and both of them were lies and both of them were true and the difference between the lies and the truth was a question he would never ask because asking was the thing that would end everything.

He put down the phone. Both phones. He lay on Bed 7 and listened to the building settle around him -- the pipes ticking, the wood groaning in the heat, the slow respiration of a structure that had been breathing since 1928 and would keep breathing long after the man on the mattress stopped. The ceiling fan turned above him. *Tick, tick, tick.* He thought: *I should stop.*

He didn't stop.

The money was too easy. The routine was too comfortable. The stopping would require a confrontation with Felix that he couldn't envision and a conversation with the police that he couldn't face and a phone call to his parents that he couldn't make. The stopping would require becoming a different person, and Connor had spent twenty-seven years becoming this person, and this person was the only person he knew how to be.

So he didn't stop. And the days passed. And the money grew. And the packages moved through the city like blood through veins, invisible and essential and alive, and the man who carried them moved too, through streets he'd learned and markets he'd memorised and doors he'd opened without asking what was behind them, and the moving was so fluid and the earning was so regular and the lie was so complete that it felt, in every way that mattered, like a life.

The life that was ending. The life that was, even now, in its final weeks, counting down toward a bus station and a suitcase and a dog that could smell the truth through any amount of tape and nylon and denial.

But that was later. Now there was only the easy money and the easy days and the ceiling fan turning in the dorm where a name waited in the wood, the same name that had waited for the last one, the same patience, the same silence.
# Chapter 18: Jake Leaves

Jake announced it over breakfast on Day 35, between bites of Mama Siti's nasi lemak, with the casual finality of a man who made life decisions the way other people chose between menu items.

"Dude, I'm going to Langkawi."

Connor's fork paused. "When?"

"Tomorrow. I booked a flight last night. AirAsia, forty-seven ringgit. That's, like, twelve dollars. This country is insane."

He said it with the wide-eyed appreciation of a man who had discovered that the world was cheaper than San Diego and had decided this was the world's primary virtue. His backwards cap was on. His fake Supreme shirt -- the one Connor had bought him at the night market a lifetime ago -- was spotted with sambal. He was grinning.

"What about Chiara?" Connor asked.

"Chiara's in Penang. She texted me. She wants me to meet her in Langkawi next week. We're going to do this, like, island-hopping thing. Jet skis. Snorkelling. She knows a guy who rents a boat for fifty ringgit a day. A whole boat, dude."

Jake said *a whole boat* the way medieval explorers must have said *a whole continent* -- with the awed reverence of a man for whom scale was always surprising and always delightful.

Connor ate his nasi lemak. The rice was perfect -- coconut-infused, fluffy, the sambal adding heat in waves. Mama Siti was at the stove, stirring something that smelled of lemongrass and the deep, amber warmth of star anise. She didn't look at the boys. She was listening, though. She was always listening.

"How long?" Connor asked.

"I dunno. A week? Two? However long the money lasts." Jake shrugged. The shrug was his primary mode of planning -- the physical expression of a man whose relationship with the future was noncommittal. "You should come, dude. Langkawi's supposed to be sick. Duty-free island. The beer is, like, nothing."

"Duty-free beer." Connor managed a smile. "You're basically describing paradise."

"Right? So come."

"Can't. I've got work stuff. The social media gig."

"The social media gig." Jake said it with the faint puzzlement of a man who had never understood what Connor did for money and had accepted this ignorance the way he accepted most things -- cheerfully, without investigation. "Dude, you can post Instagrams from anywhere. That's literally the point."

"Yeah, but I've got the local clients too. The import-export thing."

"Oh right. Felix's thing." Jake took another bite of nasi lemak, chewed, swallowed. "Is that, like, going well?"

"Yeah. It's good. Steady."

"Cool." Jake nodded with the benign approval of a man for whom all work was equally mysterious. "Felix is a legend. That guy knows everyone."

"He does."

"You know what's funny? He asked me about it once. The delivery thing. Like, a few weeks ago. Said he could use another runner."

Connor's chest tightened. The sensation was brief -- a constriction, a flash of cold, the body's response to information the mind hadn't caught up with. "Felix asked you?"

"Yeah. On the rooftop. One night after Changkat. He was saying how the business was growing and he needed reliable people. I was going to do it but then Chiara happened and I kinda forgot." He laughed. "Classic me."

Classic Jake. Classic, golden-retriever, limbic-system-driven Jake, who had avoided recruitment into a drug trafficking network not through intelligence or caution or awareness but through the accidental intervention of an Italian bartender named Chiara who had great hair and a friend with a boat.

Connor looked at Jake. Jake was eating. Jake was happy. Jake was leaving tomorrow for an island where the beer was cheap and the jet skis were available and the most dangerous thing on the horizon was sunburn. Jake was getting out.

The realisation settled into Connor with the weight of something obvious that he'd somehow missed: Jake was getting out because Jake was leaving. The hostel, Felix, the packages, the schedule -- none of it could reach Jake on Langkawi. Langkawi was outside the network. Langkawi was outside the geography of drops and pickups and men who didn't make eye contact. Langkawi was free.

*I could go too.*

The thought arrived with a clarity that startled him. He could go. Tomorrow. He could book a forty-seven-ringgit flight and sit next to Jake on an AirAsia seat and be in Langkawi by afternoon and the schedule would be broken and Felix would be left with one fewer courier and the packages would be someone else's problem and Connor would be on a beach drinking duty-free beer and the fear would dissolve in salt water and sunlight.

He could go.

"Mate." Jake was looking at him. "You alright? You've gone weird."

"Yeah. Fine. Just thinking."

"Don't think too hard. That's my rule. Thinking leads to deciding and deciding leads to consequences and consequences are a whole thing."

The philosophy of Jake Porter, distilled to its essence: avoid consequences by avoiding decisions. It was absurd. It was also, in this specific moment, the most compelling argument for action that Connor had heard.

"Maybe I'll come," Connor said. "Let me think about it."

"Sick! We can share a room. I found a place on Booking.com -- a beach hut. Sixty ringgit a night. It has a hammock, dude. A *hammock*."

Jake said *hammock* the way Connor said *content* -- as though the word itself contained a lifestyle, a philosophy, a complete vision of what life should be.

They finished breakfast. Jake went upstairs to pack, which for Jake meant throwing everything he owned into a duffel bag with the systematic approach of a man throwing confetti. Connor sat at the kitchen counter with his empty banana leaf and thought about Langkawi.

---

He went to Felix's room at eleven.

The door was open. Felix was at his desk, laptop open, the screen angled away from the door. He looked up when Connor appeared, and the smile arrived -- warm, inclusive, the Felix smile that made you feel like the most important person in the building.

"Morning, Connor. Come in."

Connor stepped inside. The room was tidy, as always. The bed made. The shutters partially closed, the slats casting horizontal lines of light across the floor that looked like the bars of something Connor chose not to name. On the desk, beside the laptop, a phone -- not Felix's usual phone but a different one, a phone Connor hadn't seen before, matte black, no case, the screen dark but angled toward Felix's hand with the casual proximity of an object that was used often and urgently. It was the kind of phone Connor recognised because he had one too -- the burner, the second device, the phone that belonged to the other life. But Felix's second phone was different from Connor's second phone in the way a general's radio was different from a foot soldier's walkie-talkie: same technology, different altitude. Felix's second phone spoke to the people above. Connor's second phone received instructions from Felix. The hierarchy was in the hardware. Felix closed the laptop as Connor sat on the bed.

"Jake's leaving," Connor said. "Tomorrow. Langkawi."

"I know. He told me last night." Felix's expression was neutral -- the neutrality of a man receiving information he already possessed. "It's a good island. He'll enjoy it."

"He said you asked him about the delivery work."

Felix paused. The pause was imperceptible to anyone who wasn't watching for it, a fraction of a second in which the machine behind Felix's eyes recalibrated. "I mentioned it. Casually. He wasn't interested."

"He was interested. He just got distracted."

"Jake gets distracted by many things." Felix smiled. "It's his charm and his survival mechanism. He's too scattered to be useful. I recognised that early."

The sentence was clinical, delivered with the diagnostic precision of a man who assessed people the way a mechanic assessed engines -- for function, for reliability, for the probability of breakdown. Jake was unreliable. Therefore Jake was not recruited. Therefore Jake was safe.

Connor felt something move in his chest -- a cold thread of understanding, pulling tight. Felix had looked at both of them -- Connor and Jake -- and chosen Connor. Not because Connor was smarter, or braver, or more qualified. Because Connor was more vulnerable. Because Connor was broke and desperate and wanted to belong and would do what he was told and would not ask questions and would carry the packages and accept the money and call it logistics.

Felix had chosen him the way a predator chose prey: not the fastest, not the strongest, but the one most likely to follow.

"I was thinking about going with Jake," Connor said.

The words came out before the machine could stop them. They emerged from the territory that the machine hadn't yet colonised -- the shrinking, gasping territory of honest impulse, the last corner of Connor's consciousness where self-preservation still had a foothold.

Felix looked at him. The smile didn't vanish -- it thinned, the warmth drawing back from the surface like a tide retreating, revealing the architecture beneath. The architecture was not warm. The architecture was structural, functional, designed to bear weight.

"Going to Langkawi," Felix said. Not a question.

"Maybe. For a week or two. Jake's got a place--"

"What about the schedule?"

"I'd pause it. Come back after."

"The schedule doesn't pause, Connor." Felix's voice was level, measured, the German accent precise. "The clients expect deliveries. If you disappear for two weeks, I have to find someone else. And finding someone else takes time. Training time. Trust-building time. The network doesn't run on holidays."

The word *network* landed in the room like something dropped from a height. Felix had never used the word before. In his careful lexicon, the operation was always *the business*, *the work*, *the clients*. *Network* was a different word. *Network* implied structure, hierarchy, scale. *Network* implied something larger than two men and a schedule.

"I'm not talking about a holiday," Connor said. "I'm talking about a week. Maybe two."

"And I'm telling you that the clients won't wait a week." Felix leaned forward, elbows on his knees, the posture of a man about to deliver information he'd rather not deliver. "Connor, I've invested in you. Time, trust, money. You're the KL leg of a chain that runs to Penang and Singapore. If the KL leg goes dark, the whole chain stops. And when the chain stops, the people above me ask questions."

"The people above you?"

"The company. The management. Import-export doesn't run itself."

The correction was swift, smooth, the mask repositioned before the gap had fully opened. But the gap had opened, and Connor had seen through it -- briefly, incompletely, the way you see a room through a door that opens and closes in a draught. The room behind the door contained people Felix answered to. People who asked questions when the chain stopped. People who were not photographers, not backpackers, not the kind of people you met in hostels.

"I can't stop you from going to Langkawi," Felix said. His voice softened. The warmth returned, modulated, controlled. "But I'd ask you to think about it. The schedule is working. The money is good. You've built something here -- a routine, a life, a system that works. Langkawi is a week on a beach. This is a career."

A career. The word was grotesque and seductive simultaneously, the way all the best lies were. A career in carrying packages you'd never opened, for people you'd never met, through a city that would kill you for carrying them. The career counsellors at Monash University had never mentioned this option.

"Think about it," Felix said. "Sleep on it. And tomorrow, when Jake leaves, if you still want to go, I won't stop you. But I hope you'll stay."

The word *hope* performed its function. It was a word that implied vulnerability, that suggested Felix needed Connor rather than owned him, that recast the relationship as partnership rather than employment. *I hope you'll stay.* As though Connor were a guest at a dinner party, free to leave at any time, the door right there, the evening entirely optional.

Felix smiled. The smile was warm. The shutters filtered the midday sun into thin, pale lines that had narrowed since Connor sat down, or seemed to have narrowed -- the room contracting by imperceptible degrees, the walls holding their position but the air between them thickening, the temperature climbing despite the fan that turned overhead with the slow, indifferent rotation of something measuring time rather than moving it. The matte black phone sat on the desk. The laptop sat beside it, closed, its secrets sealed. The bed Connor was sitting on was made with hotel precision, the sheets tucked so tightly they could have been stitched to the mattress, and the tightness of the sheets was the tightness of the room was the tightness of the conversation -- everything held in place, everything contained, everything neat and functional and impossible to escape without making a mess that Felix would not tolerate.

Connor stood. "I'll think about it," he said, and the sentence was already a concession, because *I'll think about it* was the language of a man who had already decided and needed the fiction of deliberation to make the decision feel like one.

"Good," Felix said. He didn't stand. He didn't need to. The room had done its work.

And in the silence between Felix's hope and Connor's indecision, the trap closed another inch, the way traps closed -- not with a snap but with a settling, a gentle, incremental tightening that felt like gravity and looked like choice.

---

Jake left the next morning.

The goodbye was at the front door of the Lantern Hostel, in the early heat, with the morning sounds of Petaling Street providing the soundtrack -- vendor calls, motorcycle engines, the distant prayer from Masjid Jamek. Jake's duffel bag was enormous and poorly packed, bulging in organic shapes that suggested the contents had been organised by chaos theory.

"Dude. Come with me." Jake said it one more time, standing on the pavement, his Grab waiting, the backwards cap slightly askew. "Last chance. Hammock. Duty-free beer. Chiara's friend has a *boat*."

"I can't, mate. The work."

"The work will be here when you get back."

"I know. But the clients--"

"Connor." Jake was not, as a rule, a man who used people's names with emphasis. The emphasis meant something. "You look tired, dude. Like, not body tired. Brain tired. You look like someone who needs a beach."

"I'm fine."

"You always say you're fine. That's, like, your whole thing. 'I'm fine, mate. She'll be right.' But I'm watching you and you're not fine. You're doing this thing where you smile but your eyes don't move, and that's -- I don't know what that is, but it's not fine."

Jake Porter, who never noticed anything, had noticed something. This was perhaps the most alarming development of the past five weeks, more alarming than the checkpoint or the photographs or the printed law. If Jake could see it -- Jake, who navigated the world with the observational acuity of a golden retriever in a butterfly garden -- then the thing that was happening to Connor was no longer subtle. It was visible. It was on the surface. It was leaking through the mask.

"I'm fine," Connor said. "Have an epic time. Send me photos."

"I'll send you so many photos. My Instagram story is going to be, like, forty slides of just ocean."

They hugged. The bro hug -- one arm, two back-pats, the choreography of male affection that allowed intimacy without admitting to it. Jake smelled of sunscreen and the hostel's communal soap and something that was just Jake, the irreducible essence of a man who had never been complicated enough to be in danger.

Jake got in the Grab. The car pulled away. Connor stood on the pavement and watched it turn onto Jalan Sultan and disappear into the morning traffic, and he kept watching after it disappeared, the way you watch the space where a plane was after it passes behind a cloud, as though the watching could maintain the connection that the distance was dissolving.

The morning sounds of Petaling Street filled the space Jake had occupied. A vendor three doors down was unrolling a tarpaulin over a table of counterfeit watches, the fabric snapping in the breeze from a passing truck. The motorcycle repair shop across the lane was already running its compressor, the pneumatic hiss rising and falling like mechanical breathing. Someone was frying something -- oil crackling, the smell of garlic and dried chillies hitting the heat, the specific morning smell of Chinatown waking up and getting to work. The sounds were the same sounds Connor heard every morning. But the sounds had always been background -- texture, atmosphere, the ambient noise of a life he was living inside. Now the sounds were foreground, because the foreground was empty, because the person who had stood in it was gone.

He remembered the first night Jake had arrived at the Lantern, three weeks ago -- stumbling through the front door at eleven PM with the duffel bag and the backwards cap and the bewildered grin of a man who had been delivered to the wrong address and decided to stay. Connor had been on the rooftop with Felix, and Jake had appeared at the top of the stairs and said, "Dude, is this the hostel with the good breakfast? A guy at the airport told me to come here. I think he might have been lying." He hadn't been lying. And Jake had stayed, and for three weeks Jake had been the person Connor could sit with and not perform for, the person who required nothing except company and beer and the occasional reassurance that things were, indeed, "sick."

Now the pavement was empty. The Grab was gone. The morning continued without interruption.

The street was the same street it always was: vendors, tourists, motorbikes, the red doors of the temple, the phone repair shop with its fluorescent light. But something had changed. Something had been removed from the equation, and the equation now balanced differently.

Jake had been the last uncomplicated thing in Connor's life. The last person who knew him without suspecting him, who liked him without diagnosing him, who spent time with him without trying to save him. Jake was the mirror that showed Connor the version of himself he wanted to be -- the traveler, the adventurer, the mate.
