Without Jake, the mirror was gone, and what remained was the version that everyone else saw: the courier, the mule, the man with two phones and a schedule and a growing bank balance and a shrinking soul.

He went inside. The hostel was quiet. Mama Siti was in the kitchen. Mei Ling was at reception.

Connor climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked. On the second-floor landing, the Japanese characters said nothing. In Dorm 3, Bed 7 waited with its carved name and its thin mattress and its view of nothing but the air well's grey light.

He lay down. He pulled the blue towel over his chest. He closed his eyes.

Jake was gone. Priya would be gone in nine days. Tomoko was still watching. Felix was still smiling. And Connor was still here, in the building that had been many things, in the bed that had held many people, carrying things he'd never opened for reasons he'd never examined in a city that was simultaneously the most beautiful and the most dangerous place he'd ever been.

---

Priya found him in the common room at noon.

She was carrying her Lonely Planet -- the rubber-banded, dog-eared Bible of her travels -- and a cup of the hostel's instant coffee, which tasted like it had been manufactured from the concept of coffee rather than actual beans. She sat in the armchair opposite and set the guidebook on the coffee table, and the gesture had the weight of a woman placing a marker, establishing territory, preparing for something.

"Jake's gone," she said.

"Yeah."

"He asked you to go with him."

"He did."

"You should have gone."

Connor looked at her. She was wearing her white T-shirt and her round glasses and the jade bracelet he'd bought her, and her face was carrying the expression he'd come to think of as her clinical face -- the one that saw through surfaces, that diagnosed conditions the patient didn't know they had.

"I couldn't. The work--"

"The work." She said it the way you'd say the name of a disease you'd been tracking. "Connor, I have nine days left. Nine days before my flight. And in those nine days, I can either watch you keep doing what you're doing, or I can try one more time to make you see what you're doing. I'm choosing to try."

"Priya--"

"Don't. Don't 'Priya' me. Don't deflect. Don't charm. Just listen."

He listened. Not because he wanted to but because Priya's voice, when it reached this register -- the low, steady, unflinching register of a woman who had spent three years learning how to talk to people who were dying -- was a force he couldn't redirect.

"Jake leaving is the best thing that could happen to you, because Jake leaving proves it's possible. He walked out. He booked a flight for forty-seven ringgit and he walked out of this hostel and got in a car and left. Nobody stopped him. Felix didn't stop him. The network didn't stop him. He just left. Which means you can leave too."

"It's different. Jake wasn't--"

"Jake wasn't doing deliveries. I know. That's the point. Jake got out before he was in. You're in. But 'in' is not 'stuck.' You're not trapped, Connor. You're choosing. Every morning you wake up and choose to stay and choose to carry and choose not to look, and the choosing is the thing that's killing you."

The word *killing* sat between them. It was the first time Priya had used it without qualification, without softening, without the clinical distance that medical training provided. The word was raw and personal and it hit the air between them with the force of something thrown.

"I'm not dying," Connor said.

"You will be."

The sentence was delivered without emphasis, without drama, in the flat, informational tone of a doctor reading a test result. It entered the space between them and stayed there, occupying the air the way smoke occupies a room -- not filling it but changing its composition, making every breath after it different from every breath before. Connor's body received the sentence before his mind did: a contraction in his stomach, a coldness across his shoulders, the involuntary straightening of his spine that was the body's oldest response to threat, the primate reflex of a creature hearing a predator's step. He was sitting in an armchair in a common room in a hostel and his body was preparing to run. But there was nowhere to run to. The threat was not in the room. The threat was the room. The threat was the building and the city and the schedule and the man upstairs with the matte black phone and the precise German accent, and running from all of that would require a velocity Connor did not possess.

The silence after *you will be* lasted four seconds. Connor counted them -- not deliberately but with the automatic, metronomic awareness of a person for whom time has become material, each second a unit of weight added to the distance between the word and its consequence. Four seconds. Priya did not look away. She held his eyes with the steadiness of a woman who had said the worst thing she could say and would not retreat from it.

Priya looked at him and her eyes were wet behind her glasses and the wetness was not crying -- Priya did not cry, not about this, not yet -- but the pre-crying, the physiological response to a grief that had not yet fully formed because the thing it was grieving had not yet fully happened.

"I'm leaving in nine days," she said. "And when I leave, there will be nobody in this hostel who cares whether you live or die. Tomoko cares about the story. Mei Ling cares about liability. Razak cares about his arrangement. Felix cares about his schedule. Nobody will care about *you*."

The words were precise and they were cruel and they were accurate, and the accuracy was the cruelty, because what Priya was describing was not a possibility but a certainty -- the certainty that Connor Briggs, once stripped of the people who loved him, would be alone in a building full of strangers, carrying packages for a man who saw him as a tool, in a city that would process his death with the same bureaucratic efficiency it processed everything else.

"Come with me," she said. "To London. Or to Melbourne. Wherever. Just leave. Just get on a plane and leave this building and this city and this man, and we'll sort the rest out later. I'll buy your ticket. Right now. On my phone."

She had her phone in her hand. The screen was on. A flight booking app was open. The cursor blinked in the search field, waiting for a destination, waiting for a name, waiting for the word that would change everything.

Connor looked at the screen. He looked at Priya. He looked at the common room -- the ceiling fans, the red lanterns, the bookshelf, the TV, the coffee table where the printed law had sat for one night before being swept into the trash. He looked at the building that had become his home, the only home he'd had in four years, the home that was not a home but a trap designed to feel like one.

And he almost said yes. The word formed. It was there -- in his throat, behind his teeth, a single syllable that weighed nothing and would change everything. *Yes.* He could feel the future that lived inside the word: the booking confirmed, the e-ticket generated, the taxi to KLIA, the departure board showing Melbourne or London or anywhere, the plane climbing above the Titiwangsa Range and banking west and the city shrinking below him until it was a circuit board, until it was a smudge, until it was nothing, until the packages and the sports bags and the blue doors and the matte black phone were just coordinates on a map of a place he used to be. The cursor blinked in the search field of Priya's phone. The cursor was patient. The cursor would wait as long as it took. He could see, on the screen, the airline logos -- AirAsia, Malaysia Airlines, Malindo -- and the departure times arranged in rows, and the prices in ringgit, and each row was an exit, each price was the cost of freedom, and the cost was negligible, the cost was nothing, the cost was less than two deliveries to Mr. Tan on Jalan Ipoh.

He opened his mouth. The word was there.

"I can't," he said.

The word *can't* was a lie. The word was *won't*, and the difference between *can't* and *won't* was the difference between a man who was imprisoned and a man who had locked his own cell and thrown the key through the bars. The machine had intercepted the yes and replaced it with can't, the way it always did, the way it had intercepted the phone call to his father, the way it had intercepted the impulse to follow Jake to Langkawi, the way it intercepted every exit before Connor could reach it -- smoothly, silently, with the practised efficiency of a system that had learned to mistake its own survival for his.

Priya's thumb hovered over the screen. The flight app waited. The cursor blinked.

She closed the app. The screen went dark with a small, definitive sound -- the click of the lock button, the sound a door makes when it closes for the last time, the sound of an offer expiring. She put the phone face-down on the armrest, the gesture slow and deliberate, the way a doctor sets down a chart when the diagnosis is final. She picked up her Lonely Planet and held it against her chest, the rubber bands pressing into her arms, the guidebook a shield now rather than a map, something to hold against the body when the body needed holding. And she looked at Connor with the expression of a woman who has offered everything she has and watched it refused, and the expression was not anger and it was not contempt and it was not even sadness. It was something beyond those things -- the particular, terminal acceptance of a person who has done everything possible and knows that everything possible is not enough.

"Okay," she said.

She stood. She walked to the staircase. At the foot of the stairs, she stopped.

"I'll be here for nine more days," she said, without turning around. "If you change your mind. Any time. Any hour. I'll be here."

She climbed the stairs. She was gone.

Connor sat in the common room. The ceiling fans turned. The red lanterns glowed. The empty armchair where Priya had been sitting held the impression of her body -- a slight compression in the cushion, a warmth that faded as the minutes passed, the ghost of a presence that had tried to save him and could not.

He was alone. Not the hostel alone, the dorm-full-of-strangers alone that backpackers called solitude. Really alone. The alone of a man who has pushed away everyone who could help and clung to the one person who would destroy him. The alone that is the last stage before the falling, when the safety net has been removed and the ground is coming up and the only question is when, not if.

The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.*

The burner phone buzzed. Felix.

*Tomorrow's schedule is confirmed. Jalan Ipoh, 10 AM. New item -- larger than usual. Be ready.*

Connor read the message. He typed back: *On it.*

He put the phone down. He stared at the ceiling. And somewhere on a highway heading north toward KLIA, in the back of a Grab, Jake Porter was telling his driver about a boat in Langkawi and a girl in Penang and a week that was going to be "absolutely epic, dude," and the driver was nodding with the patient courtesy of a man who was paid by the kilometre, and the car was moving, and Jake was leaving, and the leaving was the thing that saved him, though he would never know it, the way you never know the bullet that missed, the train you didn't catch, the bed in the hostel where the name was carved and the ceiling fan turned and the boy who stayed was the boy who died.
# Chapter 19: The Backpack

The backpack was red.

This was the first thing Connor noticed, and the noticing was significant because the sports bags had been black -- generic, anonymous, the kind of bag that dissolved into a crowd the way a raindrop dissolved into a puddle. The red backpack was different. It was a Deuter hiking pack, forty litres, the kind designed for multi-day treks, with a waist belt and chest strap and compression straps and the particular engineering that German outdoor brands applied to carrying loads over distance. It was also clearly not Connor's.

It was on the desk in Felix's room on the morning of Day 37. Beside it, Felix was standing with the posture of a man about to explain something complicated in simple terms.

"New delivery," Felix said. "Different from the usual."

Connor looked at the backpack. The backpack was full -- packed tight, the compression straps cinched, the zippers closed, the waist belt coiled and clipped. Whatever was inside had been arranged with the precision of someone who understood how to distribute weight in a hiking pack, the heavy items centred and close to the spine, the lighter items at the periphery.

"This goes to Sentul," Felix said. "Industrial area, north of the city. Address is in your work phone. Man named Ah Keat. He'll be at a warehouse -- I'll text you the description. The delivery is straightforward but the distance is longer than usual. Take a Grab there, walk the last two blocks. Ah Keat will meet you at the loading dock."

"Sentul." Connor hadn't been to Sentul. He knew it by reputation -- an area north of KL Sentral that was part industrial, part residential, the kind of neighbourhood that tourists didn't visit because there was nothing to visit, just warehouses and workshops and the working infrastructure that kept the city running.

"What's in it?" The question came out before the machine could intercept it, propelled by the backpack's colour, its size, its weight -- the sheer physical difference from the sports bags that had been his cargo for a month.

Felix looked at him. The look was the familiar one -- the half-second assessment, the recalibration, the smooth return to warmth. "Specialty electronics. Circuit boards, processors, high-value components. The backpack is better for this -- more padding, more protection. These are fragile items."

"Right."

"The payment is higher. RM800."

The number landed. RM800. Double the standard rate. The mathematics was clear and the mathematics was a message: the number was proportional to the risk, and the risk was proportional to the cargo, and the cargo was proportional to whatever was inside the red backpack that Felix had called specialty electronics with the same smooth conviction he'd called everything else phone components.

Connor reached for the backpack. He lifted it from the desk.

The weight was wrong.

Not in the way the sports bags had been wrong -- the subtle, almost-plausible wrongness of something slightly heavier than chargers and cables. This was a different wrongness. The backpack was heavy -- genuinely heavy, the weight of something dense and compressed, the weight pulling on his shoulder and arm with an insistence that demanded acknowledgement. He estimated seven kilograms. Maybe eight. The weight was distributed well -- centred, close to the spine, the work of someone who knew how to pack -- but the mass was there, unavoidable, physical, present.

Seven kilograms of circuit boards. Seven kilograms of processors. Seven kilograms of specialty electronics that required a forty-litre hiking backpack with compression straps and a waist belt and RM800 for an hour's work.

The machine ran. The machine produced: *Electronics are heavy. Circuit boards are dense. High-value components require careful packaging, which adds weight. The backpack is overengineered because the contents are fragile. Felix is paying more because the items are valuable, not because they're dangerous.*

The rationalisation was competent. It addressed the weight, the payment, the packaging. It provided an explanation that was internally consistent and externally plausible. But the rationalisation had a quality it hadn't had before -- a transparency, a thinness, the quality of a paint that's been applied too many times and has begun to crack, revealing the surface beneath.

Connor put the backpack on. Adjusted the straps. The waist belt sat on his hips and the chest strap crossed his sternum and the weight settled into the pack's frame, distributed, managed, but present -- always present, a constant physical reminder that what he was carrying was not the same as what he'd carried before.

"Be safe," Felix said. "The Sentul area can be rough. Stay on the main roads. Deliver, collect confirmation, come home."

Connor nodded. He walked to the door.

"Connor."

He turned.

"Don't open the backpack."

The instruction was the same as always. But this time Felix didn't smile when he said it. This time the words were delivered flat, without the warm packaging of a boss reminding an employee of procedure, without the casual ease that made the instruction sound reasonable. The instruction was delivered the way a command is delivered -- clean, direct, non-negotiable -- and the absence of the smile was its own communication, a signal that whatever was in the red backpack was different enough from whatever had been in the sports bags that Felix had abandoned the pretence of normality and replaced it with the raw mechanics of control.

"Wouldn't dream of it," Connor said.

---

The Grab to Sentul took forty minutes.

Connor sat in the back seat with the red backpack beside him, occupying the middle seat like a passenger, its bulk pressing against his thigh with a warmth that was not warmth but weight -- the dense, insistent weight of something that wanted to be acknowledged. The backpack was the colour of a warning. The colour of stop signs and fire extinguishers and the little flags that divers planted on the surface to say *something is happening below*. In the dim back seat of a silver Proton Saga, the red was muted, almost maroon, but it was still there, still wrong, still the colour of a thing that did not belong in a car with a pine-scented air freshener and a phone playing Waze directions in Bahasa Melayu.

The driver was a Malay man in his fifties, soft-faced, wearing a songkok and a button-down shirt that suggested another life -- a teacher, perhaps, or a government clerk moonlighting for Grab. He glanced at the backpack in his mirror. He glanced at Connor. The glance contained the calculation that all Grab drivers performed: assess the passenger, assess the cargo, decide whether to speak or drive in silence.

"Going to Sentul, ya?" he said. His English was careful, practiced, the English of a man who used it as a professional courtesy rather than a native instrument.

"Yeah."

"Business or visiting?"

The question was casual. The question was devastating. Connor said the thing that backpackers said when they didn't want to answer questions.

"Just checking out a different part of the city. Trying to see the real KL, you know?"

The driver smiled. "Sentul is real," he said. "Very real. Not many tourist there. You are the first *orang putih* I take to Sentul in a long time."

*Orang putih.* White person. Connor had heard the term before -- in markets, in hawker stalls, always at the edge of conversations he wasn't meant to understand. The term was not hostile. It was classificatory, and in Sentul, the category it assigned him -- *foreigner* -- would be visible in a way it was not in Bukit Bintang or Petaling Street, where white skin was part of the landscape, expected, catered to, absorbed.

The city changed as they moved north. The gleaming towers of the city centre -- KLCC, the Petronas Towers, the glass-and-steel monuments to Malaysia's ambition -- gave way as they turned onto Jalan Ipoh, the broad artery that ran north through the city's older body. The buildings lowered. The glass and steel surrendered to concrete and corrugated zinc. The pavements cracked. The traffic thickened with lorries and motorcycles, the heavy diesel machinery of a city's circulatory system, the vehicles that moved goods rather than people. Connor watched through the window and the watching was like watching a translation -- the same city, rendered in a different language, the tourist-facing version replaced by the version that existed when the tourists weren't looking.

He checked the GPS on the driver's phone. The blue dot was moving through streets he had never seen, into a territory that his mental map of KL -- bounded by Petaling Street to the south, KLCC to the east, Changkat to the west, the monorail to the north -- simply did not contain. He was off his map. He was in the white space at the edges, the part of the city where @ConnorGoesGlobal had never taken a photo because there was nothing to photograph, nothing that would generate engagement, nothing that would look good with a Valencia filter and a caption about discovering hidden gems.

The backpack sat beside him. Its weight had shifted during a turn, pressing harder against his thigh, and the pressure was a nudge, the physical equivalent of a hand on the shoulder saying *I'm still here, I'm still heavy, I'm still the thing you're pretending not to know about*.

Sentul was grey. Not uniformly grey -- there were patches of colour: a Hindu temple's painted tower rising from a row of workshops, its gopuram crowded with painted gods in blues and greens, a roti canai stall with a yellow awning where a man was stretching dough with the wrist-flick mastery of a lifetime's practice, a school playground where children in blue uniforms were running in the heat. But the dominant tone was industrial grey, the grey of concrete and steel and the flat, functional buildings that housed the machinery of commerce. This was a neighbourhood that existed for the verb *to work*, and the work was visible everywhere -- in the oil stains on the road, in the forklift tracks on the pavement, in the men in coveralls walking with the slow, deliberate gait of people who carried heavy things for a living.

"Here, ya?" The driver had pulled over on a wide, quiet street. Ahead, the road continued past warehouses with corrugated walls and loading docks.

Connor looked at the backpack. He looked at the street. He was two blocks from the warehouse, as instructed, and the instruction to walk the last two blocks was not about exercise or fresh air -- the instruction was about distance, about separation, about ensuring that no Grab driver's trip history showed a pickup or a dropoff at the exact address where a man named Ah Keat weighed things on a digital scale.

"Yeah. Here's good. Thanks."

He took the backpack. He opened the door. The heat hit him -- not the tourist-district heat modulated by air-conditioned malls and shaded walkways, but the raw heat of an industrial street, rising from asphalt and zinc and the exhaust of idling lorries. The air smelled of machine oil and hot metal and, beneath that, the faint sweet rot of tropical vegetation reclaiming the gaps between buildings.

Connor got out of the Grab two blocks from the warehouse, as instructed. The street was quiet -- no vendors, no tourists, no market stalls. Just warehouses and workshops and parked lorries and the smell of machine oil and hot metal. A stray dog trotted past on some private mission, its ribs visible under matted fur.

He walked. The backpack's weight was on his hips and shoulders and spine, and the weight was conversation, the weight was communication, the weight was the backpack saying *I am here and I am heavy and you know why I am heavy and you are choosing not to know*.

The warehouse was at the end of the street. A large building, single-storey, corrugated zinc walls, a loading dock with a metal roller door raised to half-height. Outside, a white van was parked at an angle, its rear doors open. A man was leaning against the van, smoking.

Ah Keat was approximately forty-five. Chinese-Malaysian. Short, stocky, his forearms thick and scarred, the build of someone who moved things for a living. He wore a white polo shirt stained with something dark, dark trousers, rubber-soled boots. His face was flat, unreadable, the face of a man who had optimised himself for function rather than expression.

He saw Connor approach. His eyes went to the backpack. He straightened from the van, dropped the cigarette, and ground it under his boot with the automatic precision of a man who ground out a hundred cigarettes a day.

"You're the Australian," he said. Not a question.

"Yeah. From Felix."

"Inside."

He ducked under the roller door and Connor followed. The warehouse interior was dim -- high ceiling, fluorescent tubes hanging from chains, only half of them lit. The space was large and mostly empty, the concrete floor stained with oil and scored by forklift tracks. Along one wall, metal shelving held boxes of various sizes. Along another, a workbench with tools, a lamp, and a large digital scale.

A scale. The same kind of scale Tomoko had photographed in Wei's shop. The flat metal platform, the LCD readout, the precision equipment of a person who measured things in grams.

Ah Keat held out his hand. Connor slipped the backpack off and handed it over. The weight transferred -- from his shoulders to Ah Keat's hands, from his responsibility to someone else's -- and the transfer produced a relief so intense it was almost physical, a lightness that made him feel briefly, absurdly, like he could float.

Ah Keat took the backpack to the workbench. He unzipped it with a single fluid motion, the sound of the zipper loud in the warehouse silence, the sound of something being opened that should not be opened in the presence of the person who had carried it. Connor was standing five metres away, near the roller door, and from five metres, in the dim light, with Ah Keat's body partially blocking the view, he could see the backpack's contents.

They were not circuit boards.

The contents were packages. Multiple packages, each one wrapped in layers of cling film, then sealed in vacuum bags, then wrapped again in something opaque -- plastic sheeting, black, taped shut. The packages were rectangular, flat, dense. Ah Keat removed them one by one and placed them on the workbench, and the placing was careful, methodical, the movements of a man handling material that required respect. His hands moved with the efficiency of repetition -- no hesitation, no fumbling, no wasted motion. He had done this before. He had done this a hundred times, perhaps a thousand, and the doing had been refined into a choreography, a set of movements as practised and automatic as a surgeon tying sutures or a mechanic changing spark plugs.

Seven packages. Each one approximately the size of a paperback novel. Each one sealed, wrapped, anonymous.

The fluorescent light above the workbench hummed at a frequency that was almost too low to hear, a vibration that lived in the teeth and the sinuses. The light cast everything in the flat, shadowless pallor of an operating theatre -- every surface rendered in clinical detail, every edge sharp, every colour drained to its institutional version. Under that light, the packages looked medical. The vacuum seal looked sterile. The cling film caught the fluorescence and threw it back in small, sharp gleams, and the gleams were like the flash of instruments, the glint of things designed to cut or measure or quantify.

Ah Keat placed one on the scale. The LCD display flickered and resolved. Connor was five metres away. The display was small. The numbers were not fully visible.

But the gesture was visible. The weighing was visible. The scale, the packages, the careful handling, the vacuum seal, the multiple layers of wrapping designed to contain something that could not be contained by brown paper and tape -- all of it was visible, present, undeniable, the accumulated evidence of every suspicion he'd suppressed and every question he'd refused to ask.

Connor watched. His hands were at his sides and his hands were doing something he had not authorised -- his right hand was opening and closing, the fingers curling into the palm and releasing, curling and releasing, the unconscious rhythm of a body trying to discharge the electricity that the mind refused to acknowledge. His breathing had changed. He could hear it -- the shallow, too-fast breathing of an animal in the presence of a predator, the breathing that said *run* in a language older than thought. He did not run. He stood. He breathed. He watched Ah Keat place the second package on the scale and note the number and place the third package and note the number, and each placement was a sentence in a language Connor understood but would not translate, a language that spoke in grams and vacuum seals and the precise, clinical movements of a man who weighed things that could not legally be weighed.

He almost spoke. The word was rising in his throat -- not a specific word but the precursor to a word, the gathering of breath and intention that preceded speech, the moment before the moment of asking *what is that* or *what am I carrying* or simply *what*. The word gathered. The word rose. And the machine intercepted it -- not gently, not with the smooth rationalisation of the early weeks, but violently, desperately, the way a hand clamps over a mouth, the way a door slams shut on something that must not be let in. The machine killed the word before it reached his lips and replaced it with silence, and the silence was louder than any word would have been, the silence of a man who had chosen not to ask because the answer was already inside him, fully formed, waiting in the dark.

Connor's mind was running -- not the machine, not the rationalisation engine, but the other mind, the deeper one, the one that processed information before the conscious mind could edit it. The deeper mind was assembling the evidence: the scale, the packages, the wrapping, the weight, the payment (RM800 for an hour's work), the location (a warehouse in an industrial area), the contact (a man who didn't smile, who didn't talk, who weighed things on a digital scale).

The deeper mind reached a conclusion. The conclusion was a word. The word was *drugs*.

The machine intercepted. The machine ran. The machine produced: *You don't know what those packages contain. They could be specialty electronics. They could be high-value components that require vacuum sealing for moisture protection. Circuit boards are sensitive to humidity. The scale could be measuring the total weight for shipping purposes. You're five metres away and you can't see the display and you're making assumptions based on packaging and Ah Keat's demeanour and your own paranoia.*

The rationalisation worked. Not completely -- a crack remained, a fissure in the wall, a space through which the truth leaked like water through a dam. But the wall held. The wall had been built by a master craftsman -- twenty-seven years of practised denial, of looking away, of choosing the comfortable interpretation over the accurate one -- and the wall could hold a crack. The wall could hold many cracks. The wall could hold until the moment when the water pressure exceeded the wall's capacity, and then the wall would break, and the breaking would be the end.

Ah Keat finished. He rezipped the backpack, empty now except for the padding, and handed it back to Connor. The backpack was light -- featherweight, impossibly light after the walk here, the absence of the weight producing a vertigo, a sensation of something missing.

"Done," Ah Keat said.

Connor took the backpack. He walked out of the warehouse. The sunlight hit him like a wall. The stray dog was still there, lying in the shade of a lorry, its ribs moving with the slow breathing of an animal that had accepted its conditions.

His work phone buzzed: RM800 transferred.

He walked to the main road. He flagged a Grab. The wait was seven minutes. He stood on the pavement with the empty backpack hanging from one hand, and the emptiness was its own sensation -- a lightness that was not relief but vertigo, the weightlessness of a thing removed, the phantom ache of an amputation. His shoulder still carried the memory of the weight, the muscles still braced for seven kilograms that were no longer there, and the absence of the weight was worse than the weight had been, because the weight had been a question and the absence was an answer, and the answer was that he had carried something to a warehouse and a man had taken it and weighed it in grams and the something was now gone and the grams were now known and the transaction was complete and Connor was standing on a pavement in Sentul holding a red backpack that contained nothing but the ghost of what it had contained.

The Grab arrived. Another silver Proton, another anonymous back seat, another driver who did not speak. Connor sat with the backpack on his lap, his arms around it, and watched the city translate itself back -- the warehouses giving way to shops, the shops to signboards in Mandarin and Tamil, the roads widening, the traffic shifting from lorries to sedans. The city reversed. The industrial grey dissolved into the commercial colour of Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, the sari shops and electronics stores, and then they were crossing the river and the KLCC skyline was ahead, the Petronas Towers rising above everything like a pair of chrome exclamation marks, and the towers were a signal, a geographic reset, a declaration that he was back in the version of KL that he knew, the version that was legible and navigable and safe.

His phone buzzed. Not the work phone -- the real phone, the Connor phone, the phone that connected to @ConnorGoesGlobal and the 4,200 followers who believed he was living the dream. An Instagram notification: someone had liked a photo he'd posted three days ago, a sunset from the hostel rooftop, the Petronas Towers backlit in orange and violet, the caption reading *Golden hour in KL. This city never gets old.* The photo had forty-seven likes. The photo was beautiful. The photo was a lie -- not in its composition but in its implication, which was that the man who took it was a man whose life was sunsets and rooftops and the uncomplicated beauty of a city seen from above. The man who took that photo did not carry red backpacks to warehouses. The man who took that photo did not watch men weigh packages on digital scales. The man who took that photo existed on a screen, in a curated gallery of a life that was increasingly fictional, and the distance between that man and the man sitting in the back of a Grab with an empty backpack on his lap was a distance that could not be measured in kilometres or ringgit but only in the specific, corrosive unit of self-knowledge that Connor had spent five weeks refusing to acquire.

He closed Instagram. He put the phone in his pocket.

He thought about the packages on the workbench. The vacuum seal. The scale. The weighing.

*Specialty electronics,* the machine said. *High-value components. Moisture-sensitive circuit boards.*

The machine said it. Connor heard it. The machine was still running but the machine was tired, the gears grinding, the output thinner, the product less convincing. The machine had been running for five weeks and the fuel was running low and the cracks were multiplying and the water pressure was building and the wall was holding but the wall was not as strong as it had been, not as thick, not as sure.

He went home. He showered. He stood under the cold water in the second-floor bathroom -- the bathroom with the cracked tiles and the showerhead that delivered water in an uneven, pulsing stream, the bathroom where someone had scratched @HostelReaper into the grout between the tiles near the drain -- and felt the water on his skin and let it run over his face and his shoulders and down the body that had carried the backpack to Sentul and back. The water was cold. The cold was supposed to be a cleansing, a reset, the physical equivalent of pressing delete, but the water only cleaned the skin and the thing that needed cleaning was not on the skin. The thing that needed cleaning was behind the wall, behind the cracks, in the place where the deeper mind had assembled the evidence and reached the conclusion and been silenced by the machine, and no amount of cold water from a hostel showerhead would reach that place.

He stood under the water until the cold stopped feeling cold and started feeling like nothing, the sensation flattening into numbness that was almost peace. Then he thought about seven kilograms and RM800 and a scale in a warehouse, and the numbness broke, and the water was cold again.

He thought about Priya's words: *You're not trapped. You're choosing.*

He thought about Jake, on a beach in Langkawi, drinking duty-free beer, the most dangerous thing in his day a sunburn.

He thought about his father: *The rules don't care who you are.*

He thought about David's brother, in Kajang Prison, counting days.

He thought about the word *drugs* and the wall that held it back and the cracks in the wall and the water behind the cracks.

He turned off the shower. He dried himself with the blue Sea to Summit towel -- the towel that had been with him through twelve countries, that smelled of every place he'd been, that would be with him at the end. He hung the towel on the hook behind the bathroom door and went to his dorm and lay on Bed 7 and stared at the ceiling and did not sleep.

The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.*

The building breathed.

And in a warehouse in Sentul, a man named Ah Keat was weighing the last of seven packages on a digital scale, and the scale's LCD display read a number, and the number was in grams, and the total across all seven packages was a number that Connor would never know but that the Malaysian legal system would eventually quantify with the precision and the finality that the law brought to all quantification, the law that didn't distinguish and didn't forgive and didn't care who you were or where you came from or how many countries your towel had been to.

The number was enough.

The number was more than enough.
# Chapter 20: The Phone Shop

Wei's phone repair shop had been next to the hostel since the day Connor arrived, and Connor had walked past it every day without going inside.

This was about to change. The burner phone buzzed at 8:47 AM on Day 39 with a message from Felix that was different from the usual messages in one specific way: the pickup location was not Felix's room.

*Today's item is at Wei's. Go to the shop. Tell him Felix sent you. He'll have a charger box for you. Drop at Bukit Bintang, Danny, Lot 22B. RM500.*

Connor read the message standing at the kitchen counter, Mama Siti's nasi lemak growing cold on its banana leaf. He read it again. The message was clear. The message was also an escalation, though Connor would not recognise it as such until later, when the recognition no longer mattered. Previously, Felix had been the intermediary -- the packages originated from Felix's room, passed through Felix's hands, carried Felix's imprint. The instruction to go directly to Wei's shop removed Felix from the chain. It connected Connor to the source.

He left the hostel at nine fifteen. Turned left. Walked three metres to the phone repair shop.

The shop occupied the ground floor of a pre-war shophouse identical to the hostel's -- narrow, deep, the facade covered in layers of signage: WEI PHONE REPAIR in hand-painted letters, SCREEN REPLACEMENT ALL BRANDS in a laminated sheet, CHEAP FAST RELIABLE in marker on cardboard. The window display was a archaeology of mobile technology: cracked iPhone 6s, Samsung cases, coiled USB cables, a Nokia 3310 that looked like it had survived a war. A bell hung above the door, the kind that rang when you pushed it open, a sound from a different century.

Connor pushed. The bell rang. He stepped inside.

The interior was narrow -- maybe two metres wide, four metres deep -- and every surface was covered. The walls were shelving, the shelving was full: phone cases in plastic bags, screen protectors in dusty boxes, earbuds on cardboard cards, charging cables coiled like hibernating snakes. The counter ran the length of the right wall, waist-high, wooden, scarred with burns from a soldering iron. Behind the counter, more shelving, more components, and a workbench with a magnifying lamp, a soldering station, and the small, precise tools of a repair technician -- tweezers, screwdrivers, spudgers, suction cups.

Wei was behind the counter.

He was approximately forty-five. Chinese-Malaysian. Thin, with the particular thinness of a man who forgot to eat, the bones of his wrists visible below rolled-up sleeves. His face was narrow, his eyes behind rectangular glasses, his expression carrying the concentrated focus of someone who spent his days peering at small things and had trained his features for precision rather than warmth. He wore a grey polo shirt and cotton trousers and had the posture of a man who spent twelve hours a day hunched over a workbench.

He looked up when Connor entered. The look was brief -- a flash of recognition, the quick assessment of a man who knew who Connor was and had been expecting him. Then the look dropped back to the phone he was working on, a Samsung with its back panel removed, its electronic guts exposed.

"Felix sent me," Connor said.

Wei nodded. Still not looking up. His soldering iron touched a connection point on the phone's board, and a tiny plume of smoke rose -- the smoke carrying the sharp, metallic smell of heated solder, a smell that lived in the olfactory territory between chemistry and craft.

"Wait," Wei said.

Connor waited. The shop was quiet -- a muffled, dense quiet, the sound absorbed by the packed merchandise on every surface, the only noises the faint hiss of the soldering iron and the tick of a wall clock that was fifteen minutes slow.

He looked around. The shop was exactly what it appeared to be: a phone repair business, functioning, stocked, legitimate. Customers had been here -- he could see the intake forms on a clipboard beside the register, handwritten, names and phone models and problems: *screen crack*, *battery dead*, *no charge*. The shelf behind the counter held phones in various states of repair, each in a labelled plastic bag. The business was real. The phone repair was real.

But the business was also something else. Connor could feel it -- the *else-ness* of the space, the way a room feels when it has more than one purpose, the way a person feels when they have more than one identity. The shop was a shop, and it was also the place where the packages originated. It was the place where Tomoko had photographed the digital scale. It was the place where Felix had stood at eleven PM with his hands flat on the counter, looking at something with the focused intensity of a man conducting business that was not phone repair.

Wei set down the soldering iron. He stood. He was taller than Connor expected -- six feet, maybe more -- the height hidden by his hunched posture. He moved to the back of the shop, to a door that Connor hadn't noticed because it was the same colour as the wall, partially hidden by a shelf of phone cases, the doorframe visible only by the thin shadow at its edge.

He opened the door. "Come," he said.

Connor followed. The door opened onto a corridor -- short, dark, maybe two metres -- and the corridor opened onto a room.

The back room was larger than the shop. It had the dimensions of the full shophouse ground floor, maybe four by six metres, the ceiling low, the walls unpainted concrete. A single fluorescent tube hung from the ceiling, casting the flat, blue-white light that fluorescents produced -- the light of police stations and hospitals and places where beauty was irrelevant.

The room was a workshop. A different kind of workshop from the front -- not phone repair but something else, something that operated at a different scale and with a different purpose. A long metal table ran the centre of the room, stainless steel, clean. On the table: rolls of cling film, boxes of vacuum bags, a vacuum sealer the size of a shoebox, rolls of black plastic sheeting, tape dispensers, scissors. And at the far end of the table, the digital scale -- the same scale from Tomoko's photograph, the flat metal platform catching the fluorescent light, the LCD display dark, waiting.

On the floor, beside the table, cardboard boxes. Stacked. Closed. Connor counted six.

Wei moved to a shelf against the back wall. The shelf held commercial packaging -- boxes for phone chargers, the kind you'd buy in any electronics shop: white cardboard, printed with product photos and spec lists and CE marks and the reassuring language of legitimate commerce. Wei selected a box. It was the size of a large phone charger -- rectangular, maybe twenty centimetres long, ten wide, five deep. He brought it to the table.

The box was already sealed. Cellophane-wrapped, the wrap tight and professional, the kind of wrapping that suggested factory packaging, mass production, the clean supply chain of a legitimate product. The box's label read: POWERMAX ULTRA FAST CHARGER -- USB-C/LIGHTNING -- 65W. Below the text, a photo of a white charger with multiple ports.

Wei held the box out. Connor took it.

The box was heavier than a phone charger.

Not dramatically heavier. Not the seven kilograms of the red backpack. But heavier than the plastic and circuit board of a 65W charger, heavier than the cardboard and cellophane that held it, heavier in a way that his hands registered and his mind, trained by five weeks of carrying things that were heavier than they should be, identified immediately.

The box weighed approximately 120 grams. A charger of this type weighed perhaps 50 grams. The difference -- 70 grams -- was the weight of what was inside the box that was not a charger.

Seventy grams. More than the fifty-gram threshold. The mandatory threshold. The death threshold.

The number appeared in his mind -- 50 grams, the number from Astrid's lecture at the bar, the number from Priya's printed law, the number that sat at the intersection of chemistry and jurisprudence like a tripwire across a road. Fifty grams of methamphetamine triggered the presumption of trafficking. Fifty grams reversed the burden of proof. Fifty grams changed the sentence from years to death.

The box in Connor's hand was heavier than fifty grams. The box in Connor's hand was a death sentence wrapped in cellophane and printed with a charger logo.

He stood in the back room of Wei's phone repair shop and held the box and the box held the truth and the truth was in his hands and his hands were shaking.

Not visibly. The shake was internal, subcutaneous, the body's honest response to a fact the mind had spent five weeks refusing to process. His fingers were steady on the cardboard. His arms were still. But inside, beneath the skin, the tremor was there -- the vibration of a system under stress, the hum of a machine running past its tolerances.

Wei watched him. Wei's expression had not changed. It had not changed because Wei's expression was not a variable -- it was a constant, the flat, neutral face of a man who assembled packages and handed them to couriers and did not invest emotion in the handoff because emotion was not part of the process. Wei was a function. Wei performed his function. The function did not require expression.

"Danny. Bukit Bintang," Wei said. The instruction was delivered in the same flat tone as *come* and *wait*, the vocabulary of a man who communicated in commands and expected compliance.

Connor put the box in his daypack. The box sat in the bag alongside his water bottle and his cracked phone and the copy of *The Beach* he was never going to read. The box was the size of a charger. The box looked like a charger. The box, to any observer, to any police officer, to any checkpoint, was a charger -- a tourist's charger, purchased at a shop in Chinatown, carried in a daypack, unremarkable.

Unless they opened it. Unless they weighed it. Unless they ran a test on the white crystalline substance that was packed inside the charger housing in a sealed plastic bag, occupying the space where the transformer and voltage regulators should have been. Unless they found the 70 grams -- or whatever the actual weight was, the weight that Wei had measured on the scale before sealing the box, the weight that was above the threshold, above the line, above the point of no return.

Connor walked out of the back room. Through the corridor. Through the shop. Past the Nokia 3310 and the cracked iPhones and the coiled cables and the bell above the door that rang when he pushed it open.

The morning heat of Petaling Street hit him. The sound of the market hit him. The smell -- fried dough, diesel, incense from the temple -- hit him. The city was there, real and present and indifferent, and Connor was there too, standing on the pavement with a daypack containing a box containing something that would kill him if he was caught with it, and he was going to carry it to Bukit Bintang and give it to a man named Danny in the back of a defunct karaoke bar and collect RM500 and come home and eat Mama Siti's nasi lemak and post on Instagram and pretend that he was living the dream.

He walked. He didn't take a Grab. He walked because the walking gave him time and the time gave his mind the space to process what it had seen -- the back room, the table, the cling film, the vacuum bags, the scale -- and the processing was necessary because the machine needed raw material and the raw material had to be converted from evidence into something else, something manageable, something that allowed him to keep walking.

The machine ran. The machine said: *The back room is a packaging facility. Import-export businesses have packaging facilities. The cling film and vacuum bags are for moisture protection. The scale is for weight compliance -- shipping companies charge by weight. The charger box is a branded product that Wei packages for distribution. Everything you saw is consistent with a legitimate electronics business.*

The rationalisation was the weakest one the machine had ever produced. It was thin, translucent, the structural equivalent of tissue paper over a hole. Connor could feel its inadequacy. He could feel the wind through it, the cold air of truth moving through the gaps in the tissue, touching his skin with a cold he'd been keeping out for five weeks and could no longer fully exclude.

But the tissue held. Barely. By a thread. By the single thread of *I don't know for certain*, which was the last and most powerful rationalisation of all -- the argument from ignorance, the defence of the man who has seen the evidence and heard the testimony and felt the weight in his hands and still, still, can claim that he doesn't know because he hasn't tested the substance, hasn't read the scale, hasn't held the truth in his palms and said its name aloud.

He walked to Bukit Bintang. The walk took twenty-five minutes through the Saturday crowds -- Petaling Street to Jalan Sultan to Jalan Bukit Bintang, the route threading through the gleaming heart of KL's retail district, past Pavilion and Lot 10, past the monorail station where tourists funnelled out in bright packs, past the Sephora and the H&M and the durian stall that sat among the luxury brands like a dare, pumping its sulfurous, custard-sweet stench into the air-conditioned draft that leaked from every automatic door. The Saturday shoppers moved around him -- families with strollers, Malay teenagers in streetwear, Japanese tour groups following raised umbrellas, Indonesian women in headscarves carrying bags from Zara. The normality of it was obscene. The normality was a wall of sound and colour and human purpose against which Connor moved with a daypack on his back containing a death sentence sitting next to a water bottle and a copy of *The Beach* he'd bought in Bali and never opened past page twelve.

He could feel the box. Not its weight -- 120 grams was nothing, less than a phone, less than a wallet -- but its *presence*, the way you could feel a spider on your arm before you saw it, the way the body registered proximity to danger before the mind had language for it. The box sat in the main compartment of his daypack, cushioned by a rolled-up hoodie, adjacent to the water bottle whose condensation was probably dampening the cellophane wrapper, and the casualness of the arrangement -- a charger box next to a water bottle next to a paperback, the inventory of a tourist's afternoon -- was the most terrifying thing about it. The thing that would kill him was touching the thing that kept him hydrated. The death penalty was nestled against a novel about backpackers in Thailand. The geometry of the daypack was a joke that no one was telling and everyone would eventually understand.

He turned off Jalan Bukit Bintang into a side alley he'd walked once before, nine days ago, on Day 30. The alley was narrow -- barely wide enough for a car -- and the transition from the main road was immediate: the gleaming storefronts vanished, replaced by the back-end infrastructure of the entertainment district, the service doors and dumpsters and stacked crates and the accumulated grime that luxury required but refused to display. Halfway down the alley, on the left, the defunct karaoke bar. The sign was still there -- GOLDEN VOICE KTV -- the neon tubes dark and dusty, the windows papered over from the inside, the roller door pulled down to knee height. The place had the particular stillness of a business that had died and been repurposed without anyone bothering to change the skin.

Connor ducked under the roller door. The interior was dark after the alley's glare, and the darkness smelled of old beer and dust and the chemical residue of whatever cleaning product had last been applied to the vinyl upholstery of the karaoke booths, which were still there, pushed against the walls, their foam cushions split and leaking stuffing. A mirror ball hung from the ceiling, dead, its facets dulled by a film of grime. The room was larger than it looked from outside -- deep, extending back into the building's interior, the rear wall lost in shadow.

Danny was at a table in the back. Mid-twenties, Chinese-Malaysian, thin, the same nervous energy Connor remembered from Day 30, the energy of a man who occupied the disposable middle of a chain and knew it. Danny's face was lit from below by his phone screen, the blue light carving his features into something sharper than they were, and when he looked up at Connor the expression was not greeting or hostility but the flat, transactional blankness of a man who was a function performing his function.

Connor took off the daypack. Unzipped it. Took out the charger box. Placed it on the table. The box sat on the scratched wood between them -- POWERMAX ULTRA FAST CHARGER, the logo cheerful, the cellophane catching a thread of light from the cracked roller door -- and the placing was the act, the handoff, the transfer of 70 grams from one set of hands to another, from one jurisdiction of guilt to another, though the law would not see it that way, the law would see Connor's hands and the 70 grams and the road between them and would draw a line that was straight and final and indifferent to the question of whose table the box was sitting on now.

Danny took it. He didn't weigh it. He didn't open it. He put it in a drawer beneath the table and the drawer closed and the box disappeared and the disappearance was the end of Connor's involvement and the beginning of something else, something that moved down the chain to places and people Connor would never see, and the not-seeing was the last, thinnest wall between him and the full knowledge of what he was part of.

His work phone buzzed. RM500 transferred. The notification produced the familiar pulse -- the small, warm dopamine hit that five weeks of Pavlovian conditioning had wired into his nervous system, the chemical reward for the completed task. But this time the dopamine was fighting something. This time the warmth was competing with a nausea that rose from somewhere lower, somewhere the conditioning hadn't reached, and the two sensations -- the pleasure and the sickness -- coexisted in his chest like two frequencies played simultaneously, producing a dissonance that was not one thing or the other but a third thing, a new thing, the sound of a man who was being rewarded for something that was killing him.

He went home. He sat in the common room. He sat in the armchair where Priya usually sat -- the worn velvet one by the window, the one that smelled faintly of her shampoo, coconut and something herbal -- and he stared at the wall and he thought about nothing, which was the hardest work he'd ever done, because nothing was now full of everything he'd seen and everything he'd refused to know and the space required to hold all of it was larger than his mind and the overflow was leaking into his body, into his chest, into his hands, into the tremor that was no longer internal but visible, his fingers shaking against his thighs in a rhythm that matched the ceiling fan.

The tremor had started in his hands -- the fine, subcutaneous vibration that had been with him in Wei's back room -- but now it spread. It moved up his forearms, into his biceps, into the muscles of his shoulders, the way cold spreads through water, the way a crack spreads through glass, following the lines of least resistance until the whole structure was involved. His hands shook against his thighs. His forearms trembled. His jaw was clenched so tight that his molars ached, the body's attempt to contain the shaking by bracing against itself, which did not work, because the shaking was not muscular but systemic, the full-body response of a nervous system that had been carrying a load it was not designed to carry and had, in the dim back room of a phone repair shop, finally registered the weight.

He stared at the common room. The bookshelf -- the same bookshelf that had been there since his first day, the spines of abandoned paperbacks leaning against each other like drunks at a bar: *Shantaram*, *The Alchemist*, three copies of *Lonely Planet Southeast Asia*, a water-damaged *Harry Potter*. The TV on the wall, playing something in Malay he couldn't follow. The red lanterns hanging from the ceiling, their warm light making everything amber and soft, the light of a place that felt safe because it was designed to feel safe, because the lanterns and the velvet and the bookshelf were the set dressing of a hostel that wanted you to feel at home while you were very, very far from it. And there, beside the reception counter, the noticeboard -- the cork rectangle where Mei Ling pinned bus schedules and tour flyers and house rules, and where, weeks ago, Priya had pinned a printed sheet: the Dangerous Drugs Act 1952, Section 39B, the relevant passage highlighted in yellow, the words MANDATORY DEATH PENALTY in bold. The sheet was gone now. Someone had taken it down -- Mei Ling, perhaps, or Uncle Razak, or the natural entropy of a hostel noticeboard that consumed documents the way the building consumed guests, silently, continuously, without record. The sheet was gone but the law was still there, the law was always there, the law did not require a printout to exist.

The machine tried to run. He could feel it trying -- the gears engaging, the mechanism reaching for raw material, the rationalisation engine attempting to convert the back room and the scale and the vacuum bags into something manageable. But the gears found nothing. The gears spun in empty space, producing no traction, no output, no product. The machine had run out of material. The tissue paper was gone. The *I don't know for certain* was gone, burned up in the fluorescent light of Wei's back room where the certainty had been laid out on a stainless steel table like evidence in a courtroom. The machine ran and produced silence, and the silence filled the space where the rationalisations used to be, and the silence was louder than any of them, because silence was the sound of a man who had nothing left to tell himself.

He sat there for an hour. The hour passed the way hours pass in hospital waiting rooms -- not in minutes but in breaths, each breath a unit of time that carried no information and offered no progress, the clock on the wall moving but the situation remaining exactly the same. Guests moved through the common room -- a Dutch couple heading out with daypacks, a solo traveler collecting laundry from the courtyard line -- and none of them saw him, or if they saw him they saw a backpacker sitting in a chair staring at a wall, and that was not unusual, that was not alarming, that was the posture of jet lag or a hangover or a bad night's sleep, the universal hostel posture of a person waiting for something to pass.

*Tick, tick, tick.*

Priya found him there. She came down the narrow staircase from the third floor, her braid over one shoulder, her round glasses pushed up on her forehead the way she wore them when she'd been reading, and she saw his face and she saw his hands and she stopped in the doorway of the common room and stood very still for a moment, the way a person stands when they see something they've been expecting and dreading in equal measure. Then she crossed the room and sat on the arm of the chair and put her hand on his shoulder and said nothing, because sometimes nothing was the right thing to say, the only thing to say, the thing that allowed a person to break in the presence of another person without the breaking being observed or narrated or fixed.

She held him. He let her hold him. And in the holding, in the silence, in the warm amber light of the common room, something gave way. Not the wall -- the wall held, the wall would hold for a few more days, the wall was stronger than love and stronger than fear and stronger than truth. But something behind the wall shifted, the way tectonic plates shift before an earthquake -- a deep, slow, grinding movement that was not yet a break but was the precondition for a break, the mechanical prerequisite for the moment when everything would move at once and the landscape would change and the man who had been carrying packages would become the man who had carried packages, and the difference between the two was everything.

"I went to Wei's shop," Connor said. His voice was quiet. Flat. The voice of a man reporting something he'd seen rather than something he'd done -- the voice of a witness, not a participant, the dissociation already active, the self splitting from the body that had carried the box. "The back room. There's a--" He stopped. Started again. The details came in the wrong order, the way a person describes a car accident -- the aftermath first, then the impact, then the moments before, the chronology scrambled by the force of what had happened. "There's a scale. Digital. Like a kitchen scale but -- no. There's a table first. Stainless steel. And on the table there's cling film and vacuum bags and a vacuum sealer and tape and scissors and-- Priya, there are boxes. Charger boxes. The same boxes. The same--" He stopped again. "It's not a phone shop, Priya."

She held him tighter. Her arms were around his shoulders and the jade bracelet -- the one Connor had bought her at the Petaling Street night market, the one she wore on her left wrist because her mother had told her jade should sit over the pulse -- was cool against his collarbone, and the coolness was the opposite of everything else, the opposite of the fluorescent heat of Wei's back room and the Saturday sun on Bukit Bintang and the warm dopamine of the RM500 notification. Her arms were the temperature of safety and Connor leaned into them the way a drowning man leans into a current that might carry him to shore or might not, the leaning itself the only act available.

"I know," she said.

"I've known for a while. I think I've always known."

"I know that too."

The common room was quiet. The ceiling fans turned. On the TV, a news broadcast in Malay showed footage of a police operation -- officers in blue, a table of seized drugs, a man in handcuffs being led to a van. Connor watched the footage and the footage watched him back.

"What do I do?" he said.

It was the first time he'd asked. In five weeks of warnings and arguments and printed laws and photographs and proverbs and business cards, it was the first time Connor Briggs had looked at someone who loved him and asked for help.

Priya's answer was immediate. She spoke the way she spoke about medicine -- in protocol, in steps, the voice of a fourth-year medical student who had been trained to convert crisis into procedure, to replace panic with sequence, to impose order on the body's chaos. "You stop. Right now. Today. No more deliveries. No more packages. No more Felix."

"And then?"

"And then we call Sergeant Ahmad. You tell him everything -- the routes, the names, the drop points, Wei's shop, the back room. You cooperate fully. Voluntary disclosure before arrest is the strongest position you can be in." She was thinking aloud now, the plan assembling itself in real time, the medical student's mind doing what it was trained to do: triage, prioritise, act. "Then we get to KLIA. Tonight. There's a midnight flight to Melbourne on Malaysia Airlines and a six AM to London on Qatar. We get on whichever one leaves first. You fly to Melbourne, I fly to London, and once we're out of the country you contact the Australian High Commission from outside Malaysian jurisdiction. You tell them everything you told Ahmad. You get a lawyer. A real one, not a hostel recommendation."

The plan was clear. The plan was specific. The plan had five steps and each step was possible and each step led to the next and the final step led to a life in which Connor Briggs was alive and free and answering questions in a room with a lawyer instead of a room with a fluorescent tube and a scale. The plan was the thing that would save his life, the open door at the end of a burning corridor, the exit that was still accessible, still functional, still available to a man who was willing to walk through it.

Connor looked at the door. He looked at Priya. He looked at his hands, which had carried things he'd never opened and were now shaking in the amber light.

"Okay," he said.

Priya's eyes widened. The word -- *okay* -- was the word she'd been waiting for since the night she'd printed the law. The word was yes. The word was agreement. The word was the sound of a man finally, finally, choosing to save himself.

"Okay," she said. "I'll help you. Right now. We'll call Ahmad together."

She reached for her phone. Connor reached for his wallet -- the wallet with the business card, the card that said NARCOTICS DIVISION, the card that was the lifeline, the card that had been waiting.

His burner phone buzzed.

The sound came from his left pocket -- the Nokia, the burner, the work phone, the phone that existed in a parallel jurisdiction from the iPhone in his right pocket. The two phones sat on opposite sides of his body like two identities separated by a spine, the personal and the professional, the curated life and the criminal one, and the buzzing came from the criminal side, the left side, the side closest to his heart, which was a coincidence of pocket placement that felt, in this moment, like architecture.

Felix.

*Need to see you. Rooftop. Now. Important.*

Connor looked at the phone. He looked at Priya. The two options sat before him -- the business card and the burner phone, the lifeline and the chain, the future and the past.

"I should see what he wants," Connor said.

Priya's face changed. The change was not dramatic -- she was not a person who performed her emotions, not a person who widened her eyes or opened her mouth or made the gestures that fear was supposed to make. The change was smaller and worse: a closing. A withdrawal. The light in her eyes -- the specific, fierce, medical light that had been there while she outlined the plan, the light of a person who believed the crisis could be managed -- went out. Replaced by something flat and knowing. The expression of a woman watching someone she loved choose to drown, the expression of a doctor watching a patient refuse treatment, the grief of someone who has offered the cure and watched the hand reach for the poison instead.

"No. Connor. No."

"Just to hear what he has to say. Then I'll call Ahmad. I promise."

"You promise." She said it the way you'd say the name of something that had stopped existing. "Connor, if you go to that rooftop, you won't call Ahmad. You know you won't. You'll talk yourself out of it. You always do. Felix will smile, and you'll find a reason, and tomorrow you'll be carrying another package."

She was right. She was right the way a diagnosis is right -- clinically, absolutely, in a way that the patient can acknowledge intellectually while still refusing to act. Connor knew she was right. He knew it the way he knew the packages weren't phone accessories and the boxes weren't chargers and Felix wasn't a photographer. He knew it, and knowing was not enough, because knowing required action, and action required breaking the only structure he had, and the structure -- the schedule, the money, Felix's approval, the warm, poisonous illusion of belonging -- was the only thing between him and the void.

"Five minutes," he said. "That's all. Then I'll call."

He stood. He put the wallet -- with the card, with the lifeline -- back in his pocket. Right side. He put the burner phone in the other pocket. Left side. The two objects resumed their positions, separated by his body, the choice deferred, the architecture of indecision restored. He walked to the staircase -- the narrow staircase, the one where two people could not pass, the one that funnelled a person upward through the building's dark interior toward the rooftop where Felix waited. The staircase that was too narrow for Priya to follow even if she wanted to, which she didn't, because following was not what you did when someone chose the wrong door. You stood and watched. You stood and watched and you remembered the plan you'd made -- the five steps, the midnight flight, the lawyer, the life -- and you folded it up and put it away in the place where the things that almost happened went to wait.

Priya did not follow. She sat in the armchair and watched him go and felt the fracture between them widen into something she recognised from her orthopaedics rotation -- not a stress fracture anymore but a complete break, the kind where the two halves could not be held together by anything short of surgery, and Connor would not consent to surgery. It had been broken since the first envelope, and everything since had been the two of them standing on opposite sides of the break, reaching across, their fingers almost touching but never quite connecting.

Connor climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked. The rooftop door opened. Felix was there.

And the next chapter began.
# Chapter 21: The Noose

Felix was standing at the railing, silhouetted against the city, and the city behind him was beautiful the way all traps were beautiful -- illuminated, inviting, designed to draw you closer.

The Petronas Towers were silver-white against the darkening sky, the last light catching their cladding and throwing it back as something colder than warmth. Below, the grid of Petaling Street was beginning its nightly transformation -- the daytime market contracting, the night market expanding, the LED lights stringing to life in blue and white and orange. From the rooftop, the city looked manageable. From the rooftop, everything looked manageable. That was the rooftop's lie.

"Sit down, Connor." Felix's voice was calm. Not warm -- the warmth had been recalibrated in the past few days, rationed, deployed more sparingly, the way a declining empire conserves its resources. What remained was something more efficient: authority without performance, command without charm.

Connor sat. The plastic chair was damp with the evening's humidity. His hands were still trembling -- the aftershock of what he'd seen in Wei's back room, the aftershock of almost calling Ahmad, the aftershock of choosing this rooftop over that phone call.

Felix turned from the railing. He didn't sit. He stood, and the standing was deliberate -- the physical arrangement of a conversation in which one person held the power and the other held the chair.

"I know what happened today," Felix said.

The sentence sat in the air between them like something placed rather than spoken.

"Wei told me you went into the back room. He said you saw the workbench. The packaging materials. The scale." Felix's voice was even, measured, the voice of a man reading a report rather than making an accusation. "He said you looked. He said your hands shook. He said you took the charger box and left without speaking."

Connor said nothing. The machine tried to engage -- tried to produce a deflection, a denial, a smooth rationalisation that would restore the equilibrium -- but the machine was running on fumes and what it produced was silence, which was the most honest output the machine had ever generated.

"I understand," Felix said. "I do. You've seen things that are difficult to reconcile with what I've told you. The packaging, the scale, the weight. You're not stupid, Connor. You were never stupid. You were trusting, which is different, and trust was what made you valuable."

The word *valuable* landed like a coin on the zinc railing -- metallic, precise, its worth calculated in advance.

"I'm going to tell you the truth now," Felix said. "Because we've reached the point where the truth is more useful than the story."

He paced -- two steps left, two steps right, the compact movement of a man who thought on his feet. The scar on his eyebrow caught the city's ambient light.

"The packages you've been carrying contain methamphetamine. Crystal meth. The envelopes contained cash -- payment for previous shipments. The brown paper packages contained small quantities -- fifty, sixty grams. The sports bags contained larger quantities -- two hundred to four hundred grams. The backpack you took to Sentul contained approximately six hundred grams, divided into seven packets. The charger box you picked up today contained seventy-two grams."

He said the numbers the way a banker says interest rates -- factual, decimal, without the weight that the numbers carried in other contexts. In other contexts -- in courtrooms, in police reports, in the Dangerous Drugs Act of 1952 -- these numbers were death sentences. In Felix's mouth, they were inventory.

Connor heard the numbers. The numbers entered his mind and arranged themselves in a column -- 50, 60, 200, 400, 600, 72 -- and the column had a total, and the total was a number that represented, in grams, the cumulative weight of everything he'd carried across KL in the past five weeks. The total was a number so far above the fifty-gram threshold that the threshold was irrelevant, a speed bump in a rearview mirror.

The machine tried. The machine made its best attempt -- tried to engage the rationalisation protocols, tried to find the gap in Felix's arithmetic, the decimal point in the wrong place, the unit error that would collapse the total back down to something survivable. But there was no gap. The arithmetic was clean. Felix had said the numbers the way you'd read items off a receipt, and Connor's mind was now performing the calculation it had refused to perform for five weeks: each delivery multiplied by the fifty-gram threshold, each multiplication producing a mandatory death sentence, fourteen deliveries producing fourteen death sentences that were really one death sentence carried fourteen times by a man who had thought he was carrying phone accessories and import-export samples and things that didn't need names because names would have required questions and questions would have required answers and the answers were in Felix's mouth right now, numbered and weighed and delivered with the flat precision of a man reading inventory. He had carried death sentences like groceries. He had slung them over his shoulder in a daypack next to a water bottle and a copy of *The Beach*. The machine searched for something to say about this and the machine produced nothing, because the machine had been built to process ambiguity and there was no ambiguity left.

"Why are you telling me this?" Connor's voice was hoarse. The voice of a man who has been breathing the wrong air.

"Because you already know. You've known since the back room. Maybe longer. And because what happens next depends on whether we're honest with each other."

Felix stopped pacing. He stood in front of Connor -- close, two metres, the distance of a conversation between friends, the distance of a conversation between a handler and his asset.

"Here's the situation, Connor. You have been carrying methamphetamine through Kuala Lumpur for five weeks. Fourteen individual deliveries. Multiple locations, multiple contacts. Your face is on CCTV at every pickup and every drop -- Wei's shop has cameras, the hostel has cameras, Mr. Tan's building has cameras, the Sentul warehouse has cameras. Your fingerprints are on every package -- the paper, the nylon, the tape. Your phone -- the work phone I gave you -- contains a record of every instruction, every address, every confirmation. Your bank account contains RM14,000 in deposits that cannot be explained by social media consulting."

Each sentence was a brick. Felix was building a wall, and the wall was around Connor, and the wall was made of evidence, and the evidence was irrefutable because the evidence was real -- it was the trail that Connor had left, delivery by delivery, transfer by transfer, the breadcrumb trail of a man walking into the forest who had never looked back to see what the breadcrumbs spelled.

"If I go to the police--" Connor started.

"If you go to the police, you are confessing to drug trafficking. The CCTV footage, the fingerprints, the phone records, the bank deposits -- they are evidence against *you*. Not against me. I'm not on those cameras. My name is not in your phone -- you have a number, not a name. My fingerprints are not on the packages -- I wear gloves, Connor. I have always worn gloves."

The word *gloves* detonated in Connor's mind. Felix had worn gloves. Felix had always worn gloves. The thin leather driving gloves he wore when handling the packages -- Connor had noticed them, had even commented once ("Bit fancy for KL, mate"), and Felix had laughed and said something about eczema, and Connor had accepted it because accepting was what he did, because accepting was the machine's fuel, because not accepting would have required a question and the question would have required an answer and the answer was *I'm wearing gloves so my fingerprints aren't on the drugs I'm giving you to carry*.

He could see the gloves now. He could see them with a clarity that was almost hallucinatory -- the soft brown leather, the stitched seams, the way Felix pulled them on before touching any package, every time, without exception, the gesture so practised it had looked like habit rather than protocol. Connor had stood there with his bare hands, his fingerprints pressing into paper and nylon and packing tape, his skin leaving its signature on every surface, and two metres away Felix had been wearing gloves and the gloves were the moat between Felix and the evidence and the moat had been visible the entire time and the machine had looked at the moat and called it eczema.
