The precision of her language -- the legal vocabulary, the distinction between trafficking and possession, the reference to Section 39B's presumption clause -- was not improvised. She had spent hours on her laptop in Dorm 4, searching Malaysian legal databases, reading human rights reports, studying the cases of foreigners arrested for drug trafficking who had cooperated with authorities and received reduced sentences. She had found cases where mules who testified against networks had been charged with possession rather than trafficking. She had found the numbers: possession carried a maximum of life imprisonment. Trafficking carried a minimum of death.

The gap between life and death was the gap between cooperation and silence. The gap was the letter in her bag.

"I need time," Connor said.

"You've had time. You've had forty-six days. Time isn't what you need. Time is what Felix needs. Every day you wait is a day Felix uses to prepare the final job. Every day you wait is a day closer to the suitcase and the bus and the checkpoint that you know -- you *know*, Connor -- is coming."

"The job is today. Felix said--"

"I know what Felix said. That's why I'm telling you now. Before the job. Before the suitcase. Before you get on a bus with four hundred and fifty grams of methamphetamine in the lining and drive through a country that will execute you for carrying it."

She knew the weight. She knew the amount. The specificity of the number -- four hundred and fifty grams -- was not a guess. Priya had calculated it from what Connor had told her, from the escalation pattern, from the amounts he'd described carrying in packages and backpacks, from the logic of a final job that was bigger than all the others. She had done the math. The math said death.

Connor looked at the red suitcase. The suitcase that was going to London. The suitcase that contained clothes and books and toiletries and a letter that held his life in its paragraphs, a letter that could save him or destroy him depending on variables he could not control -- the honesty of Ahmad, the corruption of the system, the willingness of a Malaysian court to distinguish between a mule and a dealer.

"Send the letter," he said.

The words came from somewhere he didn't recognize -- somewhere beneath the machine, beneath the fear, beneath the five weeks of accumulated denial and rationalisation that had converted him from a tourist into a defendant. The words came from the part of Connor Briggs that still existed, the part that his mother would recognize, the part that had said *okay* in the common room on Day 39 before the burner phone buzzed and Felix's summons pulled him upstairs.

Priya's eyes filled. Not dramatically -- not the cinematic weeping of a farewell scene, not the tears that actors produced on cue. This was different. This was the slow, quiet overflow of a woman who had been holding her breath for five weeks and had just been given, in two words, the permission to exhale.

"You mean it," she said.

"Send the letter. From London. To Ahmad, to the embassy, to everyone. And I'll--"

He stopped. The sentence had a second half and the second half required a commitment and the commitment required a decision about what he would do between now and the letter's arrival, between this morning and the afternoon when Priya would land at Heathrow and open her laptop and press send.

"And you'll what?" Priya said.

"I'll wait. I won't do the job. I'll tell Felix I'm sick, or I've left, or-- I'll find a reason. I'll stall. Until Ahmad comes."

"Connor, if you're here when the letter arrives, Felix will know. Felix will know because the police will come and Felix has eyes everywhere and the interval between the letter arriving and the police acting is the interval in which Felix decides what to do with you."

"Where else would I go?"

"The Australian Embassy. Go today. Walk in. Tell them everything. They can't protect you from Malaysian law but they can ensure you're in custody when the letter arrives, not at the hostel where Felix--"

"The embassy will call the police. The police will arrest me. I'll be in a cell within hours."

"You'll be in a cell where Sergeant Ahmad knows your name and your story and your willingness to cooperate. Not a cell where Felix's contacts can reach you. There's a difference."

The difference was the letter. The difference was whether Connor entered the system as a cooperating witness or as a caught mule. The difference was the distinction between walking into a police station and being dragged out of a bus. The difference was survival.

Connor looked at Priya. She looked at him. The common room was filling with morning light -- the amber glow of the red lanterns replaced by the blue-white of tropical dawn, the light that came through the air well and hit the mosaic tiles and scattered in patterns that moved as the sun moved, the slow celestial clock that measured something larger than human choice.

"Okay," he said. Again. The word he'd said on Day 39 and failed to honour. The word that was simultaneously the easiest and hardest word in the English language -- easy to pronounce, hard to mean.

Priya took his hand. The jade bracelet clinked against the bones of his wrist. Her skin was warm. Her grip was strong -- the grip of a woman who had been holding on for five weeks and was about to let go and the letting go required the belief that the holding had accomplished something, that the effort had not been wasted, that the man whose hand she held would, this time, do the thing he said he would do.

"I love you," she said.

"I love you."

"Then survive. That's all I'm asking. Survive this."

---

Mama Siti appeared in the kitchen doorway. She carried two plates of nasi lemak -- the banana leaf wrapping, the coconut rice, the sambal, the ikan bilis, the slice of hard-boiled egg and the slice of cucumber, the complete breakfast of a country that understood that mornings required sustenance and that sustenance was not just calories but ceremony.

She placed the plates on the counter without speaking. Then she looked at Priya. She looked at the red suitcase. She looked at Connor.

"Makan dulu," she said. *Eat first.*

They ate. The nasi lemak was perfect. The sambal burned. The rice was fragrant with coconut and pandan. They ate in the silence of two people performing a normal act on an abnormal morning, the normalcy of the food a temporary shelter from the conversation that had preceded it and the departure that would follow.

Mama Siti watched from the kitchen. Her face was still. Her eyes moved between Priya and Connor with the slow deliberation of a woman reading a text in a language she'd learned decades ago, the language of farewell, the language that the hostel had taught her through ninety-seven years of arrivals and departures, the language that said: *this one is leaving and the other one is staying and the staying is the dangerous part*.

She spoke once, to Priya, as Priya carried her empty plate to the wash area.

"Dia masih ada masa," she said. *He still has time.*

Priya looked at Mama Siti. Mama Siti's expression was unchanged -- the worn geography of her face, the deep lines around her eyes, the mouth that dispensed proverbs and nasi lemak with equal precision. But her eyes held something that her face did not express. Not hope exactly. Something harder. Something closer to the word for the belief that a story might end differently than you expected it to, the belief that the building might release one of its guests instead of keeping them.

"Terima kasih," Priya said. *Thank you.*

Mama Siti nodded. She turned back to her stove. The wok hissed. The morning continued.

---

At eight forty-five, Mei Ling called a Grab to KLIA2.

The car arrived at eight fifty-three -- a silver Proton Saga, the driver a Malay man in his fifties who had the patient, incurious expression of a man who drove people to airports every morning and had long ago stopped wondering where they were going or why they looked the way they looked. He loaded Priya's suitcase into the boot. The red suitcase disappeared into the car's interior, and with it, the letter.

Connor stood on the pavement outside the Lantern Hostel. Petaling Street was awakening -- the vendors setting up their stalls, the morning market taking shape in its daily configuration of canvas and trestle and merchandise. The street smelled of fried dough and diesel and the chemical sweetness of the durian stall three doors down that was already unpacking its thorned cargo for the day's trade.

Priya stood in front of him. They were on the pavement where he had arrived forty-six days ago, dragging his own bag from the KTM station, looking up at the red lanterns and the pre-war facade and thinking *this'll do for a week*. The pavement where he had entered this story. The pavement where Priya was exiting it.

"The embassy," she said. "Today. Promise me."

"I promise."

"Not like last time. Not *five minutes* and then the rooftop. Today. Now. After I leave, you walk to the embassy and you--"

"I promise, Priya."

She searched his face. She searched it the way she searched diagnostic scans -- methodically, looking for the signs that indicated truth or its absence, the microexpressions that the face produced when the mouth and the mind were not in agreement. She was a medical student. She knew how to read bodies. She had been reading Connor's body for five weeks, and the reading had been consistent: the body said one thing and the person said another, and the gap between the body's truth and the person's words was the gap that Felix exploited, that the machine maintained, that the denial required.

This morning, the gap was smaller. Not closed -- the gap might never close, might be a permanent feature of Connor Briggs's architecture, the structural flaw in the building that could not be repaired but only reinforced. But the gap was smaller. The words and the body were closer to alignment than they had been at any point since Day 6, since the first envelope, since the beginning of the long walk into the forest.

"I believe you," she said.

She believed him the way a doctor believed a patient who said they'd take their medication. Not with certainty. Not with the trust that comes from evidence. But with the qualified, hopeful, professionally calibrated belief of a person who had done everything in her power and was now transferring the outcome to the patient, the way all caregivers eventually transferred the outcome, the way all people who loved people eventually stepped back and let the loved one choose.

She kissed him. The kiss was long. The kiss was the kind of kiss that people gave at airports and train stations and hospital beds and any place where departure was real and the return was uncertain. The kiss compressed everything -- every hawker stall, every night market, every rooftop sunset, every argument, every morning, every conversation about the law she'd printed and the card he hadn't used and the life they might have had if the variables had been different, if the hostel had been different, if the man in the common room had been a photographer instead of a handler.

The kiss ended.

Priya got into the Grab. The door closed. The window was down and she looked at Connor through the opening and her eyes were wet and her face was the face of a woman who was leaving a burning building because staying would kill her too and the leaving was not abandonment but survival and survival was the thing she had asked Connor to choose and the asking was the last thing she could do.

"Embassy," she said. One word. The word was a command and a prayer and a diagnosis all at once.

The car pulled away. The Proton Saga joined the morning traffic on Petaling Street, threading between the market stalls and the delivery vans and the motorcycles, the red suitcase in the boot growing smaller as the car moved away, and Priya's face in the window growing smaller, and the hand she raised growing smaller, and then the car turned onto Jalan Sultan and was gone.

Connor stood on the pavement. The vendors worked around him. A man carrying a box of counterfeit handbags brushed past. A motorcycle horn blared. The durian stall's fragrance intensified as the morning heat began its work.

He was alone.

Not alone the way he'd been alone in the first week, when aloneness was a choice and a pose, the solitary traveler performing his solitude for an imagined audience. This aloneness was different. This was the aloneness of a man who had been stripped of everyone who might save him -- Priya gone to London, Jake gone to Langkawi, Tomoko's camera stolen, Ahmad's phone ringing to voicemail, his parents in a kitchen in Hawthorn that might as well have been on a different planet. This aloneness was structural. This aloneness was the building's gift, the hostel's contribution to the project of isolation that Felix had been engineering since the first evening in the common room.

He stood on the pavement for three minutes. Three minutes in which the morning moved around him and the city continued and the choice was still available -- the embassy was seven kilometres away, a thirty-minute Grab ride, a walk through security, a conversation with a consular official who would listen and act and connect him to Ahmad and to the system that might, if Priya's research was correct, distinguish between a mule and a dealer, between fifty grams and four hundred and fifty grams, between death and life.

The embassy was available. The embassy was open. The embassy was waiting.

Connor turned and walked back into the Lantern Hostel.

---

He told himself he was going to get his passport. The embassy would need his passport. He was going upstairs to get his passport from the locker under Bed 7 and then he was going to the embassy. That was the plan. That was what he was doing.

He climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked. The second-floor landing was empty. The Japanese characters watched from under their paint. Dorm 3's door was ajar.

He pushed it open. The dorm was empty -- the transient population of backpackers who had occupied the other beds were out, exploring, living the lives that travellers lived, the lives that Connor had lived for twelve countries and seven months before the thirteenth country and the sixth week changed the category of his existence from *living* to *surviving*.

Bed 7. His bed. The thin mattress. The vinyl surface. The blue towel on the pillow. The wooden frame with LENA carved into the underside of the rail -- the name he'd been sleeping on for forty-six days, the name of the woman who had done what he was doing and ended where he was going.

He opened the locker. His passport was there -- the navy blue Australian passport with the coat of arms on the front, the kangaroo and the emu facing each other across the shield, the animals that couldn't walk backwards, the national symbol that was also, he realised with a clarity that felt like being hit, a description of his situation. Connor Briggs could not walk backwards. Connor Briggs could only go forward, and forward was the suitcase and the bus and the checkpoint.

He held the passport. He could leave now. Walk downstairs, out the door, into a Grab, to the embassy. The passport was in his hand. The embassy was waiting. Priya was in the air, or in a departure lounge, or at a gate, and the letter was in her bag, and the letter was his lifeline, and the lifeline required his cooperation, and his cooperation required his legs to carry him down the staircase and out the door and away from the hostel, away from Felix, away from the machine.

His burner phone buzzed.

The vibration came through the pocket of his board shorts, through the fabric, into his thigh, into the nerve endings that had been conditioned -- over five weeks, over fourteen deliveries, over the Pavlovian training of instruction followed by compliance followed by payment -- to respond to the vibration with attention. The phone was a leash. The phone had always been a leash. The leash vibrated and the dog turned.

He took the phone out.

*Details for today. Come to my room. 10 AM.*

The message was from the number. The number that was Felix. The number that was the network. The number that was the system that had recruited him and used him and was now, in the final act, consuming him.

Ten AM. Seventy minutes from now.

Connor put the passport back in the locker. He sat on Bed 7. He held the burner phone in one hand and the real phone in the other -- the two phones, the two identities, the two lives that had been running in parallel since Day 15 and were about to converge.

He could still go to the embassy. Ten AM was seventy minutes away. The embassy was thirty minutes by Grab. He could be there and back. He could be there and not come back. He could be there, and the *there* would become a different kind of *here*, a *here* that included a consular official and a phone call to Ahmad and the beginning of a process that was terrifying but survivable.

He sat on the bed. He held the phones. The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.*

At nine fifty-eight, he stood up. He put the burner phone in his left pocket. He put the real phone in his right pocket. He put his passport back in the locker. He locked the locker. He left the dorm.

He climbed the staircase. Not down, toward the door, toward the Grab, toward the embassy. Up. Toward the third floor. Toward Felix's room. Toward the suitcase.

The third step squeaked. The building noted his direction. The building had been noting his direction since Day 1, since the first ascent with a backpack and a confidence that had been eroded, delivery by delivery, into the thing that replaced confidence when confidence was gone, which was momentum -- the pure, directionless, physical fact of a body in motion that continued in motion because stopping required a force and there was no force left, no Priya in the common room, no Jake on the rooftop, no Ahmad on the phone, no force except the gravity of what Felix had built, the gravity that pulled Connor upward, toward the third floor, toward the room where a suitcase waited with four hundred and fifty grams of methamphetamine in its lining and a ticket to Penang in its pocket.

He reached the third-floor landing. Felix's door was at the end of the corridor. The door was closed. Behind the door, the German waited. Behind the door, the suitcase waited. Behind the door, the rest of Connor's life waited -- however much of it remained.

He knocked.

The door opened.

---

The common room was empty when Mei Ling came to clean it at eleven. She wiped the counter. She straightened the magazines. She checked the TV remote batteries. She did the things that receptionists did in hostels that had been functioning for ninety-seven years, the routine maintenance of a building that required constant attention because constant attention was what kept entropy at bay.

She paused at the sofa where Connor and Priya had sat. The cushions were still depressed -- the two depressions, side by side, the ghosts of two bodies that had occupied the space an hour ago and left behind only the physics of their weight. She straightened the cushions. The depressions disappeared. The sofa returned to its neutral state, ready for the next bodies, the next conversations, the next goodbyes.

On the reception desk, Priya's checkout form was in the completed pile. Room 4D. Priya Sharma. British. Checked out 09:00, 46th day of stay. Next destination: London Heathrow. No forwarding address. No review left on the guestbook.

Mei Ling filed the form. She opened the booking system on the old desktop computer. Bed 4D was now available. She changed the status to VACANT. By tonight, a new backpacker would be in that bed -- a gap year student, a digital nomad, a solo traveller with a guidebook and a sense of adventure and no idea that the building they were sleeping in was a system, and the system had inputs and outputs, and the outputs were checked-out guests and empty beds and the silence that occupied the space where a person used to be.

She looked toward the staircase. Connor had gone up, not down. She had seen him. She had been at her desk, filing the morning's checkout forms, and she had seen him walk past the reception counter and turn not left, toward the front door, but right, toward the staircase, and climb not to the second floor where his dorm was but to the third floor where Felix's room was, and the climbing was the direction she had been afraid of, the direction that every sign she'd posted and every warning she'd delivered had tried to prevent, the direction that meant the next form she filed for Connor Briggs would not be a checkout form but something else, something that arrived on official letterhead with a police crest and a reference number and the specific, bureaucratic language of a system that processed humans the way conveyor belts processed packages.

She closed the booking system. She picked up the phone. She dialled a number -- not the police, not the embassy, but the number of a man she had known for twenty years, a man who owned the building, a man who had hung a map of deaths on his office wall and watched the pins accumulate.

"Uncle Razak," she said. "Connor went upstairs. To Felix's room. The girl has left."

A pause on the line. The pause of a man receiving information he expected but hoped would not arrive.

"The girl sent a letter," Mei Ling said. "I heard her talking about it. A letter to the police. From London."

Another pause. Longer.

"How long?" Razak asked.

"She said she'd send it when she landed. Her flight is at eleven thirty. She lands in London at--" Mei Ling calculated -- "six AM tomorrow, London time. One PM our time."

"So we have until tomorrow afternoon."

"We have until tomorrow afternoon."

The line was quiet. The hostel was quiet. Somewhere on the third floor, a door opened and closed and the sound travelled through the building's bones -- through the plaster and the timber and the ninety-seven-year-old structure that had been absorbing sounds since the British colonial era -- and the sound reached Mei Ling's ears and she registered it the way she registered every sound in the building, which was with the total, involuntary attention of a woman who lived inside a machine and could not stop listening.

"I'll talk to him," Razak said.

"You've talked to him."

"I'll talk to Felix."

The name -- *Felix* -- sat in the telephone line between them, heavy, electric, the name of the man who had broken the hostel's unwritten rule, the man who had used the building as a base of operations, the man who had taken Uncle Razak's tolerance -- the tolerance that allowed certain activities as long as they remained invisible, as long as the guests remained safe, as long as the building's name remained clean -- and exceeded it, pushed past it, turned the tolerance into complicity and the complicity into guilt.

"Be careful," Mei Ling said.

She hung up. She straightened the reception desk. She aligned the pens. She checked the guest register. She did the things that receptionists did, and the doing was a form of control, and the control was the only thing she had in a building that was accelerating toward something she could feel but not stop, something that moved through the corridors and the staircases and the air well with the silent, inevitable momentum of water finding its level.

The ceiling fan turned in the common room. The red lanterns glowed. The building breathed.

Priya's plane was on the tarmac at KLIA2, loading passengers, preparing for the eleven-hour flight to Heathrow. In the cabin, in seat 34A, a woman with a jade bracelet and a red suitcase and a letter in her bag was looking out the window at the Malaysian landscape -- the palm oil plantations and the construction cranes and the haze that hung over everything like a gauze, like a filter, like the thing that made distance beautiful and proximity unbearable.

She was thinking about Connor. She was thinking about whether *okay* meant *okay* this time. She was thinking about the letter in her bag and the hours between now and London and the things that could happen in those hours in a hostel on Petaling Street where a man she loved was climbing a staircase toward a door behind which his life was being decided by someone who had never cared whether he lived or died.

The plane began to taxi. The engines rose in pitch. The runway appeared through the window, long and grey and straight, the kind of line that existed in only two places: airports and corridors that had no turns.

The plane lifted.

Priya was gone.

---

At eleven thirty-two, as the AirAsia flight to London climbed through seven thousand feet and the Strait of Malacca appeared below as a sheet of hammered silver, Connor Briggs was sitting in Felix Decker's room on the third floor of the Lantern Hostel, looking at a suitcase.

The suitcase was black. Mid-size. Hard-shell. The brand was a Malaysian brand -- a name Connor didn't recognise, the kind of suitcase you bought at a market stall for RM150, the kind that looked like every other suitcase in every other bus luggage compartment in every other transport hub in Southeast Asia. The suitcase was anonymous. The suitcase was designed to be anonymous. The anonymity was the point.

Felix had placed it on the bed -- his bed, the single bed in the private room, the room that cost RM120 per night and had its own bathroom and a window that overlooked the alley and a door with a lock that actually worked. The suitcase lay on the bedspread like a patient on an operating table, its surface catching the overhead light, the black shell reflecting the fluorescent tube in a long, distorted streak.

"Tomorrow," Felix said. "Eight AM bus from TBS -- Terminal Bersepadu Selatan. KL to Penang. Five-hour journey. The bus stops once, at Tapah, for fifteen minutes. The suitcase goes in the luggage compartment. You sit in the bus. You don't touch the suitcase until Penang."

Connor looked at the suitcase. The suitcase looked back. Not literally -- suitcases did not have eyes, did not have intentions, did not participate in the moral calculations of the humans who carried them. But the suitcase occupied the room with the density of an object that knew what it contained, the way a loaded gun occupied a room differently from an unloaded one, the weight of potential changing the atmosphere around it.

"In Penang, you take a Grab to a guesthouse in George Town. I'll give you the address. You check in. A man will come to the guesthouse at three PM. You give him the suitcase. He gives you an envelope. RM10,000. You take the bus back to KL. And you're done."

"Done," Connor repeated.

"Done. Free. No more phones, no more drops, no more schedule. The footage stays where it is. The records stay where they are. You go to Langkawi, to Bali, to wherever. Back to Melbourne if you want. You're done."

Felix's voice was calm, professional, the voice of a man concluding a business arrangement, the voice that had been calibrated -- through years of recruiting mules in hostels across Southeast Asia, through Lena and the mules before Lena and the mules who would come after Connor -- to deliver the final briefing with authority and reassurance braided together, the two strands indistinguishable. The authority said: *this is happening*. The reassurance said: *and then it's over*.

"What's in the suitcase?" Connor said.

The question was ceremonial. He knew what was in the suitcase. He had known since the rooftop. He had known since the charger box at Wei's. He had known, if he was honest with the honesty that had arrived five weeks too late, since the first envelope. The question was not a question but a ritual -- the last act of the machine, the denial machine, the machine that had run for five weeks on the fuel of *I don't know for certain* and was now running on fumes, on vapour, on the final wisps of a fiction that had been sustaining him since Day 6.

Felix looked at him. Felix's expression was patient -- the patience of a man who had answered this question before, from other mouths, in other rooms, in other hostels in other cities. The question was part of the script. The answer was part of the script. The script had been written by the network and performed by the network and the network had been performing it for years and would continue performing it after Connor was gone.

"Four hundred and fifty grams of methamphetamine," Felix said. "Sealed in vacuum bags, sewn into the lining of the suitcase. The suitcase will pass a visual inspection. It will pass an X-ray -- the bags are layered between the shell and the fabric lining, the density is consistent with the shell's polymer. It will not pass a dog."

*It will not pass a dog.*

The sentence arrived in Connor's mind and detonated there with the quiet force of a fact that contained its own consequence. The suitcase would pass a visual inspection and an X-ray but would not pass a dog. The sentence meant: if there is a dog at the checkpoint, you are dead. The sentence meant: your life depends on the absence of a dog. The sentence meant: the distance between living and dying is the distance between a bus that is stopped and inspected by an officer with a dog and a bus that is waved through by an officer without one.

"How many checkpoints?" Connor said.

"Usually one. Sometimes none. The North-South Expressway has random checkpoints -- PDRM sets them up on a rotating schedule. Fridays are usually quiet. That's why we're going Friday."

"Usually."

"Usually."

The word *usually* was the margin. The word *usually* was the space between survival and execution. The word *usually* was the width of the plank that Connor was being asked to walk, and the width was determined not by Felix or by Connor but by the Royal Malaysia Police and their deployment schedule and the dogs that the dogs' handlers decided to bring or not bring on a Friday morning on the North-South Expressway between Kuala Lumpur and Penang.

Connor sat in Felix's room and looked at the suitcase and the suitcase was black and mid-size and anonymous and inside it, in the lining, in the vacuum-sealed bags that Wei had sealed in the back room of the phone repair shop, was the substance that Malaysian law considered sufficient to warrant the killing of the person who carried it. The substance was 450 grams. The threshold was 50. The ratio was nine to one. Connor was carrying nine times the amount required to trigger the mandatory death penalty.

Nine to one. Those were not odds. Those were a measurement of how far past the line he had gone, how deep into the territory of irreversible consequence he had travelled. The line was at fifty grams and he was at four hundred and fifty and the distance between them was the distance that separated a prison sentence from a death sentence, a courtroom from a gallows, a life from no life.

"I'll send you the bus ticket tonight," Felix said. "The Grab to TBS leaves at seven-fifteen. The suitcase stays in my room until tomorrow morning. You pick it up at seven. You carry it downstairs. You get in the car. You go."

Connor nodded. The nod was the agreement. The nod was the contract. The nod was the final motion of a man who had been nodding for five weeks -- nodding to envelopes, nodding to packages, nodding to backpacks, nodding to charger boxes -- and the nodding had become the only language he spoke, the language of compliance, the vocabulary of a man who had forgotten how to say no because the machine had removed the word from his dictionary, had replaced it with *yeah* and *sure* and *no worries* and the Australian casualness that was also, it turned out, the perfect language for a drug mule, the language that treated everything as minor, that treated death as an inconvenience, that treated the end of a life as something that would sort itself out.

He left Felix's room. He descended the staircase. The third step squeaked. The common room was empty. The sofa cushions were flat -- Mei Ling had straightened them, erasing the impression of two bodies that had sat there an hour ago, one of them now at seven thousand feet and climbing, the other descending.

Connor went to Bed 7. He lay down. He pulled the blue towel over his chest. The towel was smooth and cool, the microfiber that had been to twelve countries and would go to one more -- not as luggage but as evidence, not as comfort but as instrument, the blue fabric that would be present at the end of something that was already ending.

The ceiling fan turned.

*Tick, tick, tick.*

Tomorrow.
# Chapter 29: Running

At three PM on Day 46, Connor Briggs left the Lantern Hostel with his passport in one pocket and RM2,400 in cash in the other and the intention to reach the Thai border before sunrise.

The plan -- if the frantic, half-formed series of decisions that had assembled themselves in the ninety minutes between Felix's room and this moment could be called a plan -- was this: KTM train from KL Sentral to Padang Besar, the border town where the railway crossed from Malaysia into Thailand. The journey was approximately eight hours. If he left now, at three, he'd arrive at Padang Besar by eleven PM. Cross the border on foot -- the land crossing was open until midnight, and the passport control was, according to a blog post he'd found on his phone while sitting on Bed 7 staring at the ceiling, relatively casual on the Malaysian side. Walk into Thailand. Take a bus to Hat Yai. From Hat Yai, another bus to Bangkok. From Bangkok, the Australian Embassy. From the embassy, a flight home. From home, safety.

The plan had the architecture of a fantasy -- each step logical in isolation, the chain of them held together by the same wishful engineering that held together the plans of every desperate person who had ever looked at a map and seen escape as a function of geography rather than circumstance. The plan assumed that Felix did not have contacts at the train station. The plan assumed that the police did not have his name. The plan assumed that the border crossing at Padang Besar was not monitored by the network that Felix operated within, the network that moved methamphetamine between Malaysian cities and had the operational reach to place a man named Rizal in a prison cell at the appropriate time.

The plan assumed many things. Connor was aware of this. He was aware of the plan's fragility in the way that a man climbing a ladder is aware that the ladder is leaning against nothing -- he could feel the wobble, could sense the absence of structural support, could hear the ladder's announcement of its own inadequacy in every creak and shift. But the alternative was the suitcase. The alternative was the eight AM bus to Penang tomorrow morning, the black hard-shell case in the luggage compartment, the five-hour journey through a country that had written his death into its statute books in the specific, unambiguous language of Section 39B, Subsection 2, Dangerous Drugs Act 1952.

The ladder was better than the fall.

---

He walked to KL Sentral. He didn't take a Grab. Taking a Grab left a digital record -- the pickup address, the destination, the timestamp -- and the digital record was evidence, and evidence was the currency that Felix traded in, and Connor had been generating evidence for five weeks with the prodigal generosity of a man who didn't understand the value of what he was giving away.

The walk took forty minutes. Petaling Street to Jalan Sultan, Jalan Sultan to Jalan Tun Tan Cheng Lock, through the covered pedestrian bridge past Pasar Seni, and then the long straight approach to KL Sentral along Jalan Tun Sambanthan, the road that cut through Brickfields -- Little India, where Connor had delivered a package on Day 9, a package that had been heavier than phone accessories, a package that he'd carried through streets that smelled of incense and jasmine and the spices of a neighbourhood that had existed since before the railway and would exist after everyone currently walking its pavements was gone.

The walk was hot. The afternoon heat of KL was a specific kind of hot -- not the dry heat of desert but the humid heat of a city built on a river confluence at three degrees north of the equator, the heat that saturated the air with moisture and turned every surface into a conductor and every step into a negotiation between the body's desire to cool and the atmosphere's refusal to cooperate. Connor sweated. The sweat ran from his hairline into his eyes, from his armpits into the fabric of his grey T-shirt, from the small of his back into the waistband of his board shorts. The sweating was excessive, even for KL -- the excess was the body's commentary on the situation, the physiological expression of the fear that the mind was trying to contain.

He walked through Brickfields. The Indian shops were open -- the flower garlands hanging in doorways, the banana leaf restaurants preparing for the dinner service, the jewellery shops with their gold in glass cases. A temple bell rang somewhere. The sound was clear and high and lasted longer than it should have, the way temple bells did in neighbourhoods where the buildings were old and the acoustics were shaped by decades of sound bouncing off plaster and stone.

He reached KL Sentral at three fifty. The station was a glass and steel cathedral of transit -- the main hub of KL's rail network, the building where KTM, LRT, monorail, and KLIA Transit converged in a nexus of escalators and platforms and the smell of metal and rubber and the collective anticipation of thousands of people going somewhere. The station was busy. The afternoon crowd was a mix of commuters and travellers, the commuters moving with the purposeful efficiency of people who knew where they were going, the travellers moving with the distracted uncertainty of people who didn't.

Connor was neither commuter nor traveller. Connor was a man running, and the running was visible in the way that running was always visible, even when the legs walked -- in the eyes, which moved too quickly, scanning for threats; in the posture, which was simultaneously rigid and hunched, the body trying to be both alert and invisible; in the hands, which checked the passport pocket every thirty seconds with the compulsive regularity of an anxiety that had found a physical expression.

He found the KTM ticket counter. The counter was on the ground floor, next to a 7-Eleven and a currency exchange. The queue was short -- four people ahead of him, two Malay women with shopping bags, a Chinese man in a business suit, an Indian family with two children. The children were arguing about something, their voices sharp and clear in the station's acoustic space, and the argument was about a toy or a seat or the kind of thing that children argued about when the world was still small enough that a toy or a seat could be the most important thing in it.

Connor waited. The queue moved. The ticket counter was manned by a woman in a KTM uniform -- blue shirt, name badge, the neutral expression of a person who had been selling train tickets for long enough that the act had become autonomous, the fingers moving on the keyboard without the mind's participation.

He reached the counter.

"One ticket to Padang Besar, please. Tonight."

The woman typed. The screen reflected in her glasses. She frowned -- a small frown, the kind produced by data rather than emotion.

"Padang Besar. Tonight. The next train is the 6:15 PM ETS -- Electric Train Service. Arrives Padang Besar at 11:47 PM."

"Yes. That one."

She typed more. The frown deepened.

"Coach A is full. Coach B has..." She paused. "One seat. Window. RM74."

"I'll take it."

She looked up. The look was brief -- the professional assessment of a ticket seller evaluating a customer -- and the assessment took in Connor's face, which was sunburnt and tired and carrying the specific quality of a face that had not slept properly in several days, and his clothes, which were the clothes of a backpacker, which was normal in KL Sentral, which was full of backpackers, and his demeanour, which was the demeanour of a man trying very hard to appear normal and thereby appearing the precise opposite of normal.

"Passport," she said.

Connor handed over his passport. The navy blue Australian passport with the kangaroo and the emu. She scanned the photo page. She typed the number into the system. The system processed the number. The system did whatever systems did with passport numbers -- checked them against databases, flagged them against watchlists, compared them to the lists that existed in the servers of the Royal Malaysia Police and the immigration department and the agencies that monitored the movement of foreign nationals through a country that took the monitoring seriously.

The system processed. Connor waited. The waiting was ten seconds. The ten seconds lasted a year.

"RM74," the woman said.

Connor paid in cash. She printed the ticket. She handed it to him with the passport. The ticket was a small rectangle of thermal paper with the route -- KUALA LUMPUR SENTRAL  PADANG BESAR -- and the time -- 18:15  23:47 -- and the coach and seat -- B, 14A -- and the date -- today.

He had a ticket. He had a passport. He had RM2,326 remaining. He had two hours and fifteen minutes until the train departed.

He should have felt relief. The ticket was the exit. The ticket was the door that Priya had been trying to push him toward for five weeks -- not the embassy, not the police, not the courtroom, but the simpler exit, the physical exit, the putting-distance-between-yourself-and-the-danger exit. The ticket was a seat on a train that would carry him away from Felix and the suitcase and the bus to Penang and the checkpoint with or without a dog.

He didn't feel relief. He felt the opposite of relief, which was not dread exactly but the specific, paradoxical anxiety of a person who has committed to an escape and is now more afraid than they were before the commitment, because before the commitment the escape was theoretical and theories don't generate adrenaline, but after the commitment the escape was real and reality generated adrenaline in quantities that the body was not designed to process.

He found a bench. He sat. He held the ticket. He checked his phone -- the real phone, not the burner. No messages. No calls. Priya was in the air. His mother's last text was still on the screen: *Hi darling! So glad to hear from you.*

He looked at the departures board. The 6:15 ETS to Padang Besar was listed. Track 3. On time.

Two hours.

---

At four twenty, a man sat down beside him.

The man was Malay. Forties. Stocky, with the broad shoulders and thick neck of a man who had been physically powerful in his twenties and had maintained some of that power through his thirties and forties by means that were not gym memberships. He wore a black T-shirt and jeans and sneakers and a watch that was either an expensive fake or an inexpensive original and the distinction didn't matter because the watch's function was not timekeeping but display -- the display of a man who wanted other men to see his wrist and draw conclusions.

The man sat on the bench. He did not look at Connor. He looked at his phone. He scrolled. The scrolling was casual, unhurried, the scrolling of a man killing time.

Connor looked at him. The look was instinctive -- the evaluation of a nearby body, the threat assessment that the brain performed automatically in environments of stress. The man was not threatening. The man was sitting on a bench in a train station looking at his phone. The man was one of ten thousand men sitting on benches in KL at this moment, doing exactly this thing.

But the man was sitting close. Not inappropriately close -- the bench was long and there were no other seats available and the proximity was explained by the station's afternoon crowd. But close. Close enough that Connor could smell his cologne -- a sharp, chemical scent, the kind sold in small bottles at night market stalls, the kind that announced itself from a metre away and lingered in a space after the wearer had left.

The man scrolled. Connor held his ticket. The station moved around them.

At four twenty-seven, a second man sat on Connor's other side.

This man was younger. Late twenties. Chinese-Malaysian. Thin, wearing a white polo shirt and khaki trousers, the uniform of a man who worked in an office or wanted to look like he did. He carried a backpack -- not a travel backpack but a commuter backpack, small, nylon, the kind that held a laptop and a lunch container and nothing else.

The second man also looked at his phone. The second man also did not look at Connor. The two men on either side of Connor scrolled their phones in the specific, synchronised non-attention of men who were very much paying attention to the person between them.

Connor's body knew before his mind. The body's knowledge arrived as a sensation -- not a thought but a physical event, a tightening of the muscles across his shoulders and down his spine, the body's ancient response to encirclement, to the reduction of escape routes, to the geometry of two bodies positioned on either side of a third body in a way that was casual and deliberate and terrifying.

He looked left. The stocky man scrolled.

He looked right. The thin man scrolled.

He looked forward. The departures board showed the 6:15 to Padang Besar. Track 3. On time.

He could stand up. He could walk to the platform. He could board the train. The ticket was in his hand. The passport was in his pocket. The platform was fifty metres away, through the turnstiles, down the escalator, across the concourse. Fifty metres was thirty seconds of walking. Thirty seconds was nothing. Thirty seconds was the time it took to reach the platform and board a train that would carry him to the border and to Thailand and to safety.

He stood up.

The stocky man stood up. Not simultaneously -- a second later, the delay calculated to appear coincidental, the way a shadow's movement appeared coincidental to the body's, the shadow rising because the body rose, the relationship causal but denied.

Connor took a step. The thin man stood up. The same delay. The same coincidence.

Connor stopped.

He was standing in KL Sentral with a train ticket to freedom in his hand and two men flanking him like brackets around a word, and the word was his name, and the brackets were the network, and the network had known -- had known before Connor knew, before the plan formed, before the forty-minute walk through Brickfields and the ticket counter and the thermal paper rectangle that said PADANG BESAR. The network had known because the network monitored, because Wei's cameras recorded, because the hostel's geography funnelled all exits through a single door and the door was watched, and the watching was not a person standing and looking but a system that registered movement and reported deviation and dispatched response with the mechanical efficiency of a machine that had been built to prevent exactly this -- the mule's last-minute attempt to bolt.

The stocky man was on his left. One metre. The thin man was on his right. One metre. The geometry was symmetrical, professional, the spacing of men who had done this before and knew the distance that communicated control without attracting attention.

"Connor."

The voice came from behind him. The voice was Malay-accented English, male, calm. Not a voice he recognised. He turned.

A third man. Standing three metres back. Older than the other two -- fifties, grey at the temples, wearing a batik shirt in blue and green, the formal-casual attire of a man who occupied a position that allowed him to choose his own wardrobe. His face was unremarkable -- the kind of face that disappeared into crowds, that was designed by genetics or training or both to resist description, to be forgotten the moment you looked away.

"Felix asked me to give you a message," the man said.

The man reached into his pocket. Connor flinched -- the flinch of a body expecting a weapon, the flinch that the body produced without the mind's permission. But what the man produced was not a weapon. It was a phone. He held it up. The screen was facing Connor.

On the screen, a photo. The photo showed a living room -- Connor's parents' living room. The room he'd grown up in, in Hawthorn, Melbourne. The room with the cream leather sofa and the framed family photos on the mantelpiece and the bay window that looked onto the garden where his father had taught him to kick a football. The photo was recent -- taken through the bay window from outside, the glass reflecting the photographer's flash, the room visible through the reflection, and in the room, on the sofa, his mother. Karen Briggs. Sitting with a cup of tea. Watching television. The photo was taken from outside. From the garden. From the perspective of someone standing in his parents' garden in Hawthorn, Melbourne, at a distance of approximately three metres, looking through a window at his mother.

Connor's legs stopped working.

Not collapsed -- the legs didn't buckle, the knees didn't fail, the body didn't fall. The legs simply stopped. The signals from the brain that instructed the muscles to fire and the joints to flex and the body to move were interrupted, diverted, re-routed to a process that was larger and more urgent than locomotion, the process of absorbing the information that the photo contained.

Felix had someone at his parents' house. Felix had someone who knew where his parents lived, who had stood in their garden, who had photographed his mother through a window. Felix's network extended not just across KL and not just across Malaysia but across the world, to Melbourne, to Hawthorn, to the cream leather sofa where Karen Briggs sat with her tea unaware that a man with a phone was standing in her garden documenting her existence as leverage against her son, twelve thousand kilometres away, in a train station, holding a ticket to the Thai border.

"Felix says the bus is at eight AM tomorrow," the man said. His voice was conversational, pleasant almost, the voice of a man delivering a routine message. "He says you should go back to the hostel and get some rest. He says the train to Padang Besar is not part of the plan."

The man put the phone back in his pocket. He nodded -- a small, polite nod, the nod of a man concluding a business interaction. He turned and walked away. His batik shirt disappeared into the crowd. The stocky man and the thin man also walked away, in different directions, absorbed by the station's afternoon population, dissolved into the mass of commuters and travellers who were going somewhere because they could, because their destinations were chosen and their journeys were voluntary and their arrivals were not appointments with death.

Connor stood alone.

The ticket was in his hand. The train was at six fifteen. Track 3. Fifty metres. Thirty seconds.

His mother's face was in his mind. The cream sofa. The cup of tea. The bay window. The photographer in the garden.

He looked at the ticket. The thermal paper was slightly damp from his palm, the printing beginning to blur at the edges where the moisture met the ink. KUALA LUMPUR SENTRAL  PADANG BESAR. The route to freedom. The route to the Thai border. The route that Felix had anticipated and blocked, not with violence, not with physical restraint, but with a photograph -- a single photograph of a woman on a sofa, the most effective prison ever built, the prison of a son's love for his mother, the love that was the only thing in Connor's architecture that the machine had not processed, the one structural element that could not be rationalised or denied or ignored.

He tore the ticket in half. The two halves fell to the station's tiled floor. A cleaner in a yellow vest would find them later and sweep them into a dustpan and deposit them in a bin and the bin would be emptied into a truck and the truck would carry the ticket to a landfill and the ticket would decompose and the route it described -- Kuala Lumpur to Padang Besar, freedom to the border -- would disappear from the physical world, though it would remain in the KTM booking system as a no-show, a seat that was sold and not occupied, a ghost in the railway's data.

Connor walked back through KL Sentral. Past the ticket counter, past the 7-Eleven, past the currency exchange, past the families and the commuters and the travellers. Past the turnstiles. Past the glass doors. Into the afternoon heat of Brickfields, where the temple bell was still ringing or was ringing again, the sound clear and high and lasting longer than it should have.

He walked back to Petaling Street. The walk took forty minutes. The same route, reversed. The same heat, the same sweat, the same streets. But the walk was different now because the man walking was different -- the man who had walked to KL Sentral had been a man with a plan, a man with an exit, a man who believed that geography could solve what circumstance had created. The man walking back was a man without a plan, without an exit, a man who understood that the trap was not geographical but total, not located in a building or a city but in the network of leverage and surveillance and threat that Felix had built around him with the patience and precision of a man who had done this before and would do it again.

The walk back was the walk of a man returning to his cell.

---

The hostel was quiet when he arrived. The afternoon lull -- the time between checkout and the evening's social energy, the time when the building rested and the fans turned and the red lanterns glowed for no one. The common room was empty. The kitchen was clean. Mama Siti was gone -- her shift ended at two, and the kitchen became, in her absence, a space that was merely functional rather than alive, a room with appliances rather than a room with a cook, the difference being the difference between a house and a home.

Connor climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked. He reached the second-floor landing and stopped.

Uncle Razak was there.

Razak was standing in the corridor outside Dorm 3, leaning against the wall with the posture of a man who had been waiting. He wore his usual attire -- the batik shirt, the reading glasses pushed onto his forehead, the expression of a man who had seen more than he wanted to see and was now in the process of deciding how much of what he'd seen he was willing to act on.

"Connor."

"Uncle Razak."

Razak straightened. He was not a tall man -- five seven, five eight -- but he had the compressed authority of a man who owned the building and had owned it for seventeen years and the owning was not just a legal fact but a physical one, the building responding to his presence the way a ship responded to its captain, the creaks and settlings modulating, the atmosphere adjusting.

"Come," Razak said. "My office."

Connor followed. Razak's office was on the ground floor, behind reception, through a door that was usually locked. Connor had been in the office once -- on Day 11, when Razak had shown him the map, the red pins, the newspaper clippings, the collected record of deaths in hostels worldwide. The map of the dead.

The office was unchanged. The clippings covered the walls -- yellowed newspaper articles, printed web pages, handwritten notes. The map was on the far wall, the large world map with its red pins, each pin a death, each death a story, each story ending in the same place: a building designed for temporary occupancy, a guest who became permanent in the wrong way.

Razak closed the door. He sat behind his desk. The desk was covered in papers -- invoices, booking records, the administrative debris of a business that functioned on the border between hospitality and complicity.

"Sit," Razak said.

Connor sat. The chair was old -- wooden, the seat worn smooth by years of use.

"I know what Felix is asking you to do," Razak said.

The sentence was delivered without preamble, without the gradual approach that most people used when addressing difficult subjects, without the circumlocution and the euphemism and the careful, cowardly navigation of uncomfortable truths. Razak said it the way he said everything -- directly, with the economy of a man who had learned that indirect language was a luxury afforded to people who had time, and time was the one thing they did not have.

"I've known what Felix does since he arrived," Razak continued. "Eighteen months ago. He came to the hostel and he asked for a private room and he paid in cash and he stayed. Weeks. Months. He paid above rate. He was quiet, polite, clean. He didn't cause trouble. He didn't bring trouble into the building. Not at first."

Razak opened a drawer. He took out a folder -- Manila, worn, the kind of folder that contained documents someone had been collecting for a long time. He placed it on the desk.

"I made an arrangement with Felix. An arrangement I am not proud of. The arrangement was this: he could operate from the building as long as he followed rules. No drugs in the hostel. No recruitment of staff. No violence. No attention from the police. The hostel remained clean. The hostel's name remained clean. The guests remained safe."

He opened the folder. Inside: papers, photographs, printouts. Connor could see the edge of a photograph -- a woman, young, blonde, the partial image of a face he didn't recognise.

"The arrangement held for a year. And then Felix started recruiting guests."

Razak's voice changed -- not louder, not angrier, but thicker, heavier, the voice acquiring the weight of something that had been carried for months and was now being set down.

"The first one was a girl from Sweden. Lena. Twenty-two. She was in Bed 7. Your bed."

Connor's body went still. The stillness was not the stillness of calm but the stillness of collision -- the body's response to the impact of information that confirmed what he already knew but had not heard spoken aloud by someone who was not Felix, not Priya, not himself.

"Lena stayed for six weeks. She carried packages for Felix. The same packages you carry. The same routes, the same contacts, the same schedule. She was arrested at the border crossing at Bukit Kayu Hitam, near the Thai border. She had two hundred grams of methamphetamine in a bag. She is now in Kajang Prison. She is awaiting trial. The charge is trafficking. The sentence, if convicted, is death."

Razak paused. The pause was not dramatic but necessary -- the pause of a man who needed to breathe before continuing, the pause of a body managing the physical cost of speaking the truth.

"I did nothing. When Lena was arrested, I did nothing. I told myself that the arrangement was still in place, that Felix had broken the rules, that I would end the arrangement. But I didn't end it. Felix paid. The hostel needed the money. I needed the money. And so the arrangement continued, and Felix recruited another mule -- not from this hostel, from another building, a guesthouse in Bukit Bintang -- and the mule was arrested and the mule is also in Kajang and the arrangement continued because the arrangement was easier than the alternative and the alternative was the police and the police would ask questions about the arrangement and the questions would lead to answers that would end me."

He looked at Connor. The look was not the flat assessment of previous encounters -- not the ex-businessman's calculating gaze, not the hostel owner's professional evaluation. The look was something else. Something older. Something that might, in a man who was less damaged by his own complicity, have been called shame.

"And now you," Razak said. "And now a suitcase. And now I am sitting in my office looking at the next pin on my map and the pin is a twenty-seven-year-old Australian in my building and the pin is tomorrow unless someone does something and the someone is me because there is no one else."

"What can you do?" Connor said.

"I can call the police."

"Felix has the footage. My fingerprints. My--"

"I know what Felix has. I also know what Felix doesn't have. Felix doesn't have a cooperative witness. Felix doesn't have a hostel owner willing to testify about an eighteen-month arrangement. Felix doesn't have Mei Ling's records -- the checkout forms, the booking logs, the dates that match Felix's tenancy with the arrests of mules from this address. Felix doesn't have Tomoko's photographs -- and yes, I know about the photographs, and I know Felix stole the camera, and I know the photographs are backed up to a cloud server because Tomoko told me so three weeks ago."

The information arrived in Connor's mind like a sequence of lights turning on in a dark building -- each fact illuminating a space he hadn't known existed, each fact revealing that the building around him was larger and more complex than the single corridor he'd been walking, that there were other rooms, other people, other stories running parallel to his.

"Tomoko backed up the photos."

"Tomoko is a journalist. Journalists back up everything. The camera was bait -- she let Felix take it because the camera was empty. The real photographs are on a server in Tokyo. She's been waiting to use them."

"Waiting for what?"

"Waiting for someone to cooperate. Photographs without testimony are evidence but not a story. A story requires a voice. Tomoko needs a voice."

"My voice."

"Your voice."

Connor sat in the old wooden chair in Razak's office and looked at the map on the wall and the pins that marked the dead and the space on the map where Kuala Lumpur was, where the pin for the Lantern Hostel would go, where his name would join the list of guests who checked in and never checked out.

"If I cooperate," Connor said. "If I go to the police, or to Ahmad, or to the embassy. Felix has someone in Melbourne. At my parents' house. He showed me a photograph of my mother."

Razak's expression did not change. The information about Melbourne, about the photograph, about the network's reach into Connor's family home -- the information was received and processed by a man who had learned, over eighteen months of the arrangement, to not be surprised by Felix's capabilities.

"Felix's network is not as large as Felix wants you to believe," Razak said. "A photograph through a window is not a man with a weapon. A camera in a garden is not an operation. Felix uses fear the way he uses money -- precisely, economically, at the exact amount required to achieve compliance. The photograph of your mother is not a threat to your mother. It's a threat to your perception. It's designed to make you believe that running is impossible and compliance is the only option."

"How do you know?"

"Because the same photograph was shown to Lena. And to the mule after Lena. The photograph changes -- different house, different parent, different window. The technique is the same. It's a tool. Like the burner phone. Like the CCTV footage. Like the money."

Connor sat with this. The information rearranged something in his mind -- not the fear, which remained, but the architecture of the fear, the structure that Felix had built around it. The structure was not a fortress. The structure was a stage set. The walls were not concrete but painted canvas. The locks were not steel but theatrical props. The fear was real but the infrastructure of the fear was performance -- Felix's most sophisticated product, more valuable than the methamphetamine, more carefully manufactured than the vacuum-sealed bags in Wei's back room.

"What do I do?" Connor said.

"Tomorrow morning. Before eight. Before the bus. You go to Dang Wangi. You ask for Sergeant Ahmad. You tell him everything. I will call Ahmad tonight and tell him you're coming. Tomoko will send her photographs to The Star newspaper at the same time. Mei Ling will provide the hostel records. And the letter that Priya is carrying to London will arrive as confirmation, not as the first report."

The plan was different from Priya's plan. Priya's plan had been the embassy -- the safe option, the diplomatic option, the option that placed Connor under the protection of his own country's bureaucracy. Razak's plan was the police -- the dangerous option, the option that placed Connor directly into the system that would charge him, the option that trusted Ahmad to be clean, to be competent, to be the officer that his business card said he was.

"Ahmad is clean," Razak said, reading Connor's face. "I've known Ahmad for fifteen years. He's Narcotics Division, Dang Wangi district. He's been watching Felix for six months. He doesn't have enough for an arrest -- Felix is careful, the evidence is on the mules, not on the handler. But a cooperating witness changes the calculus. A cooperating witness is the thing Ahmad needs."

"And if he's not clean?"

"Then we are all destroyed. You, me, Mei Ling, Tomoko. The building. Everything. If Ahmad is not clean, then the system is too broken for any of us to survive, and the question of whether you carry the suitcase or don't carry the suitcase is irrelevant because the system will find you either way."

The assessment was brutal and honest, delivered with the flat clarity of a man who had calculated the odds and accepted them. Razak was gambling -- gambling on Ahmad, gambling on the system, gambling on the possibility that the mechanism that had failed Lena might not fail Connor.

"Think about it," Razak said. "Tonight. You have until seven AM. After seven, Felix will give you the suitcase. After the suitcase, the options narrow. Before the suitcase, they're still open."

He stood. The conversation was over. The folder on the desk remained open -- the photographs, the documents, the collected evidence of eighteen months of complicity that Razak was now preparing to trade for something that might be redemption or might be destruction.

"One more thing," Razak said.

Connor looked at him.

"The name on your bed frame. Lena. She carved it with a coin. The night before her last delivery. She told me she wanted someone to know she'd been there."

The information was not new -- Connor had known about the name since the air well, since the night he'd sat on the tile bench and thought about carving his own name. But hearing it from Razak -- from the man who had let Lena sleep in Bed 7 and carry packages and be arrested and said nothing -- hearing it from the man who was trying to not let the same thing happen again -- the hearing was different from the knowing, the way testimony was different from suspicion, the way a spoken truth occupied a different space in the mind than an inferred one.

Connor left Razak's office. He climbed the staircase. The third step squeaked.

---

He lay in Bed 7. The dorm was empty. The afternoon light came through the air well, softer now, the tropical light beginning its evening descent from white to gold to the deep amber that preceded the dark. The ceiling fan turned. The name was under his palm on the bed frame. L-E-N-A.

Two options. Two doors.

Door one: the suitcase. Eight AM. The bus. The five-hour journey to Penang. The checkpoint that might have a dog. The delivery. The RM10,000. The freedom that Felix promised, which was not freedom but the extension of a leash, the lengthening of a chain that would remain attached no matter how far he walked.

Door two: Dang Wangi. Seven AM. Ahmad. The confession. The charge. The cell. The trial. The system that might distinguish between a mule and a dealer, or might not. The system that had killed Lena -- no, not killed, was killing, was in the process of killing, the legal system's particular form of slow killing, the killing that took months and years and appeals and the waiting was its own form of death.

Two doors. One led to a bus. One led to a police station. Both led to places where a blue travel towel would be irrelevant because the places he was going didn't have beaches or showers or the kind of morning that required a towel.

He closed his eyes. The ceiling fan turned. The name pressed against his palm.

Tomorrow. Seven AM or eight AM. Dang Wangi or TBS. Ahmad or the bus. The badge or the suitcase.

The countdown had reached its final digit.

*Tick.*
# Chapter 30: The Suitcase

The last night.

Connor knew it was the last night the way bodies know things that minds refuse to articulate -- not as a thought but as a condition, a state of being, the cellular recognition of finality that preceded the conscious acknowledgement of it the way thunder preceded rain. The body knew. The body had known for days. The body had been preparing for the last night with the quiet, autonomous efficiency of a system shutting down non-essential processes, redirecting resources to the core, the biological equivalent of a building turning off its lights floor by floor as the occupants left.

Day 46. Evening. The sun was setting over Kuala Lumpur with the operatic excess that tropical cities produced -- the sky turning shades of orange and red and purple that would have been dismissed as oversaturated if they'd appeared in a photograph but were, in person, simply the sky doing what the sky did at three degrees north of the equator, the light bending through the atmospheric moisture and the particulate haze and the collective exhalation of eight million lives and producing, at the horizon, a colour that had no name in English but that the Malays called *senja*, which meant dusk, which meant the time between day and night, which meant the time when the world was neither one thing nor the other.

Connor was on the rooftop.

He had come up here because the rooftop was where the story had started -- the rooftop where Felix had stood against the railing on the first night, silhouetted against the Petronas Towers, and said *I could use someone reliable around here*. The rooftop where Connor had sat in a plastic chair and felt the warmth of Felix's attention and mistaken it for friendship. The rooftop where, six weeks ago, a man with a scar on his eyebrow and a linen shirt and a German accent had looked at a broke, lonely Australian backpacker and seen raw material.

The plastic chair was still here. Connor sat in it. The chair was damp with humidity, the same humidity that had been on it the first night, the humidity that was KL's constant companion, the moisture that lived in the air the way fish lived in water -- not as a visitor but as a resident, permanent, inseparable from the medium it occupied.

The Petronas Towers were lit. Twin silver columns against the darkening sky, connected by the skybridge at the forty-first floor, the entire structure performing its nightly transformation from architecture into icon, from building into symbol, from steel and glass into the thing that appeared on postcards and screensavers and the Instagram feeds of a million travellers who had photographed it and captioned it and moved on.

Connor had photographed the towers on his second night. The photo was still on his Instagram -- @ConnorGoesGlobal, the account with 4,200 followers that he hadn't posted to in ten days because posting required the maintenance of a fiction and the fiction had collapsed, the fiction being that he was a content creator on a gap year rather than a drug mule on a countdown. The photo showed the towers at night, lit silver, the sky behind them the deep blue of a KL evening, and the caption read: *These two beauties tho. KL is UNREAL. #PetronasTowers #KualaLumpur #BackpackerLife #LivingTheDream*

Living the dream. He had written that forty-four days ago. The dream was over. The waking was here.

---

At seven PM, Mama Siti appeared on the rooftop.

This was unusual. Mama Siti's domain was the kitchen. She moved between the ground floor and the kitchen the way planets moved in orbits -- predictable, gravitational, defined by a force that was not physical but operational, the force of a woman who had been cooking in the same kitchen for thirty years and had established a territory that extended from the stove to the prep counter to the wash area and no further. The rooftop was not her territory. The rooftop was the territory of guests, of Felix, of the evenings that belonged to the building's transient population rather than its permanent staff.

But Mama Siti was here. She had climbed three flights of stairs -- the narrow, steep staircase that made her knees ache, the staircase that she usually sent younger staff to navigate, the staircase that the building had not been designed for but had acquired during one of its many renovations, the addition of a rooftop access that turned the building's highest point into a social space. She had climbed the stairs and pushed open the door and stepped onto the rooftop and the effort was visible in her breathing, in the slight rise and fall of her chest, in the careful way she placed her feet on the uneven surface.

She carried a plate. The plate held nasi lemak.

Not the morning nasi lemak, which was the standard version -- the coconut rice, the sambal, the ikan bilis, the cucumber, the egg. This was a different version. This was the version that Mama Siti made for occasions, for visits from family, for the Hari Raya celebrations that she prepared with weeks of advance planning. The rice was cooked with extra pandan leaves, the fragrance richer, deeper. The sambal was the special sambal -- the one with fresh-ground chilli and dried shrimp and the particular sweetness that came from palm sugar rather than white sugar. The ikan bilis were fried crisp. The egg was a perfect half-moon of fried egg, the edges lacy, the yolk still soft.

She placed the plate on the zinc table beside Connor's chair. She didn't speak. She stood beside the table with her hands folded in front of her apron and looked at Connor with the expression that she had been wearing since Day 1, the expression that had been there behind every plate of nasi lemak and every proverb and every silence -- the expression of a woman who knew.

"Thank you, Mama Siti," Connor said.

She nodded. The nod was small, economical, the gesture of a woman who conserved movement the way she conserved ingredients -- nothing wasted, everything measured, the minimum necessary to convey the maximum meaning.

She sat on the zinc railing's ledge. Not the chair -- the ledge, which was lower, which brought her closer to the rooftop's surface, which was the posture of a woman who intended to stay.

Connor ate. The nasi lemak was extraordinary. The rice was fragrant, the sambal burned with a heat that was complex rather than aggressive, the ikan bilis were salt and crunch, the egg was perfect. He ate and the food was the best thing he had tasted in six weeks and the tasting was the first time in days that his senses had operated at full capacity, the flavour breaking through the numbness that had insulated him from the physical world since the rooftop conversation with Felix, since the numbers, since the truth.

He ate slowly. He ate the way people ate when the eating was not just nutrition but ceremony -- the way families ate at Christmas, the way friends ate at farewell dinners, the way the condemned ate their last meal, savouring each bite because the bites were countable and the count was low.

Mama Siti watched him eat. Her eyes were dark and still and the stillness was not emptiness but depth, the stillness of water that was very deep, the stillness that concealed rather than revealed.

When he finished, she took the plate. She held it on her lap, the empty plate, the plate that still carried the ghost of the food that had been on it, the residue of coconut oil and sambal and the fragrance that would linger on the ceramic for hours.

"Dulu," she said, "ada seorang budak perempuan." *Once, there was a girl.*

Connor looked at her. Mama Siti's voice was different from her kitchen voice -- not louder but softer, more intimate, the voice of a woman telling a story rather than giving an instruction, the voice that she used for proverbs and the voice that she used for truths and the distinction between the two was smaller than most people realised.

"Dia tinggal di kampung di Perak. She lived in a village in Perak. She was young. She was clever. She wanted to go to the city -- to KL, to the lights, to the life that the village could not give her."

She paused. The pause was part of the story -- the Malay storytelling tradition in which pauses were not absences but presences, the silence between sentences carrying as much meaning as the sentences themselves.

"She came to the city. She found work. She found a room. She found a man who told her she was special, who told her he could help her, who gave her money and attention and the feeling of belonging. The man asked her to carry things. Small things. Envelopes. Then packages. Then bigger packages. The girl carried them because the man had been kind and because the money was good and because she was young and because the young believe that the world is a place where kindness is kindness and money is money and carrying is just carrying."

Connor's chest tightened. The story was not about a girl in a village. The story was about him. The story was about Lena. The story was about every person who had ever been recruited by someone who understood the mechanics of loneliness and the engineering of trust.

"The girl was caught," Mama Siti said. "She was caught at a roadblock on the road to Ipoh. The police found what she was carrying. She was arrested. She was charged. The man who had told her she was special was not there. The man had never been there -- not truly, not in the way that *there* meant being present for the consequence and not just the cause."

She looked at Connor. The look was direct, unfiltered, the look of a woman who had abandoned the indirection of proverbs and the obliqueness of kitchen wisdom and was now speaking in the clear, simple language of a truth that could not be softened.

"The girl is my niece. She is in Kajang Prison. She has been there for four years. Her name is not Lena. Her name is Nurul. And I cook nasi lemak in this hostel because this hostel is where the man who recruited her operated, and I cook here because cooking here is the only way I can watch, and watching is the only way I can try to prevent what happened to Nurul from happening to the next person who sleeps in Bed 7."

The information detonated in Connor's mind. Mama Siti was not a cook. Mama Siti was not a fixture. Mama Siti was a woman whose niece had been destroyed by the same system that was destroying Connor, and the cooking and the proverbs and the silence were not the habits of an eccentric old woman but the surveillance of a woman who had stationed herself at the intersection of the network and the building and was watching, always watching, for the next face that would appear in the kitchen with that hollowed-out look, the eyes going flat, the mouth forgetting how to smile -- the face of a person being consumed by something they couldn't name.

"You've been watching me since Day 1," Connor said.

"Since before Day 1. Since Felix returned. Since I heard he was recruiting again. Since the bed -- your bed, Nurul's bed, Lena's bed -- was occupied by a young foreigner who was broke and lonely and exactly the kind of person Felix looks for."

"Why didn't you tell me? On Day 1. Why didn't you say *the man in the private room is a drug trafficker who will use you and discard you*?"

"I told you. In every way I knew how. The proverbs. The silences. The way I looked at you when you came back from a delivery.
