He had not read any of the texts the world had written for him, the texts placed in his path with the frequency and urgency of a world trying desperately to communicate one piece of information: *this country will kill you for what you are doing.* And now he was in a room with nothing to read except the walls, and the walls said nothing, and the silence of the walls was the silence he had chosen -- the silence of a man who had been surrounded by information and had refused it all.

---

Ahmad.

The name surfaced suddenly -- Sergeant Ahmad bin Ismail, Narcotics Division, this building. Ahmad was here. His desk was somewhere on the other side of the locked doors and the corridors that separated cell C-7 from the offices where the narcotics officers did their work. The machine that had prevented Connor from speaking to Ahmad -- the machine that required denial to operate -- was gone. You could not deny what you were sitting inside. You could not rationalise a three-by-three-metre concrete room. He could speak now. He could say the simple sentence that would have changed everything: *My name is Connor Briggs. I've been carrying methamphetamine for Felix Decker.*

He went to the bars. "I need to speak to Sergeant Ahmad. Narcotics Division. He gave me his card. I have information about a trafficking network operating out of a hostel on Petaling Street. Names, locations, routes. I can cooperate."

The corporal appeared, unhurried.

"No, please -- this is important. Sergeant Ahmad knows about Felix Decker. He's been watching --"

"Sergeant Ahmad is not on duty tonight. Tomorrow."

Tomorrow. The word again. The concrete wall of the word. Connor returned to the bench. The towel had cooled against his shoulders, the microfiber releasing its warmth into the cell's air-conditioned atmosphere, the warmth leaving the fabric the way the warmth was leaving Connor's body, the slow, physical process of a warm thing becoming a cold thing in a cold environment.

He pulled the towel over his head. A hood. A tent. A cave. The towel's blue fabric blocked the blue-white buzz and the blue was the blue of the towel and not the blue-white of the tube and the difference mattered because the towel's blue was his blue, was the blue of the Andaman Sea and the Blue Mountains and the swimming pools and the beaches where the towel had been, the blue that was the colour of the life that had existed before the cell. Under the towel, in the small, dark, soft space that the fabric created, he could not see the cell. He could not see the bars or the wall or the squat toilet or the corridor. He could only see the blue of the towel and the dark beneath it and the dark was better than the light because the dark was chosen and the light was imposed and the difference between chosen and imposed was the difference between freedom and imprisonment, the difference that he was learning now, in the fluorescent hours, with the intimacy of a student whose education had been delayed but was now proceeding at the accelerated pace of total immersion.

Under the towel, he closed his eyes. Under the towel, in the dark, with his eyes closed, he could be anywhere. He could be in a hostel dorm. He could be on a beach. He could be in his childhood bedroom in Hawthorn with the cricket posters and the surfboard in the corner and the sound of his mother in the kitchen and the smell of whatever she was cooking and the certainty -- the absolute, unquestioned, foundational certainty -- that the world was safe and the world was his and the world would never, ever put him in a cell.

Under the towel, he breathed. The towel smelled of sunscreen and the sea. Under the towel, for a moment, the words stopped circling.

---

The call to prayer came from somewhere far away.

The muezzin's voice entered the cell the way water entered stone -- not through openings but through the material itself, through the concrete and the steel and the glass and the institutional architecture that was designed to keep sounds out but that could not keep out the sound of a human voice amplified by speakers mounted on a minaret and projected across the city by the power of a tradition that was older than the building, older than the law, older than the statute that had put Connor in this cell.

The voice was beautiful.

The beauty was not the beauty of performance. The muezzin was not singing for an audience. The muezzin was performing an obligation -- the adhan, the call, the summons to prayer that the Islamic tradition required five times daily and that the Malaysian mosques fulfilled with the particular, Malaysian expression of the adhan, the melodic line that was both Arabic and Malay, both universal and local, the voice rising and falling in the intervals that had been established fourteen centuries ago and had been repeated, with variations, every day since.

*Allahu Akbar. Allahu Akbar.*

The words reached the cell in fragments, the consonants and vowels scattered by the distance and the concrete, the voice arriving as more melody than language, more shape than substance, the muezzin's words broken into their musical components and reassembled by the cell's acoustics into something that was neither the original call nor a different call but a third thing, a cell-filtered version, the call to prayer as heard from inside a holding cell at Dang Wangi, the sound that was beautiful and terrible and completely indifferent to Connor's situation.

The indifference was the beauty's sharpest edge. The muezzin did not know Connor was in the cell. The muezzin did not know that his voice was reaching a twenty-seven-year-old Australian backpacker who had been arrested for drug trafficking and was sitting on a steel bench with a blue towel over his head. The muezzin was performing the adhan because the time for prayer had arrived and the adhan was performed when the time arrived, and the time arrived regardless of who was listening and regardless of where they were listening from and regardless of whether the listening was voluntary or involuntary, whether the listener was a believer at a mosque or a prisoner in a cell or a tourist on a rooftop or no one at all.

The call did not care. The call was, in its indifference, the purest expression of the truth that Connor's father had spoken at Tullamarine and that Connor had spent forty-seven days denying: *the rules don't care who you are.* The adhan was a rule. The adhan was a call that operated on its own schedule, by its own logic, for its own purposes, and the purposes did not include Connor Briggs. The purposes included the faithful, the community, the tradition, the God to whom the call was directed -- but not Connor. Connor was incidental. Connor was the accidental listener, the prisoner who happened to be within earshot, the man whose cell happened to be in a building that happened to be within range of a mosque that happened to be performing the obligation that it had performed every day for however many decades or centuries the mosque had existed.

The voice faded. The call ended. The silence returned -- not a full silence but the cell's version of silence, which was the fluorescent hum and the distant sounds of the building (a phone somewhere, a door closing, the mechanical rhythm of an institution operating through the evening) and Connor's breathing, which had slowed, which had returned to something approaching normal, the respiratory rate descending from the panic's peak to the lower, slower rhythm of a body that had exhausted its panic and was now in the phase that followed, the phase that was not calm but was the absence of acute distress, the plateau between the peaks, the flatland of endurance.

---

The fluorescent light never turned off.

The permanence was the horror. The switch was somewhere beyond the bars, in the territory of the people who controlled the cell and its conditions, and the institution had decided: light. Always. The light of surveillance, of the state's need to see what was in the cell at all times, the light that served not the prisoner's comfort but the institution's control. The light was the opposite of the ceiling fan in the hostel. The fan in Dorm 3 had moved -- blades cutting the warm air, producing wind and shadow and the rhythmic comfort of a machine working for you, its tick marking time, each revolution a unit of time passing toward morning and then afternoon and then night, and the night was dark and the dark was relief. The tube did not move. The tube produced a single, sustained, unwavering tone, the tone of a system in steady state, the tone of permanence. The fan had been in a place where time moved. The tube was in a place where time stopped -- no day, no night, just the light, always the light, the light that made every moment identical to every other moment. The light of consequence. The light of after.

Connor lay on the bench. The steel was cold beneath his shoulder blades. The towel was beneath his head, folded into a pillow, the microfiber providing a thin barrier between his skull and the steel, the barrier insufficient for comfort but sufficient for the idea of comfort, the idea that a pillow was present and that the presence of a pillow meant that this was a place where sleeping was possible, even if sleeping was not possible, even if the light was on and the hum was loud and the words were still circling -- mandatory, death, penalty -- the three birds that could not land.

He stared at the tube. The tube stared back. The tube was, in this moment, the most present thing in his existence -- more present than the walls, more present than the bars, more present than the distant sounds of the building or the fading memory of the muezzin's call. The tube was the cell's eye. The tube was the cell's voice. The tube was the cell's answer to every question, and the answer was always the same: *you are here, and here is lit, and the light is not for you.*

He thought about nothing. He tried to think about nothing. The trying was the failure -- the mind could not think about nothing because the mind's nature was to think, to process, to produce, and the mind's production in this cell was the words, always the words, the three words and their variants and their implications and their echoes. The words were not thoughts. The words were conditions. The words were the atmosphere. The words were the air he breathed, the light he saw, the hum he heard. The words were the cell.

The three words.

He had been in the cell for approximately two hours. The approximation was based on the pacing -- the circuits he had counted, the minutes he had derived, the time he had estimated with the imprecise mathematics of a man using his body as a measuring instrument. Two hours. Two hours of the flat white light. Two hours of the hum. Two hours of the three-by-three-metre world.

Two hours.

The night was long. The night was the distance between now and tomorrow. The night was the territory that he had to cross to reach the morning, to reach the embassy, to reach the lawyer, to reach Ahmad. The night was the desert that lay between the cell and the oasis, the lightless hours -- except the hours were not lightless, the hours were lit, perpetually lit, the fluorescent tube ensuring that the night would not be night but a continuation of the timeless, directionless, institutional light that was the cell's permanent condition.

He closed his eyes. The closing did not produce darkness. The closing produced the red-orange glow of light passing through eyelids, the tube's glare penetrating the thin skin and the blood vessels and reaching the retina even through the closed lids, the light refusing to be shut out, the light insisting on its presence, the light saying: *you cannot escape me. I am the condition. I am the cell. I am here.*

He pulled the towel over his face. The blue fabric dimmed the light. Under the towel, with his eyes closed, the light was finally reduced to a suggestion rather than a presence, the faintest glow of blue-filtered fluorescence, the minimum light, the almost-dark.

In the almost-dark, he waited.

---

A sound.

The sound was different from the sounds that had constituted the cell's acoustic environment for the past two hours -- different from the hum, different from the distant building sounds, different from his own breathing. The sound was specific, metallic, close. The sound was a key.

A key in a lock.

The sound of metal entering metal, of tumblers engaging, of a mechanism designed to open when the correct key was inserted and turned. The sound was at the cell door -- the barred door, the green-painted bars, the door that separated the cell from the corridor and the corridor from the world.

Connor sat up. The towel fell from his face. The fluorescent light hit him full -- the blue-white assault after the towel's blue shade, the tube reasserting its dominance, the cell snapping back into focus, every surface and every edge and every bar and every bolt and every stain and every crack in the concrete visible in the comprehensive, merciless illumination.

The key turned. The lock clicked. The door opened.

An officer stood in the corridor. Not the corporal from before -- a different officer, younger, the face unfamiliar, the uniform the same. The officer held the door open with one hand and with the other hand gestured into the corridor, where a second figure stood.

A man. Mid-thirties. Malay. Average height, average build, the build that was unremarkable in the specific way that made a person forgettable. He wore a dark red T-shirt, jeans, running shoes. His hair was short, neatly cut. His face was calm -- notably calm, the calm of a person who was where he expected to be, or who had decided to treat the situation with the equanimity that was either a personality trait or a performance.

The officer ushered the man into the cell. The door closed. The lock clicked. The footsteps receded.

The man surveyed the cell -- a quick inventory, eyes moving from wall to wall, bench to toilet, bars to tube. Then he looked at Connor. The look was brief, open, the look of a man acknowledging another man in a shared space. He smiled -- small, practiced, the minimum unit of human connection.

"Bar fight," he said, with a shrug that said *it's nothing, it's the kind of thing that happens to anyone on a Friday night*. The shrug was the body language of a man who had been in cells before, or who wanted Connor to believe he had.

He extended his hand.

"Rizal," he said.

The name entered the cell and the cell held it. The fluorescent light hummed. The night stretched ahead, unmeasured and immeasurable.

Connor looked at the hand -- open, extended, the universal gesture of greeting. He took it.

"Connor," he said.

And the cell, which had been a space for one, became a space for two.

---

*End of Chapter 33*
# Chapter 34: Rizal

Four hours in Cell C-7 and Connor had spoken maybe sixty words to other human beings, most of them in one direction -- the arresting officer reading the charge, the transport officer saying *tomorrow* three times to three different questions, the processing clerk issuing instructions in procedural monotone, the guard tossing the blue towel into the cell with two words of English: "For comfort." Sixty words. Four hours. The fluorescent light buzzing its sixty-hertz hum into the concrete box and the concrete box humming back and the exchange between light and architecture being the only conversation the cell had to offer.

The blue towel was around his shoulders. The towel was not providing comfort. The towel was preventing his body temperature from dropping further in the eighteen-degree air conditioning that Dang Wangi maintained across its holding cells. Comfort required human input -- a voice, a face, the back-and-forth of conversation, the social stimulus that his brain had been receiving for twenty-seven years and that had been severed four hours ago with the abruptness of a power outage. He was the man who had befriended Felix because Felix was there, who had fallen for Priya because her attention was a form of oxygen. He was a man whose entire architecture of self depended on the presence of other people, and the other people were gone -- Priya on a plane, Jake in Langkawi, Felix wherever Felix went when the mule was caught -- and the phone that held their names was in an evidence bag and the cell was three metres by three metres and the silence was not the absence of sound but the absence of anyone who cared whether he made sound or not.

He sat on the steel bench with his head in his hands and the blue towel on his shoulders and the fear that had passed through fear into something chronic, something metabolic, and he was, for the first time in his twenty-seven years, completely alone.

And then the corridor filled with sound.

---

The sound was footsteps. Two sets. One heavy, the measured tread of a police officer in standard-issue boots, the boot-steps that Connor had been hearing at intervals all afternoon -- the guard walking the corridor, checking cells, the mechanical perambulation of a man performing a routine that required his body but not his attention. The second set was different. Lighter. The sound of shoes, not boots. Shoes on concrete. The sound of a civilian walking in a place where civilians did not walk voluntarily.

The footsteps grew louder. Closer. The corridor had the acoustic properties of a concrete tube -- sound travelled through it with minimal absorption, the hard surfaces reflecting rather than dampening, the footsteps arriving at Connor's cell with a clarity that made them seem closer than they were, the acoustic illusion of a space that had been designed for surveillance, not comfort.

Connor sat up on the bench. The sitting up was involuntary -- the body responding to the sound of approaching humans the way a dog responded to a key in a lock, the autonomous activation of attention, the social animal's hard-wired response to the presence of its species. He straightened. He pulled the towel tighter around his shoulders. He looked at the bars.

The guard appeared first. He was the same guard who had been on shift since Connor arrived -- a Malay man in his forties, solidly built, the face neutral, professional -- a cell corridor face, carried the way a uniform was carried, as a tool rather than an expression. He walked past Connor's cell without looking in, which was standard -- the guards looked in on scheduled checks, every thirty minutes by Connor's estimation, and between checks they passed the cells as they passed the walls, as features of the environment rather than points of engagement.

Behind the guard, a man.

The man was Malaysian. Thirties, maybe thirty-two, maybe thirty-five -- the age difficult to pin because the man's face had the quality of faces that settled early and aged slowly, the bone structure set, the features defined, the face that would look substantially the same at thirty and forty and fifty. He was solidly built -- not tall, maybe five-eight, but wide through the shoulders, stocky, solid, weight sitting on him like something he'd been born with, the shoulders and arms of someone for whom strength was occupational rather than recreational. His hair was black, short, neat. His skin was brown -- the medium brown of the Malay majority, the skin that placed him in the demographic that constituted the majority of Malaysia's population and the majority of its police force and the majority of its prison population and the majority of its everything.

He wore civilian clothes. A dark polo shirt. Jeans. Running shoes -- white, scuffed, rubber-soled, the same pair for mosque and market. No watch. No rings. No visible tattoos. Nothing on his person that distinguished him from the millions of other Malaysian men in their thirties who wore polo shirts and jeans and running shoes and moved through the world with the unremarkable solidity of people who were not noticed because they did not invite notice.

The guard stopped at Cell C-7. He took keys from his belt. The keys were on a ring -- a large ring, institutional, the kind that janitors carried in American movies but that here was carried by police officers assigned to the holding cell corridor, the ring containing the keys to every cell in the row, each key identical to every other key because the cells were identical to every other cell and the locks were identical to every other lock and the system did not differentiate between one cell and another because differentiation was the province of the humans inside, not the structures around them.

The guard unlocked the cell. The lock turned with a sound that was metallic and final, the sound of tumblers engaging, the mechanical vocabulary of access and restriction. The door swung open. The hinges were oiled -- the door moved silently, the silence a maintenance achievement in a building where most things creaked.

The man stepped into the cell. The stepping was casual -- not the step of a man entering a cage but the step of a man entering a room, the foot placed with the confidence of someone who had been in rooms like this before, who understood the dimensions, who knew where the bench was and where the toilet was and where the light fell and where it didn't.

The guard closed the door. The lock turned again. The guard walked away. The footsteps receded. The corridor was silent.

The man stood in the centre of the cell. The centre was approximately one-and-a-half metres from Connor's bench. In a cell of nine square metres, one-and-a-half metres was both a distance and a proximity -- far enough to not be threatening, close enough to be social, the distance that humans maintained in elevators and queues and all the spaces where strangers were forced to share volumes that intimacy had not sanctioned.

The man looked around the cell. The looking was slow, deliberate, the survey of a person acquainting himself with an environment -- the bench, the toilet, the walls, the bars, the fluorescent light. His eyes moved across the surfaces the way a tradesman's eyes moved across a new job site -- cataloguing, assessing, the professional's appraisal of a space that was not personal but operational.

His eyes reached Connor. They settled. The settling was not a stare -- it was a regard, the social regard of one person acknowledging another person's presence in a shared space, the look that strangers exchanged in waiting rooms and train carriages and all the places where proximity was involuntary and acknowledgement was the currency that purchased coexistence.

"The light, right?" the man said.

His voice was unremarkable. Not deep, not high. The English was good -- accented, the consonants slightly harder than a native speaker's, the vowels slightly flatter, but fluent, the English of a Malaysian who had been educated in the national school system where English was compulsory, or the English of a man who had spent time around foreigners, who had absorbed the language through immersion rather than study.

"The light," the man said again, looking up at the fluorescent tube. "It never goes off. They do that on purpose, you know. Messes with your head. You lose track of time. That's the point."

Connor looked at the man. The man was looking at the light. The man's face, illuminated from directly above by the fluorescent tube, was mapped with the particular shadows that overhead light created -- the eye sockets slightly darkened, the cheekbones highlighted, the nose casting a shadow down the upper lip. The face was not handsome or ugly. The face was a face. It was human. It was present. It was the first face that had spoken to Connor in full sentences since the arresting officer on the highway, and the fullness of the sentences -- the casual, conversational, almost companionable sentences about the light and its purpose -- was so far from the monosyllabic proceduralism of every other human interaction in the past six hours that the effect was physical, a loosening in Connor's chest, the relaxation of a tension that he hadn't known was there until it eased.

"Yeah," Connor said. His voice was hoarse. The hoarseness surprised him -- he hadn't spoken in four hours, and the vocal cords had apparently entered a state of disuse, the muscles that produced speech having stood down when speech became purposeless. "Yeah, the light's doing my head in."

The man nodded. The nod was sympathetic -- not performative, not exaggerated, just the small, downward motion of a head that had heard something and agreed with it. The nod said: *I understand. I'm in here too. The light is doing my head in as well.*

The man walked to the bench. The bench was three metres long -- bolted to the wall, steel, the surface flat and unpadded, designed for sitting rather than comfort. Connor was at the left end. The man sat at the right end. The gap between them was approximately one-and-a-half metres -- the same distance that had separated them when the man was standing, the distance maintained not by calculation but by instinct, the social instinct that calibrated physical proximity according to relationship, and the relationship between two strangers in a cell was the relationship of the gap, the metre-and-a-half that said *I'm here but I'm not in your space*.

The man sat. The sitting was unhurried. He placed his back against the wall, the way you sat when you expected to be sitting for a while, the posture of someone settling in. He extended his legs. The running shoes were scuffed, the soles worn -- worn thin at the heels, walked-in, the shoes of a particular socioeconomic band that moved through the city on foot and on public transport rather than in the air-conditioned interiors of Protons and Peroduas.

He stretched. The stretch was physical, genuine -- the reaching of arms overhead, the arching of the back, the expansion of the chest, the movements of a body that had been confined and was now recalibrating, redistributing its tensions across the available space. The stretch was ordinary. The stretch was the thing that people did when they sat down after a period of standing or walking. The stretch was human.

"Stupid thing, honestly," the man said, settling back against the wall. He looked at Connor. He smiled. The smile was small, self-deprecating, the smile of a man about to tell a story about his own foolishness. "Bar fight. Changkat. Had too much to drink, said the wrong thing to the wrong guy, and then..." He made a gesture with his hand -- a quick, illustrative movement that suggested a punch thrown, the physical shorthand for violence that transcended language. "Woke up with the police standing over me. The other guy's nose is broken. I'm in here."

He shook his head. The head-shake was rueful, the gesture of a man who recognised his own idiocy and was neither proud of it nor destroyed by it but simply observing it, the way you observed weather -- *it happened, it was unfortunate, it will pass*.

"Stupid," he said again. "My boss is going to kill me."

The phrase *my boss is going to kill me* was so ordinary, so completely the phrase that every person who had ever done something foolish at night and would face consequences in the morning had used, that it landed in the cell like a piece of furniture from the outside world -- familiar, normal, the linguistic artefact of a life that operated on the axis of employment and socialising and the consequences of mixing the two. The phrase was the opposite of Section 39B. The phrase was the opposite of mandatory death penalty. The phrase was the vocabulary of a man whose worst problem was a broken nose and an angry boss, and the vocabulary was a window -- a small, verbal window that opened onto the world outside the cell, the world where people had bar fights and bosses and the word *kill* was a metaphor rather than a statute.

Connor felt something shift. The shift was tectonic -- not large, not visible, but deep, the movement of a plate beneath the surface. The plate was the plate of isolation, the solid mass of aloneness that had been compressing him for four hours, and the shift was caused by the man's voice, by the man's presence, by the simple, irreducible fact that there was another person in the cell and the person was speaking and the speaking was directed at Connor and the direction meant that Connor was no longer alone.

"I'm Rizal," the man said.

He extended his hand. The hand was across the gap -- reaching from the right end of the bench to the space between them, the hand offered in the universal gesture of introduction, the handshake that cultures worldwide had adopted as the first physical transaction between strangers. The hand was clean, the nails trimmed, the skin callused across the palm, the hand of a man who worked with his hands, who gripped things, who used his body as a tool.

Connor took the hand. The handshake was firm but not aggressive -- the grip calibrated to the middle register of social introduction, not the bone-crushing assertion of dominance and not the limp surrender of indifference but the measured, appropriate pressure of two strangers establishing contact. The hand was warm. The warmth was the warmth of a living body, the metabolic heat that humans produced and transmitted through their skin, and the warmth passed through the handshake from Rizal's palm to Connor's palm and the transfer was the first warm thing Connor had felt in four hours.

"Connor," Connor said.

"Connor," Rizal repeated. The repetition was the way Malaysians often processed foreign names -- saying the name back, tasting the syllables, fitting the foreign phonemes into the Malay phonological framework. "Australian?"

"Yeah. Melbourne."

"Melbourne. Cricket. Coffee. That lane with the street art."

"Hosier Lane."

"Hosier Lane, that's it." Rizal smiled again. The smile was the smile of a man who had just made a connection, who had found a piece of shared knowledge between himself and a stranger, the social lubrication of common ground. "My cousin went to Melbourne. Studied engineering at... Monash? RMIT? One of those."

"Monash," Connor said. "I went to Monash."

This was true. He had gone to Monash. He had attended for one year. He had studied business. He had dropped out. But the statement -- *I went to Monash* -- was not the full truth, it was the edited version, the version he had been telling for four years, the version that implied completion and competence and the shared institutional identity that came from naming a university. In a holding cell at Dang Wangi, the version was what it was. Nobody was checking transcripts.

"Small world," Rizal said. The phrase was a cliche, the cliche that people used when coincidences appeared in conversations between strangers, but the cliche was functional -- it performed the work of establishing that the world was small and that the two people in this cell had things in common and that the having-in-common was a bridge and the bridge was crossable.

Rizal leaned back against the wall. He reached into his pocket and emerged with a single cigarette, slightly bent, the paper wrinkled from pocket-storage. No pack. Just the one cigarette.

"The guard let me keep one," Rizal said, noticing Connor's look. "Professional courtesy."

He produced a lighter from his other pocket -- small, red, disposable, the BIC lighter that existed in the gap between regulation and reality, the gap that Malaysian institutions maintained between what the rules said and what happened. Rizal lit the cigarette. The flame appeared for two seconds and disappeared, leaving behind the orange glow of the ember.

The smoke filled the cell. The smoke was the most alive thing Connor had experienced since the arrest -- organic, warm, the acrid-sweet scent of tobacco displacing the disinfectant and the older smell beneath it, the smell that decades of confinement had baked into the concrete. The smoke was a visitor from the outside world, and Connor inhaled it the way a starving man inhaled the smell of food.

"Sorry," Rizal said, gesturing with the cigarette. "Should have asked. You mind?"

"No," Connor said. "It's good, actually."

"So," Rizal said, exhaling smoke toward the fluorescent light where it rose in a white-grey column. "What happened to you, then?"

The question was the casual interrogative of a cellmate, not a police officer. *What are you in for, what's your story.* Connor looked at Rizal's open face and felt the familiarity of it -- not the features but the energy, the posture, the expression. A hundred hostel common rooms had trained him to recognise this face, the face that said: *I'm here. You're here. Let's talk.*

"It's a long story," Connor said.

"Brother," Rizal said, gesturing at the cell, "we've got nothing but time."

Connor almost smiled. The muscles achieved approximately 60 percent of it.

"I'm not sure I should..." Connor began.

"Hey, no pressure." Rizal raised his free hand, palm out. "You don't have to tell me anything. I'm just..." He shrugged. "I'm a talker. My wife says it's my worst quality. Can't sit in a room with someone without trying to have a conversation. It's a problem."

The self-deprecation was disarming -- the generosity of a person who offered their own weakness as a gift, making the space safer, the gap on the bench smaller without either person having moved.

"You married?" Connor asked. The question surprised him -- it had emerged from the social autopilot his brain was now running at full capacity.

"Six years," Rizal said. "Her name's Ain. Two kids. Boy and a girl. She's going to be furious." He drew on the cigarette. "The bar fight thing. She told me to stop going to Changkat. She said *one day you're going to hit someone and end up in a cell*." He exhaled smoke. "She was right. She's always right. That's the other problem."

"What about you?" Rizal asked. "Married? Girlfriend?"

"I had a..." Connor paused. Priya. The name rose in his mind and the name carried weight -- the weight of a person, the weight of mornings in the kitchen and afternoons at the Batu Caves and the night on the air well bench when she'd asked about Malaysian law and he'd kissed her to avoid answering. "There was someone. She left."

"Left you?"

"Left KL. Went back to London."

"Ah." Rizal nodded. The nod was knowing -- the nod of a man who understood that relationships had geographies and that geographies had endings. "Long distance doesn't work. My brother tried it with a girl from Sarawak. Lasted two months."

"Yeah," Connor said. "It wouldn't have worked."

Rizal finished the cigarette. He dropped the butt on the concrete floor and ground it out with his shoe. The grinding was thorough -- the shoe twisting on the butt, crushing it, extinguishing the ember completely, habitual, careful about fire even in a concrete cell. The butt lay on the floor, a small cylinder of grey ash and white paper, the residue of seven minutes of combustion that had changed the cell's atmosphere from institutional to human.

The smoke lingered. Rizal settled back against the wall, his posture relaxed now, his eyes moving idly across the cell until they landed on Connor's towel.

"Nice towel," Rizal said.

Connor looked down at the blue microfiber draped over his shoulders. The towel that had been with him through twelve countries. The towel that smelled of sunscreen and the South China Sea and the accumulated history of his travels. The towel that the guard had tossed into the cell for comfort.

"Smart to keep it," Rizal continued. "It gets cold in here. The AC. They keep it cold on purpose, same as the light. Messes with your body, you know? You can't sleep if you're cold. You can't sleep if the light's on. You can't sleep, you get tired, you get confused. And confused people..."

He didn't finish the sentence. The unfinished sentence hung in the air the way the cigarette smoke had hung -- present, suggestive, the meaning clear without the words. Confused people talked. Confused people cooperated. Confused people signed things.

The observation was sharper than a bouncer's casual knowledge should have been. But Connor didn't notice the sharpness. He noticed the solidarity -- *they* were the police, and Rizal was on his side of the bars.

"I didn't know about the cold," Connor said. "I thought the AC was just... on."

"On, yeah, but on high. Always high. The offices upstairs, they have heaters. I know a guy who worked here. He said the holding cells are set to sixteen degrees. They want you uncomfortable. It's a technique."

"You seem to know a lot about this place," Connor said.

Rizal shrugged. "I've been here before. Not this cell. Another one. Two years ago. Different bar fight." He smiled. The smile was sheepish, the smile of a man whose history contained repetitions that he was not proud of. "I told you, Changkat is my problem. Too many bars, too many drunk guys, too many chances for things to go wrong."

"What happened the first time?"

"Night in the cell. Fine in the morning. Magistrate, pay a fine, community service, go home. Ain didn't speak to me for a week." He laughed. The laugh was short, genuine, rueful with the memory of his wife's anger -- a different kind of anger from the anger of the law, a domestic anger, an anger that was negotiable. "This time might be worse. The other guy's nose. That's proper damage. Might be ABH. Might be a few days in here."

"What do you do?" Connor asked. "For work?"

"Bouncer," Rizal said. "Club on Changkat. SUTRA. You know it?"

Connor didn't know it. He had been to Changkat -- the nightlife district that Felix had taken him to on the first nights, the street of bars and clubs and the Malaysian entertainment industry's concentration point, the street where the night economy happened. But SUTRA was not a name he recognised. He had been to other places, Felix's places, the bars where Felix was known and the drinks were free and the VIP sections opened without question.

"Big place," Rizal said. "Three floors. House music. Lot of tourists. That's where I learned English, actually. Tourists. You talk to them every night. *No, sir, you can't bring that in. No, ma'am, the capacity is full. Yes, the DJ starts at eleven.* After a few years you sound like a guidebook."

"Sounds like a good gig," Connor said.

"It's okay. The money's okay. The hours are bad. You're up all night, sleep all day. Your wife thinks you're having an affair because you come home at four AM smelling like perfume and beer. You're not having an affair -- you're just surrounded by drunk people who fall on you." He paused. "The fights are the worst part. People get stupid when they drink. Especially tourists. No offence."

"None taken."

"Australians are the worst." Rizal said this with a grin -- the grin that softened the statement, that turned it from observation into joke, the humour of a man speaking to an Australian about Australians and trusting that the Australian would receive the stereotype with the good humour that the delivery invited. "Three drinks and they want to wrestle. Every time. Is it the sun? Is there something in the water in Australia that makes you all want to fight after three beers?"

Connor laughed -- small, reduced, but real. "It might be the sun," he said.

"It might be the sun," Rizal agreed, stretching again, making himself at home in the uncomfortable space. The conversation paused, and the pause was comfortable. Four hours ago silence had been the enemy. Now, with Rizal on the bench, silence was shared space.

"So," Rizal said. "What are you doing in KL? Travelling?"

"Yeah," Connor said. "Travelling."

"How long?"

"Six weeks."

"Six weeks in KL?" Rizal's eyebrows rose. The rise was the expression of mild surprise -- six weeks was a long time for a backpacker in one city, and the surprise was the surprise of a local who understood his city's tourist appeal and knew that most tourists stayed three to five days before moving to Penang or Langkawi or the Cameron Highlands. "That's a lot. Most mat salleh stay a few days."

"I liked it here," Connor said. And the statement was true, or had been true, or was a version of true that contained the core fact without the surrounding circumstances. He had liked KL. He had liked the food. He had liked the heat. He had liked the hostel. He had liked the feeling of being somewhere that was cheap enough and warm enough and alive enough that staying felt easier than leaving, the inertia of a place that was comfortable enough to prevent departure and dangerous enough to eventually demand it.

"Where are you staying? Hotel?"

"Hostel. The Lantern. On Petaling Street."

"I know the Lantern." Rizal nodded. The nod was the nod of local knowledge -- a man who lived in KL and knew its landmarks, its businesses, the geography of a city he inhabited. "Old building, right? Red lanterns. Petaling Street. Near the temple."

"Yeah, that's the one."

"Good location. Cheap. My cousin -- different cousin, not the Melbourne one -- he did some painting work there a few years ago. Old Chinese shophouse. He said the owner was a character."

"Uncle Razak."

"That's the name. With the map. The pins."

Connor felt a flicker of something. Not alarm -- the flicker was fainter than alarm, more subtle, the faint registration of a detail that was either a coincidence or something else. Rizal knew the Lantern. Rizal's cousin had worked there. Rizal knew about Razak's map. The connections were the kind of connections that existed in KL's social fabric -- the city of three million that operated, at the neighbourhood level, like a village, where everyone knew someone who knew someone who had been somewhere and the degrees of separation between any two points in the social network were fewer than the degrees suggested by the city's size.

The flicker passed. The flicker passed because Connor's brain was not operating in the mode that detected flickers -- the brain was operating in the mode that craved connection, that needed conversation, that was running the social programmes at full capacity and allocating its processing power to the production and reception of speech rather than the analysis of anomalies. The brain was starving. The brain was being fed. The brain was not going to question the food.

"So what happened?" Rizal asked. "If you don't mind. Six weeks in KL, nice hostel, and now you're in here. Something went wrong."

The question was gentle -- the fundamental interrogative of the backpacker circuit: *what happened? How did you end up here?* Connor had been asked this question a hundred times in a hundred hostels, but the context was different now. In a hostel the answer was a story. In a cell the answer was a confession.

"It's..." Connor began.

He stopped. The last moment of caution -- *be careful, this is a police station, anything you say can be used as evidence*. But the circuit was weak, weakened by four hours of isolation and the desperate need for human contact, and the idea of stopping the conversation, of returning to the silence, was physically repellant. For Connor, the social need was the survival instinct. Had always been.

"I got in trouble," Connor said. The admission was the crack in the wall through which everything else would flow.

"Drugs?" Rizal said. The word landed soft, almost tender -- not an accusation but the educated guess of a man who understood that foreign nationals in this particular station were, more often than not, here for this particular reason.

Connor nodded.

"Mate," Rizal said -- the word slightly accented, borrowed from the Australian lexicon and adapted to the Malaysian mouth, a bridge. "That's heavy. Like, trafficking heavy? Or possession?"

"Trafficking," Connor said. The word was in the air and could not be retrieved.

Rizal was quiet for five seconds. Long enough to honour the weight of the word and short enough to not leave Connor alone with it.

"How much?" Rizal asked.

"Four hundred and fifty grams."

The number sat between them. Rizal's face changed -- not dramatically, not the theatrical shock of a man performing surprise, but a subtle recalibration, the eyebrows drawing slightly closer, the mouth tightening slightly, the micro-expressions that conveyed recognition of scale. Four hundred and fifty grams was nine times the fifty-gram threshold. Four hundred and fifty grams was not a mistake or an experiment or a personal supply that could be argued down in court. Four hundred and fifty grams was a quantity that the law had no ambiguity about.

"Methamphetamine?" Rizal asked, and the asking was quiet now, the voice lowered, the register shifted from conversational to confessional, the acoustic change that humans made when the subject matter crossed from public to private, from shareable to sensitive.

"Yeah."

"Connor." Rizal shook his head. The head-shake was slow, heavy, the head-shake of a man who understood the implications and was communicating his understanding through the most basic gestural vocabulary available -- the shake that said *this is bad, this is very bad, I understand how bad this is*. "Four fifty. That's... you know what that means in Malaysia?"

"I know now."

"You didn't know before?"

The question was the question that defined Connor's entire story. The question that Priya had asked and Tomoko had implied and Mei Ling had contained in her silences and Mama Siti had buried in her proverbs and Ahmad had been waiting to hear the answer to. *Did you know? Did you know before? When did you know?*

"I didn't know what I was carrying," Connor said. "Not at first. I thought it was..." He paused. The pause was the hesitation of a man on the edge of a longer story, the story that extended backward from this cell to the hostel and from the hostel to the common room and from the common room to the first night and the rooftop and the German with the scar on his eyebrow and the words *I could use someone reliable around here*. "I thought it was phone accessories. Business documents. That kind of thing."

"Someone told you that?"

"Yeah."

"Someone at the hostel?"

"A guy I met there," Connor said. "At the Lantern. He was staying there. He was... he seemed like a mate. He was cool, you know? He knew everyone. He always had money. He bought rounds. He told good stories."

Connor was talking now. The talking had acquired its own momentum -- the momentum of a story that had been contained for hours, for days, for the forty-seven days since the first envelope, the story that had lived inside him as a growing mass of fact and fear and rationalisation, the story that he had never told anyone in its entirety because telling required the dismantling of the machine, the machine that converted warnings into noise and truth into trivia and the word *trafficking* into the word *logistics*. The story wanted out. The story had pressure. The story was like the confession that the police station was designed to extract, except that the police station had not extracted it -- the police station had placed a man on a bench and the man had been warm and interested and available and the warmth and the interest and the availability had done what the cold and the light and the silence could not.

"He was German," Connor said.

"The guy at the hostel?"

"Yeah. German. Older than me. Thirty-one. He had a private room. He was... different from the other backpackers. Polished. Like he had money but wasn't flashy about it. He spoke five languages. He knew KL like a local. He knew where to go, who to talk to, how to get in anywhere."

Rizal listened, body angled slightly toward Connor, head tilted.

"He started asking me to do things," Connor said. "Small things. Carry an envelope to a cafe. Deliver a package to a shop in Brickfields. He said it was business stuff -- import-export, phone accessories, that kind of thing. He paid me. Cash. Two hundred ringgit for the first one. Then five hundred. Then more."

"And you didn't check what was in the packages?"

"No." The word was flat. The word was the confession within the confession, the admission that contained the entire story's moral architecture -- the single syllable that represented every warning ignored, every red flag rationalised, every moment when Connor could have opened a package or asked a question or looked at the thing he was carrying and chosen instead to look away, to not know, to maintain the fiction that ignorance was innocence and that a sealed envelope was just a sealed envelope and that a man who paid cash for deliveries and lived in a private room and wore leather driving gloves was just a generous friend with eczema.

"I didn't check," Connor said. "I didn't want to know. I needed the money and I trusted him and the two things together were enough to stop me from asking questions."

Rizal nodded. The nod was understanding, not judgemental.

"How long?" Rizal asked. "How many deliveries?"

"Six weeks. Dozens. I don't know exactly. It started with envelopes and ended with..." He gestured vaguely, the gesture encompassing the cell and the charge and the suitcase on the highway shoulder. "A suitcase."

"The four fifty was in a suitcase?"

"In the lining. Vacuum-sealed. Sewn in. I was supposed to take a bus to Penang. They got me at a checkpoint on the highway. There was a dog."

"A dog," Rizal repeated. "The K-9 unit."

"Yeah. The dog sat next to the suitcase. And that was it."

"That was it," Rizal echoed. His voice was soft -- not pity but the horizontal sympathy of a person on the same bench, in the same cell, receiving the story as a human story rather than a legal one.

The distinction was also, if Connor had been capable of seeing it, the technique. The professional listener's creation of a non-judgemental space, the calibrated warmth of a man who knew exactly how warm to be. But Connor was not capable of seeing it. Connor was seeing what he needed to see -- a face and a voice and the presence of another human being -- and the need was shaping the perception, the same way it always had.

"This German guy," Rizal said. "At the hostel. He set you up?"

"I don't know if *set up* is the right word. He... groomed me. That's what the police will probably call it. He found me when I was broke. He was nice to me. He gave me easy money. He made the deliveries feel normal. By the time I found out what I was actually carrying, I was already..." He trailed off. The trailing was the verbal equivalent of a man reaching the edge of a cliff and looking down and deciding not to jump but also not turning back, standing on the edge with the void below and the solid ground behind and unable to move in either direction.

"Already in too deep," Rizal finished.

"Yeah."

"CCTV?"

"How did you know about the CCTV?" Connor asked -- the first flicker of something that might have been caution, the brain pausing long enough to register that Rizal had said *CCTV* as though the specific mechanism of Connor's entrapment were obvious. Rizal shrugged. "It's how they do it, isn't it? These rings. They film you so you can't go to the police. My mate -- the one who worked at this station -- he told me about it. It's standard." The explanation was plausible, referencing the same contact who had explained about the cold and the light, and the moment of caution passed because caution would have meant losing the one source of human contact Connor had, and losing that was worse than any risk.

"Yeah, they had me on camera. Every delivery. My face at every location. He showed me the footage. And he said if I went to the police, the footage would be sent to... I don't know. Prosecutors. Media. Everyone. He said I was already in the system and the only way out was to do one more job. The big one. The suitcase."

"And you believed him."

"What choice did I have?"

The question was rhetorical but Rizal answered it anyway. "You could have gone to the police," Rizal said. "Before the suitcase. Before the bus."

"I tried." The admission came out fast, pushed by the pressure of guilt and regret and the specific anguish of a man who had come close enough to salvation to taste it and had turned away. "I called a cop. A narcotics sergeant. Ahmad. He gave me his card weeks ago. I called him twice. Once I got voicemail. Once I got through. I couldn't speak. I just... I couldn't make the words come out."

Rizal was quiet. The quiet had a texture now -- a thicker quiet, a more concentrated quiet, the quiet of a man who was processing information that was, perhaps, more than conversational. The quiet lasted three seconds.

"Ahmad," Rizal said. "Narcotics. Dang Wangi?"

"Yeah. Sergeant Ahmad bin Ismail."

"I think I know that name. Serious guy? Forties? Moustache?"

"I don't remember a moustache. But serious, yeah. Very serious."

"That's him. He's known. Tough. By the book." Rizal paused. "He'd have helped you, Connor. If you'd talked to him. He'd have helped."

The statement was a blade. *He'd have helped.* The conditional -- the cruellest tense, the tense that described the world that would have existed if Connor had spoken into the phone instead of hanging up.

"I know," Connor said. "I know he would have."

"The German guy," Rizal said. "You said he was at the hostel. The Lantern. What was his name?"

Connor looked at Rizal. Rizal's face was open, patient, the face of a man who had nowhere else to be. The face was kind. The face was the same kind of face that Felix had worn on the rooftop on the first night -- the face of a man who made you feel chosen.

Connor opened his mouth. And then he spoke. He told Rizal everything.
# Chapter 35: Confession

Connor told Rizal everything.

Not all at once. Not in the ordered, chronological manner of a statement prepared for a courtroom or a letter written to a police sergeant. The telling was organic, disordered, the telling of a man who had been silent for too long and was now unsilent and the unsilencing was not a tap being opened but a dam breaking, the water finding its own channels, flowing where the terrain allowed, accumulating in pools before rushing forward again.

He told Rizal about Felix.

"Felix. His name's Felix Decker. German bloke. Thirty-one, maybe thirty-two. He's at the hostel -- the Lantern, on Petaling Street, third floor, he's got a private room because he's -- he pays for the private room, right? He's been there... eighteen months? Yeah. Eighteen months. And the gloves. He wears these gloves. Leather. I thought it was eczema. He told me eczema and I just -- I just believed him. The gloves are so his fingerprints aren't on the packages. He told me that himself. On the rooftop."

The words came out in a rush, tumbling over each other, the syntax collapsing under the weight of the content, the sentences running together without pause or punctuation because pausing required the breath that Connor couldn't spare and punctuation required the composure that Connor didn't have. The words were the words he should have spoken to Ahmad. The words were the words that Priya had begged him to speak to the embassy. The words were the words that Razak had offered to facilitate, that Tomoko had been waiting to corroborate, that Mama Siti had been watching for. The words had been assembled and ready for weeks, and they were now being spoken, and they were being spoken to the wrong person.

Rizal listened. Rizal's listening was expert -- the listening of a man who understood that the most effective extraction technique was not interrogation but silence, not questions but the absence of questions, the open space that a desperate person rushed to fill. Rizal sat on the steel bench opposite Connor, his back against the concrete wall, his legs crossed at the ankle, his posture relaxed, his expression attentive. He nodded at intervals. He made small sounds of understanding -- "Mm," "Yeah," "Right" -- the acoustic currency of a listener who was engaged but not directing, who was receiving but not steering, who was letting Connor talk because Connor talking was the objective and the objective required no intervention beyond presence.

"He recruited me in the common room," Connor said. "Day 1. My first night. He bought me a beer. He told me travel stories. He was charming -- that's the thing, that's the thing that nobody understands, he was *charming*, he was the most charming person in the building, and the charm was real, it worked, I felt it, I felt chosen, I felt like he'd picked me because I was special, because I was different, because I was the kind of person who deserved a friend like Felix Decker."

He laughed. The laugh was not funny. The laugh was the sound that humans produced when the alternative was the other sound, the sound of breaking, and breaking was not an option yet because there was more to tell and the telling required the structural integrity that breaking would destroy.

"It started with an envelope. Day 6. Just an envelope, sealed, deliver it to a man at a caf in Bukit Bintang. Twenty minutes of walking. RM200. I didn't open it. I didn't think about it. The money was good and the task was easy and the person who asked me was my friend and friends asked friends for favours and this was a favour. That's what I told myself. That's what the machine told me."

"The machine?" Rizal said. The question was the first question he'd asked. The question was casual, interested, the question of a man following a story rather than conducting an interrogation.

"In my head. The thing that... rationalises. The thing that takes the evidence and converts it into something manageable. The machine that said the envelopes were business documents and the packages were phone accessories and the backpack was electronics and the charger boxes were chargers. The machine that said *you don't know for certain* every time I almost knew for certain. The machine kept me going. The machine kept me carrying."

He told Rizal about the deliveries. All of them. The envelopes -- three in the first week. The packages -- brown paper, taped, the weight that felt wrong. The contacts: Mr. Tan at the caf in Bukit Bintang. Auntie Lim at the shophouse in Jalan Ipoh. Danny at the defunct karaoke bar in Bukit Bintang, Lot 22B. Ah Keat at the nasi kandar restaurant behind Petaling Street.

He told Rizal about the backpack. The red Deuter, six hundred grams to the warehouse in Sentul. The warehouse with the men who weighed packages and sealed them and spoke in Hokkien and didn't look at Connor because looking at the mule was not part of the protocol.

He told Rizal about Wei. The phone repair shop, two doors from the hostel. The back room -- the stainless steel table, the vacuum sealer, the digital scale, the rolls of cling film, the charger boxes that were not charger boxes. Wei's precision. Wei's silence. Wei's function.

He told Rizal about the money. Fourteen thousand ringgit in his bank account. The deposits that couldn't be explained by social media consulting. The money that Priya had seen and questioned and he had deflected.

"Priya," Rizal said. The name registered with the interest of a man who had been listening for names. "Who's Priya?"

"She's... she was at the hostel. British. A medical student. She tried to warn me. She printed the law -- the Dangerous Drugs Act, Section 39B. She put it on my bed. She confronted Felix. She... she's on a plane right now. To London. She has a letter. A letter to the police, to the embassy, to a newspaper. She was going to send it when she landed."

"She's coming back though, yeah? Or she's gone for good?"

Connor calculated. Priya's flight was at eleven thirty last night. A thirteen-hour flight. She would land at Heathrow around five AM London time, which was one PM KL time. It was now -- he looked at the cell, at the absence of a clock, at the fluorescent light that gave no indication of time -- it was now late afternoon, maybe four or five PM. Priya had landed. Priya might have already sent the letter.

"She's already landed," Connor said. "She might have already sent it. To Sergeant Ahmad. Narcotics Division. Here. At this station."

"Ahmad," Rizal said. "You know Ahmad?"

"He gave me his card. At a checkpoint. Bukit Bintang. Weeks ago. He looked at me and said *Malaysia is not a game*. I kept his card. I called him -- twice. The first time I got voicemail. The second time he answered. I couldn't speak. I just... I couldn't."

Rizal nodded. The nodding was slow, thoughtful, the nodding of a man processing information. Behind the nodding, behind the calm exterior, behind the performance of a man listening to a cellmate's story, calculations were being made. The calculations were not Connor's to see. The calculations were the internal process of a man who was tallying names -- Felix Decker, Wei, Mr. Tan, Auntie Lim, Danny, Ah Keat, Priya Sharma, Sergeant Ahmad -- and locations -- the Lantern Hostel, the phone repair shop, the Sentul warehouse, Bukit Bintang, Jalan Ipoh -- and assessments -- a letter in transit, a journalist with photographs, a hostel owner with records, a narcotics officer with a card that connected him to the mule.

The calculations were the network's calculations. The calculations were the risk assessment that the network performed when a mule was caught -- the assessment of what the mule knew, what the mule had said, what the mule might say, and the degree to which the mule's testimony could damage the infrastructure that the network had built over years of operation.

Connor's testimony could damage the infrastructure. Connor's testimony, combined with Priya's letter and Tomoko's photographs and Razak's records and Ahmad's case file, could dismantle the infrastructure. The network's calculation was simple: the mule had to be silenced before the testimony could be delivered.

But Connor didn't know this. Connor was talking because talking was the thing that silence had denied him for forty-seven days, and now silence was over, and the talking was a release, a catharsis, the opening of a valve that had been closed too long. The talking felt good. The talking felt like the thing he should have done on Day 6, on Day 15, on Day 39 when Priya had said *call Ahmad* and he had gone to the rooftop instead. The talking felt like salvation.

The talking was the opposite of salvation. The talking was the mechanism of his destruction.

---

He told Rizal about the suitcase.

"Four hundred and fifty grams. Felix told me. He told me the number. He said it would pass a visual inspection and an X-ray but not a dog. He said Fridays were usually quiet. He said *usually*."

"Usually," Rizal repeated. The word sat between them in the fluorescent light.

"There was a checkpoint. Between Tapah and Ipoh. Two checkpoints, actually. The first one was routine -- three officers, no dog. Waved through. The second one had dogs. Two dogs. German shepherds. The dog went along the luggage compartment and stopped at my suitcase and sat down. The handler said *positif*. And that was it. That was the end."

He paused. The pause was not for effect but for breath, the body's insistence on the mechanical requirement of oxygen even while the mind was operating at a level that made oxygen feel irrelevant.

"They opened the suitcase on the highway shoulder. Cut the lining. Found five vacuum bags. Tested the contents. Blue. Positive for methamphetamine. They arrested me. Read me my rights. Put me in a car. Drove me here."

"To Ahmad's station," Rizal said.

"To Ahmad's station. Yeah. The irony isn't lost on me."

Rizal looked at Connor. Something shifted -- not in his expression, which remained attentive and calm, but in the architecture beneath it, the way a building settles on its foundations when a load is added and the settling is invisible but the structure knows. Rizal uncrossed his legs. The movement was small, unhurried, but the new posture was different from the old posture in a way that Connor did not register: the old posture was the posture of listening, of a body arranged for the purpose of absorbing information, and the new posture was the posture of a body that had absorbed enough and was rearranging itself for the next function. Rizal's hands, which had been resting loosely on his knees, moved to the bench on either side of his thighs, the fingers curling around the steel edge, the grip light but present, the grip of a man who was no longer a listener but something else. His questions, in the last minutes of Connor's telling, had become fractionally more precise -- "Ahmad, you said? Narcotics Division?" and "The letter -- she was sending it to Ahmad specifically?" and "The journalist -- she had photographs of Felix?" -- the questions arriving with the focused economy of a man who was no longer following a story but confirming an inventory, ticking items off a list that existed somewhere behind his calm, attentive eyes. The fluorescent light caught those eyes and for a moment -- less than a moment, a fraction of a second that Connor would never consciously recall -- there was something in them that had not been there before. Not menace. Not cruelty. Certainty. The specific, settled certainty of a professional who had confirmed what he needed to confirm and now knew the shape of what came next.

The look was the look of a man who had heard enough. Not enough as in sufficient for a conversation, but enough as in sufficient for a purpose, the purpose that Rizal's presence in this cell served, the purpose that Connor didn't know and wouldn't know until the purpose was enacted.

"Better you rest, brother. Long day already," Rizal said.

"I can't sleep."

"Try. Lie down. Use your towel as a pillow. The bench is shit but it's better than the floor."

Connor looked at the bench. The steel surface was cold and hard and the bench was designed not for comfort but for containment, the minimum accommodation that the system provided to the bodies it held. He lay down. The bench was short -- his legs hung off the end, his knees bent. He folded the blue towel and placed it under his head. The towel was soft against his scalp. The microfiber compressed to a thin cushion. The towel smelled of sunscreen and the faint, chemical scent of hostel soap and the accumulated olfactory memory of twelve countries.

He closed his eyes. The fluorescent light buzzed behind his eyelids, the light penetrating the thin skin, the darkness not complete but red -- the colour of blood seen from behind the lid, the colour of the world when you closed your eyes in a room that never went dark.

Rizal sat on the opposite bench. Rizal did not close his eyes. Rizal watched Connor with the steady, patient attention of a man waiting for sleep to arrive, the way a hunter waited for prey to settle, the patience that was not idleness but preparation, the stillness that preceded action.

The cell was quiet. The fluorescent light buzzed. The disinfectant smell was constant -- the chemical signature of a space that was cleaned with industrial products by people who cleaned without care, the cleaning a function rather than an act, the function maintaining the minimum standard of hygiene that the system required.

---

Connor didn't sleep. He drifted -- the shallow, incomplete drift that existed between wakefulness and sleep, the state in which the mind produced fragments rather than dreams, the fragments assembling and disassembling with the random, kaleidoscopic logic of a consciousness that was too exhausted to organise itself but too afraid to surrender.

The fragments were memories.

His mother's kitchen. The yellow curtains. The Vegemite jar with the red lid. The morning light coming through the window above the sink, the light that fell on the counter in a rectangle that moved as the sun moved, the slow clock of domestic life.

His father's hand on his shoulder at the airport. "The rules don't care who you are." The hand heavy and warm and the weight of it carrying the authority of a man who knew something about the world that his son didn't know and was trying to communicate it through a palm and five fingers and the pressure of a grip that said *please listen*.

Priya's face at the hawker stall. The first time. Her glasses reflecting the stall's fluorescent light (the light -- always the light, the fluorescent light in every memory now, the light contaminating the past the way the drugs had contaminated his luggage). Her expression: amused, sharp, the face of a woman encountering a specimen she found irritating and interesting in equal measure.

Felix in the common room. The beer. The stories. The scar on the eyebrow. The linen shirt. The charm that was a weapon. The smile that was a tool. The word *reliable*. "I could use someone reliable around here." The word that had opened the door, the first door, the door that led to all the other doors.

The fragments cycled. The kitchen. The airport. The hawker stall. The common room. The envelope. The package. The backpack. The charger box. The suitcase. The dog. The handcuffs. The cell. The light.

The light.

Always the light. The fluorescent tube on the ceiling of the cell, the tube that buzzed and hummed and cast its flat, blue-white illumination on everything -- the walls, the bench, the toilet, the towel, the two men, the air. The light was the cell's defining feature. The light was the thing that made the cell different from every other space Connor had occupied -- not the bars, which were expected, not the concrete, which was expected, but the light, which was unexpected in its permanence, in its refusal to turn off, in the message that its permanence conveyed: *there is no night here, there is no rest, there is no darkness to hide in, there is only this -- this light, this buzzing, this brightness that reveals everything and conceals nothing*.

He opened his eyes. The light was there. The light was always there.

Rizal was watching him. Rizal's eyes were open, steady, the eyes reflecting the fluorescent light in two small points, the eyes of a man who had not slept and did not intend to.

"What time is it?" Connor said.

"Late. Maybe ten. Maybe eleven."

"How do you know?"

"The shift change. The guards. You hear the doors. The evening shift ends at ten. The night shift starts."

Connor listened. The sounds of the station were distant but present -- the muffled rhythm of a building that operated on a schedule, the opening and closing of doors, the footsteps in corridors, the occasional voice. The sounds were the sounds of a system running, the bureaucratic machinery of a police station performing its nightly transition from day operations to night operations, the change of personnel, the change of rhythm, the change from the brisk efficiency of daylight hours to the slower, quieter tempo of the night.

A sound at the cell door -- metal on metal, the scrape of the observation slot sliding open. A rectangle of light appeared in the door at eye level, the light from the corridor brighter than the cell's fluorescent tube, sharp-edged and briefly blinding. A face filled the rectangle: a guard, new, not the one who had processed Connor. The night-shift officer. His face was the face of a man four hours into a shift that would last until six AM -- the eyes carrying the particular fatigue of institutional boredom, the mouth set in the neutral expression of a person performing a task he had performed a thousand times, the check a function rather than an investigation, the eyes moving without searching, seeing without analysing. The guard's gaze swept the cell -- two prisoners, one lying down, one sitting -- and found nothing that required action, and the observation slot scraped shut, and the rectangle of corridor light vanished, and the cell was again sealed in its own fluorescent universe.

On the opposite bench, Rizal's eyes tracked the slot as it closed. The tracking was brief -- a flick of attention -- but in the moment after the slot shut, Rizal's right hand moved. The movement was nearly invisible: his index finger extended from the loose fist resting on his thigh and tapped once, softly, against the steel bench. A single tap. The tap of a man marking a timestamp. Then the finger curled back into the fist and the hand was still and the movement was over and it had meant nothing, or it had meant everything, and the difference between nothing and everything was a difference that Connor, lying with his eyes half-closed, could not perceive.

Footsteps. Receding. A door, distant, opening and closing. Then the corridor was silent, the guard absorbed into the station's nighttime architecture, gone.

"Night shift," Rizal said. "One guard for the whole block. Checks every hour. Maybe every forty minutes if he's keen. Maybe every ninety if he's not."

"How do you know?"

"You hear the pattern. First check is always prompt -- the new shift, the fresh guard, the supervisor maybe still around. After that it loosens. The gaps get wider. By two, three AM..." He made a gesture with his hand, an opening, a spreading, the gesture of a man describing the natural expansion of unsupervised time. "The station is quiet. The guard has a desk somewhere. A phone. Earbuds. Maybe a game, maybe a show. Six hours of checking cells and paperwork and the boredom that is the specific boredom of a man who is employed to watch other men sit in rooms. The boredom wins. It always wins."

The information was delivered casually, conversationally, with the warm tone of a man sharing institutional wisdom with a newcomer -- *this is how it works, this is what to expect, this is how the night will go*. The information was comforting. But the information was also reconnaissance -- Rizal was narrating the security environment, mapping the intervals between checks, calculating the window of unobserved time that would open in the hours ahead, the way a professional assessed a space before operating in it. Every detail -- the guard's routine, the loosening intervals, the desk and the earbuds and the boredom -- was a variable in an equation that Connor could not see, an equation whose solution was a span of uninterrupted minutes sometime between two and four AM, a span long enough for the task that Rizal's presence in this cell had been arranged to accomplish.

Connor didn't hear the reconnaissance. Connor heard a man who knew about police stations, who understood the system, who could help navigate the long, terrifying night ahead.

"I need to talk to someone," Connor said. He sat up on the bench. "Ahmad. Sergeant Ahmad. Narcotics Division. He's in this building -- this building, this station, Dang Wangi. He gave me his card. He looked at me at a checkpoint and he knew, he *knew*, he could see it, and he said *Malaysia is not a game* and he gave me his card because he was giving me a chance, and I didn't take it, and I need to take it now. If I can talk to him--"

He was rehearsing it already, the speech assembling itself in his mouth, the words that Priya had helped him research in those desperate final days at the hostel -- the legal terminology she had found on the Malaysian Bar Council website, the phrases she had underlined in her precise handwriting on the printout she'd left on his bed. *I am a cooperating witness. I wish to make a voluntary statement under Section 112 of the Criminal Procedure Code. I have information regarding a drug trafficking network operating in the Kuala Lumpur metropolitan area. I can identify the handler, the supplier, the distribution contacts, and the locations of operation. I am requesting consideration under Section 39C, which provides for reduced sentencing in exchange for cooperation with the prosecution.* The words were legal, formal, the words of a system that Connor had spent his entire adult life refusing to engage with, the words that were now, in this cell, under this light, the only words that might save his life. He had memorised them, refined the delivery during the hours on the bench, imagining Ahmad's face as he listened -- the stern, professional face softening into the expression of an officer who recognised that the boy in front of him was not a trafficker but a fool, a useful fool who could bring down something larger, and the recognition would be the beginning of the process that would transform Connor from a prisoner into a witness, from a dead man into a living one.

The hope was enormous. The hope filled every cubic centimetre of the fluorescent air and the hope was built on the belief that Ahmad -- the man who had stood on a Bukit Bintang pavement and looked at Connor with the eyes of someone who had seen a hundred Connors -- would listen, would intercede, would reach into the machinery of the Dangerous Drugs Act and pull Connor out before the machinery did what machinery did. The hope was desperate and irrational and it was all Connor had, and he held it the way a drowning man held a plank, with the full, white-knuckled grip of a body that understood the alternative to holding was sinking.

"In the morning," Rizal said.

The words were gentle. But beneath the gentleness there was something else -- something in the fractional pause between "the" and "morning," a pause so small that only a machine calibrated for such measurements could have detected it: the pause fractionally longer than the words required, as though "in the morning" were not a promise but a sedative, a verbal anaesthetic administered to keep the patient still and cooperative in the hours remaining.

"Tonight nobody is coming, lah. Morning, they come," Rizal continued.

The morning. Everything was the morning. The embassy was the morning. The lawyer was the morning. Ahmad was the morning. The morning was the boundary between the night and the process, between the cell and the system's official response, between the waiting and the acting. The morning was twelve hours away. The morning was the thing that Connor had to survive to reach.

He pulled the blue towel tighter around his shoulders. The towel was warm now -- warmed by his body, the microfiber absorbing his heat and reflecting it back, the thermal loop of a body trying to comfort itself with its own warmth. The towel was the only soft thing in the cell. The bench was steel. The walls were concrete. The bars were iron. The towel was the exception -- the one material that yielded, that gave, that pressed against his skin with the quality of something that was not trying to contain him.

He thought about the morning. The guard would come at six, or seven. The day shift would begin. Connor would stand at the bars and say the words -- *I am a cooperating witness, I wish to make a voluntary statement* -- and the words would travel through the system the way signals travelled through wires, from the guard to the desk officer to Ahmad, and Ahmad would come, and Ahmad would listen, and the listening would be the beginning of something that was not this cell, this light, this night.

The words were ready. The words had been ready for weeks. The words would be spoken in the morning. The morning was the thing he had to reach.

He closed his eyes again. The light persisted behind his eyelids. The light was permanent. The light was the condition of the cell, the condition of the night, the condition of the last night of Connor Briggs's life, though he didn't know that yet, though the not-knowing was the last mercy the universe would extend.

Rizal sat across from him. Rizal's eyes were open. Rizal was watching. Rizal was waiting.

The fluorescent light buzzed. The cell was quiet. The station was quiet.
