She placed it at the end of the counter, the position where Connor had stood every morning, the position that was between the coffee station and the bread toaster, the position that Connor had occupied because it was closest to the charging outlet where he plugged in his phone while he ate. The position was not marked. The position was not labelled. The position was simply the place where Connor stood, and the plate was placed there because the plate was for Connor, and Connor was dead, and the plate was for Connor anyway.

No one claimed the plate.

At 8:00 AM, the German couple from Dorm 1 came down and took plates from the stack and served themselves from the communal tray of nasi lemak that Mama Siti had prepared for the guests. They did not take the plate on the counter. The plate on the counter was not part of the communal offering. The plate on the counter was separate, individual, prepared for a specific person. The couple did not know this. The couple did not know that a specific person had existed or that the specific person was absent or that the absence was permanent. The couple ate their breakfast and discussed whether to visit the Batu Caves or the Petronas Towers. They chose the towers.

At 9:00 AM, a backpacker from Dorm 2 -- a Canadian, twenty-one, on his first trip abroad -- came down and saw the plate and reached for it.

"That one is taken," Mei Ling said from the reception desk. She said it without looking up. She said it in the flat, informational tone of a receptionist communicating a policy. The Canadian withdrew his hand and served himself from the communal tray.

The plate sat on the counter. The rice cooled. The sambal developed a thin film. The ikan bilis softened in the humidity. The egg's yolk set to solid. The plate was a plate of food that had been prepared for a person who would not eat it, and the preparation was not rational and was not intended to be rational. The preparation was ritual. The preparation was Mama Siti's grammar of grief -- the language she spoke when Bahasa Melayu and English were insufficient, the language of cooking for the dead, the language that said: *you were here, you ate what I made, the making was my caring, and the caring does not stop because you have stopped*.

At noon, Mama Siti cleared the plate. She scraped the food into the bin. She washed the plate. She dried it. She placed it back in the stack.

The next morning, Sunday, she prepared the plate again. Same position on the counter. Same arrangement. Same care. No one claimed it. At noon, she cleared it.

Monday: the plate. The counter. Noon. Cleared.

Tuesday: the plate. The counter. Noon. Cleared.

This continued for seven days. Seven plates of nasi lemak, prepared and unclaimed and cleared. Seven mornings of rice moulded on banana leaf and sambal in its red comma and ikan bilis scattered and cucumber in its crescent and egg with its lace edges. Seven noons of scraping and washing and drying and stacking.

On the eighth day, a Sunday, Mama Siti prepared the plate. She placed it on the counter. She stood beside it. She looked at it the way she had looked at Connor on the rooftop -- the direct, unfiltered look of a woman who had abandoned indirection.

She spoke. She spoke in Malay, quietly, to the plate, to the counter, to the position where Connor had stood, to the air that had once contained him and now did not.

"*Pergi dengan selamat*," she said. *Go safely.*

She picked up the plate. She carried it to the air well -- the open courtyard at the centre of the building, the space where the sky was visible above and the mosaic tile bench sat below and the laundry lines crossed like the strings of an instrument. She placed the plate on the mosaic bench. She left it there.

The plate sat in the air well for the rest of the day. The afternoon rain came at 3 PM -- the daily equatorial thunderstorm, the deluge that dropped from the visible sky through the open air well and hammered the tiles and the bench and the plate, the rain dissolving the rice and washing the sambal into a red streak across the mosaic and scattering the ikan bilis and lifting the egg and carrying everything into the drain at the corner of the courtyard, the drain that led to the pipes that led to the river that led to the Strait of Malacca that led to the sea.

The plate was empty after the rain. The plate was clean. The rain had done what Mama Siti's hands had done for seven days but with the finality that hands could not provide, the finality of the natural world performing the function that ritual had been performing, the function of clearing, of completing, of ending.

Mama Siti collected the plate. She brought it inside. She washed it, though the rain had already washed it. She dried it. She placed it in the stack.

She did not prepare the plate on the ninth day.

The position at the counter remained empty. The charging outlet was used by other phones. The mornings continued. The nasi lemak was served from the communal tray. The building performed normalcy.

But the staff knew. Mei Ling knew, and her knowing was in the way she looked at Dorm 3's door each time she walked past it, the look that lasted a fraction of a second longer than a look at any other door, the fraction that was the distance between routine and memory. Uncle Razak knew, and his knowing was in the new red pin on his map -- the pin that was placed on the map of Kuala Lumpur, not on the map of world hostels but on a separate map, a new map, a map of just this city, just this building, a map that had only one pin, the pin that said: *here, this one, this was ours*.

Aziz knew. Aziz, who had fixed the fan in Connor's dorm and opened his mouth to speak and closed it and left. Aziz, who had been a police officer and had lost his career to the act of speaking. Aziz stood in the alley behind the building and smoked and the smoking was the same as it always was but the standing was different, the standing was heavier, the standing of a man who had added another silence to the collection of silences that he carried, the collection that had begun with the silence that cost him his badge and had grown, silence by silence, into the weight that pressed him against the wall of the alley, the weight that was invisible and permanent and the precise weight of the words he had not said to Connor Briggs on Day 6 when he stood in the doorway of Dorm 3 and opened his mouth and closed it.

The French student arrived at 6 PM. She checked in. She climbed the narrow staircase. She entered Dorm 3. She found Bed 7. She put her backpack on the bed. She looked around the room -- the ceiling fan, the air well window, the bunks, the lockers, the peeling paint, the red lantern glow from the corridor. She smiled. The room was perfect. The room was exactly what she had hoped for -- authentic, atmospheric, the real Southeast Asian hostel experience, the kind of place that had stories.

She climbed into bed. She pulled the sheet over herself. Her hand rested on the wooden rail.

She did not feel the letters carved into the wood. She did not read them. She did not know that beneath her fingertips was the name of a Swedish woman who had slept in this bed and carried packages for a charming man and been arrested and imprisoned and whose name was the bed's only memory, the only mark left by the procession of bodies that had occupied this specific horizontal surface.

The ceiling fan turned. *Tick, tick, tick.*

Outside, the city hummed. The neon signs of Petaling Street cast their colours on the wet pavement. The smell of char kway teow rose from the hawker stalls. The call to prayer from Masjid Jamek would come at 5:32 AM. The nasi lemak would be ready by 7:15 AM. The communal tray would be full. The counter position would be empty.

The hostel was open. The hostel was operational. The hostel was accepting guests.

Check-in was at 2 PM. Check-out was at 11 AM. The rules were posted in four languages. The wifi password was on the whiteboard behind reception. The house rules were clear, and the last rule, the one written in red at the bottom of the laminated card, the one that Connor had never read, the one that was the building's only explicit warning, was still there:

*Guests are responsible for knowing and obeying Malaysian law. The hostel is not liable.*

The building breathed. The lanterns glowed. The air well was dark and wet from the afternoon rain. The mosaic bench held no plate. The drain at the corner held the faintest trace of sambal, a red residue that the rain had not fully washed away, a mark that would be gone by morning but was, for now, still visible -- the colour of chillies and the colour of blood and the colour of lanterns, the red that was the building's signature, the red that meant warmth and welcome and warning, the red that said: *come in, the door is open, the bed is ready, the price is listed, the law is posted, the rest is up to you*.

---

*End of Chapter 41*
# Chapter 42: Priya's War

The flat in Bermondsey was cold.

Not the cold of Kuala Lumpur's air conditioning, which was the cold of machines -- the aggressive, artificial chill that Malaysian buildings deployed against the equatorial heat, the cold that hit like a wall when you walked through a door and announced that you had crossed from outside to inside, from the natural world to the institutional one. This was a different cold. This was London cold. February cold. The cold of a city that existed at fifty-one degrees north and had been grey since October and would remain grey until April and the greyness was not an absence of colour but a colour itself, the pervasive, suffocating grey that was London's contribution to the emotional spectrum, the grey that entered buildings through single-glazed windows and settled on surfaces and on people and on the interior architecture of the mind.

Priya Sharma sat at the kitchen table in the flat she shared with two other medical students in a converted warehouse on Tanner Street, SE1, and the table was covered with paper.

The paper was the evidence. The paper was the reconstruction. The paper was the project that she had been building since she landed at Heathrow thirty hours ago, since she cleared customs and turned on her phone and found three missed calls from Tomoko and two from a Malaysian number she didn't recognise and a text from Razak that said only *Priya. Call me now.* and she had stood in the arrivals hall at Terminal 4 with the phone pressed to her ear and the crowds flowing around her and Razak had told her and the telling had taken forty-seven seconds and in those forty-seven seconds the world had changed, the atoms of the world had rearranged themselves into a configuration that did not include Connor Briggs alive on the earth, and the rearrangement had activated something in her that was not grief, not yet, not the grief that would come later when the adrenaline subsided and the project was done and there was nothing left to build, but something harder, something colder, something that her medical training had given a vocabulary for but that no training could prepare a person to feel.

"Dead," Razak had said. "In the cell. Last night. The police are saying suicide."

She had stood in arrivals. The arrivals hall at Heathrow Terminal 4 smelled of jet fuel and floor polish and the accumulated exhalation of a thousand passengers. A family was reuniting next to her -- a man lifting a child, a woman crying with happiness, the sound of the happy crying entering Priya's ears at the same moment as the word *dead* and the two sounds existing simultaneously in the same airspace, the sound of reunion and the sound of permanent separation occupying the same cubic centimetre of air.

She had not cried then. She had not cried in the taxi home. She had cried at 2:17 AM, alone in her bedroom, when she had written the words *Feb 14, 02:17 AM MYT -- body discovered in Cell C-7* and the specificity of the time had broken something that the word *dead* had not broken, because the word was abstract and the time was specific and the cell number was a location -- a three-by-three-metre concrete room with a fluorescent light that never turned off -- and she had been asleep on a plane over the Bay of Bengal at 2:17 AM and she had been asleep while he was dying and the sleeping was the thing that undid her, the sleeping was the betrayal, the failure of her body to know across eleven time zones that the person she loved was fighting for his life in a cell in Dang Wangi.

She was a fourth-year medical student at King's College London. She had completed rotations in emergency medicine, in surgery, in oncology. She had seen death in the clinical context -- the controlled, documented, institutionally managed cessation of life that occurred in hospitals. She had held the hand of an eighty-four-year-old man in his final hours because his family was in traffic on the M25 and someone needed to be there.

She understood death. The physiology. The bureaucracy. The paperwork.

The understanding made the emotional understanding worse.

Because she knew what ligature strangulation did to the body -- the compression of the carotid arteries, the loss of consciousness in eight to twelve seconds, the irreversible brain damage in four to six minutes. She knew the physical sensations -- the pressure, the panic, the involuntary struggle, the narrowing of vision. She knew these things because she had studied them, and the knowledge that had been abstract and academic was now specific and personal and applied to a throat she had kissed, to a neck she had rested her head against on a rooftop in Kuala Lumpur while the Petronas Towers glittered and he had said something stupid and wonderful and she had laughed and the laughing had been the sound of a woman falling in love with a man she knew was doomed and could not stop falling because love did not consult the evidence before making its decisions.

She knew what the towel had done. She knew the timeline -- the seconds, the minutes, the physiological stages. She could narrate the death with medical precision, and the precision was a knife, and the knife was inside her, and the knife turned every time she thought about the blue towel, the blue Sea to Summit microfiber towel that he had hung on the bunk rail every night and that she had used once, wrapped around herself after a shower in the hostel's perpetually damp bathroom, the towel that had smelled of sunscreen and salt water and him.

The jade bracelet on her left wrist caught the grey light from the kitchen window. The bracelet was green -- the deep, cool, translucent green of nephrite jade, the green that the night market vendor had called *lucky green, very good fortune*, the green that Connor had pointed to and said "That one, the green one, it matches her" and had paid forty ringgit for without bargaining, the only time in six weeks that Connor Briggs had not bargained, the only purchase he had made in Malaysia where the price asked was the price paid, because the bracelet was for her and for her the rules were different and the difference was love and the love was the thing she wore on her wrist and could not remove because removing it would be an ending and she was not ready for endings.

The bracelet was cool against her skin. The bracelet was always cool. Jade held the temperature of its environment, and the environment was a flat in Bermondsey in February, and the temperature was cold.

The grief would come. The grief was already coming -- she could feel it in the periphery, the way you could feel a migraine approaching before it arrived, the aura that preceded the pain. But not yet. The grief was being held at bay by the project, by the paper on the table, by the work.

---

The paper on the table was arranged in columns. The columns were chronological. The columns were labelled in Priya's handwriting -- small, precise, the handwriting of a medical student who had learned that legibility was not optional.

Column 1: DATES. Every date that mattered, from Connor's arrival at the Lantern Hostel (Day 1, January 1) to his death (Day 47, February 14). Forty-seven days, each one a row, each row annotated with what she knew had happened.

Column 2: DELIVERIES. Every delivery she had confirmed or suspected. Day 6: envelope to Bukit Bintang. Day 9: package to Brickfields. Day 11 onwards: scheduled deliveries, locations listed where known. Day 47: suitcase, bus to Penang, 450 grams of methamphetamine.

Column 3: PEOPLE. Felix Decker. Wei. Rizal. Guard Hafiz. Inspector Kamal. Every name Connor had mentioned to her, every name she had overheard, every name she had inferred from three weeks of watching a man she loved walk deeper into something she couldn't name but could feel.

Column 4: EVIDENCE. Tomoko's photographs. Mei Ling's booking records. Razak's cooperation. Connor's own Instagram -- @ConnorGoesGlobal, 4,200 followers, the curated digital life of a man who had documented his own entrapment in sunset filters and nine-hashtag captions without knowing it. The @HostelReaper posts. Connor's bank records. Felix's flight record (MH752, KL to Phnom Penh, 04:15 AM, February 14, the same morning, the same hours).

Column 5: WHAT THE REPORT SAYS. Suicide while in custody.

Column 6: WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENED. Murder.

She adjusted her glasses. She had been wearing her glasses for thirty hours straight because her eyes were too swollen from the 2:17 AM crying to tolerate contact lenses, the crying that happened in bursts, unpredictable, the body releasing grief in controlled detonations while the mind continued working, one building and one destroying, one constructing the case and one processing the loss.

She picked up her phone.

---

The call to Sergeant Ahmad connected on the fourth ring.

"Pejabat Polis Dang Wangi. Sergeant Ahmad."

"Sergeant Ahmad, this is Priya Sharma. I sent you a letter. From London. About Connor Briggs and the Lantern Hostel."

Half a second of silence. Priya heard him shift in his chair, heard the ambient noise of the police station -- the phones, the footsteps, the hum of air conditioning -- and within the ambient noise, the specific silence of a man who was about to have a conversation that he could not have freely but would have carefully.

"Miss Sharma. Yes. I received your letter. This morning."

"Then you know it wasn't suicide."

Another pause. This one longer. The length of the pause was the length of a man choosing his words with the precision that his position demanded, the precision that distinguished a statement from an implication, a fact from an opinion, an official position from a personal belief.

"I can confirm that an investigation has been opened into the circumstances of Mr. Briggs's death. I cannot provide details about the investigation at this time."

"He was murdered. In your station. In a cell in your station. By a man named Rizal who was placed in the cell to kill him, who used Connor's own towel -- a towel that should have been confiscated during processing under SOP 14.2.3 -- and who was released two hours after the body was discovered. The guard on duty took a bribe. The report was filed by the same inspector who authorised Rizal's release. Felix Decker, the man who recruited Connor into the trafficking network, boarded a flight to Cambodia before the body was officially found."

The silence that followed was not the silence of a man who was hearing new information. The silence was the silence of a man who was recalibrating his assessment of the person on the other end of the phone, the recalibration that occurred when a professional who had been evaluating people for twenty years encountered someone who had done the homework, who had the evidence, who was not the bereaved partner he might have expected but was instead a precise, controlled, furious intelligence pointing itself at his case like an instrument.

"Miss Sharma. I want to be clear about something. Off the record."

"I'm listening."

"The official report was filed by an officer who is not part of my division. The investigation I am conducting is separate. It is looking at the full circumstances -- the detention, the cell assignment, the guard's conduct, the cellmate's background, and the network. This investigation is active and it is progressing. But it takes time. Evidence must be gathered properly. Legal standards must be met. The people responsible -- all of them, not just the ones in the cell -- must be identified and charged through a process that will hold up in court. Do you understand?"

"I understand. I also understand that every day that passes is a day that Felix Decker spends in Cambodia and a day that the official report says suicide and a day that the truth stays on page seven."

The reference to page seven was deliberate. Tomoko had sent Priya a photograph of the article in The Star -- the article she had found online three hours after the phone call from Razak, the article she had found by searching "Connor Briggs Malaysia" and "death custody Dang Wangi" and "Australian drug trafficking KL," the searches producing a single result, a single article, six paragraphs on page seven of a Saturday newspaper, 147 words between a condominium advertisement and a water main break.

She had read the 147 words on her phone screen, the jade bracelet cold on her wrist, and the words had produced a sensation that was not grief and was not anger but was something between the two, something in the territory where the emotional response to injustice was indistinguishable from the emotional response to loss.

*FOREIGN NATIONAL DIES IN POLICE CUSTODY.* Six paragraphs. Connor James Briggs, 27, of Melbourne. Suicide by hanging. Standard procedures.

"Miss Sharma." Ahmad's voice was careful now, the careful of a man making a decision. "Please send your detailed statement to my direct email. Everything you have -- dates, names, locations, observations, documentation. Everything."

"I already have it prepared. Twelve pages. Single-spaced."

"Of course you do."

The sentence was not sarcasm. The sentence was recognition -- the first moment of professional respect between a Malaysian narcotics sergeant and a British-Indian medical student, the respect that emerged when two people who were separately pursuing the same truth discovered that their pursuits were converging.

"And Sergeant Ahmad -- I want you to know that I intend to contact SUARAM. And the press. And the families of previous victims, if the pattern is what I think it is."

A pause. The pause of a police officer weighing the utility of an activist against the complications of one.

"I cannot advise you on your personal actions, Miss Sharma. I can tell you that the investigation benefits from public pressure. Off the record."

"Understood."

She hung up. She sat at the table. She opened her laptop. The statement was already written -- twelve pages, the medical-student precision of every date, every delivery, every conversation, every warning ignored. The statement was not emotional. The statement was clinical. The statement was the anatomy of a murder, dissected and labelled with the same care that a medical student brought to the dissection of a cadaver.

She attached the document. She pressed send. The email left London at 11:47 AM GMT. It arrived in Kuala Lumpur at 7:47 PM MYT. It was the second piece of ammunition that Ahmad's investigation had received that day -- the first being Priya's letter, the letter she had posted at Heathrow before boarding her flight home, the letter that had arrived at Dang Wangi on the morning of February 14, seventeen hours before Connor's death was discovered, the letter that had been on time and too late simultaneously, the letter that was the right action at the wrong time.

---

The second call was to SUARAM.

SUARAM -- Suara Rakyat Malaysia, the Voice of the Malaysian People -- was a human rights organisation based in Petaling Jaya that had been documenting deaths in Malaysian police custody for thirty-seven years. Two hundred and fifty-seven documented cases since 2000. Priya had found them through a Google search at 2:00 AM, the night when sleep was not available and the alternative to sleep was research.

A case coordinator named Fatimah answered. Her voice carried not desensitisation but calibration -- the adjustment of the emotional register to a level that was empathetic without being overwhelmed, the register of a person who had heard this kind of call many times.

"SUARAM, Fatimah speaking."

"My name is Priya Sharma. I'm calling from London. My partner, Connor Briggs, was found dead in a holding cell at Dang Wangi police station on February 14th. The official report says suicide. It was murder."

Fatimah did not ask for proof. Fatimah said: "Tell me everything."

Priya told her. The telling took forty-seven minutes -- a minute per day, she would realise later, though the symmetry was a coincidence and not a plan. She told Fatimah about Felix, about the deliveries, about the escalation from envelope to package to backpack to suitcase, about the towel that should not have been in the cell, about the cellmate, about the guard's absence.

"The towel being in the cell is significant," Fatimah said. "SOP 14.2.3 requires removal of all ligature-risk items. In our records, sixty-three percent of hanging deaths in custody involved a ligature that should have been removed during processing. The failure is either negligence or complicity."

"I believe there are other victims. The same pattern. The same cellmate."

"We'll file a formal inquiry with the Inspector General of Police. We'll request the full incident report, the guard's duty log, the cell assignment records, and the release documentation. We'll also request the post-mortem -- the autopsy may contain evidence inconsistent with suicide."

Defensive injuries. The phrase activated the medical knowledge she had been both using and suffering from -- broken fingernails, abrasions from the victim's own hands trying to pull the ligature away, petechial haemorrhaging, bruising inconsistent with self-inflicted hanging. She knew Connor had fought. She knew this not from evidence but from knowing him, from knowing the body that had surfed and held her on a rooftop, the body that would not have submitted without the desperate, futile struggle that was the body's final argument against its own extinction.

"I'll send you everything I have," Priya said.

"And Miss Sharma -- the right to life is not conditional on innocence. Connor Briggs was entitled to the protection of the law. The law failed him."

Priya thanked her. She hung up. The flat in Bermondsey was still cold but the cold was now a background condition rather than a foreground sensation because the foreground was occupied by the sensation of mechanisms activating, of the process of accountability beginning to turn.

---

At 4:00 PM, Priya opened Connor's Instagram on her laptop.

@ConnorGoesGlobal. 4,200 followers. The last post: a selfie at a Petaling Street night market stall, the caption "KL, you absolute legend" and nine hashtags. The post had forty-seven likes. The post had been made six days before his death. The account was still live, still public, the digital ghost of a man who had curated his own trajectory toward destruction in golden-hour filters and #livingmybestlife captions.

She scrolled through the feed. The feed was a timeline no one had looked at yet because the feed was Instagram and Instagram was not where investigators looked. But the feed was evidence.

The early posts were the usual -- KLIA2 grin, Petronas Towers at sunset, nasi lemak with Mama Siti's hand at the frame's edge. The feed of a man becoming a city. Then:

Day 9: Connor and Felix on the rooftop. Felix's hand on Connor's shoulder. Caption: "New mate Felix. This bloke's been everywhere. Legend." Thirty-one likes, and not one of the thirty-one had looked at that hand and seen a handler establishing contact with a recruit.

Day 14: The jade bracelet on Priya's wrist, the jade green against her brown skin, the night market lights blurred behind. Caption: "She said she didn't want anything. I said the bracelet did." Forty-four likes. His most-liked post. The only one where the caption was not performing.

Day 38: the last photograph. A sunset from the hostel rooftop, no caption, no hashtags. Just the sky and the city and the silence of a man who had, perhaps, run out of words.

Priya took screenshots. Every post. Every photograph. Every caption. Every date. She organised them chronologically in a folder on her desktop. The folder was labelled CONNOR -- INSTAGRAM EVIDENCE. The folder would be sent to Ahmad, to SUARAM, to the journalist she was about to contact.

Then she opened a new browser tab. She logged into her own Instagram -- @priya.s.sharma, 312 followers, mostly medical school friends and family. She had not posted in three months. She did not use social media the way Connor had used it, the way a generation used it, as a mirror and a megaphone and a substitute for the interior life that the platform simultaneously demanded and destroyed.

She created a new post. The image was Connor's Day 14 photograph -- the jade bracelet on her wrist. She had saved it months ago, when he posted it, when she was still at the hostel, when she had seen it in her feed and had smiled and had not known that the photograph would become an artefact, a relic, the digital equivalent of a saint's bone, the evidence that a person had existed and had loved and had been loved.

The caption she wrote was not @ConnorGoesGlobal's voice. The caption was Priya's voice. The caption was precise and it was controlled and it was the opening salvo of a campaign that she was building in real time, the campaign that would give the machinery a name and the name would be a hashtag and the hashtag would be the thing that moved the story from page seven to the place where stories that mattered lived.

*Connor James Briggs, 27, from Melbourne, Australia, died on February 14, 2026, in a police holding cell at Dang Wangi District Police Headquarters, Kuala Lumpur. The official report says suicide. It was not suicide. He was murdered.*

*Connor was my partner. Connor was a person -- not a case file, not a headline, not a statistic. He was kind and he was careless and he was loved. He was manipulated by a drug trafficking network that used him as a mule and then killed him when he was arrested because dead men can't testify.*

*The Malaysian police report is a lie. The 147-word article on page 7 of The Star is not the story. This is the story. Connor deserves the truth and the truth requires your attention.*

*#JusticeForConnor #DeathInCustody #ConnorBriggs #DangWangi*

She posted it. The post went live at 4:47 PM GMT, 12:47 AM MYT. The algorithm would decide whether a jade bracelet and a dead man and the word *murdered* constituted the kind of content that generated the engagement metrics the platform rewarded with visibility.

The algorithm decided yes.

By midnight the post had been shared 340 times. By morning, 2,100. The hashtag #JusticeForConnor appeared in the feeds of human rights organisations, travel bloggers, Australian media accounts, Malaysian civil society groups. A journalist from The Age in Melbourne screenshotted the post and wrote a 1,200-word article: "British Medical Student Claims Aussie Backpacker Was Murdered in Malaysian Custody." The article was on page three. The article named Felix Decker. The article quoted SUARAM. Twelve times the length of the 147-word piece in The Star.

Priya watched the numbers from her kitchen table. The accumulation of attention was a form of pressure, and the pressure was the thing that institutions responded to not because they had consciences but because they had public relations departments, and the metrics included the number of times an institution's name appeared in proximity to the word *murder*, and the number was rising.

---

The call to Karen Briggs was the hardest.

She had saved it for last. She had made the other calls first -- to Ahmad, to SUARAM, to the British consulate, to a journalist at The Star named Lim Wei Ling whose byline had appeared on the 147-word article -- she had made these calls because these calls had structure, because these calls had objectives, because these calls engaged the part of her brain that was trained and competent and capable. These calls were work. The call to Karen was not work. The call to Karen was the thing that no training prepared a person for.

She dialled the number. Connor had called his mother from Priya's phone once, on the rooftop, on a night when his phone was dead. He had dialled from memory -- the digits stored not in the phone but in the body, in the fingers that had dialled the number since childhood -- and Priya had seen the number on her call log and saved it, not knowing why.

Karen answered on the second ring. The speed of a woman answering every call because every call might contain new information.

"Hello?" The voice was stripped. Not the social voice, not the telephone voice. The voice that existed beneath all the other voices, produced when the social infrastructure had collapsed and all that remained was the mechanism -- the vocal cords, the breath, the words.

"Mrs. Briggs, this is Priya Sharma. I was... I knew Connor. In Kuala Lumpur."

"Priya." The name was spoken with recognition -- not from having met but from having been told. Connor had mentioned her to his mother on one of the Sunday calls, the calls he answered every third week, the curated, abbreviated narration that children used with parents, and Priya had been one of the good parts. "He told me about you. He said you were brilliant. He said you were the smartest person he'd ever met."

The information arrived in Priya's body and the processing produced the tears -- the involuntary release that occurred when the emotional stimulus exceeded the cognitive capacity. The tears were not a decision. The tears were a hydraulic event. She let them come because the tears were the body's way of doing what the mind could not, which was to acknowledge the magnitude of the loss.

"Karen. I need to tell you something about how Connor died. And I need you to listen, because what I'm going to tell you is different from what the police report says."

"I know." The words were immediate. The words were the words of a mother who had known since the phone call at 3 AM, who had heard the word *suicide* and had rejected it the way a body rejected a foreign organ, immediately, completely, at the cellular level. "I know it wasn't suicide. David knows. We both know. Connor would not have... he was not... he was many things, Priya, he was careless and stubborn and infuriating and he didn't listen, God knows he didn't listen, but he was not that. He wouldn't have."

"He didn't."

The two words travelled from London to Melbourne and the two words were the confirmation of what Karen already believed and the confirmation changed nothing and changed everything, the way a diagnosis changed nothing about the disease but changed everything about the patient's relationship to the disease, the naming of the thing giving the thing a shape that could be grasped and, eventually, fought.

Priya told her. The controlled, precise language. Felix. The deliveries. Rizal. The towel. The guard. The investigation. SUARAM. The statement.

Karen listened. Karen's listening was the listening of a mother -- the filter that converted every fact into a felt experience, every element of the story into a moment in the life of a child she had borne and raised and loved and worried about and sent money to and called every Sunday and not heard from often enough and lost.

When Priya finished, the silence was the silence of two women in two cities on two continents who loved the same man and who were both refusing to let the destruction be the end of the story.

"We're flying to KL," Karen said. "David and I. To bring him home."

"I know. The High Commission's Sarah Chen -- I've been in contact with her. She'll meet you."

"Will you be there?"

The question was the extension of a hand across twelve thousand kilometres. Priya looked at the jade bracelet on her wrist. She looked at the paper on the table. She looked at the grey February light pressing against the kitchen window.

"My term starts Monday. My clinical placements..."

"Of course. I'm sorry. I shouldn't have--"

"No. Wait." The word came before the decision, or perhaps the word was the decision, the body making the choice before the mind could intervene with logistics and obligations and the reasonable objections that reasonable people offered when unreasonable things were asked of them. "I'll come. I need to come. The evidence I have, the contacts -- Ahmad, SUARAM, Tomoko at the hostel -- I need to be there. I can defer the placement. I'll speak to my supervisor."

The decision was not rational. The decision was the decision of a woman who had sent a letter from Heathrow and the letter had arrived seventeen hours too late and the lateness was the thing she carried. She had left KL and Connor had died. The leaving was the thing she could not undo but could answer with the inverse action -- the return, the going back to the place where the loss had occurred to ensure that the loss was not also a silence.

"Thank you," Karen said. "Thank you."

"And Karen?"

"Yes?"

"He talked about you. Every day. Not on the phone -- on the phone he was performing. But in person, when it was just us, when it was late and he wasn't performing, he talked about you. Sunday roasts. The cricket on TV. Vegemite toast when he came home from school. He talked about you the way people talk about the thing they love most and are most afraid of losing."

The sound that Karen made was not the sound she had made in the hallway at 3 AM. That sound had been the sound of a mother learning her child was dead. This sound was different. This sound was the sound of a mother learning her child had loved her, had spoken of her with tenderness to a woman he cared about, had carried her in the part of himself that was not the Instagram persona, not the digital nomad, not @ConnorGoesGlobal, but the boy from Hawthorn who missed his mother's Vegemite toast.

The sound was private. Priya held it the way she had been trained to hold the sounds that patients made -- with presence, with silence, with the understanding that some sounds required not a response but a witness.

"Will they catch the people who did this?" Karen asked.

"I'm going to make sure of it."

The words were a declaration of intent made by a woman who had arranged the evidence on her kitchen table and made four phone calls and written a twelve-page statement and launched a hashtag that was, at this moment, converting the 147-word page-seven silence into noise, into visibility, into the pressure that moved stories from the margins to the centre.

Justice was not enough. Justice was never enough. Justice was the consolation prize that the living gave to the dead, the acknowledgement that the system had failed and the failure would be documented and the documentation would be called accountability -- partial, insufficient, necessary. Necessary because the alternative was nothing, and nothing was not acceptable, and the refusal to accept nothing was the engine that drove the campaign, the anger that Priya Sharma carried in her chest like a second heart, beating alongside the first, generating the energy that grief alone could not provide.

---

She hung up the phone. She sat at the table. The paper was still there. The columns were still there. The evidence was still there.

She opened her laptop. On the screen, the #JusticeForConnor post was accumulating. The numbers were rising. The system was responding. The story was migrating.

She opened a new email. The email was to Lim Wei Ling, the journalist at The Star. The email would be the beginning of a professional relationship that would last months, that would result in investigative articles that moved from page seven to page three to page one, that would name Felix Decker and the network and the pattern of deaths in custody, that would cite SUARAM's records and Priya's statement and Tomoko's photographs, that would force the Inspector General of Police to convene a special inquiry.

But that was the future. That was weeks and months of the slow, grinding process of a truth migrating from the margins to the centre, from 147 words to fourteen thousand.

For now, Priya typed. The flat was cold. The grey was at the windows. The jade bracelet was cool on her wrist. The paper was on the table. The second heart was beating.

She had a flight to book.

---

*End of Chapter 42*
# Chapter 43: The Investigation

## I. The Letter

The letter arrived at Dang Wangi at 7:47 PM on Saturday, February 15th -- seventeen hours after Connor Briggs was pronounced dead in Holding Cell C-7 on the ground floor of the same building in which Sergeant Ahmad bin Ismail now sat, at his desk, on the second floor, in the narcotics division, reading the email that had travelled from a kitchen table in Bermondsey to his inbox in the time it took for a signal to cross eleven time zones, which was approximately one point four seconds, which was less time than it took for a man to lose consciousness under ligature compression, which was the fact that Ahmad's mind produced without his permission, the fact arriving the way facts arrived in the minds of police officers who had spent twenty years learning the technical specifications of death.

The email was from a woman named Priya Sharma. The email was twelve pages. The email was single-spaced. The email was, in its precision and its controlled fury, the most comprehensive witness statement Ahmad had received in his twenty years with the Royal Malaysia Police -- and the statement had not been written by a police officer or a prosecutor or a forensic investigator but by a fourth-year medical student at King's College London who was sitting in a cold flat six thousand miles away and who had assembled, from memory and observation and the careful accumulation of forty-seven days of paying attention, a document that mapped the entire architecture of a trafficking network operating out of a phone repair shop on Petaling Street.

Ahmad read the letter twice.

He read it once quickly, the way a man reads when the content is urgent and the time is limited -- the eyes scanning, the mind filtering for names and dates and locations, the executive summary that the brain performed automatically when confronted with a document that contained more information than could be processed in a single pass. The first reading yielded: Felix Decker. Wei. Rizal. Guard Hafiz. Inspector Kamal. The Lantern Hostel. The phone repair shop. The suitcase. The towel. The death that was not a suicide.

He read it a second time slowly. The second reading was the reading that mattered -- the reading in which the details emerged from between the facts, the reading in which the connections became visible, the reading in which the letter transformed from a statement into a map and the map showed him not just what had happened but how the system worked, the system that had recruited Connor Briggs and used him and killed him and filed a report that said suicide, the system that Ahmad had suspected existed but had lacked the external evidence to prove.

He had given Connor Briggs his card.

The memory surfaced from the spreadsheet he kept on the personal laptop at home -- the ThinkPad in the drawer beside his bed, password-protected, the laptop where he tracked the investigation that did not officially exist. In the notes column beside what would become Connor's row, he had written weeks earlier: *Checkpoint stop, Jalan Alor area, approx. January 20. Australian male, cooperative. Passport PA7734819. Advised caution. Gave card.* The card was one of four hundred and twelve that Ahmad had given out in six years -- his own cards, printed at his own expense at a shop in Brickfields, each bearing his name, his rank, his number, and a line in English and Bahasa Melayu that no official protocol required but that Ahmad had added because the system did not protect people and someone had to try:

*If you are in trouble with Malaysian law, call this number before you speak to anyone else.*

Connor had kept the card. Connor had placed it in his wallet beside his Australian driver's licence. And Priya's letter told Ahmad what happened next: Connor had dialled the number. In the final days, when the truth about what he was carrying had become undeniable, Connor had held the phone to his ear and heard the line connect and had hung up after three seconds -- three seconds in which Ahmad's phone had registered an incoming call from an unknown number and Ahmad had looked at the screen and let it ring because unknown numbers at midnight were usually nothing, wrong numbers or telemarketers or the noise of a telecommunications system producing its thousands of daily errant connections.

Three seconds. The width of the gap between a man asking for help and a man deciding not to. Three seconds that Ahmad would carry the way Priya carried the jade bracelet, the way Karen carried the silence at 3 AM -- the personal artefact of a near-miss that was worse than no contact because no contact was the absence of possibility and the three-second call was the presence of possibility that existed and expired.

Ahmad put the card back in the drawer. He closed the drawer.

He began to work.

---

## II. The Towel

The investigation began with Standard Operating Procedure 14.2.3.

Detention of Persons Pending Charge. Seventeen pages. Step 14 of the processing protocol: *All items presenting a risk of self-harm shall be removed from the detained person prior to placement in a holding cell. Items include but are not limited to: belts, shoelaces, drawstrings, scarves, lanyards, ropes, cables, towels, bedsheets, and any item of clothing or equipment that could be fashioned into a ligature.*

Towels. The word was in the protocol. The word was printed on the laminated card attached to the wall of the processing room, the card that every officer passed every time they processed a detainee, the card that was positioned at eye level, the card that was impossible to miss unless missing it was the intention.

Constable Hafiz bin Mohd Noor had processed Connor Briggs at 17:08 hours on February 13th. Hafiz had catalogued the belongings -- wallet, phone, sandals, bracelet -- and placed them in a plastic bag. The blue Sea to Summit microfiber travel towel was not in the bag. The processing log contained a marginal note in Hafiz's handwriting: *Towel left with detainee for comfort.* Two words in a margin. Either an act of kindness or an act of preparation. The determination of which would be the first thread that Ahmad pulled.

Ahmad pulled it on a Tuesday evening, six days after the letter arrived.

The pulling was not dramatic. The pulling was digital -- a number on a screen in a banking database, the result of a court order that Ahmad had obtained from a magistrate at the Kuala Lumpur Magistrate's Court, the order compelling Bank Negara Malaysia to provide transaction records for Savings Account 7142-8899-3301 at Maybank, Jalan Tun Perak branch, the account registered to Hafiz bin Mohd Noor.

At 10:47 PM on February 13, 2026 -- approximately an hour before Connor Briggs was found dead -- a deposit of RM5,000 had been made to the account. The deposit was via cash transfer at an ATM on Jalan Bukit Bintang, a machine that accepted deposits without a card, without identification, without the human intermediary of a teller window. Anonymous. Untraceable in the traditional sense.

But the deposit was there. RM5,000 in an account that had not received a deposit larger than RM2,800 -- Hafiz's monthly salary -- in the previous twelve months. The deposit was made on the night that Hafiz had left a towel in a cell where a towel should not have been, on the night that Hafiz had taken a forty-minute bathroom break during which the cell was unmonitored, on the night that Hafiz had returned to find a body and had filed a statement saying he discovered it during a routine check.

Ahmad printed the transaction record. He opened the CCTV footage from the custody corridor -- footage he had subpoenaed on Sunday, the day after the letter arrived, from the station's own surveillance system, the subpoena necessary because the footage was under Inspector Kamal's administrative control and Kamal had not included it in the original report. The subpoena bypassed Kamal. The subpoena was the legal instrument that allowed Ahmad to access evidence in his own building without the permission of the man who had reason to ensure the evidence was never seen.

The footage showed: at 23:15, Hafiz standing from his desk, removing his earbuds, walking toward the toilet at the end of the corridor. He did not return until 23:55. Forty minutes. The custody corridor was empty for forty minutes. Whatever happened in Cell C-7 happened without a witness whose testimony the investigation could compel.

The footage showed something else. At 04:27 AM -- approximately two hours after the body was discovered -- a man walked out of the custody wing through the rear door to the station car park. Medium build. Grey institutional tracksuit. The unhurried gait of a person who was not fleeing but departing, not escaping but being released. Ahmad tracked the man through the external cameras: across the car park, through the rear gate -- the gate that was supposed to be locked after midnight, the gate whose keypad code was known only to custody wing officers -- and left onto Jalan Dang Wangi, where a silver Toyota Vios waited on the opposite kerb, engine running, headlights off, registration plates removed. The man opened the rear door. Climbed in. The car pulled away eastbound.

Timestamp: 04:32 AM. Vehicle description submitted to PDRM traffic division. The Vios would not appear on any camera after Jalan Dang Wangi. The Vios would vanish the way the man inside it would vanish -- professionally, completely.

But Ahmad had the footage. Ahmad had the timestamp. Ahmad had the open gate. And from Priya's letter and the station's own records, Ahmad had the name of the officer who had authorised the man's release at 04:30 AM: Inspector Kamal bin Yusof. The same inspector who filed the death report. The same inspector who classified Connor Briggs's death as suicide.

Ahmad placed the transaction record and the CCTV analysis in the folder on his desk. The folder was growing.

He was building a case against a superior officer in his own station. The case was being constructed in the same building where the crime had been committed, the evidence gathered from the same systems that the suspects had access to. The geometry was the geometry of a man defusing a device that he was standing on.

---

## III. The Pattern

The IC number was the key.

Mohd Rizal bin Ahmad. Identity Card 890412-14-5567. Ahmad entered the number into the PDRM criminal records database on a Monday morning, nine days after Connor's death, his office door closed, his screen angled away from the corridor window. The database returned a thin record -- deliberately thin, the kind maintained at minimum detail because maximum detail would have revealed what Ahmad was looking for.

Ahmad was not looking in the local records. Ahmad was looking across jurisdictions.

The PDRM's databases were siloed by district, each station's records existing in isolation, the information architecture designed for local case management rather than pattern detection across multiple stations. The pattern was there. The pattern had been there for years. The pattern had been invisible because the system was not designed to see its own patterns, the way a mirror was not designed to reflect itself.

Ahmad cross-referenced. He pulled detention records from four districts. The cross-referencing took three days -- three days of formal requests and inter-station protocols and the bureaucratic friction that the system generated when one station asked another station for records, the friction that was normally an inconvenience but that in this case was the barrier that had prevented the pattern from being detected, the administrative architecture that had allowed a man to move from cell to cell across the Klang Valley leaving bodies behind him without any single station connecting its death to the deaths in the other stations.

The cross-reference produced:

IC 890412-14-5567 -- the number registered to Mohd Rizal bin Ahmad -- appeared in the detention records of four other police stations. Each appearance followed the same structure: arrested on a minor charge, placed in a holding cell with a prisoner facing drug trafficking charges, the prisoner found dead within twelve hours, death classified as suicide, Rizal released the following morning.

Serdang. July 2023. Cellmate: Daniel Park, 24, Korean-American. 200g methamphetamine. Found dead at 03:40 AM. Ligature: belt. Should have been removed per SOP 14.2.3. Rizal released 05:15 AM.

Shah Alam. January 2024. Cellmate: Mikhail Sorokin, 29, Russian. 180g methamphetamine. Found dead at 02:55 AM. Ligature: drawstring from tracksuit trousers. Should have been removed. Rizal released 04:00 AM.

Petaling Jaya. June 2024. Cellmate: Abdul Rahim bin Yusof, 31, Malaysian. 75g methamphetamine. Found dead at 01:20 AM. Ligature: shoelaces. Should have been removed. Rizal released 03:45 AM.

Sentul. October 2025. Cellmate: Suresh Pillai, 35, Malaysian-Indian. 120g methamphetamine. Found dead at 04:10 AM. Ligature: towel. Rizal released 05:30 AM.

Dang Wangi. February 2026. Cellmate: Connor James Briggs, 27, Australian. 450g methamphetamine. Found dead at 02:17 AM. Ligature: microfiber travel towel. Rizal released 04:30 AM.

Five cells. Five cellmates. Five dead. Five suicides. Five ligatures that should have been removed. Five releases in the hours following the death.

Ahmad looked at the list. The list was not a list. The list was a production schedule. The list was the operational record of a man whose function in the network was the elimination of arrested mules, a function performed with the regularity of a maintenance task, the network activating the protocol when a mule was caught the way a company activated its insurance policy when an asset was compromised -- automatically, procedurally, without sentiment.

Five dead. Five human beings who had been converted to five rows in Ahmad's spreadsheet, five cases in the PDRM system, five entries that SUARAM had documented without connecting them, five families in five countries who had received phone calls in the night and been told the word *suicide*. The word had been accepted by the system because the system had accepted it, each station examining its own death in isolation, each death an anomaly within its own district, the anomalies never aggregated, the pattern never assembled, the five data points never plotted on the same graph.

Until now. Until a letter from London and a spreadsheet on a ThinkPad in Wangsa Maju and a narcotics sergeant who could not stop following patterns.

Ahmad called the Deputy Public Prosecutor's office. The call initiated the process by which evidence became authority -- the process of warrants and charges that would give a sergeant the power to arrest the people in his folder, regardless of their rank or their proximity to his own desk.

---

## IV. The Arrests

The warrants were executed on a Thursday morning.

February 27th. 06:00 AM. Thirteen days after Connor Briggs's death. Three warrants. Three simultaneous operations -- the simultaneity coordinated so that no arrest would alert the others, the timing the tactical requirement of an investigation that could not afford to lose a suspect to flight. Ahmad had requested operational support from the Federal Narcotics Division at Bukit Aman -- not Dang Wangi officers, not officers who owed their positions to Inspector Kamal or their loyalty to the institutional hierarchy that Kamal occupied. The request was the tactical decision that removed the operation from the jurisdiction of the compromised station and placed it in the hands of the institution that the station answered to.

The first arrest was at WEI'S MOBILE: REPAIRS & ACCESSORIES, Petaling Street.

The shutters were down. The shop had been closed since February 14th -- since the morning when Wei had arrived for work and found Petaling Street full of police cars and the hostel cordoned off and had understood, with the immediate calculation of a man who knew what the police cars meant, that the protocol had been activated and the aftermath was two doors away. Wei had not run. Running was the amateur's response. Wei had closed the shop and maintained his routine and waited, the stillness of a man who understood that disappearance attracted attention and that the system processed the visible and overlooked the still.

The Bukit Aman team breached the shutters at 06:02 AM. The sound was the investigation's first public act -- metal giving way, the screech of the roller mechanism, the percussion of entry on Petaling Street. The char kway teow vendor across the road was lighting his wok, the blue flame catching. He watched the way vendors watched everything on Petaling Street -- with the studied indifference of a man who had been selling noodles in the same spot for twenty years and who had learned that the business of the street and the business of the police were parallel tracks that never touched.

Wei was in the back room. The back room contained what Ahmad's surveillance had anticipated and what Priya's letter had described: a vacuum sealer, commercial grade; a digital scale accurate to 0.1 grams; rolls of cling film; empty phone charger boxes with their interior padding removed; and on the stainless steel table, three vacuum-sealed bags containing a white crystalline substance that would field-test positive for methamphetamine. Packaging materials. The infrastructure of a logistics operation.

Wei was arrested. Wei said nothing. Wei's silence was the silence of a professional calculating the cost of every word, the silence that would hold for approximately fourteen hours before the evidence from the back room and the bank records and the CCTV footage from Wei's own security camera -- the camera that had recorded every pickup and drop-off, every face that entered the room, including Felix Decker's -- before all of this was presented to Wei and his lawyer and the silence became more dangerous than speech and the calculation shifted from concealment to cooperation. That calculation, and its consequences, would unfold in the weeks to come, in the interview rooms at Sungai Buloh, where Wei would describe the supply chain and the protocol and the names of eight mules recruited from the Lantern Hostel.

But that was later. On the morning of February 27th, Wei was cuffed and placed in a car, and the shop was sealed with yellow crime-scene tape -- bright against the old shophouse facade, the present's assertion over the past's architecture, the visual declaration that this building was no longer a phone repair shop but a point on the map that Ahmad was drawing.

The second arrest was in Kepong.

Constable Hafiz bin Mohd Noor lived in a flat on the seventh floor of a housing development twelve kilometres north of the city centre -- the standard configuration of a government-subsidised unit, the kind of flat that a police constable on RM2,800 per month could afford. The banking records told the rest of the story: not just the RM5,000 deposit on February 13th, but a pattern -- RM4,000 on October 10, 2025, the date that Suresh Pillai was found dead in his cell at Sentul. The dates of deposits corresponded to the dates of deaths. The correlation was the evidence. The evidence was in the folder. The folder was in Ahmad's hand when the team knocked on Hafiz's door at 06:08 AM.

Hafiz answered in a sarong and a T-shirt. His two-year-old daughter was on his hip. Behind him, his wife was preparing the morning's rice, the domestic smell that would become, in Hafiz's memory, the smell of the last normal moment.

"Constable Hafiz bin Mohd Noor, you are under arrest for conspiracy to commit murder under Section 302 of the Penal Code, and for abuse of power under Section 23 of the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission Act 2009."

Hafiz did not speak. His face performed the operation that Ahmad had seen on the faces of arrested officers -- the rapid recalculation of identity, the collapse of the self-image that said *I am the law* and the emergence of the new image that said *I am subject to the law*, the transformation that occurred in the eyes, the eyes of a constable becoming the eyes of a suspect in the duration of a sentence.

The wife appeared in the hallway. She held a cooking spoon. The spoon dripped water onto the floor. Her face was the face of a woman who understood -- not the details, not the deposits and the bathroom breaks and the towels, but the shape. She had known the shape of what was happening because she had known that the money was wrong, that the amounts were wrong, that the explanations were wrong, and she had not asked because not-asking was the condition of the arrangement, the silence that was the premium paid for the surplus.

Hafiz handed the daughter to his wife. He held out his wrists.

In approximately four hours, in an interview room at Bukit Aman -- not Dang Wangi, the investigation had moved beyond Dang Wangi -- Hafiz would break his silence. He would describe the phone call that offered the money. The voice on the phone had mentioned his daughter's name -- Aisyah, seven months old -- and the mention was not a threat but was understood as a threat, the way a gun displayed on a table was not a threat but was understood as a threat. Fear, not greed. The distinction mattered legally. The distinction did not matter to Connor Briggs.

The third action was not an arrest. It was a suspension.

Inspector Kamal bin Yusof was summoned to the Deputy Commissioner's office at Bukit Aman at 09:00 AM, three hours after the arrests. A staff officer delivered a sealed envelope to Kamal's office on the third floor of Dang Wangi -- one floor above Ahmad's -- containing his immediate suspension from duty pending investigation into his conduct in the matter of Report Number DW/KL/2026/0847-M.

Kamal read the letter. Kamal placed it on his desk. Kamal removed his badge and his service weapon and the authority that the badge and the weapon represented and placed them on the desk beside the letter. Kamal stood and walked out of his office and down the corridor and past Ahmad's office -- Ahmad was there, the door open -- and the two men's eyes met. The meeting of the eyes was the meeting of two men who had worked in the same building for four years and whose relationship had just been redefined from colleagues to investigator and suspect, the redefinition occurring in the space of a glance that held everything the investigation contained.

Kamal walked out of Dang Wangi. Kamal was not arrested because the evidence against him was still being assembled -- Hafiz's testimony, the banking records, the cell assignment authorisations, the release documentation for Rizal. Kamal was free. Kamal was the kind of free that was not free -- the freedom of a man whose phone was now monitored, whose bank accounts were now frozen, whose movements were tracked by the same system he had once commanded.

The international warrants were filed the same day. Felix Decker: INTERPOL Red Notice, transmitted through the Malaysian National Central Bureau to 195 member countries. Last known location Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Immigration records confirmed Felix had cleared departure at KLIA at 03:47 AM on February 14th -- twenty minutes before his flight, ninety minutes before the body was officially discovered, the timing not coincidence but choreography, the scheduling of the murder and the scheduling of the flight coordinated with the precision that was Felix's signature, the logistics of disappearance planned alongside the logistics of death.

Rizal's warrant was issued to a fiction. Mohd Rizal bin Ahmad, IC 890412-14-5567, was a constructed identity -- a name attached to a body, the identity a tool used and discardable. The warrant was for the body. The body was somewhere in Southeast Asia, absorbed into the infrastructure that had deployed it, the network consuming its own operative the way it consumed its mules, the difference being that mules were consumed as liabilities and operatives were consumed as assets to be preserved, relocated, redeployed.

Ahmad issued the warrants knowing they would not immediately produce their targets. He issued them because the warrants were the system's declaration that these men were no longer free, the documents that converted the state's attention from passive to active, from surveillance to pursuit.

---

## V. The Photographs

On the morning of the arrests, Tomoko Sato sent her photographs to two recipients: Sergeant Ahmad bin Ismail at Dang Wangi, and Lim Wei Ling at The Star.

Fifty-nine photographs, backed up to a cloud server in Tokyo before Felix's associates stole her camera. Felix and Connor on the rooftop. Connor carrying packages on Petaling Street. Felix at Wei's shop window. Connor at the Jalan Ipoh drop. The chronological record of a recruitment, captured by a woman who had recognised the predator's pattern from Day 3 and had documented it with the professional discipline of a photojournalist and the professional detachment that she would later identify as her greatest failure.

For Ahmad, the photographs were corroboration. For The Star, they were a story.

---

## VI. The Front Page

The Star published the photographs on Tuesday, March 3rd. Page one. Above the fold.

**MURDER IN CUSTODY: PHOTOGRAPHS REVEAL DRUG NETWORK THAT KILLED AUSTRALIAN BACKPACKER**

Four thousand words spanning pages one, four, and five. The photographs reproduced across page four. The names that had been in Ahmad's folder now in the information stream that three hundred thousand households received. The article named Felix Decker, the Lantern Hostel, Wei's phone repair shop. It described the network's method. It cited SUARAM. It quoted the Australian High Commission. It did not name Priya. It could not quote Ahmad.

The original one hundred and forty-seven words had become fourteen thousand. The word *suicide* was being replaced by the word *murder*, and the replacement was migrating through the system, slow but irreversible.

---

## VII. The Desk

Ahmad sat at his desk at Dang Wangi on the evening of March 3rd. The article would not compromise the case -- the photographs were evidence independently submitted to both the police and the newspaper. Ahmad had not leaked. Ahmad had not briefed. Ahmad had done what Ahmad always did: built the case, executed the warrants, filed the charges, and let the evidence speak through the channels that the evidence found.

He opened the laptop. The spreadsheet. Six rows. Six names. Six deaths.

BRIGGS, Connor James.

The file was open. The arrests were made. The warrants were issued. The front page had been printed. The machinery of accountability was turning, and the turning, however slow, was the thing that distinguished this death from the five that preceded it.

Ahmad closed the laptop. He walked down the corridor, past the night crew, past the door to the custody wing where Cell C-7's fluorescent light was on. The light was always on. He walked out of Dang Wangi into the warm KL night.

And somewhere, in a city that Ahmad could not reach, in a hostel that Ahmad did not know the name of, a man with a German accent and a thin scar on his left eyebrow was sitting in a common room, drinking a beer, smiling at a stranger who was broke and lonely and far from home. The stranger was young. The stranger was exactly the kind of person the man looked for.

The pattern continued. The investigation continued. The two ran in parallel, locked together in the oldest geometry of all.

---

*End of Chapter 43*
# Chapter 44: Priya Returns

The air at KLIA2 was the same air.

Priya walked through the budget terminal -- the AirAsia terminal, the terminal where Connor had arrived twelve weeks ago on a cheap flight from Bali, his phone at three percent, his plan nonexistent, his fatal confidence intact. She walked past the sign above customs. DADAH MEMBAWA MAUT -- DRUGS BRING DEATH. Red letters the height of a child. She read it. She had always read it. Connor had walked past it without reading. The not-reading was the first act of a chain that ended in a cell at Dang Wangi.

She had not come for the body -- the Australian High Commission was handling the repatriation, the bureaucratic process of transporting human remains across international borders. She had come to bring the truth home. The truth that the police report had not told. The truth that the word "suicide" had concealed.

She collected her bag, passed through customs in twelve seconds, and stepped outside into the heat of KL in late March -- thirty-two degrees, ninety percent humidity, the air pressing against her skin. She stood on the kerb and thought: *This is the last air he breathed before the cell. This heat. This country. This.*

She took a Grab to KL Sentral, then the LRT to Pasar Seni, then walked the ten minutes to Petaling Street. The walk took her past the Guan Di Temple, past the market stalls, and past Wei's phone repair shop -- sealed now with police tape and a new padlock, the shop where the packages had been assembled and the network had operated in plain sight, two doors from a hostel full of backpackers who noticed nothing.

She turned and walked to the hostel.

---

The Lantern Hostel stood where it had always stood, at the narrow end of a lane off Petaling Street, between the phone repair shop and the traditional Chinese medicine store. The facade was the same -- the pre-war plasterwork, chipped and faded, the ornate mouldings above the windows, the narrow door, and above the door the red lantern that gave the place its name. The lantern was lit. The lantern was always lit. The lantern was the first thing a guest saw and the last thing a guest remembered and the light it cast was warm and red and the warmth and redness were the hostel's invitation, the building's way of saying *come in, come in, there is shelter here, there is company, there is a bed and a meal and the temporary community of strangers*.

She entered. The bell above the door rang -- the same sound for every arrival and every departure, the bell not distinguishing between the living and the dead.

Mei Ling was at reception. Mei Ling looked up. Her expression when she saw Priya was not surprise -- Mei Ling's expression was rarely surprise, because Mei Ling had seen too many things at this reception desk to be surprised by any of them. The expression was something else. Recognition. Acknowledgment. The look of a person who had been expecting something without knowing when it would arrive.

"Priya."

"Hi, Mei Ling."

The two words were the same two words that Connor had said to Priya on the morning she left. *Hi.* The word that carried everything it couldn't say. The word that was a placeholder for the language that grief had erased.

"You came back," Mei Ling said.

"I came back."

Mei Ling reached under the counter and produced a key. Not a dorm assignment -- a private room key. Private Room 2, the room that was usually storage, sometimes rented. The room on the third floor, across the hall from Felix's former room, Felix's room that was now empty, Felix's room that had been searched by Ahmad's team and stripped of its contents and left as a hollow space that contained nothing but the memory of the man who had occupied it.

"Razak said to give you this. No charge."

Priya took the key. Brass, old, the kind of key the building had used since 1928. She held it and the holding was the first physical connection to the building that had been the setting of the worst thing that had ever happened to her.

"I need to go to Dorm 3," she said.

Mei Ling didn't ask why. Mei Ling knew why. Mei Ling nodded and Priya walked past the reception desk and through the common room -- the common room where she had sat with Connor on the sofa, where she had met him, where she had argued with him, where she had kissed him, where she had told him about the letter, where she had said goodbye -- and up the narrow staircase, the staircase where the third step from the top still squeaked, and onto the second floor, and down the corridor, past Dorm 1 and Dorm 2, to the door of Dorm 3.

She opened the door.

The dorm was the same. Eight bunks, four on each side, the wooden frames dark with age and the accumulated oils of a thousand bodies. The ceiling fan turned. The air well let in the grey light of an overcast afternoon, the light filtered through the laundry that hung on the lines above the courtyard -- a German flag beach towel, a pair of cargo shorts, a sports bra, the textile archaeology of a hostel's current population. The room smelled of damp wood and Tiger Balm and the faint, sweet rot that all old buildings in the tropics carried, the smell of timber slowly returning to the earth.

Bed 7 was on the right side, second from the back, lower bunk.

A person was sleeping in it.

The person was young -- early twenties, female, dark hair spread on the pillow, the sheet pulled to her chin. A French passport was visible in the mesh pocket of the bed frame. A copy of Camus's *L'Etranger* lay face-down on the mattress beside her, the irony of the title -- *The Stranger*, *The Outsider* -- so precise that Priya almost laughed, almost produced the sound that existed between laughter and the other thing, the sound that the absurd generated when it was too accurate to be coincidence and too cruel to be comedy.

The girl was sleeping in Connor's bed. The bed where he had lain awake at three in the morning, his hand brushing the carved letters he never read. Another body in the same space, the replacement without ceremony, the way the sea closed over a swimmer.

Priya stood in the doorway and looked at Bed 7 and the looking was the goodbye.

The goodbye she had not had. The system had taken that too -- along with his body, his belongings, his bed assignment. Processed him out. She stood in the doorway the way she had stood at bedsides during her hospital placements, beside patients who were already gone, the body present, the person absent, the gap between the two the thing that medicine could measure but not close.

She stood for three minutes. She did not enter the room. She did not touch the bed. She did not wake the girl. She stood and looked and the looking was enough, was all she could have, was the closest she would get to the physical space where Connor had been alive, the space that had held his body and now held another body and would hold another after that and another after that, the space that was the same space and was different space because the person who had made it his was gone and the gone was permanent.

She turned and walked back down the corridor. The third step from the top squeaked. The squeak was the same squeak. Everything was the same and nothing was the same and the sameness was the cruelty.

---

Dang Wangi District Police Headquarters was a building that looked like what it was.

The building was concrete and functional, the architecture of authority -- square, solid, designed not to invite but to contain, not to welcome but to process. The Malaysian flag flew from the pole above the entrance. The PDRM crest was mounted on the wall. The air conditioning hit Priya as she entered and the cold was the cold of institutions, the artificial climate that government buildings maintained as proof of their separation from the street, the temperature saying *this is not outside, this is inside, and inside the rules are different*.

She had called Ahmad from London. She had called him on the number he had given Razak, the number that was now in her phone under the name SGT AHMAD -- DANG WANGI. She had told him she was coming back. He had said: "You don't have to." She had said: "I know." The exchange was the exchange of two people who understood that obligation was not the same as compulsion, that the drive to return was not duty but something else, something that lived in the space between duty and love and guilt and the need to see, to physically see, the place where the person you loved had died.

Ahmad met her in the lobby. He was shorter than she expected -- shorter than his voice, which was deep and measured and carried the authority of a man who had spent twenty years in the police force and had learned that authority was not volume but precision. He wore the uniform of the PDRM -- the khaki shirt, the dark trousers, the insignia of a sergeant in the Narcotics Division. His face was the face of a man in his forties who had seen things that had aged him, the lines around his eyes deeper than they should have been, the grey at his temples more than genetics alone could account for.

"Miss Sharma."

"Sergeant Ahmad."

They shook hands. The handshake was formal, correct, the handshake of two people meeting in a professional context who were connected by a tragedy that made professionalism both necessary and insufficient. His hand was dry and firm. Hers was damp from the walk from the LRT station.

"Thank you for your letter," he said. "And for coming back. You didn't have to come back."

"I had to come back."

He nodded. The nod carried something that the professional handshake had not -- the weight of a man who had read the same report that Priya had read and who did not believe it either.

He led her to his office. The office was on the second floor -- a room with a desk, two chairs, a filing cabinet, a window that looked onto a car park. The desk was covered in folders. The folders were the case -- the case that had started with Priya's letter and Tomoko's photographs and Razak's cooperation and had grown, in the weeks since, into the bureaucratic mass of a murder investigation, the mass that consisted of statements and forensic reports and phone records and bank records and CCTV footage and the accumulated evidence of a system responding to its own failure.

"I can show you some of the file," Ahmad said. "Not all. There are things that are sub judice -- the prosecution is building its case. But the parts that involve your statement, your evidence, the context."

He opened a folder. He turned it toward her. She read.

She read the arrest report. The report described Connor's arrest at a police checkpoint between Tapah and Ipoh on the North-South Expressway. The report described the drug dog's alert. The report described the opening of the suitcase, the discovery of five vacuum-sealed bags containing 450 grams of methamphetamine concealed in the suitcase lining. The report described Connor's response: *Subject became distressed. Subject stated: "I didn't know. Mate, I swear, I didn't know." Subject was advised of his rights under Malaysian law.*

She read the processing record. The record described Connor's arrival at Dang Wangi. The record listed his belongings: one mobile phone (Samsung, cracked screen), one wallet (containing RM340, one Australian driver's licence, one debit card), one pair of Birkenstock sandals, one braided leather bracelet, one blue Sea to Summit microfiber travel towel.
