She stopped at the towel. The towel was listed between the bracelet and the entry that said *End of personal effects*. The towel was an item on a list. The towel was a thing that had been catalogued and recorded and placed in a plastic bag and the placement was the last bureaucratic act performed on a possession that had been Connor's most constant companion, the towel that had been to twelve countries and dried his body on beaches and been wrapped around his shoulders in the cell and been the instrument of his death.

The towel was listed. The towel was in evidence. The towel was not in the cell.

"Can I see the cell?" she asked.

Ahmad paused. The pause was the pause of a man weighing a request against protocol, protocol against compassion, the rules of an active investigation against the needs of a woman who had loved the victim.

"It's not standard procedure."

"I know."

He stood. She stood. He led her out of the office and down a staircase -- not the main staircase but a side staircase, the staircase that connected the administrative floors to the custody level, the staircase that descended from the world of desks and files and the bureaucratic management of crime to the world of cells and bars and the physical containment of the accused. The staircase was narrow. The walls were painted the same institutional grey as everything else in the building. The fluorescent lights buzzed.

The custody corridor was at the bottom. The corridor was long, narrow, concrete floor, cells on both sides. The cells were identical -- three metres by three metres, concrete walls painted grey, a steel bench bolted to the wall, bars on the front painted institutional green, a squat toilet in the corner. Each cell had a number painted on the wall above the door.

They walked to the end of the corridor. Cell C-7.

Ahmad stopped. He did not enter. He stood to the side and let Priya stand at the bars and look in.

The cell was empty. The cell was clean -- the industrial clean of a space that had been processed by a forensic team and then cleaned by a janitorial crew, the double erasure of evidence and trace, the professional removal of everything that had happened followed by the chemical removal of everything that remained. The concrete floor was spotless. The steel bench was bare. The squat toilet was dry.

The fluorescent light was on. The light was always on -- on when Connor was alive in this cell, on when he was dying, on when he was dead, on now. The light was indifferent to the states of the bodies it illuminated.

Priya looked at the cell. She looked at the bench where Connor had lain. She looked at the bars from which his body had been hung. She looked at the ceiling, at the fluorescent tube, at the buzzing white light that had been the last thing Connor saw, the light that had narrowed to a point and then to nothing.

She looked for the towel. The towel was not there. The towel was in evidence, in a plastic bag, in a locker, in a room in this building, catalogued and tagged and preserved as Exhibit 14 in the murder investigation that the towel had made necessary. The towel's absence was the loudest thing in the cell. The absence was louder than the fluorescent buzz, louder than the silence, louder than the institutional hum of the building's ventilation system. The absence said: *something was here that is no longer here, and the no-longer-here is the evidence that something happened, and the something that happened is the reason you are standing at these bars*.

"How long did it take?" she asked.

Ahmad was quiet for a moment. The moment was the moment of a man deciding how much truth to share, how much clinical detail a grieving woman could hold, how much of the forensic reality was necessary for the understanding she sought.

"The pathologist estimated three to four minutes of sustained compression. Loss of consciousness within twenty to thirty seconds. Brain death within four to six minutes."

"Was he awake? Did he know?"

"The evidence suggests he was conscious when the attack began. There were defensive marks on his hands. Abrasions on his fingernails consistent with attempting to grip a smooth surface. He fought."

"He fought."

The words were not a question. The words were a statement, a fact, a piece of information that Priya received and stored in the place where she stored the things about Connor that mattered -- the real things, the things that the Instagram persona and the breezy confidence and the "she'll be right" had concealed. Connor had fought. Connor, who had never fought for anything, who had drifted through life on the current of his own ease, who had taken the path of least resistance at every turning -- Connor had fought. In the cell, at the end, when the towel was around his neck and the light was narrowing, he had fought.

It wasn't enough. It was never going to be enough. But he had fought.

"Thank you," she said.

*Bas*, she thought. *Enough.* The Gujarati arriving uninvited, the way it did when she was small and frightened, the language her mother used to end things.

She stepped back from the bars. She did not touch them. The not-touching was deliberate -- the bars were the boundary between the world she occupied and the world where Connor had died, and the boundary was a kind of membrane, and crossing it, even with a hand, felt like a transgression, like entering a space that belonged to the dead and the dead alone.

They walked back up the staircase. The fluorescent lights buzzed. The institutional grey surrounded them. The building processed their passage the way it processed everything -- silently, efficiently, without acknowledgment.

---

Tomoko was in the common room when Priya returned to the hostel.

She was sitting at the table by the window, her replacement Canon beside her, and spread on the table, printed on A4 paper in rows of six, were photographs. Fifty-nine photographs.

They had not seen each other since the day Priya left. Tomoko stood and crossed the room and put her arms around Priya -- brief, firm, the embrace of a person who did not embrace easily but who understood that certain moments required it.

They sat. The photographs were between them.

"I backed them up before the camera was stolen," Tomoko said. "Cloud server in Tokyo. Ahmad has everything. But these are the ones The Star is publishing."

The photographs were organised chronologically. Felix in the common room, Day 3. Felix and Connor on the rooftop, Day 4, Felix's hand on Connor's shoulder -- the hand of a handler establishing contact with a recruit. Felix at Wei's phone repair shop, Day 9. Connor on Petaling Street with a package under his arm, Day 10. Connor at a shophouse in Jalan Ipoh, Day 16, handing a package to a woman Ahmad had since identified and arrested.

"You had all this," Priya said.

"I had it from Day 9. I had enough to go to the police and I didn't go."

"Why?"

"I was building a story," Tomoko said. "I'm a photojournalist. When I started seeing Felix's operation, I thought: this is the story. The photographs, the evidence, the narrative arc. I was thinking in frames and deadlines, in column inches and publication dates."

She paused.

"I was building a story when I should have been making a phone call. One phone call. That's all it would have taken. Instead, I took photographs. I documented. I watched a man walk into a trap and photographed the walking and told myself the documentation was a form of action. The documentation was not action. It was the thing I did instead of action. And it cost a man his life."

The ceiling fans turned. Through the kitchen doorway, Mama Siti was visible at her station, the rhythm of her hands constant.

"The photographs are being published," Priya said.

"The Star. Tomorrow. Front page."

"We both failed him," Priya said.

"Yes."

"I left. You watched."

"Yes."

"And he's dead."

"Yes."

The third *yes* settled between them on the table, among the photographs, and the settling was not absolution but was, perhaps, the beginning of the thing that preceded absolution.

---

The Australian High Commission was on Jalan Yap Kwan Seng, in the diplomatic quarter. Priya arrived at ten the following morning. Sarah Chen -- the consular officer who had called Connor's parents at 3 AM, the voice that had crossed twelve thousand kilometres of telephone line to change the shape of two lives -- met her in the waiting area.

They sat in a small meeting room.

"I want to be clear about what the High Commission can and can't do," Sarah Chen said. "We've requested a full post-mortem, which has been conducted. We've lodged a formal request for a coroner's inquest."

"The police report said suicide."

"The murder investigation says otherwise. The inquest is the legal mechanism for resolving that conflict. But the process can take months."

"His parents are coming."

"Tomorrow. I'll be accompanying them to the morgue for the formal identification."

Priya looked at Sarah Chen -- the system's human face, steady-eyed, hands folded on the table, professional and person simultaneously.

"I want to tell you something," Priya said. "Not as a witness. Just as a person."

"Of course."

"He was arrogant and careless and ignorant and he dismissed every warning and he trusted the wrong person and he did everything wrong. Everything." She paused. "And he was kind. He bought me a jade bracelet at the night market because I looked at it for three seconds. He sat with Mama Siti in the kitchen and tried to learn how to make sambal and burned his hand and laughed. He called his mother on Sundays. He was a person. Not a headline. Not a case file. Not a mule. A person."

The jade bracelet was on Priya's wrist. Sarah Chen looked at it. She looked at Priya. She nodded.

"We're pressing for a full inquest," she said. "And we'll keep pressing."

Priya took a taxi back to Petaling Street. She entered the hostel. The bell rang. She climbed the staircase. She sat on the bed in Private Room 2 and held the jade bracelet and the holding was the holding of the last physical evidence that a man had loved her in this building, in this country where the penalty for ignorance was death and the payment was final and the receipt was a bracelet made of jade.

Tomorrow, the parents would come.
# Chapter 45: The Parents

They had never been to Asia.

David and Karen Briggs had been to Europe -- Italy, twice, for the food and the art, the trips that Australians of their generation and class took because Europe was the place you went when you could afford to go somewhere. They had been to New Zealand, which barely counted as abroad because New Zealand was the close neighbour, the cousin, the country that was different enough to be interesting and similar enough to be safe. They had been to Fiji, once, for their twenty-fifth anniversary, the resort holiday where the pool was never more than thirty metres from the room and the food was Western and the danger was sunburn.

They had never been to Asia. Asia was where Connor went. Asia was the place their son had gone four years ago and not come back from, the place that existed in his Instagram posts and his occasional phone calls and the monthly withdrawal of $2,000 from their account, the place that was simultaneously their son's home and a abstraction, a concept rather than a reality, a word rather than a world.

Now they were in it.

KLIA2 arrived around them the way airports arrived around everyone -- suddenly, totally, the transition from the sealed container of the aircraft to the open space of the terminal, the transition from the controlled atmosphere of recycled air and seat-back screens and the muted conformity of long-haul travel to the located, irreducible reality of a place. The place was Malaysia. The place was the last place their son had been alive. The place was the place where their son had died.

The terminal was large, modern, crowded. The signs were in Bahasa Melayu and English and Mandarin and Tamil, the four-language system of a country built on the confluence of civilisations. The announcements came in two languages -- Malay first, then English, the priority reflecting the constitutional hierarchy. The faces in the crowd were Malay and Chinese and Indian and European and the diversity was the diversity of a country that sat at the crossroads of trade routes and had accumulated, over centuries, the human cargo of commerce and colonialism and the modern traffic of tourism.

David carried a small backpack. The backpack was navy blue, practical, the kind of bag a property developer from Hawthorn carried when he didn't want to check luggage. The bag contained three shirts, two pairs of trousers, a toiletry bag, his passport, and a folder of documents -- the police report, the consular correspondence, the printed emails from Sarah Chen, the contact information for the lawyer they had retained in KL, the paperwork that grief had generated, the bureaucratic output of a death that had occurred in a foreign jurisdiction and required the administrative apparatus of two countries to resolve.

Karen carried a photograph.

The photograph was not in a frame. The photograph was a print -- a 6x4, glossy, the standard format of photographs from the era before phones replaced cameras. The photograph was of Connor at seventeen, in his school uniform, the Scotch College blazer and tie, standing in the front garden of the Hawthorn house with the jacaranda tree behind him. His hair was shorter than it would become, his face rounder, his expression the expression of a boy who was not yet the man who would travel to twelve countries and carry drugs in a hostel in KL and die with a towel around his neck in a cell at Dang Wangi. In the photograph, he was a boy. He was their boy.

Karen held the photograph the way she had held it for the entire flight -- in her right hand, face up, the image visible. She had not put it in her bag. She had not slipped it into the seat pocket. She had held it from Melbourne to KL, eleven hours, the photograph her companion and her evidence and her proof that the person they were flying to identify had once been a boy in a blazer in a garden and the jacaranda was blooming and the light was the golden light of a Melbourne autumn afternoon.

The flight had been AirAsia -- the budget airline, the same airline Connor had flown. They had not planned this. The flights available on short notice were limited, and the AirAsia flight was the soonest departure, and the soonest departure was the only criterion that mattered because Karen had said *today* to Sarah Chen on the phone and *today* had meant *today*, the urgency not of logistics but of biology, the maternal imperative to be near the child, to close the distance between the living mother and the dead son, the distance that was twelve thousand kilometres and was also infinite.

They passed through immigration. The officer stamped their passports. The stamps were the stamps that Malaysia issued to arriving visitors -- the red ink, the date, the permitted duration of stay. The stamps were the same stamps that Connor's passport had received forty-eight days ago. Connor's passport was now in evidence, in a plastic bag, in a locker at Dang Wangi, tagged as property of the deceased. The passport would be returned to them. The passport would travel back to Melbourne in their luggage, the document that had enabled the journey that ended the life, the administrative key that had opened the door to the country that contained the cell that contained the death.

They emerged into the arrivals hall. The heat was there, waiting, the heat that was not like Melbourne's heat -- Melbourne's heat was dry, seasonal, the heat of a temperate city that experienced summer as a visitor. KL's heat was permanent, structural, the heat of a city that existed at three degrees above the equator and did not experience seasons but only rain and the absence of rain, the heat that was not weather but climate, not a condition but an identity.

David felt the heat and the heat entered his body and he thought: *This is what he felt. When he walked out of this building forty-eight days ago, this is the air that met him. This is the heat that pressed against his skin. This is the first thing Malaysia gave him.*

Karen felt the heat and did not think about the heat. Karen was looking at the crowd beyond the barrier -- the drivers with name signs, the families waiting, the greeters and the meeters, the human infrastructure of arrival. She was looking for Sarah Chen. Sarah Chen had said she would meet them. Sarah Chen's face was not known to Karen -- they had only spoken on the phone, three times, the first time at 3 AM in the hallway, the second time the following morning when the emergency generator had been replaced by the deeper, more durable engine of purpose, the third time to confirm the flight details. Sarah Chen was a voice. Sarah Chen was about to become a face.

A woman stepped forward from the crowd. She was in her thirties, professional, the grey blazer and white blouse of a consular officer at work. She held a small sign: BRIGGS.

"Mr. and Mrs. Briggs. I'm Sarah Chen. We spoke on the phone."

The voice was the voice. The voice that had entered the Hawthorn house at 3 AM and changed the shape of the world. The voice was now attached to a person, a face, a body, a woman standing in an arrivals hall holding a sign with their name on it, the name that was also their son's name, the name that had been in newspapers and police reports and consular correspondence and would be in more newspapers soon.

David shook her hand. Karen did not -- Karen's right hand held the photograph and Karen's left hand held David's arm and the holding of both was the holding of the two things she could not let go: the image of her son and the body of her husband, the evidence of the past and the anchor of the present.

"Thank you for coming," Sarah Chen said. "I know this is --"

"Where is he?" Karen said.

The question was direct, unmodified, the question of a mother who had travelled twelve thousand kilometres and eleven hours and had not slept and had not eaten and had held a photograph for the duration and wanted only the answer to the question that had been forming since the phone rang at 3 AM: *where is my son?*

"The hospital. The forensic mortuary at Hospital Kuala Lumpur. I'll take you there now, if you're ready."

"We're ready," David said. He said it because Karen was already moving, already walking toward the exit, already crossing the arrivals hall with the purpose of a woman for whom ready was not a state to be achieved but a condition that had existed since the moment she learned her son was dead, the readiness to see him, to be near him, to touch him one more time, the readiness that was not courage but compulsion, the need that was stronger than fear and older than reason.

---

Hospital Kuala Lumpur was a complex of buildings on Jalan Pahang, the public hospital, the government hospital, the hospital where the people of KL were born and treated and died. The forensic mortuary was in a separate wing, a low building at the edge of the complex, the architecture functional, the purpose singular.

Sarah Chen drove them. The car was the High Commission vehicle -- a Toyota sedan, air-conditioned, clean. The drive from KLIA2 took an hour. During the hour, Sarah Chen explained the process. The explanation was delivered in the measured, rehearsed language of a person who had done this before -- not with the Briggs specifically but with other families, other parents, other people who had flown to Malaysia to identify the body of someone they loved.

"The identification is a formal process," she said. "You'll be taken to a viewing room. The body will be on a table, covered by a sheet. The attendant will fold the sheet back from the face. You'll be asked to confirm the identity. You can take as long as you need."

David nodded. He was in the front passenger seat. He watched the city through the windscreen -- the highway, the buildings, the traffic, the palm trees, the construction cranes, the billboards in three languages. The city was modern and sprawling and unfamiliar and every part of it was the last place his son had been and every building might have been a building Connor had walked past and every street might have been a street Connor had walked on and the *might have been* was the particular torment of a parent in a dead child's city, the inability to know which surfaces had held the child's footprints, which air had held the child's breath, which lights had been the last lights the child had seen.

Karen was in the back seat. She held the photograph. She had not spoken since the question in the arrivals hall. The not-speaking was not silence -- the not-speaking was the concentration of a mind engaged in a single task, the task of getting to the place where her son was, the task that required the conservation of every resource, every word, every breath, for the moment when she would see him.

The mortuary entrance was a door. Not a grand entrance, not an architectural statement, but a door -- grey, metal, institutional, the door that separated the living from the dead and the dead from the living, the door that families walked through once and carried the walking through for the rest of their lives.

A mortuary attendant met them. He was a Malay man in his fifties, quiet, experienced, gentle in the way that mortuary workers became gentle over years of dealing with grief in its most concentrated form. He spoke to Sarah Chen in Bahasa Melayu. Sarah Chen translated.

"He'll take you to the viewing room. He asks if you need a moment."

"No," Karen said. The word was the same word she had said on the phone: *today*. The word was the word of a woman who understood that moments of preparation were moments of delay and delay was the thing she could not tolerate, the thing that stood between her and her son.

The corridor was long. The floor was linoleum. The walls were pale green. The lighting was fluorescent -- the same fluorescent that lit every institutional space in this country, the same fluorescent that had lit the cell where Connor died, the universal light of systems that processed humans without regard for the humans' preference for warmth.

The viewing room was at the end of the corridor. The room was small. The room contained a table, a steel table, the kind of table that existed only in places where bodies were placed on tables -- hospitals, morgues, the rooms where the living came to see the dead. The table was covered by a white sheet. Under the white sheet was a shape.

The shape was a body. The body was their son.

Karen entered the room first. David followed. Sarah Chen waited at the door. The attendant stood by the table.

The attendant looked at Karen. Karen nodded.

The attendant folded the sheet back from the face.

The face was Connor's face.

The face was Connor's face and was not Connor's face. The face she had known for twenty-seven years -- the delivery room at the Royal Women's Hospital, the face red and creased and crying and the most beautiful thing she had ever seen. The face that had grown and changed and become a boy and a teenager and a man, and was now in repose, but the repose was not sleep, was the permanent stillness that death imposed on the muscles that had animated the face and made it Connor's rather than a face.

The tan was fading. Four years of equatorial sun retreating, the skin returning to the colour he had been born with, the colour of a baby in Parkville, the first colour, underneath the years.

His hair was the same. Dirty blonde, sun-bleached. The hair she had washed when he was a child.

Karen touched his hair.

Her hand moved from her side to his head and the movement was the movement of twenty-seven years of touching, the hand that had smoothed this hair when it was wet from the bath and when it was tangled after sleep and when it was sweaty after sport and when it was hidden under a hat. The hand knew this hair. The hand recognised this hair the way it recognised nothing else in the room -- not the table, not the walls, not the sheet, not the country -- the hand found the hair and the finding was the last recognition, the last physical confirmation that the body on the table was the body she had made, the body she had grown inside her and delivered and held and bathed and clothed and fed and loved and watched walk through a departure gate four years ago and not come back.

David's hand was on her shoulder.

The hand was on her shoulder the way it had been on Connor's shoulder at the airport, four years ago, the day Connor had left. The same position. The same weight. The same five fingers resting on the same place -- the bone, the muscle, the fabric of a shirt. At the airport, the hand on Connor's shoulder had been the hand of a father saying goodbye to a son. Now, the hand on Karen's shoulder was the hand of a husband holding a wife while she touched their dead son's hair. The hand was the same hand. The position was the same position. The weight was the same weight. But the meaning had changed because the person under the hand had changed and the person on the table had changed everything, the death changing not just the dead but the living, not just the body but the bodies around it, the death radiating outward from the table through the room through the building through the city through the sky to a house in Hawthorn where a photograph sat on a table in a hallway and the photograph was all that remained of the original configuration, the configuration of a family with two children both alive.

Karen's hand stayed on Connor's hair. David's hand stayed on Karen's shoulder. The three of them -- the living couple and the dead son -- held the position in the viewing room of the forensic mortuary at Hospital Kuala Lumpur and the holding was the last time the three of them would be together, the last time the family would occupy the same space, the geometry of three bodies in a room and one of the bodies was still and the stillness was the condition that made this the last time and the last time was a thing that could not be known as the last time until it was over and then it was always the last time, retroactively, permanently.

"That's Connor," David said.

The words were the formal identification. The words were required by the process -- a family member confirming the identity of the deceased, the legal act that converted a body from anonymous remains to a named person with a citizenship and a family and a history and a file. The words were procedural. The words were also the last time David would say his son's name and have his son be present to hear it, even though the hearing was impossible, even though the dead did not hear, even though the words travelled from David's mouth to the air and the air held them and the air was the air of a room where hearing had ended.

"That's our boy," Karen said.

The attendant waited. Sarah Chen waited. The room waited. The building waited. The city outside the building waited, the traffic and the heat and the eight million lives continuing while in this room, in this building, in this city, two parents from Melbourne stood over the body of their twenty-seven-year-old son and the standing was the thing they had flown twelve thousand kilometres to do and the thing they would never be ready for and the thing that was happening now, in this moment, in this room, under this light.

---

The hostel was a ten-minute walk from the LRT station. Sarah Chen offered to drive them but Karen said no. Karen wanted to walk. Karen wanted to walk through the streets that Connor had walked through, to feel the pavement under her feet that had been under his feet, to breathe the air that had been his air. The walking was not sightseeing. The walking was pilgrimage, the movement of a body through a landscape that was sacred not because of what it contained but because of who had moved through it before.

They walked down Petaling Street. The market was active -- the stalls, the vendors, the shoppers, the permanent commerce of a street that had been trading since the tin-mining days of the nineteenth century. The noise was the noise that Connor had loved, the chaos that he had filmed and posted and captioned with hashtags. The smells were the smells he had smelled -- the char kway teow frying, the diesel exhaust, the incense from the Guan Di Temple. The colours were the colours he had seen -- the red of Chinese signage, the gold of temple decorations, the green of tropical plants growing from cracks in old buildings.

David walked beside Karen. He was quiet. He had been quiet since the mortuary. The quietness was not the silence of a man with nothing to say but the silence of a man whose capacity for speech had been temporarily exhausted, the reservoir drained by the two sentences he had spoken in the viewing room -- *That's Connor* -- the sentences that had required the last of his available language, the last of the energy that the emergency system provided.

They reached the hostel. The narrow door. The red lantern. The facade that looked like what it was -- an old building in a Chinatown that had been many things and was now a hostel and would be something else after the hostel, the building cycling through identities the way beds cycled through occupants.

They entered. The bell rang. Mei Ling looked up.

"Mr. and Mrs. Briggs."

The words were spoken with the care of a receptionist who had been told to expect them, who had been briefed by Razak, who had prepared the common room and asked Mama Siti to cook and who now stood behind the wooden counter and said their name and the name was the name of their dead son and the name was the last thing they wanted to hear and the first thing they needed to hear because the hearing confirmed that they were in the right place, the place where their son had lived, the place where the name was known.

Mei Ling led them upstairs. The staircase was narrow -- too narrow for two people to pass, the staircase that Connor had climbed every day, the staircase where the third step from the top squeaked. Karen stepped on the third step. The squeak was a small sound. The small sound was enormous. The small sound was the sound of a piece of the building responding to weight, the same piece that had responded to Connor's weight, the wood flexing under her foot the way it had flexed under his, the building's memory stored not in consciousness but in physics, in the compression and decompression of timber that had been walked on by a thousand bodies and would be walked on by a thousand more.

Dorm 3. The door was open. The room was the same room Priya had stood in the day before -- the eight bunks, the ceiling fan, the air well light, the smell of damp wood and Tiger Balm.

Bed 7. Lower bunk, right side, second from the back.

The French girl was out. The bed was made -- the white hostel sheet pulled tight, the pillow straight, the bed the bed of an occupant who was tidy, who folded her sheets in the morning, who would return in the evening and sleep and wake and leave and the bed would hold another body and the cycle would continue.

David walked to the bed. His hand found the bed frame. The wood was dark, smooth, worn by the oil of hands and the humidity of years. His fingers moved along the rail. His fingers found a groove. The groove was a letter. The letter was L. His fingers moved. E. N. A.

LENA.

He didn't know what the letters meant. He didn't know they were a name. He didn't know the name belonged to a twenty-two-year-old Swedish woman who had slept in this bed and been recruited by Felix and arrested carrying drugs to Thailand and was now in Kajang Prison awaiting trial. He didn't know that the letters were the previous occupant's mark, the same kind of mark that prisoners carved in walls and lovers carved in trees, the human compulsion to leave evidence of having been, to say *I was here* in a medium more durable than memory.

He thought the letters were damage. Just wear. Just the marks that buildings accumulated -- the scratches and dents and grooves of daily use, the entropy that age imposed on surfaces, the evidence of nothing in particular, the random record of a building's passage through time.

His hand rested on the letters. His hand held the bed frame the way it had held the phone in the hallway at 3 AM, the way it had held Karen's shoulder in the mortuary, the way it had held Connor's shoulder at the airport. The hand was the same hand. The hand was always the same hand. But the things it held kept changing, and the changes were the changes that the death had made, the death converting every object from a thing into a relic, every surface from a surface into a site, every touch from a gesture into a memorial.

Karen stood behind David. She looked at the bed. She did not touch it. She looked at the pillow and thought about her son's head on the pillow and the thought was the thought of a mother imagining the physical space her child had occupied and the imagining was the only way she could be with him now, the imagination the only bridge across the gap that death had opened, the gap between the mother and the child, the gap that was the width of a mortuary table and the depth of the earth and the distance of the twelve thousand kilometres and the immeasurable, uncrossable distance of death itself.

"This is where he slept," she said.

"This is where he slept."

David's repetition was confirmation. The repetition was the married couple's grammar -- the statement and the echo, the call and the response, the shared language that thirty-one years of marriage had developed, the language that was not just words but the pattern of words, the rhythm of speech that two people created when they had been speaking to each other long enough that the speaking was not communication but communion.

---

Mama Siti was in the kitchen.

She was always in the kitchen. The kitchen was her domain -- the stove, the rice cooker, the spice rack, the chopping board, the space that she had occupied since before the building was a hostel, the space where she performed the daily miracle of converting raw ingredients into the food that brought people back and held them and nourished them and was the only magic the building possessed that was not dark.

She had prepared nasi lemak. The nasi lemak was on two plates on the kitchen table -- the coconut rice, the sambal, the fried anchovies, the roasted peanuts, the hard-boiled egg, the cucumber slices. The arrangement was precise, the arrangement of a woman who cooked not just with skill but with intention, each element placed with the care that the food deserved and the eaters needed.

David and Karen sat at the table. They sat because Mama Siti gestured for them to sit, the gesture simple and commanding, the gesture of a woman who had been feeding people for longer than anyone could remember and whose authority in the kitchen was absolute.

Karen looked at the food. The food was unfamiliar -- the coconut rice, the sambal red and fragrant, the anchovies tiny and crisp. She had never eaten nasi lemak. She had never been to Malaysia. The food was the food of a country she had come to because her son had died in it, and the food was the first tangible thing the country offered her that was not grief or bureaucracy or the fluorescent-lit corridors of institutions.

She ate.

The food was good. The food was more than good -- the rice was rich and creamy, the sambal was hot and sweet and complex, the anchovies were salty and crunchy and the combination of all of it was the taste of a cuisine that had been developed over centuries by people who understood that food was not fuel but language, that a meal was not nourishment but communication, that the plate was a letter and the flavours were the words and the message was: *you are here, you are fed, you are held*.

Karen ate and the eating was the first normal thing she had done since the phone rang at 3 AM. The eating was the body's insistence on the body's needs, the body overriding the mind's objection that food was irrelevant when your child was dead, the body saying: *you are alive, and the alive must eat, and the eating is not betrayal but survival, and survival is the thing you have to do now because the alternative is the thing that happened to your son and you cannot follow him there, not yet, not this way*.

The food was the last thing Connor ate.

Karen didn't know this. Mama Siti did.

Mama Siti knew because Mama Siti had served Connor his last nasi lemak on the morning of Day 47, the morning he had come downstairs at six thirty with the look of a man who was about to do the thing he had been dreading and the dread was visible and the visibility was the thing that Mama Siti had seen and understood and filed in the place where she filed the things she knew about the people who passed through her kitchen, the knowledge that was not recorded and not spoken and not shared but was held, in the body, in the hands, in the memory of a woman who had been in this kitchen since before the hostel and would be in this kitchen after it.

Mama Siti watched Karen eat. She watched the way Karen held the fork -- tentatively, the grip of a person eating unfamiliar food in an unfamiliar place. She watched the way Karen chewed -- slowly, carefully, the chewing of a person who was tasting something for the first time and the first time was also the first time she had tasted what her son had tasted and the tasting was a kind of connection, the flavours a bridge between the living mother and the dead son, the sambal the shared experience that they could not have shared when he was alive because he was here and she was there and the distance was the distance of a family separated by a son's restlessness and a mother's inability to follow.

Mama Siti watched Karen eat and said nothing. The nothing was not silence. The nothing was restraint, the decision not to tell the mother that the food she was eating was the food her son had eaten on the morning he died, the decision that the information was a weight the mother did not need, a fact that would convert the meal from nourishment into archaeology, from food into evidence, from the taste of Malaysia into the taste of the last morning.

David ate too. He ate mechanically, the eating of a man who was performing a function rather than experiencing a pleasure, the fork-to-mouth rhythm of a body fuelling itself while the mind occupied a different room, a different country, a different time -- the time before the phone call, the time when Connor was alive and the monthly deposit was a worry but not a grief and the house in Hawthorn was a home and not a monument to a family that no longer existed in its original form.

Mama Siti sat across from them. She did not eat. She watched. Her face was the face of a woman who had watched many things -- the building's transformations, the occupants' arrivals and departures, the cycle of beds filled and emptied, the rhythm of a place that consumed people and was consumed by them. Her face was old. The age was not a number but a quality -- the quality of a face that had absorbed time rather than merely passed through it, the face that was a repository of the building's history, the face that knew.

She spoke. She spoke in English, her English careful, accented, the English of a woman who had learned the language not in school but in a kitchen, from the guests who passed through, the words accumulated over years the way the building accumulated marks.

"Your son," she said. "He was kind. He did not know he was kind, but he was. He sat in this kitchen. He tried to cook sambal. He burned his hand." She held up her own hand, showing the gesture. "He laughed. Always laughing. Even when he should not have been laughing. Even when the laughing was the thing that kept him from seeing."

Karen looked at Mama Siti. Karen's eyes were the eyes of a mother hearing someone describe her son, the particular pain and gratitude of hearing the dead described by someone who had known them in a place the mother had never been, the testimony of a stranger who was not a stranger because the stranger had fed her son and watched her son and known her son in the specific, daily, intimate way that the people who shared a kitchen knew each other.

"He ate here every morning," Mama Siti said. "Every morning, he came down the stairs and he said *Morning, Mama Siti* and I gave him nasi lemak and he ate and he said *legend* and the word meant thank you."

Karen's hand was on the table. Mama Siti's hand crossed the table and covered it. The two hands -- the Australian mother's hand and the Malaysian cook's hand, the hand that had held a photograph for eleven hours and the hand that had held a ladle for decades, the hand of grief and the hand of knowledge -- the two hands held each other across the kitchen table and the holding was the bridge between two women who had loved the same person in different ways and lost the same person in different ways and were now connected by the loss the way two shores were connected by the water between them, the water that was the grief that flowed between them and touched them both.

"Thank you for feeding him," Karen said.

Mama Siti's eyes were bright. The brightness was not tears -- Mama Siti did not cry, or if she did, she did not cry in kitchens, in front of guests, in the space where her authority was absolute. The brightness was the thing that preceded tears and sometimes replaced them, the internal pressure of a feeling too large for the vessel that held it.

"He is fed," Mama Siti said. The tense was ambiguous -- the present tense that could have been a statement about the past or a statement about a different present, the tense that Mama Siti used when she spoke about the dead, the tense that did not distinguish between the living and the gone because in Mama Siti's understanding, in the understanding that the building had taught her, the gone were not absent but relocated, not ended but elsewhere, and the elsewhere was a place where the kitchen reached and the food reached and the feeding continued.

---

Priya was in the common room.

She had been waiting. She had been waiting since she heard from Sarah Chen that the parents were coming to the hostel, since she had understood that the meeting she had been dreading and needing was going to happen, since she had sat on the edge of her bed in Private Room 2 and looked at the jade bracelet on her wrist and thought about what she would say to the mother of the man who had given it to her.

She had not prepared words. She had tried -- in the hours of waiting, she had composed sentences, discarded them, composed new ones, discarded those. The sentences were always wrong. The sentences were either too much or too little, too clinical or too emotional, too explanatory or too simple. The sentences failed because sentences were insufficient for the thing that the meeting required, the thing that lived beyond language, in the space where two kinds of love met and the meeting was not competition but communion, the mother's love and the girlfriend's love standing in the same room and the room holding both and the holding being the closest thing to enough that the situation allowed.

David and Karen came from the kitchen. Their faces carried the remains of the meal and the conversation with Mama Siti. David's face was composed -- the composure of a man who had decided that composure was the contribution he could make, the structural support that the situation required, the wall that held while the interior was in ruins. Karen's face was open -- the openness of a woman who had stopped trying to contain the thing that could not be contained, the grief that would not be managed or scheduled or limited to appropriate moments but would arrive when it arrived and express itself as it needed to express itself.

Karen saw Priya.

She knew. She knew the way mothers knew -- not from introduction or explanation but from the look, the posture, the quality of the grief on the young woman's face. The young woman sitting on the common room sofa with the battered Lonely Planet guide on the table and the jade bracelet on her wrist and the expression that was the expression of a person who had lost the person that the mother had lost and the loss was written on the face the way grief was always written on faces, the handwriting of the heart visible on the skin.

"You're Priya," Karen said.

"Yes."

Karen crossed the common room and sat beside Priya. She saw the glasses, the braid, the practical clothes, the jade bracelet.

"He bought that for me," Priya said. "At the night market. On Petaling Street. He saw me looking at it and he bought it. He said it was the same green as my eyes, which was wrong -- my eyes are brown. But he said it with such confidence that I didn't correct him. That was Connor. He was always confident about things he was wrong about."

Karen laughed. The laugh was the first sound she had made since the mortuary that was not grief -- the sound was the sound of recognition, the sound of hearing her son described in a way that she recognised, the precise, vivid description of a trait that she had known for twenty-seven years. The confidence about wrong things. The absolute, unshakeable certainty about matters he had not investigated. The charm that made the wrongness endearing rather than infuriating. She knew this. She had raised this.

The laugh became something else. The laugh became the sound that existed next to laughter, the sound that was laughter's neighbour, the sound that used the same muscles and the same breath but produced a different output. The sound was the sound of the mortuary. The sound was the sound of the hallway at 3 AM. The sound was the sound that had no name because naming it would have required the clinical distance that the sound made impossible.

Karen held Priya. The holding was sudden -- Karen's arms around Priya's shoulders, the embrace of a woman who had crossed a room and sat down and heard a story about a bracelet and laughed and then could not stop the other thing from coming, the thing that the laugh had opened the door to, the way a crack in a dam opened the door to the water.

Priya was held. Priya held back. The two women held each other on the sofa in the common room of the Lantern Hostel, the sofa where Connor had sat for six weeks, the sofa where Priya had kissed him and argued with him and said goodbye to him, the sofa that was the last piece of furniture in the building that held the shape of his body and the warmth of his presence and the echo of his voice saying *she'll be right, babe* in the way that meant nothing and everything.

They cried. The crying was not performative and was not restrained and was not the crying of a scene in a film where the tears were lit and the music swelled and the audience was moved by the beauty of the grief. The crying was the ugly, bodily, uncontrollable crying of two women who had lost the same man and who were now in the same room and the room was the room where he had been alive and the being-alive was what they were crying for, not the death but the life, not the loss but the having-had, the brief, insufficient, irreplaceable time when Connor Briggs was a person in this room and the room held him and they held him and the holding was the thing that was over.

David stood in the kitchen doorway. He watched his wife hold a woman he had never met and understood that the grief in this room was not his to enter -- mother and girlfriend, the knowledge of the beginning and the knowledge of the end.

Mama Siti appeared beside him. Hands folded in front of her apron. Eyes on the two women on the sofa.

"The same," she said softly. "Always the same."

The jade bracelet caught the light.

The ceiling fans turned.

Outside, on Petaling Street, the market continued its ancient commerce, and the vendors called their prices, and the incense rose from the temple, and the city breathed, and the breathing was the breathing of a place that held the living and the dead equally, without preference, without judgement, the breathing of a city that had been breathing for a hundred and fifty years and would breathe for a hundred and fifty more, the breathing that was the only permanence in a world of impermanence, the only constant in a world of change, the only thing that remained when everything else -- the people, the buildings, the names carved in bed frames, the blue towels, the jade bracelets, the nasi lemak, the love, the grief, the laughter, the crying -- when all of it was gone.

The parents had come.
# Chapter 46: The Photographs

The story ran on Tuesday.

Not page 7 this time. Not the brief, three-paragraph mention that Malaysian newspapers typically gave to deaths in custody -- the mention that was the system's acknowledgment of the event and the system's containment of the event, the mention that said *yes, this happened* in a voice quiet enough that the saying could be denied if the saying became inconvenient. Not the kind of story that appeared and disappeared in the same news cycle, consumed by the next day's headlines, digested by the public's appetite for new information and expelled from memory before the week was out.

Front page.

The Star led with the story. The headline ran across the full width of the page, above the fold, in the black bold typeface that The Star reserved for the stories that could not be contained in the body of the paper, the stories that demanded the architecture of the front page.

The headline said:

**DEATH IN CUSTODY: PHOTOS REVEAL DRUG NETWORK AT KL HOSTEL**

Below the headline, three photographs. The photographs were Tomoko's. The photographs were the fifty-nine frames reduced to three, the editorial selection that converted a photojournalist's body of work into the three images that told the story in the language that newspapers spoke most fluently -- the language of the visual, the image that the eye consumed before the mind engaged, the photograph that made the reader stop and read the text below.

Photograph one: Felix Decker at Wei's phone repair shop, seen through the window, Day 9. Felix in profile, his angular face lit by the shop's fluorescent strip light, his hand on the counter, Wei visible behind him, the shelves of phone cases and the door to the back room. The photograph was sharp, composed, the work of a professional photographer who had stood across the street with a long lens and captured the moment with the precision that separated documentation from art. The caption identified Felix as a German national wanted in connection with Connor's death. The photograph made Felix real -- not a name in a police statement but a face, a body, a man caught in the act of the mundane transaction that was the architecture of trafficking: two men in a shop, one counter between them, fluorescent light above.

Photograph two: Connor Briggs on Petaling Street, Day 10, a brown-paper package under his arm. He was walking. His face was visible -- the dirty blonde hair, the squint, the board shorts, the braided leather bracelet. He was walking with the unselfconscious stride of a man who did not know he was being photographed and did not know the package under his arm contained a substance that carried the mandatory death penalty and did not know that the walk he was taking was being documented by a woman with a camera who was building a case he didn't know existed about a crime he didn't know he was committing. The photograph was the last image of Connor Briggs as a free man. The photograph was the before. Everything after the photograph was the after.

Photograph three: The Lantern Hostel. The facade -- the narrow door, the red lantern, the pre-war plasterwork. The photograph was taken at night. The lantern was lit. The glow was warm and red and the glow was the hostel's face, the face it showed to the street, the invitation that it extended to every traveller who passed. The photograph was beautiful. The photograph was the photograph of a place that looked like shelter and had been a trap. Readers would linger on this photograph longest -- the image that made the ordinary sinister, that converted a building into a character, that said *this is where it happened* in the visual grammar of true crime that turned locations into landmarks of the terrible.

In the newsroom at The Star's offices in Petaling Jaya, Lim Wei Jie -- the crime beat reporter who had written the story, who had covered deaths in custody before, other deaths, other cells, other families -- watched the print run come in and held the front page in his hands. The ink was fresh. The photographs were vivid -- Tomoko's work reproduced at a resolution that preserved the detail, the grain, the quality that elevated the images from documentation to evidence. The newsroom around him was quiet in the way that newsrooms were quiet when they knew the paper had a story that would move -- the hush of journalists watching a colleague's work hit the street, the professional respect that replaced the usual noise of keyboards and phones and the ambient cynicism that was the newsroom's default emotional register.

Lim had been writing this story for years, in different iterations, with different names and different nationalities and different cells. This time the story had photographs. This time the story had a name that was not Malaysian. This time the story had an international dimension that converted a local death-in-custody story into a story that crossed borders.

The story was 2,400 words. It occupied the front page and continued on pages 4 and 5, with additional photographs and a sidebar headlined "Malaysia's Deaths in Custody: The Numbers." The sidebar listed 257 deaths in police and prison custody between 2000 and 2026, of which 89 were classified as suicide, and of which 14 had subsequently been reclassified following investigations or inquests. The numbers were the numbers that the system produced when the system was asked to account for itself, and the numbers were simultaneously the evidence of the problem and the evidence of the system's capacity to absorb the problem without changing.

By noon, the hashtag #JusticeForConnor was trending. By evening, the story had crossed borders -- The Guardian, ABC Australia, the BBC, twelve countries, several hundred thousand readers -- and the story was no longer a story about one person in one cell but a story about a system. The story had escaped the containment of page 7. The story was everywhere.

---

The Lantern Hostel was besieged by journalists on Wednesday morning.

They arrived at seven AM, the first of them -- a camera crew from TV3, the Malaysian television network, a reporter and a cameraman and a sound technician, the three-person unit that was the basic architecture of television journalism, the minimum crew required to convert a location into a story, a building into a backdrop, a doorway into a stage.

By eight AM, there were six crews. By nine, there were twelve. The narrow lane off Petaling Street, which was ordinarily the quiet passage between the phone repair shop and the Chinese medicine store, was now a corridor of cameras and microphones and the frenetic, self-generating energy of a media event, the energy that was generated when multiple news organisations converged on the same point and the convergence created a feedback loop -- each crew's presence justifying every other crew's presence, the collective attention validating the individual attention, the physics of news gathering producing its own gravity.

Mei Ling stood at the reception desk and turned them away.

She turned them away with the efficiency of a woman who had spent two years standing at this desk and dealing with every kind of person who walked through the narrow door -- the drunk, the lost, the demanding, the entitled, the police, the health inspector, the occasional rat. The journalists were a new category but the skill set was the same: firm, polite, unyielding.

"The hostel is not giving interviews. Please direct your inquiries to the police."

"Is the owner available?"

"The owner is not available for comment."

"Can we see the room where Briggs stayed?"

"The hostel is a private establishment. Guests have a right to privacy."

"Is it true that the hostel was used as a base for drug trafficking?"

"Please direct your inquiries to the police."

The journalists filmed the facade. They filmed the red lantern. They filmed the narrow door. They filmed the lane and the phone repair shop -- sealed, padlocked, police tape -- and the Chinese medicine store and the Guan Di Temple at the corner. They filmed Petaling Street and the market stalls and the vendors who watched the filming with the bemused indifference of people who had been selling watches and handbags on this street for decades and had seen stranger things than a pack of journalists outside a hostel. One reporter did a piece to camera standing in front of the red lantern, the lantern framed behind her left shoulder, the iconic image already forming -- the lantern that would become the visual shorthand for the story, the way certain images attached themselves to certain stories and became inseparable from them, the lantern the story's logo.

Mei Ling watched from behind the desk. She had called Razak at 6:45 AM, when the first van pulled up. Razak had said: "Turn them away. Be polite. Say nothing." The instructions were clear. The execution was Mei Ling's, and Mei Ling executed with the practised competence of a woman who had grown up in the service industry in Kuala Lumpur and had learned early that the face you showed to the world was not the face you wore behind it. Her face showed calm. Behind the calm was the calculation of a person who had worked at this hostel for two years and who was now calculating the number of weeks of employment she had remaining, the calculation producing a number that was smaller than she wanted and larger than she feared.

Inside the hostel, the guests watched from the common room window. The French girl from Bed 7 sat on the sofa and watched the cameras through the glass and she did not know why the cameras were there because she had not read the newspaper and did not know the history of the bed she slept in and did not know that the building she was staying in was now famous for the terrible reason that buildings became famous when someone died in them. A German backpacker, newly arrived, stood behind her and filmed the journalists on his phone, filming the people who were filming the building, the recursive loop of documentation that the media age produced when events attracted attention and the attention attracted more attention and the multiplication was infinite.

Razak gave one interview, to The Star, to Lim Wei Jie. His confession -- "I chose money over morality. I am responsible." -- ran as the next day's headline on page 4, the quote extracted and enlarged across two columns, the sentence that was simple and damning and human in a way that the rest of the story was not.

---

The PDRM issued a statement on Wednesday afternoon.

The statement was read by a press officer at a press conference at Bukit Aman, the national police headquarters. The press officer was a woman in her forties, uniformed, professional, the face and voice of the institution that was being asked to account for a death that had occurred within its custody. She read from a prepared text -- the language measured, careful, legalistic, the language that said everything and nothing, that acknowledged without admitting, that addressed without answering.

"The Royal Malaysia Police takes all deaths in custody seriously. The death of Mr. Connor James Briggs at Dang Wangi District Police Headquarters is under active investigation. A murder inquiry has been opened. Two arrests have been made in connection with the case. International warrants have been issued for two additional suspects. The investigation is ongoing. No further details can be provided at this time."

The journalists asked questions. The questions probed the gap between the statement and the reality, the gap that the statement was designed to close and that the questions were designed to keep open.

"Is it true that the initial report classified the death as suicide?"

"The initial report reflected the preliminary assessment. The subsequent investigation has led to the current classification."

"How many deaths in custody have been initially classified as suicide and later reclassified?"

"I don't have that information available at this time."

"Is there any connection between this case and other deaths in custody involving the suspect known as Rizal?"

"The investigation is ongoing. No further details can be provided."

"Will there be an inquest?"

"The matter of an inquest is for the coroner to determine."

Twelve minutes. The press conference lasted twelve minutes and produced twelve minutes of the unsatisfying, choreographed theatre of institutional accountability -- questions asked and not answered, the not-answering itself the answer, the institutional voice saying *we acknowledge the event, we are investigating the event, we cannot discuss the event*, the opacity that was the system's defence against the light that the questions brought. The press officer left the podium. The journalists packed their equipment. The footage would air on the evening news and the footage would show what it always showed -- a podium, a uniform, a prepared text, the choreography of a system performing accountability without being accountable, the dance that the system had perfected over decades and that the press conference format enabled because the format was designed for statements, not for truth, and the twelve minutes were the system's statement and the statement was: *we are here, we are speaking, and the speaking is the thing we are offering you in place of the thing you are asking for*.

---

The Malaysian Home Minister was asked about the case on Thursday, during Question Time in Parliament.

The question came from a member of the opposition from Petaling Jaya, a woman named Siti Mariam who had been asking questions about deaths in custody for six years -- the same questions, the same answers, the same gap between the asking and the answering that never closed. She had a folder on her desk. The folder contained the names of families who had written to her office, the names of the dead and the names of the living who carried the dead, the names that were the human substance of the statistics that the government declined to cite.

"Yang Berhormat Menteri, in light of the recent death of Australian national Connor Briggs at Dang Wangi police station, and the subsequent opening of a murder investigation, can the Minister confirm how many deaths in police custody have occurred in the past five years, and how many of those deaths were initially classified as suicide?"

The Home Minister stood. He had developed the particular skill of responding to questions without answering them -- the practised art of the public figure who understood that every word spoken in Parliament was recorded and every record was permanent.

"Every death in custody is investigated," the Home Minister said. "The government takes the welfare of detainees seriously. The case of Mr. Briggs is under active investigation by the Royal Malaysia Police. I have every confidence in the investigation. The government's commitment to the rule of law and to the rights of all persons in custody is unwavering."

He did not say how many deaths there had been. He did not mention the number 257. He did not mention the 89 classified as suicide. He did not mention the 14 that had been reclassified, or the 75 that had not -- the 75 that remained on the books as suicides, that existed now only in folders in filing cabinets and in the memories of families who believed what Priya believed and what the Briggs family believed, that the word *suicide* was a wall and behind the wall was a different word.

He did not mention the three other deaths that Rizal was connected to -- Taiping in 2022, Johor Bahru in 2023, Shah Alam in 2024 -- deaths that had been classified as suicides and that were now being reviewed, the files reopened, the investigations re-initiated by a system that was being forced, by the pressure of a front-page story and international attention that a dead Australian generated in a way that dead Malaysians often did not, to look again at the things it had chosen not to see.

He said: "Every death in custody is investigated."

Siti Mariam sat down. She placed her hands on the folder. The folder remained closed. The names inside the folder remained unspoken. The names would be spoken another day, in another Question Time, the cycle continuing -- the asking and the not-answering and the gap between them that was the space in which the families waited.

The non-answer was recorded in Hansard. The recording was the democracy's method of preserving the non-answer for future reference, the record that said: *this question was asked, and this was what was said, and what was said was not what was asked, and the gap between the two is the gap that persists*.

---

At Kajang Prison, fifty kilometres south of Kuala Lumpur, a woman named Nurul -- Mama Siti's niece, mid-twenties, fourteen months into a sentence for trafficking under Section 39B -- read a two-day-old copy of The Star that had been passed hand to hand through the informal distribution system of the prison.

She read about the Lantern Hostel. She read about Petaling Street. She read about Felix Decker. She read about Connor Briggs, a twenty-seven-year-old Australian who had been recruited in the same hostel where she had been recruited two years earlier, by a man who was not Felix but who was Felix's predecessor, the previous handler, the previous occupant of the private room on the third floor.

She had been silent for fourteen months. The silence was survival -- the network had people inside the prison, and the people who spoke about the network were the people who were silenced, in cells, at night, with towels or sheets or the improvised ligatures that the system's failures made available.

She read about Mama Siti. The newspaper mentioned Mama Siti only in passing -- "the hostel's long-serving cook" -- but the mention was enough. The mention was the name that Nurul knew, the name that was not just a name but a history, the history of a family that had been entangled in the network's operations through the building where the family's matriarch cooked and the building's owner had made an arrangement and in that space Nurul had been recruited, two years ago, by the previous handler, the previous occupant of the private room on the third floor.

She put the newspaper down. She sat on her bed and looked at the wall and the wall was concrete and the concrete was the same colour as the concrete of every cell in every prison in Malaysia and the colour was the colour of containment.

She made a decision. The decision was not sudden. The decision had been forming for fourteen months, the way a stalactite formed -- slowly, invisibly, the accumulation of drops, each drop too small to be a decision but the accumulation eventually producing a structure that was a decision, a solid thing, a thing with shape and weight and consequence.

She called for the guard.

"I want to speak to a lawyer," Nurul said. "From SUARAM."

The word changed the guard's expression. SUARAM -- Suara Rakyat Malaysia -- was the human rights organisation that had been documenting deaths in custody for decades, the organisation that existed on the other side of the wall that separated the system from the people who questioned the system.

"I want to give a statement," Nurul said. "About the network. About the hostel. About the man who recruited me. About the man who recruited the Australian. About all of it."

The guard left to file the request. The request would take days. But the request had been made and the making was the first sound after fourteen months of silence, the first word in a statement that would add to the case that Ahmad was building -- the case that had started with Priya's letter and Tomoko's photographs and Razak's confession and that was growing, document by document, into the mass that the system required to hold itself accountable.

Nurul lay on her bed. The fluorescent light buzzed -- the same light that had been on in Connor's cell, the universal light of custody, the light that illuminated without warming, that was on when the living were there and on when the dead were there. She thought about the decision she had made. The decision was dangerous. The decision might get her killed in the same way that Connor Briggs had been killed. But the decision had been made and the making was irreversible.

The story was out. The story could not be put back. The story was the light that the system had tried to prevent by calling the death a suicide and filing the report and closing the case and moving on. The light was on the front page and on the internet and in the Parliament and in the prison and in the cell where Nurul lay with her eyes closed and her decision made, and the decision was a light too, a small light, the light of one person choosing to speak after fourteen months of choosing not to, the light that was not enough to illuminate everything but was enough to illuminate something, and the something was a start, and the start was the thing that the system feared most.

The fluorescent light buzzed.

Nurul waited for the lawyer.

The story continued.
# Chapter 47: The Reckoning

Razak closed the hostel on a Wednesday.

He stood in the common room at 7 AM and watched the last guests leave -- a Korean couple who had seen the police tape and the forensic team and the headlines on their phones. They paid in cash and left without speaking, their rolling suitcases bumping down the narrow staircase. The bell rang once and settled.

Silence. Forty-two empty beds in six rooms on three floors. A kitchen without a cook -- Mama Siti had not come in since the news broke. The sambal pot was clean, upside down on the drying rack.

Razak climbed the staircase to Dorm 3. The room had been stripped by the forensic team, the mattresses bare. Bed 7 was in the far corner, bottom bunk, against the wall. The towel was gone -- sealed in an evidence bag at Dang Wangi, transformed from an object of comfort into an object of law.

Names were scratched into the bed frame. LENA, in thin, precise letters -- the Swedish girl who had slept here and been recruited here and was now in Kajang Prison. Below LENA, other names: TOM. JULIE. HANS. Connor's name was not scratched into the bed. Connor had not left a mark on the wood. The bed did not remember Connor. The bed was a bed.

Razak descended to his office. The newspaper clippings covered the walls. The map with its red pins hung above the desk, each pin marking a hostel where someone had died. There was a new pin. Kuala Lumpur. The Lantern Hostel. This pin was different from the others. The others marked deaths he had read about. This pin marked a death that had happened in his building, facilitated by his silence, enabled by his arrangement with a network he had tolerated because tolerance was easier than resistance.

"I'm sorry," he said to the map.

He locked the front door and pocketed the key. The red lanterns stayed on -- the lanterns were on a separate circuit that Razak had never turned off. He walked down Petaling Street toward Pasar Seni while the hostel behind him sat empty and the lanterns glowed for no one.

---

Ahmad interviewed Wei at the remand centre at Sungai Buloh.

The interview room was standard -- a table bolted to the floor, two chairs on each side, a camera in the corner, fluorescent lighting. The room was designed for function, not comfort: a space in which information was exchanged under conditions of asymmetric power, the interviewer holding the authority and the interviewee holding the information and the exchange requiring the careful calibration of pressure and release that was the art of interrogation.

Wei sat on the far side of the table. He was smaller than Ahmad had expected -- a thin man, early forties, Malaysian-Chinese, with the careful posture of a person who had spent his life in rooms where precision mattered. His hands were on the table, palms down, the fingers long and fine-boned, the hands of a technician. The hands that had assembled the packages. The hands that had sealed the methamphetamine in vacuum bags and placed the bags in charger boxes and backpack linings and suitcase walls. The hands were still now. The hands were on a table in an interview room and the stillness of the hands was the stillness of a man who was calculating the cost of every word he was about to speak.

Wei's lawyer sat beside him. Encik Ibrahim, a criminal defence lawyer from a firm on Jalan Sultan Ismail, retained by the network. The lawyer was there because the network's protocol included legal representation for arrested operatives -- the protocol recognising that legal representation was not a gesture of care for the operative but a mechanism of control, the lawyer's function not to defend the client but to manage the information that the client disclosed, to ensure that the client's cooperation served the client's survival without endangering the network's infrastructure.

But the lawyer's calculation had changed. The lawyer had reviewed the evidence. The lawyer had seen the CCTV footage that Tomoko's photographs had led Ahmad's team to subpoena -- the footage from Wei's own shop cameras, the cameras that recorded every pickup and drop-off, the cameras that showed Connor Briggs entering the back room on Day 39 and receiving a charger box, the cameras that showed Felix Decker and Wei in conversation over a table covered in packaging materials. The lawyer had seen the phone records. The lawyer had seen the banking transactions. The lawyer had seen the quantity -- four hundred and fifty grams of methamphetamine in the suitcase, plus the accumulated evidence of months of trafficking operations.

The lawyer had done the math. The math was Section 39B. The math was the mandatory death penalty for trafficking in dangerous drugs. The math was the difference between cooperation and silence, between information exchanged for a reduced charge and silence maintained until the gallows.

The same law that had ensnared Connor -- the law of which Connor had been ignorant, the law whose existence Connor had dismissed as "that's for big-time dealers" -- the same law now motivated Wei to speak. The irony was structural, built into the architecture of the legal system: the law was a pressure, and the pressure was applied equally to the ignorant mule and the knowing supplier, and the pressure produced different responses -- the mule's panic, the supplier's calculation -- but the pressure was the same pressure, and the source of the pressure was the same seven words that appeared at the top of every briefing, every warning, every sign that Connor had failed to read: *Mandatory death penalty for drug trafficking.*

"My client is prepared to cooperate," Encik Ibrahim said. The sentence was formal, rehearsed, the legal preamble to the transaction that was about to occur. "He will provide information about the network's structure, supply chains, and operatives in exchange for the prosecution's agreement to pursue charges under Section 39A rather than 39B."

Section 39A: trafficking, reduced charge, fifteen to thirty years. Section 39B: trafficking, mandatory death. The difference between the two sections was the difference between a sentence and a death warrant, between years in a cell and a noose around a neck, between a future that was diminished and a future that did not exist. The difference was the lawyer's leverage.

Ahmad nodded. "The prosecution has agreed in principle, pending the quality of the information provided. This interview is recorded. Begin."

Wei began.

He began with the supply chain. The methamphetamine came from a lab in Shan State, Myanmar, transported overland through northern Thailand, across the border at Sadao, down the peninsula to KL. The route had been operational for four years. The volume was approximately two kilograms per month, distributed through seven cells in Peninsular Malaysia -- KL, Penang, Johor Bahru, Ipoh, Kuantan, Malacca, Kota Bharu. Wei ran the KL cell. His function was logistics: receiving the raw product, packaging it for transport, and coordinating the local distribution through couriers.

"The couriers," Ahmad said. "Tell me about the couriers."

Wei's hands moved on the table. A small movement -- the fingers shifting, the palms lifting slightly, the adjustment of a man who was about to describe the part of the operation that most directly implicated him in a boy's death.

"There are two types. Local couriers -- Malaysians, paid, permanent. They handle the domestic routes. KL to Penang, KL to JB, the regular distribution. And foreign couriers. Backpackers. Tourists."

"Mules."

"Yes."

"How are they recruited?"

"Felix handles recruitment. Only Felix. That's his function. He lives in hostels. He identifies targets -- young, Western, broke, naive. He builds relationships. He starts with small favours -- envelopes, packages. He escalates. By the time the target understands what they're carrying, they're too deep. The CCTV records every pickup. Felix shows them the footage. They're trapped."

"How many?"

Wei was quiet for a moment. The quiet was the sound of a man counting, and the counting was the counting of bodies -- not dead bodies, but the bodies that had been used, the bodies that had carried the product, the bodies that had been trapped in the system the same way Connor had been trapped.

"In KL, since I started. Eight. Connor was the eighth."

Eight. The number sat in the room like a verdict. Eight young people, over four years, recruited from the common room of the Lantern Hostel, introduced to a charming German who bought them beers and told them stories and gradually, methodically, turned them into couriers for a methamphetamine supply chain that stretched from the hills of Myanmar to the streets of Malaysian cities.

"Names," Ahmad said.

Wei provided names. Some were first names only -- the transient nature of hostel relationships meaning that Wei knew the mules by the names they used at check-in, the names that might be real or might be the names they travelled under, the names that were entered in the hostel's guest book in Razak's careful handwriting and that were now evidence.

"Lena Ekstrm. Swedish. Twenty-two. Recruited fourteen months ago. Arrested at Bukit Kayu Hitam, carrying for the Thai border route. She's in Kajang now."

"I know," Ahmad said. "She's asked for a lawyer."

"She'll talk. She has the same information I have. Felix's name. The hostel. The pattern."

"Who else?"

Wei named six more. An American. A New Zealander. Two Britons. An Australian woman, before Connor. A Canadian. Some had been arrested. Some had completed their routes and moved on, the network releasing them with the understanding that their fingerprints were on file and the CCTV was stored and the information was leverage that could be activated at any time, the leverage the network's insurance against the mules' testimony.

"The ones who were arrested," Ahmad said. "What happened to them?"

Wei looked at his lawyer. His lawyer looked at the table.
