"Two were arrested and convicted. They're serving sentences under Section 39A -- they cooperated, like me, and the charges were reduced. One was arrested and..." Wei stopped. His hands lifted a centimetre off the table and settled again. "One was arrested and died in custody."

Ahmad leaned forward. "Which one?"

"The first one. Two and a half years ago. A man named Daniel Park. Korean-American. Twenty-four. He was arrested with 200 grams of meth at a bus terminal in JB. He was taken to the Johor Bahru district police station. He died in his cell. The report said suicide."

"Was it?"

Wei's hands were still on the table. The hands that had packaged the drugs that Daniel Park had carried. The hands that had sealed the vacuum bags and handed them to Felix and Felix had handed them to Daniel and Daniel had put them in his bag and walked to a bus terminal and been arrested and taken to a cell and died.

"It was the same as Connor. The network's protocol. When a mule is caught, the mule is silenced. The network has contacts in the police. A prisoner is placed in the cell. The guard takes a break. The death is staged as suicide."

The room was silent. The fluorescent light buzzed. The camera recorded. The silence was the silence of a system describing itself, the silence that followed the revelation that the system's efficiency included the efficiency of murder, the efficiency of silencing the people who could expose the system, the efficiency that converted a human problem into a logistical solution.

"Daniel Park," Ahmad said. He wrote the name in his notebook. The name was the second name, after Connor Briggs, in what would become a list of names -- the names of people who had been killed by the network's protocol, the names that the investigation would uncover over the coming months, the names that would appear in the court documents and the newspaper articles and the parliamentary inquiry.

"Connor Briggs," Ahmad said. "Walk me through it."

Wei walked through it. The recruitment. The escalation. The suitcase. The checkpoint. The arrest. The protocol. The guard -- Hafiz, night shift, paid three thousand ringgit in cash, delivered by an intermediary whose name Wei did not know. The prisoner -- the man they called Rizal, whose real name Wei did not know, whose function in the network was the function that no one discussed, the function that existed at the bottom of the organisational chart, below the suppliers and the packagers and the distributors and the recruiters, the function that was activated when all other functions had failed, the function of silence.

"Rizal," Ahmad said. "How do I find him?"

"You don't. He finds the network. He's contracted. He's not permanent. He operates across the region -- KL, Bangkok, Jakarta. He has multiple identities. He enters the cell as a petty criminal, does the job, is released the next morning, disappears."

"Released how?"

"The same officer who arranges the break. Hafiz, in this case. The record shows the petty criminal was released on bail. The bail is posted by a proxy. The record is clean."

Ahmad wrote. The writing was methodical, unhurried, the writing of a man who had been building a case for six months and had just received the testimony that connected the dots, that drew the lines between the nodes, that converted a suspicion into a provable pattern. The pattern was what Ahmad needed. The pattern was the evidence that this was not a single death but a system, not an incident but a method, not a tragedy but a business model.

"Felix Decker," Ahmad said. "Where is he?"

"Cambodia. Phnom Penh. He flew out on Thursday afternoon, twelve hours before Connor's arrest. He always leaves before the arrest. That's his protocol."

"How do you know he's in Cambodia?"

"He called me. Saturday morning. From a Cambodian number. He asked if the protocol had been completed. I told him it had."

Ahmad looked at Wei. The look was the look of a man who had heard a confession that was also an admission of complicity in murder -- the phone call in which one man asked another man if a third man had been killed, and the second man confirmed that the third man had been killed, and the conversation was conducted with the businesslike efficiency of two men confirming a logistics update.

"You told him the protocol had been completed," Ahmad repeated.

"Yes."

"Meaning you confirmed that Connor Briggs had been killed."

"Yes."

The word was flat. The word was the word of a man who had accepted that the word was the price of the other word -- the word that meant thirty years instead of death, the word that meant a cell instead of a gallows, the word that meant survival. Wei had made his calculation. The calculation was the same calculation that the law imposed on everyone it touched: the calculation of self-preservation, the arithmetic of survival, the mathematics of a system in which every participant was simultaneously a perpetrator and a potential victim.

Ahmad closed his notebook. He looked at Wei's hands on the table. The hands were still. The hands would remain still for a very long time -- the years of incarceration reducing the hands' function to the eating of prison food and the turning of prison-issue pages and the occasional writing of letters that no one would answer. The hands that had packaged methamphetamine would package nothing. The hands that had sealed the vacuum bags would seal nothing. The hands were finished.

"We're done for today," Ahmad said.

---

Nurul's testimony arrived via video link from Kajang Prison.

The screen showed a room -- a small, bare room with a table and a chair and a wall painted the institutional green that was the Malaysian prison system's colour of containment. Nurul sat at the table. She was twenty-four. She had been in Kajang for eleven months. Her face was thinner than the face in the photograph that Mama Siti kept in her wallet -- the photograph of a girl at a family gathering, round-cheeked, smiling, wearing a bright blue tudung, the photograph of a girl who had not yet been recruited and arrested and convicted and sentenced and transformed from a niece into a prisoner.

Nurul wore the prison uniform. Her hands were folded on the table. Her eyes were steady. The steadiness was not strength in the conventional sense -- it was the steadiness of a person who had spent eleven months processing the thing that had happened to her and had arrived at a state that was not acceptance but was the thing that existed beyond the exhaustion of all alternatives to acceptance.

"My name is Nurul binti Hassan. I was arrested on 14 March at the Butterworth bus terminal in Penang state. I was carrying a backpack that contained approximately three hundred grams of methamphetamine. I was charged under Section 39B of the Dangerous Drugs Act 1952. I was convicted. I am currently serving a life sentence, reduced from the death penalty under the court's discretion."

The words were practiced. The words had been spoken before -- to lawyers, to judges, to the prison counsellor. But the words were being spoken now to a camera that was connected to a screen in Ahmad's office at Dang Wangi, and the audience was different, and the purpose was different, and the difference was that the words were no longer a confession but a corroboration, a pattern piece, a second data point that, when placed beside the first data point of Connor Briggs, created a line, and the line pointed toward the system.

"I was recruited at the Lantern Hostel," Nurul said. "Petaling Street, Chinatown, KL. I was not a guest. I worked there -- I helped my aunt, Siti binti Ahmad, the cook. I was in the kitchen every morning. I lived with my aunt in her flat in Cheras but I spent most of the day at the hostel."

She paused. The pause was the breath before the part of the story that cost the most to tell.

"A man named Felix approached me. He was a guest. A foreigner. German. He was polite. He was charming. He said he needed someone local, someone who spoke Malay, to help with a delivery business he was setting up. Import-export. Phone accessories. He offered me five hundred ringgit a week, cash, no questions."

Ahmad listened. The listening was not passive -- the listening was the active, analytical listening of an investigator hearing a second testimony that matched a first testimony, the details aligning, the pattern emerging from the overlap. Felix. The Lantern Hostel. The charm. The offer. The phone accessories.

"He started me with envelopes," Nurul said. "Small. Sealed. Delivered to addresses in KL. Then packages. Then backpacks. The contents got heavier. I didn't ask. He told me not to ask. He said asking was bad for business."

The pattern. The identical pattern. The escalation from envelopes to packages to backpacks. The instruction not to ask. The progression that was not improvised but designed, the recruitment method that was a system, a process, a replicable template that Felix applied to each new target with the consistency of a manufacturing process -- the same inputs producing the same outputs, the same charm producing the same trust, the same trust producing the same compliance, the same compliance producing the same crime.

"When did you learn what you were carrying?" Ahmad asked.

"After six weeks. I found a bag that had torn. White powder inside. I confronted Felix. He said it was nothing -- protein powder, supplements. I didn't believe him. I told him I wanted to stop."

"What happened?"

"He showed me CCTV footage. From the shop two doors down -- the phone repair shop. The footage showed me picking up packages, putting them in my bag. He said if I stopped, the footage would go to police. He said if I went to police myself, the footage showed me but not him. He said the evidence pointed to me. I was the one on camera. I was the one carrying."

The trap. The identical trap. The CCTV as leverage, the footage as insurance, the mule's own actions converted into evidence against the mule, the system's recursive logic ensuring that the person who could expose the system was the person most endangered by the exposure. Connor had been trapped the same way. Daniel Park had been trapped the same way. Eight mules, the same trap, the same method, the same calculated, professional, systematic destruction of eight lives.

"I continued for three more months," Nurul said. "I carried larger amounts. The last delivery was the Penang route. A backpack with three hundred grams. Felix said it would be the last one. Felix always said it would be the last one."

"Tell me about the arrest."

"Butterworth bus terminal. A random check. The police found the methamphetamine in the backpack's hidden compartment. They arrested me. They charged me under 39B. The mandatory death penalty."

"And then?"

"I was in Kajang for four months before my trial. During those four months, I received a visit from a man. He said he was a lawyer. He gave me a name, a firm. He said he was there to help me, sent by friends. He asked me what I had told the police. I told him I had given the police nothing. The man said that was good. The man said that if I continued to give the police nothing, the firm would represent me and seek a reduced charge."

"The firm represented you at trial?"

"Yes. They negotiated the reduction from 39B to a life sentence. They told me to plead guilty to trafficking but to say I acted alone. No mention of Felix. No mention of the hostel. No mention of the network."

"And you agreed."

"I agreed. I was twenty-three. The alternative was death. I agreed."

The video feed was steady. Nurul's face was steady. The steadiness held everything -- the months of isolation, the four months of pre-trial detention, the trial, the sentence, the eleven months of incarceration, the accumulation of time and silence and the particular loneliness of a woman who had been recruited by a charming foreigner and arrested with a backpack of methamphetamine and abandoned by the network that had recruited her and defended by the lawyers that the network had sent and convicted on the terms that the network had negotiated. The network had managed every stage of her destruction, from recruitment to conviction, with the same efficiency that it managed the supply chain. Nurul was not a person to the network. Nurul was a logistics problem that had been solved.

"Why are you speaking now?" Ahmad asked. The question was the question that the investigation needed answered -- the question of motivation, the question of why a woman who had been silent for eleven months was now, after learning of Connor Briggs's death, willing to provide the testimony that could expose the network.

Nurul looked at the camera. The look was direct, unblinking, the look of a person who had arrived at the place beyond fear.

"Because he died," she said. "Because the Australian boy died the way Daniel died. Because I was supposed to die too -- did you know that? I was supposed to die in my cell. The protocol. But the prison moved me to a different wing the night before. A routine transfer. Administrative. The man they sent -- the one like Rizal -- he arrived at an empty cell. I was in a different wing and I was alive because of paperwork. Because of a form that someone filed that moved me from one wing to another. Paperwork saved my life."

The room was silent. The video feed continued. Nurul's face on the screen was the face of a woman who had been saved by bureaucracy, by the arbitrary, impersonal, procedural machinery of a prison system that had moved her from one cell to another without knowing that the move was the difference between her life and her death.

"I've been silent for eleven months because I was afraid. I'm not afraid anymore. The boy died. If I stay silent, another one dies. There will be another one. There is always another one."

---

Mama Siti visited Nurul on a Thursday afternoon.

The visiting room at Kajang Women's Prison was divided by a wall of glass -- thick, scratched by years of hands pressed against it. Mama Siti sat on the visitors' side wearing her apron, the white cotton apron stained with turmeric and chilli. She had not removed it. She had worn it through the LRT and the prison registration and the waiting, the apron that said *I am the cook, I am the one who feeds*.

Nurul appeared on the other side. She picked up the handset.

"Anak," Mama Siti said. *Child.*

"Mak Cik." *Auntie.*

"There was a boy. An Australian. He slept in the bed. The same bed."

"Bed 7," Nurul said.

"Bed 7."

"He was like me? Felix? Envelopes first, then packages?"

"Yes."

"He's dead," Nurul said. Not a question. "In custody. The protocol."

"Yes."

Nurul's eyes were wet but the wetness did not fall. "I should have spoken. Eleven months. I should have spoken on the first day."

"You were afraid."

"I was afraid. And the boy is dead because I was afraid."

Mama Siti pressed her hand against the glass. Nurul pressed hers from the other side. Palm to palm, finger to finger, separated by the thickness of institutional glass. The glass was cold on both sides.

"You can't stop it," Nurul said.

"I know."

"But you'll cook."

"I'll cook," Mama Siti said.

"Bring nasi lemak," Nurul said -- half joke, half plea.

Mama Siti looked at her niece through the glass. "I'll bring nasi lemak."

She walked out into the Kajang afternoon, an old woman in an apron heading for a train station, heading home to cook because cooking was the only answer she had to the question the system kept asking.

The hostel would reopen. The beds would be filled. The ceiling fans would turn.

---

*End of Chapter 47*
# Chapter 48: The Next One

Six weeks later, the Lantern Hostel was open.

This is how quickly the world forgets: six weeks. Six weeks between Connor Briggs dying in a holding cell and the return to normalcy at the building where he had lived for forty-seven days and slept in Bed 7 and eaten nasi lemak and carried packages and loved a woman and ignored the warnings and done all the things that a living person did in a building that housed the living until the living became the dead and the building continued without them.

Six weeks. In six weeks, the investigation had moved from the hostel to the courts. The media had moved from the hostel to the next story. The guests had moved from avoidance to curiosity to indifference. The Hostelworld reviews had moved from one-star warnings ("Someone DIED here, avoid!!!") to three-star qualifications ("Heard about the incident but the hostel seems fine now, good nasi lemak") to the standard four-star assessments that made no mention of death at all ("Great location, friendly staff, would stay again, wifi is a bit slow").

The world forgot. This was not cruelty. This was the world's mechanism for continuing -- catastrophe into history, history into amnesia, amnesia into a hostel listing on a booking website: THE LANTERN HOSTEL. RM35-85/NIGHT. FREE BREAKFAST. WIFI. WALKING DISTANCE TO PETALING STREET. 7.6/10 (352 REVIEWS).

The rating had dropped from 7.8 to 7.6. Two tenths of a point. That was the quantified cost of Connor Briggs's death on the hostel's commercial viability -- two tenths of a rating point, the aggregate effect of twelve one-star reviews posted in the weeks after the news broke, diluted by the three hundred and forty reviews that preceded them and the steady accumulation of new reviews from new guests who did not know or did not care about the death that had made the building temporarily famous and was now making it famous for something else, which was the same thing it had always been famous for, which was the nasi lemak and the red lanterns and the location and the view of the Petronas Towers from the rooftop.

The hostel was open. The beds were full. The ceiling fans turned. Mama Siti cooked. Mei Ling manned the reception. Razak was absent -- Razak had stepped back from daily operations, his role in the investigation requiring his presence at police stations and lawyers' offices more than at the hostel he owned. A temporary manager, a young man named Hafizul who had previously managed a hostel in George Town, handled the bookings and the complaints and the daily business of keeping forty-two beds occupied and the building functional.

The investigation continued in the background, the way investigations did -- slowly, bureaucratically, through the accumulation of documents and the scheduling of hearings and the procedural choreography of a legal system that moved at the speed of paperwork rather than the speed of grief. Wei was in remand at Sungai Buloh, cooperating, his testimony building the case file page by page. Hafiz, the guard, had been arrested and charged with accepting a bribe and facilitating a homicide. Felix Decker was the subject of an international warrant issued through Interpol, the warrant circulating through the law enforcement databases of twelve countries, the warrant a digital ghost pursuing a physical man who was, according to the intelligence, operating out of a hostel in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, a country with which Malaysia had an extradition treaty that was, like many extradition treaties, easier to invoke than to execute.

The story was in the courts. The story was in the Star's archive, searchable but no longer front-page. The story was on Tomoko's Instagram, where her photographs had been viewed 4.7 million times and shared by accounts with names like @TrueCrimeDaily and @BackpackerSafety and @JusticeForConnor. The story was on the #JusticeForConnor hashtag, which had trended for nine days and then declined in the way that all hashtags declined -- not because the cause became less just but because the algorithm moved on and the algorithm was the arbiter of attention and the attention span of the internet was measured in news cycles and the news cycles were measured in days and the days had passed.

Connor's parents had taken his body home. The repatriation had taken eleven days -- eleven days of consular paperwork and morgue releases and embalming procedures and flight arrangements and the grinding bureaucracy of moving a dead body across international borders, the bureaucracy that required certificates and permissions and the payment of fees that were the administrative cost of death, the invoices that arrived in the mailbox of a house in Hawthorn while the occupants of the house were in a state of grief that made the opening of mail an act of superhuman effort.

Connor was buried in a cemetery in Kew, three suburbs from the house where he'd grown up. The funeral was attended by two hundred people -- family, friends from school, his mother's medical colleagues, his father's business associates, the community of Hawthorn that had known the Briggs family for thirty years and that attended the funeral not because they had known Connor well (many had not seen him since he was a teenager) but because the funeral was the community's ritual of acknowledgement, the collective recognition that a member of the community's extended family had been lost and the loss required the physical presence of bodies in a chapel and the speaking of words and the lowering of a coffin into ground that was, in a different hemisphere and a different climate, the same ground -- the earth, the dirt, the surface of a planet that received bodies without distinction.

The funeral was over. The investigation continued. The hostel was open.

And on a Tuesday evening, six weeks and two days after Connor Briggs died, a young man walked through the narrow door between the phone repair shop (still closed, the shutters down, the sign dark) and the Chinese medicine store (open, smelling of dried herbs and ginseng), and entered the Lantern Hostel.

---

His name was Oliver. Oliver Price. British. Twenty-four. From Croydon, which he described as "South London" because South London sounded better than Croydon, the same way "digital nomad" sounded better than "unemployed" and "gap year" sounded better than "running away."

He had arrived that morning on an AirAsia flight from Bangkok, fleeing the slow realisation that the money was running out and the thing he'd come to find -- "myself" or "perspective" or "the real world" -- remained unfound and the looking was becoming indistinguishable from the avoidance of everything he'd left behind: a job, a relationship, a flat, a life that had ceased to feel like a life.

He was tall, thin, pink-skinned, wearing a T-shirt from a hostel in Chiang Mai and carrying a battered Osprey covered in patches.

He rang the bell.

Mei Ling appeared. Mei Ling looked at Oliver the way Mei Ling looked at every new guest -- with the practised assessment of a receptionist who had checked in thousands of young travellers and had developed, over those thousands of check-ins, an instinct for categorisation. She categorised Oliver in approximately four seconds: British, broke, solo, between things. The category was the most common category. The category was the hostel's primary demographic. The category was Connor.

"Checking in?" Mei Ling said.

"Yeah. I booked online. Oliver Price."

Mei Ling consulted the screen. The booking system was the same booking system that had processed Connor's reservation six weeks and forty-nine days earlier. The system was digital. The system did not remember Connor. The system remembered data -- names, dates, bed assignments, payment methods -- and the data was stored in a database on a server in Singapore and the server did not know that one of the names in the database was the name of a dead man and the bed assignment attached to that name was the bed on which the dead man had slept.

"Passport, please."

Oliver handed over his passport. British. Issued in London. The photograph showed a younger, cleaner Oliver -- the photograph taken in a booth at Croydon station eighteen months ago, the face the face of a man who had not yet been to Southeast Asia and had not yet lost the girlfriend and the job and the flat. The face was recognisable but altered, the way all passport photographs became altered by the time they were used for the purpose for which they were taken, the face a historical document, a record of who the holder had been when the document was issued, not who the holder was now.

Mei Ling photocopied the passport. She entered the information into the system. She assigned a bed.

"Bed 7, Dorm 3. Second floor, end of the corridor, bottom bunk on the left."

The bed number arrived in the air between them and settled. Mei Ling did not flinch. Mei Ling had assigned Bed 7 fourteen times since the hostel reopened. Fourteen guests in six weeks, the turnover rate the standard turnover rate for a budget hostel in a major tourist city, two to four nights per guest, the guests arriving and departing and the bed receiving and releasing bodies with the regularity of a system that was designed for exactly this -- the temporary housing of transient people, the provision of a surface on which to sleep for a price that was the price of a meal in a mid-range restaurant, the transaction so minor and so routine that the assignment of the specific bed on which a man had slept before being murdered was, to the system, unremarkable.

"WiFi password's on the board," Mei Ling said. "Breakfast is seven to ten. Kitchen's communal. Quiet after eleven. You'll need your own padlock for the locker."

"Cheers."

Oliver took the keycard. He climbed the staircase. The staircase was narrow. The walls were covered in stickers. The stickers were the same stickers, minus the handful that had peeled off and plus the handful that new guests had added in the six weeks since the hostel had reopened. A new sticker: a rainbow-coloured oval that said KHAOSAN ROAD SURVIVOR. Another: a small square with a QR code that, if scanned, led to the Instagram account of a Swedish backpacker who was attempting to visit every country in the world and was currently at number forty-seven and whose account had six thousand followers and whose life was, like Connor's life had been, curated for an audience that was smaller than the curation effort warranted.

The third step squeaked.

Oliver noticed the squeak. He noticed it the way every guest noticed it -- a brief sensory registration, a filing of the information under "hostel character," a forgetting that began immediately and would be complete by the third ascent. The squeak was the building's voice and the voice said the same thing it always said, which was *I am here, I am old, I have been climbed by thousands of feet and I will be climbed by thousands more and the climbing is my purpose and my wear.*

Second floor. Corridor. Dorm 3.

The room was the room. Eight bunks, ceiling fan, air well. Five beds claimed by the evidence of absent people: backpacks, clothing, a novel, a phone charger. Bed 7 was empty, the mattress bare except for the folded sheet and towel.

Oliver sat on the mattress. He heard voices from the air well -- laughter, ease -- and smelled cooking from the ground floor. Mama Siti's kitchen, the eternal kitchen.

He lay back and closed his eyes. The flight from Bangkok had been early. He was tired. He slept.

The ceiling fan turned above him. And in the bed frame beneath his sleeping body, the letters were still there. LENA. Four letters scratched into dark wood. And below LENA, the other names -- TOM, JULIE, HANS -- the names of people who had slept here and left and survived and forgotten.

Connor's name was not there. But the bed that Connor had slept in was the bed that Oliver was sleeping in, and the continuity was the continuity of the system -- the system that produced young travellers and cheap hostels and the intersection of the two, and the occasional, inevitable interruption of the flow by violence or the law.

---

Oliver came downstairs at seven in the evening.

The common room was occupied. Three guests on the vinyl couch, watching CNN on the wall-mounted television -- the news cycle that was, as always, a rotation of crises and recoveries and the perpetual middle-distance of geopolitics that was the soundtrack of hostel common rooms worldwide. Two guests at the communal table, laptops open, the blue glow of screens reflecting off their faces, the digital nomads or the pretenders to digital nomadism, the people who sat in hostels with laptops and called it work and called themselves location-independent and were, in their way, performing the same ritual that Connor had performed at the same table six weeks ago.

Mama Siti was in the kitchen. The kitchen was warm. The kitchen smelled of onion and garlic and the particular, complex fragrance of sambal being cooked -- the chilli paste that was the base of half of Malay cuisine, the paste that Mama Siti made fresh every morning and that was, by evening, reduced to the remnants that clung to the pot and perfumed the air.

Oliver entered the common room and stood for a moment in the doorway, performing the social assessment that every solo traveller performed when entering a communal space: who is here, who looks approachable, who is too absorbed to disturb, where is the entry point to conversation. The assessment was unconscious, practised, the survival skill of a person who had been travelling alone for six months and had learned that the difference between loneliness and companionship was the willingness to walk into a room of strangers and say something.

He said something. "Anyone know where's good to eat around here?"

The question was the universal hostel opener -- the question that was not really about food but about connection, the question that said *I am here, I am new, I am available for the temporary friendship that this building facilitates.* The question was answered by one of the laptop users -- a Dutch woman, twenties, who recommended a hawker stall on Jalan Alor without looking up from her screen, the recommendation delivered with the practised efficiency of a person who had answered the same question from the same type of person in the same type of building in the same type of city dozens of times.

Oliver nodded. He started toward the door.

"Actually, mate, I was just heading out. I know a brilliant spot if you want company."

The voice came from behind him. Oliver turned.

The man was sitting in a chair by the window, a chair that Oliver had not registered because the man had been still, the stillness of a person who had been waiting, although waiting was not the word -- the word was *watching*, the passive, patient observation of the common room's traffic, the watching of a person who was looking for something and had just found it.

The man was Malaysian. Young -- late twenties, maybe early thirties. He was handsome in the way that charming people were handsome, which was to say that the handsomeness was not purely physical but was a combination of features and expression and the animation of the face that came from an intelligence that manifested as social ease. He wore a clean collared shirt, rolled at the sleeves, and dark jeans and leather shoes that were slightly too nice for a hostel common room. He had a beer in his hand -- a Tiger beer, the green bottle sweating condensation in the humid air.

He was not Felix. Felix was in Cambodia. Felix was operating out of a hostel in Phnom Penh, a city with cheaper rents and looser enforcement and the restless, accelerating energy of a Southeast Asian city that was experiencing the kind of growth that attracted both investment and exploitation, the growth that created opportunities for the legitimate and the illegitimate alike. Felix was in Cambodia and Felix was not coming back and Felix's warrant was circulating through the databases and the warrant would find him or it would not and the finding or the not-finding was the system's business, the slow, procedural pursuit that was the legal system's version of a chase, the chase measured not in kilometres but in documents.

This man was not Felix. This man was someone else. This man was the system's next iteration, the pattern's next expression, the proof that the pattern was not dependent on Felix, was not the product of a single charming German but was the product of conditions -- the conditions of a hostel in a city in a country where drugs moved through bodies and the bodies were recruited from the common rooms of buildings like this one by people like this one, the people who were charming and local and knew the city and knew the opportunities and knew the targets.

"I'm Riz," the man said. He extended his hand. The handshake was firm, warm, the handshake of a person who had been trained in the social protocols that made strangers comfortable, the handshake that was the first gesture of a relationship that would develop according to a pattern that was not Riz's invention but the pattern's invention, the pattern reproducing itself through a new operator the way a franchise reproduced itself through new locations, the product the same, the branding different, the system identical.

"Oliver," Oliver said.

"British?"

"Yeah. London. Well, Croydon. South London."

Riz smiled. The smile was the smile of a person who found the other person's answer charming, who found the distinction between Croydon and South London amusing and endearing, who found Oliver -- broke, alone, between things, newly arrived -- to be exactly the kind of person who was worth smiling at, worth buying a beer for, worth investing an evening in.

"First time in KL?"

"Yeah. Just got in from Bangkok."

"Bangkok." Riz nodded, the nod of a person who understood Bangkok and its particular intensity, the nod of a person who had context for Oliver's arrival and could place it in the narrative of a young traveller moving through Southeast Asia. "Bangkok's intense. KL's different. KL's... easier. More relaxed. You'll like it."

"I hope so."

"Come on, I'll take you to a hawker centre. The real one, not the tourist one. My treat."

The offer was the offer. The offer was a beer and a meal and the company of a local who knew the city and who was generous and charming and who had appeared at exactly the moment when Oliver needed exactly what this man was offering -- connection, guidance, the antidote to the loneliness that had followed him from Croydon to Bangkok to KL.

Oliver hesitated. The hesitation was brief -- approximately two seconds, the duration of a thought that did not fully form, the thought that was less a thought than an instinct, the instinct that something about this situation was familiar in a way that Oliver could not place because Oliver had not been in this situation before but the situation had existed before, the situation was a pattern, and patterns generated a frequency that some people could detect and some people could not, and Oliver was in the category of people who could detect the frequency but could not interpret it, who felt the vibration without identifying the source.

The hesitation passed. The two seconds elapsed. The thought -- or the instinct, or the vibration -- dissolved, the way all such subtle warnings dissolved when they were not reinforced by knowledge, by context, by the specific information that would have converted the instinct into a decision. The information that would have converted the instinct into a decision was: a man named Connor Briggs sat in this common room six weeks ago and a man named Felix Decker made the same offer and the offer led to envelopes and the envelopes led to packages and the packages led to a suitcase and the suitcase led to a checkpoint and the checkpoint led to a cell and the cell led to a towel and the towel led to death. This information existed. This information was in police files and newspaper archives and Tomoko's Instagram and the memories of Priya and Jake and Mei Ling and Mama Siti and Ahmad. This information was everywhere except in Oliver's head, and the absence of the information in Oliver's head was the absence that made the pattern possible, the gap in knowledge that was the gap through which the pattern moved, the ignorance that was not stupidity but was the human condition of not knowing what you did not know.

"Yeah, alright," Oliver said. "Sounds good."

Riz bought Oliver a beer from the cooler behind reception. Tiger, the same green bottle, RM8. Mei Ling processed the sale. Mei Ling looked at Riz. Mei Ling looked at Oliver. Mei Ling looked at the beer.

Mei Ling's expression did not change. The professional composure held.

But behind it, Mei Ling felt the recognition. Not the man. The sequence. New guest. Charming local. Beer. The offer. She had watched this sequence before. She knew how it ended.

Mei Ling handed the beer to Oliver. "Enjoy," she said.

The word was the word of a receptionist. The word was also a prayer. The word was the hope that Oliver would enjoy his beer and his evening and his stay at the Lantern Hostel and would leave alive and would never know how close he was, in this moment, to the beginning of a sequence that had killed the man who had slept in his bed six weeks ago.

Oliver and Riz left through the front door. The bell rang. The door closed. The common room resumed its evening rhythm -- the CNN broadcast, the laptop screens, the slow accumulation of guests returning from the day and gathering in the shared space that was the hostel's social heart.

---

Mama Siti saw.

She was in the kitchen. She was always in the kitchen. She observed through the window between kitchen and common room -- the frame through which the hostel's daily drama played, the cast rotating but the plot unchanged.

She saw Oliver. She saw the beer. She saw Riz. She saw the offer. She saw the acceptance. She saw the departure.

Her face did not change. Guests described it as "inscrutable," which was the word tourists used for a face they could not read. The face was not inscrutable. The face was the face of a woman watching the first scene of a story she had seen before.

She turned from the window. She went to the rice cooker. The rice cooker was plugged in. The rice was soaking -- the basmati that she used for nasi lemak, the rice washed three times and soaked for two hours in coconut milk and pandan leaf, the preparation that was the ritual's beginning, the first step in the process that would produce, by 6 AM the next morning, the nasi lemak that would be placed on the counter in the kitchen.

She checked the sambal. The sambal was in the pot on the stove, reduced and resting, the chilli paste that was the heart of the dish, the paste that had been cooked since early morning and was now at the stage of its preparation where it needed only to cool and be stored and be reheated tomorrow. The sambal was ready. The anchovies were fried. The peanuts were roasted. The eggs were boiled.

The nasi lemak would be ready in the morning. The plate would be set at the counter. The banana leaf would be laid out. The rice would be mounded. The sambal would be spooned. The anchovies would be scattered. The peanuts would be placed. The egg would be halved and positioned, the yolk bright against the white, the white bright against the green of the banana leaf.

The plate would be there. The plate would be the question. The question was the question that Mama Siti asked every morning, the question that was not spoken but was contained in the plate, in the food, in the act of preparation, the question that was:

*If you come to eat, I will know you are still alive.*

The question would be asked of Oliver, as it had been asked of Connor, as it had been asked of every guest who had slept in the hostel during the seventeen years that Mama Siti had cooked in its kitchen. The question was not a magic spell. The question was not a protection. The question was a woman's way of counting the living, of taking attendance, of performing the daily census that was the cook's privilege and the cook's burden -- the burden of knowing that the absence of a person at breakfast was the absence that might mean departure or might mean death, and the difference between the two was the difference between a guest who had checked out and a guest who had been checked out, and the checking out was sometimes voluntary and sometimes was not.

Mama Siti covered the sambal pot. She wiped the counter. She removed her apron and folded it and placed it on the hook by the door. She turned off the kitchen light.

She walked through the common room. The guests did not notice her. The cook was part of the building's infrastructure, invisible in the way that all service workers were invisible to the people they served.

She walked to the front door. She paused. She looked back at the common room. The room was warm. The red lanterns glowed. The ceiling fans turned. The guests sat and talked and typed and lived.

Somewhere in the city, a young British man was eating hawker food with a charming local man who had bought him a beer and who was asking about his plans and who was saying, perhaps at this very moment, the words that were the words: *I might know a way to make some easy money.*

The words would be spoken. Or the words would not be spoken -- not tonight, maybe, but tomorrow, or the next day, or the day after. The words would be spoken because the words were the pattern's dialogue, the script that the system produced, and the system did not require Felix to produce the script. The system required only the conditions -- the lonely foreigner, the financial pressure, the charming stranger, the offer -- and the conditions were met, and the conditions were always met, and the meeting of the conditions was the pattern's activation, the system's ignition, the beginning of the sequence that began with a beer and ended, sometimes, with a cell.

Mama Siti did not know if the sequence would complete. She did not know if Oliver would accept the offer, if Oliver would carry the envelope, if Oliver would escalate from envelope to package to backpack to suitcase. She did not know because the future was the future and the future was unknowable and the knowing of the future was not her function. Her function was the kitchen. Her function was the nasi lemak. Her function was the plate on the counter and the question in the plate and the counting of the living.

She stepped into the street. Petaling Street was busy with the evening crowd -- the tourists and the locals and the hawkers and the traffic, the sensory tumult of a city that did not slow down at night but merely changed its register, the daytime commerce replaced by the nighttime commerce, the market stalls replaced by the food stalls, the shoppers replaced by the diners.

She walked toward the LRT station. Her steps were slow. Her steps were the steps of a woman who had been walking this street for longer than the hostel had existed, who had been present in this neighbourhood since before the building was a hostel, since before it was an abandoned ruin, since before it was a brothel and a gambling den and a Japanese administrative office. Her steps were the steps of continuity, the human thread that connected the building's iterations, the woman who had cooked in the kitchen under every version of the building's identity and who would cook in the kitchen under the next version, whatever the next version was.

The nasi lemak would be ready in the morning.

The plate would be set at the counter.

The question would be asked.

And the answer -- the answer that was not words but was the act of arriving, the act of sitting, the act of eating, the act of being present at breakfast in a body that was alive and hungry and capable of the simple, essential, irreducible act of consuming food -- the answer would be given or it would not, and the giving or the not-giving would tell Mama Siti what she needed to know, which was the only thing she had ever needed to know, which was: *are you still here? Are you still alive? Did you survive the night?*

The night would tell.

The night always told.

---

In the common room, the television showed the news. The news was not about Connor Briggs. The news was about a trade deal and a typhoon and a football match and the rotation of events that was the news cycle's content, the cycle that had absorbed Connor's story and processed it and expelled it and moved on to the next story and the next, the cycle that was the mechanism by which the world converted events into history and history into the past and the past into the material from which the future was built.

The common room was warm. The lanterns glowed. The ceiling fans turned.

Upstairs, in Dorm 3, Bed 7 was empty. The mattress held the impression of Oliver's body -- the slight depression, the warmth that was fading, the evidence of recent occupation that would be gone by morning. The bed waited. The bed was patient. The bed had the patience of a thing that had no consciousness and therefore no impatience, a thing that existed in the permanent present tense of objects, the tense in which there was no waiting because there was no expectation of what came next.

The ceiling fan turned above the bed.

*Tick, tick, tick.*

The sound was the building's heartbeat. The sound was the metronome of the system. The sound measured nothing and the sound measured everything -- the interval between arrivals, the interval between departures, the interval between the filling and the emptying of a bed that had been filled and emptied hundreds of times and would be filled and emptied hundreds of times more.

The pattern was not Felix. The pattern was the system. The system was not the network. The system was the world. The world was the world, and the world produced the conditions, and the conditions produced the pattern, and the pattern produced the deaths, and the deaths were absorbed by the building and the building continued and the pattern continued and the world continued.

The ceiling fan turned.

The lanterns glowed.

The night fell on Kuala Lumpur the way night fell on all cities -- without discrimination, without mercy, without awareness of what the darkness concealed, which was everything: the charming strangers and the lonely travellers and the hawker stalls and the police stations and the cells and the towels and the law that applied to everyone and the law that spared no one and the law that was the law and the law did not care and the law did not forgive and the law was waiting, the law was always waiting, for the next one.

---

*End of Chapter 48*
# Chapter 49: @HostelReaper

Tomoko found the account on a Wednesday, three months after Connor's death.

She found it the way all digital investigations began -- not with a search but with a recognition. A piece of information encountered casually, peripherally, that was not noise but signal, not random but patterned. The recognition arrived at 2:17 AM in Osaka, where Tomoko had returned after three months of travel -- KL to Bangkok to Hanoi to Hong Kong and back to Japan.

She was sitting on the floor of her room in Tennoji -- the desk she never used, the floor she always used, the laptop open in front of her like a viewfinder into the digital residue of Connor Briggs's death.

She had been looking for three months. The looking had begun on the day after the death, when she had received Priya's message -- the WhatsApp message that had arrived while Tomoko was in the hostel's common room, the message that said *Connor is dead, murdered in custody, the letter went to Ahmad, the photographs, use them, tell the truth* -- and the message had activated in Tomoko the thing that was her function, which was the documentation of truth, the recording of the thing that had happened, the translation of event into image and image into story and story into public record.

Her photographs had been published. The Star had run them first -- the photographs of Felix Decker in the hostel's common room, the photographs of Felix and Wei at the phone repair shop, the photographs of Felix's late-night exchanges on the rooftop, the photographs that were the visual evidence of a trafficking operation that had been conducted in plain sight, in a building full of witnesses, by a man who was charming enough to make the witnesses look elsewhere. The Star had run the photographs and the international wire services had picked them up and the photographs had appeared in The Guardian and The Sydney Morning Herald and The Asahi Shimbun and on websites and social media accounts and in the briefing documents of the parliamentary committee that was reviewing the circumstances of Connor Briggs's death.

The photographs were her contribution. The photographs were the thing she could do. But the photographs were not enough -- the photographs documented the trafficking operation but they did not explain the death, did not explain the system, did not explain the pattern that connected Connor's death to the deaths that had come before and the deaths that would come after. The photographs were evidence but they were not understanding. Understanding required investigation, required research, required the kind of sustained, obsessive, sleepless inquiry that Tomoko was now conducting at 2:17 AM on the floor of her room in Osaka with a laptop and a pot of green tea and the focused, sleepless energy of a person who had found a thread and was pulling it.

The thread was @HostelReaper.

She had first encountered the account on the day of Connor's death -- the Instagram post that had appeared at 4:17 PM Malaysian time, the photograph of the empty cell at Dang Wangi, the caption that named Connor and his age and his nationality and the day of his death, the hashtags: #LocalLaw #101Ways #MandatoryDeath #TheRulesApply. She had seen the post because she had been searching Instagram for posts tagged with #LanternHostel and #ConnorBriggs, the search that journalists conducted in the immediate aftermath of a newsworthy death, the search for the digital traces of the event, the social media footprint that accompanied every death in the modern world.

The @HostelReaper post had been one of many posts in the search results. She had noted it, screenshotted it, filed it. She had not investigated further -- the immediate priority was the photographs, the story, the evidence that needed to be delivered to The Star and to Ahmad's investigation.

But the post had stayed with her. The post had occupied a space in her mind that was reserved for the things that did not fit, the anomalies, the pieces of information that could not be explained by the available context. The post did not fit because the post had been made at 4:17 PM on Saturday -- approximately fourteen hours after the body was found, before the hostel had been officially notified, before the Australian High Commission had contacted the family, before any media outlet had reported the death. The post contained information that should not have been available to anyone outside the investigation: Connor's name, his age, his nationality, the specific cell number, the date of death.

The post knew things it should not have known.

This was the thread. This was the thing that Tomoko had been pulling for three months, the thread that had led her from the single post about Connor to the account's other posts, and from the other posts to the other deaths, and from the other deaths to the pattern that connected them, the pattern that was @HostelReaper's archive, the digital record of a series of deaths in hostels across the world that the account had documented with the same specificity and the same impossible foreknowledge.

Twelve posts. Twelve deaths. Eleven countries. Three years.

Tomoko had a spreadsheet. The spreadsheet was the journalist's tool -- the organized, systematic record of the data she had collected, the data arranged in columns: Post Number, Date, Location, Victim Name, Age, Nationality, Cause of Death, Hostel Name, Time Between Death and Post, Source of Death Confirmation.

She read the spreadsheet. She read it the way she read all data -- not as numbers but as stories, each row a life, each cell a fact, each fact a fragment of a narrative that, when assembled with the other facts, produced a picture that was both clear and incomprehensible.

Post 1. 22 March, three years ago. Luang Prabang, Laos. Emma Whitfield. 21. British. Drowned in the Mekong River after falling from a hostel's riverside deck. Gecko Guesthouse. The post appeared six hours after the drowning, eight hours before the local newspaper reported it. The caption: *Emma Whitfield. 21. UK. Day 12. Checked out. #101Ways #TheRiverKnows.*

Post 2. 7 June, three years ago. Bogota, Colombia. Marcus Chen. 23. Canadian. Fell from the fourth floor of a hostel in La Candelaria. The police report said accidental. The hostel's security camera showed Marcus alone on the balcony at 3 AM. The post appeared four hours after the fall, twelve hours before the Canadian embassy was notified. The caption: *Marcus Chen. 23. Canada. Day 8. Checked out. #101Ways #TheHeightOfIt.*

Post 3. 14 September, three years ago. Kathmandu, Nepal. Ingrid Larsson. 26. Swedish. Food poisoning. Died in her dorm room. The hostel staff found her in the morning. The post appeared two hours after the body was discovered. Two hours. The caption: *Ingrid Larsson. 26. Sweden. Day 31. Checked out. #101Ways #LastSupper.*

The spreadsheet continued. Post 4: Cape Town, South Africa. Post 5: Hanoi, Vietnam. Post 6: Cartagena, Colombia. Post 7: Siem Reap, Cambodia. Post 8: Nairobi, Kenya. Post 9: Quito, Ecuador. Post 10: Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Post 11: Johor Bahru, Malaysia -- Daniel Park, the Korean-American, the death that Wei had described in his testimony, the death that was the same as Connor's, the death in custody, the protocol.

Post 12. Connor Briggs. KL. The Lantern Hostel. The post that had started Tomoko's investigation.

Twelve deaths. Eleven countries. Three years. Every post matched a real death. Every post appeared before the death was publicly reported. Every post contained specific, verifiable details -- names, ages, nationalities, the number of days the victim had been at the hostel. Every post used the same hashtag: #101Ways. Every post used the same sign-off: *Checked out.*

Tomoko had verified each death. The verification had taken three months -- three months of emails to police departments and embassies and local newspapers and the families of the dead, the families who had, in most cases, never heard of @HostelReaper and who responded to Tomoko's inquiries with the particular mixture of confusion and grief that was the response of people who had lost a child to a foreign country and were now being asked about an Instagram account that had documented the loss before they had been notified of it. The verification was painful. The verification required Tomoko to contact people who were still grieving and to ask them questions that reopened wounds that had not closed. The verification was the cost of the investigation, and the cost was borne by the families, and the families bore it because the families wanted answers and the answers were not available from the police or the embassies or the governments that had presided over their children's deaths.

Every death was real. Every post was accurate. The account knew.

The question was: how?

---

Tomoko wrote the article in three days.

The article was titled: "The Account That Knows When Backpackers Die." Eight thousand words. An investigation that began with a single Instagram post about a death in KL and expanded outward to encompass twelve deaths in eleven countries over three years.

The @HostelReaper Instagram account had no profile picture. Bio: *101 Ways. Check-out is mandatory.* Following zero accounts. 147 followers -- true-crime enthusiasts, travel bloggers, and two journalists tracking the same digital traces Tomoko was tracking.

The account had been created three years and four months ago. The first post -- Emma Whitfield, Luang Prabang -- appeared three days after creation. The posting schedule followed the deaths.

Tomoko had attempted to identify the account's operator. The attempt had involved three avenues of investigation, each of which had reached a dead end.

Avenue one: Instagram's data. Tomoko had submitted a formal request to Meta's press office for information about the @HostelReaper account -- the email address used to register the account, the IP addresses from which the account had been accessed, the device identifiers associated with the account's activity. Meta had responded with a form letter stating that the company could not release user data without a valid legal order from a law enforcement agency. Tomoko had contacted Ahmad, who had contacted Interpol, who had submitted a request to Meta through the Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty process. The request was pending. The request had been pending for six weeks. The request would likely be pending for several more months, the speed of international legal cooperation being the speed of international legal cooperation, which was the speed of bureaucracy multiplied by the number of jurisdictions involved.

Avenue two: digital forensics. Tomoko had consulted a cybersecurity researcher at Osaka University, a colleague who specialised in social media analysis. The researcher had examined the account's posts for metadata -- the digital information embedded in photographs, the EXIF data that could reveal the camera model, the GPS coordinates, the time and date of the photograph. The metadata had been stripped. Every photograph posted by @HostelReaper had been processed through a metadata-removal tool before being uploaded, the processing the mark of a person who understood digital forensics and who had taken precautions against precisely the kind of analysis that Tomoko's colleague was attempting. The photographs were clean. The photographs contained no information beyond the visual content.

Avenue three: the content itself. Tomoko had analysed the photographs and the captions for patterns that might reveal the poster's identity, location, or methodology. The analysis had produced several observations but no conclusions.

Observation one: the photographs were taken from inside the hostels. The photographs showed interiors -- dorm rooms, common rooms, bathrooms, corridors. The photographs were not taken from public spaces or external vantage points. The photographer had been inside the buildings. This meant that the photographer was either a guest, a staff member, or had access to the buildings through some other means.

Observation two: the photographs of the death locations were taken after the deaths but before the areas were secured by police. The photograph of Connor's cell, for example, showed the empty cell with the fluorescent light on and the word REAPER scratched into the bench. The photograph was taken after Connor's body had been removed but before the forensic team had processed the scene. This meant the photographer had access to the cell between the removal of the body and the securing of the scene -- a window of approximately two hours, according to Ahmad's timeline of the investigation.

Observation three: the captions contained information that was not publicly available at the time of posting. The number of days the victim had been at the hostel, for example, was not information that would be available to a casual observer or a person monitoring news reports. This information was available to hostel staff (who would know the check-in date), to police (who would obtain it during the investigation), or to someone who had been observing the victim during their stay.

Observation four: the hashtag #101Ways appeared in every post. The number 101 was not random. The number appeared to be a count -- or a target. If @HostelReaper was documenting deaths in hostels, and if the number 101 was a target, then the account was documenting its way toward a goal, and Connor Briggs was a data point, and each death was a data point, and the data points were accumulating toward a number that was, perhaps, a completion, an endpoint, a final checkout.

But this was speculation. The article did not speculate. The article presented the observations and left the conclusions to the reader, the reader who would draw the conclusions that the evidence supported and the conclusions that the evidence did not support and the conclusions that existed in the space between evidence and imagination, the space that was the territory of mystery, the territory that @HostelReaper occupied.

The article was published in *The Bureau of Investigative Journalism*. Shared 47,000 times in its first week. Picked up by the BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera, news outlets in each of the eleven countries where the deaths had occurred.

The article did not solve the mystery. The article deepened it -- placing a single, strange Instagram account in the context of twelve real deaths, converting what might have been a macabre hoax into something that demanded explanation. The account did not explain itself. The account simply posted. The account simply said *I know* and offered no account of how it knew.

---

The @HostelReaper account posted one final photograph related to Connor's death.

The photograph appeared three days after Tomoko's article was published. The photograph was the thirteenth post. The photograph showed a bathroom stall.

The bathroom stall was in the Lantern Hostel, second floor, the bathroom adjacent to Dorm 3. The stall was the stall that guests used daily -- the tile walls, the squat toilet, the plastic cistern with the flush that required three attempts, the drain in the floor that was perpetually damp. The stall was unremarkable in every way except one.

On the wall, at eye level for a person sitting on the toilet, words were written in black marker. The handwriting was neat, small, controlled -- not the scrawl of a drunk or the rushed tagging of a vandal but the deliberate, careful letters of a person who had taken the time to write legibly, who had wanted the words to be read, who had treated the wall of a bathroom stall in a Chinatown hostel with the same attention that a calligrapher treated rice paper.

The words were: @HostelReaper was here. Check-out is mandatory.

Below the words, a small drawing -- a reaper figure, the cloaked skeletal figure that was the Western iconography of death, the figure rendered in miniature with a level of detail that was incongruous with the medium, the figure drawn with the care of an illustration rather than the haste of graffiti.

The photograph showed the graffiti in sharp focus. The tile wall behind it was the pale green of Southeast Asian bathrooms, the colour that was the colour of institutions and public spaces and the shared facilities of budget accommodation. The lighting was the lighting of a bathroom -- fluorescent, flat, the light that made everything look clinical and slightly unwell.

The caption was: *#LocalLaw. Filed. // Next: somewhere the river runs through the rooms. #BookOfTheNile. Check-out is mandatory. Always.*

The post had one additional element that the previous posts had not included. Below the caption, in the space where Instagram allowed additional text, a line: *"Orang yang tak tahu undang-undang, undang-undang tak tahu dia."*

Mama Siti's proverb. The proverb she had told Connor on his seventh day at the hostel. The proverb that meant "he who doesn't know the law, the law doesn't know him." The proverb that Connor had ignored and that was now, three months after his death, inscribed in the digital record of his death by an account that should not have known the proverb was spoken, that should not have known the proverb existed in the context of Connor's story, because the proverb had been spoken in a kitchen, in a private conversation, between an old woman and a young man who was dead.

Tomoko saw the post. She saw it at 11:42 PM, Osaka time, in her room, on her phone, the phone resting on the floor beside the futon on which she was not sleeping because sleep was the thing that eluded her when the investigation was active, the investigation a kind of insomnia, the pursuit of the answer the thing that kept the mind turning like the ceiling fans at the Lantern Hostel, turning and turning without arriving.

She looked at the photograph. She looked at the caption.

*#LocalLaw. Filed.*

The words were a close. The words were the ending of a chapter -- not a chapter of a book but the chapter that was Connor's story, the iteration of the @HostelReaper archive that was designated #LocalLaw, the hashtag that had appeared in every post about Connor, the hashtag that was the account's filing system, the taxonomy of death.

*Next: somewhere the river runs through the rooms. #BookOfTheNile.*

The words were an opening. The words were the beginning of the next chapter, the next story, the next death. The Nile. Egypt, perhaps. Or Sudan. Or Uganda. Or any of the eleven countries through which the Nile flowed. The words were a prediction -- or an announcement, or a promise, or a threat. The words said: *I am not finished. There will be another one. The account will continue. The documentation will continue. The deaths will continue.*

Tomoko screenshotted the post. She added it to the spreadsheet. She updated the article with an addendum. She sent the addendum to the Bureau's editor with a note: *New post. The account is still active. The account is moving to a new location. The next death is being anticipated.*

She sat in her room. The room was small. The room was quiet. Three months. Twelve deaths. Eleven countries. An account that knew things before the knowing was possible. She stared at the dark screen of the laptop the way she stared through a viewfinder -- waiting for the image to resolve.

The mystery was the point. Tomoko understood this. As a journalist, she wanted answers -- she wanted the name behind the account, the method of the knowledge, the explanation that would convert the mystery into a fact and the fact into a story and the story into a publication that would satisfy the reader's need for resolution. But the mystery resisted resolution. The mystery was designed to resist resolution -- the metadata stripped, the identity hidden, the account's operation conducted with a level of security that suggested not amateur obsession but professional infrastructure, not a person with a hobby but a system with a function.

The function was documentation. The function was the recording of deaths that the world would otherwise forget, the deaths that occurred in hostels and guesthouses and budget lodges in countries where young travellers went to find themselves and sometimes found, instead, the thing that waited at the end of every journey, the thing that was not enlightenment or adventure or love but was the other thing, the final thing, the thing that @HostelReaper called checkout.

Who was @HostelReaper?

Tomoko had theories. She did not publish them because theories were not facts and she was a journalist and journalists published facts. But in her room in Osaka, at midnight, with the green tea cold and the laptop's screen the only light, she allowed herself the theories, the speculations, the possibilities that existed in the space between what she knew and what she did not.

Theory one: @HostelReaper was a person. A single person. A traveller, perhaps, who moved through the hostel circuit the way that all travellers moved through the hostel circuit, staying in dorms, eating communal breakfasts, climbing narrow staircases. A person who was present at the hostels where the deaths occurred, who witnessed the deaths or their immediate aftermath, who photographed the locations and posted the photographs with the information they had gathered during their stay. This theory explained the interior photographs and the specific knowledge. This theory did not explain the timing -- the posts appearing before the deaths were publicly reported, the posts appearing in hostels in eleven different countries over three years, the logistical impossibility of a single person being present at twelve deaths in eleven countries unless the person knew, in advance, where the deaths would occur.

Theory two: @HostelReaper was a network. A group of people, distributed across the hostel circuit, each person responsible for a region or a city, the network coordinating through the shared Instagram account. This theory explained the geographic distribution and the timing. This theory did not explain the consistency -- the identical voice, the identical formatting, the identical aesthetic of the photographs, the uniformity suggesting a single sensibility rather than a collective.

Theory three: @HostelReaper was connected to the deaths. Not a witness but a participant. Not a documenter but an architect. The account did not report deaths -- the account predicted them, or caused them, or was part of a system that caused them. The darkest theory. The 2 AM theory. The one she returned to the way her fingers returned to a scar -- not wanting to touch it, touching it anyway. Behind the data, a door. Behind the door, something she was not sure she wanted to photograph. This theory explained everything -- the timing, the specificity, the impossible foreknowledge. This theory was also the theory that, if true, meant that @HostelReaper was not a mystery to be solved but a danger to be confronted, and the confrontation was not a journalistic task but a law enforcement task, and the law enforcement agencies of eleven countries were not yet coordinated enough to confront it.

Theory four: @HostelReaper was something else. Not a person, not a network, not a participant. Something that existed in the digital space the way a haunting existed in a physical space -- a presence felt but not seen, detectable but not identifiable. Tomoko did not believe in ghosts. But the feeling persisted: @HostelReaper was not a who but a what. Not a person but a condition.

Tomoko did not choose between the theories. Tomoko held them all, the way a good journalist held multiple hypotheses, the holding not a failure of conviction but a discipline of inquiry, the discipline that said: *I do not know, and the not-knowing is the honest position, and the honest position is the position from which the investigation proceeds.*

The investigation would proceed. Tomoko would continue. The account would continue. The deaths would continue. And the investigation and the account and the deaths would continue in their parallel tracks, the tracks intersecting at the points where the documentation met the reality and the reality met the documentation, the intersection the place where the truth lived, the truth that was not a conclusion but a process, not a destination but a direction.

---

The graffiti in the bathroom stall was there before Connor arrived. The graffiti would be there after.

This was the fact that Tomoko had confirmed through her investigation. She had contacted Mei Ling, who had confirmed that the graffiti had been noticed by a guest approximately seven months before Connor's check-in. The guest had mentioned it to Mei Ling at the reception desk: "There's some weird graffiti in the second-floor bathroom. Something about a reaper?" Mei Ling had noted it and done nothing because the hostel's walls were covered in graffiti and the removal of one piece would have required the removal of all pieces and the removal of all pieces would have required the repainting of all walls and the repainting was not in the budget and the budget was the arbiter of aesthetics in a hostel that charged RM35 per night.

The graffiti was a physical artefact -- the tangible counterpart to the digital account. The wall was real. The ink was real. The hand that had held the marker was real, and had belonged to a person who treated the writing not as vandalism but as inscription.

The graffiti was the only physical evidence of @HostelReaper's existence. The graffiti was the place where the digital and the physical met, the point of contact between the Instagram account and the real world, the proof that whatever @HostelReaper was, it was not purely digital, was not purely an online phenomenon, was not a bot or an algorithm or a piece of software but was, at some point, in some form, a physical presence in the physical world, a hand holding a marker, an eye seeing a wall, a mind deciding to write.

The graffiti remained on the wall. Hafizul, the temporary manager, had been told about it by Mei Ling after Tomoko's article was published. Hafizul had considered removing it. Hafizul had decided not to remove it because the removal might destroy evidence and the evidence was potentially relevant to the investigation and the investigation was still active and the decision to preserve or destroy evidence was not Hafizul's decision but Ahmad's decision.

Ahmad had visited the hostel to photograph the graffiti. Ahmad had stood in the bathroom stall with a camera and photographed the words and the figure on the wall, the detective performing the same function as the journalist, the documentation of the documentation, the recording of the recording, the recursive act of a system that documented everything including its own documentation.

The graffiti remained. The mark, the signal, the proof that @HostelReaper had been here. The hostel was the reaper's territory. The guests were the inventory. The checkout was the function. And the function was mandatory.

*Check-out is mandatory.*

The words on the wall. The words on the screen. The words that connected the physical building in Chinatown to the digital account on Instagram to the twelve deaths in eleven countries to the next death, wherever it would be, the death that was designated #BookOfTheNile, the death that was being anticipated or planned or predicted or simply known, known by whatever @HostelReaper was, known in the way that @HostelReaper knew, which was a way that Tomoko had not identified and might never identify and that the not-identifying was the mystery and the mystery was the point and the point was the thing that kept her awake at midnight in Osaka, the thing that kept the investigation alive, the thing that made the story not a story about a death but a story about a system, a pattern, a phenomenon that was larger than any single death and older than any single account and more persistent than any single investigation.

---

Tomoko closed her laptop.

The screen went dark. The room went dark. The darkness was the darkness of a small room in Osaka at midnight, the darkness that was populated by the shapes of familiar furniture and the red standby light of the laptop and the faint glow of the city outside the window, the permanent ambient light of a city that, like all cities, did not fully darken.

She stood. She walked to the window. She opened the curtain. The view was Tennoji -- the rooftops and the neon and the elevated train line and the distant tower of Abeno Harukas, the tallest building in Osaka, lit at night in blue and white. The view was her city, her neighbourhood, her home, the place that was the fixed point from which she travelled and to which she returned, the place that was the opposite of the hostels she documented, the place that was permanent rather than transient, the place where she slept in the same bed every night and woke in the same room every morning and the sameness was the stability that made the instability of her work possible.

She thought about the Lantern Hostel. She thought about the common room -- the vinyl couch, the abandoned novels, the television playing CNN, the ceiling fans turning. She thought about Mei Ling at the reception desk, sharp-eyed, watchful, the woman who had tried to warn Connor and had not been heard. She thought about Mama Siti in the kitchen, ancient, knowing, the woman who cooked as a form of vigil, who counted the living by counting the plates. She thought about Razak in his office, surrounded by his clippings and his pins, the collector who had become a data point in his own collection.

She thought about Connor. She thought about him not as a victim or a case or a photograph in an article but as a person -- the sun-bleached hair, the squint, the board shorts, the compass tattoo, the voice that said *she'll be right* and *relax, it's Asia* and the voice that said *I didn't know, mate, I swear I didn't know*. She thought about the gap between the two voices -- the voice of confidence and the voice of terror, the gap that was Connor's life, the gap that was the distance between the rooftop where he'd been happy and the cell where he'd died.

She thought about Oliver. She did not know Oliver's name -- she did not know that a British backpacker named Oliver Price had checked into Bed 7 six weeks after Connor's death. But she knew Oliver existed. She knew Oliver existed because Oliver was the statistical certainty, the next data point, the next young traveller who would arrive at a hostel and be broke and be lonely and be vulnerable and be approached by a charming stranger with an offer. Oliver was the pattern's next iteration. Oliver was the next one. And the next one after Oliver was the next one after Oliver, and the sequence was infinite, the sequence was the world, the sequence was the condition of a planet that produced eight billion people and a travel industry that moved them and a hospitality industry that housed them and a criminal industry that exploited them and a legal system that punished them and a social media account that documented them.

She thought about @HostelReaper. She thought about the account the way she thought about the hostels themselves -- as a container, a structure, a thing that held other things. The account held death the way the hostels held life. The account was the archive, the record, the memory that the hostels did not have. The hostels forgot their guests. The account remembered them. The hostels erased the traces -- the sheets washed, the beds remade, the names forgotten. The account preserved the traces -- the names posted, the dates recorded, the deaths documented. The account was the hostels' shadow, the dark counterpart to the bright, warm, lantern-lit spaces where young people slept and ate and fell in love and made plans and ignored warnings and carried packages and climbed staircases and heard squeaks and felt ceiling fans and did all the things that living people did in buildings that were designed for living until the buildings became, for a moment, buildings that were designed for dying.

@HostelReaper was here. @HostelReaper was always here. @HostelReaper was the thing that waited in the bathroom stall, in the Instagram feed, in the space between the building and the internet, in the gap between the physical and the digital, in the territory that the modern world had created and that no one had named, the territory where the living and the dead coexisted as data, as profiles, as posts, as the ones who were tagged and the ones who were not.

Tomoko closed the curtain. She lay on her futon. She did not sleep. She did not sleep because the investigation was not finished and the investigation would not be finished because the investigation was not the kind that finished, not the kind that arrived at a conclusion and closed a file and typed THE END. The investigation was ongoing. The investigation was the investigation of a system that was ongoing. The system did not stop. The account did not stop. The deaths did not stop. And Tomoko, lying on her futon in Osaka at midnight, did not stop, the journalist's mind the mind that did not stop, the mind that continued to process and connect and question and doubt, the mind that was the human equivalent of the ceiling fan, turning and turning in the darkness.

---
